(Note: I was given this product for free in exchange for an honest review. This does not affect my review.)This review is more of a comparison with the Bracoo Leg Sleeves. (Note: I was given this product in exchange for an honest/unbiased review. This does not affect my review in any way.)(Another Note: This is a support meant for activities. For those of you looking for more of a more solid support that doesn't allow you to move your ankle, this isn't the one for you.)I'm a very cautious person when it comes to my ankles. Since I play sports all the time I know the pain of many injuries. One of the most painful of them is an ankle injury. I've had injuries from broken wrist, torn muscles, dislocated shoulders, ankle sprains, knee injuries and more. Trust and believe that I know what I'm talking about when I tell you I know what an injury feels like.Comfytopia asked me to review a new product called Bracoo Leg Sleeves. After reviewing them, they gave me the option to review another product of my choosing. I asked if they had any ankle or knee supports. They sent me a knee strap (which you can find the review for it, and the leg sleeves on my profile page) and this ankle support.Immediately after trying this support on you can feel a huge difference. It's very comfortable, and has a strong/firm grip. When I go play basketball I usually wear ankle sleeves, leg sleeves, and knee strap (Like I said before, I'm very cautious.). After twisting my ankle again yesterday while playing basketball, I decided to put on the ankle support on top of the sleeves. The the support isn't too tight that you can't move it, but one thing is for sure. I won't be twisting it anytime soon. I did a little test to try to twist it to see how much it could withstand and it was hard to get very far. Extremely firm yet still lets you run comfortably. I haven't had any problems with long term use.PRO's:+ Firm Grip.+ Breathable material retains heat and prevents skin irritation.+ Comfortable for long term use.+ Adjustable to fit most and both feet.+ Open heel allows you to move easily when playing sports or any other kind of activity.+ Cross straps allow easy adjusting to firmly hold and evenly support weak, sore, or injured ankles.+ Great PriceCON's:- Nothing to say here.Conclusion:This is just the type of support that I need for all the sports that I play. 5 Star rating is firm. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a good ankle support while doing any type of activity. Take it from a person who lives an active lifestyle. I hope you guys enjoy and thanks for reading.

(Note: I was given this book for free in exchange for an honest review. This does not effect my review in any way.)IImmediately after you start to read this book you can tell the book has some surprises just from the way it starts. After about 3 chapters into the book, the main character Dana started to seem like a very familiar character. As of I had met her before. As I kept reading I started to realize that she had somewhat of a close resemblance to another character I know from a show. The fact that she resembled this character made me want to keep reading this book. The more I read, the more interesting the book became.This book has a few crazy twists that really just make you want to keep reading it to see what's going to happen. Now I'm not much of a reader (Per Say). For some reason I just couldn't help but to keep reading. The plot of this book is surprisingly detailed for such a short book. I'm a big fan of a good twist. Something that makes you think one thing and then takes a completely different turn. This one wasn't as big as you would expect or maybe it was just because I saw it coming. But none the less a good one. If you just visualize it all in your head this book will blow your mind.Meet The Main Characters:+ Dana = The Main Character+ Zoe = Dana's Sister+ Tyler = Dana's boyfriend+ The rest are mostly support characters.As the book goes on you start to asking yourself a few questions.- Is Tyler real?...- Is Dana going insane?...- Did she make all of this up?...- What is really going on here?...The twists that happen here are some that I know you will enjoy. If I wouldn't have received this book for free to review it. I would've most definitely bought it for sure. No doubt in my mind if you enjoy a good thriller, you will enjoy this one. I would recommend this book to anyone that love a good short read, wants to pass the time, or just wants a few exciting twists.(Finally Note: Writing a review about a book without giving away any spoilers can be pretty hard. Especially from a good book like this one.)

(Note: I was giving this product for free in exchange for an honest review. This does not effect my review in any way.)I play sports all the time and as of lately have been more on the recovery side. It can be adjusted to fit most.PRO's:+ Tubular insert with focused pressure to help guide the patella.+ Fully adjustable strap.+ Comfortable for all day use.+ Protects & prevents knee injuries while any type of activity.+ One size fits most.+ Prevents an already injured knee from getting worse.CON's:- Doesn't take all the pain away from a already injured knee away.Conclusion:This is something that I use everyday since I got it and I really don't leave the house without it on. (Note: I recieved this portable speaker for free in exchange for an honest review.This does not effect my review in any way.)When I first saw the speaker, I would've never believed anyone who told me how loud it really is. She's went out and bought quite a few portable mini speakers for around the same price and I can honestly say they're no match for this one.Tech Specs:Dimentions: (L)115MM x(W)62MM x(H)56.2MMWeight: 8oz (Half a pound)Speaker: (2) 40MMImput: L/R 400MVPower Output: 4W* 2AMP Freq Range: 200Hz-16KHzBattery: 800mAhCharging time: 2HrsPlaying Time: 3-4Hrs (4Hrs from my personal use)Bluetooth: 4.0Bluetooth Distance: 30ftWhat's Included:+ BSPR300 Speaker+ USB Charging Cable+ User Manuel+ 3.5MM to 3.5MM cable+ Travel PouchPRO's:+ Compact Size+ Incredibe Bass+ Huge Sound+ Great Price+ Light Weight+ Easy To Use (Note: When you turn it on, it's already on pairing mode every time)+ Touch Controls+ Charges Fast+ Decent Battery Life+ Easily Portable+ Bluetooth 4.0+ Built-in Mic for Phone Calls+ 1 Year WarrantyCON's: (Hard to find some, but here they are)- Bass can sometime take over a song completely to the point that you can barely hear the words.- At it's highest volumes if the music you have isn't the best quality, it will show.- Sound quality for phone calls weren't the best. (You can't expect much consdering most speakers at this price don't even bring a Built-in Mic.)Conclusion:At this price, it definately competes well. I had Aspahlt 7: Heat since it was released, and let me just say "amazing". Asphalt 8: Airborne is over the top. With much improved graphics over the 7th one. This game is by far the best car racing game on the market to date.+ Graphics: (5/5) = The graphics from this game are amazing. Starting to get up to par with consoles.+ Gameplay: (5/5) = The controls and gameplay are easy to get used to. Easy to handle and very smooth.+ Performance: (3/5) = The game runs extreemly smooth for a while. If you play it for more then an hour the performance starts to lag. It got to the point where it froze my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 and I had to completely restart it.+ Sound Effects: (5/5) = The games sound effects are on point.PRO's:+ Gameplay is great.+ Graphics are phenomenal.+ Sound effects are good.+ Multiplayer is nice.+ Includes Amazon GameCircle.+ Lots of cars to choose from.+ Good selection of maps.CON's:- Performance has some lag issues.Conclusion:The game is only $0.99 and is well worth that price. If you want the best car racer on the market, then stop looking. You found it. This is the best there is. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because of that performance bug. Other then that the game is perfect. I'm sure that will be fixed in a future update really soon, but until then 4 stars is what it gets. Hope you guy/girls enjoy ths game and thanks for reading.

Note: This review is for those using the Kindle Fire HD 8.9. I don't yet know how it works with the other versions of the Kindle.Just when I was about to buy the first one. The second one wasn't available for for Kindle Fire HD yet, they add it to the Amazon Appstore. How lucky am I? Getting it on the first day, and being the first to review it. So far the game is almost perfect. A few minor issues here and there, but nothing major. Right of the bat the game force closed (FC) on me when I opened it. I thought it wouldn't work. I gave it another shot and would you look at that, it worked. (The FC must have been something unrelated to the game.) The game has a very short, but informative tutorial right when you start. I have yet to get far in the game so I will update this review if needed. Here are some PRO's & CON's.PRO's:+ 3D Graphics are great.+ Tutorial is Short, Sweet, and To the point.+ Gameplay is smooth as silk.+ Has a nice Multiplayer.+ Uses Amazon GameCircle. (More games should use this.)+ Good variety of customization.CON's:- Unresponsive on occasions (If you touch the screen while it's on a loading screen).Conclusion:The game is nearly perfect. It's well worth the $2.99 price tag. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because the game became unresponsive when I accidentally touched the screen while it was loading more then once (won't force close but it comes up with a message saying that it is not responding and asks if you want to wait or force close it). If you just click wait it will continue without any problems. That's just a minor bug that I'm sure will be fixed in a future update. The game is pretty new so you can expect a glitch/bug here and there. If you guys are looking to buy it, my suggestion is go for it. Thumbs up on the buy. You won't be disappointed. Hope this helps and thanks for reading.

I originally bought this app for my mom, not for myself. I saw this app about a week ago and I know that my mom loves Zumba workouts. Ironically enough I bought this app/game for her on my birthday (That's a turn around) two days ago. When I asked her to give it a shot she told me to try it out first. I didn't really want to. Although I do dance, Zumba dances aren't really my style. As you can expect I failed miserably for the first half of the dance. It took my about half way though the song to be able to pick some of the dance moves. It was actually really fun after I tried it the first time. It felt like playing Just Dance 4 on PS3 or Xbox 360. Lets jump into some PRO's and CON's.Pro's:+ Camera detects movements really well.+ Highly addictive.+ Has a learn the moves section.+ 6 different songs. (Up to 43 Add-on songs)+ Great workout.+ Measures calories burned (based on movement).+ Keeps track of your workout (Daily, Weekly, & Monthly).Con's:- You have to buy the rest of the songs serparately. (4 different add-on packs)* 3 packs - $9.99 each or* Full Package - $24.99 (Brings all 43 add-ons)Conclusion:The big question here is simple. Is this worth $4.99 price tag with only 6 song? The answer is "Yes". Even without the other songs this app is well worth the price. You're getting a good workout along with a ton of fun. You can have up to 6 profile for different members of the family and even have a friendly competition to see who can get the best high score. This app will amaze you even more if you can connect your phone/tablet to your flat screen TV. I did this with my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 and had so much fun competing against my mom. If you really look at it, even buying the full package at $24.99 is better then buying the DVD set. The set will rack up to $120 sometimes more sometimes less. In reality this is much more portable. Why would you take a set of DVD's with you, when you could just take your phone/tablet and have it there with you at all times. I hope you guys enjoy and thanks for reading.

The objective of this app is to complete a puzzle like Sudoku using numbers as hints to fill in the tiles. Once you fill them correctly you reveal a picture behind it and you win. This app is surprisingly more challenging then you thing from first glance. I love a challenging game and this game is nothing short of challenging. I thought I was going to end up getting gold on all the puzzles and I ended up with silver on quite a few the first time around. Although the game is fun and challenging, I could only rate it 3 stars. Check out some PRO's & CON's.PRO's:+ Slide to complete controls.+ Double tap to fill in the squares (allows for fewer mistakes).+ Simple UI.+ Surprisingly challenging.+ Stupidly addicting (at least for me it was hard to stop for a second to write a review).Con's:- Pressing back (on Kindle Fire) after a win resets your game.- Although screen real estate might be good on a phone they didn't take full advantage of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9's large screen.Conclusion:I got this game as the FAOTD, but I would have surely paid for it if I wouldn't have. It's worth the price so if you don't manage to get it while it's free it's still worth the buy for those who love Sudoku, or even just a good challenging every once in awhile when you're bored. Hope this helps and thanks for reading.

The BestFire essential oil diffuser is probably one of the best diffusers I have owned yet. I have a huge collection of essential oils that I am obsessed with. I have quite a few portable bank chargers and charging cables, but sometimes I forget my charging cables to connect my phone to my power bank to charge. My husband and I are huge beer drinkers. Now we don't drink often, but we occasionally like a beer after a long day, a meal or while hanging out with family and/or friends. My husband had been talking about making his own at home beer for while now, so I thought this DIY beer brewing book would be a great read for him. When it came in he was pretty excited about it.Now this isn't your typical cookbook and doesn't just give you a recipe. This book actually gives you 101 in making your own beer. Like the book says, "You don't have to have a degree in brewing science to make good beer"(9). This DIY gives you ten basic and easy steps to brewing beer. There is also a 23 step by step illustration process for first-time homebrewers for people like my husband. He actually needs some kind of illustration instructions to go by because he likes to be sure that he is doing it right. What my husband loved about this book is that there is history and lists the different styles of beer. Who would have known there was so many categories of Lager and Ale beers. This book gives you the list of equipment you need to start home brewing your own beer and the different types of ingredients that you need to make each beer recipe taste great.My only complaint would be that we would have liked to see pictures of finished beers just to get an idea of how dark or light the beers should be. Illustration helps to give the reader an idea of what a food or drink is suppose to look like once the recipe is completed. Overall, my husband really enjoyed reading this book and already bookmarked a few beer recipes that he plans on making. I personally think this would be a great book for anyone who is contemplating taking up beer brewing as a hobby and would recommend they check this book out. I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I love cooking and always willing to try something new. I am a huge Korean food lover and was excited to try some of the yummy recipes from this Seoul Food Korean cookbook. There is 135 different recipes to try. What I love about this cookbook is that whether you're a huge meat, drink, desert, veggie or noodle lover, there is a little something for everyone.The first chapter gives a little background on Korean food as well as some table manners which I loved reading about, because I am always interested in other cultures. Chapter two is broken into two parts. It just give you the essential cookware, tableware, spices and ingredients that are commonly used when it comes to Korean cuisine. I am a huge rice lover so I was super excited when I saw the tips and tricks to making the perfect rice. Let me tell you, when I did exactly as the recipe recommended my rice came out perfect. Each recipe has a little introduction about the meal, also has the list of ingredients, step by step instructions, prep time, cook time and also a level of pepper on the side which I am assuming is to let you know how much heat is in the actual dish. Of course, you can always adjust the recipes to the level of heat you like in your food. Some of the recipes also have a variation tip at the bottom which is great to see other ways that the meal can be eaten or served. Now that we are in the fall season I was very excited to see the recipe for pumpkin porridge because my husband and I love pumpkin anything.Now, If I had to complain about anything it would be that there is a lack of photos. There is a photo at the beginning of every chapter, but I would have loved to seen a photo of the actual finished recipe. This as a reader helps to see what the recipe is suppose to look like when it is done. I always like to compare my food with the finished food to a recipe I am following. This helps me to get an idea of what I am missing. Overall, I am very pleased with my new cookbook and very happy to add it to my collection of cookbooks. I would definitely recommend this cookbook to anyone who loves to cook a variety of foods. I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

As someone who suffers from plantar fasciitis, I was really excited when I was offered these therapy wraps in exchange for my honest opinion.  That is, until I received them and they didn't actually reach my arches, in fact, they hardly cover my heels and it isn't like I have giant ogre feet or something, I have fairly standard size 8.5 women's feet and I'm not getting arch support if it barely covers my heel.  Now, I'm giving this two stars because it did provide nice heel and ankle compression which was comforting and if I had those problems would be helpful.  But for arch support/plantar fasciitis, I did not find these useful at all in that realm and am pretty bummed.

My girls have always been interested in coloring (me too, for what it is worth!), but once they hit the 5-6 year old range, they wanted something more from their coloring books including a purpose behind the "why" of coloring  - so a love of storybook coloring books was born. It is fun products like these that make me wish I were more petite. As a somewhat anxious personality, I tend to compensate for that with snacks  so I get into a terrible catch-22 situation where I am anxious and eating and gaining weight all the time.  With a lot of changes and some losses in our family over the last few months, my anxiety has been at an all-time high and, as you can imagine, so has my weight.  I started a new workout program, but honestly, you can workout all day, everyday and without the support in the food area, that is never going to change.  So I wanted to make a change in a natural way without taking anti-anxiety medications that my doctor offered me.  I received a bottle of Chronos Pharma Super Premium Mood and Weight Support in exchange for my honest opinion.I followed the instructions to take one to two pills each night with water (I recommend this, once I missed, took it in the AM and had an upset stomach for the duration of the day).  It took about two weeks of daily use for me to really notice a difference, as though it were building in my system, though hubby says he noticed I was less worry wartish a few days before I noticed.  I have now been taking it for about a month and can say that my everyday anxiety level is significantly lower and my desire to comfort eat is close to gone. During the time of taking this, my mother-in-law had a heart attack and it was very stressful on my family, especially my husband  usually this would send me into a tizzy of anxiety, no sleep and countless bags of chips and treats.  I was able to emerge from that experience as a strong support for my husband and without needing or even craving the sweet or salty snacks to soothe anything.  It was amazing!I really like this mood and weight support dietary supplement.  For me, with a usual low level of anxiety, it worked to calm things down and allow me to control my appetite for snacks and treats.  I feel better and am even sleeping through the night (previously I would wake up one to two times just to think).  You can see the full list of ingredients on Amazon and if you think it may work for you, share the list with your doctor and see what s/he thinks  it may just help you, too*.*Please check with your medical provider before starting any supplements or stopping any current treatment prescribed to you.

Being of the "top heavy" persuasion, I end up spending a tidy sum on my bras so that I can have both support and style, but then I wash them and my washer and/or dryer promptly try to destroy them - either by eating them entirely (where DO those things go?!?!) or by stretching out the straps, bending wires, etc.  I received this pack of laundry bags from Miss & Co in exchange for my honest opinion.You get five bags in varying sizes for all your laundry needs, including two bra bags, which honestly, were the most important to me!  I threw a bra into each and was in love after the first cycle that my bras came out clean, fresh and intact!  No more stretching or ruining for me!  The large bag is great for gathering all the socks from a load of laundry to ensure that your washer will not have a hearty sock snack during the cycle.  We are losing less underclothes than ever and I can contribute that to using these bags.  The bags are well-made, sturdy and the zipper is great too.  Since the zippers are plastic, there is no rust to worry about down the road and no snagging of your clothing that you put in.  I like the beautiful style of these bags too, even if no one else will ever see that unless a neighbor has the sudden urge to change my laundry out for me!

I travel a fair amount for work so I need to be able to take more than just my basic toiletries with me when I am on the road. As an avid bike commuter, hubby puts about 20-25 miles per day on his bike and he does this year-round, even in the cold/snow of Wisconsin.  He has an "old beater bike" as he calls it for the winter to minimize wear and tear on his more expensive bike, but often complains about the seat on it.  I received this replacement bike saddle in exchange for my honest opinion.  I should say, this is a road bike style seat - so if you are a casual biker or a first time "trying to get into shape" rider - this is not going to feel comfortable or natural to you.  Hence why I had hubby test this out - my bike has a big, squishy seat that is for comfort, not speed.  This bike saddle is meant for those doing the road bike/commuter thing and are going for speed/agility.  For those purposes, it's quite decent.  Hubby took it on several long rides and said it was significantly better than the standard saddle that came with his cheap bike, but obviously, not as nice as his English leather one that we invested a pretty penny.  That being said, at this price point and the ease at which this installed, it is a good seat and will be perfect for the winter months for him.  It seems well-made and quite sturdy.

With the recent US attempt at normalizing relations with Cuba, I really wanted to brush up on my history of Cuba and get into a better understanding.  Honestly, I hadn't put much thought into it since my freshman college Political Science class and that was the end of it.  I received this book in exchange for my honest opinion.Let me just say that I'm not sure this book was intended to sit down and read in large, long chunks - at least, that isn't the feeling I get based on the Q&A style that it is written in.  I really like it actually - I can scan through the contents to find a question that stands out most to me and then flip specifically to that section to read and learn exactly what I wanted to know.  The books itself is quite verbose and in some sections the author gets a bit heavy handed in her academia meets opinion, but overall I found her style to be enjoyable and informative.  I feel like I have picked up new facts and have an overall better understanding of Cuba, as well as US/Cuba relations and interactions.  I would recommend this book to anyone looking just to learn more about another area of the world, or to better understand the importance of normalizing the relations.

My brother travels regularly to Cuba as part of his job and has gotten to know the island fairly well.  I gave him this book after I received it in exchange for my honest opinion to get his thoughts.  I read through it and as someone who hopes to visit Cuba in the near future when my brother is there found it to be helpful in giving me ideas about things - for example, I really like the tips on when to travel to certain areas and the "why" behind those recommendations.  But when my brother looked it over, he noted that some things were already out of date and a bit of misinformation here or there with the "places to go".  He felt that most of the restaurant reviews were a bit overstated and enthusiastic, but perhaps that is because he really has gotten to know many of the locals and mostly avoids the touristy areas now.  I can appreciate that it is hard to keep a printed copy of something current particularly in a country where things change (isn't that every country?!?!) - but I will take this with me for a general guideline in January to see how it pans out.

Not as often as I would like, but occasionally, hubby and I get to go on mini-getaways just the two of us. If you've ever needed to decorate for a party of any sort, you know how quickly that cost can get out of hand and usually you end up with the same old stuff since options are limited.  My favorite way to decorate for parties now is using chalkboard markers to create custom and reusable items for each event!  I have invested in chalkboard paint, chalkboard signs and stickers to make different "props" and combine them with lovely chalkboard markers to create whimsical signs and decor that my guests will remember!I received this set of chalkboard markers from US Art Supply in exchange for my honest opinion.  This set is a great starter for all your decorating needs - it includes 10 colors (all of the rainbow plus brown,white and black).  Why black you ask?  Since most chalkboards are black?  Well, turns out chalkboard markers and windows are wonderful friends and these markers are a bit bigger so they are perfect for just such an occasion.  They are also waterbased so it will wipe off without issue (bonus!).  I plan on using them to draw a Thanksgiving feast on the window in my dining room for the fall as a fun and different type of decoration in that room.  I could also see using these to write on the windows in the car as something for the kids to do on long trips and let them write and wipe off to their heart's content.These are vibrant chalkboard markers that look great, have very little dripping and once you get the flow going, they work great.  They also come with a spare set of tips to let you write in wider or more narrow "font" - I haven't needed to change mine yet, but it is a nice option to have.

As a kid, I would sit and color for HOURS - I found it soothing, but then over time, much like many things of childhood, it sort of faded out of my realm and was replaced with other things. It's funny, we spend tons of time coloring as kids, and then BAM! I was not blessed with long, lush, dark lashes like some others in my family.  In fact, mine have some length, but they are so light you can't see them and if I happen to forget to put on mascara or eyeliner, I have to endure people asking me all day about my health and if I am ill or not.  So I definitely love having quality mascaras and have tried a few of the 3D lash ones, but find many can get crazy in pricing.  I received this natural 3D lash mascara in exchange for my honest opinion.This 3D lash mascara comes with the two products that you need to have fuller, longer looking lashes in just minutes (with some practice!).  One is the liquid mascara (and also plays the part of sealant) and the other is the 3d lash fibers that give you that faux fabulous lash look.  What I like most about this brand of 3D lash mascara is that the product is made without parabens or SLS - which I appreciate knowing I'm not coating the delicate area around my eyes with things like that.  I found that these applied very easily and I like the wand for applying the fibers.  I was excited that even with the first application I didn't have any flaking and my lashes appeared longer, fuller and overall very nice.  Great 3D lash mascara - I would definitely buy again.

We have a black lab/beagle mix and he LOVES to chew on ropes but can get them undone very quickly.  I received this set of dog rope toys in exchange for my honest opinion.  As someone who loves jungle animal everything, I found these to be super cute and different than most of the rope toys out there - it also gave us a chance to "name" the toys so he would know which one to get "Go get your giraffey" etc.These rope toys are a mixed review for me - they are cute and the stretch in them makes them extra great for tug-of-war and pulling, but there are also small pieces that can become a problem if your dog is a quick chewer, like ours is.  He had the legs, tail and ears off of both rope toy animals within an hour and I was worried he would choke on these small pieces.  Once we got those away from him and he was left with quadruple amputee animals, he has been very happy and I am impressed with the durability and design of the bodies of these toys.  So we like these toys, of course, ropes are great for dogs' teeth and he finds them to be fun - but if I buy them again in the future, I'd have to remember to watch for those small nubbies that are somewhat troublesome.

I have recently begun participating in core classes through my local rec department and that involves a lot of "floor work" - the first class I attended, I took a regular thin yoga mat that we had around the house and my back was in pain for days afterward, so I needed a better option since my core definitely needs these classes! We are big fans of the wireless dog fence and this additional 500 ft of cord allowed us to create an essential "force field" around our entire house, as well as cordoning off our gardens from our precocious pooch who likes to wander and visit people. I have a very excitable and friendly dog who wants to greet everyone he meets, especially delivery people that come to our door. This is such a cute and fun summer dress!  I received this dress in exchange for my honest, unbiased opinion. It's funny how trends come and go and then come and go again - like stroller size. We recently remodeled our bathroom and I headed to the store to pick up a new fabric outer shower curtain - I was SHOCKED to find many are well over $50 - I mean, seriously? Over the last year, I have really gotten into focusing on getting my workouts in.  One simple and inexpensive workout that was recommended to me was jump rope - so I was immediately taken back to my days of school and sing-song versions of Miss Mary Mack while jumping, as it turns out, jump rope is harder now that I am in my 30s and have birthed a couple of kiddos.  I also tend to give myself more credit for the jumps that I am doing (oh yeah, I totally jumped 100 times) - but now that I received this jump rope in exchange for my honest opinion, it turns out I did not jump that many times, more like 30 - WOW, that is hard!  I like this particular jump rope because it keeps track of your jumps, but it is adjustable for many heights - from someone around 6 feet tall all the way down to being sized for my kiddos (who enjoy taking this to a competitive extreme!).  We did find that at the longer lengths for taller people, it tangled more easily and you couldn't jump as quickly due to that, but at the shorter, more child-size settings, you got longer jump times in.

We are huge fans of using Baltic Amber jewelry for our children from infancy on up to help with pain and reduce anxiety.  I received this Baltic Amber teething bracelet in exchange for my honest opinion.  I had planned on sharing this bracelet with my sister-in-law for my nephew, however it was a bit big on his tiny wrists and even his ankles, so we decided to wait on that for him and I gave it to my 6-year-old daughter instead.  My daughter has been wearing Baltic Amber since she was a new born and it has helped tremendously with pain for her from teething to general growing pains.  She likes to wear it now because it is pretty to wear, but it also helps her feel calmer in new situations (i.e. first day of school, new soccer team, etc).  She really likes this bracelet because she can see it and she rubs the stones "for good luck" - while I've never heard of luck properties of Baltic Amber, I can say that is helps sooth her and that is all this mama needs!

The Full Circle Grunge Buster Grout and Tile Brush is a unique scrub brush that is optimally designed for one job, and one job only.The Grunge Buster Brush has a long, slender row of white bristles connected to a purple plastic base that loops around to a wooden handle on the other end.  That evenly looped-back form also serves a nifty purpose--the brush can stably stand up on it's bottom edge and allow the bristles to dry without any mildewy build-up.  I really liked this simple, yet impressive feature.  There is an additional row beige bristles that flank the each side of the white ones nearly halfway through the base to increase the scrubbing area.  I was amazed by how well I could work the slender white bristle row into the grout spaces of tile or into crevasses of my other single-panel shower. The pinpoint accuracy and effectiveness for hitting those tiny spots was great with this brush.  However, I have to recommend against using this as an all-purpose bathroom brush for all surfaces.  It just doesn't have a wide enough bristle base to clean large, non-tiled areas. Having a full-sized brush alternative is so much more efficient to clean a large, flat surface.  Given that this brush is being marketed as a cleaning supply that can take care of the grout between tiled surfaces, I can't knock it a star there.  Still, I had to drop the brush from 5-stars down to 4 because of the wooden handle.  Blasting away the gunk that builds up in grout takes some effort, and the wooden handle isn't all the comfortable while applying a lot of pressure.  After some hard scrubbing I was wishing for a softer, plasticky type handle.  I can appreciate the visual touch the wood provides, but c'mon, it's brush, and we should all primarily care about function over aesthetics.  Additionally, I found that while wet, my hand would slide around on the wooden handle more than a comparable plastic-handled brush.  Maintaining a perfect grip wasn't easy.Overall, the Full Circle Grunge Buster is an effective brush to clean away tile grout.  I loved the accuracy of the bristles and the edge-standing capabilities.  I just think I'd also probably keep a larger scrub brush in your cleaning supply bin to complement this one.

The Arm Tunnel Micro Cloud Pillow probably looked good on paper in the design shop, but somehow isn't as fantastic as I hoped.  In theory, the idea of a pillow that has a built-in space for your arm is a great concept (primarily for stomach or side sleepers).  However, the pillow is questionably constructed, marginally comfortable, and oddly noisy as you change positions.  It's not bad for lounging on the couch, but it's not great for an 8 hour sleep session.Pros:*  Somewhat comfortable*  Shapes to head and neck*  Arm space is helpful, if you don't move around a lot when sleeping.  I started sleeping on my stomach, with my arm neatly placed in the arm space for this pillow. However, once I started moving around and changing positions, I ended up bunching up the pillow in the same way I would bunch up a regular pillow.  Maybe that's more my fault, which is why I still considered this a Pro and not a true Con.Cons:*  Wished it was more comfortable and the beads didn't bunch up on one side a lot*  Not a lot of consistent support compared to other pillows*  Noisy - the little beads in the pillow shift around a lot when sleeping and are surprisingly noisy*  Although the stitching is okay and the seams are fine, the cover material feels overly smooth and cheesyOverall, I give this pillow a 3 out of 5.  It's not the worst pillow I've slept on by any means, but it's not as great as I was hoping for.  As the title shows, there was less sleeping soundly and more random sounds during sleeping.

The Amazon Kindle Paperwhite is a great product, however, as it only costs a little over $119, you shouldn't have to buy a $35 case to protect it.  That's where this cost effective neoprene sleeve from Gizmo Dorks comes in.  It fits the Paperwhite with only a little bit of give--so it's easy to slide in and out, but it offers solid protection because the Kindle won't be sliding around all over the place inside the sleeve.  The extra zipper pouch up front can easily hold a USB cord for charging.  You can cram an AC wall plug adapter in there too, but that becomes a really tight fit and I worry about it damaging the Paperwhite.I primarily use the sleek, black and red-highlighted sleeve to keep my Kindle from getting dusty when it sits on my desk for a week or more when not in use.  I also will put my Paperwhite in the sleeve and then toss it into my laptop bag for travel.  The neoprene sleeve sitting in my bag has so far successfully protected my Paperwhite over the span of 5 months during 8 flights and countless driving and train trips.  If you're careful with your electronic devices, you probably don't need a fancy $35 cover for the Paperwhite and can use this sleeve to put your Kindle into your main bag without worrying about scratches and small dings.  Additionally, the zippers seem highly durable and should last a long time with normal wear and tear.Overall, I feel like you can't go wrong when buying something this affordable for your Paperwhite.  It's a cheap investment to protect your Kindle at a price that makes sense.  One final note...they throw in a free carabiner with purchase, but it's nearly worthless and shouldn't be considered when making the decision to buy this neoprene sleeve.

The Logitech Wireless MK270 is a simplistic wireless keyboard and mouse combo that offers no-frills productivity at an extremely affordable price point.To orientate everyone looking at this review, this is by no means Logitech's best keyboard+mouse package (I use the Logitech Wireless Wave Combo Mk550 With Keyboard and Laser Mouse (920-002555) for my 8-hour/day office duty).  However, if you're looking for a wireless keyboard+mouse solution that gets the job done, the MK270 absolutely works.  The small nano-receiver fits into any USB port and doesn't take up any space, so you can still plug in bulky flash drives into the USB slots next to it.  The keyboard and mouse both have easy access power buttons that allow you to shut them down at the end of the day to save battery juice.  The keyboard keys travel a satisfying distance with each stroke for good accuracy, and they produce a comforting amount of clicky noise.  There are a couple dedicated buttons at the top of the keyboard to control media functions and launch email, but there's not a lot extra happening with this keyboard.The minimalistic mouse is cut from the same cloth as the keyboard.  It simply gets the job done.  The accuracy on the mouse is sufficient for web browsing and typical Office work, however, it is not a laser mouse.  So if you want pixel perfect movements for video games or Photoshop, you'll want something with a little better tracking.The MK270 also lacks the built-in ergonomic wrist rest of the MK550, so you might want to consider buying a wrist rest pad to complement the MK270 if you're using it for extended time periods.  But if you have a computer hooked up to your TV and need a cheap keyboard to use on the couch, this works like a champ.  One final thing to note, if you're buying this for light usage (which should be the targeted use), I recommend simply plugging in the receiver and typing away.  For anything more than light usage, I recommend going to the Logitech website and downloading the SetPoint software to gain some functionality and customization options for the combo unit.  It takes up a little extra RAM as the trade-off, but it's worth it for medium-to-heavy users.In summary, the MK270 is a perfect, low-cost combo solution for people that need a wireless keyboard and mouse for less than 1-3 consecutive hours of daily light usage. Hence my five star rating above. If you're planning on using this combo unit for a daily, full work day, then you should think of it as a 3-star product.

The OXO Good Grips Double Flip in Hamper is a high quality product, but it has a price tag to match.Like many OXO products, this hamper is built to do it's single purpose very well.  The entire unit is cloth covered cardboard and is durable and sturdy.  Simply open up the hamper, fold down the two flaps that offer bottom support and then put the lid INSIDE the hamper.  If you put the lid on the outside of the hamper it only loosely hold it's shape.  Once assembled, it's as sold as any plastic hamper, really.  There are two handle on the outside which makes it easy to carry from your bedroom closet to your laundry room and the lid pops on and off for easy access.  While not a negative, the only caveat is that you can't throw your dirty clothes in the hamper.  The flip-down lid requires you to gently push your dirty clothes down into the black or light gray dividers.  Again, it's not horrible, but something to be aware of if you prefer to toss your clothes in from a distance.In summary, the OXO Good Grips Hamper is undoubtedly the best hamper I've ever used and I'm guessing you'll feel the same way if you decide to purchase one. It's simply a personal question if a fantastic hamper is worth this much to you.

The LG GA7900 is a great looking panel loaded with a GoogleTV operating system that isn't quite fully baked.  LG also makes the LG Electronics 42GA6400 42-Inch Cinema 3D 1080p 120Hz LED-LCD HDTV with Google TV and Four Pairs of 3D Glasses (GA6400) series of televisions, which I recently reviewed on Amazon.  Some of the features are identical between those two GoogleTV series, so parts of my review will be recycled, but I will point out the differences in the GA7900 below so you can compare and contrast the two units while you're shopping.HARDWAREI'll start with the physical specifications of the television first.  Assembly of the stand is pretty typical for LCD sets, and I had no problem attaching the 8 screws required to get the TV in an upright position by myself.  I would have preferred a base with a standard X pattern, but the two "arms coming out to hug you" stand is stable enough and doesn't take up a huge footprint.  It's somewhat of a bummer, but the stand lacks a tilt/rotation capability.  There are 4 HDMI inputs on the side of the TV, a headphone output, an optical out, 3 USB inputs, and some 1/8" jacks that allow you to plug in composite and component in cables via the supplied adapters.  There is an additional 1/8" jack for the IR blaster adapter (also supplied--it's a Y-adapter with two IR blasters connected to the same jack).  There is also an ethernet jack and a coax cable input for direct standard cable signal or an over-the-air antenna.  All of these inputs are on the left side of the TV (oriented while you're facing the LCD screen). The 3-prong, grounded power cord is attached to the opposite side of the TV from the inputs.  Unfortunately, I feel like the power cord could be a little longer.  The frame is slightly slimmer and has an angular, and more aggressively styled bezel on the GA7900 compared to the very squared-off shape of the GA6400, but it looks cool.  The sound on the GA7900 has a little more bass and "oomph" than the GA6400, but they're still stock TV speakers and nothing to get excited about.PICTUREI received the 47 inch version of the GA7900 for review.  It's a full 1080p, LED edgelit screen.  While I can't find specifics on the technology used, the GA7900 boasts some degree of local microdimming.  The result is a dramatic difference between the GA7900 and GA6400 in terms of black levels and contrast.  The GA7900 does an excellent job of producing something close to a "true" black on an LCD with a substantial contrast range.  Basically, most of the cost and performance difference between the GA7900 and GA6400 is located here, as the picture is significantly improved in the 7900.  I was also impressed with the clean black around the edges of the panel.  I didn't detect any noticeable light bleeding out near the bezel.  You'll have to move up to the very high-end (and more expensive) microdimming Samsung F8000s, Sony XBRs and Sharp ELITEs to reach better black levels on an LCD.  And of course, good plasma TV tech still produces the best blacks. Color reproduction on the GA7900 is very good compared to similarly priced sets.  Reds and greens have an appropriate amount of saturation and color accuracy.  I didn't find anything looking too warm or too cool.  The 240Hz refresh rate holds up well versus similarly priced sets and does a commendable job handling live sporting events.  I only noticed minimal digital motion blur during very fast NHL hockey action.  Overall, the GA7900's panel pretty much performs as well as anything in its price range.3DThis LG comes with 4 pairs of passive 3D glasses (similar to the glasses you get in a movie theatre).  Since my 3D options are somewhat limited, I ordered a free OnDemand viewing of Ice Age 4 in 3D.  I enjoyed the 3D effect and I never experienced any cross-signal.  The 3D viewing angle isn't that wide, but you can maintain a quality depth effect if you're sitting  within 45 degrees away from straight-on.  I was surprised that I wound up preferring this passive 3D effect over my active-shutter 3D glasses I use with my Samsung ES7500.  It's also nice that you don't have to worry about putting batteries in the glasses.  The 3D here works more or less as well as the GA6400.REMOTEIf you're reading this review the reason you're considering this TV is because it's a Google TV.  Well, really, the GoogleTV software goes hand-in-hand with this iteration of the LG magic remote (the remote is the same for the GA6400and GA7900).  LG made an incredible remote for this TV, however, they also annoyed me to no end by not going the extra mile and including a couple simple, intuitive features.  First, the good...the keyboard works great and is so much better than trying to type out search phrases in a SmartTV with a D-pad.  The pointer works very well.  It's basically a poor-man's version of a Wiimote.  Some of the features, like holding down the gesture button and air-drawing semi-circles to zoom in can be next to useless, but for the majority of the GoogleTV interface this remote is a wonderful match.  Unfortunately, the remote has problems whenever I try to use my Comcast DVR.  There are times when I want to use my DVR's channel guide (see below) and unfortunately, this remote does NOT have page up and page down buttons.  This problem could be alleviated if LG can fix the firmware and allow a single click of the scroll wheel down to send a "page down" signal to the DVR through the IR blaster.  The other main issue is that, amazingly, there is no STOP button.  There is a separate play and a separate pause button, but no stop.  Why not make one button PLAY/PAUSE and the other button STOP?  When I'm watching DVR video I need the stop button to get me out of the program I'm watching and give me the option to delete it.  Instead, all I can do is pause, and then hit BACK, which takes me all the way out of the DVR menu structure.  It's annoying.  Buried within the menus is the ability to assign functions to the red, yellow, green, and blue buttons, but I tried to assign the page up and down functions and it didn't work.  There is a lot of empty space on the front of the remote.  Why didn't LG add a couple more buttons for page up/down and stop...and even 0-9 while they're at it?  The other minor things I miss are having a backlit display and a "flashback" button to flick back and forth between two channels.  Finally, some keys have secondary functions, but they are written in a tiny red font that is nearly impossible for me to see and probably invisible to people with red-green color blindness.GOOGLE TVObviously, this is the differentiator for LG's GA series of televisions.  If you ask me is it worth paying a little extra cash for a GA model over a competitive panel with the same picture quality to have GoogleTV built-in, my answer as of June 2013 would be---not yet.  Hopefully some software and firmware updates will soon change that answer to a definitive YES.  GoogleTV essentially tries to overlay its interface on top of your DVR's interface and cable (or satellite) signal.  When you start up your GoogleTV, you are required to log in with a Google account.  Not a fan of Google's privacy policies?  Too bad, you'll have to deal with it.  The main purpose of your account is to provide access to the Google store for app downloads to your TV.  Once you're logged in, you calibrate the unit to the type of TV signal you receive, what area you're in, and whether or not your receive premium channels.  From there it takes a few minutes to load, but GoogleTV takes over and provides you with its channel guide.  The GoogleTV channel guide is similar to Apple's cover flow for music.  Instead of seeing a common spreadsheet grid from your DVR, you instead thumb through mini-images of movie and TV show posters.  At first glance, it seems like a much more intuitive way to find content.  However, it only works well for live TV and shows that are going to start within 5 minutes.  You won't see shows that are going to begin in an hour.  On a normal DVR channel grid, I can flick around and randomly notice a program that will come on in one hour.  At that point in time, I can either choose to record it or plan to watch it.  With GoogleTV, you are instead supposed to know what you want to watch and use the keyboard or voice search to find it.  The search will find it on upcoming TV listings, Netflix, Amazon Video, YouTube, etc (there is no Hulu Plus on this set as of June 2013).  The difference is that you have to know what you are looking for ahead of time.  While using GoogleTV, a double press of the Guide button will send you to the DVR channel grid, but without the aforementioned page up/down buttons navigating is an imprecise chore.  The TV has a 2-hour sleep feature to keep its content up-to-date.  If you shut off the TV and come back an hour later you won't miss a beat.  If you shut off the TV and return the next day, it can take 30 seconds to 5 minutes for the Guide to update and be ready to use.The GooglePlay app store is...weird.  Within the app store I can click GAMES and I'm taken to a page that shows subheadings for featured items, editor's picks, etc.  Except that there are zero, and I literally mean zero apps on these pages.  It's as if the store is empty.  However, if I search within the store for "solitaire," I'm given the option to download a game that works on the TV.  Once again, you need to know exactly what you're looking for.  There are a very limited number of apps, though.  I believe the problem is that GoogleTV is running a variant of Android 3.2 instead of the 4.X running on most phones and tablets for 2012-2013.  I have no idea if an upgrade to 4.X will provide more apps.  Of the apps that are there, it's a somewhat mixed bag.  The internet browser is amazingly not horrible for a TV, thanks in large part to the keypad remote with scroll wheel and Wii-like pointer.  I had a difficult time with streaming services, though.  Short YouTube clips have worked well, but AmazonPrime hasn't been perfect.  At first, I searched for "Avengers," and Google directed me to an option to watch a comprehensive list of movies that I could pay for or watch for free.  That search part is wonderful.  I selected the movie, Thor, because it was free through my Amazon Prime subscription.  I was able to get through the whole movie, but there were 2 instances where I had to wait for buffer loading in HD.  While not perfect, recent updates in the AmazonVideo app have dramatically improved streaming performance and it gives me hope that a few more software/firmware updates will really improve GoogleTV.SUMMARYIn conclusion, the GA7900 is a very good television.  The panel's picture quality and its ability to compete against similarly priced sets on the market today is why I'm giving this product a 5-star review.  You could still simply use this set like any other TV and choose to ignore the GoogleTV features and be pleased with the picture (you'll still need to create that Google account, though).  My only caveat is that the GoogleTV functionality as of June 2013 still has a ways to go before it can fully and precisely interact with a DVR's menus, or altogether replace them.  The software has some cool advantages with its image-based content scrolling, but it's still too limited in its current form.  Hopefully Google can update the software to Android 4.X (rumored to happen later in 2013), and offer ways to stumble onto TV programs without me needing to know exactly what I want to watch.  The remote is one step away from being one of the best gadgets of the year, but the lack of just a couple buttons is a mind-blowing admission.  It would be great if LG can provide some new firmware to perhaps assign more functions to the colored remote buttons.  The mystical TV-watching experience I was hoping for is so tantalizing close, but yet remains beyond the reach of my magic remote clenched hand.(If Google/LG push out significant upgrades I'll try to update this review).

The OXO Good Grips Measuring Cups, Stainless Steel, Updated Design deliver all of the things you expect from OXO products - ergonomic design, sturdy construction, form and function.Pros:- The measuring cups have rubber handles that are easy to grip, especially when your hands are wet or sticky from baking mishaps.  The rubber handles also make it easier to hold the cups when washing them.- The cups are held together by a plastic ring that keeps them from getting separated and lost in the drawer.  You can detach the measuring cups from the ring when you need to use them, but it's a nice feature to be able to reconnect them for storage purposes.- The measuring cups are stainless steel, so they're durable.  I have my share of cutesy, porcelain, decorative measuring cups that look great on the shelf, but don't exactly hold up to the frantic, last-minute baking that I so often do.  These will hold up to a little heating if necessary, you can bang them against a stainless steel mixing bowl to tap out ingredients in a rush, and they'll survive being thrown in the sink with all of your other baking gadgets and spatulas.  Perhaps I should be a bit gentler with my baking equipment, but these measuring cups can handle the punishment.Cons:- The shape of the measuring cups allows them to fit into almost all of my containers and canisters for flour, sugar, etc.  However, I have a few glass jars that are a bit too narrow for these measuring cups, so it was somewhat of a struggle to measure the ingredients.  I have some other measuring cups in my baking arsenal that will fit into these jars, so it was disappointing that these didn't fit.  It's not enough of a problem to subtract a star from the rating, since it's probably more my fault for buying glass jars with narrow openings, but I thought it was worth pointing out.In the end, I give these measuring cups a 5 out of 5.  They are durable and should last a long time.  They're easy to use, easy to clean, and easy to locate in a cluttered drawer of baking supplies.  OXO does not disappoint.

The LG 42GA6400 is a mixture of solid performance and underdeveloped promise.  At the time of this review (May 2013), the 42GA6400 is a 4-star television.  I put that disclaimer up front because I firmly believe that some thoughtful software fixes could definitely bump this TV up to 5-stars.HARDWAREI'll start with the physical specifications of the television first.  Assembly of the stand is pretty typical for LCD sets, and I had no problem attaching the 8 screws required to get the TV in an upright position by myself.  I would have preferred a base with a standard X pattern, but the two "arms coming out to hug you" stand is stable enough and doesn't take up a huge footprint.  It's somewhat of a bummer, but the stand lacks a tilt/rotation capability.  There are 4 HDMI inputs on the side of the TV, a headphone output, an optical out, USB inputs, and some 1/8" jacks that allow you to plug in composite and component in cables via the supplied adapters.  There is an additional 1/8" jack for the IR blaster adapter (also supplied--it's a Y-adapter with two IR blasters connected to the same jack).  There is also a coax cable input for direct standard cable signal or an over-the-air antenna.  The 3-prong, grounded power cord is attached to the opposite side of the TV from the inputs.  Unfortunately, I feel like the power cord could be a good 1-2 feet longer.  The frame is about an inch in each direction around the screen, and is made of a pretty slick, metallic-looking gray plastic.PICTUREThe 42 inch panel on this TV holds up well against similar $750-900 competition (obviously scale up the cost on 47-55 inch models).  It's a full 1080p LED backlit screen.  There is no microdimming from the LEDs, and as a result the best black it can produce is a dark, dark gray.  I didn't have any issues with lighting bleed around the bezel or at the edge of the screen.  Still, the black levels and contrast are consistent with panels in this price range.  You'll have to drop another couple hundred to get better contrast.  I do find the color reproduction to be very good compared to similarly priced sets.  Reds and greens have an appropriate amount of saturation, but due to the limited dynamic contrast the overall picture just lacks a little bit of vibrancy.  I watched NBA and NHL playoffs on the set, and I was pleasantly surprised with the ability of the 120Hz refresh to keep up with most of the action.  Hockey still had some noticeable digital motion blur, but by no means was it bad.  Overall, the screen slightly exceeded my expectations for this price range.3DI don't watch much 3D because content is limited and there are rarely any live sporting events that transmit a 3D signal.  This LG comes with 4 pairs of passive 3D glasses (similar to the glasses you get in a movie theatre).  Since my 3D options are somewhat limited, I fired up Green Lantern in 3D (yes, I know the movie is awful) and put on the glasses.  Wow.  For a TV the 3D effect was solid and I never experienced any cross-signal.  The 3D viewing angle isn't that wide, but you can maintain a quality depth effect if you're sitting 30-45 degrees away from straight-on.  Again, I was surprised that I wound up preferring this passive 3D effect over my active-shutter 3D glasses I use with my Samsung ES7500.  It's also nice that you don't have to worry about putting batteries in the glasses as well.REMOTEIf you're reading this review the reason you're considering this TV is because it's a Google TV.  Well, really, the GoogleTV software goes hand-in-hand with this iteration of the LG magic remote.  LG made an incredible remote for this TV, however, they also annoyed me to no end by not going the extra mile and including a couple simple, intuitive features.  First, the good...the keyboard works great and is so much better than trying to type out search phrases in a SmartTV with a D-pad.  The pointer works very well.  It's basically a poor-man's version of a Wiimote.  Some of the features, like holding down the gesture button and air-drawing semi-circles to zoom in can be next to useless, but for the majority of the GoogleTV interface this remote is a wonderful match.  Unfortunately, the remote has problems whenever I try to use my Comcast DVR.  There are times when I want to use my DVR's channel guide (see below) and unfortunately, this remote does NOT have page up and page down buttons.  This problem could be alleviated if LG can fix the firmware and allow a single click of the scroll wheel down to send a "page down" signal to the DVR through the IR blaster.  The other issue is that, amazingly, there is no STOP button.  There is a separate play and a separate pause button, but no stop.  Why not make one button PLAY/PAUSE and the other button STOP?  When I'm watching DVR video I need the stop button to get me out of the program I'm watching and give me the option to delete it.  Instead, all I can do is pause, and then hit BACK, which takes me all the way out of the DVR menu structure.  It's annoying.  Buried within the menus is the ability to assign functions to the red, yellow, green, and blue buttons, but I tried to assign this page up and down functions and it didn't work.  There is a lot of empty space on the front of the remote.  Why didn't LG add a couple more buttons for page up/down and stop...and even 0-9 while they're at it?GOOGLE TVObviously, this is the differentiator for this set.  If you ask me is it worth paying roughly an extra $100 over a competitive panel with the same picture quality to have GoogleTV built-in, my answer as of May 2013 would be---not yet.  Hopefully some software and firmware updates will soon change that answer to a definitive YES.  Basically, GoogleTV tries to interact with your DVR and essentially overlay its interface on top of DVR's interface and cable (or satellite) signal.  When you start up your GoogleTV, you are required to log in with a Google account.  Not a fan of Google's privacy policies?  Too bad.  The main thing is that your account gives you access to the Google store so that you can load up your TV with apps.  Once you're logged in, you calibrate the TV to the type of TV signal you receive, what area you're in, and whether or not your receive premium channels.  From there it takes a few minutes to load, but GoogleTV takes over and provides you with its channel guide.  The GoogleTV channel guide is similar to Apple's cover flow for music.  Instead of seeing a common spreadsheet grid from your DVR, you instead thumb through mini-images of movie and TV show posters.  At first glance, it seems like a much more intuitive way to find content.  However, it only works well for live TV and shows that are going to start within 5 minutes or so.  You won't see shows that are going to begin in an hour.  On a normal DVR channel grid, I can flick around and see that a program will come on an hour from now.  I can either record it or plan to watch it.  With GoogleTV, you are instead supposed to know what you want to watch and use the keyboard or voice search to find it.  The search will find it on upcoming TV listings, Netflix, Amazon Video, YouTube, etc.  The difference is that you have to know what you are looking for ahead of time.  While using GoogleTV, a double press of the Guide button will send you to the DVR channel grid, but without the aforementioned page up/down buttons navigating is an imprecise chore.  The TV has a 2-hour sleep feature to keep its content up-to-date.  If you shut off the TV and come back and hour later you won't miss a beat.  If you shut off the TV and return the next day, it can take 30 seconds to 5 minutes for the Guide to update and be ready to use.The GooglePlay app store is...weird.  Within the app store I can click GAMES and I'm taken to a page that shows featured items, or editor's picks.  Except that there are zero, and I literally mean zero apps on these pages.  It's as if the store is empty.  However, if I search within the store for "solitaire," I'm given the option to download a game that works on the TV.  Once again, you need to know exactly what you're looking for.  There are a very limited number of apps, though.  I believe the problem is that GoogleTV is running a variant of Android 3.2 instead of the 4.X running on most phones and tablets for 2012-2013.  I have no idea if an upgrade to 4.X will provide more apps.  Of the apps that are there, it's a somewhat mixed bag.  The internet browser is amazingly not horrible for a TV, thanks in large part to the keypad remote with scroll wheel and Wii-like pointer.  I had a difficult time with streaming services, though.  Short YouTube clips worked well, but AmazonPrime had a rough start.  At first, I searched for "Justified," and Google directed me to an option to watch free season 2 episodes via my Amazon Prime subscription.  Great!  UGH...except that streaming was unwatchable with constant buffering pauses in HD and even in SD.  After taking 21 minutes to watch the first 10 minutes of the show because of horrible buffering lag, I shut off the TV, fired up my Samsung ES7500 (which was positioned right next to this LG) and was able to stream the same episode from the same source, in HD, with no lag.  I was going to post my review last week and drop it another star, but just recently there was an update that dramatically improved the performance.  I still had 4 buffering incidents in a 1-hour long show, but it was at least watchable now.  It gives me hope that a few more software/firmware updates will really improve this TV.SUMMARYOverall, the LG 42GA6400 is a competitive TV in the $750-900 price range (scale the 47-55 inch units appropriately).  The picture is solid and the hardware looks good.  The remote is one step away from being one of the best gadgets of the year, but the lack of just a couple buttons is a mind-blowing admission.  The software has some cool advantages with its image-based content scrolling, but it's still too limited in its current form.  If Google can update the software to Android 4.X (rumored to happen late summer 2013), offer ways to stumble onto TV programs without me needing to know exactly what I want to watch, and if LG can provide some new firmware to improve WiFi streaming and perhaps assign more functions to the colored remote buttons--we might have a 5-star winner here.  But until that time, the functions fall just short.  You're still getting a good set; it's just not the magical TV experience I was hoping for.(If Google/LG push out significant upgrades I'll try to update this review).UPDATEThere's been some minor updates to the OS and several apps.  The Google Play store now lists a few featured apps under the headings (instead of nothing), but apps are still woefully underrepresented.  There is no Hulu app, nor is there an Xfinity app.  And HBO GO is incompatible with this GoogleTV.  I wanted to catch up on Game of Thrones, but the app just sends to you the Chrome browser-based website and nothing loads. I doubt HBO GO gets fixed until (if?) GoogleTV gets updated to Android 4.X.X.  On the bright side, Amazon Prime is working much smoother than before, and the Zillow app with the magic remote is really fantastic if you're house hunting.2ND UPDATEThe second gen Google TVs from LG just got updated to an Android 4.2.2 variant in the past week.  The update took about 15 mins to download and install.  The GooglePlay store has a few more apps available when you open it, but Hulu Plus and HBO GO are still missing at the moment (end of Oct 2013).  However, with the new update in place, I have much greater hope that we'll see better apps coming soon to this device.

The Heartmath 6400 Inner Balance Sensor is a unique and interesting product, but it's value and usefulness to each user will probably vary.The 6400 is an overall quality product.  There's not too much in the box, just a 30-pin connector with a 1/8" jack and a corresponding male 1/8" cord with a clip sensor.  Heartmath also included a drawstring pouch to carry the sensor--a thoughtful touch.  To begin, I went to the app store and searched "heartmath" to find the free, 70+ MB app.  Curiously, the app says it's optimized for the iPhone 5, yet the connector won't work with an iPhone 5 (the box states it will work with a 30-pin to lightening adapter, but I didn't test this).  Anyway, I installed the app on a 4th gen iPhone Touch.  From there, just clip the sensor to your ear and plug the 30 pin connector into the iPhone/iPod Touch.  A notification pops up asking permission to use the sensor and clicking yes whisks you into the app.  The construction of the hardware is simple, yet seems effective and durable.The app itself is a cleanly designed 3rd party piece of software.  An initial mini-tour explains the very basics of convergence and heart rate variability (HRV).  Not surprisingly, all the instructions and details are digital, so you'll have to click some tabs within the app to actually find out what the principles of inner balance are and what is the point of the app.  Some things are still not explained as thoroughly as I would have preferred.  The basic idea is by learning to control your breathing, you can decrease the amount of variability between heartbeats.  If your heartbeats are more consistent, you'll have a greater capacity to lower to your stress, increase cognitive functions, and be more productive.  As a partial con, I would have liked to see some examples of "perfect" and "poor" heart rate wave traces so I knew what I was trying to aim for.A session starts by tapping the center area of the app.  A timer begins along with a visual wave reading that sort of looks like an EKG heart rate monitor.  You can swipe left and right to find your desired breathing-guide image.  The standard image is a color wheel that expands and contracts, providing a tempo for your breathing.  But there are other images, like waterfalls with a sliding metronome-type guide. You can even use your own images.  Additionally, you can further customize your breathing experience by loading a playlist or individual song.  While you're breathing and looking at the screen, the goal is to even out those heart rate waves shown on the dynamic EKG-like trace.  Chimes will also go off if you're performing well.  The more even your breathing and heart rate, the more time you'll spend in a high level of "convergence."  The program will also award achievement points, much like Xbox.  Once you're done with a session, just double tap the center of the screen.  The program will record your session, as well as a smiley-face mood indicator that you pick.  If you'd like, you can also journal about your experience.This is a neat product with a sensor that works amazingly well.  But how much will you get out of this product?  I think it's up to the user.  I can tell you that I used it 1-2 times a day for a week or two and didn't appreciably notice changes in stress level or cognitive function.  In general, though, I'm not a big believer of these types of stress-relieving techniques so it's no shock that the 6400 didn't do too much for me.  I haven't given up on it, though, and I plan to continue recording daily sessions for a month.  If you already practice breathing exercises and believe in their calming powers, then the Hearthmath 6400 could be a very powerful product to help you monitor and record your stress-beating levels.  If this was $30, I probably would have zero reservations about recommending this to anyone, as it would be worth a shot.  With a normal sticker price much higher than that, however, I recommend the Hearthmath 6400 inner balance sensor for people who believe in these types of breathing exercises or for people who are desperate to try anything to help them with anxiety and focus.

I have to say that I'm pleasantly surprised by the Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista's features and functionality for the price.The Cafe Barista is rather lightweight and has a standard sized footprint.  I'm coming from a sub $100 cheap 4-cup coffee maker/espresso combo machine and the durability and feel of this Mr. Coffee obviously blows that away.  However, I'm still impressed with how well it stacks up against the $400 and up espresso machines I see at the store.  Making an espresso, cappuccino, or latte is a straightforward process of loading your favorite espresso grounds into the included single or double shot filter, loading milk if necessary, and pushing the pre-set single or double buttons on the front of the machine.  The Mr. Coffee brews quick and can produce a consistently great froth with 1% milk (I didn't try any other types).  The milk frother's arm is adjustable and there is a cool mini-tray that you can pull out to position smaller glasses closer to the dispenser to minimize splashes.  The latter is an extremely simple, yet clever feature that I love.I have a couple cons, but they're minor.  For starters, filling the water reservoir in a shallow sink isn't always the easiest task.  The reservoir is tall, but slim.  For my shallow sink I would have loved to see a a slightly wider, but shorter reservoir.  Also, the dispenser tends to drip/leak a little after you're done brewing.  Everytime I think my beverage is totally done, I wait another minute and watch a couple extra drips fall, but there always seems to be a few more that fall out after I grab my mug.  Still, the overall clean-up isn't bad and these complaints and somewhat personalized and/or trivial.  Given the price of this unit compared to the competition, I believe it's still worth 5-stars.  Well done, Mr. Coffee...quality at-home espresso/cappucino/lattes at a price that's good for the masses.

This year is the first year I'm really noticing that my skin isn't as soft as smooth as it used to be.  For this reason, Ive been looking at different products to see what would help best.  I've been using this product for the past 3 weeks, and found it to improve my complexion by evening out my skin tone.  Although I was at first surprised by the bright orange carrot juice colour, I found the texture and the citrusy fragrance to be pleasant.The main ingredients of this product are :25% vitamin C20% hyaluronic acid2.5% niacinamide2.5% COQ105% Alpha Arbutin1% Wakame BiofermentVitamin C contains antioxidants, stimulates the production of collagen, and the acids act as an exfoliant. Its also used in many cultures to lighten your skin tone or even out pigmentation and discoloration.Hyaluronic Acid helps the skin retain moisture and plump up your skin by being able to attract and draw in water from the environment. This works well in more humid locations but note that in really dry climates this water binding ingredient cant draw moisture from the environment and may actually pull from deeper layers of the skinNiancinamide (or vitamin B3) works to increase ceramide and free fatty acid levels in the skin. This helps simulate microcirculation and increases water content.CoQ10 is another anti-oxidant, while Alpha Arbutin works to even out your skin tone.  Its a glucosulated hydroquinone (a product often used in skin lightening products).So this product helps to even out the skin tone, inhibit pigment formation and plumps up the skin.  I received a sample of this product in exchange for my honest opinion, and I found it to help with all these effects.  I see myself continuing to use the product.

The number of devices that I own has been steadily multiplying and there came a day where I was fighting for wall charger space with other members of the household.It was time to get one of these chargers.  I looked at a few different chargers and decided to order this one, mostly based on looks and the fact that it was a "smart" charger that figured out what power requirement each device had.The unit is fairly compact and feels solid and sturdy.  I plugged in all my ipads, iphones, kindles and android phone and they all seemed to be able to charge fine from the unit.  I'd read before from previous reviews that this product doesn't charge faster, but the fact that I can charge all the devices at once is good enough for me.  I like that this product comes with a travel pouch.  I've been taking the unit with me to the office since we also fight for one wall outlet over there too.The one thing I wish with this charger (and why it doesn't get a full 5 stars) is I wish there was some indicator light to show that the product was on / charging / fully charged.  I'm used to that with my camera charger and that would have been a nice feature.  Otherwise, the product is solid.  I received a review sample of this product for my honest opinion.  If I notice anything different I'll update this review.

I'd seen these mugs around but never felt compelled to buy one until my neighbour handed me a rosemary lemonade on a hot day in one of these types of mugs.  The refreshing taste was so nice I decided to go and look for my own."These copper mugs keeps your drinks colder" I was told.The idea just didn't make sense: copper is an excellent heat conductor. Why should it keep my drink colder?So when I received this cup, I set out to find out if the Mule cup really did keep my drinks colder.I added equal amounts of ice, vodka and ginger ale to both the copper mule cup, and just a regular old glass cup.  I started my temperature readings with a laser reader, and both were about 33 degrees.I waited let them sit for about 20 minutes, gave them a quick stir, noticed that most of the ice was gone from both cups and read their temperature again.  The glass came out at about 42 degrees, but the mule cup was about 44.  Not wanting to risk inaccuracies from the laser bouncing off ice or something, I took out a good old cooking thermometer.  The glass read at 46 degrees and the mule cup at 50.I then let them sit for a full hour, gave them a stir and took their readings again with the cooking thermometer.  The glass cup had raised to 59 degrees, and the mule cup to 61 degrees.So, the mule cup turned out to be consistently 2-4 degrees warmer than the regular old glass cup. So does it keep drinks colder?  No.THAT said, I think what is meant is that these copper mule mugs have better conductivity, meaning that you need less ice for your drink to feel cooler to the touch and to your tongue. Plus, drinking out of these mugs also IS cooler.Overall, in terms of this product specifically, the mug is extremely sturdy and comes in a nicely packaged box.  It definitely makes an excellent gift and I'm glad to have one.  I received this product at a discount in exchange for my opinion.  I plan to buy a 2nd one to have a matching set for the house.

If you buy this product with the right expectations, it works great.I was looking for a waterproof case because I like to go kayaking and paddleboarding, and I never bring my phone because I worry about it getting wet.  I saw a paddleboarder with a waterproof bag similar to this one and decided to go searching for my own bag.  Then the opportunity to try a review version of this bag came up.This waterproof case claims to keep water out, fits a number of different phones, and floats.
