Because I wasn't going to risk my phone, I put a piece of paper towel into the bag and submerged it under water.  For the minute I held the bag, it held fine and my paper towel stayed dry.  When I let go, the case floated.  That said, there are many reviews that talk about their phones getting wet if they leave this pouch submerged, so I wouldn't count on keeping this phone under water for any extended period of time.  For most water sports, water resistance should be more than fine.  I definitely wouldn't try to take this snorkelling or scuba diving just in case, or without testing out the particular bag by submerging it in water overnight.If you search for waterpoof case, there are a number of cases like this.  They all have a similar design, so I imagine they are all the same.  The price ranges and fluctuates, so shop around to see which product has the best price when you purchase.The one thing to note about this bag is that it is designed to fit a number of different phones. As a result, it's larger than it needs to be if your phone is an iphone, for instance.  Not a big deal, but if you don't want a clunky phone bag you might look for a pouch designed specifically for your phone type.Overall, I would use this product for my next trip out of the water, but I would still use a lot of care to keep my phone from getting wet anyway.  I received this product at a discount for review purposes.

I like mixing up shampoos and use everything from Aveda and Bumble and Bumble to Pantene and Fructis.  I found this shampoo to lather well and clean well.  One thing I hate about some shampoos (especially the ones that come in cheap motels) is that squeaky texture that your hair gets.  This didn't happen at all with this shampoo.  I have long hair and my hair didn't tangle, plus my hair felt nice and soft afterwards.  I still used conditioner, but my boyfriend only used the shampoo and his hair felt soft afterwards as well. The smell was pleasant (hard to identify exactly what it was, but maybe more floral).One thing I really like about this shampoo is that it has a more compact pump bottle.  A lot of the salon bottles have a much taller and narrower bottle, which doesn't fit in my shower nook nor my shower rack.  This bottle fits in the built in nook comfortably.  Overall, I liked using this shampoo and would keep it in my shampoo rotation. :)  I received a review sample of this product for my honest opinion.

When we bought our house we inherited travertine floors and the hassles that come with it.  If the floors aren't cleaned and sealed regularly a tonne of water damage happens.  I already have a sealer, but I was looking for a regular cleaner to keep the floors in tip top shape.  I'd looked at a number of different brands, but decided to try this one based on the reviews.The product comes concentrated, and you mix your own solution.  The ratio is 4 ounces per gallon, so at 32 ounces in the bottle you get 8 gallons of cleaning solution.  Compared to the other brands that are already pre-mixed, it's a great value, but it is an extra step before you can start cleaning.  It's helpful to pick up a $3 empty spray bottle at Lowes to mix the solution.  I mixed up my solution, poured it into a spray bottle and got to work scrubbing my floor with a sponge (Next time I'll just use a mop.)I found the product pretty easy to use, and had a pleasant citrusy fragrance (pleasant for a cleaning product :)  It didn't leave a high shine like Pledge does on wood, but it left my floors slightly shinier than before.  I scrubbed the floors without gloves and the product didn't wreck my skin, but it's still probably better to wear gloves with cleaning products.  Floors felt nice and clean afterwards to my bare feet.Overall a great cleaner and great value if you don't mind doing your own mixing.  I received a review sample of this product in exchange for my opinion.

I've been seeing so many Dead Sea Mud masks as of late I was really curious to see what the benefits were.  In general, clay / mud masks are great for cleaning pores.  Dead sea mud masks have the extra benefit of being high in concentrations of magnesium, sodium, calcium and other minerals.  (Apparently most of us are deficient in magnesium and magnesium is best absorbed topically!)  It can help with some skin conditions such as eczema, acne and psoriasis.The specific ingredients in this product are : deionized water, dead sea mud, kaolin, shea butter, sunflower oil, aloe vera juice, vegetable glycerin, jojoba oil, hickory bark extract, calendula oil and xantham gum.For me, this product had a pleasant fragrance and the texture was what I expected of a mud mask.  I was able to easily apply a nice thick layer, and the mask washed off to leave my skin with a nice soft texture.  There did appear to be a bit of a film on my face after I washed it off, but it wasn't unpleasant.  I haven't had any bad skin reactions to date and the price appears competitive with other mud masks.  As I continue to use this product I will update my review.  I received a review sample of this product for my honest opinion.  So far very happy with the product!

This was a super easy product to install.  I was able to have my lock replaced within 5 minutes.  The handle feels solid, has good heft and a comfortable good grip to it.  It as a smoother finish than I expected for being satin nickel, but that's not a negative.  What I also liked is that the package comes with both the rounded latch plate and square latch plates so it didn't matter which type you had in your door before.  I had previously ordered a Baldwin handle set and I believe it only came in square form so I wasn't able to use it without notching out my door frame first.I bought this handle used via Amazon Warehouse.  For the minimal price difference, I would opt to buy it new next time, as the way it was packaged meant the handle arrived quite scratched up.  That aside, this was a great door handle and I'm happy with the purchase.

There are some mixed reviews about this product - mostly that it's not very sharp.  The pair I got seemed totally fine and had good grip.  I tried tweezing fine hairs and thicker hairs and picking up little beads and had no trouble with doing any of those tasks.I'd been purchasing Tweezerman tweezers forever, but given the fact that I'd been discovering a lot of generic brands that were as good quality as the brand names, I decided to branch out and try different tweezer brands.  In terms of heft and structure, there was no major difference between my Tweezerman and this pair (aside from stylistic where these tweezers have 3 holes where you grip).  Time will tell how sharp this stays.  The only reason this doesn't get a full 5 stars is because the lifetime guarantee is unclear.  With Tweezerman, they have a clear tweezer sharpening policy with directions for how to send back your tweezers.  I followed through with that and DID get back nicely sharpened tweezers from Tweezerman (albeit 2 months later.)  When I went on the Bodyline web site, I did not easily locate this information.  If you're not the type to send in old dull tweezers, Bodyline is a better bet for you given that it's a bit cheaper than other 'professional' quality tweezers at a comparable quality.  I received a review sample of these tweezers for my honest opinion.

We have a problem with bees in our roof.  Since a beekeeper charges you less to remove the bees (alive) if you prepare access to the beehive first ($250 vs $1-1.6K) we were highly motivated to open up the roof ourselves, but there was no way we were going to do that without protection.  After reading all the different reviews, we decided to go with this suit.  I liked that it was a full suit with elastic bands around the arms and legs.  We ordered one size larger (M instead of S for a 5'8" person) since it sounded like it was better for the suit to be loose, and to allow clothing underneath.  We ordered gloves as well and wore long socks.  There are several different styles of bee suit out there for the head piece - I like that this one had a reinforced frame that protruded out so it wasn't as intimidating having bees buzz in your face.  I'd read that it helps to wear a baseball cap under the suit to keep the face mesh away from your face so we did that as well.  Then the suit was put to the test.  We put it on, got into the thick of the hive, and sure enough, we were well protected as hundreds of agitated bees started swarming around (and actually tried to sting us) as could be seen by all the stingers on the gloves.  Happily none of the bees got through this suit.  Glad to have gone with this suit.

I've hated how ugly whiteboards look for years, so when we found this glass whiteboard, we immediately ordered one for the home office.Due to the size and weight (I ordered the 4x6 size), the product ships with appointment delivery.  The packaging arrived this morning completely beat up to the point that the delivery fellow suggested we open the package to make sure the contents weren't broken. Thankfully it was not.  The 4x6 size which does flex, so that can feel a bit nerve racking carrying up the stairs.As other reviewers said, it would have been nice if this whiteboard came with a mounting template since it's heavy enough to be a pain to measure directly on the wall.  We ended up using a laser level, screwed a support plank into the studs where we wanted the whiteboard to sit, and propped the whiteboard up on that to determine where the holes should go (and for drawing circles on the wall).  I recommend discarding the drywall anchors that come with it (they are the cheapest anchors ever) and getting your own sturdier ones (I used toggle lock anchors) as I wasn't confident with what came with the package.This whiteboard IS magnetic, which was a happy bonus, but because the metal backing is very thin, you may not be able to use regular magnets.  (I've attached a picture to show what the back looks like.)  The board comes with two rare earth magnets that seem to hold to the board pretty well.  It also comes with one marker which was already dry and pretty unusable.The board doesn't lie flush to the wall, but rather protrudes about a 1/2 inches out, so when you are writing in the middle the board you can see it flex a bit, but so far it's holding up ok and I think it's normal.Overall while the board does have its faults (mounting hardware especially), it's the best alternative to the standard whiteboard I've come across.  Once installed, it looks great and is worth the hassles.

I like a strong gum.If it's not burning it's not worth chewing.  And this is the strongest flavour I've been able to find readily short of just chewing on Altoids (and that's not gum.)I prefer this packaging format over the packs of gum that you can buy at Costco because I find these containers stay fresh better than the foil packs.  I also prefer this to the zip top bags as I don't always properly seal zip bags.  I keep one of these containers at my desk, and also use this to refill a small metal tin that I take with me on the go.Dentyne better not ever discontinue this flavour!!

I used to work for L'Oreal, and one of the things I learned is that if you wait long enough, the technology that is in their salon brands (such as L'Oreal Professional, Kerastase, Redken, etc.) make it to their mass market lines. :)  And being that the company was originally founded by a scientist, they actually do a decent amount of R&D on their products (857M in R&D across all brands in 2013).  I can't say I know which technologies might be in this product, but this is one of the few conditioners I can use that leaves my hair smooth and relatively frizz free (and I have coarse, thick, unruly hair.)  This product doesn't make my hair oily, but then again, I try not to apply too much conditioner near my scalp.  It's on the thicker side for conditioner and has a fairly mild fragrance.

I was offered a chance to try these laces, and since my boyfriend has a pair of shoes in dire need of new laces, I ordered him a pair of black laces and made him restring his shoes to try them out.Here are his impressions:I like these laces.  I used them to replace the laces on some dress shoes I didn't like, you know those really waxy ones that never hold a knot?  These replacement laces were slightly thinner than my old ones and less waxy, which means they held a knot much easier and could be double-knotted if needed without being too clunky.  I also liked that the ends of the laces where you have that half inch of hardened area wasn't extremely glossy and was very durable.  On my old black laces it practically looked like somebody had wrapped them with packaging tape, but the new ones are a nice black semi-gloss.  My only worry is that the weave on these laces isn't as tight as my old pair, and you can see some straw fibers starting to stand out (probably because they aren't overwaxed).  This isn't an issue visually, but may mean that the shoe laces won't be as long lasting.  Only time will tell on that, they might be just fine and either way I'm pleased enough that I'd buy more for my dress shoes.Note - I would recommend measuring your existing shoe laces rather than going straight off the recommendation chart.  He's a size 9 and the standard shoe lace was a way too long.In summary:+ good price for quality+ available in lots of colours+ not too waxy; can hold a knot well+ good quality wrapper around the ends of the lace (not too glossy, doesn't look like shipping tape)- weave is not as tight as some other laces. Some fraying already.*** check to make sure you have the right length

Got these for my sister's wedding.  I hate wearing heels and you're more likely to find me wearing flats and runners, but for a non high-heels wearing person these were surprisingly comfortable.  I wore these shoes for most of the wedding and was able to keep wearing them even when the other bridesmaids had to take their heels off.  I like that the design is pretty simple, and are versatile enough to wear with regular cocktail dresses post wedding too.

I needed to drill some holes to mount a towel rack on a solid porcelain tile wall and these were a great price compared to some of the other options.  I spritzed a little water on the tile as we were drilling, but found that I didn't have to use much water at all. I was able to get the drill started by applying a little bit of pressure, and then the 'hole' process went pretty quick. :) To get through the solid porcelain took about 2 minutes at a medium/low speed.  Don't know how many I holes I'll be able to do with these drill bits without the bit wearing out, but it did the two fine, and the bit still looked to be in decent condition. The drill bits come in a small transparent plastic pouch.

Ordered this product because I liked their chia seeds, and I wanted to see what the difference was between this brand and Viva Labs http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HES9CMS (which is slightly cheaper).Overall, the product was not bad, but I actually prefer Viva Labs (which I received as a testing sample) better.Navitas Cacao is slightly more expensive, has a bit of a sour aftertaste, and has a pull tab resealable package that closes from the back of the pouch.  While this was fine for chia seeds, cacao powder is so fine that it just got all over my zip top and I had trouble closing it without making a mess.Also watch for the expiry date when you get it.  I ordered a two pack and found out that the cacao powder will expire within the next 4 months, so I'll be trying my best to use it up quick!Here are some of the recipes I've tried with cacao powder that have all been great so far:1. Cacao truffles.This was super simple and easy. Blend 3/4 cup of cacao powder, 10 dates, 2 tbsp of coconut oil and a sprinkling of sea salt. Rolled the "dough" into balls and dusted with cayenne pepper & rolled in cocoa nibs. Delicious, guilt free result. I made a batch, brought them to my neighbours and we ate the whole batch right then and there..2. Raw Brownies.Base  blend cacao powder, raw almonds, cashews, walnuts, dates, cherries, sea saltFrosting : blend cacao powder, coconut butter, almond extra, sea salt, agave nectar (or maple syrup :)Sister loves them.3. Cacao smoothiesBlend frozen bananas, berries and milk with a tablespoon of cacao. I heard that mixed with hazelnut and avocado is really delicious too for hedgehog smoothies but havent tried that yet.4. Warm cacao.Couldnt resist. I mixed it with some honey and warm milk and it was pretty delicious. It dissolved easily. Havent tried cold yet.5. Tiramisu topper.Ok the rest of tiramisu isn't all that health but the cacao was still delicious on top '

I love chocolate so much I have an entire pantry wall dedicated to couverture, cocoa, chocolate bars, truffles etc. It's probably a little ridiculous.I got interested in raw cacao because I was curious about the health benefits, and also to better understand the taste difference between raw cacao and roasted cacao beans (roasted cacao is the precursor to making chocolate.).  So when I was given the opportunity to try a sample of Viva Labs' Cacao powder and give an honest review, I said yes and decided to also order a bag of Navitas to do some comparison.WHAT IS CACAO POWDER?Cacao powder is formed by taking cacao beans, grinding them into a paste, then removing the fats by doing a cold press.  Cocoa powder on the other hand can come raw or roasted. Cocoa powder may sometimes still contain a bit of fat, and can also sometimes be mixed with sugar. Technically the FDA doesn't differentiate between cacao powder and cocoa powder so just look for the term "raw"WHY CACAO?  WHAT ARE THE BENEFITS?Cacao is considered a "superfood".  Superfoods are high nutrient foods that are especially beneficial.  There are over 700 nutrients and phytochemicals found in cocoa.  Among them:- High in antioxidants.  Cacao is ranked higher in antioxidants than blueberries and green teas.- High in essential minerals like magnesium, calcium, sulfur, zinc, iron, copper, potassium and manganese- Increased levels in certain neurotransmitters like serotonin and endorphins, which helps you feel good and gives you a something similar to a "runner's high"- Good source of dietary fiber- Low in cholesterol and sodiumTo keep the benefits, you would ideally not heat your cacao above 46oC (~115oF).VIVA LABS : THE PRODUCTThe Viva Labs cacao powder has a slightly bitter, very dry flavour which I like.  In contrast, I found the Navitas cacao powder to be slightly sour tasting (which has its uses - goes better with yogurt :).  Viva Labs cacao powder melted easily into my coffee, and also blended well into my desserts.  Viva Labs cacao is made is Peru (as is Navitas).  According to many artisan chocolate makers, South American cacao is the best tasting in the world (with Venezuela & Ecuador being subjectively the very best).VIVA LABS : PACKAGINGViva Labs cacao powder comes in a big see-through zip-top bag.  It's nice because you can see how much is left and it's easy to reseal.  In contrast, I didn't like that the Navitas cacao powder had a side zip pouch.  It's prettier looking but not very practical because the cacao powder got all over the seam.VIVA LABS : PRICINGI found this brand to be one of the more affordable priced brands on Amazon. It's definitely much cheaper to order online than in stores.VIVA LABS : SHELF LIFEMy bag of cacao powder has an expiry that's 7 months out, so it should be used fairly quickly. Navitas cacao powder had an even shorter expiry of 4 months out.  Eek!VIVA LABS : CACAO EXPERIMENTS & USESGiven that most of the benefits require consuming cacao raw (< 46oC), I focused my recipes on that.1. Cacao truffles.This was super simple and easy.  Blend 3/4 cup of cacao powder, 10 dates, 2 tbsp of coconut oil and a sprinkling of sea salt.  Rolled the "dough" into balls and dusted with cayenne pepper & rolled in cocoa nibs.  Delicious,  guilt free result.  I made a batch, brought them to my neighbours and we ate the whole batch right then and there..2.  Raw Brownies.Base  blend cacao powder, raw almonds, cashews, walnuts, dates, cherries, sea saltFrosting : blend cacao powder, coconut butter, almond extra, sea salt, agave nectar (or maple syrup :)Sister loves them.3. Cacao smoothiesBlend frozen bananas, berries and milk with a tablespoon of cacao.  I heard that mixed with hazelnut and avocado is really delicious too for hedgehog smoothies but havent tried that yet.4. Warm cacao.Couldnt resist.  I mixed it with some honey and warm milk and it was pretty delicious.  It dissolved easily.  Havent tried cold yet.5. Tiramisu topper.Ok the rest of tiramisu isn't all that healthy but the cacao was still delicious on top. :)If the price stays reasonable, this will probably be my go-to brand going forward.

Picture has been fixed since this review was written.  Rest of the review applies.------As other reviewers have noted, the picture of the mounting plate is upside down.  You'll want to flip it and fold it the other way so the screws are not visible.  The towel ring came well packaged and there is a nice hefty feel to it. It's already assembled as you see in the photo, plus a mounting plate + 2 screws.I HAD to write a review because I was so impressed with Delta (or in this case Liberty Hardware).  I ordered this towel ring in the middle of a major bathroom remodel, and parts were everywhere.  So I actually managed to lose the mounting plate and screw before I had a chance to install this.  I emailed Delta to see how to order replacement parts and they redirected me to Liberty Hardware, who actually shipped me a new set of plates and screws at no charge!The only (minor) complaint is that this towel ring is very long, so my towel hangs a little lower than I'd like.  I wish they offered a shorter version.  Measure to make sure the towel ring is at a good height with towel.Overall this ring looks and feels great in the bathroom.  Glad to have ordered it.

Got this lock because I really liked the idea of having a occupancy indicator on the door handle itself, and well, this was the only option I could find.The install was pretty straightforward.  It installed like any normal lock and came with all the parts.  It's nice that the handle was reversible and the parts feel sturdy.  The product shipped relatively quickly.The part I didn't like as much was the actual locking mechanism.  It's the turn knob kind where I have to check that I've turned the knob all the way to make sure it actually locks the door.  A few times the door didn't actually properly lock (and of course then the sign still said vacant.)  I prefer the push button kind since there's less of a "halfway" mode.  I understand the company is releasing that version in the future.Overall it's a bit pricey (@ $75.99), but I'm glad I have it.

I am a scented candle junkie, so when I had the opportunity to try a sample of this product, I jumped at the chance.Id never heard of a 2 in 1 candle + moisturizer before and was intrigued by the concept.  The idea is that you can light the candle to scent your room, and afterwards use the melted wax on your skin as a moisturizer or massage oil.Unlike some of the cheaper candles that smell really artificial, this candle has a nice strong natural smell.  It does a great job of scenting up the room, even when unlit.The instructions for the moisturizer / massage part were to pour onto your palm or directly on the skin.  Ill admit I dipped the tip of my finger into the melted wax first assuming that it would be way too hot to touch but it was pleasantly warm and not too hot at all.  I dont know Id use it as a moisturizer regularly (candle is pretty hard at room temperature) but its very nice as a moisturizing oil when softened.  I have really dry skin and while it made my skin all greasy and shiny looking, it DID moisturize my dry scaly skin.  As a massage oil, it was great.The only ingredients on the candle are : natural soy wax, shea butter, jojoba oil and pure essential oils.  There is a 3-year shelf life for the candle.I didnt know a thing about the difference between soy wax and paraffin wax (the typical candle wax) so I looked it up.  Some facts:1. Soy burns safer and cleaner.  It doesnt produce as much soot as paraffin2. Soy candles burn at a lower temperature 38oC -40oC (~100-120oF) so THATs why its comfortable to apply on your skin.  Its only a little bit higher than your body temperature3. Soy is a renewable product, unlike paraffin that is derived from oil4. Soy burns slower  up to 50% longer which oftentimes offsets the higher price5. Soy is rich in Vitamin E  theres the moisturizer!  Vitamin E is also great for neutralizing free-radicals.At it's current price I would definitely buy more since its a cool date night or gift idea!

For the price, this is terrible value.  This product has no weight to it, the wood feels cheap, the pump top feels like plastic, and the soap bottle dispenser is only 1/3rd the size of the rectangle cube pictured.  I got it for $45 as part of a 2 piece set on Gilt and I'd say it feels like it's worth $5.  Looks wise, the product is nice, but it just doesn't have a quality feel to it.

I really wanted to like this shower.  I know someone who has the 59" x 32" x 97.4" shower installed, and 5 years later it's still working great.  So I figured this should be a no brainer.Please note when they say that this shower is for right-side configuration, they mean it.  I have a 47" nook in my bathroom and I figured it would be fine.Wrong.The shower is designed so you need to have access to the right side during installation, otherwise you cannot push the pieces together.  We were unable to mount some of the framing screws due to access and had to find other solutions to keep the frame sturdy.  Also while the pieces are beautiful, they could use some work on QA.  The pieces were too tight to fit the frame, and burrs in the cutout holes needed to be filed down to fit.  We ended up having to use a crowbar to widen the metal frame in order to slide all the shower walls in.  (We used the same installer who installed that other shower that's lasted 5 years, and he said the other shower was a breeze to put in, in comparison)When you fit the drain in, make VERY SURE that it is flowing smoothly.  We poured 5 gallons of water in as a test before mounting and that wasn't enough.  Once the shower was installed we realized the drain didn't flow quickly.  We ended up having to cut a hole in our drywall to access the drain to fix the problem.Also be sure to check all the seals in the back wall panel before you mount.  It might not hurt to add extra sealing on all the parts as we discovered that every part of the back shower leaks.  To be extra sure, we ran silicone caulking across all the edges again as well.For this shower, you will need 220v electricity.  For that, in our case we had to run a 10-3 wire to the circuit box and buy a new 30amp GFCI breaker.  That part was relatively straightforward -- except finding the breaker.  I had to go to 4 different electrical supply stores to get it.Now that the shower is installed it looks great, but it sure was a stressful install with lots of hiccups.  Let's hope it lasts as long as the other shower!Note: the instructions are very poorly translated.  I recommend finding a YouTube installation to watch the installation.  Also I got this shower on Wayfair because it's cheaper via their Premier program.UPDATE :I've had the shower for a few weeks now and have had a chance to use it more.  Overall the shower is holding up well, but the drain is a big problem.  We have to constantly monitor the drain or it backs up.  I would definitely recommend making sure the drain is functioning properly before you seal the shower in.

Just installed this fan and it looks as good as the photos.  The fan comes with a short and regular down rod, and if you need a longer rod you can purchase it separately.  The fan came very well packaged - each blade was bundled in its own protective pouch, plus the box came with white gloves for the installation so you don't smudge up your new fan.  The installation instructions weren't difficult, but they were a bit sparse.  Overall it took us about 30 minutes to install and we'd installed a few other fans before.  Once installed, the fan looks very sleek and runs super quietly.  On the highest setting you can really feel the breeze.  Only things I wish were that it had a wall-switch option, and that it had smart phone capabilities (like the Big Ass Haiku fan does).

Of all the things I saw at CES, this was the only item I decided to buy.  I actually found their competitor, DynaFlex Powerball first but decided to go with the NSD Spinner brand instead because it sounded like they were more on top of customer service.  I also liked that they had an affordable wind up version that didn't require using the cord.  You wind it up by turning the ball in the direction of the arrow (see picture attached, the arrow is embossed into the green part.)  I'd read these kinds of balls were popular with rock climbers as a forearm exercise and it was fun to use, so I decided to give it a shotPros:- Don't have to worry about losing a cord.  You can take this thing with you anywhere and give it a spin.- Easy to use - I find myself picking this up while I'm watching TV or just walking around.- Helps with wrist / forearm pain - I have pretty bad pain from using the computer too much, and I found using the ball helped me stretch my forearms and hands and helped reduce the pain a lot- I can't validate, but when I have the ball spinning on high RPMS it takes a lot of effort to maintain my grip on the ball so I feel like I'm doing something to build up my strength.Cons:- If you have sweaty hands like I do, it's sometimes tough to wind up the ball- Very confusing lineup of options.  I recognize in the end reading and taking note of the titles is super important.  Here's an overview of the lineup -~$20 : NSD Power Essential Spinner= regular ball, no counter to show rpms, no self starter, vibration free to 15,000 RPM~$30 : NSD Power AutoStart Spinner Gyroscopic Wrist and Forearm Exerciser with Auto Start Feature= regular ball, no counter to show rpms, w/ self start, vibration free to 15,000 RPM~$40 : NSD Power Winners Roll and Spin Spinner Gyroscopic Wrist and Forearm Exerciser with Digital LCD Counter and Auto-Start Feature= ball w/ rpm meter, w/self start, vibration free to 15,000 RPM **what I got**~$50 : NSD Roll 'N Spin Rainbow Lit AutoStart Spinner Gyroscopic Wrist and Forearm Exerciser with AutoStart and Multi-Lit LED == ball no counter to show rpm, w/ self starter, has LED lights that light up to different colours depending on how fast you're spinning, vibration free to 15,000 RPM~$75 : NSD Power Winner's Precision Sterling Spinner Gyroscopic Wrist (SILVER COLOUR)= ball w/rpm meter, NO self starter.  Vibration free to 15,000 RPM.  Delivers more resistance than the plastic balls.  Inertial resistance: 19kg at 10,000rpm (350Hz) 3.2kg at 10,000rpm (450Hz) "up to 41.3lbs"~$75: NSD Power Ultimate Winner's Precision Sterling Spinner Gyroscopic Wrist (GOLD COLOUR)= ball w/rpm meter, NO self starter.  Designed to deliver higher RPMS.  Claims vibration free operation at up to 27,000 RPM.Overall, since these aren't expensive, it was worth it for me to try out.Update: I still love this ball but I recommend not leaving it anywhere really hot.  Since I take this ball with me everywhere, I'd left it in the car overnight in the hot summer weather and I think the glue that held the grip band to the ball melted.  Now I can't keep the rubber grip on the ball when I spin as easily.

I wanted a recycle bin with a giant recycle symbol on the front of it so that guests would know we recycle in this house.I also wanted my recycle bin to fit under the kitchen sink.Since most kitchen sinks feature a garbage disposal situated smack in the middle of the kitchen sink, there's usually not a lot of room in the cabinets under that sink -- especially if you already have a garbage bin in there.  I'm happy to say this compact recycle bin is a great size and it fits perfectly under the sink in front of the garbage disposal, meaning I can have both my garbage bin and recycle bin side by side under the sink.  This bin is small, but I only end up needing to empty it about every other day.  Which is totally worth it that I can get everything out of sight and tucked away neatly.

This chandelier looks just as it does in the picture -- which looks great!  And all the parts feel very sturdy.There are some things to be aware, however:- There are very few instructions, but many tiny parts.  It took close to two hours to assemble this.  The chandelier came with only one instruction sheet, which is a diagram of the sequence of parts for the ceiling anchor only- This light uses T10 bulbs with E26 bases.  If you want LEDs they come to about $12 per bulb x 6 at Lowes- Maybe obvious for some, but I'm a chandelier newb, and I didn't realize the stem HAD to attach to the ceiling.  I thought it could partly hang from the wires.  The package comes with 78" of lead wire, however you only have 64 1/2 inches of stem.  So if you have a taller ceiling you will need to purchase additional stems.  Measure where you want the chandelier to go, then search for and add 2999NI 12" stems or 2997NI 24" stems as you need to get the chandelier to the right height.Overall I'm glad I have it, but wish I knew about the stems before I went and installed it to the ceiling!

UPDATE 1/17/2015I had this for a year, and loved using it -- until it stopped working.  I had purchased 6 of these in total (5 as gifts), and at least 2/6 of these things no longer hold a charge.  When I emailed support, because I contacted them just over the year mark (Jan 6th purchase date), the best they could offer me was a 25% discount.  It's great when it works, but such a high failure rate within a year seems disappointing.==========================The Withings Pulse claims to track your activity, your sleep, and your heart rate.If you're looking for something that is precise and accurate for exactly what you've done, this isn't it.  I don't think the technology is quite there yet in any device.But if you're looking for something that is effective as a motivator, and that gives you a consistent baseline to measure your progress, this is perfect for that.I've been eyeing activity trackers for some time.  Many of my friends choose the Fitbit while others chose the Nike Fuel band. I finally pulled the trigger on this device specifically for a few reasons:1. Integration with a smart scale.  I think if you're really motivated to change yourself - get more active, lose some weight, you want to get the smart scale with it to close the loop.  It is that much more rewarding and encouraging to keep up with your daily goal if you see the results of your work (whether it's lower fat %, lower weight).  The Fitbit also has a scale, but I liked that the Withings scale had been around for longer.  Sure you could just get any scale and put in manual measures to your app, but I'm a lazy person and having all of that integrated and automatically synchronized is a big deal.2. Works for both iPhone and Android.  I can't find the studies right now, but it's far easier to get fit and stay healthy if everyone else is doing it too. So for group motivation and support, when I finally committed to the Withings platform, I went ALL in and got 6 trackers + the Withings scale as Christmas presents to myself and everyone around me.  The fact that it works on both mobile platforms is a big plus.  As was getting a group of us on this at the same time.  Our friendly competition has definitely pushed me on the days I felt like slacking off.3. Accurate enough.  When I've gone on hikes and walks with friends who run, we've ended up with roughly the same number +/1 100 steps (albeit different calorie counts) at the end of the trail.  So while it might not exactly match the listed distance on a trail you've gone in terms of miles, it is at least consistent enough with itself which is the most important thing.  Also, while it might log a few steps as I'm moving the pulse from the strap to my pocket and vice versa, it consistently does that so I'm going to know on any given day if I've done net more or less.4. Has motivated me.  I wasn't sure how well this thing would work, but the simple act of having a concrete measure of my activity has motivated me to move and do more than any other system I'd set up for myself before.  I periodically glance at my tracker during the day, and find myself adjusting (ok an extra-long route to the store, maybe stepping in place while I'm on the phone, pacing while I watch TV).  Knowing exactly how much I've done means there's no excuse for me to "feel like I've done a lot".  I know if I've been active.  Or not.5. Good customer service. I'd read online that people have had problems with their customer service.  My personal experience was far from that.  5 days after I got the tracker, my clip holder broke.  Personally I think it's poorly designed as the repeated act of taking the clip in and out of the holder every night to move put in your night armband for sleep tracking is going to add a lot of strain to the corner of the clip.  Well I emailed customer service and they offered to replace my clip for free.  I just sent them my proof of purchase and 9 days later a package arrived from France.  I can't believe they sent the replacement from France but I'm happy to have the replacement.6. Detailed app and web interface.  I haven't seen the competitor apps, but for me, the web site and the app contain all the information I need.  At a glance, I can see my overall trends (compared to the normal range), and I can see my weekly trends of when I'm sleeping, how well I'm sleeping, when I'm most active.  I tried integrating MyFitnessPal.  I couldn't stick with that kind of dedicating food logging, but if you're that kind of person, the integration gives you a complete in/out/impact picture.7. Decent battery life.  I'd say your tracker will last well over a week with regular use. And it charges back up quickly (maybe 15 minutes).  The first days I got my tracker I was religiously syncing my tracker with my phone several times a day a few days later I'd only used about a bar of battery.That said the device does have some limitations:1. The plastic clip is really fragile.  I've read reviews of people having problems with the clip falling out of the holder.  To be safe, I keep the pulse in my pocket.  At $99 (or $70 during the Christmas sale), I sure don't want to be dropping and losing this thing that often.2. Some sort of data override would be nice.  Given that the sleep tracker works by being strapped to your body, the assessment of light and deep sleep (or being awake) is measured by your amount of movement.  I can be prone to insomnia, but sometimes that involves just lying awake and feeling frustrated.  It usually doesn't involve thrashing around like a mad person because I'm so upset I'm awake.  So the tracker has mistakenly taken my lack of motion to mean I'm in blissful deep sleep.  I wish!  It'd be nice in those cases to add manual entries (the way you can with weight) to add notes.  But in generally there is a correlation where more deep sleep (or sleep overall) has resulted in feeling more rested the next day.Bottom line: The resultsHow are the results?  This was a gift to myself for Christmas.  Since then, I've used the tracker every day and have committed to doing 10,000 steps every day.  I didn't change my diet and still continued to eat a few pieces of chocolate and some kind of dessert once a day.  This is not to say I prescribe this as the best way to get healthy.  I just happen to have a healthy love of food and was also curious to see what straight up physical activity would do to my weight.  I've never been overweight and lead a relatively active lifestyle, but 8 months of living off mayonnaise laden hotdogs while living in Chile did leave me a little plumper than I cared to staySo 19 days into this I've walked an average of 73K steps every week and slept an average of close to 8 hours.  I have gone from 111 lbs to a trendline average of 108 lb (naturally my weight will fluctuate at every measure but it steadily goes down.).  I feel great and am feeling as motivated as I was on day one.  Short of accidentally washing this thing or losing it, I'm going to keep using the Pulse and keep tracking!  This device has been one of my favourite purchases in recent memory.

I love this zester / grater.  It does a great job of grating up a decent quantities of hard cheeses into nice fluffy strands.  Unlike box graters, I'm able to get just the zest off limes and lemons without getting the rind as well.  It works great with fresh or frozen ginger, but not as well with older soft soggy ginger (duh, I suppose.)  Lately, I've expanded my grating horizon to include grating chocolate shavings onto my hot cocoa.  Suffice to say I find myself using this tool a lot.  I've had this grater for a few years and it's still working well and staying sharp enough for my purposes.On the down side, if you are any kind of klutz you should probably take a bit of care when using the grater.  I have accidentally grated my knuckles more times than I'd prefer to admit.  Slow down when you get to the end of your block, or buy one of those microplane mesh protection gloves.The other issue (especially with zest) is that the zest has a tendency to get stuck inside the grating edges.  Most of the time swishing the grater around in a bowl of water does the job so it's not a big showstopper, just an extra step to cleanup.Overall this is a great tool to have in your kitchen -- just be a bit careful with it. :)

Envelopes are not a purchase category I'd traditionally given a lot of thought to.  I knew I hated the licking type and went in search of self-seal envelopes.  Having bought these, I have now become enlightened to the fact I care a little bit more about envelopes than I'd guessed.For instance, the next time I buy envelopes I'd opt for the peel-off sticker type, and not the fold up type like these.  If you're like me and you usually write the address on the envelope first before sealing, you'll quickly realize that the fold down flap lines up right around where the TO address goes, making for some bumpy text writing.  Also, while the envelope feels nice and sturdy and they are security tinted, you can still see the contents within the envelope.  Plus this type of seal means you can peel the envelope open again.  Overall, for the price I'm fine with the envelopes for my every day purposes, but I'd still go with a different style the next time I am on the envelope shopping market again.

The online price for this product is too high!  I'd recommend printing out a 40% off coupon from Michaels or JoAnns to buy it for a better price.While this glucose is made using corn syrup, it's not the same as grocery store corn syrup in that it is much more viscous and has a lower water content.  The product itself performed the same as other glucose products I bought, but this one loses 1 star for the price, and another for the fact that the lid doesn't seal very well.  My closed container got tipped over and that was enough to pop the lid off and the contents oozed all over my bakery box.  The cleanup was not fun.

Ever since I took a chocolate class I've been addicted to making chocolate.  And with chocolates, the addition of glucose slows down the rate of crystallization so your chocolates don't get all gritty tasting.  While a lot of glucose is made using corn syrup, it's different than the corn syrup you buy in stores in that it's much more viscous and has a lower water content.The price of this brand seemed decent when you can get it with free shipping or as an add-on item, although in a bind you can buy a smaller container of Wilton's glucose from Michaels or JoAnn's with a 40% off coupon for a comparable price.  I was able to make about 300 chocolates + 2 batches of salted caramels with this container, but will probably upgrade to a 2.2 lb tub so I don't run out so fast.  It's true that the container doesn't have any kind of seal, but I didn't have any problems with it leaking.

I had the most delicious incredibly moist 72 hour short rib at Ad Hoc roughly one year ago.  At that very moment, I knew I was going to need to own a sous vide machine.  Since this was the only consumer sous vide brand available (at the time), I promptly ordered one.My impressions so far:SIZE:The unit arrived much larger than I expected.  It's roughly the size of a 1.5L coke bottle.  While this might have been really obvious to everyone it was a surprise to me. :)  The unit still fits comfortably within a stockpot for small items, but the sous vide unit will take up  of the available space of the pot.  I ended up primarily using the 12x20 plastic tub I got with my unit as the main cooking container.NOISE:Provided you have enough water it's a quiet steady hum (much like a small fish tank) that you can quickly tune out.  If the water level is too low it can be a bit noisy.ELECTRICITY USE:Given that low and slow was my plan (meaning days of cooking), I was curious to know how much electricity the unit consumed.  According the PolyScience web site, the cost of using the sous vide at 59oC (138oF) comes to about $0.03/hour.  In comparison from a study, using a gas or electric oven ranges from $0.07 - $0.10 per hour.  Good to know using it a lot doesn't break the bank :)WATER EVAPORATIONAfter an unfortunate granite-cracking incident (details below), I wasn't allowed to use the machine in the kitchen anymore, so the only possible place to use the machine was in the garage.  I was worried about water evaporation since I didn't have insulation for the container, however if you are to fill your container to the max fill line before you sleep, you can safely leave the unit overnight.  That's using a 12x20 plastic tub with no insulation and no lid.FOOD SAFETY:The most delicious medium-rare short rib is cooked at 133oF for 72 hours.  The texture you get at the end is just not replicable by any other cooking technique and these ribs alone are worth getting the machine.  However, at that temperature, my friends (aka food test subjects) were naturally curious about food safety.  The sous vide manual actually has a whole section on this.  The #1 thing to keep in mind is just to minimize the amount of time that food is kept between 5oC  (41oF) and 50oC  122oF ("the danger zone".)  The total time that food stays in this range must not exceed 4 hours.  In general most sous vide dishes are cooked above 130oF, and above 122oF most pathogens will die off.  Just make sure your food is well chilled and goes straight from the fridge to the sous vide.  After cooking, if you aren't serving food just chill the food in an ice bath and get it in the fridge or freezer ASAP.  Also if you use the freshest ingredients possible and sear to finish off food you should be pretty well covered.THE FOOD EXPERIMENTS:1) 24 hour pork shoulder @  149oF.  Seasoned with pepper and wrapped in 2 strips of bacon.  By then, the bacon had almost entirely disintegrated leaving behind one chunk of delicious moist meat that promptly disappeared within moments of being served.  My faux ziploc bags leaked and got waterlogged so I'm looking forward to a repeat for 48 hours and with proper vacuum sealed bags.2) 1 hour poached eggs @ 145oF.  I'd never made poached eggs in my life, but all the pictures of eggs in the quick reference guide convinced me to give it a shot.  I poached them in their shells for 1 hour, and then cracked them straight onto salad for absolute deliciousness.  The only thing I'd say is you want to serve them pretty quickly because the eggs already felt a bit cold between the time we cracked the eggs and when we all sat down to eat.3) 72 hour short rib @ 133oF , 3 styles.  Here's where you absolutely need a proper vacuum sealer.  My cheapo generic brand zip bags broke within 2 hours resulting in a boiled watery mess.  Ziploc brand bags lasted the full 3 days but one of them still got waterlogged.  And after waiting 3 days for meat you don't want any hiccups!  It's painful, trust me!!  The results when everything works are where it's AT.  It's also where you can mess things up.  I did one batch plain, one with a Korean Galbi marinade and one with a red wine marinade.  Given that the sous vide is doing the tenderizing for you, you do NOT want to use marinades that tenderize.  It changes the flavor of the meat to mush and gives weird not exactly tasty results.  Likewise don't salt too much as you end up curing the meat.  If you use a marinade, try to avoid acid or alcohol (or boil it off) and make sure you allow time for your marinade to penetrate before cooking because your food will actually cook before the flavor of the marinade has time to penetrate the meat.4) 30 minute butter poached lobster at 143oF.  I got lobster tails, soaked them for 3 minutes in almost boiling water to get the shells off, chilled the lobster tails in the fridge again before combining lobster w/ butter.  Pure glutton heaven.FINISHING:Having tried blow torching and pan searing, I think I preferred the taste of pan searing better but will continue to experiment.  I used the Iwatani blowtorch.BAGS:I was so excited to use the sous vide that I didn't want to wait to buy a chamber vacuum sealer.  After using zip top bags for a week I'd say you definitely want to use a vacuum sealer if you can.  I'll be ordering a VacMaster VP112 Portable Chamber Vacuum Sealer but friends have used a FoodSaver without problems.  I'll report on using it when I do.  I know there have been some problems with the lid cracking, but at the same time upgrading to the next size means a much larger footprint.  Word of advice if you do use zip tops: NO GENERIC!  They are just too flimsy and break too easily.RANDOM COUNTERTOP INCIDENT:The first night I used the sous vide, I put it on a granite countertop.  Within hours, we discovered a crack under the counter.  According to the repair professional, granite is rated to withstand heat up to 900oF and I was cooking something at 149oF, so it shouldn't have been an issue, however I learned that granite counters often have imperfections that are filled with epoxy and this sealant CAN wear down at much lower temperatures.  While no direct cause-effect could be determined with absolute certainty, I would still say to be safe, don't put your container directly on the counter, and at least lay down a towel.  The sous vide was warm enough to actually transfer heat to the whole slab of counter.BOTTOM LINE:Since my purchase, I discovered a slew of Kickstarter sous vide machines that cost far less than this unit.  While I'm completely happy with this unit and feel like it was still worth the price I paid, were I to be on the market today I'd seriously consider a Sansaire or Anova for~$199 instead of ~$799.  Since I have what I have,  I don't regret it, and am looking forward to more sous vide action once my vacuum chamber sealer arrives!  This is definitely a must-have tool for the home kitchen!----------Update 9/4/2015 : Well I've had this machine for a few years now and it's been used continuously so I know that this machine can survive the long haul!  I even have super hard water and the poor thing has to go through getting descaled regularly.  I'm finding that my foods perform best with just a dry rub or salt and pepper.  I haven't been happy with how most of the marinades recipes have turned out as marinades seem to turn my meat to mush.  I DID buy a VacMaster VP112S to seal my bags and I much prefer it over zip loc bags.  When you buy the 250 pack bags it comes out cheaper than ziploc!  The VacMaster is quite clunky but I just keep it in the garage and it hasn't gotten in my way.  I also bought an Anova as a backup / 2nd sous vide machine but still end up using this as my main machine.About few months ago, I thought I had a calibration problem and contacted PolyScience.  I was surprised to receive a VERY detailed response from a chef at PolyScience Culinary and not just a customer service rep.  As he explained, calibration problems are very unlikely because :==========Our SVP unit features a platinum PT1000 probe that has been checked against a traceable thermometer that is calibrated against a government standard. It is possible, but highly unlikely that it's calibration is off, as every sinlge unit is tested for accuracy and stability before being air dried and packaged before leaving our facility in Niles IL.There are many great thermometers available, but they aren't as fast as the PT 1000 in the SVP. Typically, discrepancies are common and we highly DO NOT recommend offsetting the circulator based upon even a thermocouple reading. The way that the probe in the SVP works is quite different.To expand upon this topic:From Philip Preston: "Most thermocouple type thermometers are not as fast and have inherent inaccuracies of  0.7 degrees. This and the location of their thermometer compared to the location of the probe on the SVPro can influence discrepancies between the two references.There are several factors at play here. First would be the thermal response time of differentprobes. We use a platinum (PT-1000) sensor and most kitchen thermometers use athermocouple. Thermocouples are fine and they are very fast, but they have an inherent absolute accuracy of plus or minus 2.0C. We need high accuracy and linearity. The sensor location is another factor. Even though there is circulation, our control sensor is in a close relationship to the heating element. When the heater is full on we will see a slight offset as compared to the reservoir as a whole."From Thermoworks: Our proprietary circuit yields accuracies better than 0.7F. Thermocouples are fast but not suitable for accurate control. Even though it has been calibrated at ice point it is not linear and therefore lacks accuracy at cooking temperatures. I would never calibrate (offset) the Sous Vide Professional using a thermocouple. We test and calibrate using a Hart data logging reference thermometerhttp://www.hartscientific.com/products/1529.htmand the SVP has faster response than the reference.Recovery time is also a complex issue. In a PID control system the integrator "I" term must move slower than the largest anticipated thermal mass of the system being controlled. On our more accurate systems where we achieve plus or minus 0.004C stability the recovery time is very slow. There is plenty of good reading on the internet on velocity based PID control systems.===========So I guess while there are a bunch of lower cost alternatives out there, this is still likely a more precise and industrial machine.

I recently took several chocolate making classes from Chef Marco Ropke, head pastry chef at the Beijing Ritz Carlton during the 2008 Olympics, and in class, he basically suggested that if we were to buy any one chocolate book, THIS book was it.Why?  It's a comprehensive 4 in 1 book:1) The science behind chocolate, sugarwork and the various components.  Why might you want to include glucose in your chocolate and not just any sugar syrup?  What is the difference between using agar-agar, gelatin, pectin and cornstarch in making gummies and jellies?  This type of information helped me better understand why some of the steps to chocolate making mattered, and also gave me more comfort in knowing where I could deviate from recipes (e.g. I can add whatever liquid flavourings I want so long as I add them at the right time and keep my fats to liquid ratio consistent).2) Techniques - how do you temper chocolate?  how do you make aero-bar style chocolates?  what's the proper way to handle ganaches or molded chocolates?  how do you make a praline or marzipan?  what's the secret to those meltaway type chocolates?  what about the honeycomb material inside crunchie bars?3) Troubleshooting - invariably a chocolate recipe will go wrong.  how do you save a ganache that's been separated?  why did your pates de fruit sweat and what can you do about it?4) LOADS of really delicious recipes from chai tigers to a thai lemongrass truffle or toucan passionfruit chocolate to marshmallows, nougats, chocolate bars, candy crisps, caramels, fudges and more.  I made several recipes (scaled down since the recipes are for ~180 truffles each!) from the book and they have all been hits.  I have ordered more chocolate and I can't wait to try more.The book also included suggested equipment and a brief explanation of some of the tools and why they were important.The one thing missing from the book that I wish they spent time on was decorating in general -- the different techniques for finishing chocolates such as adding chocolate swirls, etc.  To be fair each recipe has a description for how to finish the chocolate such as adding bits of salt or adding candied fruit bits and they did show you how to make spiked chocolates, but I wanted to know more about selecting colours and other types of chocolate flourishes.In all it's a pricey, but valuable book that I anticipate I will be referencing a lot as I continue to learn and make chocolates.

These are great value.  I got these for my iPad and Kindle Fire 8.9", and both fit great in the bigger pouch.  I like that there's a second external pouch that I use to stuff the cables in.  In case you were curious, the smaller outside pouch actually also fits a Kindle Fire (the older smaller version).  So it's great stuff for like $7.  The only weird thing about the pouch is that on the inside, there is a mini sleeve to hold your device on one side, but the corner elastics to hold it in place are on the opposite side.  I don't know if that's a stitching defect?  Now I only wish there were even more colour variants available. :)

I'll admit I never used to see much value in a mouse pad.And then I bought one of those glossy Ikea tables and my mouse stopped working because the surface was too reflective.At first I went with the duct-tape-to-the-table approach, but decided eventually it was time to class things up and along with that came to the conclusion that buying a real mousepad would achieve that goal.The whole reason I didn't like most mousepads was that the raised surface just usually got in my way, and my piles of paper were already getting enough in my way.  But then I found out about mousepad skins, and eventually narrowed my search down to Razers skins and the 3M mousing surface.  What gave Razer the edge is that I already own a Razer mouse, and I figured the Razer team would design things so their own products would play nice together.  I also liked that Razer surfaces came in larger sizes.Having now my Razer Sphex mousepad-skin for a few months now, I'm really pleased with the decision.  The surface is very thin so papers don't snag, and it's a good size so that my sloppily pointed mouse still finds traction on the mousepad surface.  The edges haven't come off or frayed at all and I've repositioned the skin a couples times.  I like how my mouse feels when it glides over the slightly rough surface, and I definitely have a lot more precision with the mouse-mousepad than I expected, which is great since I do a lot of photo retouching and graphics work as a hobby.  In retrospect I might have gone for the even larger surface, but the nice thing about this size is that you can still stick it on a laptop and take it with you places.

I've owned a set of ALTEC LANSING PRO SLS6221 FLAT PANEL POWERED SPEAKER SYSTEM WITH SUBWOOFER for years.  I love them - they've survived 8 moves across 2 countries and 7 years and are still going. Well worth the $300 I paid.  I have warm fuzzing feelings looking at them right now.I decided I wanted a 2nd pair of speakers, and given that my speakers are now 7 years old, supposed it was best to get a newer model, on the assumption that speaker technology had advanced some in the interim.So I ordered GOgroove BassPULSE Hi-Fidelity 2.1 Speaker Sound System with Subwoofer for PC , Mac , MP3 , iPod , Tablets and Home-Theater for $60.  They lasted about 10 minutes out of the box before they were packed back up and returned.  They sounded like $60 speakers, were a bit tinny and had flimsy cords to boot.  Note to self, speaker advancement doesn't happen like computers.After more research, I decided on the Harmon Kardon Soundsticks.  I didn't consider them at first because I thought the speakers were weird looking, but they've definitely grown on me a lot.  I like that everything is solidly constructed and the cables are thick braids in clear plastic.  I also love that the Satellite stands are adjustable so you can angle them as you see fit.And then there's sound.  They sound great!  Able to fill up a room the size of a 2 car garage nicely.  They're great value for the price and I'd definitely choose these again.

If you are looking for a functional, inexpensive laptop sleeve, this one will do the job -- provided it fits.  It's cheap, I like the retractable handle, and the bottom corners of the laptop are reinforced with a slightly thicker canvas material. (Two corners on the shorter edge if you are placing the laptop in a backpack)I have a 15.6 inch Acer and unfortunately that computer doesn't fit inside the sleeve without the zipper scratching the case.  I was also disappointed that the trim is a different shade of blue than pictured. (Instead of like an Azure blue, it comes across more like a Persian blue - not bad, but not what I expected from the picture).At the end of the day, I would have kept this sleeve if it was slightly bigger, but given the fit issues I'll be returning the item.

Ordered these shoes for my friend right before a big hiking trip to the French Alps.  Given that they arrived the day before our trip, there was no time for him to break them in.We needn't worry, as the shoes fit comfortably right from the start.  He got no blisters, told me they felt sturdy, yet lightweight enough to still run and jump around like a ninja. Shoe name is "scree shield"?
