Having relied on Cooks Illustrated recommendations for many of my favourite kitchen tools, buying this book was a no brainer.  Needless to say I had high expectations going in, and this book did not disappoint.I'm an avid cook, and while I've had great success with certain types of food, I've been frustrated by inconsistent results in others.  (I can't seem to get a consistently moist pot-roast -- reason: my cooking temperature was probably too high; wrong cut of meat + oven braising is better than stovetop since it heats more evenly in more directions)The Science of Good Cooking breaks down why food cooks a certain way, and which techniques are best for what purpose.  The book is organized into 50 concepts with recipes reinforcing each concept.  There's a section called "why this works" following each recipe, which breaks down the science behind each step -- for instance why use a certain type of marinade, cooking technique, take extra steps, etc to achieve a desired outcome.  It's nice that it's not just a list of recipes.Experiments back each concept.  Meats were weighed, measured, smashed to determine tenderness, and moisture loss.  They came up with a range of ideal resting times for various meats based on actually measuring the amount of juices lost at various times, and they sent food to the science lab to analyze their structure.  They even stuck bones on mashed potatoes to test out whether keeping bones on makes food taste better.  This book debunked some assumptions I had (acid does not actually make food more tender), and helped me understand other ones better - why salt directly applied on skin makes it more crispy, but if you brined the skin you'd get a different outcome.  I also learned that the direction you cut your onion affects its taste - obvious in retrospect, but I never thought about that!I was disappointed I couldn't see a table of contents before purchase, so here are the 50 concepts you will find within the book -1.  Gentle Heat Prevents Overcooking2.  High Heat Develops Flavor3.  Resting Meat Maximizes Juiciness4.  Hot Food Keeps Cooking5.  Some Proteins Are Best Cooked Twice6.  Slow Heating Makes Meat Tender7.  Cook Tough Cuts Beyond Well Done8.  Tough Cuts Like a Covered Pot9.  A Covered Pot Doesn't Need Liquid10. Bones Add Flavor, Fat, and Juiciness11. Brining Maximizes Juiciness in Lean Meats12. Salt Makes Meat Juicy and Skin Crisp13. Salty Marinades work best14. Grind Meat at Home for Tender Burgers15. A Panade Keeps Ground Meat Tender16. Create Layers for a Breading That Sticks17. Good Frying is All About Oil Temperature18. Fat Makes Eggs Tender19. Gentle Heat Guarantees Smooth Custards20. Starch Keeps Eggs from Curdling21. Whipped Egg Whites Need Stabilizers22. Starch Helps Cheese Melt Nicely23. Salting Vegetables Removes Liquid24. Green Vegetables Like it Hot -- Then Cold25. All Potatoes Are Not Created Equal26. Potato Starches Can Be Controlled27. Precooking Makes Vegetables Firmer28. Don't Soak Beans -- Brine 'Em29. Baking Soda Makes Beans and Grains Soft30. Rinsing (Not Soaking) Makes Rice Fluffy31. Slicing Changes Garlic and Onion Flavor32. Chile Heat Resides in Pith and Seeds33. Bloom Spices to Boost Their Flavor34. Not All Herbs Are for Cooking35. Glutamates, Nucleotides Add Meaty Flavor36. Emulsifiers Make Smooth Sauces37. Speed Evaporation When Cooking Wine38. More Water Makes Chewier Bread39. Rest Dough to Trim Kneading Time40. Time Builds Flavor in Bread41. Gentle Folding Stops Tough Quick Breads42. Two Leaveners Are Often Better Than One43. Layers of Butter Makes Flaky Pastry44. Vodka Makes Pie Dough Easy45. Less Protein Makes Tender Cakes, Cookies46. Creaming Butter Helps Cakes Rise47. Reverse Cream for Delicate Cakes48. Sugar Changes Texture (and Sweetness)49. Sugar and Time Makes Fruit Juicer50. Cocoa Powder Delivers Big FlavorThe only thing I would have loved was a trouble shooting / Q&A section - e.g. How do you keep meat from cooling too much when you rest it?Overall a great book if you want to improve your cooking technique, and also if you just want to learn more about why things behave the way they do!Update: Looks like "Look inside" is now available for this book so there's finally a table of contents! :)  Since I've been cooking with the new concepts in mind, I'm happy with how my meat dishes (especially the stews) are turning out.  I also tried using vodka instead of water to make pie crust (with the tip of putting a heated pan under the pie pan) and the pie crust turned out flaky and delicious as promised.

I got this for a friend who has trouble getting up.Seemed like a pretty cool concept!Unfortunately the product feels pretty flimsy, is made of fairly poor quality material and broke within a few weeks of purchase.So ok as a novelty gag gift but not practical at all for any real use as an alarm clock.Alarm clock: 0Sleep: 1

Of all the chores in the world, laundry was, I mean IS, my least favourite thing to do in the world.And worst of all is taking care of washing delicates.  I used to handwash those.  Ulgh!  I still shudder at the thought.Then I discovered these wash bags, which allows you to just toss your delicate shirts into the wash.  OMG brilliant!I'd previously bought Honey-Can-Do LBG-01148 3-Piece Mesh Wash Bag Set, White but what I like about the LBD-01145 version is that the cloth is much thicker and feels more durable.  Instead of a drawstring, you've got a covered zipper.  The drawstring cord would catch onto stuff and the thin bag got fuzzy over time, whereas this doesn't snag into anything.  Each bag fits one shirt / thin sweater or a couple bras.I still hate laundry, but at least this makes it slightly less intolerable!Now will someone please invent something that just does all the laundry for me too??!!

The attached photo shows that this torch fits easily onto any standard size asian hotpot tank.This is my third blow torch, and thankfully, it's also the end of my search.  I've had it for 3 years now and it still works great.I first tried one of those torches that come with creme brulee kits.  Those suck.  They have weak flames, meaning it takes so long to get the job done that you'd better have 2nd dinner planned because your guests will be hungry again by the time you finish with your first pot of creme.  They are also a pain because you need to buy specialized canisters to refill the torch.I then went to the hardware store and got a soldering torch.  It was definitely far more powerful, but 1) I thought I was going to torch the whole kitchen, the flame was so large, and 2) the model I got didn't seem to handle being tipped very well and would go out.  The canisters were also way big and heavy.  I felt like I was holding a mini fire extinguisher, which knowing me I probably *should* have had on hand.Then, I found this torch.And I tell you, I'm in torching bliss.I love that it's powerful enough to brulee things quickly and evenly.  The flame is adjustable so you can have a wide, even flame or a tight targeted one.  Most of the time I just leave mine on a wide flame, which works best for creme brulee to have that even finish.  It also seared my prime rib roast nicely (I cooked my roast low and slow and wanted to finish the roast with an even crust.)  The browning of the gristle smelled so good I'm getting hungry thinking about that roast and I'm writing this review in the AM.  I've used it to finish a lot of my sous vide dishes and it's consistently worked great.The unit is compact (it comes with just the top), but it fits on top of any of the standard butane canisters you'd find at Asian grocery stores.  Just ask for the canisters for hotpot.  It means refills are cheap and relatively easy to find.  I hate the other type of blowtorch where you have to refill it into a little compartment in a handle.  Those were such a hassle.One thing is that the tip of the torch changes to a copper colour with use, which my previous torches didn't  But hey it doesn't hinder performance so who cares.  It looks well used as a result and you get more cred for being a hard core torcher.Can't wait to use this to sear the top of some pressed sushi as well.Yum!

I was interested in learning Spanish and finally took lessons.  This book was recommended by my Spanish teacher and I can see why.There are 15 short stories in total organized under:- Scary Stories- Tricksters- Strong Women- MythsThe stories start with english, followed by the spanish version.  I like that the stories are bite-sized, meaning I can read both versions in one go pretty easily.Like another reviewer said, I do wish that they put english on one side, spanish on the other so I could go back and forth a little more easily.  I found I kept flipping between the two language versions, but the stories themselves were engaging, quick, and offered good insight into spanish folklore.Overall reading the book helped with my reading comprehension, and was a good supplement to learning basic vocabulary by memorizing words.  Even better would be an audio version to go alongside :)

I first discovered these giant bags because my friend used to work at SC Johnson, and he showed up one day and gave me some.They turned out so handy I've since bought more.  Who says sampling isn't effective? :)The 4 count one is a good size to store thin blankets, large winter coats, bed sheets and things like that.  I've been moving a lot so I like them because they don't take up as much room as plastic bins, and the items stay well protected.  I've read online of people using these bags to marinate large cuts of meat as well.  Since I have a tiny fridge, I won't be trying that anytime soon but if I get to hosting parties again, why not?The bags feel very sturdy, but I wish the handles were slightly reinforced.  They can stretch a bit if the contents get heavy.  Overall the bags are the same thickness as heavy duty garbage bags.Get the 3 bag pack if you want to hold larger items like comforters.

With the Olympics coming up again, what better thing to do than to read a pop-sci book on super-achievers written by a former Olympian?  And this former Olympian gives you insight on his journey to that level.I thoroughly enjoyed the book.  Let's start with that.My biggest gripe though is, aside from learning about the author's background and his personal relevance to this subject, I didn't learn too much new.Perhaps it's because this book tends to be a bit too enthusiastic in referencing other books, and also in citing really famous experiments (Polger sisters) to showcase how what seems like raw talent is actually a whole lot of painstaking dedication to practice.  Not just any kind of practice --deliberate, smart practice that challenges your boundaries.Malcolm Gladwell's Outliers is where I first learned about the 10,000 rule for excellence.  And the author clearly read the same book as it's cited a number of times.  I wish there was fresh or new insight, or more obscure studies, as I'd heard of most examples he used, BUT I still give this book 4 stars because if it's your first book on the subject, it's a really well organized and an informative journey on how superstars are built, and how you can grow and be great in something you care about  I appreciated the refreshers, and reading the book gave me the motivation to go back and improve.  It was also an easy, well-written read.And a book that spurs action has got to be worth at least 4 stars. :)

Being that I love my caipirinhas and mojitos, a good muddler is a must.And this muddler makes marvelous mojitos.The handle at the top is comfortable to hold, while the plastic toothed bottom grips and bruises mint leaves easily.  I used to just mash the heck out of my mint and limes by grinding down at the glass mercilessly, but I finally learned that pushing down and twisting in continuous quarter-turn motions yields better flavour with less effort.I've also owned a wooden muddler, but those are usually too short and the wood got icky, where as this is long enough that I can use it with beer glasses or a shaker and it rinses off quickly.Me gusta this muddler!

I must love Cuisinart Food Processors because this is my 3rd purchase in 10 years.  It's not that they break, I just keep giving them away to people.  I guess it's all about sharing and caring? :)I picked out this model because I wanted a sturdy, high-powered food processor that looked good on the counter.And of all the models I've owned so far, this is the best looking model.  The die-cast material is way nicer looking than the brushed stainless.But it comes with a tradeoff:  the die-cast is heavy, so don't plan on moving it around too much.  Unless you happen to need an arm workout.  And you've just blown your month's budget buying stuff like this instead of weights. (Guilty!)This unit is also tall!  The base is much taller than DLC prep, meaning the unit won't fit under my cabinet.In terms of power, I honestly don't notice a difference between it and my old model.  I don't think the cheaper models had problems chopping up products anyway.  I'm sure it IS more powerful.  That said, this model has the same limitations as others - I tried grinding down peppercorns but a spice grinder is still needed for things like that - even with the smaller bowl.Interesting for me is that the lid-locking mechanism no longer twists to lock / unlock.  It hinges on/off.  I don't know that one is better.  There is rubber lining inside the container now too -- PLUS is that it gives a better seal; MINUS in that it's a little more work to get the guck out of that.One thing I really like about this model is the container that comes with the box for holding the different blade disks and attachments.  The other model only held the attachments, so finally I have a good way to store all those components.  The box is also feels way sturdier, but it still will crack if you drop it from the counter -- which I learned.  Doh!Overall though, this is a good solid good looking workhorse.  I'm glad I have this model.  I don't see needing a replacement unless I end up giving this one away again.

So I received this book as a birthday present.The person who gave it to me rationalized that the book might be able to accomplish what he failed to do -- persuade me to get out and get running.You see, I'm don't run.  I'll hike to any destination, but run?  Forgetaboutit.Yet the book was able to convey the spirit and passion of extreme runners - ultra marathoners who run for days at a time in such a way that I didn't read about these runners' stories and think "they're nuts".  I started rooting for them.I enjoyed the base story - that of the author seeking answers to his running pain problem and that of the main protagonist's quest to create the ultimate race among running greats.But what I enjoyed more were the forays into our ancestral history - hypotheses for why we were made for running, nutritional facts on superfoods like chia seeds, and the history of Nike and its impact on the sport of running.I enjoyed how everything wove into a cohesive and riveting tale.  I read through the book in a day, and at the end of it, found the book both touching and thought provoking.As for getting me to run?  Well it didn't motivate me any better on the treadmill the next day, but I'm certainly willing to get out and try trail running again and I'm definitely interested in seeing how I can improve my running form --Maybe tomorrow.:p

There are so many miracle health products out there it's hard to know what's for real.  But enough people have said good things about these seeds that I decided to jump on the chia seed bandwagon and order up a bag.***Health Benefits***- extremely high concentration of omega-3 acids (more than salmon)- complete protein!  What does that mean?  I had to look it up too. :)  It means chia seeds contain all the essential amino acids your body needs.  So you could just eat nothing but chia seeds and survive.  Most veggies don't have that, meaning you need to mix and match various plant sources to get everything all the things your body can't synthesize on its own. 1 serving (10g / 1 tbsp) = 2g protein -- higher than most other grains and seeds.  Other plant sources with complete protein = quinoa, soybean, buckwheat & hempseed- good source of fibre & potassium & calcium- 3x the iron than spinach- low in cholesterol & sodium- doesn't have drawbacks like flaxseed does with being a laxative and doesn't have estrogen-like effects***Uses & Taste***Chia seeds taste pretty good!  Rather, there's no strong taste the way sesame does, so you just have more of a crunchy texture if you eat them dry, or a thicker jelly-like texture if you soak them in water for a little bit.Ideas for use: In a salad, added to smoothies, in a breakfast granola or yogurt, in oatmeal, used as an egg replacement in baked goods, on sushi, to make iskiate (chia fresca) -- a Tarahumara energy drink, or just straight up have a spoonful.  I recently made pancakes and threw in a few tablespoons and it worked out great.One thing to note is these seeds can stick in your teeth, so be sure to do a quick mirror check after eating them. :)***This brand***I haven't bought any other brand of chia seeds, but this one works so why switch?  Seeds tasted fresh when I opened the package and stayed fresh during the 2 months it took me to go through my bag.  Bag is resealable, price on Amazon was better than in stores = a good buy.Overall I'm feeling pretty good about eating chia seeds instead of cupcakes although that has me thinking...next kitchen experiment - lemon chia cupcakes!  Bye bye poppy seeds!

I believe in alternatives as well as faith healing, but I have a lot of doubts about the true source of this book being God's number two man, named Compassion.Facing multiple serious health issues, I was wildly excited to get a copy of Medical Medium. I knew the publisher and author had been promoting it very heavily. Then I read it. Almost everything in the book is said to stem from a variation of the Epstein-Barr Virus (the one that causes mononucleosis).  It supposedly hides away for years, and attacks in ways unknown to medical science. Most are mystery illnesses, a lot that are difficult to diagnose and often mis-diagnosed. If you suffer from chronic fatigue, or fibromyalgia, etc, you are so sick of not being taken seriously by your Dr. And friends, that you are grateful as heck to have someone tell you your disease is real, and gives you hope that you can get better. That is what is good about this book, the dietary recommendations will certainly improve most people's health.Here is why I am deeply skeptical:1. Serious illnesses that usually carry a death sentence are not addressed at all, like cancer. Does God not want us to know the 'true' causes of cancer and heal from it? Really? None of his clients had cancer?2. To get a consultation, you must fill out a form, staring why you want a consultation. These cost $500 for a half hour, not to worry, major credit cards accepted. I.e., $1000 per HOUR.  He doesn't have time to get to everyone, so applicants are selected by 'lottery'. Or is it really that the ones who likely have the conditions in the book he claims are caused by EBV get in? The huge amount of money charged to people who are already desperate, who have already likely gone deep into debt with medical expenses and lack of work, makes me doubt that he is charging the rated God approved of.3. The online book push from Hay house was huge. You were given little chapter summaries and access to his Facebook page as gifts for pre-ordering the book. The day the book arrived in stores, you were given an offer of even better gifts, supposedly worth about $1500, if you buy another copy for a friend if you had already bought the book. I even did that for a friend with MS, before my Amazon copy arrived. The free gifts, an audio summary of the chapters, and the top 12 radio shows, which seem to track pretty exactly the content of the book. So no wonder the book is instantly on the best sellers list.4. Every cure is related to diet, mostly a vegan diet, with some supplements. Quantities of supplements are not given, 'spirit' must not know a good general average, we are told to seek the advice of a naturopath. Problem is, the conventional and alternative doctors don't know that any of this really helps, since God only made it known to Anthony it seems. The diets are likely very helpful though, since anyone with very poor health has discovered, the most healing diets in the world recommend very similar ones. You must stay on the diet sometimes for two years, I wonder how many millions more books will be sold before you decide it it worked? If it didn't work, is it because you have not eaten enough wild blueberries, or slipped back in November and had a cookie? My point is, diets of any kind are always difficult to follow, and the patient is always blamed when they do not!5. Who can question the Spirit, number two to God, who talks only to Anthony and nobody else on earth? For the Spirits information is 20-40 years ahead of medical science. By the time it is proven or disproven, Anthony and Spirit will be worth more than Bill Gates, and laughing their butts off on some nice beach.  If Spirit, who is named "Compassion", HAD compassion wouldn't he teach as least one person in every city how to heal, as Jesus did, immediately? And then tell people to clean up their diet? After all, Jesus taught his disciples to heal everyone who asked, and he told them to do it FREELY as their gifts were given freely. He also said that everything He did, we could do and MORE. Now I know everyone must make a living, pay for a home, a car, a staff to handle the emails, credit card charges, etc. and I don't object to that, I object to this all being very general, slow-working dietary recommendations that are available if you are a student of alternative diets, as I have been for the last several years. It makes sense of course that God should charge more per hour than anyone on earth that I know of. I am so happy God takes Visa!6. Having battled poor health for most of my life and been given the 'death sentence' of metastasized cancer, I have spent a huge amount of time and money exploring every option out there. As a result, I know that sadly, on both the conventional and alternative sides of the equation, many people out there are just trying to make money, a lot of money, on people who are desperate to feel better.7. Hearing what Anthony said on his radio show one to a caller, that wheat was not a problem, that people are not really allergic to it, because many people eat it with no problem, left me to wonder why God is so ignorant of the huge number of hybrid varieties of wheat that have been created by man. We don't eat ancient, natural wheat anymore, we eat a highly hybrid variety that bears little resemblance to the plant God created. I see though in the section on foods not to eat, that he lists gluten.The part about ADHD and Autism says that metal toxicity is the cause, but says most of this is passed on by the parents. Spirit make no mention about the toxic metals in vaccines apparently. Spirit would not want Anthony to wade into too much controversy I suppose!8. Why are there so many 5 star reviews? Because an email was sent out to everyone on his Facebook page, which he got pretty much everyone who ordered the book to sign up for, it was a free gift after all, implying that if you gave a 5 star review, you might win a grand prize that included 6 autographed copies of the book, some other things, and best of all TWO coveted free consultations. And shame on me, I was even tempted to give it 5 stars just because I would really like to hear what he said! But I suspect I already know....a version of the EBV so eat your wild blueberries and drink your celery juice!9. Why is it forbidden to record your client sessions you pay so much for? It seems like he does not want you to be able to re-hear it.Why did I give this 3 stars? Because the book does bring hope, and pretty good dietary recommendations that should improve your health. I would love to believe he is not just making this all up, and I could be wrong! I think only if you have told him nothing about your health, and he really gets all your issues accurately on a diagnostic call, could you truly believe. I am extremely spiritual, and believe very much in alternatives as well as faith healing, but I have a lot of doubts.

I have several books on Urban sketching, and sketchbooks in general. Most have examples of beautiful pages of the authors sketchbook, but really very little in the way of how to improve your drawing and painting skills so that you can do it too. But this book has such clear, beautifully formatted (uncluttered) examples of how to draw and paint, that it makes me feel that I can someday do beautiful sketchbooks too! The author has worked for Disney, I wonder if he took their Drawn From Life classes, because his teaching is certainly excellent. Very nice step by step examples. The aim of the book is to teach you, not to just show you page after page of the authors beautiful sketches as other books do.

This book is a work of art, but I found it to be discouraging for me. The author says that two types of people are drawn to urban sketching; architects and fine artists. I am certainly in neither camp, but hoped for solid techniques for how anyone could begin to capture the scenes around them quickly and accurately. There are some techniques in here, but honestly each page is so packed with so many super detailed and brilliantly colored sketches that I totally missed the techniques the first pass through. I do love the book, it is a stunning example of what is possible! But for technique I like the other book I ordered at the same time much better, The Urban Sketcher by Holmes. He has very clear step by step examples that you can easily follow.

I ordered these because I would like to start using pastels again, and do not want the possibly toxic chemicals in them to be in contact with my skin. They work great, and hey, they fit like a glove! The Book of Common Prayer portion is great, but the Bible part has Incredibly tiny print, very difficult for me to read with reading glasses. Note that this is a very small book. I have the BOCP with the Hymnal, which is much larger L x W, and years ago saw the same size BOCP with RSV Bible, with very readable print. My mistake not to note the small size of this, but there are other issues I have with it. First, I spent a lot of extra money to get the genuine leather, but it feels like bonded leather. It is not soft. Then there are small beads of dried glue coming out along the cover binding. I was hoping for a nice feeling, readable Bible AND prayer book, and sadly this is not it.

This Bible is titled 'study Bible', but there are not any study notes that explain the text,  such as the in- depth ones in the excellent HCSB Study Bible. Instead, the entire Bible is devoted to Princilpes to Live By, as written by Gene Getz. Scriptures are highlighted in rather dark blue, that Getz thinks applies to these principles. Then there are text inserts that discuss briefly the principles, and have a QR reader block to scan if you want to hear him talking about it on a you tube video.  That is the main feature of this Bible, and if you would rather listen to sermons than read, you will likely really love this Bible. I tend to prefer to read in a quiet room, but the sermons I listened to were good.There are a few maps in the very back, but the text is all in black and blue. The light blue text is not that easy to see. When a text dialog of a principle is on the page, the text continues above the box from volume A to B, instead of continuing to read A all the way down the page as you do the other pages. This is a bit confusing for the shorter dialog boxes. There are no pictures, or drawings, for example of the temple, that make the HCSB Study bible so excellent. The HCSB text is my favorite to read out of all the translations, since it translates cubits into feet, which makes it so much easier to understand. However, the large amount of deep blue highlighting detracts from the readability of the text, it would have been much nicer in a lighter shade of blue. I like to highlight my own verses, but will have to do that in a different version.The cover I ordered was green and brown, and other Bibles have basically the same cover on the front and back. This one has the nice green and brown on front, but just plain brown on back. The index version is nice, the OT books are in black and the NT books in red. The index cut outs are more of a rectangular shape than the usual round.This is an excellent Bible if you intend to use the QR scanner to listen to the lectures and want to learn the Principles. However, there are more comprehensive study Bibles if you don't plan to use the interactive features.

This is a cute book to read at Christmas. It contains three stories about fumbling angles trying to answer prayers just in time for Christmas. The angles seemingly are not supposed to interfere, but how they are supposed to help without doing anything was always a mystery to me. All three stories are well written, with good characters, however, I had already read all three of them published in different books in years past. It was still fun to reread them, and I will pass it along to friends to enjoy.

A remarkable, 5 star translation! Thank God for this clarifying work, that translates Hell as the burning garbage dump near Jerusalem. I love reading this, and hope she will translate the OT as well.  My only issue is the terrible formatting. I wish the publishers had studied other study bibles and made this similar, so readers could easily find chapters and verses.

Have to admit I got my copy at Family Christian, so I got the correct version! I am a Bible-aholic. I have a lot....and I love the Holman study bibles very much, they are my favorite. They are all beautifully formatted, colorful, and have gorgeous photos and maps that are very helpful! I got this one because the turquoise cover is just gorgeous, even though I thought I liked to read the HCSV more than the NKJV. However, I find that I love reading the NKJV very much, and this Bible in particular. I grew up reading the KJV, which is too difficult to read for easy understanding, but this has a bit of that language, while being easy and beautiful to read. I only wish the verse on the cover was different, instead of being about women who fear the Lord, something about mothers and love!

Beautiful formatting, great study notes and aids, nice binding and cover. I really like the extras, like having all of Jesus miracles listed. There is a list of Prayers of the Bible too, and many other features. A note even tells you that The word for Hell was a reference to the garbage dump in Jerusalem. The pictures and maps are really nice, and the book introductions are terrific!

This novel is astonishing, brilliant, unforgettable. The central storythe effect on Daniel and Susan Isaacson of the arrest, trial, and execution of their parents, Paul and Rochelle--- is sorrowful. However, it is not the only story. There is the story of the adult Daniel, abusive husband and 60s leftist, a man so divided and often so cruel that one cant rely on what he says, even though it is his book. There is the story of 40s radicalism as it is represented in the lives of the Isaacson parents (modeled in part on Ethel and Julius Rosenberg). The purity and innocence of their worldview is juxtaposed with the student activism of the 60s, in which Daniel participates, although with a certain detachment. There is the story of the American legal system in the grip of an anti-Communist hysteria that can make or break the careers of opportunistic prosecutors and judges and, as well of idealistic lawyers like Jake Ascher, who represents the Isaacsons, as well as Robert Lewin, who becomes a father to Daniel and Susan.And thats not the half of it. Every character, and there are many, is drawn with the finest detail: Rochelles mad mother, born in a shtetl; Selig Mindish, who betrays the Isaacsons; the black man who lives in the basement of Daniels house; the aunt who first takes the children in to her dreadful claustrophobic house, and so on. The same is true of the set pieces: the Paul Robeson concert in Peekskill, where patriots violently assault the concert-goers; the childrens flight from the childrens shelter in search of their Bronx home; Disneyland, where Daniel encounters Mindish; and, ultimately, the deaths of Paul and Rochelle in the electric chair.This is not a comfortable book. There is not a single character who is completely sympathetic. However, in its presentation of the intermingling of politics, history, and human character, it is very fine.M. Feldman

Oh those rich blueblood WASP New Yorkers! Writers just cant take their eyes off them. Henry James couldnt, Edith Wharton couldnt, F. Scott Fitzgerald couldnt---and a good thing too. By paying meticulous attention to them, these writers wrote novels that we remember.Too bad Amor Towles did not do the same. Rules of Civility looks away a lot; it is as if Towles sensed that this ground had been covered, and covered well. As a result, his characters are as insubstantial as the smoke that drifts out of their cigarettes. Then what is he looking at, you ask, if hes bored with his stock character WASPs?Atmosphere, lots of it. (If there isnt already a screenplay in the works, Ill eat my hat.) Theres plenty of literary allusion; Katey Kontent, the (unconvincing) working class narrator talks a lot about the books she is reading; the effect is rather like little intermittent book reports to establish her intellectual bona fides. Theres thirties period detail; clothes, martini shakers, restaurant menus, cars, movie stars---to help you get the picture, of course. Unfortunately, some of this period detail isnt quite of the period, like the Appalachian Trail in Maine hiked by Kateys love interest Tinker (b. 1910) when he was a lad. Unfortunately, the AT didnt begin to take shape until the twenties and the Maine stretch wasnt completed until 1937. The book is set in 1938. The cooking detail is off, too, as in that leg of lamb roasting pan that one of the WASPS deglazes with mint jelly and cognac. Lets eat out at the 21 Club, shall we? Theres a fellow who, for unclear reasons, goes off to fight in the Spanish Civil War. When he left, I scribbled in my margin, Will get killed. Sure enough. Finally, theres lots and lots and lots of drinking and there are paper airplanes and yachts and an Adirondack lodge thats really huge and some chauffeurs and door men who seem to be much nicer than their employers.Now that last might have been a story---Depression-era help dishing on the swells (albeit in an imitation of the method of The Help). To her credit, Katey Kontent, in her magazine editorial assistant phase, sets out to get it. We hear about the droves of men who answer her ad and show up eager to tell all, but that plot line disappears into the general dashing about and tying of loose ends at the end.I love period movies. Soon a good screenwriter will take this novel in hand, stripping away the tiresome dialogue, ditching the paper airplanes and the literary allusions, zeroing in on the Evelyn-Tinker-Katey triangle, likely with more explicit sex. The movie will have fabulous sets and even more martinis and, if its good, will make clear that this story is set in, yes, the Depression. That is something that the novel, in its fascination with all things upper class, keeps forgetting.M. Feldman

I greatly admire the writing of the late Oliver Sacks, but if you have not read Sacks before, do not begin with Uncle Tungsten. It is not Sackss best work. His forte is the essay, not the book-length memoir. There is no more moving example of this than his last published essay on, of all things, gefilte fish, published in The New Yorker just a short time before he died.Uncle Tungsten is an uneasy hybrid of memoir and science history. As a boy, Sacks fell in love, in a most precocious way, with chemistry. He was encouraged in this by several family members in a most remarkable family, chief among them his Uncle Dave, the Uncle Tungsten (he owned a light bulb factory) of the title. The family recollections are the most appealing part of the book, but they constitute only about a third of its length. The rest is filled with little accounts of the achievements of the great 19th century men of science, men like Humphrey Davy, John Dalton, Joseph Priestley, and others. As the literary glue between the science parts and the family parts, Sack supplies an account of his discovery of these scientists and his own attempts to replicate their discoveries in his home laboratory. This doesnt work very well, since the writing in the science parts is workmanlike and often simply not very interesting. One begins to think filler, as if some editor had suggested Sacks write a memoir and it turned out that the personal parts didnt quite add up to a book.Oddly, the science parts also lack attribution, although the information must have come from somewhere. There is not even a bibliography.So stick to the essays, whether in the collections, like " The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat, or in periodicals or even the newspaper. Sacks wrote several compelling short pieces for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times about the last year of his life, when he knew he was dying of cancer. This is the sort of writing this gifted man did best.M. Feldman

Purity is big and sprawling, like a Dickens novel. It has plenty of unlikeable characters, like a Dickens novel. It is full of acid observations about the way we live now, like a Dickens novel. And all of the subplots, digressions, and various entanglements come together at the end, with a measure of happiness, just like a Dickens novel. If we lived in different times, it even might lend itself to being published in serial form, as Dickens novels were. (The Andreas Wolf section did appear in The New Yorker this summer.) And of course one of the main characters is a woman named Pip, who turns out to have some Great Expectations.Of course, Purity has some things a Dickens novel does not: some explicit sex; a plot that moves all over the place, from San Francisco to East Berlin to Bolivia and Denver, with stops in Texas, Philly, and New York; big shifts in time, from postwar Berlin to now, when self-designated transparency experts yank back the curtain on murky government doings by dumping data on the Internet. So, unlike a Dickens novel, Purity moves in great swoops of time and place and sometimes its hard to keep it all straight AND catch those sly jokes on the literary establishment, German slang, and etc.  You have to pay attention.Its worth it. (And whoever said that you have to like characters in order to enjoy a book?) Purity is a novel about tyranny and absolutism, about the power of governments and corporations (think Google) and experts (the Sunlight data dumper Andreas Wolf) and even parents who think that they best suited to telling us what is good for us. It is also about secrets and about the difficulties of discovering what is true, whether that is the reality of capitalist prosperity, if you live in communist East Berlin, or the identity of your father, if you are Pip, who keeps on looking when most people would give up. Most people do give up when confronted with a monolithic government or corporation---thats the bleak strain running through the novel.The novel starts slowly (with the unlikable Pip) and its worth a bit of patience until you are 100 pages or so in and the intertwining stories start making you keep the light on at night. If you dont like thinking about this stuff, you can always pick up your device and start texting.M. Feldman

This very interesting account of three Japanese women sent to the United States as children in 1871 in order to acquire a "Western" education makes for compelling reading for at least the first half of the book. Nimura does a competent job in describing the opening of Japan, the Meiji restoration, and the loss of samurai status faced by the families of these girls. In the ten years of their sojourn in the U.S., each girl emerges as a distinctive personality, perhaps because there seems to be a variety of English language sources to draw upon to depict them. Their return to Japan as young women is also quite interesting, since there seems to be quite a bit of information about their difficulties with the Japanese language and with re-acquainting themselves with the culture.After that, the focus of the book is more blurred, since each woman follows a different path; one marries into the highest echelon of Japanese society; one teaches music and focuses on her family; and the youngest remains unmarried and devoted to the education of Japanese women. Nimura tries hard to convey the difficulties and compromises of their lives as adult women, but often the detail that is available to her (I don't know if she was able to use Japanese language sources) is either dry (details of balls and luncheons) or reticent (personal letters). I suppose it sounds odd to say this about a work of history, but one wonders what a novelist, less constrained by absolute fidelity to the historical record, might have made of this story.M. Feldman

There is no book quite like this one, so strange and cruel and gorgeous. The five Bas-Thornton children whose parents send them back to civilization (England) after a hurricane levels their house in Jamaica, could be anyones children. When they are captured by pirates, one feels sympathy for them, but not for long.While they are, in some sense, innocent in terms of their ages and life experience, they harbor emotions and impulses that are the same as those of adults, only more secret and unrecognized---and just as devastating and even murderous.At the center of the novel is the consciousness of Emily, the second oldest Bas-Thornton children, and the only one who, in the course of the novel, matures into a semi-awareness of herself as a separate human being. At times she is a child, turning somersaults, at other times she carries on a creepy flirtation with the pirate captain (although she does not really understand flirtation), and eventually she comes to hold his life, rather casually, in her hands (although she does not really understand her power).These children, and they are meant to stand for all children, have only the most rudimentary understanding of ethics and possess absolutely unreliable memories. One cannot rely on them for anything, as more than one confounded adult discovers. It is fitting that Emilys father, unsuccessful in Jamaica, becomes a drama critic upon his return to London. The illusory lives he sees on the stage are, ironically, more real to him than the lives of his children.I dont quite see the connection to Lord of the Flies. One book that does resemble it in terms of an interest in the consciousness of children is Elizabeth Bowens The House In Paris. Both novels leave a reader feeling very unsettled.M. Feldman

Kindred sets up a kind of back-to-the-future scenario in which Dana, an African-American woman circa 1976, is repeatedly drawn backward in time to an antebellum plantation in Maryland. Here, the relationship between a slave and her owner sets up the line of kinship that will lead to Danas own birth. Its an interesting premise for an alternative history, but it doesnt really work.The biggest problem is the novels didactic tone. We must believe that Dana knows little about the lives of slaves in this period, so Butler is often forced to digress from the plot to teach Dana about life in this period. Trouble is, theres far more powerful (and firsthand)  testimony about this by a man whose Narrative, published in 1845, spared no words to depict the harshness of slavery----that is, Frederick Douglass, himself a slave on a Maryland plantation. On top of this, it seems inconceivable that Dana, an aspiring writer, would be so ignorant of African-American history.The novel struck me as most suitable for a high school reader, probably because of that same didacticism. Some secondary students will encounter Toni Morrisons Beloved, but for many younger readers, it is too demanding. Kindred is not difficult and would make an interesting pairing with Douglasss Narrative.It also would, in the right hands, make a very interesting movie.M. Feldman

This memoir is a very slight one. It reads like a rummage through boxes stored away. Or, to use another image, it's like a scrapbook of images, some of them very sentimental, put together for the family. (Maxine Kumin died last year.) She's a better writer than this memoir indicates. Although I am not a particular fan of her poetry, I've always admired the woman who left the city behind to move to an old farm in New Hampshire, and I've always admired her eye for the details of country life. She became an accomplished mushroom hunter, an avid horsewoman, the kind of gardener who hid the last of tomatoes under old bedsheets to keep the frost away. Better to look into another book of hers, the collection of essays entitled "In Deep: Country Essays". It's a better book and a better memorial for a sharp-eyed writer who relished her adopted New England (see the essay "A Sense of Place"). Hers was a hillside farm, neither in the rich bottom land the farmers coveted  nor on the heights where the rich folks built for the view. She rather liked being in the middle.M. Feldman

James Rebanks, a man descended from Lake District sheep farmers, a man who went from alienated high school dropout to Oxford graduate, has an inspiring life story. His devotion to raising sheep, a demanding profession, is evident, and the detail of his shepherds life are compelling---at first.As the book develops, its flaws become irritating and then maddening. The entire book is written in the first person. It drifts aimlessly from past to present, from the life of his grandfather to a sheep sale, from his tense relationship with his father to a difficult lambing. Inevitably, it becomes repetitious and often dull. The writing is often banal. One particular subject of his ire (teachers are another) is the poet Wordsworth, for whose poetry and life in the Lake District Rebanks has scant understanding. He appears to view him as some kind of invading literary tourist. (He also dislikes regular non-poet tourists, at least when they appear in his part of the world.)Its too bad an editor couldnt have helped to shape this story, cutting out the fat and repetitions, lending narrative coherence, getting rid of the wretched you are there present tense.  I think this writer might be best appreciated on Twitter, where he apparently has quite a following. The 140-word restriction strikes me as just right.M. Feldman

Virgin Territory is Nancy Harmon Jenkinss comprehensive, and often passionate, guide to the world of extra virgin olive oil. The first third of the book is informational, covering the history of olive cultivation, the mechanics of oil extraction, the differences between types of oil, misconceptions about tasting and storing oil, and the health benefits of olive oil. You will learn how to properly taste olive oil and how to distinguish well-made oil from rancid or fusty oil. I learned a lot about how to seek out good quality olive oil. There is a helpful appendix that lists suppliers and online sources.The rest of the book is devoted to recipes using extra virgin oil. I found that the most compelling were the simplest---that is, those in which the taste of good quality oil is ascendant. The recipe for marinated green olives is worth the price of the book. More complicated and highly seasoned recipesone for curry, for examplewell, I couldnt see the point of using olive oil, even a less expensive one, in these. And fried chicken? Really? My Yankee thriftiness balked.One aspect of this book, which is absolutely devoted to helping a consumer appreciate honest, well-crafted oils, struck me as rather dishonest. The oils of many countries are mentioned, including those of Palestine, one of whose producers merits a two-page cameo. Nowhere are the olive oils of Israel mentioned, except those of biblical times. Is olive oil no longer produced in Israel?  Or, if it is, is it of such poor quality as to not be worth a mention? Should a consumer be warned against it?  Of course not. In this book, which aims to be THE last word on olive oil, Israeli producers appear to be the subject of a literary boycott. I say appear, because Ms. Jenkins confines herself to a few highly critical observations about difficulties the Israeli army creates for some Palestinian producers. Nowhere does she forthrightly state what becomes evident, which is that her political views have led her to exclude any mention of Israeli olive oil in her book. Perhaps she felt that these views would affect the sale of her book. However, in politics, as in the world of olive oil, honesty is always the best policy.M. Feldman

I encountered an excerpt of this semi-autographical novel  in The New Yorker, and I recall then being very moved by the story of an Indian immigrant family whose promising eldest son, Birju, is grievously injured when he strikes his head after diving into a swimming pool. The narrator, the younger son, Ajay, relates the effect of the accident on himself, on his father, who becomes an alcoholic, and on his mother, who neglects her younger son in her all-consuming care for Birju. Ajay's voice is bruised, flat. He often does not know how he should react or what he should say to others. He tries on different versions of himself: the helpful son, the rebellious son, the boastful middle schooler, the romantic teen, the secret artist. None of these seem to quite fit.However the center of the novel, at least for me, is Birju, brain-injured and blind, lying in the middle of the house in his hospital bed. This is one of the most honest and detailed depictions of this sort of injury that a reader is likely to encounter. A story like this does not have a happy ending. Caring for Birju is not uplifting and transforming. It does not make anyone in his family a "better person." Most people like to think that "something" can be done, and in the Indian community of the novel, it means that the family must submit to a series of people who pray or otherwise claim they can produce a miracle. There are also those who prey, peddling insurance policies and the like, or seeking some sort of spiritual understanding--for themselves."Family Life" is a novel based on real circumstances, but it reads like a memoir. There is an interesting account on a blog on The New Yorker website about how Sharma came to write the book.M. Feldman

The inhabitants of the barges moored to a shore of the Thames live in walking distance of 1960's London but also distant from it. Mail delivery is unpredictable, telephones scarce, authority figures few. One boat is shipshape, but the rest are in varying stages of decay; one functions as a receptacle for stolen goods, another sinks. However, the inhabitants, utterly diverse, function as a tiny community, and the two children in the novel, Martha and Tilda, along with a wonderful cat named Stripey, move fluidly back and forth among the boats, which are not only at anchor (kind of) in the Thames, but tied, in physical and human ways, to each other.If you require  a tidy novel that gathers up its characters and deposits them in a satisfying ending, you won't like Offshore. If you'd like to live for a few hours in a microcosm of humanity that's full of humor, pathos, and the oddest sort of happenstance, then you'll enjoy it. Penelope Fitzgerald herself lived for a time on a Thames barge and perhaps there is a bit of her in Nenna, the mother of the two children and a woman whose marriage is unraveling. It is Nenna who most appreciates that "sagacious brute" of a cat Stripey, who dashes to and fro most days but, when she needs to, knows how to find a warm hold.M. Feldman

I picked up this novel from the booksellers remainder table. I should have left it there. It is terrible.This historical novel is anything but. It is as if the author did some rudimentary research into nineteenth century science and history, then tossed it in whenever a bit of authentic color was needed. There is simply no sense of what it was like to live in the Philadelphia in this period. Some of the historical background  (and thats what it is---background) is little better than information in a Wikipedia entry. Compared to writers of historical fiction like A.S. Byatt or Hilary Mantel----well, there simply is no comparison.The big theme of the novelintelligent but ugly woman turns to botanizing because no man will have heris absurd. Perhaps this is because Gilbert reminds the reader at every turn that her protagonist, Alma Whittaker, is REALLY ugly. She even gives her a gorgeous adopted sister to underscore the point. And thats it: Alma is depicted either a brilliant woman who can hold her own with the men in intellectual conversation or as an emotionally starved woman. As a character, she is like a cartoon; there is no depth or complexity to her at all.Then, there is the authors supremely irritating tone. She has no confidence at all that readers might understand life in a different era, so she constantly nudges in irritating asides. Get it? she seems to say. We know how they were back then (wink wink). Since she cant bring us into the period on the strength of her writing, she must tell us about it.And finally, this novel, implausible, pretentious, and oh so cloying, is a bore. If George Eliot, a writer not known for her great beauty, were alive, shed throw it into her coal stove.M. Feldman

My Brilliant Friend, by the writer whose nom de plume is Elena Ferrante, is set in 1950's Naples, a time when Fascism and the war are not so long ago. What's interesting about the friendship between Elena Greco and her friend, Lila Cerullo, both of them the children of impoverished families, is how similar circumstances send these two bright girls in completely different directions. Both families have little use for education (for girls) and place a high value on marriage and economic security. Both families are caught up in the old, violent, and seemingly unending feuds that define the neighborhood.Yet as Elena begins to push past the boundaries of the neighborhood, entering high school and tentatively finding her voice as a writer, Lila, arguably the more "brilliant" of the two, falls back. At the beginning of the novel, Elena seems to live in the shadow of Lila, and even when she enters middle school and Lila does not, she feels behind, since Lila takes books out of the library to stay even with Elena. Eventually Elena pulls ahead and, at a wedding, her mother, having finally taken notice of her daughter's accomplishments, literally holds onto the hem of her dress to keep Elena from dancing with a boy who will never be more than a mechanic.Since this novel is the first in a trilogy, a reader can't know for sure which friend is the "brilliant" one. Their old teacher is certain that it is Lila, but Lila herself calls Elena the brilliant one. And of what does this brilliance consist: escaping from poverty and the chronic angers of a "pleb" household to a home with a phone, a bath, and a car? Or defying the immutable expectation of parents that their daughters, with only a basic education, will marry as teens and begin to have children? Escape takes more than one form in this novel.M. Feldman

This cream will not make your skin feel immortal, despite the label. The name comes from a Mediterranean flower that lasts a long time after being picked, or so the company says, and it goes on to say that it will make your skin "younger-looking," and etc. etc. etc. If you believe that kind of beauty hype, you are bound to be disappointed. However, if you might enjoy a skin cream whose weight is perfect, neither too thin nor too thick, and whose scent is delicate, you'll like this one. The French do have a way with skin creams. I tested this one as a Vine reviewer, but when it's gone, I'm going to buy it.M. Feldman

The Greenlanders is a tour de force, utterly enjoyable from start to finish. I knew Jane Smileys work from A Thousand Acres, the book that won her the Pulitzer, and while I admired that book, I also found (on a second reading) its connection to King Lear to be a bit contrived.  The Greenlanders will bring to mind that other saga of medieval Scandinavian life, Sigrid Undsets trilogy Kristin Lavransdatter, but to my mind The Greenlanders is the better book.Whats remarkable is the way that Smiley depicts the precarious nature of life in 14th century Greenland. There is simply no predicting what will happen next. Although the novel follows the fortunes of one particular family, it does not focus on them; different family members move in and out of focus as their lives intertwine with others: lovers, enemies, skraelings (native) people), worldly visitors from the Norwegian homeland. Characters suddenly appear, and, just as suddenly, disappear. Death takes them; skraelings kill or abduct them; murderous feuds erupt into terrible violence; madness, famine, and wasting diseases grip the living.However, the book is not just about the fragility of life in a community that is in decline from its best and most prosperous days. It is also about the beauty to be found in a bleak landscape inhabited by a Christian people who wait patiently for the bishop from Norway who never comes. These people measure their wealth in sheep pastured, seals and reindeer hunted, cheeses stacked in the storehouse. So rich and varied are their lives that, even in the famine years, they never seem poor. Dont miss this book.M. Feldman

I tried this one out on a coast to coast red-eye flight. I don't sleep much on planes, so I can't say if this neck pillow will save you from waking up with a sore neck. However, it is comfortable if you're a short napper, like me. It feels stiff at first, but the memory foam does adapt to your neck so that your shoulders, tense from holding your head up in an uncomfortable cattle car seat, will ultimately relax. Frankly, I'd prefer to be in business class, comfort-wise, but this pillow is a whole lot cheaper.

Carolyn Chutes new novel, the second in a projected series, follows The School on Hearts Content Road in its depiction of the Settlement, a utopian agrarian community in the lake and hill country of western Maine. Set in the late 1990s, this novel centers once more on the Settlements charismatic founder, Gordon St. Onge, but it is full of characters, as many as a Russian novel. (There is a helpful list of them all in the back of the book.)Actually, there are four utopian visions in the novel: the communal one of the Settlement, opposed to materialism and corporate greed; the conspiracy-minded one of a local militia group, obsessed with racial purity and the Second Amendment; and the anarchist one of a group that calls itself the Anti-Rich Society. The fourth and newest one, led Bree Vandermast, a Settlement teenager who challenges Gordons leadership, calls itself the True Maine Militia and winds together elements of the first three as the young people of the Settlement seek to find their way into the future.The title of the novel, Treat Us Like Dogs and We Will Become Wolves speaks for itself. Chutes subject has always been the poor and dispossessed, but in this novel the social and economic pressures on Egypt, Maine, have become unbearable. The outside world pushes in; it is not enough any more to smash televisions to keep it away. The press writes sensational articles; FBI agents snoop around; DHS social workers inquire. Divisions also arise within the Settlement: should it attach to the Internet? should it allow in a friendly reporter? should it keep its distance from the armed militia led by Gordons old friend Rex York?However, the great power of this novel lies in the way Chute writes about people who dont get written about much. It is here that you will find pitch perfect renderings of Maine French Canadian patois and rural Maine vernacular. Sometimes the novel wanders off to describe in loving detail a childs homemade jumper;  a rack of loaded canning jars, so seedy and tomatoey, a winter comfort; a Maine blue sky; a falling-down mobile home. Each character, no matter how minor is rendered as an individual, clothes, quirks, speech patterns, and all, as if in refutation of the view Gordon articulates of the outside world: There izzz only democracy among lords and ladies and the top. The rest of us are just yard fowl.Other novels set in Maine, novels like Strouts Olive Kitteridge or Russos Empire Falls, go down a lot easier than Treat Us Like Wolves. It is hard to imagine it being turned into an HBO mini-series. It is a long book that, like a novel by Faulkner, another chronicler of the dispossessed, demands your time and your attention. Throughout the novel, a blaring cartoon television-character characterizes Chutes people asthe scrungy bad people in the cities and towns across America! They can hurt us! They blow up buildings, they rob, they shoot, they let their children roam and never read to them, they collect welfare, they rape, they piss in front of people and cut people up, they smell and have sores and tattoos and nose rings and nipple rings and swastikas and they never wear pastels. They are dripping in drugs and explosives and have no teeth. They want to hurt us! They are filled with envy and madness. They make our taxes soar.  A lot of them are illegal immigrants. Some are not. Whatever, they are COSTING.In Treat Us Like Wolves, Carolyn Chute , astute, sympathetic, and more humorous than the cartoon TV could ever be, answers back.M. Feldman

Pans with a ceramic coating, like this Kyocera, are an alternative to "nonstick" pans that utilize coatings containing the chemical BTFE. (Nothing is creepier than noticing that bits of a nonstick coating have flaked away and may be making their way through your insides.) Kyocera, a Japanese company well known for its ceramic knives, has put out a line of moderately-priced ceramic lined cookware that offers good non-stick properties. (The pans are made in Vietnam.) Eggs and crepes release effortlessly. Clean-up is easy, too. The company recommends that you not put these pans in the dishwasher.The sides on this pan are a bit higher than they are in some skillets, which is useful. The pan has a nice feel, especially the stainless steel handle, which stays cool. Apparently you can put the pan in the oven, up to 400 degrees, although I'd never do that for any pan except cast iron.Only steady use will tell how the ceramic coating holds up, so I'll update the review later.M. Feldman

Atul Gawande, a surgeon who also specializes in writing about medical issues for The New Yorker, is a talentedl writer. In his book Being Mortal, he draws on his experiences as a physician to examine the generally dreadful choices that people must make as they face death. In a particular moving essay, he describes the ordeal of his own father. The elder Gawande, a physician himself, endures physical and emotional suffering, debilitating medical procedures, and profound changes in the way he lives his life before the end comes. Other essays deal with cultural shifts in the way American society cares for its elderly: the rise of the nursing home, the development of the assisted living concept, the spread of hospice care, the shift away from and, now, back to deaths at home. However the focus of the book is Gawande's ideas about how to empower dying people to take control of their lives in the time they have left.It is hard to disagree with any of Gawande's observations. One could wish that every person in America who deals with the elderly---doctors, in particular---would read the book. Gawande himself strove to learn from others about how to talk to patients with terminal illnesses and how to actually listen to their desires. This is also a useful book for anyone with a parent or family member at the end of life. Perhaps some teenager will even pick it up and decide to enter that humble specialty, geriatrics, a medical specialty not nearly as lucrative as most others. One hopes it falls into the hands of every nursing home administrator in the country.But ........There is one topic that appears hardly at all in Being Mortal. That topic is money. Certainly Gawande decries the uselessness of the medical procedures that simply prolong suffering. However, he seems to suggest that things might improve if only patients were better informed, if only they had more help in making choices that enhanced rather than degraded the quality of their last days.  A recent article offers a harsher perspective.This is a stunning piece ("Fighting to Honor a Father's Last Wish: To Die At Home," 9/25/2014) in the New York Times by the investigative reporter Nina Bernstein.  It details a woman's battle to bring her frail elderly father home to die. Her attempt is mostly a failure, as in the last year of his life her father is shifted among hospitals, nursing homes, "rehabilitation" centers," poor quality home care, and various iterations of hospice. The cost? More than one million dollars. All of these so-called "providers" are chasing Medicaid and Medicare money; none of them offers even close to the ideal of care that Gawande talks about and (in a few instances) finds. As a gerontologist quoted in the Bernstein article says, "We have these frail older people moving about in the medical-industrial complex that we've constructed. It's all about profit margins. It's not about caring for people." (You can find the article at http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/26/nyregion/family-fights-health-care-system-for-simple-request-to-die-at-home.html)From within that very medical-industrial complex, Gawande's Being Mortal sounds a graceful warning. However,  it's rather like tapping your glass for attention when the Times article suggests that what's needed is a fire alarm.M. Feldman

"Local Souls" consists of three novellas set in the imaginary small town of Falls, North Carolina. As a reader who greatly enjoyed Gurganus's novel "Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All," I looked forward to this new book. There is much to enjoy. The three different narrators of these stories (a writer, a mother with an insufferable daughter, a man whose life intertwines with that of a revered doctor) speak in language that can veer from bleak to comic in an instant. Gurganus's feel for the perfect (often funny) simile, for the details of setting, for the fine points of social class differences, for the abiding strangeness of human behavior, is as good as I remembered it from "Confederate Widow."However, the stories are uneven. "Fear Not," about the consequences of a terrible accident, is melodramatic without being very convincing. "Decoy," the longest of the three, is so talky that it eventually becomes tiresome. I liked "Saints Have Mothers," told in the voice of an embittered middle-aged woman, the best, even though the details of the accident in this story (all three novellas contain a drowning of one sort or another) are close to improbable.What's odd about these three stories is that although the speakers are of different genders, ages, and backgrounds, they sound much the same, as if they all shared the same outlook in life: self-mocking, sometimes witty, sometimes despairing. Perhaps I would have liked them better had I not read them one after the other, but that's the way they're packaged.M. Feldman

Finally. I've lived in Maine for decades, but until I now had never read a book by Stephen King. Can you believe that I didn't even know a single thing about the plot? I must say that I enjoyed it in the way that I enjoy watching a cop show on TV: you can tell where it's headed pretty quickly, but the trip is terrifying anyway. As for those who would compare this master of horror fiction to a writer like Dickens? Nah. I suspect King would agree with that.

"Tracker" is bound to be a disappointment to those who admire Gary Paulsen's best fiction, like "Hatchet." The idea at the heart of the novel is complex: can the adolescent John Borne  somehow deflect his grandfather's death by an almost surreal pursuit of a doe he sets out to hunt for meat? This is a tale that might make a short story, but "Tracker" feels padded out by long, repetitious stretches of descriptive prose. A better choice is John Gardner's "Stone Fox," another story about a grandfather laid low by illness and a boy who must manage on his own. In both books, there is a kind of magical thinking about death, but "Stone Fox" is not only a better read, but a more approachable "take" on adolescents struggling with the idea of the mortality of people they love.M. Feldman

This set is useful for a lunch composed of leftovers. (It isn't quite big enough for a filling salad.) It has no problem in the dishwasher. The lid snaps securely. Like most OXO products, it is well-designed.

The Testament of Mary is really two stories about storytelling. On the one hand, it is the story of Mary herself as she approaches the end of her life and reflects, with regret, on her role in her sons adult life and his crucifixion. Before the crucifixion, she was a peasant woman who drew strength from her husband, her son, and her religious faith. After the crucifixion, she experiences only fear and unhappiness as she replays the events over and over in her mind, thinking about what she might have said or done differently.On the other hand, The Testament is also a story about how stories are made---that is, the story of Jesus life and death being created by his disciples. As Mary says of them, they want a simple, pleasing narrative, one stripped of complexity and doubt, one that will uplift and inspire. Marys very existence as a doubter of her sons divinity is a challenge to this kind of story making, and the men who are in charge of the story keep watch on Mary, lest she spoil it.For herself, Mary has built a kind of psychological jail, a testament that may be far harsher than it needs to be. As she says herself, the death of her son unhinged her. She narrates her testament inside a second jail, since her minders keep her close in a kind of home detention in Ephesus, far from the places where Jesus grew up, taught, and was buried.None of these narrators is reliable, neither the woman berating herself nor the careful mythmakers of the new religion.  Mary, as a powerless and nearly voiceless woman, is drawn finally to the old gods, particularly Artemis, who seems to her a figure of comfort. She cannot foresee that this is precisely the role that she will acquire, long after she is dust, in ascendant Christianity.M. Feldman

"Dissident Gardens" tells the stories of three generations of American radicals: Rose Angrush, a Communist of the thirties; her daughter Miriam, a sixties activist; and Rose's grandson Sergius, who falls in with the Occupy movement. Even though Miriam, as a teenager, furiously rebels against her mother Rose, who in retaliation once pushes her daughter's head in the gas oven, the two are joined by a common desire to upset the prevailing order.These two women are surrounded by a cast of "fellow travelers," some of them, like Tommy Gogan, Miriam's folksinger husband, and Cicero Lookins, the obese professor who's the child of Rose's African-American lover, quite wonderfully depicted. There are some great set pieces, as well, as when Rose is read out of the Party while serving cookies to her fellow communists in her own kitchen. Food is at the center of another wonderful scene, when Cicero visits the senile Rose in the Lewis Howard Latimer Care Facility.All in all, however, the novel does not really hang together. For one thing, there are too many minor characters, like the distasteful cousin Lenny, to whom pages and pages are devoted---to no particular end except to slow down the novel's pace. And even though the novel centers on Rose's home, Sunnyside Gardens in Queens, the story ranges all over the place: a Bowdoin-type Maine college, a Greenwich village commune, a Pennsylvania Quaker boarding school, Nicaragua. By the end, I found myself reading (okay, skimming) past paragraph after paragraph of period detail and philosophical digressions. It's as if Lethem could not bear to leave anything out.Rose Zimmer Angrush is the best character in the book. Had this been her story, and not many stories, I would have loved "Dissident Gardens."M. Feldman

First: a commercial. If you haven't read Rachel Kushner's first novel, "Telex From Cuba," stop reading this and go get that book.If you have read "Telex," you might be wondering if "The Flamethrowers" is as good. It isn't.However, Kushner is a gifted and interesting writer, and there are pleasures to be had in her second novel.The flamethrowers were World War I soldiers who carried great canisters of gas, the better to hurl fire into enemy trenches. This novel is about two different sorts of flamethrowers: avant garde artists who attack old ways of thinking about visual art and political radicals who attack existing political and economic ideas and institutions. Their worlds intersect in the 1970's, in New York (the art scene, political unrest, the Great Blackout) and Italy (the Red Brigades, political oligarchies, unreconstructed Fascists).They also intersect in the person of a young woman from Reno (she has no other name) who has come to New York to make it as an artist. Reno is nave and vulnerable, but she has a camera, and she focuses it on everything. Everything.Thus there are wonderful set pieces, like the looting after the blackouts or the street demonstrations in Rome, like the preening dinner table conversationalists of the New York art scene, like Reno's trip to the Bonneville Salt Flats, where she becomes the world's fastest woman (on a motorcycle). However, what Reno is thinking and feeling often ends up being rather uninteresting, perhaps because there isn't much to her. She is always looking ahead to what she might become. In addition, the research that went into the recreation of this era often feels like---research.So grab "Telex," if you've read this far and didn't immediately take my advice. That way, you'll know to keep an eye out for whatever Kushner writes next.M. Feldman

The best way to describe "The Dream of Scipio" is to call it an historical novel with a philosophical bent. In the beginning, the three intertwined stories, set in Provence during the 5th, 14th, and 20th centuries, move rather slowly. Pears has set himself the task of sketching three historical periods when the world seems to be coming undone---the twilight of the Roman Empire, the period of the papal schism and the black death, the Nazi occupation of France. The necessity of establishing each of these historical settings before the novel ever even gets going almost derails it.However, a patient reader will be rewarded as the pace picks up. What interests Pears is not the disintegration of established societies, but the tension between political figures with the power to "save" civilization and relatively powerless characters whose actions (although they may have far reaching consequences) are focused on personal relationships.Thus Manlius, the wealthy Roman turned Christian bishop, attempts to buy a bit more time for the world he knows by cutting a deal with encroaching "barbarians." The consequences of this action reverberate in the life of the poet Olivier de Noyen, a minor figure in the court of Pope Clement VI and again in the life of the scholar Julian Barneuve, who becomes a functionary in Vichy France. For each man, the world turns on a relationship with a charismatic woman.To say more is to spoil the book. However, "The Dream of Scipio" well repays a reader who possesses a bit of patience.M. Feldman

This is a short memoir. It is about a relatively short period in the author's life when, although she is young and beautiful, she abstains from sex. There is a short time when a reader will think that the premise--examining one's life independent of a sexual relationship--is an interesting one. There is a longer time, in this short book, when the author spends much too long describing how she must fend off well meaning friends who wish to find her "someone." In fact, she must spend so much time impressing her friends (and readers) with how attractive she is, despite her choice to abstain, that a short book eventually comes to seem--endless. It is a relief, not a disappointment, when she finally does take a lover.M. Feldman

Jill Lepore is a scholar who has a gift for writing about history.  You don't have to be a specialist to enjoy reading her books or the articles on American history she writes as a New Yorker staff writer. In fact, it was her appealing article there about how she came to write about Jane Franklin that interested me in the book.In "A Room of One's Own," Virginia Woolf imagined what life might have been like for Judith, a talented imaginary sibling of William Shakespeare. In "Book of Ages," Lepore reconstructs the life of the real Jane Franklin, a younger sister of Ben. Letters and other documents of Jane Franklin's do exist, but there are great gaps, so sometimes Lepore must surmise, using other evidence, what life might have been like for this intelligent woman who lived most of her life on the edge of poverty.The resulting biography gives us a real woman, one who stands, for the first time, out of the shadow of her famous brother, whom she admires mostly from afar. Their affectionate relationship, which endures until her death, makes vivid a period of tumultuous political change.Like Laurel Thatcher Ulrich's "The Midwife's Tale," Lepore's biography of Jane Franklin allows a reader to understand what life was like for humble women who endured war, the deaths of children, the difficulties of making a living, and illness. Jane Franklin's education was meager, as was typical for women of her era, but her brother Ben sent her spectacles that she might better read about him and about the great doings of the age. Lack of education did not stifle her curiosity; it only sharpened it.M. Feldman

This isn't "Gone Girl," not even close. The plotting is not nearly as tight. The protagonists are not very interesting. The secondary characters are poorly developed, with the exception of the dog. Much ink is spilt on descriptions of home furnishings, luxe dinners, and so on. Clichs abound. I could go on. Save this one for a night when you have insomnia or for when you're stuck on the phone queued up for tech "support" or possibly for a plane ride so bad any distraction will do.M. Feldman

"MaddAddam," the last book in Margaret Atwood's dystopian trilogy set in a world beset by predatory corporations, plague, and environmental disaster, is like one of those musicals in which everyone comes on stage for the final number. The characters from Oryx and Crake" (2003) are here, even Oryx and Crake themselves, if only in myth. The same is true for the characters from "The Year of the Flood,"(2009) although in the new novel Zeb now takes the lead. If you have not read the earlier books, forget about "MaddAddam" for a while.Yes, Atwood does begin with a reprise, "The Story So Far," but it is not enough. I had read both of the earlier books, but still found myself frustrated by constantly trying to remember events from those novels.
