Atwood herself seem aware of the problem, as she regularly weaves in little reminders of the previous action.  Finally in frustration, halfway through, I resorted to Wikipedia summaries of ""Oryx" and "Flood." That helped, and you may, like a student sneaking a peek at SparkNotes, find yourself doing the same.The interesting thing about "MaddAddam" is that all of the "types" of the previous books--the Gardeners, the genetically engineered pacifist Crakers, the scientists, and the people, like Zeb, who move among these types, find themselves sharing the same refuge, along with a bunch of gene-spliced animals. It's rather like Noah's ark, except that the "flood," a pandemic, has already happened. In these tight quarters, as the inhabitants must get ready to defend themselves against the murderous Painballers, Atwood asks this question: what sort of world will arise from the remnant of humans and quasi-humans that still survives? Jealousy flourishes in the compound. Ethical debates (capital punishment, abortion) arise. Even as weeds and kudzu break apart the ruined cities, trees and shrubs commence flowering, and bees return to human hives, the humans themselves seem to be reproducing true to type----or maybe not, if one considers the interspecies cooperation that sets up the final battle."MaddAddam" ties up most of the loose ends from "Oryx" and "Flood," but it only makes sense if you read those two first.M. Feldman

For the first 25 or so pages of this wonderful novel, I didn't know what to expect. In truth, I felt a little negative. Why was I reading a book about a man who seemed to be a fusty Boston Brahmin? As much as I love Boston, I don't have much patience with those for whom Harvard (and certain clubs, and the Athenaeum, and so on) are the center of the universe. And they were certainly at the center of George Apley's universe.As I read on, I was hooked, despite myself, on the story of this upright and well-meaning man for whom a rich life, at least as he comes to understand it, seems always just out of reach. Marquand narrates the story through the use of fictional letters by Apley's family members and friends (along with his replies). This technique lends a quality of delicate formality to the "biography," as if one were reading one of those old books whose pages must be cut. Not only are the man and the world he inhabited lost to us, but also the very way in which men and women of his time expressed their thoughts and hopes.Its twin is William Dean Howells' "The Rise of Silas Lapham." This is a tale of a man from the provinces (Vermont, then) who makes a fortune in paint manufacturing and comes to take his place among the wealthy inhabitants of Gilded Age Boston. One can imagine Lapham and Apley meeting in some velvet-draped drawing room, and one can imagine as well their mutual incomprehension. The seemingly crass new world that Apley deplores is the sphere of Lapham; the snobberies and fingerbowls that so confuse Lapham is the sphere of Apley.Both of these novels give great pleasure and desire a wider readership.M. Feldman

This was one of the few Mary Renault books I had not read, and indeed it had been quite a while since I picked up something by her, although I have always enjoyed her books.  An interesting profile by Daniel Mendelsohn in The New Yorker prompted me to read "The Last of the Wine."This account of a friendship between two young men, Alexias and Lysis, during the Peloponnesian War, is a serious book. One might call it "scholarly," if such a word could be applied to historical fiction. Renault is intent on taking a reader to a time and place that is a lost world, so distant that one can only wonder at it, even if its depiction of love and friendship and intellectual awakening is something a modern reader might feel empathy for.I confess that I did not love this book, most likely because I found the characterizations of the few women who appear in the novel to be so sad.  There is Alexias' father recommending that should his new young wife bear a female child, the infant should be exposed. There are the enslaved war captives and the prostitutes and the famously (but was she?) shrewish wife of Socrates. The author does not draw a contrast between the high-minded intellectual pursuits of the men and the degradation of the women, but it is there.M. Feldman

Luke Barr's great-aunt is the famous writer M.F.K. Fisher. Years after her death, he visits a storage unit in California and uncovers a journal of a period she spent in Provence, in 1970. It turns out that, for different reasons, an entire cast of stars--Julia and Paul Child, Simone Beck, Richard Olney, James Beard, the editor Judith Jones---were in Provence at exactly the same time. The impulse to write a book about this, with the newly discovered journal as the centerpiece, must have been irresistible.It's an impulse that should have been resisted. First of all, the journal itself is not very interesting; it appears to mostly be a record of places visited and meals eaten. Oddly enough, M.F.K. Fisher is the vanishing figure in this chronicle of big personalities. It surely must be difficult to write about a close relative, but Barr simply can't bring to life this prickly and interesting woman. Read her books, instead.It should be no surprise that Julia Child is the dominant person in this book, both in accomplishment and personality. Barr's thesis is that 1970 is a watershed moment in American culinary history, when writers like Child broke away from formal (and ossified) French culinary practice, as well as from the snobbery and privilege associated with fine dining. He makes much of the already well-documented tension between Child and her collaborator, Simone Beck. However, this is a false thesis, designed to hold together a book that is mostly a collection of gossip, menus, meals eaten, chauffeurs befriended, Provencal landscapes described, more gossip, more menus, and on and on. By 1970, the food revolution was already well underway.The book has an annoying stylistic tic. Not content with quoting from the extensive and lively correspondence of these writers, Barr must give them made-up thoughts that he thinks they might have had. Since the subjects are all deceased, they are unable to defend themselves.  Thus, James Beard dwells on his unworkable diet. Richard Olney has caustic thought bubbles about just about everyone, and M.F. just wants to be alone. If you're interested in an antidote to this sort of thing, be sure to read Julia Child's "My Life in France," which is a good book.However, if you enjoy the reverent food prose of, say, Bon Appetit, combined with the delicious scene painting of a posh travel magazine, along with a soupon of spicy People magazine gossip, perhaps you'll enjoy "Provence." Here's a sample:" Norah had the oysters, M.F. had the clams, and they shared the scallops, which they agreed were beautiful. The Pomerol was superb and so was the cheese. The weather outside was a soft gray drizzle, and they were happy."Two hundred and fifty pages of this is enough to give a reader indigestion.M. Feldman

Prim Henry Pulling, retired British bank manager, lifelong bachelor, and fussy tender of dahlias, turns out to have a wild and crazy Aunt Augusta. They meet at his mother's funeral, but it turns out that Auntie A. has been keeping her eye on Henry for a while. No sooner are his mother's ashes in the urn, thanshe begins to lead him into down the primrose path. And who better do this than a woman whose professional career appears to have been that of a madam?However, this book, intended to be comical, is not exactly a side-splitter. Characters are hackneyed, the humor a bit dated. However, the twisting plot eventually gets so nutty that you just have to give in to it and enjoy the road trip that becomes a train trip that becomes a sea and river trip and ends up in (where else?) Paraguay.Given a choice between thinking about the passage from midlife to death  la Julian Barnes  (the weighty pronouncements of  "Nothing to be Frightened Of") and thinking about it  la Graham Greene, I'll take "Travels with My Aunt" any day. Might as well have fun.M. Feldman

"The Radetzky March" is one of the great depictions of a lost world, this one the Austro-Hungarian empire on the verge of World War I.  One can sense a new age coming in Roth's depiction of the "borderlands," where nationalism is on the rise, but the poignancy of the novel lies in the collapse of the old: the relationships between parents and children; the dissolution of social hierarchies, changing sexual mores, the decline of a military ideal, the rotting away of the Hapsburg monarchy. All of this is reflected through three generations of the Trotta family.At the center of the novel is the aimless and dissolute Carl Joseph, who know he is unable to live up to his father's plans for him and so loses himself in alcoholism, gambling, and illicit love affairs. Yet Carl Joseph is not an unsympathetic figure, merely a weak one. Roth's great gift is to make Carl Joseph's world seem at once very distant from us and utterly familiar, so perfect are the details of setting and psychological characterization.This novel is one of the great ones. It is right up there with Tanizaki's "The Makioka Sisters" in its rendering of a world about to disappear forever.M. Feldman

Many readers have pointed out that "The Orphan Master's Son" incorporates several different genres, from bildungsroman to love story. The central character, Jun Do, even disappears into a North Korean gulag and emerges as----someone else. However, as well-written and interesting as the novel's shifting perspectives are, they aren't the only things that make this a wonderful novel.It's all about the research. This is as knowledgeable and as in-depth a look at North Korea as you are likely to find, all wrapped up in an enthralling work of fiction.Lest you doubt Johnson's bona fides, look no further than some of the nonfiction material that generally gets little notice, unless you're a specialist. There are films like "Crossing the Line" and the wonderful "A State of Mind"; memoirs like that of the deserter Charles Robert Jenkins or the prison memoir "The Aquariums of Pyongyang"; third person accounts like Barbara Demick's "Nothing to Envy." Johnson's has read and seen it all, and then some. (He also traveled to North Korea, not an easy thing to do.)Through "The Orphan Master's Son" you'll travel to a place that people can barely imagine, so isolated is North Korea. And you'll be in the hands of a travel guide cum novelist who knows as much as anyone can about this perfect Orwellian state.M. Feldman

The basis of the plot of "The Lowland" is the Naxalite movement, a Maoist political insurgency in India that advocated violence on behalf of impoverished and landless Indian peasants.  The time period is the late 1960's-early 1970's, although a short section of the novel is set in an earlier period and most of the novel is set in the decades following. Two brothers, Udayan and Subhash Mitra, grow up in the "lowland" of Calcutta that give the novel its title; Udayan joins the insurgency and his elder brother Subhash does not. What happens to Udayan, who thinks he is acting only for himself, eventually transforms every member of his family.The novel is narrated through several different characters in the Mitra family. When Udayan in effect turns his back on his brother, his parents, and even his wife, he does so in what he considers to be the service of a higher cause. "The Lowland" seems to ask the question: is devotion to a political ideal worth the pain it inflicts on those one loves, even on those not yet born? There isn't a single answer, although the conclusion of the novel suggests that the answer is "no."I'm an admirer of Lahiri's short stories, and while I appreciated the ambitious scope of this novel, I did not find it as pleasing as some of her earlier work. The fine detail of the scenes set in India---surely essential for Western readers--is matched by an equal amount of detail for scenes set in the novel's other setting, Rhode Island. The American settings often seemed overly detailed, and I found my eye skipping past them. Lahiri also likes to convey the jumpy quality of thought by the use of sentence fragments, and I sometimes found myself longing for a paragraph where the sentences were complete. The novel must cover the almost the entire life span of Subhash Mitra and his wife, which leads to great jumps in time."The Lowland" is, most of all, about love. Udayan's violent break with his upbringing and his family turns out be no break at all, just a wrenching twist in a rope of interwoven lives.M. Feldman

Many people dream of taking a road trip across the United States. If you're a writer, it makes sense to turn such a journey into a book. Or maybe not. "The Longest Road", has all of the interest of a trip on an interstate highway.Yes, Caputo and his wife and two dogs, traveling in a vintage Airstream, do avoid the interstates. They seek out the local good eats, the local colorful characters, and the quirky or bypassed towns. In a time of economic hardship (about which Caputo writes with great sympathy), he says he seeks to understand the forces that hold such a disparate country together.The book hasn't got an answer for that. Instead it relies on a formulaic approach to each section of the country, as the couple travels from Key West to Deadhorse, Alaska. And that formula is:  a little historical background; a mechanical problem and/or parking problem with the Airstream (named Ethel); the aforementioned interview with the local colorful person and dinner at the local joint; musings on the wonders (or not) of technology, GPS, etc.; and descriptions of the scenery. Many of the observations are hardly new; did you know that the Pacific Northwest had a serious coffee culture or that immigrants do the hard work in the slaughterhouses of Nebraska? These things, and many other of Caputo's observations, have been better written about elsewhere.Caputo saw a lot of interesting things, no doubt, but his journalist's skill does not extend to the travel writing genre. This book is a snoozer.M. Feldman

"The Son" is historical fiction that, thank heavens, does not ever glorify its subject, the settling and development of the state of Texas. It is a story of dispossession: of the Comanches (who had themselves pushed out other tribes); of the Tejanos, some of whom held ancient land grants from the King of Spain; of the small-scale settlers who first inhabited the borderland, often at great personal risk.  The dispossession of all of these groups is intertwined with the story of the McCullough family, whose enormous land holdings, and, later, oil riches, come to them through hard work, vision, luck, and murder.The novel is told primarily through three voices from different generations, and it moves back and forth among them. (You will need the genealogy printed at the beginning of the book; if you have a Kindle, you'd better bookmark that page.) Each voice is distinctive. There is the patriarch, Eli McCullough, whose is kidnapped by the Comanches as a child and who lives well into the 20th century; there is his son, Peter, whose more settled existence makes him a reflective and conflicted man; and there is Eli's great-granddaughter Jeanne Anne, who must manage the family's wealth at a time when few women ran a business.The novel's epigraph is from Gibbon, and, yes, this book is about a rise, a decline, and a fall. But whereas some of the characters in the book speculate nostalgically about a parallel between the settling of the land and a gradual loss of "manly" frontier attributes, Meyer does not. The real parallels in the novel are between what happens to the McCulloughs and what happens to other powerful families, like that of the Comanche chief Toshaway or the rancher Pedro Garcia. Their decline, and that of the McCulloughs, is complex, tragic, and also inevitable.And, for a reader in no danger of scalping, "The Son" is a powerfully good read.M. Feldman

If you have not read Paul Theroux before, his most recent travelogue, "The Last Train to Zona Verde" is not the best book with which to begin, as it's a valedictory of sorts. Better to start with the travelogue "Ghost Train to the Eastern Star," an account of his journey down the entire continent of Africa, from Egypt to South Africa. Better to start with "The Lower River," his fictional account of a man who goes back in late middle age to the village in Malawi where he had once (like Theroux) been a Peace Corps volunteer.In "The Last Train to Zona Verde," Theroux returns to the Cape Town shantytowns he describes in "Ghost Train," then winds his way through two countries in southwest Africa, Namibia and Angola. Theroux is well known for his antipathy towards Western philanthropic organizations and Western celebrities (like Bono) and their efforts---mostly failed, by his account---to ameliorate poverty in Africa. One senses in this new book that he is striving to be fair-minded as he looks at the evidence of some improvement in the slums of Cape Town. By the end of the book, however, he is again thoroughly disillusioned---perhaps more so---by the great sprawling slums that surround the cities he visits. One person he meets comments that these slums seem to offer a vision of what the end of the world might look like.Theroux is happiest in the rural areas he travels through, but as he himself remarks, the bush is in the process of being lost to urbanization, to climate change, to tourism, and to warfare. Everywhere he goes, he sees Chinese laborers doing work that could be done by Africans. In the end, he declare himself unfit to chronicle what he is in fact chronicling:  "The traveler in cities needs to understand cities better than I do and not to be disgusted by their chronic deficits; that traveler needs to care more, to be more expert in some areas, more innocent in others, more hopeful."Don't take Theroux at his word here. "The Last Train to Zone Verde" is engaging from start to finish. The sights he describes are sometimes appalling, sometimes hopeful, sometimes comic, and always related in that clear-eyed, unsentimental voice that is like that of no other literary traveler. This is Theroux's last book about Africa, or so he says. Just don't read it first.M. Feldman

Other readers have pointed out that this book is a collection of recipes that the Jamisons have published elsewhere. I see no problem with that, although it isn't made quite clear in the book. However, this is not a book that will teach you how to grill.  For that, you're better off consulting a publication by the Weber people or even some of the well-tested grilling recipes that Cooks Illustrated publishes.These recipes, as the Jamisons make clear, are mostly based on direct heat grilling. That is, you had better be standing by the grill if you don't want that nice chicken to burst into flames. There are also some recipes for the use of a spit. I confess to being rather indifferent griller; I much prefer the controls on a stove to the vagaries of charcoal, and as for a gas grill, what's the point except that it is outdoors?However, I tried. Dr. Pepper's Baby Back Ribs were tasty and left me with at least a quart of leftover sauce. The Dr. Pepper part could easily be subbed, however, in favor of Coke or Pepsi, as there is too much going on in the sauce for anyone to notice. Church-Picnic pork chops had a nice rub and came out well. Do not leave them unattended, however! There are quite a few variations in the book on hamburgers and other burgers, although a "recipe" for grilled hot dogs seemed silly.Buy this book if you are a committed griller and want to up your game with some fancier stuff---"Goat Cheese Wrapped in Grape Leaves" or "Dry Rubbed Tuna Steaks" or "Skewered Shrimp with Romesco Sauce."  Me, I'm going back inside.

I have no complaint about these measuring cups. They are not too heavy and feel good in the hand. The color-coding ensures that you won't have to put your glasses on when trying to distinguish between a 1/3 and a 1/2 cup measure. They do come on a plastic ring, and I didn't find it all that easy to detach them, so I ditched the ring. Tidier persons might like this feature, however.I cannot really justify spending this kind of money for measuring cups. You'll have to decide that one. And it's true that my favorite measurer (only the 1 cup measure is left after many years of service, including in the sandbox, no doubt) is an ugly green plastic number. It just feels right---what can I say?M. Feldman

Two kinds of stories intertwine in Transatlantic, a novel set in Ireland (and, later, Northern Ireland), the U.S., and Canada.  The first strand is historical fiction, an imagining of three events: the first non-stop transatlantic flight by John Alcock and Arthur Brown, which touched down in Ireland; the Irish sojourn of the abolitionist Frederick Douglass; and the establishment of the 1998 Northern Ireland peace accords through the efforts of former Senator George Mitchell. The second is another transatlantic story, that of the emigrant Irish housemaid, Lily Duggan, and her descendants, whose lives take them from Missouri to Newfoundland and then to Northern Ireland. These two strands, the historical lives and the ordinary lives, are bound by an unopened letter. Transatlantic is a novel about the impossibility of separating Big Events and private sorrows.The sheer span of the novel, over a time period of more than 150 years, works against it. McCann's earlier novel Let the Great World Spin (which I admire) explored intersecting lives in a particular time and place, the New York of the 1970's.  Its characters, fully-developed, were convincing. The ambitious sweep of Transatlantic, on the other hand, makes it necessary to render the characters in a kind of shorthand, through extended interior monologues built on thought fragments. These passages have a lot of work to do: depict setting, establish relationships between characters, link the famous characters to the ordinary ones, render an emotional state. In the end, it's too much work, and I felt my eyes sliding over these sections.The sections of the novel that follow the lives of Lily Duggan her daughter Emily, her granddaughter Lottie, and great-granddaughter Hannah are the best ones, despite the interior monologues. By contrast, the account of Frederick Douglass seemed contrived or perhaps constrained by facts, and the depiction of George Mitchell seemed oddly voyeuristic, given the fact that he is still living. That part felt a bit creepy; maybe it's because I'm from Maine, where Mitchell is revered.Still, there are sections of great power in Transatlantic, the kind I remembered from Let the Great World Spin. In particular, the last chapter, set in contemporary Northern Ireland, pulls all of the strands together with lyric intensity. If you're looking for a successor to Let the Great World Spin, I don't think you'll find it in Transatlantic, but a novel by McCann always has its pleasures.M. Feldman

This clever and enjoyable novel is constructed around an authorial wink. The novel, told entirely in the second person, follows an unnamed narrator who lives in a country that looks a lot like Pakistan. Beginning as an impoverished village boy, he migrates to the city and joins millions of his countrymen in an attempt, through hard work, cleverness, and sheer nerve, along with (as he prospers) bribery, deception, and violence, to rise from his beginnings. Hence, the chapters are structured on some tenet of a business self-help book: "Move to the City, "Don't Fall in Love,"  Learn From a Master," and so on. The wink comes in the author's knowledge that readers in places like the United States might  also be looking for some "self-help" in understanding a particular part of the world.Without giving away the novel's last few self-help principles, it is fair to say that they move away from the business model and toward an exploration of human dignity in an economic culture that leaves the poor, which is to say most people, "with their faces pressed to that clear window on wealth afforded by ubiquitous television." It's a conclusion that is a commentary on avarice and on human desires, whether in an unnamed country in the so-called developed world or in other countries that consider themselves a good deal more developed.M. Feldman

These small knives are indispensable in the kitchen. They are sharp and hold their edge longer than knives that are much more expensive. These, along with the same company's chef's knife and serrated bread knife, will take care of all of your knife-ly needs. About the only thing that might be a problem is that these knives are quite light, which could make it easier to lose them in, say, a heap of trimmings you've brushed into the compost bucket.  Fortunately, their inexpensive price makes their replacement a lot more bearable than having to replace an expensive German-made knife that suffers the same fate. An inexpensive Accu-sharp makes sharpening these knives a breeze.M. Feldman

This complicated novel, set primarily during the period of the Gulf War, is of interest for its perspective on the relationship between America and Pakistan and for its depiction of everyday life in Karachi and in rural Pakistan.There are many stories here, told through different narrators and through shifts back and forth in time. There is the story of an unhappy young Pakistani man attending an American college that seems to be a cross between Amherst and UMass. There is another plot line that follows the lives of several different women, from different generations, as they push up against religious and cultural barriers. At times the novel offers a lyrical rendering of Pakistani scenes like a seaside cove and a silkworm factory, while at other times it strives to depict the difficulties of life in a sprawling city where the water and electricity are never reliable. Yet another story follows a village man who comes to the city and, for a time, casts his lot with dispossessed men empowered by a flood of cheap American arms. All of this is wound around a love story that seems designed to appeal to---it's hard to say to whom, exactly. The illicit embraces of the lovers, Dia and Daanish, ultimately prove wearying to read about, and thus the final revelation of the fate of their love is only a fizzle.This might have been a better novel had it not tried to do so many things, in so many different voices. The dialogue is often flat and predictable, and the author's use of metaphor is sometimes cringe-inducing.For its depiction of life in Pakistan, I much prefer Daniyal Mueenuddin's In Other Rooms, Other Wonders.M. Feldman

This book is a good guide to getting started using a pressure cooker. As in all of the publications produced by the Cooks Illustrated People, the recipes are well written and there is plenty of additional information---in this case, brands of pressure cookers and how they work. (Mine is a Fagor.)I tried four recipes, one from each of the first four chapters. All were tasty. Chipotle Pork and Hominy Stew, from the soups, Stews, and Chili section, was delicious. Braised Chicken Thighs with Potatoes (Fast and Easy Suppers) was a good weeknight dish that combined main meal and side, with the plus of a nice sauce. Ziti with Sausage and Peppers (One Pot Pastas and Pasta Sauces) came out astonishingly well; I had my doubts about cooking pasta in a pressure cooker!  The ziti was perfectly cooked, and the whole thing came together in 30 minutes. We splurged on osso bucco  (Big Roasts), which does take 2.5 hours. The recipe was a bit unclear on how to tie them. Even though they kind of came apart in the pot, they were very tasty.All of the recipes have a troubleshooting guide that gives acceptable substitutions, like different kinds of pasta. However, it is very difficult to figure out if the recipes can be adjusted (down) for size; the recipes seem designed for 6 people, for the most part. The recipes often warn against making changes, so I was stumped on this topic.I liked the feature called "the language of the pressure cooker." It looks like a sidebar, however, and I wish it had been more prominent. At first, when starting a recipe, I didn't know the difference between a natural release and a quick release. This section explains things like that. All recipes have two numbers in the bottom left corner of the page. The larger number is the time the recipe needs to be under pressure (and it can take a pot a while to get there), while the smaller number is the total time needed.All in all, this is a solid guide to using a pressure cooker. If you are buying a pressure cooker as a gift, this would make a nice addition.M. Feldman

I was familiar with only a few poems by Simic when I began to work through New and Selected Poems, reading front to back, back to front, and sometimes in the middle. Most of the unrhymed poems themselves are not long or particularly difficult to read, but the recurring themes---war, childhood loneliness, adult loneliness, darkening city evenings, shabby apartments---are often painful to read about.There are bits of happiness, too---a fragment of natural beauty, jazz, a lover, a book of poetry. In fact, one of my favorite lines, from "Romantic Sonnet," is this one: "Happiness, you are the bright red lining/Of the dark winter coat/Grief wears inside out." That expresses the feeling of reading Simic.There is a fine essay on Simic's poetry, entitled " A World of Foreboding," in Soul Says, Helen Vendler's collection of essays on contemporary poetry.M. Feldman

This is the second edition of the well-regarded Bringing Words to Life: Robust Vocabulary Instruction. In addition to incorporating the newest research on vocabulary instruction, it now addresses the Common Core standards and the Response to Intervention (RTI) structure. A new chapter, on "Vocabulary and Writing," discusses the intuitive sense that most teachers have that a rich vocabulary improves writing, although it also notes the paucity of research on this topic.Bringing Words to Life makes a powerful case for the need for systematic direct instruction in vocabulary and persuasively debunks the idea that students can readily learn the meanings of new words simply from context and reading exposure. Unlike so many education texts, it is well written, with clear summaries of current research along with excellent descriptions and examples of how to carry out "robust" vocabulary instruction in the classroom. Bringing Words to Life encourages high expectations for even the youngest students, who can readily learn to move from the everyday (Tier One) words that they frequently encounter to what the authors call "Tier Two" words; for instance, "talking about" something can become "mention."This book won't write a teacher's lesson plans but it can fill them with ideas. Like any new curricular idea, learning to incorporate rich vocabulary takes practice, both for teachers and for students.As a practitioner of the Orton Gillingham method of dyslexia remediation, I wondered why the book makes no reference to the use of morphology (prefixes, suffixes, Latin roots, Greek combining forms) as an efficient way to expand a student's vocabulary. In response to my inquiry, one of the authors indicated that a companion book, Creating Robust Vocabulary: Frequently Asked Questions and Extended Examples (which I have not seen), does examine the use of morphemes. This author also indicated that she considered this to be a useful approach.Anyone who works with students who have limited vocabularies should own this book. It contains that rare combination of theory and practice that distinguishes the best books about teaching.M. Feldman

This is a delightful book, funny and dark at the same time. Since the perpetrators of the explosion that brought down the plane of the real General Zia ul-Haq in 1988 have never been conclusively identified, Hanif imagines how it might have happened. Most of the novel alternates between the voice of a young Army cadet named Ali Shigri and the voice of the security-obsessed General himself.Wild plots abound amid the bloated security apparatus of the modern Pakistani state. General Zia, he of the oiled mustache and expanding midsection, is bent on the Islamization of his country, although his subordinates are mostly bent on getting and keeping power. His opposite number, the lowly Shigri, has to keep one eye open when in group prayer, the better not to make an embarrassing spiritual mistake. The action moves at dizzying speed from the lowest, most filthy dungeons to the rarified dining rooms of powerful officials.The humor is crazy, sometimes sophomoric, always amusing. How else can one shoot barbs at fat generals, loony CIA operatives, manipulative information ministers, and greedy "widows" brought in as props for the General's charity? How else to mock a third world country with, as one character puts it, a first world security service?By the time the mangoes actually get around to exploding, the madcap humor does begin to wear a little thin, rather like the second half of Saturday Night Live. However, the many good bits make this novel a pleasure to read.M. Feldman

Before you plunk down your money for this hefty (almost five pounds) book, it might help to know what you are buying.Above all, this book is a work of culinary history, which accounts for why the title in bold on the cover is 101 Classic Cookbooks, with 501 Classic Recipes in smaller print beneath. The food history part of the volume is very attractive, with full color reproductions and facsimile pages from each cookbook, along with an introduction for each and several longer essays by famous food persons like Alice Waters and Laura Shapiro. The cookbooks span the 20th century, from Fannie Farmer and Sarah Tyson Rorer to Thomas Keller and Mark Bittman. Recommended recipes from each appear in a box on the page, with page references to those that are actually incorporated into the 501 section of the book. This section offers hours of pleasurable browsing.What the book is not---at least not exactly---is a proper cookbook. Of the 501 recipes, some are (as the editor notes) primarily of historical interest. Others are just plain interesting and create a fine record of changing culinary tastes. There is one problem. Always wanted to try something from, say, The French Laundry Cookbook, a book that you dont happen to own? There are recipes, all right, but they are not complete. Take his Macaroni and Cheese, the one with Butter-Poached Maine Lobster with Creamy Lobster Broth and Mascarpone-Enriched Orzo. The main recipe is there, but not recipes for three essential components, the creamy lobster broth, the beurre mont, and the coral oil.  So forget it, or plunk down some more money for the French Laundry Cookbook. To be fair, most of the included recipes are not like this, but a cook will want to look carefully at a recipe before getting out the knives and bowls.The best place for this book may be the nightstand, if you are a cookbook-reader-in-bed person like me. You cant actually make Rose Levy Beranbaums Blueberry Swan Cake  (p. 627) from this book, but youll have sweet dreams.M. Feldman

Turbo Tax is an old friend of mine, and the newest version is just as efficient as ever. Yes, it offers annoying prompts for services I don't need, like audits and upgrades, but I'm used to saying "no" to those. As for the things I need---up to date information, seamless importing of financial data, transferring information from a previous year---it's all there. And for those times when I want to do the data entry myself, as opposed to following the "easy guide," there is no problem. E-filing is quite efficient, too. If you can put your hands on the records you need, why not do your taxes at home?M. Feldman

Yes, this is a kind of spy novel, set in a dreary Britain of coal miner strikes and power shortages, circa 1972. The only place thats  warm is bed. And thats where the spy, a young woman Cambridge graduate named Serena Frume, ends up, quite happily, when she falls in love with the subject of her first assignment for MI5.However, this is also a novel about writing, about literary taste, and about the shifty line between reality and imagination.  Serena and her lover, the writer T.H. Haley, both love books, but they have entirely different tastes. She prefers the real and falls in love with a mental image of Haley before she has even met him, simply by conjuring him up from the characters in his short stories. He, in turn, tries to interest her in poetry and in more avant garde fiction. Many reviewers have pointed out that Haley seems to resemble, in some respects, the young Ian McEwen. A reader will realize pretty quickly that McEwen is going to have fun with Serenas disdain for what she calls literary tricksThere is also some interesting writing in Sweet Tooth on the extent to which governments enlist the arts, either covertly or directly, to buttress political arguments.A reader interested in the spy novel aspects of Sweet Tooth might do well to beat a retreat back to Le Carr.  McEwens novel is for the bookish, readers who enjoy thinking about the kind of espionage involved in creating novels.M. Feldman

I've never owned a flexible spatula like this one, which means I've spent most of my life using square-edged spatulas in round pans. This is fine until you need to get something intact out of the pan. OXO has designed this spatula for omelets, but it works just as well for lifting the edge of a crepe (to flip it, for which I then usually use my fingers). It neatly lifts the edge of a frittata, to let the uncooked egg run beneath, or a grated potato cake, to check for browning. Someone who likes to cook will appreciate this utensil.M. Feldman

Mama's Milk is an excellent book for a young child with a newborn sibling. The detailed drawings (and an illustrated spread of facts at the back of the book) explain a process that the child himself probably does not remember, except through photographs. Although the spare, rhyming text is aimed at toddlers, there is enough factual information to hold the interest of an older child in the early elementary grades. The bilingual text will also interest this older child, and the drawings will appeal to a child of any age. This is a perfect book for a father to read to a child when mother is preoccupied with caring for the infant.M. Feldman

This lightweight plastic cutting board is well-designed. In addition to the special edge that helps funnel cut food into a pan or bowl, it has a raised edge whose material helps anchor the board on a counter so that it does not slide around. There are narrow grooves to catch juices, but the medium -sized board is not really designed for carving, say, a turkey. It's best use, I think, is as a dedicated board for cutting vegetables and fruits. It would also make a nice wedding or shower gift.M. Feldman

I generally avoid memoirs, but what drew me to Wild was its setting on the Pacific Crest Trail. I've only hiked a tiny bit of it, but someone close to me hiked the whole thing, from the Mexican border to the Canadian border. In my role as supply-box-sender (like Strayed's friend Lisa), I got a pretty good sense of the strength and determination required to undertake such a hike. It's clear from the book that Strayed possesses those qualities, too.Of course a redemption story (and this is one) is no good unless there is plenty of sin to be redeemed, and Wild is full of that: drugs, sex, bad boyfriends, a dysfunctional family, a broken marriage. The death of Strayed's mother begins the book, and grieving runs through it. This is the part I liked the least, but then I told you I don't like memoirs. If you've read Mary Karr or Tobias Woolf or Dave Eggers, you've got the picture here, and those three are better memoirists.The trail part of the story is more compelling. It seems likely to me that Strayed was in possession of the necessary distance-hiker strength and determination before she ever set foot on the trail. Her accounts of her painful feet, of her loneliness and desire (more than once) to quit, of her physical and spiritual hungers, of the people she meets and the dangers she encounters seem true and are often moving. The resupply boxes with the twenty dollar bills, the new (and well-chosen) books and some other amusing items function almost like a character. Will they be there for her or not?The book ends in a literary way, with Strayed, at the end of her hike, looking out at the Columbia River, the border between Oregon and Washington. It's clear that this is meant to be a metaphor for a better life going forward and a difficult life left behind. That's nice, but the rest of the book suggests that life is really more complicated than that.M. Feldman

Buy this book for the wonderful illustrations by Sylvia Long. The bedtime rituals  and beds of all sorts of insects will make even the smallest child laugh. There are PJs with extra legs, sets of bedroom slippers for the possessors of multiple legs, and so on. The text is a series of simple rhymes. This book would make a nice addition to the toddler bedtime shelf, alongside Goodnight Moon and Each Peach Pear Plum.M. Feldman

In my ancient student days, professors generally referred to Margaret Fuller in dismissive tones. They acknowledged her brilliance, but never failed to mention her physical homeliness and the way that she could dominate a room with her talk. In short, she made men uncomfortable, both in her own time and after her death.  (Another famous 19th century woman, George Eliot, had a similar effect; many a commentary is sure, even today, to mention her lack of physical beauty.)In Megan Marshall, Margaret Fuller has, a last, a biographer whose appreciative and sympathetic portrait may give this remarkable woman her due. The book is subtitled "A New American Life," and what a life this is, beginning with Fuller's childhood, when her difficult father gave her the kind of classical education usually reserved for boys. The family itself existed in a kind of genteel poverty (and sometimes real poverty) that made it certain that Margaret Fuller would have to work for a living and, after her father's death, support her mother and her younger siblings.The biography traces Fuller's life as a teacher and as an inspiration for other women who aspired to intellectual achievement. It follows her journey to the West (now the American middle west), where she wrote about the destruction of Native American culture. It points out the physical illnesses, including spinal curvature and migraines, which would have sidelined a less resilient person. And it details her life as a journalist in New York, writing on books and culture for Horace Greeley's Herald TribuneMost interesting to me was the account of Fuller's years in Italy during the fight for Italian unification. If there was ever an embedded journalist, 19th century style, it was she, sending eyewitness accounts back to the Tribune. Her biographer gives a particularly balanced account of her liaison with Giovanni Ossoli, of the birth of their child, and of the difficulties that attended a mother and wife who had to keep on earning a living in the midst of a revolution, all the while concealing her relationship, unorthodox for its time, from the eyes and ears even of those who loved her.The shipwreck will break your heart.Margaret Fuller: A New American Life is a detailed, scholarly biography. Marshall incorporates Fuller's actual words whenever she can, usually to good effect, although sometimes the incorporation of many short successive quotations conveys the quality of her speech but slows down Marshall's own prose. However this is a quibble. Marshall set out to let us hear Margaret Fuller's voice as it must have sounded to her contemporaries, and in this she succeeds very well.M. Feldman

This steamer's chief virtue is that it rolls up in a neat cylinder, making it easy to store in a drawer. Anther advantage is that it is silicone, which means that things like dumplings don't stick. (I tested this with gyozas.) It will hold approximately the same amount of food as a regular metal collapsible steamer. It's true that the silicone material means that the steamer can bend to fit differently sized pots, but the high handles, while making it easy to lift it out of a hot pot, limit its use to a fairly capacious pot. It won't fit easily into a saucepan; a pasta pot or dutch oven is best.M. Feldman

This appealing book for preschool age children explores the world of play as it pertains to a variety of animal species, including humans.  Each page depicts, in colorful drawings, adults engaged in play with their young; there are familiar animals, like cats and dogs, along with less familiar animals like wombats and sea lions.The youngest children will enjoy pointing and naming these animals, while an older child may be interested in the specialized names for the baby animals, names like  "calf" or "joey," some of which are common to more than one species. (Each animal is carefully identified.) There is a simple rhyming story line, which helps to build phonemic awareness in preschool children. Finally, older children may notice that "play" is sometimes "work," as in the drawings of a father helping a child learn to cook or a sea lion catching a fish.This is a beautiful little book that aims to show that all creatures love to play.M. Feldman

I hope it will be helpful to other readers to indicate what this book is and what it is not.First of all, it is a work of scholarship. It traces, with lawyerly precision, the members of the entire Hemings family and their associations with Thomas Jefferson. The use of the word "family" in the title of the book is important, as the book begins with Elizabeth Hemings, the daughter of an African slave woman and a white man. She and all of her children had relationships with Jefferson; the book is about several individuals, not just her daughter, Sally Hemings.Second, the book is meticulous in building its case for the nature of the relationships between Jefferson and the various Hemings family members. It relies on what records do exist, and it is careful not to project contemporary values onto eighteenth century relationships. Sometimes the author does speculate about how an individual might have felt or thought, but she makes it clear that it is indeed speculation.Third, it is true that the book does, at times, become repetitious. Gordon-Reed ponders every possible aspect of the Hemings "case" like a lawyer determined to present overwhelming evidence. However, although at times I did skim, I did not put the book down. It was just too interesting.Now for what the book is not. It is not popular history. Gordon-Reed is not Stephen Ambrose or David McCullough, to name two eminently readable historians. To enjoy this book requires an interest in Jefferson and a bit of patience.Nor is it the "story" of Sally Hemings and Thomas Jefferson, although that liaison is part of the book. It is about much more than that.Above all, this book is an account of how slavery distorts human relationships. Jefferson was sometimes a benevolent master. He freed several in the Hemings family. Yet his relationships with these enslaved people, some of whom were his own children, are complicated, calculated, and often painful. Everything in "The Hemingses of Monticello" underscores the truth of what another enslaved man, Frederick Douglass, would publish in his Narrative, two decades after Jefferson's death.M. Feldman

This fine historical novel is based on a period covering about one hundred years in Japanese history, from the mid-16th to the mid-17th century. Following the arrival of St. Francis Xavier, Catholic missionaries, most of them Portuguese, came to Japan to convert its people and to establish seminaries to educate native priests. Christianity took root in the areas around Nagasaki and Kyushu, in southern Japan, and at one point the converts may have totaled as many as a quarter million. Ultimately, however, the missionaries and their converts fell out of favor with the powerful Tokugawa shogunate, whose rulers began to outlaw Christianity through torture and by forcing converts to apostasize.The protagonist of Silence, Sebastian Rodrigues, arrives with a companion priest near the end of this period, when persecution has forced believers to hide their faith. Almost immediately they are forced into hiding and almost as quickly they are forced to contemplate the idea that martyrdom of some sort may be their fate. The trials that ensue test not only Rodrigues's faith, but the very concept of martyrdom as he understands it.  Even as he thinks of the death of Jesus, a type of suffering to which he aspires, he must also consider the mysterious apostasy of Ferreira, the Portuguese Provincial about whom nothing more had ever been heard. When the time comes, whose life will be the pattern for his own: Christ's sacrifice or Ferreira's renunciation?Shusaku Endo is himself a Japanese Catholic, and his novel also raises these questions: is it possible for an imported religion to adapt itself to a very different culture? And in the adaptation, will the new religion bend so deeply to accommodate differing customs that it is no longer recognizable?M. Feldman

The New York Times reviewer Janet Maslin gave Truth Like the Sun a big shout-out in her end of the year wrap-up of ten books she enjoyed in 2012. On the strength of that, I decided to read it, even though I have yet to read a good novel about newspapers and journalists. Most recently, I was disappointed in Tom Rachman's newspaper novel The Imperfectionists, but I still liked it better than this wooden account of Seattle circa 1962 juxtaposed with Seattle circa 2001.Overall, this novel feels like interesting material in search of a story. The newspaper characters are almost laughably stock: the pusillanimous editor who fears offending the local bigwigs, the solitary young crusading journalist, the rumpled and overweight "true" journalist whose time has come and gone. The subject of the newspaper's investigative journalism, Roger Morgan, impresario of the Seattle World's Fair, is a slightly more complex character, at least when he's not in the middle of one of the boring set pieces in which he surveys the fair and/or greets a visiting dignitary.In fact, you'll want to bypass some of the descriptive passages altogether, unless you live in Seattle and enjoy the touches of local color. This is a novel in which hot mugs "steam," nursing homes smell (surprise!) of disinfectant and other things, and the young reporter's hair (one of her physical assets) is compared, rather amazingly, to an oak tree.Maslin called Truth Like the Sun "a flat-out great read with the spirit of a propulsive, character-driven 1970s movie."  Well, yes, there are flat-out great reads about city life and politics that do make great movies, although it isn't this particular novel. Another author comes to mind, himself a great chronicler of the sort of police corruption at the center of Truth Like the Sun.  His books make great movies, too, like Mystic River. However this writer lives in Boston and his name is Dennis Lehane.  Perhaps he could be convinced to write a newspaper novel.M. Feldman

This great little thriller will never win a Big Book Award, but it entertains right down to the last page. It is best saved for those places where time passes slowly, the magazines are lousy and that copy of War and Peace you brought along just doesn't beckon. Gone Girl is clever enough to carry you right away from that middle coach seat you're in, the one by the lav, even when the occupant of the seat in front of you snaps his seat back into your knees, and the single remaining meal choice remaining is fish.M. Feldman

Raised From the Ground, now in English translation for the first time, is a good introduction to the work of the Portuguese writer Jose Saramago. His style takes some getting accustomed to, since it consists of long strings of subordinate clauses. It is not long, however, before the style is familiar, and the narrative line is in any case not hard to follow. The story follows the lives of members of the peasant Mau-Tempo family through the two world wars and the rise and fall of the dictator Antonio Salazar.In addition to the Mau-Tempos and the other denizens of a rural village of southern Portugal, there are three big players in the novel. The Church is represented by the recurring voice of Father Agamedes, who whispers his contempt for the peasantry into the ear of Senora Clemencia, the wife of a feudal (that's the only word for it, even if it is the 20th century) landlord. The system of vast landholdings concentrated in the hands of a very few and farmed by serfs like the Mau-Tempos is supported by the military apparatus of the State. Its primary function seems to be to put down--by intimidation, violence, and torture-- any attempt by the peasants to improve their miserable standard of living.  Church, landed aristocracy, and State are bound together; beneath them is the rural peasantry in a region where the twentieth century seems to have barely intruded.The overlapping phrases and clauses of Saramago's prose permit him to adopt a variety of voices, including that of a sarcastic narrator who pretends at times that he can't believe what he is describing, even though it is clear that he does. This translation has useful footnotes where needed to elucidate certain aspects of the history of modern Portugal, as well as to explain some jokes that do not translate. A reader unfamiliar with the history of Portugal is at no disadvantage. Indeed, the bitterest passages of commentary put one in mind of the commentaries in Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath. The determination of the privileged to remain privileged at the expense of the impoverished looks the same wherever you go.M. Feldman

This beautiful book, lavishly illustrated and engagingly written, is, I fear, going to fall into the wrong hands. Why? It looks like a so-called coffee table book (lush photos, oversized format). It would be a shame if it ended up on, well, coffee tables, to eventually be covered with old magazines or used as a handy coaster or, in better circles, to perform a merely decorative "house beautiful" function.It deserves to fall into better hands, specifically those of your favorite vegetable-growing friend or relative. Plenty has been written about Monticello, its architecture and beautiful grounds. This book is about Thomas Jefferson's vegetable gardens.Might you be interested in what varieties of lettuce Jefferson grew? What sort of insects attacked his crops? How he saved seeds and swapped them with his neighbors? Then this book is for you. You may never live in a house like Monticello, but you can put its vegetable varieties on your table.The book is divided in two. The first half focuses on Jefferson's interest in gardening and the development and restoration of the Monticello gardens. It presents a well-researched look at the state of American horticulture in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. The author, Peter Hatch, Director of Grounds and Gardens at Monticello, also pays homage to the African-American slaves whose labor built Jefferson's gardens and whose own garden plots often supplied the big house.The second half is a detailed look at many of the vegetables grown in the gardens, including cultural information. It is here where Jefferson's passion for experiment becomes clear. He was always trying new seeds, such as varieties of corn brought back by the Lewis and Clark expedition. His frustrating experiences with melon growing will be familiar to anyone who has tried. This section is organized by botanical families.Finally, there is a good index, an extensive bibliography, and a guide to sources of heirloom seeds. It's a lovely book; you can't go wrong.M. Feldman

This novel, shortlisted for the 2012 Man Booker Prize, is the kind of book that will inevitably be described as "elegant" or "subtle" or "beautiful" or "expertly crafted."  I like that last descriptor, probably because it sums up the kind of book whose admirable qualities leave you cold.The story is short, a kind of mystery wrapped around a tale of desire set in the south of France, where the protagonists are on holiday. The novel opens with a body floating in a pool. As the story develops, there are lots of clues to more than one mystery (what IS the other thing under the bed?). By the end, everybody is spying on (or peeking at) everybody else. Deborah Levy is a playwright as well as a novelist, and one feels that the dramatic qualities of this novel might have been better served by, well, a play, or maybe a film. As the beautiful but creepy and manipulative Kitty, I see Scarlett Johansson.Anyway, "Swimming Home" did not win the Man Booker and Hilary Mantel's "Bring Up the Bodies" did. That's another book full of people spying on other people, but the thing is, I loved it.M. Feldman

My wife and I have always loved cooking with cast iron. We have an old school cast iron skillet and really like the way it cooks. It distributes heat better than any other pan in the house. While we love cooking with it, we do not enjoy the cleanup and maintenance a traditional cast iron skillet requires.What we really like about this new Gorham skillet is that it cooks like a traditional cast iron skillet, but it looks and cleans us like a normal modern pan. It distributes heat well and allows you to do things traditionally requiring an old school cast iron skillet. This skillet also has a really good nonstick surface. It is a snap to clean up, and it looks really elegant on the stove or when used to serve a dish.I am very impressed with this pan, and happy to recommend it to others.

REVIEW UPDATE 4/30/2015I am downgrading this radio from 5 stars to one star after a month of using it. I have always been a sucker for these feature rich, low cost Boufeng/Pofung radios but have finally had it. This one has started malfunctioning after less than a month. This is the third Baufeng/Pofung radio I have had go out in the last year. I do not abuse these radios . . . they sit on my desk and are not dropped or otherwise stressed.Another gripe with this radio was that I could not get it to ever program with CHIRP. Yes, the instructions say to use the Baufeng software, but given I have my radio configurations saved as CHIRP configurations, it is annoying that these radios (at least the one I had) would not work with CHIRP.I love a good deal, but I am not fooling with these cheap radios any more, and will look into something more expensive that will last.ORIGINAL REVIEWThis radio is very similar to the popular and affordable Baofeng UV-5R radio. If you are familiar with the UV-5R, you will be comfortable using and programming this radio. The major upgrade between this radio and the UV-5R is that this radio (the BF-F9+) has higher power (8 watts vs 5 watts), and allows you to select the power level between 8 watts, 4 watts, and 1 watt. The advantage of this is that for longer distance communication, you can select higher power level. For nearby communication, or hitting a nearby repeater, you can turn the power level down to extend battery life.What I really like about this unit is that it packs a whole lot of features in a small affordable package. As of the time of writing this review, this unit is priced about $5 more than the UV-5R, I think the extra power is well worth spending the extra money to get this model.Things that I don't like about this radio. First is that the instructions are hard to read and dont really give all the information you need. To program the radio, you really need to connect it to the computer, and program it with software. The issue with this is that it requires a special cord, which costs almost as much as the radio itself.  Luckily, I already have the cord.Bottom line is that this is a full featured radio at an affordable cost. It is a great entry level radio into the world of HAM.

For years we have been using a shark NV22L vacuum (priced on amazon at about $150). So in this review I will compare this Samsung MotionSync to the lesser priced NV22L.As far as overall design, I like the Samsung. It is easier to maneuver, and easier to get under things. It takes a little to get used to the way the unit moves and steers, but once you get the hang of it, it is wonderful to use. It works well on both hard wood floors and carpets. The noise level for the machine is about typical.The Samsung wins hands down as far as ease of manuevering and making quick work of vacuuming a room. My only reservation about this machine is that I feel like the shark NV22L is picking up more dirt. For our floors, I am finding that the samsung does not pick up the dirt quiet as well as the shark.I am happy to have the Samsung and intend to continue to use it.

I enjoy drinking tea, and so am always looking for a way to heat water quickly. I have a tea kettle for the stove top, but it takes a while to bring a kettle of tea water to a boil. So, I was excited to get the chance to try this KitchenAid electric kettle.I am very impressed. The kettle makes a pot of boiling water really fast. I like the fact that the handle remains cool to the touch, so after the water boils, you can directly hold the handle to pour the water. The water pours from the spout nicely, without running back up the spout . . . a problem I have had with other products.We have really hard water where I live, and I have found that products like this last longer if you only use RO or bottled water, so I will not be using tap water in this unit. I want it to last.A great product that looks good on the cabinet.

There is a lot to like about this little screwdriver. First I like the two position handle. I prefer the "pistol" orientation as it is shown in the picture. This is best for big jobs as it is easier on the writes. I also am impressed with the battery life and the torque the screwdriver provides. Plenty of power for most jobs. I also like the little LED light that lights the work area when you are using it. It comes with a nice assortment of screwdriver heads.The main limitation of this screw driver is that it is a single speed. I would have preferred if it was variable speed. The second minor quibble is that it would be nice if the screwdriver heads were in some way attached to or in the unit. They are in a seperate little plastic box, which means over time they are easy to lose.Bottom line this is a nice unit at a reasonable price.

I was looking for a heavy duty, large glass mixing bowl, and was having difficulty finding one. I was pleased to finally find one that looked good on Amazon. I received the bowl, and have been very happy with it. I use it for making cold process soap and for making tea. It works great for both applications. I am happy and feel like I got a good deal on a great product.

I spent more on my last grill than I did on my first car. With the cost of modern full featured grills, you want to do everything thing possible to protect them from the elements. Hence, I was excited to get the chance to try this grill cover. I am very pleased with it, and feel it provides better protection than grill covers I have used in the past. I like the fact that it covers the grill all the way to the ground, and the fact that it is waterproof fabric, to protect the electronics in my Louisianna Pellet Grill.The cover is heavy duty, fits my grill well, and I am happy to recommend it to others.

I make cold processed soap at home, so needed a good stick blender. I have found that this product works great. Soap making puts a heavy load on a stick blender, and this one has worked flawlessly. I have used it pretty hard, and it is holding up well. I am happy with the product and happy to recommend it to others.

My wife and I use a lot of curry in our cooking. Locally we can only find small bottles which are insanely expensive. I was pleased to find this product in Amazon in a large bottle. This is excellent quality curry, and coming in a pound jar, you get a good price. I have been happy with the quality of the product, and happy to get it at a fair price.

I have been very pleased with the Cocoa Butter. I use it as a superfat ingredient in making soap. The product is clean and free of debris, and works great as a soap ingredient. I think this works well, and is an excellent value. I will definitely order again.

I purchased this product in the hopes of improving the Brix measurements on my greenhouse hydroponics vegetables. The publicity material indicated that it would be used in conjunction with traditional hydro chemicals. The issue that I had with this product is that it almost immediately started causing problems with clogging in both my dutch bucket system and my NFT lettuce system. It appears that it will come out of solution and clog filters, small lines and emitter tips.I really think this is probably a great product, and I believe it works great for soil gardening, but this review is just a heads up for those that might be thinking about using it in hydroponics. If you want to use it for that, start by buying a small amount to make sure you do not introduce a clogging problem.

This soap cutter works much better than using a kitchen knife. It allows you to apply the force directly above the blade, to get a perfect and straight cut every time. When you are ready to take your soap making to the next level, and get really neat and attractive bars, this soap knife will do the trick for you.

This is a great little salt pig that my wife leaves out on the counter. We do lots of cooking, and this product gives us quick and easy access to the salt. It is well made, and is attractive on your counter. I am happy to recommend it to others.

My wife and I moved to Himalayan Salt after reading the health benefits. We have been very happy with the product, and we really like the taste, and now it is all we use.I was happy to find this Sherpa Salt on Amazon. It works great and is a good value.

I use this fragrance on dryer balls as a replacement for chemically laden dryer sheets. It gives a wonderful aroma to the clothes in the dryer, and really works well.I have been very pleased with the NOW brand essential oils, and find them to be high quality and an excellent value.

This is wonderful scent, and great for making soap. I used it in combination with Frankincense to make a spicy smelling Christmas soap. Everyone loved the Frankensense and Myrrh soap, and it made wonderful Christmas presents.I have been very pleased with the Now essential oils. I find them to be high quality and an excellent value.

I found this product so tiny as to be not usable for making soap. It would be helpful if vendor would picture it with something that would give size comparison. The dimensions in the description are given in cm, which I do not have an intuitive feel for. It needs to be twice as big to be useful.
I had trouble finding these fuses locally, so was pleased to find them on Amazon. I ordered them, and they work great. I feel like I got a good deal, and am glad to have the spares.

This mold is great for making cold processed soap. I have found that it makes the perfect size "batch" for my needs. It holds its shape well when you pour in the soap, and it is easy to remove the soap brick without damaging the soap. Overall, I am delighted with the product.

We enjoy making natural facial cream, lip balm and other beauty products. These are nice little bottles for holding our creations. They seal well, and can be used over and over. I have been completely pleased with them.

These things really work! My wife is very picky, and does not automatically like new ideas. I did convince her to try these, and she is a believer now. They really do allow you to dry your clothes quicker, and without static cling. She uses a few drops of Beaumont essential oil on them, and it gives the clothes a nice, natural aroma. Great product!

After two months of these egg cases sitting in the sun in my greenhouse, only one hatched. It produced about 20 or 30 preying mantis. The other case has shown no signs of life. Of the one that produced mantises, a reasonable number have survived, and they are eating the aphids. Given the rather low percentages and small number, and the relatively expensive shipping charges, I wish the vendor would bundle more of these in an order, or give price breaks on shipping for bundling preying mantis and ladybugs in a single order.

It is hard to find a glass pitcher of this size. I was happy to be able to find it on Amazon. The glass pitcher is heavy duty, and perfect for my application, which is to make cold processed soap. The pitcher is easy to pour from, has a nice solid handle, and is easy to clean. Good product at a fair price.

I purchased these primarily to control aphids in my hydroponic greenhouse. I am unable to purchase them locally in the winter time, so am pleased to have found these on Amazon. Overall, a reasonable deal, even with shipping. I have ordered two batches. Both batches had good percentage of live and kicking bugs. The ladybugs distribute on aphid infected plants, and begin to eat and hence control them. The ladybugs then mate and lay eggs. The eggs quickly hatch and form little larvae that really eat the aphids.I have found that over time the population is not self sustaining, so I need to order new bugs every few months. I have never been able to get them to self-propagate in the greenhouse. If anyone has any ideas on how to be successful at this, I would appreciate hearing from you in the comments below.

I have been happy with the performance of this device. I have had the issue that others have mentioned that it clogs. I find though, even when it is clogged, it will produce good holes in the ground. It is sturdy, and makes quick work of aerating the yard. I am happy with the product and can recommend it to others.

I have struggled for years to get good wireless coverage in my home. I have a two story house, and there are several internal rock walls, which creates a challenge in getting good coverage throughout the house. So, when I was offered the chance to review this product, I jumped on it.First, as wireless network gear goes, this was relatively painless to set up. Basically, you plug it in somewhere between your dead spot and the main wireless router. You then connect to the Range Extender as you would a wireless network. This allows you to access a very simple setup routine which helps you get it connected. Then, once it is connected, it disappears from your wireless choices, and you simply connect to your normal wireless network. The device works seamlessly in the background.I did verify that I now have good connections in the deadspots in my house.It did take a little work to find just the right spot to make it work. The setup software warns you if you have it in a spot that is weak in signal. This of course motivates you to move the extender closer to the router. But, you can get it to the point that it connects to the router, but does not light up your dead spots. It took me about 10 or fifteen minutes of playing with it to get just the right spot where it had a solid connection to the wireless router, and provided a good strong signal to the rest of the house.So, this turned out to be a relatively painless setup, and I now have good coverage in my house for the first time. Great Product!

This is a great BP monitor that gives rock solid readings. Unfortunately, most of the home BP units I have tried give inconsistent and inaccurate readings. For something as important as blood pressure, it is worth it to spend a little extra and get a unit that will give you accurate readings.I have tried over a dozen home BP units,a nd have found the Omron product line to be the best. All the omrom units I have tested have given very accurate and reproducible results.In choosing between the omron product line, it really just depends on how many bells and whistles you want. This one will sync wirelessly with your tablet or smartphone via bluetooth. If you are tracking blood pressure to report back to your Dr., this is probably a useful feature. If you are just occasionally monitoring your BP at home, one of the lower cost Omron units might be better suited for you.Bottom line is that I am very pleased with this unit, and am happy to recommend it to others.

There is a vast array of home BP monitors out there with an array of "Bells and Whistles". At the end of the day, though, what really matters is the accuracy and consistency of the measurements. I have tried over a dozen different home BP measurement units,and unfortunately, most do not give accurate and reliable readings. In fact, a number of the units I have tried would suggest I need to be on BP medicine, when in fact my BP is fine.I have found the Omron line of home BP measurement units to give very accurate, reliable and reproducible results. One of the things I like about the omron devices is the stiff arm cuff. I have found that these stiff cuffs help give accurate and consistent readings as compared to the soft bendable cuffs. (I should also add that I have not found any of the wrist BP units that would give accurate readings).So, the bottom line is that I give this Omron product high marks because it gives me reliable readings that I can depend on. In addition to that, this unit also has all the bells and whistles. If you want to chart your BP, you can download an ap and use this with your tablet or smartphone. For those that are monitoring their BP daily, and reporting results back to the Dr., this is a useful feature.

This perfume comes in a very elegant little bottle that will look nice on any bathroom counter. The bottle itself has what to me looks like a japanese design or theme. The perfume itself I would describe as a sweet smell. It smells good on my wife and she likes it. To me it is a rather simple fragrance and not overpowering and not overdone. I like it and my wife is pleased with it.

I could not get this to work with Android. I have four android devices, some less than a year old. When I tried to download and install the required Ap, I was told that none of my devices were compatible. Note in the listing title it says "QardioArm Wireless Blood Pressure Monitor (Apple iOS and Android)". Note that being incompatible with 4 out of 4 modern android devices would indicate that this unit is not generally Android compatible. The company WEB site lists it as Android compatible, but in the instructions (that you read after you buy the unit) just mentions iphone and apple devices.The second issue I had with this unit is the instructions are almost unreadable. Very tine text, which is light grey, on a white background.I can not comment further on this, as the software would not load on my android devices, and the unit requires the link with a phone or tablet to work.If you have an iPhone, you probably should ignore my review and read the reviews from iphone users. If you have an Android, you need to dig pretty deep before ordering and be sure this will work with your device.Bottom Line: I have over a half dozen different BP monitors. At the end of the day, the best one in my mind is the Omron BP7911T. It just works. Accurate, reproducible results. It has the stiff style cuff, which I have found gives the most accurate readings. To me BP monitoring is not about bells and whistles, but about easily getting data you can trust, out of the box.

This is another great Moen product. I have been a long time Moen customer, and when we built our house we used Moen faucets throughout. I really like the style of this particular line of faucets. This particular unit is a soap dispenser. It looks good and has the quality you expect from Men products.I am happy to recommend this product to others.

I am always interested in new technology applications, and so was interested in this device. The bottom line is I really don't see that this product is useful for anything. Almost anywhere you are, you can get local weather and UV data with a variety of free weather apps. The free apps are driven from more high end weather equipment which would likely be more useful than this device. So, look at your phone and see a bluetooth connection to this device, if you are within range, or just look at the weather app connected to local professional high precision equipment? In my mind, I just don't see the need, benefit or use of this device.In addition the instructions were not readable, and it is confusing to try to use.

I take home made soup to work almost every day for lunch. The great thing about this product is that it does not leak. Period. All the other things I have tried do not seal well, and I end up with soup in leaked out in my lunch bag. This is a nice shaped dish for soup. I will say that I do not put the lid in the microwave, as I am so happy to finally find a soup bowl with a lid that is secure, I do not want to take any chances warping the lid.This is a great product at a fair price.

I really like this product. Call me crazy, but I can taste the difference between this product and normal salt. Yes, it is salty, but it has a rich deep flavor that is more robust and more varied than the simple salty "bite" you get from table salt. I have been especially pleased using this in soup recipes. It gives the broth a richer and deeper flavor. I have completely stopped using table salt and replaced it with this salt. I supplement with iodine as this is not an iodized salt.
This is a nice salt or pepper mill. I use it for Himalayan salt, and have been very pleased with the product. It is well made and it works well.

Quinoa is a very healthy grain, and an excellent alternative to rice. Quinoa is more nutrient rich than most grains we consume and is high in fiber. In really trying to watch the glycemic index in my diet, I have found this to be an excellent way to get a little grain in my diet.This is a great product. The Quinoa is clean, and comes in a convenient resealable bag. While I got this sample free as part of the vine program, I plan to order more. An excellent product I am happy to recommend to others.

This is the fourth bloop pressure monitor that I have purchased, and the first one that is really accurate and reproducible. Many of the cheaper units on the market are almost random number generators. You can take your BP several minutes apart and get drastically different results. This unit gives reproducible measurements and stable readings. Using this to monitor my BP several times a day has allowed me to make lifestyle changes that have lowered my BP naturally. I am glad I got this, and and glad I did not have to take BP medicine.
Very pleased with this product. Has helped me rebuild the soil in my Garden. I am pleased with the product and happy to recommend to others.

For those interested in taking MSM supplement, this is a good product at an excellent value. I prefer the powdered form, which this comes in. It makes it easy to use as a supplement, or to add it to home beauty products like soap or beauty cream. I am pleased with the quality and value of this product.

This is an excellent product. I use it to make home brew beauty creams. It comes in a large rather ugly chunk wrapped in saran wrap.
