UPDATE MAY 2015Now available in EVEN FEWER colors than before. Yay! :) It's a shame our society offers men so few choices when it comes to color. If I were to find a comparable garment available in 10 or 15 colors instead of just a few dull ones ... I'd jump ship in a heart beat.ORIGINAL REVIEWI love these Henley style t-shirts from Carhartt, I only wish they were available (meaning able to ship) in my size in more colors. I have quite a few and love the easy fit, comfortable feel and tough wearing durability over time. But when I try to order in other than muted colors (black, gray, very dark green, etc.), they're always out of stock in my size. Well, I'll keep trying as I really love how these shirts wear.  I think I have 2 black, 3 dark green, 1 red, 1 gray at this point. And I'll be back for more!

PHASE 1 - OPENING, INSPECTING, ADJUSTING, INDOOR TESTING:I was very excited to find a pair of walking poles for what felt like such a reasonable price and with such consistently great reviews.  I found the package easy to open, the product within in perfect condition and the instructions on adjustment and use easy to find and well written.  I adjusted the poles to varying heights (shared by family of differing heights) and got a feel for the locking mechanism easily even without using the well written instructions which do cover how this is done. The spring inside the pole does seem suitable for adding some shock absorbing capability. Comes with 4 rubber caps for the metal tip along with cups for preventing the poles from sinking into soft soil when being used.PHASE 2 - In UseI took these poles out for a long walk on a nature trail recently and I really liked how they handled. They supported me well, were easy to extend and lock into walking position and just as easy to unlock and collapse back into storage position. The rubber tips on the poles provided good "footing" on both gravel and wooden walking surfaces (a board walk, in this case) and were just as tightly secured to the ends of the poles at the end of our walk as at the beginning. The wrist straps were handy and never got in the way.I've seen some questions raised about how the poles support the full weight of the person using them, and thus far I've had no issues with this at all. I'll keep you posted as more uses of these poles provide more insight into their durability, usability, etc.

I've been using this cartridge in my Waterman Phileas pens for a long time and love them. It also fits and works perfectly in my recently purchased JinHao "Classical Chinese Dragons Playing with the Pearl Carved 3D Fountain Pen ". I noticed some JinHao buyers weren't sure what refills to use, but I find these Waterman's work perfectly.  The ink flow from this cartridge is a very opaque black, none of that watered down looking ink some cartridges deliver. A classic that just keeps on working.

I bought a box of 10 boards which arrived in perfect condition. I love working with this material, but make sure you have a really sharp knife for cutting. This board is worth taking care of. Excellent product, fair price, safe packaging, I'd definitely buy it again.

UPDATE OCTOBER 2015This pen has developed a major problem with the ink magazine leaking HUGE drops of ink onto the page. I'm not sure what the problem is. I'm using the same brand of ink that I started with and now every time I try to write, the pen  drops a large drop of ink on the paper. I'll try cleaning it and replacing the ink to see if the problem goes away, but this certainly won't do. I've been using fountain pens for over 40 years and I've never seen one do this before.UPDATE JULY 2015I have been using this pen for several months now, and while I still find it a gorgeous pen to write with, I am encountering difficulties with ink changes. The first cartridge went through the pen just fine, but when I changed to another Waterman ink cartridge (same brand and color as the first one I used), it took a VERY long time for the ink to work its way through to the tip and begin writing normally. How long? Imagine writing 200 words and still seeing only faded color coming through the tip. I've gone through this twice now and I can't say any other fountain pen I've used (and I've had about 20 over the years) displayed this behavior. In other words, if I were to take my Waterman Phileas, my Lamy fountain pen and this pen, wash them all in cool water, and load them with new cartridges, the other two pens would be writing fine very quickly. This pen seems to take days after an ink change for the normal flow of ink to return to the tip. I will try a cartridge of Lamy ink next and see if that helps. Downgrading my review to LIKE ... ink changes are a big part of life with fountain pens, and they should be quick and easy. This one ... not so far. Mystery not solved.There are pens ... and then there are pens. :)  Wow ... this one is just amazing.SHORT STORYMUCH more than I would have reason to hope for given the price. I frankly would be surprised to find this pen, in this form, available for it's original listed price of $100, but to get it for the current price is just amazing.  The photos from the seller don't do it justice, so I've added my own.  Very beautiful, very high quality and writes like a dream.  Excellent, all the way around.  Whether or not it suits your style is another matter, but now you'll have enough information to choose wisely.LONG STORYI saw this pen listed as an item I might be interested in because I'd purchased the Lamy Al-Star (which I love).  I clicked on the link and was rather taken back by what I saw.  The low quality images and low price lead me to believe that this might be a low quality item. Then I read the reviews.  Didn't sound low quality to me.  For the price, it seemed a safe bet, so I gave it a try. WOW ... what a gorgeous find.PACKAGINGThe pen arrived safely in a lined and padded wooden box, protected by an outer cardboard box, protected by a bubble-wrap sleeve, packed inside a bubble-wrap envelope. Safe?  You bet.  And in 100% perfect condition. Packaging was all easy to open and in moments I was looking at my new pen.THE BOXI have paid considerably more for pens over the years, but I've never had one come in a box this nice. I'm not sure what the wood is, but it's got a lacquer finish and gold printing and a lining that's to die for.  A small catalog is included inside the box, and it's as classy as the rest.  To be totally fair, I might expect to pay the asking price for this whole item, box + pen ... just for the box.THE BODYWhen I picked up this pen, I immediately noted its weight. For some of you who complain about how light Lamy's and other modern fountain pens are, this one is no light weight. It feels very hefty in the hand. Beefy.  And yet the details on it (see photos) are incredibly fine and delicate (though not apparently fragile.  The pen arrives with the cap screwed onto the body in the closed position. The cap can also be screwed onto the back of the pen (see photos) for a longer writing instrument, the weight of the cap adding wonderfully to the balance of the pen while writing.THE NIBThe nib is gorgeous and works really well, putting down what I'd call a fine, smooth line of ink.  It took a few minutes for the ink to penetrate through to the writing tip of the nib, but after it did, smooth sailing.  Those who are nib geeks can probably tell you more about how and from what it's made, but I know it's gorgeous and works really well. Super smooth writing on both cream smooth journal pages or simple spiral bound notebook pages.THE DETAILSThe company says they strive to blend modern pen making technology with decoration inspired by traditional Chinese cultural icons.  I'm not expert on either, but my layman's impression is they scored big time.  One thing that struck me, aside from the detail of the "sculpt" of the dragon was the alignment.  Whether in the closed (cap over nib) or writing (cap on the back) positions, the eyes of the cap and body dragons line up perfectly ... not close ... not pretty good ... perfectly.  I can't remember the last time anything I bought lined up perfectly.  The attention to detail here is very visible. The quality of the characters on the cap is so crisp and clean.  Just delightful.WHO MIGHT NOT LIKE ITIf you're not into eastern cultural images or pens that feel weighty in your hand, this pen might not appeal to you. But I can say as someone who has traditionally purchased light weight fountain pens of either modern German or turn of the last century French design, I absolutely love this fountain pen, both as a collectible item and as a writing instrument.GAMER ALERTI am the game master (Dungeon Master) for an active D&D game, and this pen is sure to score points when I use it to make pertinent notes on the game in my Dragon Journal.  :)  I'm just sayin' ...PRICEI can't get over how "beyond reasonable" the price for this pen and box set is. Given the visual, tactile and writing qualities, I would expect to pay a lot more than this. If I was in any kind of shop that dealt in this kind of item and saw it in a display case, I'd be guessing on many times higher price tag. If this sounds like something that might be up your ally, treat yourself. You won't be disappointed, I'd venture to guess.INKTakes the same Waterman fountain pen cartridges I've been using for years with my Phileas fountain pens and writes wonderfully well using that ink. Also comes with a refillable mechanical cartridge (screw the piston down, dip into the ink reservoir, un-screw the piston back up to pull ink into the cartrdige, click into pen).The biggest fun, completely satisfying pen surprise I've experienced in years. :)

Many years ago, I purchased a small leather pad holder that took small notepads that gave you a 2"x3" writing space, with another 3/8" or so above that for binding (like this one, a staple).  The overall page size was 2" x 3.375", and the usable size was 2"x3".  That is NOT the case with this Rhodia "2x3" pad.Made in France, it's clear that his is not a standard US paper size, listed on the cover as 5.2x7.5cm.  Someone noticed that, including the binding, it's almost 3" long (2.9 to be more accurate) and has tried marketing it to US buyers as a 2"x3" pad, which it is not in any sort of functional way. With .5875" of paper unusable above the perforation, this is, in effect, a 2"x2.3125" pad, with .5875" of unusable binding.  To market it as a 2"x3" pad is a misrepresentation, to say the least.  While I will use this pad, I will also be looking for a real 2"x3" pad to replace it as soon as possible.The pad itself is made of high quality materials and I'm sure will work just fine for tiny notes, but the description should be changed to read "Rhodia Classic Orange Notepad 2x2.3125.

We were able to make good ice spheres with this tray (5 stars), but it is a little tricky to get the water in the first few times (3 stars), until you get the hang of it. Once you understand what's going on with the water flow, you can pretty intuitively get the fill correct.  If the fill isn't correct, of course, the sphere inside won't be complete.  We like the final result, they're fun and as other reviewers have noted, don't interfere with drinking as much as cubes can. My step-daughter also pointed out that, unlike some soft ice cube trays we've tried, there was no funny after-taste with these (5 stars). Some of the soft trays we've tried before left the ice tasting chemically. That wasn't the case with these.  Overall, I give 4 stars and know we will use this tray again and again.

I have been using Lamy fountain pains for many years and love them to death! :)  This is the first time I noticed violet as an available ink refill color (perhaps my oversight, not sure how long they've been available) but I HAD to try it out as purple is my main theme color.INSTALLATION - 5 stars, same as all other Lamy cartridges I've used before.  Push in firmly, wait for the SNAP as the ink tube penetrates the end of the cartridge, wait a few seconds.LINE QUALITY/FLOW - I give this ink 5 stars for flow and line quality ... it literally made a perfect line the first time the nib touched the paper ... NO skip at all, not even on the first stroke.  It continues to lay down really nice, consistent, smooth lines.COLOR/HUE - (personal preference) The shade of purple ink is very pleasing to my eye.  I'm not sure what international standard color system you use, so I can't give you an absolute reference, but I'd describe it as a strong, "very slightly to the red" side of purple ... it's definitely NOT a blueish purple (not the color of the petals on a violet flower) but neither is so red as to be called a magenta. Perhaps a mulberry?  Whether or not you will like it depends on your preferences, but I do like it. See attached photo sample. I should note that I feel the color compliments the hue of the Al-Star purple Lamy pen body.DRYING QUALITIES - the ink dries fast enough that I haven't had it smear on me yet in 2 days of heavy writing.  I should note that the hue/tone change slightly as the ink dries. It starts off a bit lighter tone and slightly redder hue and dries to the darker/bluer, ending up in a medium mulberry (see photo).TRANSLUCENT/OPAQUE - I'd describe this as a medium opaque ink. Some inks, when you look at droplets of them on a bright surface, you can't see any trace of light reflecting back through the ink droplet ... completely opaque. This ink allows some light reflection back through the ink. So if you want a seriously opaque purple ink, this might not work for you.  I would NOT describe this as a watery, or "thin" or overly transparent ink.  It puts down a line I like very much.I will update this review in the future if any new properties of this ink come to light.

As a frequent reviewer on Amazon, I was offered a free sample of this product in exchange for an open and honest review ... that means if I don't like it, I'm expected to say so, and why, and I have dinged products in the past for shortcomings I felt the try had.THE SHORT FORMFive stars, love it, no complaints!THE REST OF THE STORYPACKAGING: The product arrived in tact, undamaged,  in easy to open packaging. SIZE/COLOR: I received the Blue model, and it appears as shown in the Amazon photos, dimensions check out. My step-daughter loved the color. START-UP: the unit arrived at least partially charged and fired up by pressing and holding the power-on button on the top, at which time a blue light displays and tones sound. ASSOCIATE TO DEVICE: On my Galaxy S5, I then went to Settings > Bluetooth and a) turned on my Bluetooth, b) allowed the device to be visible to other devices and c) hit scan.  The S5 quickly found the speaker. I then selected Call Audio and Media Audio. I did a quick test with a YouTube video and the speaker played and sounded very good. WATER TEST: I then gave the unit to my step-daughter who gave it five stars after using it (at 11 y.o., no instructions from me) for a long shower. She reports:A. Speaker stayed paired to her S3 at further range than Bluetooth speakers she's used beforeB. Suction cup worked very well in shower,  strong grip, no failureC. Great sound quality on music she played, no problems staying connectedD. Battery didn't run out after long showerE. Controls (play, pause, next, previous, switch to phone) worked easily and we'llF. Volume controlled by using phone volume controls (none on speaker)G. Waterproofing worked even when unit took direct spray.H. Loved size, shape, color.I. Recharges using USB cord that plugs with round jack into sealed port on speaker (open waterproof seal to charge)J. Looks forward to using again ...and again.Everyone here is 100% satisfied with this handy, easy to use, great sounding, waterproof speaker. It gets 5 stars from both my step-daughter and me.

LAP GEAR SCHOOLHOUSE LAP DESK:  Reviews for this product ranged wildly before I purchased mine (about 80% pro, 20% con) and I was a bit cautious about ordering it.  Some reviews sounded fantastic, others very disappointed.  I prefer to order when most reviews are 4 or 5 stars, and since the clear majority on this product WERE 4 or 5 stars, I did place an order.  But that 20% of bad reviews did have me a bit worried.  My lap desk arrived about 2 weeks ago, and I've been using it a lot since.  Here's my experience thus far.PACKAGE: First off, the package in which the desk arrived was entirely appropriate and there was no damage to either the wood or finish.WOOD/FINISH:  Both the wood used and the finish on this item were similar to the other wooden surface lap desk we own ... suitable to the task, but not OVERLY durable.  This item was not designed to take abuse. If you take care of this item, it should last a good long time and look and perform great.  If you play rough with it, it will show wear. I feel totally comfortable using my rubber footed laptop or a leather or paper journal on this surface.  I would NOT use a wire spiral bound notebook on this surface without putting something underneath it.  If I need/want to take notes in a wire notebook, I lay down a linen towel first to protect the finish.  The FEEL of the item is very satisfying, but NOT heavy.HINGES:  The hinged lid opened just fine the first time, closed without difficulties, and has continued to do so since, with NO issues.  The lid is not loosely mounted at all, it's all quite secure. BUT, the hinges used to mount the lid do allow for a little natural wiggle as there is play in the mechanism of the hinges themselves. If you grip the lid and try to move it about a bit, it will wiggle, but this is normal for the kind of hinges used.  The arm hinge on the right side is designed to hold the lid in the open position when desired (which it does with no issues), and the mechanism which allows for this "lock open" feature is not a hard "CLICK" lock, but a more gentle rounded notch, which will wiggle just a bit, but not objectionably so for the intended use.  I've seen this sort of hinge used before, and this one behaves like all the other ones I've seen. The two simple butt hinges used between the lid and the base also have a certain amount of natural wiggle in them, again nothing objectionable and all very normal for the type of hing it is, nor will these hinges render the motion of the lid awkward or undesirable in any way.  But, if you're expecting completely smooth, wiggle free, click-lock functionality, then look for a desk that runs about $200 or more.  COULD the manufacturer have chosen more high-precision hinges? Sure ... but you wouldn't be paying in the neighborhood of $40 for the desk any more.  So, my assessment is, given the price range, I think the hinges will be just fine and I am not at all disappointed. As a counter point, I bought a wooden writer's box 20 years ago which has incredible hinges that are smooth as glass and wiggle free.  Today such a box would run well over $200, and I think it cost me about $150 back then.MOUNTING HARDWARE:  That's the hinges themselves.  There were also some comments about the mounting of the hinges being flimsy.  Well, when you mount hinges in relatively thin (between 5/16" and 3/8" thick) pieces of wood with relatively small screws (long screws aren't an option with thin wood), it's not the sort of set up I'd suggest turning over to a child to play with.  This is a relatively delicate piece of work designed for use by careful grown ups, not a child proof "throw it around and see what it can take" sort of piece.  The way I use such items, I think it should last for many years, as some reviewers suggest theirs did (I believe one person quoted something around 10 years).  Would I jerk the lid on this unit around with all my strength or pick it up, fully loaded, by the open lid?  No.  Would I open and close it during normal use without fear of it being damaged, by all means, yes. I understand that some of us need "field grade" pieces for use outdoors or on construction or manufacturing sites.  I would not recommend this item for such heavy use. But for use in my home for my paper and PC based writing, I'm totally convinced it will work out just fine.SIZE: Some folks took issue with the size of this lap desk not being quite as big as they though it would be.  At about 18" x 14", the size of the lap desk surface is about 2" longer and 4" inches deeper than the laptop I use, (keeping in mind that 2" of the depth is the pencil shelf area in the back, behind the hinges).This provides an overall surface space which I find totally adequate for using my Dell Latitude E6530 or any of the paper journals or notebooks I use.  Some very large art pads might be an issue.INTERIOR: The inside of this unit was a real treat to discover.  There are two compartments, one running along the left (for pencils and smaller items) and one larger compartment for pads, tablets, etc.  It's felt lined (not sure exactly what fabric) and really wonderful.  The interior of this piece really gives it a special feel that I love.LAP INTERFACE:  A lap desk ... sits on your lap. :)  So what's the surface of this one like underneath, where it comes in contact with the lap? Think black beanbag.  It's a felt-like feel, easy to form around the different configurations of lap you present (straight legged, crossed, etc.) and I have had NO issues with comfort at all.  Very easy, very cozy.GAMER ALERT: If you've ever played Dungeons and Dragons or any another table-top, face to face role playing game that requires the person running the game to do some portion of their work behind a screen, this item is a total "deity-send". :)  Having played and run RPG's for about 20 years, it hit me about a week into owning this item ... "OMG! ... I can use this as a GM (game master) screen! It's perfect"  The game master often needs to perform tasks the rest of the players aren't intended to see, such as rolling dice.  The felt lined interior chamber of this lap desk is PERFECT for rolling dice (stable, hidden, completely self-contained and, best of all, QUIET!)! And the "stay open" locking hinge means you don't have to use one hand or some home-made contraption to keep the lid open while you roll the dice, take notes, or do whatever it is you do.  Got miniature figures you don't want your players to see until they make their appearance in Act 2, Scene 3?  Keep them in the handy side compartment! Whether you run your game from a laptop or paper or both, this work surface has you covered.  I really think the manufacturer should hook up with game stores ... they'd definitely move a bunch of these!For the money I paid, I have absolutely no complaints about this lap desk.  It's a joy to use, and properly taken care of, should provide me with years of use and excellent appearance and aesthetics. If it all falls to crumbs in a short while, I'll be sure to come back here and tell you the whole story.  If you want a lap desk of this design that is bigger, tougher, ready for field use and totally wiggle free, expect it to be a lot heavier and a lot more expensive.

I've tried getting my wife the classic small Victorinox knives before (opaque red and transparent green) and they just don't tend to stick around.  They get lost or misplaced, and in no time, she's borrowing mine again.  Why?  The little classic single color knife just doesn't appeal to her sense of design, at all.  It's boring, masculine and not at all fun, from her feminine point of view.When I saw this Matrioshka model in a local VX store, I asked my wife what she thought of it, and she instantly took a shine to it.  "It's kind of cute!" So I did what any loving husband would do and ordered it for her the first chance I got.  And she loves it.  It reflects her tastes (and her homeland culture) far better than the classic red or groovy green I'd gotten her in the past, and it has a fun "Oooo, let me see that" factor when she takes it out to use it among friends.But let's be real ... if I asked my lovely wife right now what she thought of this little gift, she'd probably say "It's nice ... I like it ... it's fine" ... because it's a knife, and she's really not "into" knives.  But that's totally OK with me .... because I am. :)

I will start this review by saying I am not an audiophile with demanding expectations of low cost ear buds.  I purchased these for listening to training on my computer, listening to music now and then, and for general use at work and at home around my computer.  That said, these are THE best fitting, most comfortable ear buds I've ever owned.THE USUAL PROBLEMS (for me)> Too large and don't nest well into my ear, and fall out too easily..> Ill shaped and don't conform well to the shape of my ear, and fall out too easily.> Both too large and ill shaped ... and fall out too easily.> Small enough to slide too deeply into the outer ear canal, where a partial seal is created, making them painful to pull out.WHAT PANASONIC GOT RIGHTI've never seen a pair of ear buds designed with this shape before.  I'm not saying they haven't been designed before, but I've certainly never seen it.  The base of the bud fits well in the larger part of the ear while the more tubular part of the bud nestles into the outer part of the ear canal ... each portion of the bud seats well in the different part of the ear it's designed to fit in.  Too many buds I've had over the years went for "nesting in the outer ear only" (which usually doesn't work, as the fit isn't very snug) or "nesting in the more inner portion ear".  These are the first I've had that do both, and they fit me to a T and stay in place for hours comfortably.The sound quality has been very good thus far and I have no complaints what soever.  Given the price, I'm really impressed with how nice these are.  I wouldn't trade them for anything I've tried before.

A long time owner of many a Swiss Army Knife, a Swiss Tool and an assortment of other Swiss gear, I've been a fan of Victorinox for a long, long time. So when I decided to treat myself to a new knife/tool this birthday, my heart turned to my favorite Swiss manufacturer and I went browsing through their products until my eyes landed on the Victorinox Cybertool 29.  For my taste, some of the larger S.A.K.s are over-full of items while others too sparse ... the Cybertool 29 hits the mark just right in my opinion, with the right blend of blades, screw drivers and other tools to handle most of the situations that actually come up in my life as a commuter / IT professional and picnicker and camper with none that seem useless extras.  The IT tools are very well designed for use supporting most PC's and laptops, including a pet peeve item of mine, the little hex head you need to tighten the little nuts that secure D-SUB connectors.  The toothpick and tweezers are long time favorites and happily present on this knife, along with a functioning ball point and long steel pin.  The surprise item in all this for me turned out to be the small screw driver that nests in the helix of the cork screw and is well designed for tightening the screws in glasses, another thing I end up doing from time to time in  my life as a wearer of spectacles.  The 3.5x1" design is compact and very comfortable in my pockets (not true of some of the super-wide S.A.K.s) and packs such a large number of useful items I really think it may be my all time favorite.UPDATE - OCTOBER 2014STILL my favorite Swiss Army Knife of all time, this unit is a real gem. After 1 year's use in tight places, it's my go-to tool for those tiny little screws that a lot of mini-driver sets don't handle well, and the blades and other tools are, as you'd expect from Swiss Army, just the best.

My step-daughter asked me to order this using Prime shipping advantages to make it in time for a friend's birthday party.  The doll was apparently her top priority gift "wish" and was not available in any of our local stores for 30 miles in any direction.  I ordered it using my Prime shipping options and it arrived several hours before the party in perfect condition.  And the results?  BIG success. :)  Thanks Monster High and Amazon for a great birthday treat for two young girls.

About 15 years ago, I stumbled across my first Wenger Swiss Army watch in a mall kiosk, as part of a promotion they were running. I picked it up for about $80 on special sale, about 1/3 the normal price at the time.  While not 100% identical to this model, it was about 90% the same ... dark blue face, large, easy to read light numbers, similar shapes (though the crystal was slightly domed and the blue finish matte).  It rapidly became my favorite watch of all time, and was running years later when a long bout of joblessness forced me to sell it.  It was a sad day for me, truly.Imagine my delight all these years later when I encountered virtually the same watch at virtually the same price!  It arrived today and it instantly felt like an old friend in my hands.  The quality of the make felt the same, the mechanism of the band the same ... it was a homecoming of sorts.  I'll report back in a few months and let you know how things go on this particular model.  But I'll share now what I loved so much about the previous iteration.1)  While the band is not what i was used to at the time (dual deployment latches), I rapidly became very fond of the mechanism.  It's easy to get in and out of, but never got flipped off by accident.2)  While I adjusted the band easily enough for myself last time ... no difficulties at all ... I'm going to follow the manufacturers advice this time and have a jeweler do it to avoid the slight scratches around the fittings from my less than artful application of small tools.3)  The watch kept consistent excellent time.4)  The weight feels substantial but never over-heavy.5)  The crystal face was extremely scratch resistant compared to other watches I've owned.6)  I just LOVE the way it looks.Again, I'll report back on the performance in a few months and let you know how it goes.A note to potential buyers.  Swiss Army Victorinox purchases Wenger a few years back, and in January of 2013 announced that all Wenger products would be rebranded as Victorinox, so you might want to check out their site as well.  I LOVE their knives and tools, and I'm sure the tradition of great Swiss Army watches is not in danger one ounce. Or should that be gram.  ;)PS ... thanks to my Swiss ancestors for giving birth to such great products.UPDATE - 10/20/2013I have the watch in my hands now, the jeweler has adjusted the band, and I'd have to say this is every bit as good a watch as the one I remember from 15 years ago.  The band is very high quality and the latch is top notch, no complaints.  Everything looks AOK at this point, and as the watch came with a 3 year warranty, I'm quite satisfied.  More updates as required.

I consider myself fantastically fortunate to work for an organization whose leaden laborer labyrinths happily host high-spirited, haphazard Nerf Wars. Chalk it up to "forward thinking stress management", but I love the fact that our managers, directors and VP's simply accept these outbreaks of co-worker cubicle combat as a normal part of the business cycle.  The weapons wielded in these whimsical weekly worker wars range from the smallest single shooters to behemoth, battery-operated bread-winner blasters.Having worked in this environment for over a year, I finally decided it was time for me to invest in my own personal Nerf defense solution.  Rarely in my cube for long stretches of time, my work keeps my endlessly attending meetings and scouring the office landscape for new data to analyze.  Hardly a work profile suited to large, unwieldy, motorized weapons, I quickly realized that I needed something small and portable enough to keep in one of my many vest pockets, yet offering more than the single-shot capability I'd seen in some of the smallest Nerf models. Thus, the Triad EX-3 immediately caught my eye.With three rounds at the ready and range (75 feet) as good as any but the most powerful models, this accurate, easy to use pocket ready design is a total winner in my book.  And if I happen to forget to leave it at work and it accompanies me home for the evening, our family felines love to chase the darts as they fly through the air and bounce across the floor.Office defender and cat toy, all rolled into one efficient and handsome design, the Triad is definitely the Nerf defense solution for me.Nerf N-Strike Elite Triad EX-3 Blaster

We love the entire series of As Time Goes By, but I will admit that, for some reason, season 3 is a favorite.  If we haven't been watching the show in a while and I'm wondering where to sort of just dip my toe in, at "random", for a fun sampling, I often start with Season 3.  Take that for what it's worth. ;)

Playing games or the camera mode ... I'm not sure which she loves more.  Now, she just wants to buy more games. :)  Handy, fun to keep around for long cups of coffee sipped by slow-moving parents ... a perfect gift for a wiggly 10 y.o. girl.

My wife and I have used this small coffee maker in a few B&B's we've visited for romantic or writer's get-ways and decided to buy one for ourselves.  We prefer ground coffee to instant, and find the French press a bit more hassle than we want on some days of the week.  We also love the fact that the built in timer allows you to wake up to fresh coffee in the morning.We also enjoy the fact that little coffee maker offers the option of using either paper filters or a wire mesh filter (available on Amazon, but not supplied WITH the coffee maker), depending on whether you prefer your coffee with all the oils (use the mesh filter) or "cleaner" and "less oily" (use paper filters).  The coffee maker works very well with either.NOTE:  While the DRX5 will use either wire-mesh or paper filters, it comes equipped with neither, so pre-order one or the other with your coffee maker, so you can use it the first day.SUGGESTION:  With the mesh filter selling for less than $1 on Amazon, and paper filters selling for less than a penny each, I don't see why Mr. Coffee doesn't supply one or the other in the box with this coffee maker.  My ONLY gripe about this item is that you have to run to the store and buy filters or order a wire mesh filter basket yourself.  Both are so cheap, they should be included by the manufacturer in the box to allow you to use it right away.  I don't know why they didn't do that ... cost certainly isn't the issue.  Using the standard 4 times multiplier for cost to retail, even if the company bought this stuff at full retail price, it would add only $4 to the cost of the coffee maker.

I bought these for my husband, and he absolutely loves them. I didn't think that it came in a two pack, but it made the price so much better. The color is vibrant and it shrinks just a bit in the wash, but the shrink made it fit much better.

I'm 5'0 and about 140 lbs. I wear a US 10-12. I bought the Pewter M size of these pants. Since I'm on the shorter size, these pants are a bit long on me, I'll have to sew them up. They do have about a 5 inch slit on the bottom that makes the pants look a little funny since they are so long on me, hopefully after I hem them they look great. Also, I"m a bit curvy and have junk in the trunk and these pants kinda bag up weird around the crotch area, like I could wear these backwards and they would look the same. I washed them in a hope that the baggy area up front would go down a little, but it didn't really help. Maybe I'll order size S next time. Overall, they are the color I wanted and they are cute. This is my first time buying scrubs, so it's all a learning experience.

These are a great little snack for my dog. They were not as big as I thought they were going to be, but my dog loves them anyways. She only likes the raw hides, and having a diversity of raw hides is great.
These blankets are a great addition to anyone's camping gear or emergency kit. And since this is a pack of ten you can add them to both.

This is a very well made knitted hat. The quality of this is amazing considering it's from China. It's an adorable hat and the ears make it a great addition to any cat lover's winter fashion. The hat is thick and warm and has softer yarn.
I didn't expect to have two cases, but it was a nice surprise. The kitties on this phone case are a little blurry, but for the price what do you expect.
This is a delightful movie. I'm so glad I added it to my collection. It's got all the great actors of many Wes Anderson films. The romance, adventure, and story telling is truly unique.

I love this pet food container. It has a big container that can fit the biggest dog food bag I can buy, and a small container that I can fill with treats. It also comes with a handy shovel for the food. The shovel has markings for 2 cups through 1/2 cup for accurate feeding. I would recommend this to anyone with an animal.
I bought these for an upcoming backpacking trip, What I didn't anticipate is that these would be so small! These are amazing for anyone who is planning a backpacking trip.

I bought the pink elephant, and It's extremely adorable! This little watering can is a great addition to anyone's cute little garden. The only reason it doesn't get a full five stars is that the pour is something you need to get used to. The first few times I kinda over poured but I've gotten used to the pour.

I bought these pillows for a nice addition to my camping gear. I'm planning on a backpacking trip this year and didn't think that these would be small enough for the trip. I was wrong, these are a perfect size and will be great to have while backpacking. These are a blow up pillow, but are extreamly comfortable and have a nice soft fleece side to sleep on.
I love being able to watch shows as part of my Prime Membership. Way better then Netflix or Hulu and at around the same annual cost, but with waaaaay more benefits.
Great assortment of weights to have in your tackle box. Great price and arrived in a very timely manner.
Great variety for a great price.
These are so great for backpacking. If you stuffed too much into the pack, you could always clip them onto the outer of your pack. Perfect size, and great multi-utensil.

My husband loves this tackle box. It has so many compartments and the trays fold perfectly so you can fit larger items under it. It also comes with a paper inside that for $2.50 you can get a customized name plate. Definitely a great addition to the tackle box.

This is a great Ab belt. The one I had before had the velcro strap from top and bottom, and when you had it tight around you the scratchy velco side would rub you raw. This one has a nice sturdy velcro strap that doesn't even come close to the edges. When you have it tight around you it doesn't roll up and stays in place. I'm definitely very happy with the purchase.
This product came to me with a rip in it. The material is super thin and delicate. Super disappointing.
I love this shirt. I got so many compliments and I feel so pretty in it.

I saw a trailer for this movie and thought that Micheal Cera was going to be the bad guy. That it the only reason I bought this movie, to see Micheal Cera be a creepy bad guy. He does play a creep, but he is not the bad guy fully. The American tourist is the phyco, and the ending has no resolution. It was one of those movies that when the credits role you think to yourself "What? This can't be the ending" and feel wronged by it for a little bit after.
The scarf came faster then I expected a package from China to come! Very pleased with this scarf! It's soooo cute!
I really like this shirt. Take in mind that it's from China when ordering. I usually fit an USA medium, I ordered the XXL on this and it fit perfectly.
This movie was amazing. I'm so glad I purchased it.

My hair is so thin and fair and I have such a hard time finding hair clips that actually stay. These work perfectly for my hair. I put my hair up in a bun all day with just two of these clips and I didn't have to adjust them once. My search for the perfect clips is over.

Results showed faster then I expected. I have sensitive teeth so I only treat once every other day. I saw results after the first use and it keeps on getting whiter each time. I also bought the Remineralization Gel, which is suggested if you have sensitive teeth. Very happy with this purchase.
I have to take these for my anemia. These pills are small and easy to take. I will buy again, and amazon has such great prices.

I love these movies! I was looking to buy Borat and found this three movie set at a way better price then just getting Borat. I was a little hesitant at buying this at first because in the description it says there is one disc, and having one disc for three movies is a little annoying. When it arrived I found out that all the movies come on separate discs. It was a very pleasant surprise. The case is clear, but it looks like a collectors edition.

These are great for beginners. I've started out using the 2lb set, and already after two weeks have moved up to the 3lb. I've very happy with this set. The stand is super easy to put together and it is super easy to tuck away in a corner or under the bed when not in use. I wish they had the next set of three from the same company.

This is my second time time purchasing this harness. The first time I got the Green Apple and I absolutely loved this harness so I purchased the Purple one this time. It's so soft on the inside where it's rubbing on my dog. She has very sensitive skin and and other harness I tried gave her rashes.  I don't think I'll buy another brand but this brand for my dog. My 45 lb pitbull fits in the medium after we adjust it a little bit.
Pills are a little bigger then I thought they would be. Not an issue though, I'll buy from amazon again.

My husband and I have been trying for a baby for about three years now. I read some reviews online that if I paired Maca and Zinc it worked wonders. So far I've been taking two a day for about a week. I have already noticed changes to my energy levels. It's easier waking up in the morning, I don't feel so groggy. I hope that in a few months I can say that this is a miracle pill! Fingers crossed!!

This would have received a full five stars if the packaging was appropriate. I received a package with a worn hole in the front and the tin that the wallet goes in all dinged up and not being able to close without force. But the wallet was unharmed and it looks like it'll meet my husband's needs. I just wish the case would have been fine.
This movie is a funny movie, I never saw it in theaters, but I love the main actors. I'm glad I bought it, and at such a great price too!
Great price for a funny movie!

I think all three movies are awesomely funny! Amazon offers them at a great price too. I was hesitant on buying them because I don't like when all three movies are on one disc, but this came with three separate discs.

The Zagg Limitless keyboard is practically full-size and comfortable to use.  It is not really limitless, but it does pair (using Bluetooth) with up to three different devices (Apple, Android, and Windows) allowing you to use one keyboard with multiple devices.I tested this keyboard with an iPhone, an iPad, and a PC using Windows 10.  Both Apple devices worked perfectly.  I was unable to connect with the PC; I don't know if this was user error, problems with Windows 10 unhelpful Bluetooth Settings, or something else.  I did not test it with an Android device.For Apple devices, at least, it worked great and I would recommend it.

This is a very good Nero Wolfe pastiche by Robert Goldsborough, the 11th in a series he has done since the death of Rex Stout.  This one has an exceptionally good plot with a nice twist at the end.The novel is set in the 1970's and has many of the standard characters we know and love from the original Rex Stout series.  Lon Cohen has a larger-than-usual role in this one as he represents the client when The Gazette hires Wolfe to investigate the death of one of their columnists.The main problem with this book is that Wolfe just does not sound like himself.  He sounds rather more like a parody of Nero Wolfe.  Fortunately the author does a good job with Archie's dialogue most of the time.There are some good bits for long-time readers of Nero Wolfe.  Archie and Lily have several nice scenes and hear a bit more from Fritz than in many of the mysteries.All in all this is an enjoyable read for Nero Wolfe fans.

This is a wonderful travel guide to Italy perfect for planning a trip.  However at nearly 1000 pages, it is most certainly not the guidebook you want to carry with you while travelling.The book is divided into sections, such as Rome, Northern Italy, Tuscany, Sicily, etc.  Each section has a useful introduction, a planner, recommendations for where to eat and stay, and highlights of the region - such as Venice, Florence, The Ionian Coast, etc.  There are occasional "Fodor's Features" with more information about Ancient Rome, Renaissance Art, and other topics.There are small maps throughout the book and a larger attached map of Rome.  The graphics are disappointing and uneven.  Sometimes the text is obscured by the photo and sometimes the photo obscures the text.
Comfortable and easy to launder.
The three different colors have different fits.  Otherwise they are all that one can expect from a package of briefs.
Plug and play wired headphones.  Good, low-end, stereo sound quality.  Simple volume control on the cord.  Best of all these fit comfortably and do a good job blocking out other noises in the room.
Very disappointing!  Each chapter is two or three pages long and is a set-up for a joke.  Unfortunately most of the jokes aren't funny.  But even the funny jokes don't work very well in this format.

This is a valuable record of the private meetings between Peter Kalms and the Lubavitcher Rebbe that offers a rare glimpse into the details of such meetings.  Unfortunately, the particular matters being discussed are not intrinsically interesting in themselves and the constant updates on their various projects soon becomes dull.  Kalms had the very good idea of including copies of letters received from the Rebbe at the end of most chapters.  This also provides interesting insight into how the Rebbe communicated with his followers and details on his worldview.The book is weakened by the addition of two additional sections.  The first is a one-sided reconstruction of the correspondence from the Rebbe to Chief Rabbi Jakobovitz following the Six Day War.  It is difficult to judge what Jakobovitz's contribution to the conversation might have been.  It appears that the concerns that the Rebbe had about the treaty details between Israel and its Arab neighbors were largely misplaced, though it is difficult to judge as very little context is given for the correspondence.The second additional section is by Herman Branover, a Russian Refusenik and physicist.  This is an embarrassing defense of the Rebbe's rejection of modern science.

These are very nice cotton cloths made in India.  They could serve as dish cloths or as table napkins.  The purple color is bright but not garish and the cloth has a "basket weave" finish that looks good.  There are six cloths in the package, each measuring about 12" x 12" and they do shrink a bit if washed in hot water or dried in high heat.

This Christy knife is just like the ones I remember from my childhood.  This is not a high-end knife, but the sliding blade in the protective cover works well for little jobs like opening envelopes or cutting string and is quite useful attached to a key chain.

Perhaps I am hopelessly old fashioned and expect a model kit to involve building the model.  This kit consists of 19 pieces that snap together.  The whole process took less than 5 minutes.The finished product is quite nice.  There is good detail on the molded plastic pieces and the light and sound effects were a nice surprise.  But it should be billed as a toy with "some assembly required" rather than a kit that requires some time and skill to construct.

Helen Luke's writing and insights are always valuable.  This book focuses on the psychological journey of aging.  A long chapter discusses Homer's The Odyssey as a metaphor for aging.  Some of this material is a bit repetitious, but overall still valuable.

Second novels in trilogies are often weaker than the first - think The Two Towers vs. The Fellowship of the Ring or the first two novels of the Harry Potter series.  Hofer has managed to produce a second volume in The Saucerville Trilogy that is even more exciting and fast moving than the opening novel Saucerville.  I look forward to reading the third novel in the series!i was also impressed by the characters in this novel, the author makes you care about them even when they are not entirely sympathetic - or human.  Hofer also includes some nice science in this book as he explores genetics, medicine, the effects of relativity and space travel.Readers familiar with McMinnville Oregon will enjoy the local references.  Young Adult readers will enjoy the struggles of the teen-aged protagonists.  Recommended.

Strangers often stop me on the street and ask me how I manage to have such calm skin.  In emergencies, when conditions are most stressful and trained professionals are cracking under the pressure, I remain cool and collected.  My sang froid is due entirely to the calming effects of Eucerin's Skin Calming Daily Moisturizing Cream which - you guessed it! - I use daily.Most importantly, this is the only moisturizing skin cream recommended by my Massage Therapist.  If you knew my Massage Therapist, this would be the only moisturizing skin cream you would consider purchasing.  $105 for two 8 ounce tubes may seem expensive to you, especially since you can probably purchase the same product at a local store for under $10. But you get what you pay for and no expense is too much for truly world-class calm skin.

This is a very interesting but uneven book.  Some chapters are excellent.  Others have fascinating premises that are not fully developed.  The opening is rather slow but other parts of the book are fascinating and real page-turners.Perhaps the worst problem is the space the author devotes to defending his critique of inclusive fitness theory.  This is probably a very important topic to professional biologists, but seems out of place in a book aimed at a more general audience.All in all, this book is definitely worth reading for the authors interesting and informed opinions on the human condition.  But it could have been so much better...

This book started as a popular series of photographs on Instagram.  The photos are very good and the added illustrations are frequently amusing and clever.  This is rather a "one-trick pony" idea and I would not expect the book to have a sequel, but this book is heartwarming, humorous, and fun.

The combination of an Air Conditioner and a Heat Pump in the same appliance is a clever idea and good engineering.  This unit is significantly easier to assemble and install than a conventional AC unit, particularly since you dont have to hang a heavy metal box out the window. The timer function seems decadently useful, as does the remote.All in all, a powerful unit that works well for a one-bedroom apartment.

This is a very nice low-end 32 inch TV.  It is easy to set-up and connect and has fine picture quality (using LED).  It looks rather like an extra-large PC monitor.  The only down side of this unit is the sound, which is rather tinny.  It is rather amazing that a 32 inch TV seems smallish, but its really just fine for watching movies across the room.Here are some other observations.  It is surprisingly light, easily carried in one hand.  It has a generous array of connectors in the back, including an 1/8 audio port, which makes it much easier to stream shows from a computer or tablet. This also means you can use computer speakers as a cheap and easy way of getting better quality sound. The color is clean, crisp, and bright. The unit starts in power save mode. You can get a more vivid picture by switching it out of this mode when you first turn it on.  It comes with a sturdy stoppered base. However, the threading on the screws was slightly imperfect on the model I received, and it took a significant amount of elbow grease to assemble.

Very clever!  This power strip and surge protector has four regular electrical outlets and two USB outlets.  This allows you to charge two electronic devices (such as smart phones) without using the regular electrical outlets.  It works perfectly and the cord length is just right for your desktop or kitchen counter.

This is an odd kitchen gadget suitable for those with lots of storage space in their kitchens for specialty kitchen devices.  The masher itself works great - I tested it on potatoes - and is quite large and heavy and well made.  The red plasticized handle rather detracts from the otherwise attractive wood handle.The instructions with this very large masher say that you only have to peel the avocado and then mash.  But the end produce would be much better if you also remove the pit.  This would definitely be my first choice if I ever had to make a gallon (or more) of guacamole.

This is a board game version of the original two-player card game which is light but quite good.  The board game is for two or four players and adds a mildly interesting new scoring element for those that play the long three-round version of the game.  The board game is much better for four players than for two.  There is one minor rule change for the two-player version that is not entirely successful.All in all, this remains a good light game and is fun to play.

These are very lightweight packing cubes.  They tear easily and the zippers don't allow easy access to everything in the cube.  Combine those flaws with the garish color and you have a product that I found disappointing.

A book about Mycroft Holmes, Sherlock's smarter and older brother, is welcome and one by a celebrity author is a curiosity as well.  The mystery unwinds slowly and includes some unsettling material about the slave trade in the Caribbean.  It is interesting on its own.However this book is not really a Holmesian pastiche nor is it a modern detective novel.  This novel is reasonable well-written and plotted, but it fails to capture Doyle's language or Victorian period.  Neither Mycroft nor Sherlock sound like themselves, rather they sound like contemporary Americans both in idiom and in their their psychological insights.

This hand-glazed dish is moderately attractive and is both dishwasher and microwave safe. It has an interesting dimpled surface.  It is too long to fit into a standard cupboard.Please note that this product is made in China.

This is a very strange book that manages, somehow, to be perky, OCD, and inspirational all at the same time.  I do not know how well the author's tips apply to U.S. homes - our closets seem to be structured differently than the Japanese closets she discussed - but the general emphasis on owning only things that give you joy rings true.  It's been said before by other authors, but it deserves repeating that owning things does not make you happy.The things you own end up owning you.  Chuck PalahniukOur life is frittered away by detail. Simplify, simplify.  Henry David ThoreauKeep only those things that speak to your heart.  Marie KondoAnd finally, congratulations to Cathy Hirano, translator.  This is one of the best translations from Japanese that I have ever read!

When I received my free review copy of this book through the Vine program, I was surprised to see a hardback textbook published by The MIT Press. Most writing about the Internet is just as ephemeral as most of the content on the Internet and I did not expect that a book about the Comments Sections found on many blogs, new sites, and social media sites, would have much staying power.I was wrong.Joseph M. Reagle, Jr., has written an intelligent and interesting study about the comments sections, ratings, likes, and all the other user-generated content that comes with many Internet sites and applications. I am firmly in the dont read the comments camp, but the author does make a case for the utility of some kinds of comments, such as the reviews on Amazon.There are nine chapters with titles such as Informed, Manipulated, Improved, Alienated, and Bemused. There are several especially interesting discussions: how rewards affect the balance between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, the loss of context through hypertextual and hypotextual comments, and the invisible serendipity of on-line communities.This book comes with the standard academic textbook features that I like such as footnotes collected by chapter at the end of the book and an index. I am sorry that so many non-fiction books are being published without indexes. This index is pretty good, though it is missing terms found in the book. For example, many web users do not read comments like this review because they are too long to read (tltr)  a useful term that is not in the index.This is, however, the first index that I have ever read that includes an entry for Internet f*ckwad theory, which gives you a good sense for the kind of people that often comment. The author discusses trolls (and trollplex) as well as other forms of sexism, racism, and harassment. Despite this very good book, I am still not inclined to read the comments on most web sites.

This hand-glazed dish is moderately attractive and is both dishwasher and microwave safe.  It's too shallow for a soup dish, in my opinion, and the outer lip of the bowl slopes downward.  It is, however, a very nice pasta bowl.Please note that this product is made in China.

It works!  One side of this has a towel-like material that substitutes as a wash cloth.  The other side has a nylon dish-scrubber that removes dead skin, as you can imagine.  The flexible rubbery thing that holds the two sides together feels like a Rubbermaid product, which is not so pleasant first thing in the morning when showering.

I do not know how they manufacture a polyester napkin that absorbs liquids and behaves like a cotton napkin, but it does.  They feel like cloth and they launder like cloth.  The colors are rather dull.  Please note that these are manufactured in China.

An excellent bridge book for intermediate level players about counting and how to make inferences, deductions, and informed guesses about your opponents' hands.  Each deal is laid out nicely and Stewart's analysis is always clear.The book has twelve short chapters on counting, inferences, discovery, inferences, and similar topics.Stewart often ends the hand with a few comments about the bidding or the play of the hand.  These are always valuable and often witty.  I would like to see a book on bidding by this author using the same approach.

This kit consists of dozens of (mostly) small pieces (some manufactured in China) that are assembled to create a Nerf-like blaster that shoots foam darts.  Putting it together would be challenging, I think, for most kids under 12 and takes 45 minutes or so (based on my experience).  The directions consist of Ikea-style illustrations (or photos) that unfortunately hide key details.Despite that, this is a well-engineered system, rather like Legos, that was fun to put together once I figured out how the pieces work.  And it does create a working blaster that has quite impressive range and power.

This liquid soap is good enough.  It lathers nicely.  It cleans.  But the scent is odd, a combination of lavender and sage, in which sage predominates.  I prefer lavender as sage reminds me of dressing in the Thanksgiving turkey.

Jan Chozen Bays has written a very good book about the importance of mindfulness.  She includes 53 mindfulness exercises in a series of short chapters averaging about 4 pages each.  Many of these exercises seem quite useful to me, but you would certainly want to space them out - say one a week - rather than try to do multiple ones at the same time.Overall there is an emphasis on getting people out of their heads and into their bodies (the wild elephant) with these exercises.

This is a collection of thoughtful and interesting weekly lessons on 48 principles of Mussar, a Jewish approach to improving yourself.  Many of these lessons and exercises help you explore the topic in some depth, helping you to learn how to see more deeply into Jewish teachings.Alan Morinis has written several books on Mussar.  I think this is his best since his excellent first book Climbing Jacob's Ladder: One Man's Journey to Rediscover a Jewish Spiritual Tradition.

Clear logical thinking applied to the issue of how to maximize the return on any investments (including both time and money) you make to charities.  The author finds a number of non-intuitive results, such as that buying sweat-shop goods is ethical, that donating to disaster relief is inefficient, and that donating to established charities that run multiple programs is probably not the best choice.  This book builds on the influential ideas of Peter Singer on effective altruism and follows a generally utilitarian approach to altruism.MacAskill is particularly good in assessing the counterfactual, i.e. looking at what would happen if you did not donate to a particular charity or if a particular program was not implemented, as many good ideas actually turn out to make the problem they attempt to fix worse.The emphasis throughout the book is on a rational approach to maximizing the positive effect of your altruistic actions.  I think the author overlooks that often we find ourselves emotionally drawn to one kind of charity or another that may have a low return.  However, if it is not for the emotional draw, we might choose not to donate at all.  Perhaps in such cases it makes rational sense not to try to maximize your charitable investments.

A nice little volume that quite probably tells you more than you ever wanted to know about P.G. Wodehouse and cricket.  There is a long introduction, a nice collection of Wodehouse's cricket-themed short stories, and a lot of ephemera.  The stories are mildly amusing and are early Wodehouse.  One can see early flashes of the later Wodehousian skill in humour and plotting, but this volume would really be of interest only to those that want to read everything Wodehouse wrote.

There is some surprisingly good advice in this book about mindful eating and the proper use of willpower.  The author avoids "new age" thinking and language quite successfully while laying out a thoughtful approach to life, which just happens to include advice about eating and food.

Jon Keith offers a number of straightforward techniques for remembering things.  To my surprise, many of them work quite well!  His method of remembering names did not work for me at all, but his technique for remembering both ordered and unordered lists work very well!

Joshua Foer's book about memory is an uneven mix of scientific reporting and personal memoir of competing in memory competitions.  There is a lot of interesting material here that never quite gels into a coherent book.  It's clear that one's memory can be trained and that there are some standard techniques for doing so which he almost, but not quite, describes.

A wonderful collection of essays by America's foremost essayist, the publisher has done us a service by publishing this collection.  The variety of things that Epstein writes about is impressive, as is his careful and deep reading of literature.Epstein is at his best when writing about more personal subjects such as recollections of the Chicago he grew up in, thoughts on aging, teaching, and the arts.  His political essays are less interesting, but still wonderfully written.

The National Geographic Traveler series has another winner with this book on Croatia.  It's very good on providing historical and cultural background for each of the regions with, not surprisingly, beautiful photographs.It's a bit weak on detailed maps and specific establishment guides.  I would use it for general information and planning before your trip and then switch to something like a Lonely Planet guide book when actually travelling in Croatia.

This volume Usagi Yojimbo: Senso is a very dramatic addition to Stan Sakai's Usagi Yojimbo stories and could even serve as the end of the series!  Set 15 years in the Usagi Yojimbo future, it features many of the major characters we've come to know (and love or hate) in an epic battle against the Martian Invaders from H.G. Well's The War of the Worlds!It is an odd premise, and the story has just enough science fiction to it that the reader might take this to be an alternate ending to the Usagi series, fortunately set far enough in the future that we can look forward to many more Usagi Yojimbo volumes.But it doesn't feel that way.  This book has a major emotional impact in part because so many of the characters we know in the series meet their ends here.  Well-known villains die, often with an unexpected nobility.  Others, both heroes and villains, are just killed by the fearsome weapons of the Martians.  Usagi, Tomoe, and Jotaro finally achieve some resolution to their difficult situations, but only at great cost.Sakai's drawings are superb and the action is non-stop.  There are any number of "easter eggs" throughout the book that reward careful re-reading.  Fans of the series must read this story.  New comers to Usagi Yojimbo should save it until after they've read the other volumes.Wow!

The story of the 47 Ronin is quite famous and combines politics, revenge, and honor in service of the code of Bushido.  The story line in this particular version is quite simplified, as probably fits a graphic novel format.  The art work by Stan Sakai, of Usagi Yojimbo Saga Volume 1 fame is simply superb.  Glorious colors, inspired by Japanese woodblock prints, enhance the wonderful composition of each frame.  This is a beautiful book retelling a legendary story.

Iyer's biography of the Dalai Lama is interesting and well-written.  Iyer has known the 14th Dalai Lama for more than 30 years, so it is rather surprising that the author seems so personally disengaged from the subject of his writing.Nevertheless there is a lot of interesting information here and I particularly liked Iyer's analysis of the conflicting worlds that the Dalai Lama has to navigate:  monk and politician, innovator and preserver of tradition, scientist and mystic.  And, unfortunately, it becomes very clear that the Chinese have now destroyed traditional Tibet.  Whatever remains of that ancient culture is now centered in Dharamsala, India.

This is van der Post's personal memoir of June, with extensive biographical information.  He tells a good story, though his writing style is sometimes a bit turgid.Unfortunately it is impossible to know which of these stories are true and which are, well, stories.  After van der Post's death, it became clear that he exaggerated, lied,and was otherwise an unreliable historian.  This is documented in a biography (Teller of Many Tales: The Lives of Laurens van der Post) about Laurens van der Post that makes interesting, but discouraging, reading.So I would like to believe many of the things written here about Jung's witty remarks and wisdom - and many of them may be true - but van der Post's reliability is so poor that one simply can't be sure what really happened or was said and what was just invented.  Unfortunately, I do not believe that one can take this as a reliable biography.

This is one of the better  battery  operated pencil sharpeners that I have used, but it still isn't as good as an old-fashioned hand-cranked sharpener.  However, if you want a battery operated desktop unit, this one is quite good and reasonably quiet.

Yuval Ron is a wonderful musician and storyteller.  Attend one of his concerts if you get a chance!  This book is a mixture of transcriptions of his stories with rather "New Age" chapters about music.Unfortunately the stories are less powerful in print than when told.  And his writing about his music is a colorful mishmash of mysticism, speculative research, and historical conjecture.  If you love Ron's music, buy one of his wonderful CDs instead!

This book was surprisingly entertaining for the most part, but frustrating.  One never does find out what wolves, flash boys, quants, and master of the universe are, let alone why they misrepresent the financial industry.  Trennert's authorial voice is entertaining and he clearly has a lot of anecdotes from his years on Wall Street.  Perhaps he dictated the book and then had the recordings transcribed.Although Trennert seems to be discussing the world of high finance, what he really describes is his career in sales.  He spends too much time travelling and drinking (oddly, visiting lovely Portland, Oregon seems to be one of the worst things that can happen to the frequent flyer).  Successful sales people make a lot of money but they are just selling and need to remember that they are not necessarily deep thinkers.  This becomes quite clear in the last few chapters of the book when Trennert stops telling stories and starts offering ideas.  These, unfortunately, are a mushy mix of Republican political ideas with some largely discredited supply-side economic ideas. One wishes he read The Economist.Trennert writes as if this is his retirement memoir after a long successful career on Wall Street.  Yet it appears from this book that Trennert is in his late-40's.  This makes for an occasionally jarring reading experience.

This is a collection of essays by Adam Phillips that cover a variety of topics from a Freudian psychological viewpoint.  The essays are generally well-written, erudite, humorous, and interesting, though occasionally he engages in bouts of nit-picking with other Freudian analysts.  They are organized around a general theme of making the unexamined life conscious, often by asking questions such as "what is the unconscious problem than your belief solves for you?"The book assumes a deep knowledge of Freud's writings, some clinical experience, and familiarity with later Freudian theorists such as D. W. Winnicott and Masud Kahn.  However the essays are still entertaining and interesting for those readers without all of that background knowledge.

There are too many people consuming too many resources to sustain our capitalism economic system.  That provocative thesis is the one that Jerry Mander hammers home for 11 depressing chapters.  In Chapter 12, he offers some alternatives and partial solutions to the problems.This book is very well-written, persuasive, and quite sobering.  After exposing the enormity of the environmental and social problems we face, his solutions and suggestion seem unfortunately feeble.  Mander is blunt, intelligent, and convincing on the problem.  Why then is he so tentative about the solutions?  In particular, it seems quite obvious that the Earth does not have the long-term carrying capacity needed for our current human population levels.  Yet he only devotes one short paragraph to the problem of overpopulation.Despite that odd oversight, this is a great book.  I only hope that it helps start a national (and international) conversation about taking the next steps needed to avoid a complete catastrophe.

These crescent wrenches use a couple of clever mechanisms.  One allows the wrench to handle a range of sizes and the other allows you to change, and then lock in place, the relative positions of the wrench head and handle.  This makes it easy to use in a variety of potentially awkward positions.The only thing I didn't like about these wrenches is that you have to reverse the tool to reverse the direction you turn the nut (i.e. tighten vs. loosen).  This is a bit annoying when you are trying to get it tightened "just right."

There's never been a poor Usagi Yojimbo book and this one continues Stan Sakai's tradition of fine storytelling and superb artwork.  There are a couple of surprising plot twists and Usagi tracks down the Red Scorpion gang and there's even an appearance by the Three Stooges, appropriately modified for this world.I only have one minor complaint.  Usagi meets the Lord of the Owls again and behaves in a very uncharacteristic way.  I look forward to more about this enigmatic character, but I hope Usagi is more himself when it happens.

Asher Price has written a good book with an odd combination of elements.  It is an interesting history of dunking in basketball.  It is a rather formulaic personal account of his spending a year getting exercising and dieting so that he can try to dunk a basketball.  And it is a moving history of his family centering on his 102-year-old grandmother and his father.Well-written and surprisingly entertaining to this non-basketball fan; I personally would have preferred a little less swearing in print and a lot more about his family history.

Cornelius Shields was a banker who got lucky during the Great Depression and made a lot of money as a stockbroker.  He was also a very committed sailboat racer.  He founded both the International One-Design Class and the Shields Class sloop - both of which are still in active use.This memoir is an odd combination.  There is some interesting personal material combined with a great deal of now dated technical sailboat and racing information combined with guest chapters written by others.  Some of these guest chapters are the most interesting material in the book.  These include chapters by Ted Hood, Bus Mosbacher, and a young up-and-coming sail boat racer named Ted Turner.Just a note that this is an attractive book published by Prentice-Hall which makes it all the odder that there are a number of places where the last line of a paragraph have been dropped from the text.

Man in Profile: Joseph Mitchell of The New Yorker is a good biography of a very fine writer for "The New Yorker" magazine.  Mitchell wrote long profile pieces for the magazine for decades.  One of the mysteries about Mitchell is that he did not publish anything in the last decades of his long life, leading to the joke that he had the world's worst case of writer's block.The truth is more subtle and Thomas Kunkel does a very good job of giving us both the facts of Mitchell's life and a convincing look at the inner man as well.  Readers who enjoyed Mitchell's fine collection, Up in the Old Hotel, will be pleased to get further information about some of these memorable pieces.  I was especially interested in the long description of Mitchell's interview with Mr. Hunter of "Mr. Hunters Grave."Kunkel describes how Mitchell searched for the "revealing remark" when he interviewed people.  This was the thing that really touched the speaker and made it possible for Mitchell to find out what was really important to the speaker and then write about it.  Unfortunately, Kunkel was unable to interview Mitchell for this biography and so it lacks that "revealing remark" that would let us really know Mitchell.  Nevertheless, this is an interesting and well-written biography.  Recommended.

This tea requires something like the K-Cup brewer.  It is a passable, rather weak, mint tea.If you want a really good mint tea, then I'd strongly recommend Smith's #45 Peppermint tea Smith Tea, Peppermint Leaves, 15-Count, 0.78 Ounce.  Superb mint, good flavor, and strong enough to satisfy.  It comes in tea bags, though, so it won't work with a cup-brewer system.

I was initially skeptical that an iPhone case containing a spare battery would be comfortable to use or very useful.  It only took one test to convince me otherwise.  First of all the case is very good!  It's easy to put in - or take out - the iPhone and provides good protection.  It's not noticeably larger or heavier than many other iPhone cases.But I was really sold the first time I used it to charge my iPhone remotely.  It worked great!  You push a button on the back of the case, that does not get activated when the iPhone is in your pocket, and you can continue using your cell phone as it charges.This is now my standard case and I can not imagine doing without out.

Jon Acuff's latest book, Do Over: Rescue Monday, Reinvent Your Work, and Never Get Stuck, is a blog-to-book that actually works pretty well.  He has some lightweight career advice that should be helpful to people just entering the workforce.  He points out, for example, that when you have a job you have to show up everyday on-time and actually work as long as you are supposed to.His other advice, nicely packaged, is basic and similarly useful.  You should build a "Career Savings Account" by investing energy in relationships (networking), skills, character, and hustle (effort).  Each of these four points is discussed in a number of short chapters.I confess to being annoyed by Acuff's repeated references to his "New York Times bestselling" book Start: Punch Fear in the Face, Escape Average and Do Work that Matters.  A quick Google search reveals that Start did indeed appear on the New York Times bestselling book for one week as the 5th listing in one of the self-help categories.  I don't know if this is an actual example of the recent trend of buying your way onto the list or not, but it does seem a trifle dishonest to this reviewer and inappropriate in a book in which the author stresses the importance of honesty as a character trait.Readers interested in other books about managing their careers should also consider reading:  How to Fail at Almost Everything and Still Win Big: Kind of the Story of My Life, What Color Is Your Parachute? 2015: A Practical Manual for Job-Hunters and Career-Changers, and The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People: Powerful Lessons in Personal Change.

Cousineau's book on traveling is generally interesting and well written.  It suffers from two main defects:  it is unfocused and it quotes widely from other writers without really connecting the quotations to the author's own viewpoint.  Your do not really learn very much about making a pilgrimage, let alone the art of pilgrimage, but you do get to read a number of entertaining stories and anecdotes.

This is a great book about writing that generalizes to any creative endeavor in your life.  Little of the advice given in the book is directly related to writing.  Almost all of the advice applies equally well to any part of your life where you are held back by self-criticism, unrealistic expectations, and unclear thinking.  Ueland's approach is honest and direct and inspiring.Unfortunately, the BN Publishing edition - a print on demand service - is terrible.  There are missing letters, missing words, odd line jumps, and other marks of a hasty electronic conversion.I would definitely recommend this book to anyone interested in doing any creative work.  But I would also urge you to buy a different edition.

I've had good luck with Omron pedometers.  They are sturdy and perform well.  The HJ325 is an attractive model with easy-to-use controls.  The optional belt clip-on attachment also works well.It also has the best battery case that I've seen in a pedometer.  No screwdriver required!  No small screws to lose!  It uses an ingenious locking mechanism that is built in to the battery case cover.My only (quite mild) complaint is that this pedometer does not track "steps" from cycling or the elliptical machine.  Other than that, it counts steps quite accurately.
Good cashews, with just the right amount of saltiness.  It's especially nice that they come in a foil package that actually reseals, making it easier to keep them fresh.
