This is Emma updated for the turn of the 21st Century.  It provides the early background for Emma and her father before where the original novel by Austin begins.  Then the events of the Austin novel are repeated - in an updated and simplified way - in a modern novel style.  There descriptive passages are shorter but the original Emma feeling is preserved.All in all, Smith, has produced a well-written and enjoyable update.  Unfortunately the last chapter is a let down, it fails to be appropriately romantic and preachy.  The author's message, already clear to the reader, is wielded with all the subtlety of a bludgeon - such as Smith might have used in one of his popular detective novels.

This is the seventh title in Martin Walker's series of books about Chief Bruno set in St. Denis, France.  It's one of the better titles in the series and a welcome return to form after a couple of weaker books.Some plot elements are predictable.  Muslim terrorists invade a sleepy French village yet again.  Bruno, even with the resources of the entire French police system and military, once again winds up being the person that saves the day in an exciting military-style gun battle.  And Bruno, once again, has his pick of the ladies as he cooks wonderful French food.Fortunately the Bruno character is interesting enough to carry the novel.  The plot holds together reasonably well and there are some attractive new characters in this book.  All in all, a very welcome addition to the Bruno canon.

The dry-erase markers work well and the colors are bright and easy to read.  The line width is narrow, unlike some markers.  The package comes with a cleaning solution and an eraser that also work well.  The markers have a "window" in the side that lets you see when the ink is running low. I do not know how useful that feature will be - we just tend to use them until they don't work anymore and then throw them out - but it could a nice touch.

Let's set the stage.  George Wilhelm Frederich Hegel, 1770- 1831, was an important German philosopher who made original contributions to philosophy, in part as a reaction to Kant. Jacques Marie Emile Lacan, 1901 - 1981, was a French Freudian psychoanalyst who gave a long series of annual seminars that were important in Parisian cultural life.This is an English translation of Zizek's 1982 Ph.D. dissertation. It is an exploration of Hegelian dialectic and Lacanian psychoanalysis and how these inform each other.  It is not easy reading, but it is interesting, intellectual, and surprisingly humorous at times.Zizek is a well known Marxist cultural critic and writer.  I think this would be an intimidating book for anyone without a good background in philosophy and a reasonable acquaintance with Freudian theory.  It is, I suspect, exactly the sort of book that a French intellectual would have to know.

I do not have a lot of spare counter space in my kitchen, so every appliance has to earn a place.  This blender, while perfectly adequate, does not make the cut.Although marketed as a frozen drink party machine - and the red color is nice - this is really just an average blender.  It comes with a new lid design that I liked and a insulating sleeve that I did not like.  The unit does not disassemble, so if you use it for other blending tasks besides making daiquiris, etc., it is a bit difficult to clean.

Rebels at Work: A Handbook for Leading Change from Within by Kelly and Medina is a wonderful handbook for change agents.  There are ten chapters that lay out the entire journey of a change agent, with lots of helpful hints, important advice, and useful tips.  It's like having two experience mentors at your side guiding you through the often difficult issues that change agents encounter.There are chapters on gaining credibility, navigating the organizational landscape, communicating, managing conflict, and similar essential topics.  There are helpful charts and lists.  There are interesting, and sometimes inspiring, sidebars by the two authors about their own change efforts - not all of which were successful.  This is now the first book I would recommend to anyone seeking to make important changes in big organizations.Some of the design choices for this books are a bit odd - important Notes are shown in a tiny font and the photographs of the two authors, which appear in their sidebars, are washed out.  However two sections of the book near the end - Recommended Reading and the Glossary - are superb (and humorous) and should not be skipped.  There is a link in one of the glossary entries, for example, to a fascinating blog post by Medina about Obama Care that should not be missed.  And one of the recommended books is Orbiting the Giant Hairball: A Corporate Fool's Guide to Surviving with Grace; this is one of the best business books I have ever read and it deserves to be better known.Being a change agent is both hard and difficult.  This book makes it a little easier.  Highly recommended.

This is apparently the decade for people to walk the Camino de Santiago and write a book about their experiences.  Some of these are interesting and well written (I like The Way of the Stars: Journeys on the Camino de Santiago and Along the Way: The Journey of a Father and Son), some are guidebooks (see for example A Pilgrim's Guide to the Camino de Santiago: St. Jean * Roncesvalles * Santiago (Camino Guides), and some are simply embarrassing (see The Camino: A Journey of the Spirit or The Pilgrimage (Plus).Walking Home: A Pilgrimage from Humbled to Healed by Sonia Choquette is, unfortunately, in the latter category.  Choquette's brother and father die, she breaks up with her husband of 30 years, and decides on the spur of the moment to take a 500 mile hike in Spain.  It's reasonably well-written and starts strong, but soon lapses into a mushy New Age mysticism along with descriptions of her emotional pain.  I'm sure she was in pain, but it does not make for inspired reading.  Indeed the author demonstrates just how shallow "New Age" thinking can be.I admire people who do this pilgrimage, but I wish fewer of them would write about their experiences.  This book was a disappointment.

Tattle Tea company, based in Stockton NJ, has great packaging.  The foil, vacuum packed, loose leaf tea has an attractive label with very clear brewing instructions printed right on the front.  And their Tattle Tea Spiced Chai Black Tea, 5 Ounce is reasonably good black tea with the barest hint of some flowery spice.  Perhaps this counts as chai in New Jersey, but it certainly does not by West Coast standards.Out here, we expect Chai to pack a spicy punch and to be rich with honey, vanilla, ginger, cardamon, cinnamon, nutmeg, etc.  If you want good chai, try Oregon Chai Oregon Chai Single Serve Cups, 12 Count.

Good beads. If you are curious as to which colors are included, I got ( I didn't count, but it seemed pretty evenly distributed):ClearPinkRedOrangeYellowGreenLight BlueDark BluePurpleThe light blue and dark blue are pretty hard to distinguish from each other. The pink and clear are also sometimes hard to distinguish from each other, depending on the light/angle you are looking at them.

I was very interested in getting Lewis and Clark (game) but had heard that Discoveries was coming out, so I waited for that instead. One common complaint with Lewis and Clark was that near mid/end game it really bogged down and turns took forever. Discoveries is a more streamlined dice/worker placement game that evokes similarities to Lewis and Clark but is different in its own respects.So while a game like "Roll for the Galaxy" is the dice version of "Race to the Galaxy," Discoveries is not really the "dice version" of Lewis and Clark but it is close.Each player is starts with 5 dice of their color. The dice have different faces that can be used to do different actions (the worker placement aspect of the game). The actions activated can either help the players work towards completing journeys (and getting victory points) or befriending indian tribes that left the player do more robust actions and special abilities going forward.At surface, the game seems simple with its seemingly simple components - a central game board where used dice go, player boards that depict available actions, cards, and dice. But, similar to Lewis and Clark, Discoveries becomes very deep and "thinky" mid/late game due to your camp's ever growing range of available actions and abilities. But it never really quite bogs down because you are still only allowed to use the dice as they are presented in front of you. So while there are some turns that may take some time while player's think about their strategy, generally the game moves at a brisk pace. This is especially evident on subsequent playthroughs when players have developed a strategy from the beginning.Set-up is very simple. There are some set up differences between a 2, 3, or 4 player game but it is not hard to remember or implement.Games w/ 4 players i have found take about 1 hour for new players, closer to 45 minutes or so for repeat plays.Highly recommended.Other games I really enjoy: Five Tribes, Istanbul, San Juan, Orleans, Patchwork.

don't judge this game by its cover ... both literally and figuratively.Figuratively - a board game based on quilting might not strike excitement in you, but trust me this is a fine example of engaging mechanics and enough variation and strategy to please all gamersLiterally - when i first saw the game cover, i thought it was a (square) tile laying game (like Carcassonne, Cacao, Lanterns, etc). That is completely wrong. Each patchwork piece is uniquely shaped - think Tetris. The puzzle lies within how to optimize putting these various pieces into your 9x9 player grid. You are penalized for empty spots.This is a fantastic game for 2 players. Plays within 30 minutes. Highly recommended.

Fantastic party game. Our group usually finds ourselves playing medium weight games (Five tribes, Castles of Burgundy, Dominion, Mad King Ludwig, etc) but when the group gets 5+ then we usually break out Monikers.Yes, it is based on an older public domain game (they even mention that in the instructions). Yes, there are cheaper alternatives out there (see: Times Up! Title Recall). However, I would highly suggest purchasing Monikers instead, especially if you are in the age range of 18-35.Monikers' cards contain more pop culture topics than alternatives. Sometimes they contain internet memes/stars that my group wasn't familiar with, but that was always OK beacuse of the new huge plus about monikers:Every card has a description on it!! This is where Monikers sets itself apart.Cards are high quality. Included are blank cards too, but I personally dont find myself using them.Highly recommended.

beautiful illustrations, perfect match to the original Dixit cards (some of the other expansions, while beautifully drawn in their own right, were done by different artists than the original Dixit artist Marie Cardouat)great way to breathe some new life into an already great game. Quest is just an expansion and doesnt come with anything else (no scoring markers, voting tokens, etc).

very nice pet crate. easily expandable to give your pet some more room to move around which I appreciate.The 2 entrance gates work smoothly. Assembly was very easy. I did it by myself with no issues. The bottom plastic tray is a little uncomfortable (lots of ridges to accommodate the expandable nature of the crate) but nothing a few blankets can't fix.I rate this product easily as 5 stars, although it is quite expensive compared to regular wire crates. And one caveat that I did not think of before hand --- your dog might scratch at the wood when the crate is locked. This can cause them to get splinters in their paws, or to ingest the wood. I remedied this by:- Buying 1/8" thick panels of Lexan Polycarbonate clear plastic (virtually indestructible)- Buying Hyde Tools 45730 Plastic Laminate Scoring Knife (to cut said polycarbonate into smaller panels i could attach to the wood pet crate)- Using 5/8" wood screws to secure the polycarbonate to the wood of the crate. Now they have scratch protectors : )

Nice and sharp, got the job done on Lexan Polycarbonate sheet.The sheet was about 1/8" thick I believe. I had to do many more passes than the 7 or 8, maybe twice as many, but this was my first time using this type of tool and perhaps I wasn't pressing hard enough. Regardless, the tool worked in the end and the polycarbonate sheet was easily snapped in two. Nice price compared to other alternatives too! Would recommend this tool.

Great compactor bags. Pretty heavy duty. Have not had any issues (knock on wood) with these bags holding up with a heavy load of trash.I have a kitchen aid trash compactor that has an opening that is 16" deep by 9" wide. These bags fit nicely with plenty of room to spare.I took one star off because:1) there is no way to secure the bag to the compactor. I have to manually cut holes in the side to hook onto the retainer tabs. A nice reviewer posted a video on how to do this easily.2) No built in tying mechanism. You'll either need ties of your own, tie the bag onto itself (which can be hard if it is really full), or just throw away with the bag being open.I would purchase this product again.

Great potty, very reasonably priced. I bought these for my son, whereas a couple years ago i bought the baby bjorn similar product for my daughter. I see no discernible difference between the two, except the summer infant one being much cheaper. The tag also says made in USA, which is always a plus too!

amazingly sturdy; very very easy to set up. Have had various guitars on it for many months now and the foam has not done anything to their finish.I have little ones running around the house so i wanted some extra protection in case they knocked over a guitar. So i bought a few of these:Planet Waves Acoustic Guitar Quick-Release SystemAnd used them as a make-shift lockable strap on each guitar neck.I have no doubt the guitars would NOT fall out of the rack without those extra straps, but wanted extra protection in case my 3 year old wanted to touch the guitars.

Works as intended. I'm actually using it to power my Amazon echo. The switch on the side lights up in green when the outlet is on, so you can easily see whether it is on or not. Would definitely purchase again

Does job as intended. Using with RCA DH24SPF Two Way 3 Ghz Bi-Di Splitter to split my coax line from the wall into two separate lines: one to my DVR and one to my router. Using with Verizon FiOS service. No noticeable degradation in speed. Would definitely buy again.

very good granite product. Used on my kitchen countertops and could not believe how amazing they felt afterwards. After using this wax the countertops become unbelievably smooth and slick. It makes feeling the unwaxed parts of your countertops dirty and grimy.I happen to like the smell ... reminds me of Meguiar's car cleaning products i used to use when detailing cars. Although the smell is definitely not for everyone ... however, the product really only smells strong when you are applying it. for better or worse, the smell goes away quickly after application.

very good product, very easy to install.Comes with a variety (5 different sizes i believe) of machine screws to attach the straps to the back of your TV. One of the sizes fit my 2014 Sony 60W630B TV perfectly. I would imagine it the supplied screws fit most if not all main manufacturers.It also comes with 2 different size wood screws to drill into your wall/furniture for the other end of the strap.The straps themselves are sturdy, and the length is very easily adjustable.A+ product all around, gives me a good peace of mind that the TV won't fall.

Working very well with my two machines at home. One is running Win7 and the other is on Ubuntu (i believe 12.04 LTS, but perhaps a later version too).The ubuntu machine immediately recognized the adapter (as soon as i plugged it in and got back to my chair it was already on)The win7 machine i had to use the CD included to install the driver, but after that it worked very well.My machines are very close to the router, so unfortunately i can't comment on long range distance capabilities.

Works great with my verizon fios service.i wanted to put my DVR and wifi router in the same location, but there was only one coax plug coming from the wall. So i have it set up:coax from wall ---> RCA Splitter --> one coax cable going to DVR, one going to router.i see no loss in signal. everything is working as intended.For the coax patch cables, i am using: "Cable Matters 3-Pack, CL2 In-Wall Rated (CM) Quad Shielded RG6 Coaxial Patch Cable in Black 1.5 Feet"

great case, offers solid protection at  a low cost. keep an eye on Amazon warehouse deals (returned items, or items damaged in shipping). Got one at a very low price and came in just like new.this case perfectly fits a Jim Root telecaster, just FYI.

great slim fit denim for baby. sizing (18mo) seems consistent with other major brands (carters, etc). The jeans are very, very soft and stretchy. I thought it was just an elastic waist but was pleasantly surprised to see it was adjustable too, similar to GAP baby pants. At the retail price it is outrageously overpriced but Amazon frequently slashes the prices on these and they are great.

Interesting game. It is a cooperative game where everyone can see each other cards, and you dont know what cards you yourself hold in your hand. You can either give people hints on what is in their hand, discard cards for more opportunites to give hints, or play a card down in the communal playing board (and it has to be in the correct order, which is why people need to give you hints about what cards you're holding).Our gaming group only really plays non-cooperative games (7 Wonders, Settlers, etc) so a cooperative game was refreshing to play. However my only real gripe is that there is no definitive end-game. There is just a scoring scale on how many cards your group correctly placed down in the communal area when all the cards are exhausted. So basically its kind of like you are playing for a high score so-to-speak. You could shoot for getting a perfect score but that is fairly hard to do in the base game (there are wild cards / rule variations).

fit is spot on for LG G3 (verizon)design is very nice, my wife gets compliments on it all the timeThe case itself is not too flexible, but it was fairly easy to get on. I would not want to take it on and off frequently.Only slight complaint (and this is a personal preference) that doesnt make it a 5 star item is that the case itself is kind of slick. It does not add any grip to the phone, and if you placed it on a smooth angled surface your phone would slide. I know some people prefer slicker phone cases (make it easier to get out of pockets, etc).I would rate it around 4.5 stars --- would definitely buy again.This particular color (teal) was not in stock "fulfilled by amazon" so i ordered it directly from GreatShield ... fairly quick shipping, overall good experience with them as a 3rd party vendor

love the fit. slightly baggy up top and narrows down to very slim at the bottom of your legs. i usually wear size 28-30 in pants and the size small fit me very well in the waist. I am about 5'10" and the length is a tad short, but it looks ok due to the style of pants these are. I am looking to purchase more Elwood joggers like these, hopefully they come in more colors (i only see a few on Amazon). Bonus: inside the pocket there is a tag that says Made in the USA!

very good hair product for men. very strong hold, much stronger than i was expecting. I was previously using Mitchell Tea Tree gel, which i loved the smell but that gel was a little too "shiny" for my preferences. This TIGI product is a nice blend of shiny and matte look, right in the middle in my opinion. Smell is very good too. A little product goes a long way in the hair. Definitely would recommend.

perfect match for Talis S HighArc Kitchen Faucet, Steel OptikI have the Hansgrohe Talis S HighArc Kitchen Faucet, Steel Optik Kitchen faucet, and needed to replace the air gap cover. This product was an exact match to the one that was previously installed in my kitchen. The item is pricey, but it seems all air gap covers are around the twenty dollar range.

ordered cimo grip clear case. Fits LG G3 (verizon) perfectly. Very slim fit; i can barely tell the difference between the phone without it and with it. The material itself has a little flexibility to it, although it is not as flexible as some "jelly" cases. The clear is very clear, looks great with the white G3. Although for my next case i probably wont get clear as dirt/etc gets trapped between the case and you can easily see all of it. The grips on the side work well.

these baby jeans are awesome, very cool look and color to them, but unfortunately i would personally not classify these as "slim fit" ... these seem to be pretty standard straight leg fit. The picture, at least to me, made these look like slimmer jeans that tapered down to the ankle. Definitely not the case.If you are looking for slim / skinny jeans for your little rockstar, these are NOT it. if you are looking for cool regular straight leg fit for your baby then these fit the bill

good, tight, slim fit with LG G3 (verizon). The black case actually has some subtle sparkles in it, if that is important to you. The case itself is smooth, it is NOT very grippy. The case works with no interference with my non-tempered glass screen protector (Tech Armor HD Clear). It is not a rigid plastic; it has some flexibility in it but not as much as a "jelly" type case.

I am impressed at the quality of this screen protector (i got the HD Clear, for LG G3).The packaging, instructions, etc were very nice. It even comes with 5 or so "dust removal stickers" (really just stickers) that are probably the most useful thing you can have in the installation process.Tip for those frustrated by bubbles --- if they are small bubbles that just wont seem to go away no matter how hard you try to push them out, i can almost guarantee you that they are in fact caused by a small speck of dust! Use the dust removal sticker to lift up the screen protector, then use another sticker to take off the dust speck.

loved this shirt for my son as i am a guitar player. The 9-12 month size fits the same as a Carter's "12Mo" size for reference. The shirt is very soft. It is quite expensive, but upon receiving the item it was clearly marked as Made in the USA, so that makes the price a little easier to swallow.

Perfect replacement HID bulb for a 2007 Lexus GS 350. Appears to be the exact same bulb that was installed by the factory.There are installation guides on youtube as well as in lexus forums, i highly suggest checking those out first. Also google how to get those plastic clips off of your engine cover --- you do NOT just pry them out with a flat head screwdriver as recommended in some tutorials. I did that and snapped about half of them (luckily they are cheap to replace). There is actually a way to get them in and out with no hassle. I unfortunately did not research that before hand as i was to impatient to start my project, but hopefully you will! : )

the reviews for this product seem polarized. well, for me, this product works perfectly. The desk i am using it on is a wood ikea table, and the floor is carpet. The rest keeps my guitar firmly in place, and every time i go to pick up my guitar i've never had the rest fall of the table or anything like that. It stays put nicely.As an added bonus, the product says that it is made in the USA. That's always an A+ in my book.

perfect power supply for digitech RP360 modeling pedal. Same power supply as included with the pedal. Stays cool even after hours of use (the Planet Waves 9V power supply i bought first got extremely hot after 30 minutes of use).

As long as you aware of this products limitations, i think you'd be pleasantly surprised at how well it works.Is it going to give your nice dress shirt a freshly pressed look? Absolutely not. I might use the spray on some of my work clothing to help a little with wrinkles, but for anything major this will not do the trick.What this products exceeds at particularly well at is getting rid of wrinkles in soft cotton products. Best example is that nice soft T-shirt you might have folded up in a drawer and would like to wear on a sunny day. I had a soft cotton t-shirt (95% cotton, 5% spandex) that was mistankingly left in a drawer all crumpled up after being washed. It was a massive wrinkle mess. After spraying the shirt with this spray and smoothing it out on the ground, the shirt literally looked like it was fresh out of the dryer.Bottom line: casual clothing, soft cotton = this product is great. Formal work clothing = take the time to actually iron or get dry cleaned.

we bought the "Lavender Gray" color for our daughter. The duvet cover itself is fairly soft, maybe more so than you would think with "only" a 300 thread count. It washed and dried nicely in our machines.I would just note that the color is not really as shown. The picture, at least on my monitor, shows Lavender Gray as a muted purple/gray (exactly like its named). Well in reality the color is much more a bold purple; in my opinion there is no gray in it at all. Still a very nice color, but if you were looking for a muted purple color this is not it.

my little toddler loves to wear her rain boots wherever she goes (without socks) and they have now developed a horrid smell to them as you can imagine. Stuck these charcoal bags in them and the next day the boots literally smelled like they were brand new, my wife and I couldnt believe it.

bought three of these (various lengths). Pretty nice quality, connectors are decent enough. Fairly inexpensive. I first went with the Monoprice cloth series, but those were far too stiff in my opinion (I liked the connectors on those better though).This cable is very flexible and lays on the ground like a normal guitar cable would. No noise in my signal that i can tell.

I bought this scale only to use to weigh various packages for mailing. Works wonderfully for letters and boxes. I had a quite large box (24" x 17" 6") that I needed to weight ... the scale read 5lbs 12oz. I dropped the package off at UPS and had them check it on their scale just to be sure and UPS's scale read 5.75lbs as well. If this scale is as accurate as UPS's scale then it is sure accurate enough for me. Will not work for heavy packages as it only goes up to 11lbs

These are pretty nice shoes. Way overpriced at MSRP, but Amazon had them for more than 50% off which is more a reasonable price. Nice leather.The shoes themselves are a little bulkier than I imagined from the pictures. They are somewhat "clunky." The fit is VERY large in my opinion. I am pretty much a true mens sz 8 in every brand I've had (Nike, TOMS, adidas, diesel, etc). I ordered a 7M (40EU) in these shoes based on other reviews saying they ran large and am glad I did. Even the 7s are a touch big on me (although a 6 would be too small i imagine).

these are great socks with great designs. My wife loves them. However, I am not sure why Amazon lists the size as "9-11." The size tag on the actual sock packaging says "One Size, Fits 5-9" (as expected, for a woman's sock).

The material is very soft and stretchy ... does not feel like "true" denim but rather more like a soft legging. Great for active toddlers. The inside waistband has adjustable tabs to adjust the waist size. Color is as pictures (dark gray).

This is a very nice duvet cover, the material is very soft after 1 wash and I expect it will only get softer with more washes.My only complaints/comments are:- Most duvet covers I've owned have had a button closure that gets hidden under some extra fabric, or is offset so you cant see it. This cover's button closure is right at the botton and is not hidden.- We bought the "Lavender" color. It is no where near Lavendar. It is really a dusty pink/dusty rose. No big deal for us, but just a heads up for others.

This is a great mobile - very cute! However it is only compatible with cribs whose top rail (where you would secure the mobile to) is no more than 2.75" tall.We have a DaVinci Kalani crib, which is a very widely available, popular crib (it's actually the #2 best selling crib on Amazon! And it's available at most brick and mortar stores too). Unfortunately, this mobile will NOT fit that crib. The top rail on the Kalani is about 3" tall.For a substitute, all of the Carter's mobile (Jungle Jill, Wildlife Musical, etc) fit nicely and have room to spare for even bigger rails too.

I bought this bed rail for my toddler but ultimately returned it because it did not work with her bed. She is in a convertible crib (converted to full size bed) with a mattress and a bunky board (bunky board = 2" high box spring basically).If part of your mattress is covered by the bed frame (as was my case), this bed rail will NOT work. It is designed to sit in between the mattress and box spring, and it protrudes quite a bit from the side of the mattress. Ideal situation for this bed rail is a tall box spring that elevates the mattress far away from the bed frame.Dex Baby makes a  "universal" bed rail that is supposed to work without a box spring, but it is for some reason hard to find (I believe they discontinued it and are coming out with a new model soon).

Bought this indoor trampoline for our toddler for Christmas. It is a great product but not worthy of a full 5-star rating. Below is my full review:Packaging: the trampoline comes in a box that is approx. 4 feet long and maybe 1 foot high. It is fairly heavy. My packaging was filthy, not sure if others come like it too.Setup: another review mentioned putting something on the ground to cover it while building the trampoline. If you are setting it up indoors, I highly second this idea. I bought one of those plastic drop cloths used for painting at the local hardware store for 2 dollars. The parts of this trampoline arrived extremely dirty. The metal parts, as mentioned by others, have some sort of grease on them. Prepare to wash your hands multiple times and they will still smell like metal.The instructions are horrid. I know pretty much every other reviewer says the same thing. You can pretty much throw them away and just look at the picture of the trampoline to figure out how to build it. Building it took my wife and I a couple hours and was not hard at all. A lot of the time we just spent looking at the instructions trying to figure out what they were trying to say (before ultimately just throwing them away).Finished product: pretty nice. Some of the safety netting arrived with small holes in it already. I am not sure if these are going to be an issue or not in the future. Because of this, and the poor instructions, I took off 1 star. The instructions do not state a weight limit; another reviewer said it was 150 lbs. I got in the trampoline with my toddler (combined weight over 150 lbs) and the trampoline felt very sturdy. I obviously did not jump like I would on a big trampoline.The jumping area is just shy of 6 feet in diameter. The whole trampoline, including springs/mat, is a little over 7 feet in diamter. I estimate the total enclosure to be 8 feet tall or so.

Just wanted to add my review here and say that this cover does fit my Chicco KeyFit 30 infant car seat very well. Not sure why other reviewers are saying that it doesnt fit. Perhaps Chicco changed their dimensions over time. Or maybe the other reviewers dried their product (shrinking it); I lined dried mine after washing. The product has done very well for us, stays on the car seat nice and snug.

Like most parents, I have gone through my fair share of sippy cups (Zoli, Playtex straw cup, etc.)This is a pretty good one. I have found that being leak-proof and easy-to-clean are mutually exclusive things (if your cup is leak-proof, it's probably a little harder to clean since it has mechanisms to trap water). For that reason, I grew really tired of cleaning the Zoli cup.This cup, when the straw is up, is not leakproof. Hold it upside down and water WILL drip out, either from the side of the straw or the straw itself.When the straw is down (lid twisted shut), in my experience it has NOT leaked.The act of twisting the lid to close/open the straw is, in my opinion, not easy for a 2-year (just turned 2) to do by themselves. This is a good thing or a bad thing, depending on how you use this cup.My daughter (2) is on the small side, but she is stil able to easily hold this cup.I would purchase this cup again.

As others have noted, the sizing is off on these tutus.My daughter is 24 months old, and is on the smaller side (25% height and weight percentile according to the doctor).Per the other reviews, I ordered a size up (I ordered S 4-6). The tutu fits her perfectly, with not much room to grow. The waistband is not particularly elasticky (is that a word?) either, so it might not even last her that long.

I have owned two Snark headstock tuners (the blue ones). They are great products but I find one thing about them absolutely infuriating: the design of the "ball joint" that connects the tuner to the clip. Both of my Snarks have broken off at this joint. I am a home player - I do not put the tuners under any type of stress.This Fender tuner is a great alternative. The way the tuner connects to the clip is much more sturdy than a Snark. However, as others have mentioned, this Fender tuner display can not rotate as freely as a Snark. So, for live usage it may prove difficult depending on how it is oriented. However, for the home player, this tuner will work just fine.The tuner itself is much smaller than I thought it would be. It is smaller than a Snark (but not by much). The clip works well with a PRS headstock, which does not have a lot of free real estate compared to a Strat style headstock.The only real negative I see is to change the battery (and to put the first battery in) requires the use of a very, very small phillips head screwdriver. I build computers so I had one handy, but I would guess some people probably dont have a screwdriver small enough to do the job on hand.

have a black Verizon Razr M.My previous screen protector (bought off ebay) had developed a scratch/bubble after almost a year of use (which in my opinion is pretty good!). Replaced it with this one i bought from amazon. The amazon one was a little more expensive but I wanted to have easy returns in case the product was for the wrong phone/etc.The install is very easy. Does not require water. Simple and common three step process (peel first protective layer away, smooth out bubbles, peel second protective layer off). Packaging comes with a mini plastic card to smooth out bubbles and a small lint cloth to clean your screen before you apply (fogging up your screen w/ your breath and then wiping with the cloth worked very well).The screen is matte, and does a decent job of anti-glare. Swiping feels smooth, and the screen does not interfere at all with typing/etc.I will update this review if any problems arise. Otherwise, 5 star product.

Previously had fed my dog Innova Dry Dog Food Weight Management. Innova recently had a rash of 2-3 recalls in a very short period of time. The first recall I can forgive, I know mistakes happen. To have a second recall happen so shortly after the first (like in a month or so) was very frustrating, so I decided to look elsewhere.The Organix Weight Management dog food is similar in composition to Innova, similar fat/protein/fiber/moisture %s, and also has the benefit of being "organic." I am not sure how "organic" this dog foor really is but I guess its a nice thing to have.The price, when using subscribe and save, is very comparable to Innova and other brands (Wellness, etc).Have gone through 2 bags of this so far and very happy.

i bought this nightlight in August 2011, shortly before my daughter was born. For the first 1.5 years of her life, she pretty much just used this nightlight as a toy: Constantly pushing the button to cycle through all the colors. It was dropped. It was dropped some more.Fast forward to present day, now that she is in a toddler bed, we decided to see if we could use this nightlight instead of one that plugs into an outlet. After all the abuse it took, the night light still works perfectly. We charge it during the day, and then the bear easily lasts all night off the charger (11+ hours).This is all in the instruction manual, but:1) when you turn the bear on, the default setting is to only have the light stay on for 30 minutes. You bypass this by holding the button down until the red light goes away. Now the light stays on indefinitely.2) there is a reset switch that can be accessed using a needle ... can solve a lot of problems (see other reviews)I took off one star because at the current price (doesnt ever seem to go on sale) it is quite expensive.

Have been using this scanner with two computers, one with Windows 7 64 bit and one with Ubuntu 10.04.For both OS this scanner has been plug and play, no additional software needed.With Win7, just plug in the scanner to the USB port and Windows will automatically download the correct driver. From there, you can either install Canon's provided scanning software or you can use MS Paint (included with Win7) to do your scanning. Canon's software, as other reviewers touch upon, offer some great flexibility and some useful features (such as auto-cropping) so it may suit your needs. Me personally I don't like installing additional software if I dont need to, and I dont particular need any post-processing (color adjust, cropping, etc) features that the Canon software may have because I prefer to work in Photoshop or MS Paint.So for Windows, you do NOT have to install the Canon software if you do not want to. Simply open up MS Paint, and in the file menu choose the option to retrieve from Scanner. It will give you simple options (such as scanning color picture or black and white) and if you go into the custom settings you can set the DPI of the scan. Much less flexibility than the Canon software but at least you dont have to install anyhting else on your computer.At 300dpi in MS Paint a scan of a black and white paper (say, an application form) takes ~15 seconds. If I up it to 400dpi the same scan takes ~35 seconds. The quality is great and 300dpi is more than enough for simple form scans. I'd probably bump it up as high as i could for picture scans though, if you werent pressed for time.The scanning bed is approx. 8.5" by 12". Perfect size for a regular paper size document but slightly small for a legal size document (8.5" by 14"). To scan a legal size document I had to make two scans and then crop and paste them together (which is easily done in Paint). Kind of annoying but if you wanted to scan a legal size document in one go you would need an Automatic Document Feeder (ADF) scanner and those are much more expensive, usually.This scanner is a bargain and has worked for me with no hiccups so far. Would recommend.

After our old ice pack burst and left blue gunk all over our baby's food containers, my wife urged me to find an ice pack that was filled with only water. This product was one of the only ones that fit the bill on Amazon.I appreciate the fact that it:- is filled with only purified water- is made in the USA- label says that the product is non-toxic and 100% recyclableAs it is only water, it doesnt hold a freeze as long as some of the blue goo out there but i think it is a fair trade off.In case you were wondering, it does not seem like you can cut this ice pack into smaller cubes (or at least, you arent meant to).

Have had this product for a while now and I have purposely waited on reviewing it because I wanted to see how it actually handled an "accident." Well a couple of nights ago my 9 month old daughter (and apparently her baby friends from that morning's Mommy and Me class) got sick and she threw up all in her crib. Poor girl.Her clothes and the crib sheet were soaked in vomit. The fitted pad was also soaked, however the mattress underneath was not at all wet. After throwing this pad (and her clothes/sheets) in the wash they came out looking, and more importantly SMELLING, brand new!Thankfully we had two of these sheets so we were able to put the spare one on while the dirty one was washing. We actually just ordered a third, because if our daughter had thrown up again that night we would have had to go with nothing on the mattress.In case it helps, we are using this fitted pad with this mattress:Naturepedic No Compromise Organic Cotton Classic 252 Crib MattressIt fits well, a little snug b/c i think it shrunk a little but still looks good.

For reference, my daughter right now is 9 months old, ~26 inches tall, ~16-17 lbs. She can crawl, and pull herself and stand on objects(cruise). She can not walk or stand by herself.Pros:- cute music and sounds effects for baby- my daughter LOVED the beach ball attachment- on high pile carpet, this toy was stable enough for my daughter to pull herself up on it and stand/cruise- plenty of activities for baby to play withCons:- toy is NOT stable on anything other than carpet, in my experience. When we put this toy on our daughters playmat, it would slide around whenever she wanted to stand on it. Annoying for her and also somewhat dangerous. The feet are "hollow" so there is really no area to add tacky rubber or anyting like that to the toys feet to add more traction. You need to put this toy on carpet or a plush rug.- my daughter is on the small side for her age and I feel like (at her height) she will outgrow this toy soon. Its a little low so when she stands up holding on to it, she kind of has to hunch over.All in all, I havent really found a better alternative than this toy (except our ottoman, which our daughter loves to cruise on too). Not being able to put it on her playmat is annoying, and she might outgrow it soon, but overall we do not regret our purchase.

This is a great, relatively inexpensive toy that is extremely cute. It does not require any batteries to operate. When "walked," the alligator will wiggle his body and the various wood slats will make a "clapping" noise (I didnt find this noise annoying, but this is definitely NOT a silent toy). It is a little smaller than I expected - not a con, just in case you were wondering this toy is not that large (the alligator is less than a foot long).Little ones will probably giggle and laugh when they see the alligator move, and parents will adore the way their children look when "walking" this new pet.I appreciate the fact that this toy is marketed as being made of "non-toxic natural materials such as organic rubberwood". Would definitely recommend for anyone's toddlers and also it makes a wonderful gift.

Thermometer came exactly as pictures. The red piece is removable and is a nice silicone material. The actual probe itself is about 4 inches long. Great for cooking and checking temps. Note that (you can see in the picture) you are not supposed to immerse this thermometer in water, so if you need to check water temp use something else.

This chord chart is pretty decent, especially given how low cost it is. Folded up (as shown in the picture) it is slightly bigger than a regular sheet of paper (the chart in the picture is just folded in half).Open it up and you will see a chart of chords. Down the left are the keys: Ab - G. Across the top it tells you what variation of the chord you are playing:MajorMinor7thDim.Aug.Maj 6thMin 6thNinthSo in total there are 12*8 = 96 chords shown in the chart.On the page is a one page chart, "Chord Accompaniment Guide", contains all the keys again and across the top it goes over: The three principal chords, the three relative minor chords, and 6 alternate chords.

I spent the whole weekend taking shots with this Softbox Umbrella. I paired this umbrella with my Alienbees B400 strobe. The Alienbees strobe is a lot bigger than a regular off-camera speedlite so it doesnt fit perfectly into this umbrella (the hole in the umbrella is big enough to go over the strobe, but the strobe's casing is a little too big so you can't fully close/zip up the umbrella around the strobe).This softbox produced wonderfully soft, even lighting. The catchlights were nice and round. Using the strobe for hours at a time I never felt like the umbrella trapped any excessive heat.Setup is extremely simple --- exactly like opening an umbrella. The product comes already assembled, the photographer does not have to do anything except open the umbrella. Tear down is a little longer than a regular umbrella just because you have to tuck the fabric into the umbrella when you are closing it. Takes maybe 30 seconds longer. You know something is easy to setup/teardown when you can easily get it back into its original packaging (and this product can do that very easily).I recommend this product and will buy more whenever I can afford more strobes :)

This stand is great. Previously I had 3 of Cowboy Studio's lowest level light stands (the thin black ones that come in their lighting packages). This stand is much thicker and sturdier. I found the legs to come open much easier as well. I appreciate the air cushions, which the cheaper stands do not have (the center stand does not fall if the clasp comes undone, instead it gently lowers itself thanks to trapped air in the column).Right now I have on this stand an AlienBees B400 strobe and a 43" softbox. This stand is holding it up no problem, with no extra weights/sandbags necessary. Granted, I am not using it at a very tall height (photographing babies) so I can not speak to stability when fully extended.Also, you could possibly save some money by buying used from Amazon (Amazon Warehouse Deals). I picked one of these up "Used-Like New" from Amazon and I couldnt tell it was used at all (and i saved about 40%!!).

I recently picked this lens up about 3 months ago for my Pentax K-x.Previously, my "workhorse" lens is my Tamron 28-75mm f2.8.The low-light performance of this lens compared to my Tamron is impressive. With two additional stops (1.4 vs 2.8), I am now able to capture low-light pictures of my baby that were previously impossible to capture with my Tamrom (due to such a slow shutter speed). Where my Tamron at 2.8 may indicate a shutter speed of 1/15 for accurate exposure at a given ISO, with two additional stops from this prime I can go to a shutter speed of 1/60 at f1.4, which is much more suitable for capturing kids (not ideal, but much much better!)Images are sharp. At f1.4 sometimes images are soft but I more attribute that to user error due to the razor-thin DOF you are working with a 1.4.Cons would be the price, but there are rumors that Pentax lens prices will drop sometime this year back to their "normal" price levels. Also 50mm on a DSLR like the K-x is a little long for regular use...I find myself needing to back up a lot if I want to capture everything in the scene i want to (indoors, w/ baby)For what it's worth, I bought this lens from Amazon Warehouse Deals (Used - Like New) and it came as described. I saved a bunch of money and the lens works great. Hopefully you guys can catch a deal on this lens too, because it is definitely a keeper for any pentax user.

I ordered this skirt in my regular size and unfortunately, it is made rather small.  It also has a very strong, chemical scent when you first remove it from the package.  It definitely has to air out before you can even consider wearing it.  Besides those two issues, its a really nice skirt.  It is well made and it looks like the real thing.  It is perfect for wearing with leggings and boots now that the cold weather is here and its thin enough to wear it in warm weather as well.  Very versatile and a great addition to your closet.I received this item at a discounted cost, in exchange for my true and unbiased review.

I normally don't order skin products due to having a huge stock pile of them but when I seen that this lotion has only two ingredients, I was really interested and had to try it.  Its great.  It has a very light natural scent, no added colors or perfumes.  I use it on son who has sensitive skin and eczema, it doesn't cause any irritation which is rare.The lotion slides on smoothly and is quickly absorbed.  It doesn't feel greasy or tacky.  It is a great, every day lotion that will keep your skin baby soft and I highly recommend it for winter.I received this item at a discounted cost, in exchange for my true and unbiased review.

I ordered this wig for a Halloween costume and its really nice.  It fit perfectly, its full and lush and it was very easy to style.  It didn't get frizzy and the quality is high, especially for the price.  I am very happy with it and plan on purchasing more wigs from this company.

I am not normally a fan of using eye lash curlers because they pinch and many times leave a unsightly crimp in my lashes.  I decided to give these curler a try and I am very glad that I did.  Its great.  It is very easy to use, very comfortable to hold and no pinching.  My lashes look longer, my eyes look wider and brighter. I found this book a bit confusing and perplexing. There is talk about exorcisms and possession and similar subjects that will only speak to people who are comfortable with New Age concepts like those. I had trouble relating to this language, and though the book does contain more positive references, I was a bit put off by the negative messages and harsh judgments of others. I wish there had been more of the good stuff and less of the darkness referred to in the title.

This is an engaging collection of short stories, set in a wide variety of areas of the world and reflecting lots of differing cultures, styles and approaches to writing.Some of the stories that most spoke to me include "A Permanent Member of the Family," "The Happiest Girl in the Whole USA,"  "About your Aunt" and especially, "My Grandmother Tells Me This Story." My one reservation about this book is that there were many that were similar in tone and pacing. Readers looking for some fairly light entertaining reading may wish for more humor and upbeat musings. Still, there is much to enjoy and admire in these stories and in this series in general.

This is the newer expanded edition of a little book that came out in 1974. Both editions have much to teach about mindful eating, in a unique way that some people have found a bit extreme but others have found profoundly helpful. The earlier version is more succinct, but more background information is provided in this newer version. The nicest thing about both editions is the feeling of peace, comfort, and deep healing (!) that comes from practicing what the author has developed through his own long exploration. Highly recommended.

This is a compact, readable, and very  useful guide for anyone who would like to start selling beaded items or other handmade projects. In very few words, the author manages to cover lots of essentials like getting a business license, dealing with tax responsibilities, purchasing materials, setting up a business (online or not), pricing sensibly, marketing, staying open and creative, shipping, etc. etc.The author concludes the book with a helpful Q&A chapter. I especially appreciated her discussion of the mistakes that people typically make in getting started. The book is written with teens as well as adults in mind, and though she focuses on the basic essentials, I found in inspiring.Highly recommended to anyone with a desire to have some fun, and with some good planing and effort, share it with others.

I had quite mixed reactions to this book. On the pro side, I felt that I gained a much better understanding of the wide range of attitudes (including those opposed to my own) toward religious education in the schools. All of this has been very valuable and immediately useful to me in daily life.I also feel a greater respect for the complexities and challenges raised by this whole endeavor. To my surprise, I found myself a bit overwhelmed by the touchiness of the subject matter, given the attempt to keep schools neutral on the subject of religion, the emotion behind parents' desires for their children's spiritual guidance (and their right to feel that way), and  the subjective nature the material covered. I had difficulty with the idea of religious education in school for six year old children.Wertheimer's discussion of the well designed and implemented program in Modesto was somewhat convincing, and I hope that others like it will be developed and presented with as much care and sensitivity as that one,The biggest reservations I had reading this book had to do with the actual reading...sometimes very long paragraphs that sometimes wandered, and kind of a dry, staccato writing style that for me lacked flow.Still, Wertheimer has brought up very significant points, covered them well, perhaps helped us understand each other a bit more, and raised many questions well worth deeper consideration.

These little stitch markers are a big help, and colorful and fun to use in all sorts of ways. I love being able to color code as I mark stitch patterns. I have had no problem with them breaking...someone who wrote a little review of these online recommended closing them carefully by just putting pressure toward the top of the marker (where one piece slips into the other) rather than at the bottom. That really seems to work well. Love that the bright colors are so easily to see and keep track of. Good!

I am completely pleased with this hat. The brim is really well designed - wide enough to provide good sun protection, and nicely padded for unexpected comfort. the materials feel substantial and I like that the hat is adjustable, using velcro instead of a ribbon to be tied. All good! Wish I could get one in every color.

This is a short, engaging, and  moving book by a woman whose life is an inspiration. I very much enjoyed reading about Sister Abigail's phenomenal successes and accomplishments: overcoming extreme hardships from a very young age; getting a very complete education in spite of the resistance of her father and society; realizing her dream of becoming a nurse; helping so many people in that role; and most impressive of all, adopting and supporting large numbers of orphaned children. The book provides many pages of photos that bring the story closer to us, and Sister Abe's writing is always direct and readable.There is much to ponder and learn from in this short book.I wish in a way that she had gone into greater detail about certain aspects of her life; nevertheless,  this is a beautiful story, and most highly recommended.

I almost ordered a similar product, but accidentally came across this one, and I just LOVE it.There is lots and lots of room in the main compartment to store yarn, and there are lots of pockets on the outside. What I love the most is the organizer panel...the bag becomes a very nice little work center. I am amazed at how many tools etc.can be kept at my fingertips.Until I overloaded the outside storage pockets, the bag stood up very nicely...now it sags just a little bit. It is attractive, does not smell bad, is made out of good materials (no spooky chemicals noted) and keeps lots of stuff in order. Highly recommended!

I cannot recommend this book highly enough. Daniel Willingham has done a superb job of bringing insight and empathy to parents and teachers, and to children learning to read. The process of learning to read is explored and analyzed, and its  three main elements (decoding, comprehension and motivation) are discussed again and again throughout the book.The book is divided into three main sections, each dedicated to a phase of the child's development. There are frequent illustrations throughout. Gillingham's  take on all of this is imaginative and compelling, highlighted by stories of his experiences with his own children. Warmth, loving acceptance, and empathy are present throughout. Each chapter ends with a very useful summary, another are many sidebars with suggestions for readers to try. There is an intriguing list of references at the end, followed by suggestions for further reading.There is lots to experiment with here in this very readable, friendly, comprehesive, creative book. Most highly recommended.

This book is divided into tthree parts. Part I deals with the definition and nature of failure, and the fear and stigma associated with it. Part II discusses failure as it applies to various sizes of businesses at various developmental stages. Each chapter in Part III is dedicated to one of the 7 Rs of the Failure Value Cycle. The book is full of general advice,specific suggestions and takeaways that help one be ready to cope with obstacles  in the most positive way, growing and improving from them. As the authors write, Failure happens to all of us. so lets get over it and learn from it.Both of the authors are professors (having taught at Berkeley ,among other places) and their writing is articulate and very readable. There are useful aphorisms to ponder, like failure is like gravity.There is a fair amount of key concepts, but maybe that means that one doesnt have to read from cover to cover to benefit from this book.The 7 stage Failure Value Cycle is useful, though a bit cumbersome. I found the chapter on reflection to be the most valuable.All in all, this book has much to offer, anti for a book of this kind, it is well written. Recommended to anyone interested in becoming more resilient.

This book addresses the highs and low of friendships with between women.  Some of the topics discussed include the importance women's need for female company, different types or levels of friendship, loyalty among friends, choosing relationships over trivial disagreements, establishing healthy boundaries, and the importance of  humility. I was surprised to find that this book is classified as a general self-help book; it seems to be dedicated more to Christian readers. There is much discussion of religion; in addition, there are lots of  lovely insights and suggestions for opening up to others, building relationships, and just trying to be decent human beings. She discusses the fear that can underlie some of our impulsive, unfortunate choices. I appreciate her chapter about sensible use of technology.I ordered this book hoping to get a copy of of the final version for a young Christian friend who is dealing with cliquishness and even bullying at school. The book has a good chapter on bullying which is addressed to parents, but when I showed a few passages to the girl, she found  "Heart Sisters" to have a more literal interpretation of the Bible than she was accustomed to, and the book isn't really written for young people in particular. Still, the book offers warm, loving food for thought that would be particularly good for Christian study groups..

I have used a number of Lonely Planet guidebooks, and have been consistently impressed by the depth of detail, imaginative presentation, and vivid illustrations they have provided.This book strikes me as being very comprehensive and detailed. The book is divided into sections for each main area of France. There is a wealth of information about each region:  places to stay, restaurants, nightlife, museums, tours, festivals and other special events, and other  sights not to be missed, as well as travel information, numerous maps, and historical background. and interesting facts about the region being discussed.The early chapters include an excellent "first time France" section, a chapter on the  top 15 places to visit, a really helpful "plan your trip" chapter with regions "at a glance"  and  suggestions of outdoor activity. The final chapters deal with history (fascinating!) cuisine, the arts, transportation, and even a brief guide to the French language - so much information to absorb while planning, dreaming, and  making decisions for a trip.My only reservation about the book is that it is thick (nearly two inches!) and heavy, and the print is quite small (4.5 star).. This book would be great for the planning stages, but not one to be easily carried while traveling.

"Make My Day Paris" is attractive, packed with useful information, and compact enough to fit into a daypack or purse. The pages are made of card stock and scored, so that one can flip through them and view and combine ideas for morning, afternoon, and evening activity.  Maps including a transit map are provided. Each description of a place to visit includes "must see's" at that place, as well as suggestions places to dine in the area...also, most have a bit of historical background as well as useful information like hours of operation and basic facts. A "Make my Day" app can be downloaded for further information. I like the way the Eiffel tower has a different photo and description in the "morning" section than it does in the evening section. Some places to choose from:  museums, a bookstore, a hotel with a gorgeous ceiling, great places to shop,  concerts, operas, or dance performances, theater productions...as well as familiar landmarks like the Arc de Triomphe, the Louvre, Jardin des TuIleries, Champs Elysees, etc. etc. and of course, the Eiffel tower.Descriptions often give a bit of historical information as well as hours of operation and general information.This little book, and the London version made me want to plan a trip right now...when I do, I will appreciate the wealth of information found in this little book. It will be so helpful to go through the various "mix and match" options for planning each day. Till then, it is lots of fun to flip through the little page and just dream.

This little guide to London is attractive, intriguing, and small enough to be carried when traveling. The scored pages with ideas for morning, afternoon, and evening have color photos and vivid descriptions that made me want to plan a trip immediately. Maps are provided, along with useful details like hours of operation, transportation, and for museums, etc., Must Sees. The authors even mention other interesting sites to check out in the neighborhood. Thumbing through the book is like gathering inspiration from a well travelled friend who with intimate knowledge of the area.All in all, I think anyone traveling to London for the first time would find this extremely helpful, and  I look forward to using it myself. One can always find more detailed information online, but it is great to have the details that matter most laid out so attractively and practically in this lvery portable ittle book.  Highly recommended.

This is an engrossing collection of short stories. Some are about war and some about and art, sometimes merging together and sometimes separate. I was very taken with Rebecca Makkais ability to reveal the specifics of a story (time, place, people  involved, etc.) in gentle, gradually unfolding layers, each imparting  new shades of meaning. Make is also wonderfully adept at manipulating multiple threads, pulling them all together in ways that sometimes surprise the reader. Her writing is best described as gripping: sometimes dark and haunting, at other times, quirky and titillating, and often heartrending, moving, thought provoking. I like that she requires the reader to work a bit, filling in aspects of the story that she handles with such subtlety.Some of the stories are written in the most simple and direct language, while in others, the language is very florid and rich with detail. My favorite stories (I wont say which ones - no spoilers here!) were the darker ones. The first few in the collection drew me in immediately, but some of the stories that followed were so powerful that I closed the book to let it all just wash over me. A  few stories were less engaging, but I see that other readers liked those, so I wont comment further.All in all, this is an excellent collection, and makes for very satisfying reading. Rebecca Makkai is as skillful an author as she is imaginative. Highly recommended. Five stars for the best stories; four for the others, so 4.5 stars.

n this book, author Jeremy Bloom tells about his impressive career as an Olympic skiier and NFL football player, his transition to a business career, and the ways he coped with some big disappointments and unwelcome changes along the way. I have read quite a few books about failure and building on lessons learned from tough experiences. On those subjects, this book didn't stand out as much as certain others did ("The Power of Failure" by Charles C. Manz and "Rebounders" by Rick Newmanare some examples) though readers new to these ideas might find the book more inspiring. However, I was impressed by Bloom's descriptions of a positive, satisfying "bottom up" work culture, and the ideals of mutual respect, decency, trust, and accountability that he seems to aspire to in his company.Some of the topics Bloom discusses include  applying lessons learned  in a first career to a second one; intrinsic motivation over extrinsic; leadership styles; limiting the time spent mourning losses and mistakes; transparency on the job: staying humble despite success (what he calls "productive paranoia") and the deep satisfaction that comes from helping other people. I admire the work he is doing to help senior citizens by (1) giving to individual seniors and (2) encouraging respect for older people in our society. The last few chapters of this book offer some very touching moments.All in all, this is an uplifting book with many positive ideas. Recommended.

I have used various Omron pedometers over the years, and have found them to be quite accurate and reliable.I was excited to find this new product, the HJ-327T Alvita Wireless Activity Tracker. It is little and cute and seems nicely designed. Unfortunately, I have had many difficulties setting up this product and using it.Pairing has been a problem, and I had to remove the battery several times. I was surprised that I had to give personal information to the server in order to use this device locally. The instructions say to shake it a few times in any direction to activate it...I have had to jerk it pretty hard to get any response, and then it tends to shut down after a short time. Changing from screen to screen on the device sometimes works, but often not. After my first few tries, the step counter worked more accurately, which is great, but the connection between devices seems tenuous at best.I would be happy to just use the step counter, if that were easier to do, but alas, it is not, so, sadly enough, I think I will stick with my older Omron products.

In this book, Clark Elliott tells the harrowing story of his 8 year struggle with the debilitating symptoms of a severe concussion. He describes his symptoms in detail, and recounts stories of his attempts to make some sense out of what had happened to him. He tells of the challenges posed by things we take for granted: maintaining  balance, navigating stairs, walking, sleeping, etc., as well as the frustrations of  being tested and treated with standard medical procedures; being misunderstood by other people, including police, medical workers, and bystanders; retaining a full-time job as a tenured professor; and caring for children as a single parent.We learn what it is like to live with the need to stop everything frequently to let an injured brain recover from the simplest activities, and what it is like to know that at any moment the brain's "batteries" can wear out. He acquaints us with his careful study of his symptoms, sometimes quoting his copious notes. I admire his determination to find predictable patterns in what seemed so mysterious, and his wish to share his experiences in order that other concussion sufferers might know about the treatments that worked so well for him.Elliott writes in a very readable conversational style. Brain functions are described in very simple language. I was most impressed by his ability to explain delicate sensations and symptoms so articulately, and by his perseverance through such obstacles. My one reservation about the book is that so much of the text (about two thirds of the book) is devoted to the time before he got help. The later chapters about the treatment drew me in less, though the treatment itself is intriguing. Also, the earlier chapters get a bit repetitious, as he tells story after story of his difficult times and attempts to cope.Still, this is a fascinating book, which will appeal to readers interested in brain plasticity. This book also could be interesting to anyone who has had to find their own way out of a tough medical situation. Highly recommended.

n this book, authors John Kounios and Mark Beeman present an exploration of creativity and problem solving, focusing on those elusive sudden insights that be so stimulating and fullfilling. The authors identify two thinking styles: the insightful and analytic, explaining that most people tend toward one or the other, and probe into each of these. Some of the topics discussed include the stages of thinking that lead to the "aha" moment, what happens during the incubation phaseOne author is an expert on EEG testing, while the other is equally experienced with fMRI. Explanations of both of these are clear and illuminating, as are discussions of right and left brain contributions to creative thought. I enjoyed the chapters on the effects of rewards, deadlines, and such, as well as the nature of intuition, and motivation, and I particularly appreciated the suggestions for priming ourselves for more moments of insight. The authors illustrate their points with numerous stories of"eureka" moments experienced by fascinating people. Just a few examples: Helen Keller, cancer researcher Judah Feldman, geneticist Barbara McClintock, one of Elvis's concert promoters, a Buddhist monk, and Archimedes himself.Throughout, the book is written in an easygoing, conversational, very readable style. Very entertaining as well as informative. My one reservation is that there was a fair amount of repetition of basic principles, but perhaps that makes them stay with us longer. Highly recommended.

I am really happy with these scissors and the nice little caddy that stores and presents them.  The scissors come in bright, cheery colors (The ones I received are pink, orange red, lime green, and turquoise.) They easily cut through paper, plastic wrap, yarn, and light fabric. I appreciate that the blades have ruler markings...great for crafts. The caddy is  handy and easy to toe around. Nice that the four containers can be removed for convenient distributing, and are washable. The scissors are comfortable in the hand and seem well made...nice that a name tag can be applied. Blades seem a bit sharp for a very young child. Still these scissors could be used for a children's craft class, and they will be great to have on hand around for evenings of needlework fun with adults as well as kids. Well made, comfortable, sharp blades but blunt points, ruled, fun to use, cheery colors, kid friendly - highly recommended!

These shopping bags are very high quality. They wash well (machine wash separately, cold water; dry on gentle cycle) (minimal ironing if used in a situation where that would matter) and though they are not as tall as paper shopping bags, they hold a fair amount of stuff - as much as the plastic bags I have been using will hold. The seams on these cloth bags are reinforced and the bottom of each can be folded out so that the bag will stand up. The bags are made of one long piece of canvas-y fabric, with no bottom seam. The handles seem to be sewn on (reinforced  with crisscrossed stitching )in a way that they won't come undone. I like the soft fabric used for the handles that will be easy on hands when the bag is full. Nice to have 3 different colors - easier to find them in the wash. I am tempted to pin a little zipped purse into the printed one and use it as a craft bag...really like the cheerful, well defined print. The description claims that each bag holds 30 pounds...I am not sure I would try that, but it's good to know that that may be possible.In short, these are well made, attractive, useful for all sorts of things, and (!) washable...all good! Highly recommended.

I have never used anything quite like this before, and I was struck by how delightfully creamy and smooth this product is...no heavy, goopy oiliness.  I haven't detected any fragrance at all. My skin has definitely felt so much more smooth and less dry (feels good!) in the weeks that I have been using this product. I read some articles about retinol that say the real "age defying" effects can take several weeks to be evident, but I am impressed already. My skin tends to be sensitive, but I've had no reaction to this aream.My only reservations are (1) the price - it's a small tube, so I am using it sparingly, and (2) reading further, there is a warning that this kind of product shouldn't be used by women who are pregnant or breastfeeding.I will add to this review if and when I find noticeable changes in my skin. So far, highly recommended.

This is a very sharp looking, slim bottle in a very vibrant shade of blue. I like that it holds a full 20 oz. of liquid (directions say cold and not carbonated) and that it fits so easily into the outside pocket on my bag. I wanted something leakproof, and when it functions properly, this one is very leakproof when it is closed. However, I have had trouble locking the top into place (button is very stiff and resistant to pushing to the side) and the top on my bottle does occasionally pop open on its own.I have found that the bottle definitely does keep water icy cold overnight. It is too bad that the bottle is not to be used with hot beverages...one more thing to remember about this bottle as opposed to the other Contigo bottles (Contigo Snapseal Vacuum-Insulated Stainless Steel Travel Mug) I own. It's best to wash the top in the dishwasher, because otherwise the directions advise soaking it in hot soapy water for as long as 15 minutes...another things to remember.The only other concern I have about this bottle is that it is a bit hard to use it when driving because of its length. Also, I prefer the smaller opening for drinking that the other Contigo bottles have...less risk of spilling. Nice that the bottle is BPA free and has a guarantee.OVerall, this could be a fine product if the top could be locked in place more easily, and if it weren't limited in the ways listed above.

This is in so many ways a beautiful book. David Hawkins begins with very strong, convincing writing about the regrettable damage that anger and resentment can do to a relationship. He writes with great sensitivity and directness about couples he was worked with as well as his own marriage. There are no promises of instant cures - no lists of cognitive distortions; no suggested scripts; no 3 or 5 or 7 steps to complete peace, etc.Instead, he pleads with us to open our hearts and minds to the people we care about the most, in order to grow in empathy and understanding, help each other get needs met, and heal any hurts, present and past. In Dawkins's words: "Brooding and consuming resentment have no place in  an open heart, and (italics) an opening your heart is the only way to healing. Resentment is narrow an divisive - intimacy is the opposite...Resentment keeps us locked in our belief that we are right (self-righteousness!) and have a right to resent our mates. ..if we are to open our hearts, we must let go of resentment and see our mates as being wounded as we are, as needing healing as much as we need it."Dawkins goes on to discuss what he calls "accurate empathy...the greatest elixir to end fighting  forever" and the need for each partner, get grounded in what he calls one's core self before discussing troubling issues...to ease into those subjects, so that both parties calm down in the process. He advises that couples be on the alert for escalating tension and defensiveness that can signal the inevitable setbacks that can come unbidden. He supplies numerous quotes from other writers on this subject; notably John Gottman, who has done such wonderful work with couples.While there could be more specific suggestions for working on a relationship (4.5 stars) I really appreciate Dawkins's gentle, caring approach and his intimate, conversational style in this very readable book. Though it is listed as a Christian book, aside from occasional biblical quotes, there is very little reference to a particular religion here, and the principles he is espousing seem universal.Another brief passage to ponder: "Herein lies the magic: When we talk to each other from our true, best self, rather than the angry, protective part of ourselves, we are likely to hook the best self of our mate. When we speak from our best selves, we are calm, clear and concise...from this emotional place we discover that kindness begets kindness."Easy to say and sometimes hard to do, as Dawkins acknowledges. Still, he encourages us to hold the ideal and do our best as imperfect human beings. Highly recommended.

In this book, psychologist Charles E. Dodgen tells of his work in a nursing home, and gleans 28 lessons that might be taken from his experience there. Originally intended to be a guide for those working in nursing homes, the book is divided into 28 chapters, each focusing on a particular lesson or theme. Each chapter is followed by a brief section entitled "Applying this lesson to your life," with suggestions for further thought and action. In the final chapter, Dodgen summarizes each lesson, highlighting key points for additional study and thought.Here is a quote from the book: (p. 24) "These universal truths about life and humanity, gleaned from experiences in the microcosm of the nursing home, can be employed to guide behavior in our incredibly complex, full-speed, everyday lives. My book is about a developing a positive life at any stage. It is not a book about the elderly or nursing home resident per se...the elderly are the same as anybody else. The aged person as discussed my book is you, me, and the child next door; she may be...living under different conditions...but is dealing with the same basic challenges. The solutions employed to great benefit in the nursing home can be used successfully by anybody."Some of the subjects Dodgen explores include grief as opposed to depression and demoralization; the universal importance of love; responsibility for one's health at any age; ways to create better habits; the plasticity of the brain and our ability to benefit from that; the process of adjustment to major life changes like entering a nursing home; the healing power of true empathy; our need for friends and family; and the search for the silver lining in a tough situation. I especially appreciated the chapters on changing one's attitude and making positive changes in baby steps, and resisting the impulse to overreact to upsetting situations by pausing to calm down. He also discusses the importance of spiritually fulfilling activities like meditation, focusing on gratitude, spending time of nature, etc., and he encourages us to work through crises and losses by filling our days with new interests, social interaction, etc. He instructs us on ways to both give and receive loving care.There is so much positive energy in this book. Dodge write with sensitivity and compassion. Some of the lessons will be very familiar to those who have read self help books, while other lessons are more unusual.
