Recommended to readers who seek to understand the far end of our life cycle, and who are interested in a self help book with a different approach.

In this book, anthropolgist/social worker Jorja Leap tells the story of her work coleading a group for fathers in Watts, Los Angeles, over a period of years. Leap, who had worked with Father Greg Boyle of Homeboy Industries, gives a sense of what it is like to grow up in Watts, and the formidable challenges one might face: lack of employment (especially after incarceration), young children to support, complex love and parenting relationships; the temptation to use drugs, or to sell them to support children; tensions between ethnic groups; gang related violence at times; police barreling in to control crises and in so doing creating deeper schisms between groups; disproportionate numbers of people of color in the criminal justice system; big promises by politicians that come to nothing; budget and funding struggles; etc.Leap also highlights some of the positive sides of things: support of large, extended families; the men's  desire and determination to give their children what they themselves were denied;  and the men's slowly deepening devotion to the Project Fatherhood group, as the men bonded with each other, eventually not only supporting their own children with more understanding and empathy, also but reaching out to help other young people in the community. There are some very moving moments in the book, and I was impressed by the resilience and courage of all concerned. I felt that I lgained a deeper understanding of the issues that our society has yet to seriously address and resolve.Highly recommended.

In this book, Carla Powers does exactly what the title promises: she tells about her studies of the Quran with Sheikh Mohammed Akram Nadwi, a scholar of Islam, "extremist quietist," and longtime friend. Some of the topics covered include some history of Islam; the meaning of the titles, "Islam" "Muslim," the wide range  of interpretations of the Quran and other texts; distinguishing between customs defined by local tradition vs. those dictated by the Prophet in the Quran; the issue of identity; true piety vs. going through the motions of religious observance; the meaning of "jihad" and other words that we hear in the news; Islam's relationship with other religions; salvation after death; extremist groups and their beliefs; and so on. Women's issues are discussed at great length, as Powers draws distinctions between what customs are practiced today and what the sheikh believes was done in earlier days, perhaps by the Prophet himself. A chapter is devoted to the sheikh's research on nine thousand women who were highly respected for their knowledge and wisdom through the ages. Other issues covered include education for women, veiling, separation from men in religious observances and other events, family relationships, and child marriage. Powers shares her own complex feelings about these subjects with us, and writes with sensitivity and candor. I really appreciate the glossary she provides, as well as the end notes and bibliography that suggest more fascinating books  than one could ever get to.My one disappointment was that the the title led me to expect more verse by verse discussion of the Quran. However, other books listed in the bibliography seem to fulfill that need.I recognize that this book really centers around the work of one Islamic scholar. Still, I found the book engrossing, informative, very readable, and hard to put down. Highly recommended.

This tank top is quite lightweight and open; great for summer. I really like the crisscrossed back straps. The  fabric is quite porous, which I imagine will make it more comfortable (cooler) in a workout than polyester sometimes is. I received the charcoal gray (Storm) color, which is quite muted and would go with a wide range of other shades. The top part is clearly intended to fit snugly; mine is a bit loose. The rest of the shirt is quite loose fitting and slightly flared at the hemline - a nice line to wear over pants, leggings, etc., and comfortable in hot, muggy weather. When I first unpacked the shirt, it had an odd smell, which washed out completely. No problems with washing and drying the shirt in the machine on a low setting.Because the top is quite porous and its armholes are cut very wide and hang low, one would expect to wear something under this top. The fabric feels slightly stretchy and the straps are soft elastic. The fabric is not as soft as some, but comfortable none the less.  All in all, this is a nice looking top and easy to care for.Recommended.

I have enjoyed listening to David Brooks and Mark Shields haggle things out on the PBS news hour, and find both of them keen, articulate, and as knowledgable as they are witty. In this book, Brooks traces the cultural change from the model of "little me" (based on what he refers to as "moral realism") to that of the "big me" which is prevalent today, and the current overemphasis on qualities for external success and self-promotion ("Adam I,") rather than the more subtle values that help us get along with each other, bounce back from adversity and learn from it, and lead more satisfying lives ("Adam II").To illustrate his point, Brooks examines the lives of many prominent people, presenting accounts of their lives and the prevailing attitudes of the time. I found appreciated the chapter on civil rights activists A. Philip Randolph and Bayard Rustin to be particularly stimulating. Sometimes Brooks's main point is a bit obscured by the rich detail he provides in these chapters. The final chapter,"The Big Me," is the book's crowning glory. Brooks elaborates eloquently on his basic idea, and provides a "humility code" which I found both practical and inspiring.Though some of the biographical chapters made for slow reading, I found this book extremely satisfying, and will be returning to it periodically. Brooks's ideas brought to mind two other books: Martin Buber's "I and Thou" (corresponding somewhat to the concepts of Adam I and Adam II ) and David McCullough's more recent "You are Not Special."Brooks ends his introductory chapter with these words: "These are the people who have built a strong inner character, who have achieved a certain depth. In these people, the climb to success is surrendered to the struggle to deepen the soul. After a life of seeking balance, Adam I has bowed down to Adam II. These are the people we are looking for."Highly recommended.

In this book, Amy Kittleston traces the changes of belief and attitude that unfolded from about the mid eighteenth century on, as free thinkers challenged the beliefs of Calvinism and became more open to the idea that other cultures, traditions, and even religions might have some validity, and questioned the relationship to the nature, people, and the deity.  She devotes each chapter to one of seven important people, some known to us and some less known, who were influential in this gradual evolution: John Adams, Mary Moody Emerson (aunt of Ralph Waldo), William Ellery Channing, William James, Thomas Davidson, William Mackintire Salter, and Jane Addams. She often digresses to discuss other fascinating people at great length, sometimes spending several pages on them in the midst of a chapter about someone eIse. In this manner we learn about Alexis de Tocqueville, Samuel Butler, John Stuart Mill, Walt Whitman, August Comte, William Wordsworth, and others. While all of this is engrossing, it is sometimes hard to follow the basic narrative. Sometimes Kittleston gives us so much background information that it almost seems as if this one book could have been several.Much as I enjoyed reading about the changes in peoples relationship to religion, the people she discussed, the various ways in which they interacted, and the increased attention to racial equality, womens rights and similar issues, I found this a slow read, and one that demands a fair amount of work from the reader. I intend to go back and reread sections of the book with fresh attention. Still, there is much to learn and ponder here. Recommended to readers willing to keep a very steady focus throughout.

Like other DK books I have read, this book is beautifully done, presenting a vast amount of potentially confusing information with surprisingly few words and lots of eye-catching graphics.  I have greatly enjoyed working my way through, page by page, absorbing new ideas and gaining a deeper perspective on this complex subject. I really appreciate the creative ways the authors break down and represent difficult concepts. The book has four main sections: "How Companies Work," "How Finance Works," "How Sales and Marketing Works, and "How Operations and Production Work." Each smaller section (often 2 pages)  offers its own "How it Works" paragraph and often a "Need to Know" sidebar. Case studies are also presented.  Here is an example of the way material is broken down: the section on "Financial Reporting" starts with a general explanation, followed by "Types of Financial reports,"  a brief description of the eight steps of the accounting cycle, presented in detail on the following two pages), a section on "the annual Report," "Types of Accounting," (seven of them) and "Financial Statements:" 6 questions answered, followed by brief answers and references to other pages that give further information. All of this is attractively laid out on two pages. I was fascinated by the sections about collecting and warehousing consumer data, as well as the sections about production (batch, flow, continuous - learned something about papermaking) and new product development.This is a gorgeous book and a valuable one. It would make an ideal gift - great for young people;. It  is a terrific reference and a wonderful coffee table book...so satisfying, whether read systematically or just thumbed through. Most highly recommended to readers wishing to learn more, and enjoy doing so.

This is a very nice assortment of fine chocolates. They come attractively packaged, and would make a nice gift. I appreciate the fact that they are long (about two and a half inches) and thin and scored in the middle, which makes it easier to save half of each for later in moments of self-restraint. Serious chocolate lovers might especially enjoy the chocolate mousse flavor as well as the dark cream...especially smooth,  rich and satisfying. The coffee and cream flavor has a very strong coffee flavor and a white chocolate layer on the bottom. The hazelnut chocolate is just a bit overly sweet for my taste. Milk chocolate is used in three of these; dark chocolate in the rest. The calorie count is about what one would expect. I love the creamy texture. They arrived in perfect condition. They look elegant enough for entertaining. Highly recommended.

In this book, Jia Jiang confronts his fear of rejection and consequent embarrassment, and shares his developing insights into the process with us along the way. It was interesting to read about his growing objectivity about rejection, and his realization that so often the circumstances in which we are turned down for something are really so much more complex than they might appear. I appreciate his willingness to put himself in uncomfortable and sometimes ridiculous situations and to blush a little, and I especially appreciate his ability to learn from disappointments, using these experiences to become stronger, wiser, and more understanding of other people and the world. This is a quick and easy read, though some readers may prefer to linger and absorb the lessons presented here.Many of Jia Jiang's conclusions align perfectly with common sense, and many of the concepts presented will be familiar to readers who have read self help books. For that reason, this book may appeal most to readers just starting out in life. Also, the kinds of risks that he took are for the most part so unrelated to real work issues that it is hard to take them very seriously. Still, the author makes some interesting points, often with humility and a nice dose of self-effacing humor.

I  thoroughly enjoyed reading this book about the life of Indra Devi, the times she lived in, the places she lived and worked, her wide range of abilities, the fascinating people she met, and the growth of interest in India and eastern religion, as well as the origin and development of yoga in its various versions and stages. The book is packed with information about Ms. Devi's unusual life and the many intriguing people she interacted with during her long (just short of 103 years). Michelle Goldberg states from the introductory chapter that she writes as an admirer rather than a believer, and her slightly cynical stance on the romanticized view of India that has been popular over several generations may surprise some readers.  However, I appreciate the thoroughness of her research and her efforts to dispel popular myths, particularly about hatha yoga practices. I especially enjoyed her frequent digressions from Devi's life story: we learn about the birth and growth of the Theosophical movement and the lives of Mme. Blavatsky and Annie Besant, as well as the life of Krishnamurti, from the time he was discovered as a young boy. Goldberg also tells us about the many important people Devi met, including Rabindanath Tagore, Mahatma Gandhi, Swami Vivekananda, Sai Baba, and so many other influential people like B.K.S. Iyengar, Yehudi Menuhin, and Pattabhi Jois. Goldberg also tells something about the political situation in all of the many places where Devi lived and worked. It was intriguing to follow Indra Devi through so many tages, and to learn a bit more about the situations faced by women through those years.  Goldberg tries to give an objective view of Devi's life and her character, highlighting her positive energy and dedication to her cause as well as her very human imperfections."The Goddess Pose" will be most satisfying to readers looking for a more objective look at yoga and mysticism, the emergence of new age philosophies, and the life of Indra Devi. Though this is not the quickest read due to the amount of information Goldberg manages to convey, there is much to enjoy here, much to wonder at (some real surprises!) and much to return to for further thought.

In this very interesting book, Kate Bolick explores the longstanding questions faced by women through the ages, and the ways that interpretation of these questions has changed over time. Some of the conflicts that she discusses at length include marriage vs. staying single; ongoing companionship vs. solitude; shared decision making vs. autonomy; financial independence vs. joining forces with another person; the push to acquire possessions vs. living a more spartan life; being defined by a job vs. living and working completely on one's own terms, etc. She repeatedly comes back to the strong urge for self-determination, living by her own compass, savoring the beauty of being alone, and remaining true to her overriding desire to write. Still, she doesn't hide from us the many ups and downs she experienced, including some periods of confusion, self-doubt, regret, and at times, painful depression.Throughout the book, Bolick refers to her 5 "awakeners:" strong female writers who, though they did not live as spinsters all of their lives, lived by their own ideals, going against the norms of their time. She devotes portions of a chapter to each of these women, and also refers to numerous other fascinating, bold, freethinking women along the way.  Because the early edition I read lacks a list of sources or endnotes, I found myself jotting down titles and authors of books she discusses here and there.I especially appreciate the historical information Bolick provides, particularly concerning the three decades of change leading up to 1920, when women finally acquired the right to vote.  My one reservation about the book is that Bolick's detailed stories about her love life sometimes cause things to slow down a bit, particularly in the early chapters. When she finally writes about her fascinating study the "awakeners" and its effects on her life, the pace definitely picks up. I found last two chapters  especially powerful, riveting, and often inspiring.So though the first chapters may give a misleading impression of the real content of the book, "Spinster" is  definitely worth reading;  most thought-provoking.

In "The Caregiver's Companion,"  Carolyn A. Brent tells us of her experiences caring for her elderly father in his years of illness and his unfortunate struggles with dementia. Brent has collected a formidable amount of very valuable advice gleaned from her own struggles, and she shares it here in a well-organized and extremely useable format. Each chapter of the book provides good, practical information and advice, followed by questions to be asked of oneself and others when decisions need to be made, or when things change.  Brent gives a realistic description of the various physical emotional, and financial demands that often arise in caring for an ailing loved one. A few topics covered in the book include the decision to take an ailing relative into one's home; how that decision affects the life of the caregiver; the challenges of choosing and paying for longterm care;  communicating with relatives who may not be cooperative; being prepared for emergencies; end of life issues and the various documents that need to be in place to support the patient; and the supreme importance of taking care of oneself throughout, in order to maintain a good quality of life and also give better support to the relative. I especially appreciate the chapters on crucial emotional, financial, and legal conversations to have with the patient and as a family. Lists of very helpful services and are provided at the end of the book. Throughout, Brent's love for her father are apparent, as are her compassion for others facing these challenges and her insight into the best ways to proceed.The book ends with a "cheat sheet" for caregivers, summarizing the most important considerations for all concerned.This book is an extremely valuable source of information, comfort, and support.  Brent repeats main points often, making it less necessary to read the entire book, though I found it extremely useful to do so. The only reservation when reading it was that I found it hard to read about her personal struggles with her siblings, though I a sure that her story could be helpful to others facing similar situations.Most highly recommended.

These are strong, flexible bags, and I like the silver ties. The bags are nice and tall, and a bit stretchy. I tried filling it to the top and scrunching it all down, and the bag held up really well. I put lawn wate with lots of sharp edges into the bag, and there were no punctures or tears from contact with those sharp twigs, thorns, etc. The bags can be stretched over the rim of a trashcan, and can therefore fit different shapes of cans.  (The box claims that they are puncture resistant - seems to be true.The one thing I am less thrilled about is the fragrance...perhaps it helps mask odors, but I find it quite perfumy and unforunately, a bit physically irritating.  I had hoped to use these bags for storage of some craft materials, but don't want my yarn etc. to take on that perfumy scent.  People who a light fragrance will be very happy with these bags. Others may prefer to look for an unscented product. Recommended, with that one reservation.

I am very impressed with the thought and insight and careful planning that obviously went into this program of study for the GED. The explanations of the program, pretests, online videos and other resources, practice tests, and copious instruction are well organized, making the material accessible and self-monitoring easier. The course covers four major subject areas: Reasoning through Language Arts, Mathematical Reasoning, Social Studies, and Science, which is divided into sections for LIfe Science, Earth and Space Science, and Physical Science. Each of these four subjects begins with a detailed explanation of the test for that subject. I am impressed with the vast range of material covered by the book, and am really enjoying making my way through it. The online materials are excellent, and help the student get organized and keep from getting overwhelmed.This is a terrific resource for study. Though the ideal situation would be to be part of a class, or work with a tutor, particularly for the math test, this Kaplan book and online materials can be used as a terrific supplementary guide. This program may appeal to younger students who would like to have a preview of high school material as well as  older adults interested in revisiting and reviewing these subjects. Highly recommended.

This book offers a fascinating and detailed exploration of the workings of the brain, related to human behavior;  specifically, to anxiety and depression.The layout of the book is appealing, and makes complex information accessible. There are lots of sidebars entitled "Neuroscience" in which Arden probes more deeply into the areas of the brain and their function and interaction. Other sidebars entitled  "Client Education"  provide well worded explanations and suggestions for explaining these concepts to clients. The book concludes with a long and intriguing list of references, an index of authors cited, and a general index. Also, at the end of the text of the book (p. 223, there is a list of the many abbreviations used in the body of the book - good to know about before one starts to read. Key concepts are simplified and underscored by various acronyms.This book is a wonderful resource, useful in so many ways: to expand one's own knowledge of brain function; to better understand the two sided relationship between brain and behavior; and to reassure clients and encourage them to step out of their comfort zones take steps to make their lives better. I find it admirable that the author's underlying purpose is to somehow "find common denominators among therapy types" and offer a brain-based approach that "discards the purely theory driven cul-de-sacs based only on the tight confines of a particular school," thus eliminating confusing fads based on conflicting theories. There are lots of multimultisyllable words (My favorites: "geniculohypothalamic" and psychneuroimmunological") but when necessary, good explanations are given throughout. I could not put the book down.John Arden has written several self-help books based on similar material for the lay reader. "Brain2Brain" is written for therapists, but could be useful for teachers and others with a strong interest in the inner workings of the brain.

This is a well made and useful product for organizing papers. I like that theprongs are fairly sturdy and the holes are reinforced, though the paper the dividers are made of is quite light. I have also used the Avery Ready Index Table of Contents Dividers for classification file folders with bright colored numbered tabs along the sides instead of the bottom, and frankly, though it is a little easier to flip things open using tabs at the bottom, I prefer the side tabs because of the bright colors and larger numbers (easier to read)...also, I find the side tabs more convenient when storing the folder in a file box.All in all, this is a very good product, and makes organizing easier and more enjoyable.

I didn't expect to like this book as much as I did; in fact, in many ways, I love this book, and recommend it to anyone new in business. Daniel Lubetsky does a fine job of analyzing what it takes to grow a business with the values and goals of Kind and his other pursuits: the philosophy of AND; the fervent desire to treat everyone decently, encourage and support acts of kindness stay accountable and open with all concerned, and even bring together people from conflicting groups in the process. Above all, I really admire his willingness to share both his successes and his most regrettable mistakes. In fact, that is where the book shines the most, as he tells us to "celebrate" every failure and doggedly learn from it.I also was moved by  his determination to emulate his Holocaust survivor father, who passed away suddenly some years ago. Some of Lubetzky's writing is so moving that I took it into quiet meditation, in order to fully absorb his ideas. I love his commitment to taking the high road, aspiring to high ideals, while still attending to the necessity to be financially successful. What a breath of fresh air, considering how greed without direction or guiding principles seems to affect every aspect of life today.My own reservation about this book is that there is a fair amount of repetition. Still, this is a surprisingly useful and at times beautifully written book. Most highly recommended.

These dividers are very useful, quite durable, and nice looking.  The bright colors are attractive and cheery,  the laminated tabs are nice and big, and Avery makes it easy to print the table of contents, using the templates they provide at their website. The prongs seem pretty strong, the holes are reinforced with copper, and the paper is somewhat heavier than the usual. I find the 8 tab version of this product a bit more useful, and I prefer the tabs to be on the side rather than at the bottom because they are larger and easier to see, and a little better for storage in a file box. I imagine that this product will keep its fresh appearance over time.

I am in the process of sorting and filing some old papers, and these dividers have been a big help. I really enjoy the bright colors of the laminated divider tabs and tthe able of contents sheet. the copper reinforced holes and fairly heavy paper hold things together and keep things neat and orderly. The folder, with two prongs, is quite heavy, too. Avery provides templates for customizing things. Handy, nice looking and durable...highly recommended.

This is an outstanding product: sleek, easy to maneuver, and very quiet. I really like the overall design, and I much prefer the canister shape of this vacuum to the heavier upright models I have owned in the past. The attachments fit so nicely into the unit itself, without constantly falling out (as they did in an old vacuum I used to have) and I love the way the cord is concealed in the unit, and is so easy to pull out and retract.It's great that there are 6 settings to experiment with. The vacuum works quite well on my old low pile carpet on a low suction setting, though I had to experiment a little to get it to work smoothly.  I like the long stainless steel wand and ample cord...so nice not to have to stop and change outlets constantly...I can plug it in in a central place, and progress down the hall vacuuming adjacent rooms. That alone cuts down on the dread of vacuuming and temptation to procrastinate. Cleaning is a pleasure with the three included attachments...it's easy to get under things and behind things and into little spaces, and deal with cat hair and upholstery and  dust. Changing the bag is very easy. The light is a nice extra...I was surprised by how helpful it is at certain times of day, though I had to get used to the timed fadeout.The only reservations I have are that it appears that the Miele bags are quite expensive, and that the vacuum itself is much more expensive than any vacuum I have considered buying in the past. However, it seems to be very sturdily made, and by a very reputable company.  I like to do a quick cleanup of well traveled areas in my work space fairly frequently. That is easily done with this vacuum cleaner. Highly recommended.

This is a really nicely made and practical product. I really like the feel of the wood, and the spacing of the pegs, which allows one to use worsted weight yarn.Just wanted to inform interested people that this did NOT come with a DVD or any kind of written instructions whatsoever. There are lots of good videos about this particular product and about loom knitting in general online, but I was a little sad not to get the DVD I thought I was paying for, or even the written instructions that other reviewers mentioned.Still, this is a great product and provides limitless hours of fun and creativity.

In this  well researched book, Sandy Tolan presents a  vivid picture of life in the occupied territories of Israel over the past decades. He states outright at the beginning that he is writing from the Palestinian point of view, and presents blow by blow accounts of wars, insurgencies, attempts at negotiation, disappointments, and seemingly endless strikes and retaliations. We learn what it is like for children to live amid checkpoints, armed soldiers on guard, an 8 meter separation wall, suicide bombings, etc. etc. We read about these children hurling stones from rooftops and losing relatives to violence and imprisonment. We also gain insight about infighting among various groups, national and international boycotts, UN and American involvement, etc. etc.In the midst of all of this, we also learn about the fine work of a young man named Ramji who established a music school and related programs in various locations in order to bring music (and hence, joy and perhaps even a measure of security) to Palestinian children. We follow Ramji to the US and to France as he gains a musical education, and we meet Edward Said and his wife, Marian as well as Daniel Barenboim, who founded an orchestra made up of 40 Israeli Jews, 40 Arab musicians (very few Palestinians) and 20 Spanish players. Ramji's growing frustration with the occupation opens us to a deeper perspective on this very complex subject.There is a great deal if information here, but for the first half or so of the book, I really wished Tolan would invite us into the hearts and minds of these young musicians, both Palestinians and Jews, to help understand how they really felt about other; how much they knew about each other; and whether they were able to listen to each other, truly empathize and learn from each other, and so on. We hear very little of this for a long, long time. At one point a mixed group of students takes a tour of Buchenwald. We are not told anything about the reactions of the students of either side. When we finally do hear more about the inner lives of these young people, it is fascinating, illuminating, and very moving, though it is clear that there is very deep pain and sensitivity on both sides.There are some very beautiful and uplifting moments in this book, but the overall effect is shocking, horrifying and very sad, especially considering the desparation faced by both groups in the past and the intensity of their reactions today. There is much to ponder here about human nature; attachment to land, belief, and tradition; threats to our security and our knee jerk reactions; the immense challenges of getting along; and what music can and cannot do to help us endure.

This is a very  sturdy little product, and feels more substantial than a similar one made by Polder. The TimeStick seems to be water resistant, whereas the Polder gets completely thrown off it comes anywhere near moisture, and if it gets too wet, it dies completely. The TimeStick comes in fabulous colors, and I think the cord is better quality.However, there are some other considerations with the TimeStick. First, the buttons are hard to push, and second, harder to see, which gave an elderly relative trouble. Third, the alarm is actually louder than the Polder that I own (which is a year or two old and has had a great deal of use) which is bothersome to others in the vicinity. Fourth  the TimeStick costs twice as much as the Polder.Considering how delicate the Polder is (the piece of plastic that holds the battery in place needs to be reinforced with tape, or the battery can easily be lost) and how often they need to be replaced, the TimeStick is a better buy, unless the things listed above are problematic.

These are good strings with a nice strong, even sound. I especially like the D, which is warm and resonant, and particularly, the A, which has a richness that I have been looking for for quite a while. I like is better than the Larsen or the Jargar A strings, which seem to be favorites with lots of people these days.These new strings don't seem to need a long breaking in period, unlike some other D'Addario strings I have tried; the Kaplans stayed quite well in tune and sounded beautiful from the time I put them on. I am a just a little bit less thrilled with the G (not quite as focused) and C (seems a tiny bit muted) than with the upper two strings; perhaps with more vigorous playing, they will open up a little. I am curious to see if the overall sound will change over the first weeks of playing...will report back if it does.

This book has much to offer that is positive, uplifting, and above all, particularly sensitive to the needs of young people as they face the challenges of growing up in today's hectic society. So much resonated deeply: the idea of encouraging young people to develop a strong, reliable inner compass and a well-established "command central'" as well as a set of consistent values that they can use as a foundation for decision making; a strong sense of self and their role in society; and the courage to stand up for what they know is right.  I also appreciate her attention to individuation, the brain's process of maturation (explained in simple, direct language) and especially, her concept of the process of growing up as a spiritual search. There are many beautiful passages to highlight and reflect on at length. Her lists of "Six Spiritual Strengths"and "Seven RIght Things: Opportunities for Spiritual Parenting" will certainly be helpful for many families.There is so much good in this book, but there were also some perplexing aspects to it all. First of all, the use of the word "spiritual."  She quotes people saying "Children are spiritual..." "I'm not religious, but I'm a very spiritual person..." and so on, but doesn't really define what she means in those contexts. "Spiritual" can mean everything from taking a weekly yoga class to trying with all of one's strength to evolve and conquer negative habits, to feeling strongly aligned with something greater than oneself, to being part of an extremist group, perhaps with questionable values. Her early definitions are extremely broad, opening the door to people who have very strong beliefs as well as people who love nature, but don't care for much more structure than that. However, later on in the book, she says emphatically, more that once, that in order to receive the benefits of being spiritual, young people must have a two way relationship with a higher power, in which there is give and take; communication. That is quite different from her earlier definition, and could be confusing to some readers and even discouraging to others.Also, Dr. Miller really doesn't have much to give to people who have been in some way disillusioned by religion, perhaps because the faith they grew up with didn't align what they read, heard, saw, felt, etc. in school and the world around them. While she encourages such people not to hesitate to provide some kind of spiritual substance for their children, she doesn't acknowledge the fact that some young people run away from religion - and therefore, spirituality - either because what they were taught as a child just doesn't make sense to them as adults, or in  more extreme cases, because they were actually hurt in some way by being part of that group or by the people involved. I wish she had offered some kind of encouragement for young people in these situations.Still, there is much good in "The Spiritual Child," and I admire and respect Dr. Miller's efforts to understand and reach out to young people. However, I felt throughout the book that she is providing us with a sense of the ideal here, while real life is complex, and individual situations vary enormously. Recommended, though, for good ideas that stimulate constructive thought and above all, promote empathy and compassion as we guide young people through those challenging years.

In the book (I think it may be his 17th) Derwald Wing Sue analyzes the problems that arise when people try to discuss racial issues. He devotes the first two thirds or so of the book going over the basic fears encountered in these talks; defensive reactions, different communication styles;  tensions between various groups; the lack of awareness that can generate anger and other disruptive defensive reactions; and so much more. He repeats his points many times. He begins each chapter with examples of discussions of race that did not go well, and he analyzes exactly what went wrong, and what was most likely going on inside the participants. These examples and his interpretations are fascinating and sometimes eye opening.Well into the book, Sue calls upon people (particularly white people) to embark upon a deep self-examination of their attitudes toward race, and any background influences from media, other people, etc. that  could have had an effect on them from early childhood. He emphasizes that beyond initial acceptance, guilt and extreme, ongoing self-blame are neither helpful nor constructive in improving empathy and communication.  He presents a 7 stage series of phases people  pass through to free themelves from negative condition, backing this up with 5 useful guidelines for taking action to become a nonracist, and ultimately, an antiracist. All of this is particularly directed toward parents and teachers, though everyone else is urged to take on this process.The final chapter of the book presents an example of a successful workshop discussion in which the teacher very skillfully manages a challenging situation. The book concludes with 5 ineffective strategies for encouraging dialogue, followed by 11 effective strategies.There is much to contemplate  and  work with here. This is not an easy, comfy read, but the steps listed in the last third of the book (which may not make as much sense without the information in the first two thirds) are most valuable. Recommended, with encouragement to keep reading, because readers may find that the last sections of the book bring it all together.

I have several sets of Avery dividers, and I have to say that I like these the best. There are 8 numbered dividers plus 24 lettered (A, B, and C) for subcategories, as well as a table of contents page. Like so many Avery products, they seem quite durable, with extra reinforcement in the vulnerable places. I love the bright colors (even purple!) and even the feel of the paper, which is quite stiff and therefore may outlast flimsier competitors. The letters and numbers are big enough to be read easily, and can be arranged in either landscape or portrait mode.But what I like most about these is the range of possible uses...first, for organizing work presentations, this is great. I could see building a presentation over time with this system, researching and adding categories and subcategories, but there are so many other ways these dividers could be helpful, particularly for any project that one would preplan with an outline. Work projects, home projects, tax stuff, school subjects, crafts, exercise workout sheets...not to mention writing projects (there's a novel here waiting to be written!) I found a video on Youtube entitled "Avery Ready Index Table of Contents" that shows in simple detail how to print on the table of contents page.This is a very useful and attractive and most likely, durable product. Highly recommended, especially to those who like to think in outline form.

This product consists of 4 dividers, one for each quarter, as well as a 5th for annual needs, and a table of contents page. The dividers are made from pretty sturdy paper with reinforced holes and laminated tabs that can be set in either portrait or landscape position. The colors are bright and engaging. Avery provides a brief Youtube video entitled "Avery Ready Index Table of Contents" that shows in detail how to print on the table of contents page. This set of dividers could be handy for business needs or tax records, home repair receipts, etc. Avery's products are consistently good and reliable.

In this book, author Nancy Abrams tells of her spiritual search as she faced the challenges of an eating disorder. Ultimately, her work on the 12 steps of anonymous programs inspired her to find a concept of a higher power that has been both inspirational and effective in her life. Her book is her presentation of her spiritual ideas to the world at large.In the chapters entitled "A God that Can't be Real" and"A God that Could be Real" Abrams tells us exactly who or what God as she understand it is and is not. (She uses the neutral pronoun unless she is discussing more traditional views of God, in which case she uses "He, Him," etc.) Her conception of this higher power is somehow reflected in the sum total of human aspirations, past, present, and future, from the events leading to the Big Bang into the most distant future. She emphasizes oneness with all of humanity, past and future as well as present. In all of this, she cultivates an attitude of fellowship with and appreciation for humanity as a whole, stressing responsibility and accountability in protecting and even saving our planet.  She provides some historical background and scientific information about the cosmos centering around the concept of emergence. She concludes with some very beautiful writing about these subjects, particularly relating to environmental issues, and culminating with 10 promises to focus on for a brighter future (somewhat akin to the promises widely circulated in 12 step programs).There are some beautiful things here, and the ultimate purpose of humanity saving itself from the catastrophies of climate change is a noble and crucial one. However, to get to the sense of a higher power that she is promoting, one has to pass through some pretty stringent and even hard-line reasoning processes, perhaps geared more to the philosopher of science (her description of herself in her bio at her website) than the average person, who may prefer or need to keep things simple. People who fled at an early age from dogmatic belief systems (whether religious or atheistic) may find that there is too much hard mental work involved to embrace Abrams's system of thought and belief. Still, in the spirit of Archbishop Tutu's beautiful introduction, reading this book does help one to enrich one's understanding of these vast and fathomless areas of thought.

In this book, Robert Wachter provides a comprehensive exploration of the challenges and complications of computerization across the gamut of medical care.He gives us a thorough history of the medical record (actually, the state and interpretation of the medical record (an ongoing topic throughout the narrative) and how it evolved as the medical field changed. He lets us in on medical billing practices used by insurance companies in paying doctors (an eyeopener!) he tells us what computers can and cannot do; he muses about ways that use of technology changes our behavior; he tells us about various systems (examples: Epic and Athena) in use and their costs and benefits,; he talks about the "productivity paradox" and blind trust of wrong information when it is displayed on a sophisticated and expensive machine;  and he laments the fact that medical professionals are more rushed than ever (partly because of the effects of technology) and often have their attention more on the computer screen than on their patients. In the most gripping part of the book, spanning several chapters, he recounts in detail the events leading up to a hideous medical error.In preparing to write this book, Wachter interviewed 100 highly qualified experts (their credentials are listed in a table at the end of the book) and he often quotes them  He writes about issues concerning interoperability, useability, learnability (didn't know that was a word!) privacy, and the general clumsiness of systems that don't quite fit the job they are supposed to perform. He often draws comparisons between the challenges for medical care and those for aviation, which have striking parallels.Again and again, Wachter concludes that the best solutions involve humans and computers working together, and perhaps the biggest challenge is for the human side to adapt to the needs of technology. He cites examples of government sponsored programs that have basically failed because the human beings involved were not prepared to to use them effectively.Despite or perhaps in addition to all of this, Wachter assures us he is not a Luddite, and is not pushing for a return to paper and such. He provides his own ideal vision ("Nirvana," he calls it) for the future, in which technology would be used more efficiently and effectively. All of this makes for a fascinating and thought provoking read, with a few shocks and bumps along the way.  Highly recommended to anyone curious about this crucially important  subject.

I am thrilled with these dividers. They are well made, easy to see and read, quite sturdy (good paper, laminated tabs and reinforced holes) and nice and bright. They are perfect for organizing for home, school, work, crafts, etc...for people using Flylady's system, these dividers could be used for daily routines, and the numbered dividers that Avery also sells could be used for zones, detailed cleaning lists, etc. The dividers are also really good for work projects that vary from day to day, and for papers being held for the next week, as if in a tickler file. I was surprised to find that the days of the week are printed as if in portrait mode on one side and landscape on the other. I reallly enjoy the bright colors. All good!I was also pleased to discover a brief Youtube video (search under "Avery Ready Index Table of Contents") that shows how to print on the enclosed table of contents sheet. Another excellent Avery product!

I am very happy with these dividers.  There are 5 numbered main dividers, with 3 sub-dividers labelled A, B, and C,  for each one, and a nice table of contents sheet to tie it all together.  The dividers seem sturdy enough, with nicely reinforced holes and fairly heavy paper. I love the bright colors. The sub-dividers (3, labeled A, B, and C for each numbered tab) will be extremely handy - for work presentations and other ongoing projects, for stray papers waiting to be filed, for  household routines, for keeping craft instructions organized, and for keeping any runaway papers in order...so nice for those of us who like to think in outline form (and to color code). It is great that free templates and software are provided for printing.My set came with a very solid Avery one inch D ring binder...not sure if that is always included, but those are some of the best binders out there. Avery makes good products. HIghly recommended.

This is a nice looking stapler, and takes up less desk space than other staplers I have used. It seems to be sturdily made, and I love the color (easier to spot on the desktop). I really like the fact that the staples lie flat for a neater looking pile of stapled work with no sharp little ends sticking out.  The top opens easily for loading and the stapler fits in the hand comfortably. I was able to staple through 25 pages, though the staples that came with it were a bit short for that, and i had to use a bit more muscle to do to.The little compartment for a name label is a nice feature. I like that the stapler can be used on the desktop or held in the hand. The staples that come with the unit seem sturdy and are relatively easy to remove if necessary.This is really a nice product and seems reliable. The size, color, ease of use, and especially the nice flat cinch stapling are all good reasons to give this stapler a try.

In this book, Eric Greitens explores topics related to inner toughness, resilience, and solid mental health in general, culled from from letters he wrote to a fellow Navy SEAL who was suffering from PTSD, depression, and alcoholism. Drawing on his own experience as Navy SEAL, humanitarian aide in various parts of the world, amateur boxer, police worker, and head of an organization that supports returning soldiers, Greitens counsels his old friend. He often illustrates his ideas with references to a wide range of philosophers  (some examples: Aristotle, Epictetus, Plutarch, Shakespeare, Hemingway, Emerson, DaVinci, etc. etc.)  At times he juxtaposes allusions to Shakespeare and boxing in adjacent sentences, and he seems equally comfortable writing about all of these very different subjects.The book is quite long, and there is a fair amount of repetition. Some of the advice given may have been more interesting and new to Sheets, the recipient of the letters, than to a general audience. Readers who have read self-help books may find some of the ideas here to be quite familar. However, I most appreciated reading about Greitens's experiences as a Navy SEAL; particularly, the phenomenally difficult training that they endure and especially, the attitudes that help them keep going. His writings about teamwork and leadership really seem to reflect his life experience. There is some good food for thought in this book, and the quotes from the various great thinkers are inspiring. I also very much enjoyed Greitens's earlier book, "The Warrior's Heart," (an adaptation of his book, "The Heart and the Fist" for young people) in which he describes is Navy Seal training in great detail and ends with a very strong message of hope, compassion, and true inner strength.Here is a quote that spoke to me:"We are all led better by men and women who have been hard working, resilient failures in early life than by those who, by dint of privilege, luck, or circumstance, rise through life without ever having put their souls into a task that tries them....Fine in your failures resources for your own leadership. Let them be proof that you've pushed yourself. Let them be a constant reminder of...how hard you must fight when you are down. Let them be a reminder of how and where you've earned your wisdom."A while after finishing this book, I see that there is much to revisit and thank about there. I look forward to thumbing through again and finding little gems of wisdom to ponder.

This bag is not the one that was pictured and described when I ordered it; it is the new wider model with an extra pocket for tablets, magnetic closures for pockets, and other changes. At first I thought I would return the bag, but then I fell in love with it. The new large pocket is useful for all sorts of things. I like the way the pockets stay closed ith magnets The number of pockets of all sizes is terrific; all the stuff I carry with me for work, etc. is nicely sorted and stored, so the main compartment is virtually empty and little things don't swim around at the bottom.. I love the light feeling of this ergonomic bag, and the way it snuggles against the body...also, it's great that it's machine washable...a great bag from a fine company.Al

This is a fascinating book for anyone wanting to learn with greater effectiveness and even joy. The author shares her own life story and offers a lot of encouragement, intriguing ideas, and very practical suggestions. Her writing is light, readable, and compelling...could appeal to students as well as adults at all stages of life.Highly recommended!

This is a terrific book with a Feldenkrais approach to bodywork. I found the writing fascinating and the exercises incredibly helpful. I really like the neck and upper body exercises, and especially the walking exercises, which may be  great for people with foot or knee issues and are a great complement to standing yoga postures or serious tai chi practice.Most highly recommended. Feldenkrais is great stuff and this book is one of the best I have seen.

These are really good pencils. They write easily with bold  strokes, a rich texture, and vibrant color. They last a long time and the price seems reasonable.The only thing against these pencils is that if used intensely there is a noticeable chalky smell that an asthmatic friend has found irritating.Otherwise, these are really a good product and a good buy.

This is a very lovely though wrenchingly sad story, beautifully and soulfully written, about a young boy facing occurring cancer. I really enjoyed reading about his fierce determination to do what mattered to him the most, and the various people he encountered along the way. Most of all, I appreciated the evolution in his thinking about the world and his place in it, and his growing ability to recognize, appreciate and even revel in the beauty of love and kindness offered to him. I read the book in one sitting and continue to reflect on its powerful, poignant messages...so many good, positive, constructive messages for young people. I also enjoyed the author's inventive use of language and ability to express very complex feelings in simple and direct language. Highly recommended.

This book is based on the ideas taught by Judith Humphrey's well established coaching, organization, the Humphrey Group,which teaches  women to be taken seriously in order to rise in the male dominated business world. The book's early chapters mostly have to do with communication for good self-promotion. None of this seemed particularly new, and I could see where if someone misinterpreted some of the ideas presented, the effect on those above them might not be as desired.However, the suggestions in later chapters seemed more substantial; for example, the model script for structuring meetings (formal meetings as well as casual encounters in the elevator, etc.)  Subsequent chapters deal with more specific uses for the script, and ways to project one's voice most effectively in a business setting.  It was interesting to read about ways that women unwittingly diminish themselves with vocal mannerisms like speaking in a childlike high pitched voice or monotone,  turning the voice upward at the ends of sentences, speaking too fast with too little articulation of consonants, etc.Part Four, "Stand Out on Stage," has some very good ideas for anyone who needs to speak in public. Humphrey discusses presence onstage as opposed to charisma, and goes into fascinating detail about the ways body language can help or hinder a presentation. The final chapter of that section discusses six rules for dressing for leadership.Each chapter ends with some advice for those who are leaders of women. The end notes cite some intriguing references, and I found it interesting to read about the different ways that men and women approach leadership. All in all, I found the the opening chapters a bit superficial, but there were more powerful ideas - granted, most useful for someone beginning a career - as the book progressed. Recommended to women looking to boost confidence, project competence, and understand a bit more about gender differences.

FIrst of all, unlike some other reviewers, I did receive the white rack that is pictured here.  I am very pleased with it. I have an old accordian style metal rack by Household Essentials, and I prefer the Amazon Basics one for several reasons. It is quite a bit taller than the other rack and therefore makes better use of limited space. I like that there is more space between the bars, so clothes are spread out a bit for quicker drying. I am using the rack in places where it is not likely to be bumped by pets or humans, though it is really pretty steady...wobbles a little when pushed on but doesn't threaten to collapse.  I think this is because the top bars hook much more firmly together than those of my other drying racks I have used, because the upper joining bars really hook all the way around the other ones.  The rack folds up easily for storage and is nice and light and easy to carry around.  It has a nice fresh look, and the plastic tips at the bottom of its "feet" won't harm the surface it stands on. Seems like an ideal rack for drying clothes in a bathtub.Later - upgrading this to 5 stars. It is steady, fits into a relatively small space, and accommodates lots of clothes. All good!The price seems very reasonable. A good product.

I am very pleased with this product. Though the material is a little seems slightly less sturdy than the original Oreck bags, the bag was easy to attach and remove, and I had no problems using it on very dirty floors in a well travelled area. Like the Oreck product, the bags are treated with some special antimicrobial substance. I can't say whether that makes a difference, but there have been no detectable odors with either. The price is definitely a selling point, and these less expansive bags seem to work as well as Oreck's. Nice that they fit such a wide range of Oreck vacuums.Highly Recommended.

This excellent book explores and probes just about every aspect and stage of decision making, taking account the shifting conditions in today's work environment.Some the many topics covered include setting a purpose and desired outcome, gathering and analyzing information, dealing with risk,  what to do when nothing goes right; learning and growing from mistakes; the nature of conflict and authority, getting everyone to contribute, avoiding micromanaging, specific kinds of decisions, and very specific and useful ideas for planning effective meetings (much needed!).What surprised me about this book is that it also covers softer topics like increasing trust and feelings of security among workers, building character and resilience, lots of ideas about trusting one's intuition, staying centered and calm when there is conflict,  getting to know one's "dark and shiny sides" and so on.  Many of these themes come up repeatedly throughout  the book, adding a warm and human aspect to this business oriented subject.Other useful features include an empathy map and "five things skilled decision makers do." The book ends with three sets of the usual Dummies series's Ten's: "Ten Tips for Decision-Making in Uncertain Situations," "Ten Ways to Improve Decision Making,"and "Ten Secrets behind Ethical Decision Making." A cheatsheet at the Dummies website offers more ideas for communication, faster decision making, and sticking with one's core values.There is so much good, practical material here that it could almost be overwhelming; however, a good, detailed table of contents and index can guide one through. Highly recommended, whether read straight through or used as a reference.

This book tells the story of the life of Asad Abdullahi.  Jonny Steinberg made a through study of Abdullalahi's life through extensive  interviews and visits to the places where Abdullahi had lived and worked.  Steinberg's car was Abdullahi's preferred setting for most of the interviews; in the car, he could keep an eye on any threatening situations brewing around him.Abdullahi's life has been a heartrending series of traumatic events, from the loss of seemingly everyone who cared about him (starting with his mother's murder when he was about seven or eight years old) to being utterly abandoned and left to fend for himself by other caregivers. Like so many others in similar situations, he spent much of his life on the move, seeking a safe place to support himself with honest work. We learn much about clan divisions and disagreements going back many generations, the interaction of people within the clans and the rivalries and tensions between clans. Other complications include lack of identity papers, (meaning lack of access to education or safe passage across borders) all too frequent robberies and murders, disinterested law enforcement personnel, betrayal by neighbors...also, the difficulties of sustaining a marriage in these conditions, race relations in various parts of Africa, apartheid and more recent tensions in South Africa, and so much more.Throughout, Abdullahi always comes up with a way to support himself and sometimes, others (as many as five at a time) in even worse situations than his.There is so much to ponder here about life, inequality, human nature (both sides), resilience, the things we sometimes take for granted, and what economic insecurity and old customs can do to one's judgment and ability to think rationally. The writing gets a little dry here and there, but the messages are so poignant and so important that it doesn't matter. The last series of chapters, "Capetown," was so moving and riveting that I couldn't put the book down.  Steinberg ends with a chapter suggesting further reading materials.Most highly recommended.

Hard to find the actual pages you are filling out. Turns out instead of a link to look at "my forms" you have to go to "reports" to view the forms. Some things have a form limit set by the IRS - like how many pages of items you can donate to a charity, so the choice becomes tricky but not insurmountable. Do you categorize all the ski equipment you don't use as "ski stuff" or put in a separate donation sheet for each pair of professional racing skis? Turbo Tax does that part better, at least. I actually completed my taxes this year on both TT and H&RB. Got a much lower tax due bill on H&RB.Another problem is that if you are halfway through a section of the interview, and you hit the back button, you don't just go to the previous item in the interview but back to the opening page of the interview. If you are trying out the options, say, of making a certain size deposit to your IRA and want to see how it changes the tax you owe, you have to leaf through several time-wasting pages to change the amount. It would be so much simpler if "back" simply meant back one item, not back to the beginning.Compared to TurboTax, I'd still use this one, but it has a glitch-y feeling to the way it works, and you have to be ready to really hunt for things.

Full of smutty innuendo, vulgar language, and depictions of deviant sex practices. We kept hoping there would be some redeeming value, but after 25 minutes we couldn't take any more. Robin Williams plays a dad who has lost any joy in life, is on the verge of being fired from his thankless teaching job at a high school in which he sits, bored out of his mind, in front of a few poetry students, wishing things were different, and he has a son who is a slime bag pervert who calls everyone the British slang term for a cigarette, which Amazon will not let me use here even thought the film is peppered with it. I have no idea what would make a young person become this kind of twisted filth by the time he is in high school, but I felt as if I needed to wash my mind out after just a few minutes. The whole thing seemed intended to convince a viewer that this vile behavior was normal. I don't know how it ended, but by the time we turned it off, the only redeeming thing the "World's Greatest Dad" could have done would have been to bury the world's nastiest son in a landfill. Absolutely gross.

It looks sleek and modern. The opener works when you push against the top of the handle; there is no thumb lever to press. On the inside a matching softly burnished nickel finish knob completes the set. It turns as usual. Opening this lock from the outside with hands full means just leaning against the handle or using a free elbow to enter.The deadbolt mechanism comes with a pick shield, meaning, it foils all attempts to pick into the lock with a steel sheath. Basically once this lock is in place, anyone wanting in will have to break a window because they're not going to bypass this thing.Tools needed for installation into a large solid wood door (remove existing lockset first)two screwdrivers, Phillips and flat heada drill with paddle bit (Forstner) to fit deadboltTwo wood chisels with hammerPlenty of lightInstallation was straightforward except for one thing. The deadbolt mechanism needs an extra half inch on the top side of the hole for the toothed cam to rotate. It took some fine chiseling to get it to work.Installation would actually have been much easier on a NEW DOOR. This will work on a metal door as well as wood. It will also work on a hollow core door.Cons: Not easy to install. If you've never done a doorknob set before, I suggest going to a more traditional lockset.While the outside handle is easy for a person with physical limitations to depress, the inner knob is the traditional type and not a lever, so it is no easier to use than any doorknob.

Everyone who takes and edits digital photographs and video needs this monitor. 27" is a great viewing size on a desk, and makes photo editing more clean and clear than trying to use a larger screen or TV.Sorry, if you're looking for a knowledgeable IT specific and pixel-detailed review, I'll leave that for someone else. However, I know what I see. The clarity and resolution is heavy on detail and more than I expected. Colors are so vibrant and detail so clear that I can see places I've goofed in doing some photo repair with Photoshop. The resolution makes movies and games clearer, just like the Ultra High Resolution TV we just bought. Naturally the computer began downloading a driver for the monitor when I first plugged it in, but YOU REALLY MUST USE THE DVD THAT COMES WITH IT. The results are measurably better and screen adjustments are easy and clear.Pros:Comes with power cord with resistor box, DVD for software, and a VGA cableThe main body of this monitor is only one-half an inch thick.The picture is brilliant, and with use of the included software has wonderful adjustments for viewing text, movies, games, photo enhancing, and more. Cons:The stand has only three positions.Does not come with an HDMI cable, but then, most of us have some hanging around now.The specific gravity of the monitor is immense. In other words, this puppy's heavy.

Wonderful all around saw. This one will replace a 12" Hitachi compound miter (non-sliding) saw that has been put through its paces. After just a week of use, I can say this easily draws a precise cut through a 2x10 at any number of angles. The draw is clean, the fences are high, and the LED light truly accurate. I have read other reviews which criticize this product for having bearings on one side only. Whether that is a previous model or this has had some tweaking in the design, I can't tell you because we never owned the previous model. However, this saw had absolutely no problem with bearings. I will say the kerf on the enclosed blade is a bit wide but it has good bite and cuts clean without burning. I'll put a better blade in for real furniture work. This one is a keeper. Light enough to be portable, too. Fits on a stand with good balance. The dust collector is a bit of nonsense, but our shop has a vac system so that's no problem. It hooks up with a standard pvc size pipe. REALLY love this machine.

Kills most -post emergent broadleaf weeds. Seems to control pre-emergent weed seeds for about 2 weeks. Do not use within two feet of any living plant. Weed B Gon will also get rid of grass in a sidewalk. However, in an area with sprinklers and grass in the sidewalks, the constant watering seems to wash away the affects. It is necessary to spray more than one time and keep treating due to sprinklers. The reason I didn't give it five stars is that it takes more than one use for stubborn, deep rooted weeds. Didn't do anything to desert broom, an invasive non-native plant that is havoc in So. Arizona.

When it first arrived, the zipper closure for the lid was partly ripped away in one corner. Although I can probably fix that, it seems some quality control should have been exercised. It doesn't fit any of my casserole dishes because Pyrex has decided to put huge glass handles on them, but does fit well with a 13x9 cake pan. The wide handles make it seem stable. Seems like a good picnic item to have except for the rip.

Well, this is tricky to review, because this was an Amazon Vine gift and there was no alternative to choose a size that might fit anyone in this household. Truly THESE BOOTS ARE WONDERFUL. Weatherproof, built like an army tank, warm, waterproof, and good traction for slippery surfaces. My husband is heartsick that the Vine folks sent a Men's 9 WIDE boot when he wears an 11. They are so sturdy and well made, I promised him we'd buy him a pair that do fit. Please understand with the ratings that popped up here to review the product, when I clicked how long they can be worn comfortably it reflects on the fact that they are two sizes too small, not that they are not comfortable. I tried them on myself hoping they might work, but alas, a men's 9 is not a women's 8 size.We ordered a size 11 and they were too small. Exchanged for a 12 and they are slightly too big, but will be okay with two pairs of socks.

Contrary to what I imagined from the title "Bursting Blueberry" treats do not contain any liquid that bursts out. They are the same chewy Greenies treats as always, but much softer. Greenies has made their reputation on being a healthy alternative dog chew treat which is supposed to clean teeth and freshen breath. I don't think the texture of these contributes to anything but the dogs' enjoyment, because they are not in the least crunchy. However, that said, they are easy to break in half for smaller dogs. The smell of them is like blueberry pie and this is no lie... my dogs went nuts when I opened the box and they just saw /smelled the package. So these are very nicely received, but keep them on a high shelf!

Wonderful, soft scent and smooth texture. This lotion seems to keep arms and legs moisturized for a whole day. It goes on non-greasy and is absorbed quickly. I usually stay away from scented lotions because of our allergies, but this one doesn't bother anyone and the fragrance is very gentle. It sort of goes with you, as if you'd put on a nice light perfume, and I enjoy the fragrance a great deal.

Didn't think I'd like these so well. When you open the box, the perfume is overpowering, however that soon dissipates. The result of using these bags however, is that they neutralize odors in the trash itself. Garlic, peelings, onions, etc, are much less offensive so that you can wait until the bag is full before taking it out the door to the big bin. For us, this saves money because with the unscented bags, we sometimes took out half a bag just to get smelly garbage out of the kitchen. Now we keep the bag until it is full.

Lovely color makes it easy to find in a busy drawer. Works like a champ with very sharp blade. The large handle is easier to turn and doesn't make your fingers feel as if the thumb is doing all the work. Yes, I'd definitely buy another.

Mead has always been my first choice for office products. These folders are cut with tabs in three positions, so that if you spend a moment thinking about it, you can arrange your files in an order that the titles all fall in readable order. Or, you can have all of one subject fall to the right, all of another to the left, etc. Very firm and well creased.A second use for these is the stiff paper makes good craft material, quilt patterns, and bookmarks, when cut into desired shapes.

Barilla as always, makes the best pasta. The Fettuccini, ready to serve in less than 10 minutes, is no exception. I particularly like this product for its tendency to hold the flavor of sauces and whatever it is served with, whether it is a complex concoction or simply olive oil with garlic. Makes an easy meal that's always good.
Great for a last minute fix. The double sided finish now allows for better looking cards whether you print on both sides or not. The paper is heavy and breaks apart cleanly without perforations.

It's nice, small, but has some drawbacks.Pros: Very soft whisper-hum on low, up to a more audible buzzing on high.  Adjustable speed wheel allows for any amount of airflow  Smaller than an average toaster, and fairly invisible because of solid black case.  Well balanced, hard to tip.  The three stage filter looks like it will stop a great deal of pollen and other air pollutants.Cons: Although the sound is soft, the motor makes a surging whirr sound no matter how high or low it is turned. Don't know whether this is a sign of an out of balance motor that will soon burn itself up, or the sound of power pulsing through the wires. Either way, that doesn't give me hope for its longevity. Will edit this post in a few months or whenever it croaks and let you know.  It moves a very small amount of air, which must be pulled in from the half inch gap the legs make between the machine and the surface on which it is placed.  The "clean" air comes out the back in a slot the size of an average lipstick tube, and again, not much of it.  The clean air vent is on the same side as the plug, so if you actually want the clean air to aim into the room instead of against the wall, you have to turn it around so the more attractive side is facing the wall. It is a small inconvenience but it just seems more natural to me to have the vent facing the room.Ultimately I cannot tell if it is freshening the air or not. The volume of air moving through it even on high is very small, and for people with allergies, not sure if this is adequate. Perhaps if you left it running all the time, it would eventually make a difference.
Beautiful and heavy. The people for whom this was a gift were thrilled.
Nice set. Came quickly. Didn't work.

It seems as if they made one very nice one for the photo, and then slapped a few hundred more together with no concern whatsoever for quality or looks. I wear plenty of silver jewelry in Hopi and Navajo style, and I'm familiar with silver work.It is obvious from the photo that this bracelet is very simply made, just a twist of wire, but with a high polish it has some appeal. The silver wire sides of it are very stiff, and the bracelet is very large, making it suitable for an adult, not a child. I like the design. The biggest flaw is what is supposed to appear to be a beaded knot decorating the top. It is soldered on so poorly, and mashed flat in the process, that it nearly obliterates the beading design. A chunk of white solder shows in one corner of the knot design.

Comes with two year warranty. The range finder worked great for two years and five days. Now it will give random readings for the same object - a large cactus which was not moving - from 6 yards to 54 yards. No chance of fixing anything. Crummy.

The purple band on the package is the color of the ink. Tested. Two days and still waiting for this to disappear - it says it vanishes with exposure to either air or water. Good thing I tried it in a small place on the seam allowance. I was terrified I'd ruined weeks of work on a quilt. The ink never faded away on the pale fabrics with exposure to air and light, but I am happy to report that it utterly disappeared with washing. I feel bad if you read my negative review and didn't buy it now. I plan to get more of these. I have tried other disappearing marking pens but this one goes away the most clean. Really love it.

Loving this stuff. I'd never used it before I saw it demonstrated on a youtube quilting video. Combined with ThermOWeb Spray N Bond Quilt Basting Adhesive Spray, and I may never be stabbed with pins again!

Works better than I expected. Holds tight, and doesn't smell too bad. (It does have a smell, however that reminds me of Desenex Foot Powder.)  There is a slight learning curve to using the spray. Mainly, don't use too much in a small area, hold the spray can at least a foot above the fabric to be sprayed and place the next piece on as soon as possible. It remains tacky for several minutes. Also, you can lift off and replace pieces but you have to be very careful not to stretch the diagonal grain because they can stick VERY tightly. I had one piece get crumpled and wrinkled and found the best thing to do is DON'T TRY TO STRAIGHTEN it without completely lifting it up. You can't pull it back straight, you must take the glued piece off and then re-set it.I have paid more than this for other quilting sprays and only got one side glued to the batting, and half the front. This little can has allowed me to applique the entire front, stick the backing to the batting, stick the front to the batting, stick the quilting paper to the front, and it is still at least half full.The only reason I gave it four instead of five stars is that contrary to the package claims it does indeed create little gummy balls on the needle after time. They clean off easy enough, but they are there.

This is no lightweight, flimsy vac. In fact the shipping weight is 18-1/2 pounds, and it feels every ounce of it, even more when it's running because of the amazing suction that seems to want to glue it to the floor. Selling as I write this for $99 from Amazon, this little machine is easily worth more. I had serious misgivings about trying another bagless cleaner, but this one is fantastic for the job it does.What is great about it:1.The cleaning power. Let's just say it picked up an immense amount of dirt and dog hair in one pass through a bedroom. I mean, a shameful amount! You'd think I hadn't just vacuumed 5 days ago. The bin was full to capacity with debris and an appalling amount of plain old garden-style dirt.2. The beater bar (rotating brush head) is adjustable to five heights AND will turn off on bare floors.3. All controls are handy --well, footy-- push buttons to step on. They are very large and well marked.4. The button to push the cord winder is easy to find and use, and rewinds perfectly every time. I had previously written "The cord is fairly short." However, I have found that mine had a bit of a snag inside the cord winder. After looking closely, I pushed aside a twist of cord and now the whole thing comes out. The cord length is fine.5. The suction on bare floors was so good that dust and dog hair actually migrated toward it, even before zooming over it.What could still be better:1. Well, once used unless you clean the dirt bin with soapy water, it still smells like a bagless vac. Ick.2. The thing is heavy. For me personally I would not be able to use this on stairs.3. Along with heavy, there is no propelling assist like I have on another vac. I really like that feature.4. The furniture tool is typical of every recent vac I've seen, and none of them work very well. The tool has a little rotating head inside a paw-shaped plastic case. It attaches to the hose by way of the massive suction of the hose, the wind of which is the only mechanism to rotate the brush head. Soon as you touch the sofa with it, it stops turning. Or, you can lightly waft it over the fabric, which picks up only the biggest and lightest crumbs. A piece of a Cheeto, no problem. A bit of gravel, nope. Dog hair, nope. And before you wonder why I have gravel on my sofa, I don't, I tried it on the dog's bed.Ultimate reaction is 98% positive. Would I pay this much for this vac, absolutely. If this were the only one I had, or if I was ready to replace an old one (I have a $400 top brand machine) I would DEFINITELY BUY THIS. Now, if it should croak in a couple of months, I'll report it here. But after having it just a couple of days, I am totally sold on the Eureka. The weight of this machine makes it not so suitable for an RV or small apartment. It's also pretty large to store, the power-head of the thing being as large as a boot box. The way it functions, and the large step-on buttons are fantastic. If you have a two story house, I'd put one on each floor; that's still cheaper than my fancy machine, and cleans better.
