The songs can be divided thematically into three sections (or generations, if you will):Her grandmother's generation, the Carter Family, is covered in the following songs: the bluesy, stomping "Little Black Train," the hauntingly beautiful "Give Me The Roses," the more traditional "Gold Watch And Chain" and ballad "I'll Be All Smiles Tonight." There's also the fun "Blackjack David," a duet with country-legend Kris Kristofferson and the feisty "Blackie's Gunman," a duet with Elizabeth Cook, who is a honorary Carter girl and ended up singing on six of the tracks.Her mother's generation is explored in the ensuing songs: the Carter Sisters track "Poor Old Heartsick Me," which was one of her Aunt Helen's ditties, and mother June Carter Cash's murder-suicide ballad "Tall Lover Man," a very catchy foot-tapper, while the organ-tinged pulling-on-your heartstrings "Troublesome Waters" is a stepfather Johnny Cash piece done as a duet with Willie Nelson.Her own generation is included on this album by one original and one semi-original track: the evocative "Me And The Wildwood Rose" was first recorded in 1990 for Carlene's album "I Fell In Love," but appears here re-recorded in a more sedate acoustic version, and recalls the life of the Carter family at home when Maybelle was still alive. And there's another old Carter Family piece, but with added personal verses: "Lonesome Valley 2003," on which Vince Gill can be heard harmonizing, and in which she sings about the deaths of stepfather Johnny "The Man In Black" Cash and mother June Carter Cash.All family connections come together in the boisterous album closer "I Ain't Gonna Work Tomorrow," another Carter Family classic, but amazingly, done with backing-vocals by Anita Carter, Helen Carter, June Carter Cash and Johnny Cash. For this, Carlene used the masters of recordings they made together around '86 and '87, so that's why there are the posthumous voices of John, her mom and Helen and Anita on this track, as is the guitar of the late "Cowboy" Jack Clement.With the very personal "Carter Girl," Carlene Carter has proven how powerful a tribute album can be when done right. "Give me the roses while I live . . . Don't wait till death to speak kind words," Carlene sings on "Give Me The Roses." As a young child, she was charged to always carry on the legacy of the Carter Family music and keep it alive. Well, I know no kinder words or higher praise than to finish by saying that this Carter girl has done full justice to her family's history. Recommended!

"Where It All Began is the debut-album by new country duo Dan + Shay (Dan Smyers and Shay Mooney). All 12 tracks on this album were co-written by Dan and Shay, most of them with songwriting partner Danny Orton, and can be described as country-pop music.Album-opener Show You Off, with Its use of whistling, perfectly sets the overall laid-back tone for this album. The infectious Stop Drop + Roll is made to be blasted from your car-speakers with you singing along. The up-tempo ballad 19 You + Me is perfect to get you in the mood for spring break (or for some summer-frolicking on the beach). What You Do To Me, with its use of piano and a great guitar-solo, is another fun sing-along track.Cant Say No is one of the more straight pop songs on this CD. The musical range on this album is further displayed by the ballad First Time Feeling, a song leaning more towards country with its use of mandolin and piano, and the more pop-rock track Nothin Like You, with its use of electronic drum-loop and guitar. Somewhere Only We Know is a Cole Swindell-ish party tune.The catchy Parking Brake is another of my favorites, as is the beautiful piano ballad I Heard Goodbye, easily Shays best vocal performance on this record. Party Girl is another song leaning more towards straight pop. This is followed by the folk-ish album closer, the catchy, banjo-laced Close Your Eyes.With this album, Dan + Shay have left a fantastic calling card both as songwriters and as vocalists. They have a unique sound and the duos voices seamlessly complement one another. Based on the quality of this debut Im sure that, a few years hence, when Dan + Shay have become mega-selling and award winning country stars, they can look back and say this record is where it all began."

The EP Tippin Point from Canadian rock and country artist Dallas Smith is the follow-up to his previous 2012 studio album Jumped Right In and produced by Joey Moi (Florida Georgia Line, Jake Owen, Nickelback). These 6 tracks are a great blend of country and rock, and should appeal to fans of both genres.This EP starts off with the party anthem Tippin Point, a song perfectly suited for when youre ready for a good time. It has a very catchy chorus and is one of my favorites on this mini-album. Next are the country-rockers Slow Rollin  and This Town Aint A Town. The more ballad-ish rocker Wrong About That, another favorite, is a song about enjoying being wrong when judging other peoples behavior just based on their looks, and is followed by the up-tempo A Girl Like You and another of my personal favorites, Nothin But Summer, an incredibly catchy song that is wholly appropriate for blasting from your speakers when driving to the beach this summer.Tippin Point is a pretty solid EP and a great introduction for folks new to this country-rocker, as well as a place-holder for those who are, like me, eagerly awaiting his next studio album. But that said, its just a notch below his first solo album Jumped Right In in overall quality. So if you haven't yet heard that one, go check it out. That album is truly amazing.

"The Truth" (Deluxe Edition) is the seventh album by R&B power vocalist Ledisi and also a different musical direction for the many times Grammy-nominated singer, as this record is more up-tempo than previous releases. As Ledisi stated in a recent interview: "I made a decision to not do too many ballads so it reflects the more upbeat side of me. I wanted to make songs that were about my truth. This is the most vulnerable I've ever been."On this upbeat R&B album, Ledisi showcases her incredible vocal range as she covers a wide range of topics related to love, also displaying a playful sexuality that never turns vulgar. The album opens with the very catchy "I Blame You" and the disco-esque "Rock With You." Then there is the mid-tempo "That Good Good" and the sultry "Lose Control," in which she sings about taking the lead in the bedroom: "Nice red high heel shoes, Left behind some clues, Follow the roses, Let me reward you."Next are the mid-tempo song "Like This" and the radio-ready tune "Anything." Standout-track "The Truth" showcases her vulnerability, as this is a ballad about the feelings that the songstress went through after her own breakup, and the lively mid-tempo "Missy Doubt." On the mournful "88 Boxes" she sings about packing up pictures and old love letters, or in other words: "My life, it went from years to 88 boxes." Next is my personal favorite of this album, the ballad "Can't Help Who You Love."The Deluxe Edition adds three tracks to this album: the mid-tempo "Mine," the R&B ballad "I Swear," which is my favorite of the extra songs, and the funky "Quick Fix" with sultry lyrics like "Baby, you better fix it, Come on, I'm gonna' quit this, I need a quick fix," rounding out the 13 tracks.Final verdict: with "The Truth" (Deluxe Edition) the New Orleans-born singer delivers a well-rounded R&B album. But that said, after listening to this CD repeatedly for the past several days to let the songs sink in, the truth is that, while these are all good, catchy songs, there are too few really outstanding and/or memorable tracks on this album. So I settled on four stars: I like it, a lot, but I don't love it.

With Soy El Mismo (Im The Same), Prince Royce, the bachata singer from New York, has delivered his third studio album. It follows on his 2012 album Phase II. The Spanish songs on the album were all co-written by Royce, while only one of the three English songs (Already Missing You) was co-written by him. The 11 tracks combine lots of different music styles and genres, from bachata and tropical music to pop and dance beats, with even some rock, reggae and R&B influences, making for a very eclectic Latin music album that should appeal to a wide range of tastes.The album opener Soy El Mismo is a beautiful ballad with Bachata rhythm. Next is Te Robar, also in bachata style, but with a tropical flavor. The upbeat Darte Un Beso is a more traditional bachata song that also shows some reggae influences and is ensued by the mostly acoustic You Are Fire, an English-language power-ballad. Me Encanta is another bachata track with tropical sounds. This is followed by "Tu Principe," a bachata/pop track, that even has some flute and harp (and galloping horses).A great up-tempo dance track is the English-language duet with Selena Gomez, Already Missing You. The beautiful ballad Invisible, about growing up without a father, is one of my favorite tracks on this album. Another great dance track is the English-language pop song Kiss Kiss. Next is the R&B flavored Latin pop-rock ballad Nada. The album closer is Te Regalo El Mar, another bachata song with a blend of different musical styles.There are three extra tracks on the Target/Deluxe Edition of this album, all co-written by Prince Royce: the ballad Primera Vez, the more up-tempo pop-song Solita and You Are The One, a beautiful bilingual ballad with verses both in Spanish and English, supported by some great harmonica playing. Recommended!With Soy El Mismo, Prince Royce has delivered a great album that blends a variety of musical styles as well as English and Spanish elements. Although this record is aimed at the Latin community, with this CD he will also appeal to anyone who likes bachata, R&B or pop music for that matter. In the fall of 2014 an English language pop album, with a flair of Latin/tropical, is expected to be released, and Im eagerly awaiting this next album.

The album "Shakira" by Colombian singer-songwriter Shakira is her tenth studio record and follows on her previous 2010 multi-lingual album "Sale El Sol." Shakira decided to scrap and/or rework some of the tracks she worked on since late 2011, as she wanted to set both musically and lyrically a new direction for this album since she became a mother. The music on the finished product is a mixture of rock, folk, reggae, dance and even some country, to name just a few influences, so this album should appeal to a wide range of musical tastes.She starts off with a bang, as the album opener "Dare (La La La)" is a very catchy dance-floor-ready track. This is followed by the ska-flavored song "Can't Remember To Forget You," which has also some elements of reggae and rock, and is a duet with Rihanna. The epic pop-rock ballad "Empire" is a bit of a return to her original sound at the start of her career. "You Don't Care About Me" is a delicate song with a folksy feel to it, but has also some reggae-influences."Cut Me Deep" is a "duet" with the Canadian group Magic!, and a mixture of reggae, ska and rock in which she sings about the fact that break-ups suck. Next track "Spotlight" is another pop-rock song. It has a great chorus and might have enough potential to be a future single as it's certainly catchy enough. The guitar-driven "Broken Record" is a semi-acoustic ballad which has lovely lyrics."Medicine," the incredible catchy pop-country crossover duet with Blake Shelton, is one of my favorites on this album. This is followed by the ballad "23," beautifully sung by Shakira while delicately accompanied on acoustic guitar. Shakira dedicated this song to her husband and son Milan, making this song one of her most personal ones on this record. At the end, you can hear a snippet of her son's voice. Next track, the mid-tempo "The One Thing," is a mixture of dance, pop and rock."Nunca Me Cuerdo De Olvidarte" is the Spanish version of "Can't Remember To Forget You," and this track, without Rihanna, is even more catchy than the English version. The ballad "Loca Por Ti" ("Crazy For You") is the only cover on this album, a song originally performed by pop rock group SAU from the Catalonia region in Spain. On a side note: Shakira also made a Catalan version of this track, "`Boig Per Tu," which sounds even better.With "Shakira," her first English-language release since 2009, the Colombian songstress has delivered an appealing album that is a real showcase for her vocal prowess. Just a few minor critical notes: the album is a bit too reggae-flavored (not that I dislike reggae as a genre, far from it) and ballad-heavy. Also, there's a tad too much switching between genres, so the album lacks a bit cohesiveness. These nit-pickings aside, it was certainly worth the four-year wait. Recommended to all lovers of great music.

"Gravitas is the fourteenth studio album by Asia, the legendary British melodic progressive rockers. Produced and written by founding band members John Wetton and Geoff Downes, the record also introduces their new guitarist, Sam Coulson, and is the follow-up to their XXX album from 2012.My favorites on this album are the opening track Valkyrie, a real stand-out with its great harmony vocals, the power ballad The Closer I Get To You, which reminded me a bit of a song by Boston I cant recall the name off, and the rockers Heaven Help Me Now and I Would Die For You. Another stand-out is the ballad Joe DiMaggios Glove, which seemed to show some influences from Supertramp.While this is a good, solid Asia album and a welcome addition to my Asia collection, it seemed to lack a certain, well, gravitas. Ive been listening to this album for the past couple of days to let them really sink in, as I didnt want to write a review in the heat of the moment, but the only songs that really stood out to me after repeated listenings were Valkyrie and Joe DiMaggios Glove.So to sum it up, I still enjoyed this album. All the other songs were good but not great. And last but not least, theres the fact that there are only 9 tracks on the regular CD. This is a bit flimsy, so for the above mentioned reasons I have given this album four stars: I like it, but dont love it.

"Out Among The Stars" is a previously unreleased album by country icon Johnny Cash, who died in 2003 at the age of 71. John Carter Cash found his father's lost recordings, that were recorded in the early `80s and originally produced by Billy Sherrill, while combing through the family archives. With none of the twelve songs heard anywhere before (as performed by Johnny Cash), and the sound and production technology brought to modern standards, this album is an absolute must for fans of the legendary "Man In Black."The album-opener "Out Among The Stars" starts out with the signature Johnny Cash train-track rhythm and his deep baritone singing about crime and retribution, and instantly became my favorite on this album. Other highlights are the ballad "She Used To Love Me A Lot," the bluegrass duet with June Carter Cash "Don't You Think It's Come Our Time" and "I Came To Believe," a track with some gospel influences. Other personal favorites are the catchy "I'm Moving On" which is a duet with Waylon Jennings, the darkly humorous "I Drove Her Out Of My Mind" and the even more fun "If I Told You Who It Was."So, some 30 years after these sessions were originally recorded, we get to - posthumously - enjoy a great record and the fact that this was shelved - and forgotten - is surprising as these songs show that Cash was in the prime of his voice and thus the album "Out Among The Stars" is a great final legacy of "The Man In Black."

"Loco De Amor" (meaning: Crazy In Love) is the 7th studio album by Latin pop/rock superstar Juanes from Colombia. It is his first studio album since P.A.R.C.E. (2010) but follows chronically on his Juanes: MTV Unplugged live album from 2012. Loco De Amor is a great blend of Latin rock, dance-pop, tropical, Colombian salsa and cumbia. It was produced by Steve Lilywhite (U2, Rolling Stones) and had as associate producer Emmanuel Meme del Real, who provided the necessary Latin-music counterbalance. The 11 tracks were either written or co-written by Juanes, and the Colombian singer-songwriter sings all songs exclusively in his native language.The album-opener Mil Pedazos is a Latin rocker that hooks you right in with its infectious dance beat. Bouncy Loco De Amor with its catchy chorus is a mix of conga and synthesizers while La Luz is a Latin rocker that melds electronic sounds and funk with Colombian cumbia into a song that is guaranteed to fill the dance floor. In the catchy La Verdad, even some mandolin is added into the mix. The beautiful ballad Una Flor is almost completely acoustic.Delirio is another incredibly catchy pop-song. Mid-tempo rocker Laberinto gives way to the rock & roll of Persiguiendo El Sol. This is followed by the bossa-tinged "Corazn Invisible," that starts out as a ballad but builds into a catchy pop song. Me Enamor De Ti is another power ballad, starting acoustically with some classical instruments added into the mix, but building into a hooky rocker. The album closes with the mid-tempo "Radio Elvis."Loco De Amor is an outstanding album, a great blend of styles that combine into a best of both worlds type record. All 11 tracks are great, theres not a weak song in the bunch, and his acoustic-driven pop-rock and passionate vocals should appeal to both long-time fans of Juanes as well as newcomers to his music, even if you dont know Spanish at all. Recommended!

"Crop Circles is the fourth studio album by Canadian country music artist Dean Brody and contains a dozen outstanding modern country tracks. Except for My Last Broken Heart, all songs are written or co-written by Brody. This album is a real showcase for this brilliant singer/songwriters way of painting such vivid pictures with his lyrics, you wont need Youtube to watch the video (o: These songs with their catchy melodies are further enhanced by his wry sense of humor.Opener Four Wheel Drive is a flippant, fast-paced bro-country anthem about a guy that boasts about how his prowess with beautiful women is due to his vehicle: Youre saying Look at that bucket of rust, Then my baby steps out,  Ill tell ya boys, I got four wheel drive. Next song is Bounty, a catchy song about a couple on the run that mixes southern rock with some awesome banjo and guitar work, and features guest-vocals by Lindi Ortega.The third song is the incredibly groovy and reggae-esque Sand In My Soul, that makes you want to head for the beach to be, Working on my tan with a drink in my hand. With its easy going lyrics Its the perfect hit for next summer. This is followed by Crop Circles, which tells the story of how farmer Johnsons got his shotgun runnin naked through a cornfield as he thinks aliens have landed. But is it little green men or just some kids out to Show the girls a little good time spinnin tires in the soft ground, but secretly as Farmer Johnsons got salt shot to pepper your...Another lyrically strong (and very funny!) track is Mountain Man, a fast-paced foot-tapper that pokes fun at the men who are desperate to seem manly in front of their girlfriends as theyre lost in the wilderness: "Baby, don't panic,, I can bugle an elk, I can rattle a deer, I can grow you a big ol' bushy beard, , Yeah I'm a mountain man. Next song is Another Mans Gold, a nice country ballad that provides a beautiful message through various life examples, as one mans trash is another mans gold.Another cheerful and sway-inducing song is Back To The Front Porch, a beautiful tribute to the small hometown he couldnt wait to escape, but now cant wait to return to. This is followed by the pop/folky love story Marianne with its heartfelt lyrics, when Marianne leaves town to pursue her dreams, while her man chooses to stay at home because he cant bear to leave what he knows. The 9th track on the album is The Little Things About Us,  a ballad with bluegrass-elements.Next is My Last Broken Heart, an upbeat honky-tonk song that laments a broken heart, but not without throwing several digs at the woman that is the cause of this heartbreak. This is followed by the country rock with a strong CCR-vibe of The Old Sand Bar, a laid-back and incredibly catchy song that make you want to head to A little fishin shack down a long grass road.The album closes with Kansas Cried, a beautiful bluegrass/folk-ish song with haunting lyrics which tells a Civil War story about A farm boy and an officer's daughter, In a time when young hearts shouldn't dream, as He thought of her in her white dress, As he bravely marched toward the fight that really tugs at your heartstrings.With Crop Circles, Dean Brody has delivered a fantastic album, with 12 outstanding tracks that arent just songs but finely crafted stories with life and character put to music. Recommended!

"Jumped Right In" is the first solo album by Canadian rock and country artist Dallas Smith, and it is everything a country album should be: filled with strong songs and robust vocals that should appeal to both country and rock fans alike. And if you might think that the name Dallas Smith sounds familiar: he was the lead singer of Canadian rock band Default. Now that the band is taking a break, Dallas put on boots and a cowboy hat and headed to Nashville, and "Jumped Right In" is unqualified proof that he made the right choice.This is turn the volume up, pedal to the floor music from first song until last. The 10-track album is produced by none other than Joey Moi (Jake Owen, Florida Georgia Line, Daughtry, Nickelback). Many of Nashville's well known songwriters like Rodney Clawson and Craig Wiseman, to name a few, along with Chad Kroeger and Dallas Smith himself, wrote the songs for this album. The result: a very strong record full of pop-oriented country-rock.The album opens strongly from the first chord with the up-tempo, guitar rocker "If It Gets You Where You Wanna Go," a fast and fun song perfectly suited as a summer-anthem, with the simple message to follow your heart: "It doesn't matter what it is, If it gets you where you wanna go." This is followed by "Somebody Somewhere," an upbeat tune even though he sings about a man honest enough to admit it was his own fault that his relationship failed.Thereafter comes "What Kinda Love", a cheerful love song, which is ensued by the power ballad "Jumped Right In" with its rousing chorus: "When you're young it's how it goes, Nothing to lose except our clothes, And we didn't know any better back then, We just closed our eyes and we jumped right in." This is followed by the catchy summertime-tune "Nothing But Summer."The next song, "Shotgun," is a riff-packed, witty tune that pokes fun at a girlfriend who asked her boyfriend for some time apart, followed by "Stone Cold Killers,"  where he asks the girl he's offended: "Stone cold killers, untrue lovers and fallen angels, Are walking around in heaven tonight, And if God could find the mercy to forgive them, Why can't you give me one more chance to make things right."Next up is the power ballad "And Then Some," an expressive song about a man willing to do anything for the love of his life. Another powerful ballad is the next-to-last song "Never Saw Goodbye", a poignant love-song in which he sings: "How could I have been so blind? I Never Saw Goodbye" as he's left behind by his lady-love. The album's closer, "The Song That's In My Head," is another high energy belter, which was co-written by Nickelback`s Chad Kroeger. A great rocker to end this album!Next to Smith's voice, which is terrific, the strength of "Jumped Right In" is that all 10 tracks are more than capable of standing on their own as a single. There's not a weak song among these radio-ready, hook-laden tunes. Given the quality of this debut album, I can't wait to find out how Dallas Smith will develop as a singer-songwriter in the future.

"It Goes Like This" is a musically very diverse debut album by country music singer-songwriter Thomas Rhett, the son of songsmith Rhett Akins. Except for "Take You Home," which was written by Ashley Gorley, Thomas and/or his father helped to write all the songs on this album. After having shown his talent as a songwriter by writing for Jason Aldean ("I Ain't Ready To Quit") and Florida Georgia Line ("Round Here"), Thomas is now ready to showcase his own vocal capabilities. And what a debut this is!This 12-song CD is diverse and varied, as R&B, blues, hip-hop, rock, regular country and "bro country" party anthems are mixed into a fantastic southern rock/country album that is made to be blasted from your speakers with you belting along with most of the songs. Half of the album was produced by Jay Joyce while Luke Laird (3 songs) and Michael Knox (also 3 songs) both handled production duties on the others.The album opens with the bluesy rocker "Whatcha Got In That Cup", and it is followed by another great rocker with a catchy tune, the fun "Something To Do With My Hands," a song filled with a sly sense of humor that is also evident in other songs on this album. Next we have the catchy power ballad "Get Me Some Of That," ensued by the soulful "Call Me Up" and the groovy rock-song "It Goes Like This" with its catchy melody and the equally hip "Make Me Wanna."Then there is the funky "Front Porch Junkies (remix)", a cross-breed between hip-hop and country with Thomas country-rapping his way through the lyrics, followed by the live-in-the-moment anthem "In A Minute." One of the slower songs off the album is the ballad "Take You Home." Next is the bluesy drinking song "Sorry For Partying." Now, if you're planning a party, send this one as a pre-emptive warning note to your neighbors! This is followed by the swampy rocker "All-American Middle Class White Boy."The album closer is the acoustic "Beer With Jesus," THE stand-out song on this album, showing his vocal capabilities as a balladeer. It's a thought-provoking song in which he humbly sings about wanting to sit down with Jesus and "Ask him how'd you turn the other cheek, To save a sorry soul like me, Have you been there from the start, How'd you change a sinner's heart." The song is made all the more effective because of it's simple arrangement.All in all, 12 great tracks with not a weak song among them. I've added Thomas to my list of artists to watch out for, as he's going to be a major star and I'm looking forward to see how he will develop as an singer-songwriter in the future. He certainly left his calling-card with this album!

Howling guitars, pounding drums and rocking vocals: hard-rock queen Lita Ford is back on stage with a live recording good enough for a CD release, from a October 4, 2012 concert at The Canyon Club in Agoura Hills (Los Angeles). The title (and first song on the album) comes from her cover of the Elton John classic that also appeared on the limited edition of her last studio album "Living Like A Runaway" and very much applies (in a good way!) to ultimate rock-chick Lita.Lita Ford is hard rock royalty, with a career going back to the sexy all-female rock band The Runaways in the `70s and some major solo-hits in the `80s. She has had quite a tumultuous few years, resurfacing from her long hiatus in the Caicos and Turks Islands near the Bahamas and her marriage crashing a few years ago. Luckily, Ford's voice still sounds great after all these years!This live album has a nice set list, showcasing most of the highlights of her now rich oeuvre. In total, there are twelve tracks on this CD, on which she is accompanied by Mitch Perry on guitar, Bobby Rock on drums and Marty O'Brien on bass. These three men have made their mark by working together with numerous other artists, including Tommy Lee, Methods of Mayhem and Disturbed.Five songs are from the great 2012 come-back album "Living Like A Runaway": the title track of this live-album and "Relentless," the Bryan Adams-esque mini-autobiography "Living Like A Runaway", "Devil In My Head" and "Hate", while four songs are from the 1988 album "Lita": "Back to the Cave," the Lemmy Kilmister co-penned "Can't Catch Me," plus her two mega hits "Kiss Me Deadly" and "Close My Eyes Forever," her duet with Ozzy Osbourne, in this case with his part sung by the audience.The title track of her 1983 solo debut album "Out For Blood" is also included, as is "Hungry" from the 1990 "Stiletto" album. "Dancing On The Edge" is the title-track from her second solo-album from 1984. Significantly, no songs are played from the (flopped) 2009 album "Wicked Wonderland."The live-album closes with her most memorable hit "Kiss Me Deadly," the song that, way back, was my "introduction" to Lita and one that has been seared into my memory. She performed this song live on Dutch television at Countdown (then THE major music program on TV in the Netherlands) and when host Wessel asked her what "Kiss Me Deadly" was all about, she just grabbed him and kissed him deadly... well, he was still alive afterwards, but you know what I mean (o:I only have one quibble with this album: according to the booklet which contains a set list of the songs she played at The Canyon Club, some were omitted from this live album... A very curious choice. Now why weren't these included? Maybe copyright issues, as other reviewers have noted. Anyway, this CD is very definitely one for the record collection!

"The River & The Thread", the first release of new material in nearly a decade by singer-songwriter Rosanne Cash is a wonderful "travelogue" through the South. After having listened to this album, I thought: Wow! Her late father Johnny Cash would have been so proud of her. Of course, I should mention that you need to listen to this album multiple times to be able to truly appreciate it as this is not a musical "quickie", so to speak. Take your time, sit back, close your eyes and really listen so you can immerse yourself in these wonderful songs.This album is not something you can easily put a music-label on as it has elements of country, folk, bluesy soul, jazz and pop/rock. These personal songs are lyrical stories about her travels in the Deep South put to music, using her wonderful voice to paint word-pictures as she examines what it means to be a Southern American. Rosanne Cash wrote the album's 11 original songs with her longtime collaborator and husband John Leventhal, who also served as producer, arranger and guitarist."A Feather's Not A Bird", the opening song of the album, and which reminded me of Creedence Clearwater Revival, is a great example of Rosanne's mixing of styles. "Sunken Lands", named for the area where Johnny Cash grew up, is a nice harmonic ditty, and "Etta's Tune" is an ode to Etta and Marshall Grant, Marshall being a longtime family friend and member of Johnny Cash's band. The catchy "Modern Blue" has a strong Tom Petty/Jeff Lynne-vibe and the hymn-like "Tell Heaven" is a meditation on longing and loneliness.Next is the moody Southern pop song "The Long Way Home", about memories of her father and her time in Tennessee, which is followed by "World Of Strange Design" with its catchy country chorus. "Night School" evokes the mood of a nursery rhyme while the bluesy "50,000 Watts" with its gospel overtones is one of my favorites. Another great song is "When the Master Calls The Roll", a tale of love torn apart during the Civil War with elements from gospel and Irish folk (and based on two of Cash's relatives from the Civil War era).Cash finishes with "Money Road", an evocative song about a road in Mississippi where you find the grave of blues legend Robert Johnson; the grocery store where in 1955 the black youth Emmett Till supposedly flirted with a white woman and was hanged for that offence; and the Tallahatchie Bridge, which features also in "Ode To Billie Joe," Bobbie Gentry's 1967 hit about two lovers who drop something forever mysterious off that bridge.Rosanne Cash is an outstanding singer-songwriter, making every word and every note count, with a crystalline voice that fits perfectly with her style of music. As I said at the start of this review, take your time as you listen to "The River & The Thread", as these songs are threaded together into one cohesive work that should be listened to from front to back in its entirety without interruptions. Recommended!

Ilse DeLange (correctly spelled in Dutch, Ilse De Lange) is a Dutch country and pop singer/songwriter. Her new, seventh album "Eye Of The Hurricane" is in many ways a break with predecessor "Next To Me", her 2010 album which was a return to the pure country sound from the beginning of her career. The 12 tracks on this new album are more pop oriented, with country as just one of the many influences, alternating up-tempo songs with more understated, very personal ballads that reflect her feelings of the past year.Three songs on the album are about her father, who died in January, 2012: the country ballad "Time Will Have To Wait", "We Are One" and "I Need For You". These moments of reflection are balanced by the more upbeat songs, making for a very eclectic album. For example, the song "Dance On The Heartbreak" is reminiscent of Maroon 5, while "Magic" seems to be influenced by Muse and "Just Kids" could have been a track written for Nelly Fortado.Ilse has a beautiful voice and has packed this CD with some amazing songs, a lot of them single-material with the potential to become major (international) hits, like the songs "Space Cowboy" and "We Are Diamonds". Some of my other favorites on this album are the tracks "Hurricane" and "Winter Of Love" (which have also been hit-singles in the Netherlands).

Although now all but forgotten, in his days writing for the pulps Frederick Nebel (1903-1967) was as popular and well respected as Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler. Nebel created private-eye Cardigan for the pulp magazine Dime Detective, which was second only to the famous Black Mask Magazine in the cultivation of the hard-boiled detective genre and Jack Cardigan, the two-fisted op from Cosmos Detective Agency, was one of the main reasons behind its success.Volume 1 of The Complete Casebook of Cardigan features an introduction by Will Murray and 11 stories from the period 1931-1932 with the original illustrations by John Fleming Gould. The stories are: Death Alley (November, 1931), Hell's Pay Check (December, 1931), Six Diamonds and a Dick (January, 1932), And There Was Murder (February, 1932), Phantom Fingers (March, 1932), Murder on the Loose (April, 1932), Rogues' Ransom (August, 1932), Lead Pearls (September, 1932), The Dead Don't Die (October, 1932), The Candy Killer (November, 1932), and A Truck-Load of Diamonds (December, 1932).Cardigan is a private eye stamped from the same mold as Sam Spade and Philip Marlowe, those icons of hard-boiled fiction created by Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler: a laconic, wise-cracking gumshoe with a fondness for booze and dames in trouble, as quick with his fists as his gun, and a tendency to stumble over corpses and have a run-in with the law.As Ive read these volumes a bit in reverse order (volumes 2, 3 and 4 are available in e-book version, while no. 1 is not, so this one is actually the last one I bought and read) its fun to see how Nebel developed Cardigan in the course of the series. Ive described his later stories as small gems of hard-boiled fiction; the first couple of stories in this collection are also diamonds, but still a bit in the rough, as Nebel was obviously still working on finding his Cardigan-voice.It didnt take Nebel long to hit on the Cardigan trade-marks that lasted throughout the series. At first Cardigan is just described as big and shaggy-headed. In the second story, his faded fedora pops up, which gets more battered throughout the series, while in Six Diamonds And A Dick we get introduced to Patricia Seaward, from then on a recurring character in the series.Although the first stories take place in St. Louise, with Cardigan being the head of the Cosmos Agency branch in that city, from Murder On The Loose on, he is in New York, working for agency-head Hammerhorn, having had to move because he antagonized the wrong people and they broke his license in the State of Missouri.No matter where these stories take place, these two-fisted tales are exemplars of how noir fiction should be written, filled to the brim with slam-bang action, keen characterization and crackling dialogue. Recommended for all lovers of hardboiled and pulp fiction!If you haven't read them yet and this collection has whetted your appetite for more of Nebels work: next to the three other volumes in the "Complete Casebook of Cardigan" series, there is the one-volume "Tough as Nails: The Complete Cases of Donahue", which collects the fifteen hard-boiled P.I. stories about gumshoe Donahue, a character similar to Cardigan, which Nebel wrote for Black Mask Magazine, and of course the four volumes in the The Complete Cases of MacBride & Kennedy series (of which the first two volumes are available at the time when this review was written) and which collect the 39 stories Nebel wrote featuring police Captain Steve MacBride and reporter Kennedy of the Free Press, also for Black Mask Magazine.

I got this album as a Christmas-present from American friends, who know I love the Asterix series. As a lifelong Asterix fan, I was wondering how the English version would hold up, compared to the Dutch translations I'm used to.The good news is, this one is a step up from the previous two albums. But then again, nothing could be worse than the atrocious "Asterix And The Falling Sky" (I mean, come on, Asterix and aliens??). So I was wondering what would happen now that Jean-Yves Ferri and Didier Conrad have taken over and if they would be able to breathe life back in to the series.The art by Didier Conrad: while not on a par with Uderzo, it is a reasonably close approximation. At least the characters were perfectly realized and true to Uderzo's original style. Some panels had me thinking: this is probably how Uderzo would have done the layout. But as Uderzo was involved in the production, I don't know whose idea this was. Though there is room for growth, this is a reasonable good first attempt so I give the art four stars.The scenario by Jean-Yves Ferri: the first couple of pages aren't too bad and a nice set-up for the story to follow. But then, it starts heading downhill. The overall story-line was muddled and didn't really get off the ground. The census taker seemed redundant to me (lost comic opportunity here) while lots of opportunities to poke fun at the Scots were passed over while some of the jokes that were made, fell flat. So, overall, I give the scenario two stars.The translation by Anthea Bell: in the Dutch edition of this album, the translation seemed rather bland. My French isn't good enough to read Asterix in the original language, so I was wondering if the English version would be any better. But there are only slight differences between the Dutch and English versions of this album. For example, in the Dutch translation the druid Getavix is called Panoramix and Cacofonix is called Assurancetourix (I must say, I like the English name better). MacAroon is called MacAdam and his enemy MacCabaeus is called MacAber in Dutch.Textually, what's missing in both Dutch and English versions is the sly wit and double (often triple) meanings that Goscinny would layer through the text, so I assume this is a failing not in the translation but in the French source as well. As mentioned above, the humor is very hit and miss (mostly misses), generally lacking the subtlety and warmth I'm used to from the Goscinny/Uderzo-combo. So I would say that, for better or worse, the translation is "spot on".Trying hard not to look at this album through Goscinny/Uderzo-tinted glasses, because Ferri & Conrad have some admittedly very big shoes to fill, I would say this is overall an okay first-time effort, hence the three stars. But they really need to step up to the plate in their next effort, especially scenario-wise.

"Feels Like Caroline" by the country rock group Parmalee is an outstanding debut album that features 12 very impressive and diverse tracks, ranging from party anthems to power ballads, well suited to fans of modern country as well as rock and a showcase for their ability to combine catchy melodies with great lyrics.Parmalee is a family band comprised of brothers Matt and Scott Thomas (lead vocals/guitar and drums), cousin Barry Knox (bass), and best friend Josh McSwain (guitar), who all come from the same small town in North Carolina. The bulk of the songs on this album are written and/or co-written by members of the band, who tend to describes themselves as being on "the country side of rock", and this is reflected in the songs, that nicely blur the lines between country and rock.They really rock with the fun after-the-party-is-over "Musta Had a Good Time" (must have been an epic party, considering lines like: "Hey y'all, is that my dog up on the roof?, And, good God, why's my car out in the pool?") and the even more hard-rocky  "I'll Bring the Music", but this is bridged by the laid-back, ultra-catchy tune "Day Drinkin'," and ballads like the tugging-at-your-heartstrings lovesong "Caroline", "My Montgomery" and "Think You Oughta Know That" nicely balance the album.All 12 tracks are great, there's not a dud among them, but my own favorite songs on this CD are: the groovy "Day Drinkin' ", "Caroline" and "Another Day Gone", another song with great lyrics, like the opening lines: "I screwed up seven summers, In one afternoon gone wrong, It started out like "Amazing Grace", Ended like a Springsteen song". Now that's what I call song-writing!

When I bought this CD, I thought: Wow! Gretchen is gonna rock the house with these songs! I know she can deliver, just check out her fantastic rendition of Heart's "Barracuda" on Youtube (now why wasn't that song on this album? It's classic rock from the `70s and she knocks that one right out of the ballpark in terms of matching the amazing vocals of Ann Wilson).But sadly, this 12-track album is for the most part a prime example of how not to do a cover album. Doing covers of classic rock from the `70s can be a tricky business. You either should have an original take on them (I had expected Gretchen to do a country adaptation of these songs, which might also have failed but at least could have been interesting) or you should have the power-vocals to do these classics justice if you want to do faithful-to-the-original renditions.The songs she covers are "Stay With Me" (Faces), "Doctor My Eyes" (Jackson Browne), "Everybody Wants You" (Billy Squier), "Bell Bottom Blues" (Derek and the Dominos), "Funk #49" (James Gang), "Hot Blooded" (Foreigner), "Over The Hills & Far Away" (Led Zeppelin), "I Want You To Want Me" (Cheap Trick), "Lights" (Journey), "Her Strut" (Bob Seger), "Bad Company" (Bad Company) and "Into The Mystic" (Van Morrison).I like Gretchen's vocals and CDs and I have a broad taste in music, so I'm not turned away just because she strays out of the boundaries of country. And she might be a redneck woman with a lot of sass and a great voice, but on most of these songs she suddenly seems to lack the "rock chick" power to do them justice. In fact, some of these covers sound like her heart wasn't in them. They are curiously flat with just not enough emotion in their delivery; weird, because these are supposed to be some of her favorite `70s rock songs.The only outstanding covers on this album are "Hot Blooded", "Her Strut" (those two are her best covers on this CD, showing she can really rock if she wants to) and the acoustic "Into The Mystic". While most songs hover somewhere between two and three stars, "Stay With Me", "Lights" and "Bad Company" are the worst renditions, in my opinion. So, adding the points up and dividing them by 12, I come to an average of 2.7 stars, hence the three-star rating. Luckily, her other new CD "Right On Time" is great, so go buy that one instead!

This book is definitely worth your while if you are starting the violin as an adult, or returning to it after a long break. However I cannot imagine anyone being able to successfully start from scratch as a player using only this book as a guide without running into some major problems. There are so many issues of form and posture with the violin, since it requires so many unnatural and counter-intuitive positions and movements, that you just have to not only see or read about, but have someone there physically able to correct and guide you, to learn it properly. And considering the physical consequences of playing the violin with bad form, it's bordering on irresponsible to suggest to anyone that they learn to play from a book. Once you get started with bad form--just a millimeter off, for some things--it's going to be difficult to later break yourself of that habit, and you could end up with carpal tunnel or worse.So definitely invest in a real time teacher at least to get you set up with the proper posture and form before you take off studying on your own. If you have already had some instruction and feel confident that you are able to play with good form--no chicken wing right arm, no beggar's hunch left wrist, no subluxing pinkies--then this book will make a great refresher for you.

It will be a while before I can fully comprehend, let alone appreciate, the things this machine can do. It is truly sophisticated and as such, not the best machine to buy for a beginner. The process of assembly was pretty intimidating, and then figuring out how to make it work was only a little less so. However, persistence pays off because once you figure it out, this machine can do just about everything but clean your house and feed your pets.I can see as I learn to operate all the features that this machine will allow a lot more freedom for creativity without having to worry about technical details. It does a lot of cool things and it is definitely worth it to the dedicated sewing or quilting hobbyist.

This cord is about the same length as the standard charger that came with my iphone and ipad. It works and fits well. It is slightly faster than the old cord, maybe saving about 20 minutes on the charging of my ipad mini. It seems like it will be durable and the color is exactly as shown on the product page here.

My cat has kind of a sensitive system and normally eats a grain free dry food. Sometimes I will give her a can of wet food as a treat or to help her appetite when she's under the weather, and normally she slurps it right up. She wasn't too fond of this stuff. She did try it, but she didn't seem to like it very much and didn't finish what I put out. As a cat owner, I would not buy this stuff routinely because it has grains in it, specifically advertising quinoa. Now I know quinoa is very trendy for health-conscious humans, but is it really the best thing to feed to a cat? Cats are carnivores. My cat definitely does best with grain-free food, both in terms of health and enthusiasm for eating. This brand seems more like it's meant to flatter the hang-ups of a certain kind of human than please the palate (and boost the health) of a cat.

This is a decent guide to a limited number of very common plants that have medicinal properties. The recipes are easy to follow and cover a range of needs, from culinary to comfort to cure. Most of the plants are easily found in temperate parts of North America or, in some cases, in your garden or grocery store. The book serves as a good introduction to some traditional uses of plant medicine. The only problem I have with it is I wish she had shared some more specific information about safety. Some of the herbs in this book, such as elderberry, must be prepared very carefully to separate the helpful parts from the harmful parts. And others are not ideal for pregnant women or children to use. To be sure, you will need to do some further research on your own.

This is a nicely designed test that is indeed very easy to use. The absorbent tip turns hot pink (not a light pink that might alarm the skittish hopeful conceiver) when it touches your "stream" leaving no doubt as to whether you "got it" or not. The handle is designed in a kind of ergonomic way that makes it easier to avoid drops, spills, and awkward angles. I could not find information on the box about the precise sensitivity to HCG of this test, but other sources online (trust at your own risk) claim it is sensitive to either 20 or 25 mcg, which is comparable to other early pregnancy tests. I had already confirmed my pregnancy with a Dollar Store test at 12 DPO (1-2 days before expected period) when I tried this test for comparison. I tried the Clearblue Easy test at 15 DPO. I wanted to see how the sensitivity compared to the Dollar Store product so I put it to the test--middle of the day, normal amount of fluid intake. And I got a dark blue, unambiguous positive before I even set the test on the counter. The unambiguous nature of this test makes it very reassuring. With two tests in the box, it's not a bad deal for the current list price of around $7. Other tests offer the same level of accuracy for less cost, but this one definitely has a number of improvements that may make it worth the extra expense for you. For instance, compared to the Dollar Store test, this one was far easier and less annoying to use (the Dollar Store products requires you to capture a sample in a container and use a dropper to apply it to the test). Overall, a good product that gives a clear answer.

It has been a long time since I have been so disappointed by a book, and felt so cheated by the contrast between what the cover and blurb promise, and what the content actually delivers.From the blurb I was expecting something really fascinating. Coptic monophysites in Egypt, Armenian monasteries, Ethiopia's ancient Orthodox church, the Catholics of St. Thomas in India, Russian Orthodoxy, South American Catholicism, African Anglicans...Nope. None of that. Not even one bit of it. This whole book is about a very narrow band of Christianity that matches up with the nondenominational evangelical Protestantism which the author practices in Alabama.There are over one billion Catholics in the world. The author's first stop, Brazil, is home to more Catholics than any other country in the world. Instead, we get to visit some American missionary's nondenominational church where they perform "skits," and hear about primitive pagan beliefs held by some locals.This is not just absurd and frustrating, it's insulting. The author wants to pretend her Alabama nondenominationalism is representative of Christianity as a whole. Numerically, historically, and theologically, she is just plain wrong.If you want to go on an armchair tour of nondenom Protestant missions, buy this book. Otherwise, skip it.

This is a very pretty dish, and looks nice at a potluck. It washes up easily, and is just the right size for a lasagna or casserole for our medium sized family. The only problem I have with it compared to the pyrex I usually use is that it is VERY heavy. However the lid stays very well on this, which I can't say about the Pyrex dishes. All around, a nice thing to have on hand and will see a lot of use.

My 6 year old loves this. I told her she is too old for the Dora straw sippy, but this is an acceptable compromise in her opinion. It's easy to use (she doesn't need my help getting the straw out like she did with the toddler cups) and doesn't spill. She was able to fix it herself when part of the straw came loose, as opposed to the straw cup which required major engineering. It fits nicely in the little net bottle carrier on her backpack. And it's very pretty. BPA-free is definitely a good thing too, from my perspective, and the price is not horrible. Overall, a good choice for young kids.

Spike is so cute! And this Twilight is so much nicer than the first Equestria Girls version that came out a while ago. She has real feet, nicely jointed limbs, and comes with a very cute pajama outfit. Her hair is beautiful and fun to brush. My daughter likes her a lot.

This is another "bloggy" book where everything is all casual and you wonder why you paid to have it in print instead of just browsing the archives of someone's blog for free. I would have given it more of a chance to win me over but one of the first several entries I looked at used a "humorous" invocation of violence to make a hyperbolic point. The author said something about wanting to "punch people in the throat" for saying something he found upsetting. Well he may feel that way, but as a Christian and a minister, no less, he should probably think hard about more constructive ways to frame that difference of opinion and moderate the emotional reaction so as to be a better example. Yes I know "I want to punch them in the throat" is a very popular turn of phrase among many on the internet, but when you're paying actual American currency to read a book by an ordained minister, it's absolutely acceptable to expect better.Other than that, this really is just another mediocre book of "spiritual but not religious" type insights for the liberal Protestant reader, alas.

This is just a bit on the small size for an 8/10. I'd say it's more like a 7/8. Anyhow it is very cute. There are little ears sewn on, and a lush mane that is really worthy of Pinkie Pie. There is no sewn-on tail, alas, but you can't have everything. The inside of the hoodie is nice and thick and lined with a pretty polka dot material.

I bought this a size up to allow room to grow but it fits pretty much true to size. The tail is an adorable touch, it's not on the Twilight or Rainbow Dash sweaters I got for my other two kids. This is an absolutely adorable hoodie and any Fluttershy fan will love it.

This is a really nice LED bulb. It gives a nice warm light, very similar to what you are used to from a traditional lightbulb. It doesn't have the eerie blue cast that some LEDs can. It is plenty bright, too. The cost savings over time with these things can be considerable, but I find the best part to be the lack of heat generated from the bulb, which makes it both safer and less annoying in the summer months. I have found it is definitely worth the investment to switch over to LED bulbs around the house.

This is a very hearty dog food, and seems to digest well. My pug has a fussy digestive system and has been doing just great with it. Not nearly as much gas or transition problems as she had with some of the other "natural" brands. The kibble is small enough it does not give her a problem with chewing or swallowing. The biggest problem with this food is that the cost is very high, even at the higher weights there's not a lot of savings advantage. But I guess that goes with the higher quality.

This, along with the Advent cantatas of Bach, is the most essential listening for your spiritual and musical enjoyment and enrichment in this waiting season of the year. Quiet, joyful, contemplative...I am pleased to say that the good Sisters are my 6 year old's favorite "band." I can't wait until these wonderful women treat us to another record!

This isn't like a typical chapter book. It has glossy pages and lots of bright, cute illustrations. The reading level is definitely on the easier side, so I think it works well as it is described--a bridge between picture books and chapter books.My 8 year old is already reading more complex books but she still enjoyed this one. The plot reminds me of a My Little Pony or Equestria Girls type scenario, but not as well-written. It's still perfectly fine for her to read, though. And then she read it to her little sisters who also loved it--the adorable illustrations definitely hold their attention. They're nagging me to buy the next installments, of course.

I expected to love this and looked forward to previewing it, because I have always enjoyed Lonely Planet books. I remember traveling the world with them--from my armchair--as I took in all the details of off-the-beaten-path stops and tantalizing descriptions of local food. The guides were never dry, always fun, with enough detail to take you there.This book though...I don't know what to make of it. It is a collection of infographics, many of which are cute and mildly amusing. But it doesn't really cohere at all, and each segment is so brief, it's not all that informative. There's just enough to make you think "hmm" for a second, and not any depth, resources for further study, or even that much wit. It's neither wide enough nor deep enough to really merit the inclusion of the word "expert." And as a hefty hardcover tome, it's more like an odd coffee table book than anything you would think of as "instant"--especially in the era of the internet on mobile phones.I'm not sure who this book is for. There's not enough information to help you actually fake your way through anything. And it's not witty enough to really count as enthralling entertainment. I guess it's kind of a bathroom book, but it's a bit hefty on the price scale for that humble aspiration. It's really too bad, as there was potential for something really fun here.

All of these pet supplements are kind of a crap shoot...no pun intended. Sometimes the dog hates it, no matter how healthy it is. Sometimes the dog loves it, but it makes them sick. This one the dog loved, but I can't see any difference in her health or behavior after trying it. At least it didn't seem to give her gas.

My eight-year-old actually likes this book a lot, and she wasn't even familiar with the Kaya character before reading it. She has enjoyed the "choose your own adventure" format a lot. I subtracted stars from my rating for a purely parental rating--you can't read the whole book in the book. Some of the options lead you to a website. On that website, you are shown and invited to purchase all of the numerous other books in this series and associated products. Essentially it's like they have put a big ad in the middle of the book. Not cool. Not to mention, kids in the target age range need supervision when using the internet, so it's a drag for the parents. Put the whole story, including all the options for "choose an adventure" in the book, please.

It's hard to know how long to expect for results to be apparent with a product like this. I personally have not found it to make much a difference so far for my mood and energy, but then again my seasonal issues are idiosyncratic so it may not be the best choice for me personally but work fantastically for someone else. My husband tried it out too, as a way to adjust between graveyard shift and "normal" daytime hours over days off. He says it works really great for that, gives a boost that helps him wake up when he gets to that early evening "slump." So it may be a good choice for shift workers too.I do find the light to be very, very intense and somewhat unpleasant. It reminds me of the blue bilirubin-eliminating lights used on jaundiced babies in the NICU. I have to be careful about how I position it or I start to get a headache. But the unit is very sturdily built and easy to use. So it is high quality, and for someone with more typical SAD issues, it may be just the ticket.

This is really cute, but pretty small. It would be about the perfect size for a baby about one year old, maybe two. But at the age where they really care about dressing up, like my 4 year old, it's pretty short. It doesn't quite go to her knees. It's not terribly useful as a towel but she likes just wearing it for play.

We have three of these books with the little carrying handle and my kids love to look at them during Mass or Divine Liturgy. Even the older one is drawn in by the artwork and the simple rhythm. The illustration style is definitely old-fashioned by the kids really like it.

I have a 4 year old shark fanatic and this was a birthday gift for her. These are easily the best toy sharks I have found anywhere. They are amazingly sturdy and detailed for their size and price. They are just so cool to look at, I keep picking them up and studying them myself. It definitely thrilled her and fueled her passion for learning about ancient creatures and sea life.

This is my favorite iron supplement. I don't need a ton so I only take it one week out of the month. It doesn't disagree with my stomach or cause intestinal problems like many other brands too. The herbs added are fantastic--exactly what a midwife or naturopath would prescribe. Great value and quality from Vitanica as usual.

I LOVE THIS THING! Mantis shrimp are amazing creatures. They can see a whole spectrum of colors that are invisible to us measly humans! But it is very difficult to find mantis shrimp merch. This guy made my birthday, no my month, no, my summer, no, my YEAR! Best gift ever. Very, very soft and cuddly, and awesome bright colors. So many details like his little snuffly bits and fuzzy bits and grabber bits. You will not regret buying this for the weird sea creature fan in your life!

This book is far too brief. I was disappointed at how short it is. It really only gives a short list of suggestions for each grade level. Those suggestions are very useful, sure, but I was hoping there would be a great deal more in here, especially for the price. There is a helpful collection of rhymes in the appendix, however.
This fellow is HUGE. Very huggable. My daughter uses him as a pillow. He's extremely soft and cute. Good to find some more Ice Bird gear!

I got this for my daughter who wears size 8. It fits perfectly. For a kid who actually wears a 10, it might be a little on the short side. Definitely on the short side for a size 12. So buy a size larger than you usually get. But it is a nice thick fleece, very warm and comfortable.

This is a really amazing sticker collection. If you use stickers as rewards for your kids, it will keep you supplied for quite some time. There are also some larger, fancier stickers for decorating things if you like to do that. I just wish there was more from Angry Birds Space, we all love Ice Bird and there's not much of him in here.

If you're like me, and you love strong female characters who tell it like it is,  you've probably already fallen in love with Amy Schumer.  I know I have and, when I heard she was writing her first book, I was excited.  I wanted to learn more, and the wait was killing me!Thank goodness for author Ian Fineman!  His little gem of an unauthorized biography, "Inside theReal Amy Schumer", was a fantastic read, and really gave me some insight into the lady who, right now, is my favorite stand-up comic. I loved every word, and I was very surprised by some if the facts I learned about her life.Amy Schumer is a laugh riot, and "Inside theReal Amy Schumer - An unauthorized biography" was a short but sweet tribute to her growing legend.  Highly recommended for fans of Amy and comedy!
This didn't even make sense!  The part that's supposed to hold the laptop in place is so thin and small that it kept falling off!!  I can't believe that it was manufactured this way!
I really wanted to like this but it was already broken when I took it out of the package!  Very disappointed.

I recently purchased this mount and it's sister mount for vents and I'm very highly impressed with both!  I said this for the other and I'll say it again here; the best mount I've ever used (and I've used a LOT of them!).It was very easy to install right on my dash with the super double-sided tape.  Once the phone was set up (I have an iPhone 6 Plus) putting it on the mount and taking it off the mount were (and are, because I'm using it now full-time) VERY easy.  As easy as it is to put on and take off, it holds the phone in place very firmly, even under high speed turns.So yes, I'm very, very happy with it and it's now being used in both my cars.  Highly recommended!

This is hands down the best car mount I've used for my iPhone!  II have the iPhone 6 Plus) It hold the phone perfectly in place, the phone is super-easy to attach and/or remove and the set-up was easy as pie!  Very high quality materials have been used throughout and I'm sure this will last for years!  The seller was also very helpful and courteous when I had questions.  I LOVE this car mount, and the dash mount they make also!  Very highly recommended!

I recently purchased an oral thermometer from the same company, iProven, and it is fantastic. I'm glad to say that this ear thermometer from them is just as good, maybe better.One of the best things about it is how fast it gives you a reading. Only a few seconds is what you need to get an accurate temperature, and let's be honest, it's hard to get a child to sit still for much longer than that.  The display is also very easy to read, which is excellent because a lot of times this will be used at night.The best thing however is that it's just so easy to use. Kids (and adults for that matter) just don't have the patience to sit around and wait for an oral thermometer to give a reading, or for anything else. With the iProven thermometer you get a device that gives you a fast, easy reading so that you can get it done without everyone getting all stressed out.So, I'm glad to say that just like the oral thermometer from iProven, their ear thermometer is excellent quality, very accurate, works well and takes a temperature very quickly! For that reason I highly recommend it.

My daughter turns 1 in 2 weeks.  I've been looking for an excellent thermometer since the last one we had broke, and I was recommended this brand, iProven, by a friend of mine.I've used it already several times on Valery and also myself and the speed and accuracy, as well as the feel of the device, are all top-notch.  I like that the tip is flexible because, let's face it, babies don't always sit still (LOL).  Unlike other thermometers I've used this one is very consistent.  I've done more than a few tests to make sure it was reading correctly and, every time, it was almost exactly the same.I'd give it a 10 out of 10 for build, reliability, accuracy and price.  I have an ear thermometer coming from iProven and I have high hope that it will also be exceptional quality like this one.  Highly recommended.

If you are looking for an inexpensive but still great security camera.This is the best choice for you!The camera works exactly as expected, it has great video quality and tons of features: you can view the camera through iphone or android device, you can set at what time it should start to record, you can receive notification when your home is invaded(enable motion detection function) and you can add many different cameras and monitors, all of them be in same interface!Fortunately the great price it has, because it may be easy to set up by everybody, you dont need little network knowledge, you should not set up port forwarding on your home router and configure a static IP Address. It is as simple as you play game. Install app and scan QR code.Then all is ok :-)HereiswhatIdidtosetupthecamera:1.Plug in power adapter andethernetcable2.Entergoogleplayorappstoreto download app3.ScanQRcodetoaddcamerathenyoucanviewHereishowIdidtosetupwifi:GotoSettingsWifiselectwifihotspotandenterwifipasswordthenclickfinish.RemovetheEthernetcalbe.NC300willrestart.thenwifiisOK.
0:58 Mins My video Review of the GSlife 3-Color Ink Ballpoint Pen with Stylus.  Highly recommended!

Let me start this review by coming clean and saying that, under normal circumstances, I would not have read this book.  I'm not a fantasy fan, or a romance fan, or a fantasy romance fan.  LOLThat being said, I was highly recommended Reluctant Gods from a close female friend and she's never wrong about what I will like. Suffice to say she was dead-on yet again.Reluctant Gods starts grabbed me right from the start. Author A.J. Aaron has impressive skills that are, frankly, often lacking here on Amazon. To put it succinctly, he can actually write, and write well.  His characters are fully fleshed out (even when they're not in the flesh) and the settings and surroundings came to life in my mind's eye quite vividly.The story is well put together also.  It moves along at a brisk pace but, when necessary, slows down to allow the reader some time to take in the scenery, so to speak.  It's a timeless love story with a twist, combining elements of romance, science fiction and wish-fulfillment (with liberal doses of adult-oriented situations thrown in to get the blood flowing, of course).What it is, if nothing else, is a fun, sexy and surprising tale about 2 broken people separated by time and fate that, miraculously, come back together and heal each other.What I liked about Reluctant Gods was that it surprised me.  It got into my head and left a little something behind that still has me thinking about it a week after I finished reading, and thats something that very rarely happens with me. Is it my favorite book ever?  No, but any writer who laves an image in my minds eye for anything longer than a few hours is a writer worth reading, and worth recommending.Which is what Im here to do.  Read Reluctant Gods. It will surprise you, put a smile on your face, a tingle in your heart and leave a little mark on your soul.  Highly recommended.
Absolutely fantastic!

While finding out that I'm a `gorilla' didn't exactly make me happy, I must say that the tips and advice in this book, for the most part, are right on the money.  As an overweight person for most of my life, I'm doing everything I can these days to stay slim,  which includes being very vigilant about what I put in my body every day. The advice that I've found so far in this relatively small but helpful book has been excellent.What I can say is that Living The Thin Life  is definitely helpful for people who have already lost weight and want to keep it off. The author, Elle Meyer, writes in a very refreshing style and, even though she's not a trained nutritionist, much of what she has to say, and the advice that she gives, is very helpful.I will say this; I use Garcinia Cambogia regularly to help me keep my hunger cravings down and the combination of that and the weight loss tips and suggestions on how to eat healthy and stay active in this book have been excellent.  I highly recommend it!

After spending more than 30 years as an overweight person, I devoted myself in the last few years to eating healthy, nutritious meals that are low in fat and calories. The problem is of course that, many times, those meals are also low on  taste.A few weeks back my ex-wife (go figure) told me about The Skinnytaste Cookbook. She knows I'm always looking for new recipes and I have to say, her recommendation was a really good one.  I've tried almost a dozen recipes so far and they are easy to prepare, taste amazing and are somehow still low in sugar, calories and fat! (My favorite so far, even though it's not actually a meal, are the heavenly banana nut oat muffins.)One habit that I have gotten into is to take Garcinia Cambogia  with every meal, and it's been a fantastic combination with the recipes in this cookbook. I feel full, don't have those hunger cravings that really annoy me and the food is simply delicious. It's a great combination and, if you're like me and doing everything you can to stay slim, The Skinnytaste Cookbook is an excellent choice.

I've been reading and watching Drew Canole ever since I actually wrote about his company back in 2011, so when I saw that his new book, The 10 Day Smoothie Challenge, had been published here on Amazon, I purchased it right away. I absolutely love smoothies and not only does Drew create some of the best I've ever had, the combinations of delicious, healthy ingredients that he puts together are fantastic! Of course one of the best reasons to read and use this awesome book and program is because it will definitely help you lose weight, and fast! To that end, I also took Garcinia Cambogia along with a smoothie every morning during the 10 day challenge and the results were phenomenal! If you're looking to lose weight fast, and feel incredible too,  I highly recommend this book and program!  It helped me lose almost 10 pounds and I feel great!

Ive tried Sulbutiamine in the past and have always enjoyed it. I find it gives me a good buzz in the morning in terms of focus, motivation, and memory. It puts me in a better mood and makes starting the work day go much more smoothly. Ive almost completely cut coffee out my work day. The only time I drink it now is when I am cycling off Sulbutiamine. (Sulbutiamines biggest downside is how quickly one builds a tolerance).I tried this vendor for the first time and am extremely pleased. Product was double sealed and very professionally done. As someone who has purchased many obscure racetam nootropics from online vendors in the past, I found the products presentation to be very refreshing. After using the product for a week, I feel like the buzz I get is a little stronger than what I have experienced with other vendors. Maybe this is primarily due to the placebo effect created by the products presentation but I am definitely satisfied with this purchase. I got this product for free in a nootropic giveaway in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

My fianc and I welcomed our little baby girl, Valery, into the world about eight months ago and she now can sit up on her own and is playing with her baby toys all the time.I know from experience that little children are extremely curious and love pictures and, when I saw the My First Family Photo Album on Amazon, I knew she would love it!We got it about a week ago and, just like I thought, its now her favorite thing to look at, hold onto and, of course, put in her mouth. (She is just a baby after all.)The photo album is really fantastic in every way. First, its made of a very heavy duty plastic that Im sure will last through all of the rough handling it will go through in the next few months and years. We have already put 12 pictures in it, with the faces of everyone in the family including us of course as well as her grandparents, one brother and two sisters. (It holds 15 pictures so we still have a couple more to go.)Valery absolutely loves looking at those pictures and, since the plastic is nice and thick, they dont get damaged by her little hands or by all of the drool and spit that gets on it all the time.Whats even better is that theres a mirror included on the back page of the album so that she can look at herself. Its baby safe of course and theres no need to worry about  It breaking because its not glass.Theres a small loop on top of the album so that you can hang it wherever you like, which makes it easy when we go for our daily long walks, and makes sure that it doesnt get lost or accidentally thrown out of the stroller.What we really like most about it though is that Valery gets to see pictures of her relatives, most of whom dont live close by, on a regular basis. We want her to know who the other people in her family are so that, when we visit them, she will already recognize them.The fact is, we are so pleased with the Album that were going to order a couple more of them so that we can leave one in her stroller all the time and have one for her playpen and crib too.If you have an infant or small child and want  them to be able to have fun while also familiarizing themselves with other members of your family and friends, the My First Family Photo Album is a fantastic choice. Highly recommended.
Awesome Lego set!

Ive been battling weight problems since I was a teenager and have tried just about everything under the sun to not just lose weight but also keep it off for more than just a few days or weeks.Of course since I havent been living under a rock I have heard of Garcinia Cambogia for the last few years but, thinking that it was just a fad and wouldnt really help me, I never tried any of the dozens of products out there.Frankly, I was also worried about any side effects that I might have but, when my sister-in-law started using Garcinia Cambogia from Nutrivion (she bought it on Amazon just like I did) and got great results, I decided to put my fears aside and try the product for myself.Rather than keep you in suspense, I will just say this; Im extremely pleased with the results that I have had so far. After about three days I really noticed that my hunger, which usually would get out of control around the middle of the afternoon, was almost nonexistent. Although I was worried that my mood was going to be all sorts of crazy, the fact is that I have felt very calm and relaxed over the last couple of weeks since I started taking the product and, most importantly, Ive lost almost 8 pounds!With most diet products that I have tried over the years (and boy, have I tried a lot of them) the product usually works for a few days and then my hunger just keeps building until I want to explode and I gorge myself on the worst kinds of foods.Im happy to say that this hasnt happened at all. Not only do I feel great, but Im not suffering in the afternoons and evenings from uncontrollable hunger like I used to before. Even better, I dont snack before bedtime, which I have read is the worst thing that you can do if youre trying to lose weight.I've also noticed that, when I do sit down for a meal, I can eat smaller portions and still walk away from the table feeling satisfied. That in itself is wonderful because Im the type of person that usually goes back for seconds, thirds and more.I wanted to write this review because I know there are a lot of people suffering the way I did and I want to let them know that Garcinia Cambogia  really does work.This is the only brand that I have tried and, frankly, its the only one that I will be using because it has been working extremely well. I highly recommend it and I wish everyone out there who has suffered from weight problems like me the best.
Very happy with this!

I've been using Tea Tree oil for years and years.  It's absolutely amazing stuff.  This organic tea tree oil from WellnessScent is at the top of my list now however because it's just so much better than anything else I've used. It's extremely potent and made from 100% organic stuff, which I really like. The price is very reasonable too, and it works really well.  As you might guess I'm highly satisfied and happy and recommend this tea tree oil very highly.

The reason I bought this was because, when I read the description on Amazon, I was so impressed by the features that this grow light was manufactured with. The ability to replace a single diode is not only amazing but amazingly cost-effective, and using aluminum to increase the reflective light was brilliant. The fact that I've actually started paying less for my electric bill is also impressive but, of course, the real question is whether or not my plants like the new lights.They definitely do.  I noticed a difference in less than a week.If you need a phenomenal grow light, you're looking at it right now.  Highly recommended.

I'm new to growing the particular, recently legalized plant that I grow and I wasn't sure which grow lights to purchase. I got the recommendation for these from a magazine and purchased several to 'daisy chain' together.  I have to say that the results that I've had so far have been very favorable, using them was easy and my electric bill only went up about 21%.  I was expecting around 40 so that was a nice surprise. The fact that you can easily change out a damaged diode is brilliant too!  I also like the ability to dim the lights for different types of growth.  I'm very pleased and will continue to purchase these grow panels in the future.
