I got this for my son who's 15 and I tell you what, I wish I would have had one of these when I was his age!  The rope start is brilliant and he was able to master it the first day with ease. I thought the double hand brakes would be a problem but they are another excellent reason to get this bike.  I love riding and I wanted to get Alex something that was lightweight, didn't go too fast and gave him the experience he needed to move up to a bigger bike.  This bike from Flying Horse has done all of what I hoped and more, and has helped him to get a love of motorcycles just like me.  Well done, well-made and highly recommended.

I'm very pleased with the performance of the CNS carb. As they claimed, I've seen a big difference in performance. Being able to adjust the choke and idle, as well as the air to fuel ratio,  so easily makes this an excellent product.  I really like that it's low profile for obvious reasons.  Highly recommended and field tested excellent!
My favorite car mount ever!

I've purchased a number of items from this company because they are really great, and these sheets did not disappoint either. I can't believe that these are priced so low and still deliver such impressive quality and softness!!I will definitely be getting more for all of our beds because the quality and the price simply can't be matched, and I've looked!  I love comfy sheets and these are my new favorites!I can tell that these will last for years too because they are made very well.  I have 800 count sheets that aren't as nice as these! Highly recommended, with a smile on my face!

Just purchased these along with some Queen sheets too and I have to say, I'm very impressed!  Super-soft, luxurious and comfy, I wish these could go on MY bed!  The print is very bright, the fabric is extremely well made and, again, it's soooo soft.  My daughter's going to love these I'm sure! I've purchased a number of items from this company and have been impressed every time so far. I will continue to get their stuff in the future I'm sure.  Highly recommended.

Considering his age, I'd say that the author, Ethan Taylor, has quite a future in writing science fiction novels.  This first try was a smashing success!The book is very cute, and the character, while not particularly well-drawn, is cute too.  It's hard not to think back to the days when you were a child yourself as you read Ethan's book, and reminisce on times that were simpler and carefree.I recommend this to parents who want to read something to inspire their children to use their creativity and imagination.  This book will do that, and leave a smile on your face and theirs as well.  Highly recommended.

After reading the first book in the Ana Martin series I was definitely hooked. The author has a style that Im really enjoying and the first book left me with some lasting impressions and thoughts. In other words, I was definitely ready for more and have been coming back since.Frozen Flame is Lyneal Jenkins best book by far in my opinion, and it made for a perfect conclusion to the trilogy. These characters have become like friends to me and the final storyline, with the usual twists and turns that the author loves, couldnt have been more satisfying.The character of Ana is on a par with any heroine being written about today and, although there are a number of clichs that the author relies on, she does it with such style that you can easily forgive her.If you love strong female characters, a well written yarn that will keep you guessing throughout and a fully realized world on a par with Tolkien, Frozen Flame is definitely a must read. Highly recommended.
Not worth the paper it's written on.

I have already purchased several products from the same company and all I can say is that they work fantastically and the results have been better than I could've hoped for. I don't think there's much better testimonial than to be able to say that I keep coming back for more products because I'm very pleased with the results. If you're looking for top quality products that your face and skin will really appreciate, there's no reason to look any further. I would highly recommend this product, and all the other products from Nutrapacked Labs, very highly.
Well made, heavy duty and works perfectly.  Delivered quickly too, and a great price.  Not much more you can ask than that!  Highly recommended.

I really love this product.  I have wrinkles (light) around my eyes and mouth and (moderate) on my forehead.  The Vit C serum has visibly reduced them in just a few days. Plus it's also made my skin more toned and, on my neck, it's done a fantastic job toning and making it more taut. Easy to put on and it feels nice too, I'm very impressed and happy with the results so far.  I've already recommended to a couple of friends. I also like that it's made here in the US, so I don't have to worry about what's in it.  Highly recommended.

I have a Galaxy Note and an iPad Mini and needed something I could rely on to get them both charged when I was out running around, which I all the time.  The fact that the Gembonics charger fits in my pocket is awesome because I can take it anywhere, I can charge both at the same time and it lasts a LONG time.What's even better is that it already comes equipped with connectors for both the Mini and the Note. Sweet!  Talk about convenient!  I like the blue color too.  Just saying.Anyway, it's the best.  If you need a charger THIS is the one to buy, no question!

I've had a habit for over 10 years of cutting a piece off of my aloe plant and putting the gel directly on my face and neck.  It's amazing but this product is even better. I have used it for a few days already and the difference is very noticeable.  I've even had comments from a couple of friends that I look 'younger', which was awesome. The smaller wrinkles around my eyes and mouth are practically gone and the bigger ones are much smaller. It also feels good after I shave so that's an extra bonus.  I would def. recommend the product, especially for the price. Great stuff!

I've tried a number of products from this company and they impress me every single time.  This time is no different.  Peppermint oil is one of my favorites and this is the best I've ever used, no question.  The handy guide book is a HUGE plus too, as the one I have is really outdated (it was written in the 70's).I use peppermint oil almost every day.  I love the aroma!  If you need any essential oil there is simply no better company to purchase from in my opinion.  I love them, and I love this oil!  Very highly recommended! Getting the guide is just icing on the cake!
2:02 MinsMy kids and I used the Zebby this weekend and it was awesome! We just wanted to do a Review of it so that others would know what a great little device it is.

I just turned 50 and, although my mind is as sharp as ever, I've been looking to take some supplements to make sure that it stays that way. I was talking to a neighbor and he recommended this product so I purchased a bottle and have been taking it now for about 3 weeks.I'm actually quite surprised that I've noticed a difference already, but I really have, especially in my short-term memory. I'm a professional writer and having a clear head is extremely important to me, As well as being able to focus intently when I need to. It seems that I can concentrate better since starting to use this product as well.I'm not sure how much more help it will give me but I have high hopes based on what I've seen already. I'll keep taking it whatever happens because it has already proven to be worthwhile. Definitely recommended.

As always, another excellent read by Marie F Crow.  I'm going to make this short and sweet.  If you love zombies but you're sick of the usual dreck that's been filling the virtual shelves lately, author Crow serves up something that's deliciously different and far from ordinary. If you don't read at least 1 of her books you're truly missing out on something special but, be warned; Once you DO read one, you'll definitely be back for more! Very highly recommended.

My friend bought me two of these recently for my birthday and I have to say that I'm very pleased with them. I have been practicing yoga for over 10 years and didn't think there was much more I could learn or do to improve my stretches but these have helped so much! As I've gotten older it has become a little more difficult to stay balanced when I do deep stretches in some positions and the yoga straps have  made some of my stretches a lot easier. Also, we stretch together now using these and it's not only very helpful but also a lot of fun!  If you would have told me something so simple would add so much to my yoga routine I would have probably just brushed it off in the past but I can say with all honesty that these yoga straps have definitely made a difference. Highly recommended, no matter what level of yoga you happen to practice.

I started using this about 6 weeks ago and I have to say that I am very happy with the results. I've lost almost 20 pounds, I feel great and there have been none of the side effects I've had with some other products.My energy levels have been high (but not too high) and my appetite a LOT lower. I don't think there's much more to say than awesome product.I'm almost at my goal weight and I've purchased more since the first bottle. By the way I'm almost 50, eat healthy and exercise a little.Very highly recommended!

My nephew Tom got into DJ-ing a few years back as a hobby in high school and loved it so much that he decided to try and make it as a professional. He's really a great kid and I know he's serious about it, so when he asked me for some money to get a more professional setup I told him that I would give him what he needed but I wanted to be part of the decision-making process. That's when I started looking and found Dragon Frontboards.Our budget wasn't tiny but it wasn't big either, but the guys and gals at Dragon took care of us as if we were spending big money. Honestly, I was surprised at how affordable the booth is, as well as how durable it seems to be so far. It's also easy to carry and very portable, which is great because Tom doesn't have a very big car.The best thing though is that it really looks fantastic and makes him look like a total pro. The first time he said it all up and put on the LED lights I was absolutely floored!Anyway, I'm glad to say that Tom's DJ business is doing great and a lot of it is thanks to the DJ booth we got from Dragon Frontboards. One last thing I'll mention that's important is simply that the Lycra fabric panels are easy to clean, which is great because, like most young guys, Tom is a bit of a slob.  Highly recommended.

I read Night of the Fae a few months back and, when I did, I mentioned that I couldn't wait for the sequel. Well, it finally got here and I have to say that I think I like Hidden Light even better!In the first book we were introduced to Ana,  possibly one of the most well-written female characters that I've come across in quite some time. This time around she's grown up quite a bit (due to the extraordinary experiences that she had in book 1 of course), and her character has gotten stronger, more willful and, at least for me, much more interesting.Author Lyneal Jenkins is a simply wonderful storyteller and she manages to intertwine the fantasy elements of Hidden Light  with quite a bit of action and a generous portion of intrigue and drama as well.I won't give away any of the story because it's just too good for "spoilers" but I can say that  you will definitely enjoy watching Jenkins' characters,  and their world, come to intricate and in-depth life.I enjoyed this book thoroughly, just like the first in the series, and I look forward to the next with more anticipation than I would ever have guessed. This is one of the first series I've read here on Amazon that has done this for me. If you're looking for an excellent read by  a crafty, gifted author,  Hidden Light should really do the trick.

I got wax recently for myself from BodyHonee and it worked so well that my girlfriend started using it.  We then saw here on Amazon that they had these waxing strips and, since their wax was so darn good, my sweetie decided to get these too for her legs.  Just like the first product these work really well.  They're super gentle but also pretty durable at the same time.  She complains about wax strips that rip but not with these! The wax also doesn't 'seep through' like with a lot of wax strips,  and for $10 you get 100 of them which is really a super deal!  BodyHonee is batting 1000 with us so far and we both hope they keep it up.  Kudos to a great company and excellent products!

I wanted to try this because my girlfriend doesn't really like the hair on my chest and arms and, I must say, I was surprised just how well it worked.  I got it because it's all natural but, honestly, I wasn't expecting it to be so good. We're both extremely pleased with the results and now my girlfriend is going to start using it on her own legs too. I highly recommend it especially because it's made with just 3 simple ingredients and doesn't have the harsh chemicals that most hair removal products have. It's natural and does exactly what it promises! Great stuff!

Listen, we all know that zombies are freaking everywhere today and, let's face it, the tales can get a little 'similar' after a while.  Is The Apocalypse the best zombie tale ever written?  No, but it's damn good. The word 'gritty' really fits this book well, and author Peter Meredith's writing style fits perfectly with the subject matter.  There are some parts that really took my breath away I can tell you that.  Great character development too, and the ending was absolutely fantastic!  Of all the zombie books I've read (and there have been a few) this is one of the best, seriously.  It had more or a 'real' feel to it than most, definitely.  Highly recommended!

I actually got this for my birthday and I have to say that it's definitely worth every penny that the person who bought it for me paid. LOL!  Seriously though, I've been practicing Yoga for a number of years and I've had several different mats. This one is probably one of the best I've ever had simply because, even when I'm dripping with sweat, I don't slip and slide all of the place. It's also extremely convenient because it folds very small and take up little space in my car (I keep it there). One last thing; unlike some of the others I had, this mat doesn't stink. I mean that literally. Many of the others I've used, after a few weeks or even a few days, begin to stink.  For whatever reason this one doesn't even though I've used it for a few weeks now.  So yeah, I recommend it highly.
I LOVE this book.  I wish I would have been able to meet the author before he passed.  My hard copy is dog eared from reading it so much.  Best script writing book ever.

OK, so zombies have literally take over everything these days.  Movies, TV, books, you name it.  Now along comes The Risen and, well, I wasn't going to get it to be honest. I love zombie anything but I just saw WW Z last week and it stunk, but to my surprise this book was a real treat.It gets going right away and throws you into a story that never lets up. Well fleshed out characters (pun!) and a great heroine make what could have been another run-of-the-mill zombie story into something that I really enjoyed the heck out of.Does it have some cliches? Yeah, sure. What zombie story doesn't? Is it inventive and different? Yes and yes, enough to make it worth the read. I give it 5 stars. Yeah, it's no 'War and Peace', but as zombie stories go, I thoroughly enjoyed it.  Recommended.

This book should seriously be on every guy's reading list.  I know that some guys can approach women more easily than others, but most don't have that ability (including yours truly). Pickup Lines Don't Work is like a college education on how to talk to women and will help practically every guy get better at it.It's actually a great read too, and was very engaging from page 1. It proved to me that everything in life is a skill that can be practiced and perfected. Talk about a self-improvement eye-opener!  I am now on my way to be a master of mingling and an expert on starting conversations and engaging with the ladies, all from a book that was really a breeze to read.I've actually read it twice now. Yes, it's that good. I was so overwhelmed at the idea that I could practice and become better at talking to women, and the possibilities that would soon be my reality, that I couldn't sleep for a few days!If you're looking for information on how to become a master at talking to women, not just some dumb jerk with stale pick-up lines that women hate, READ THIS BOOK. Highly recommended!

If you're the parent of a swimmer then you know that all those short trips back and forth to the pool, and all those longer ones to swim meets on the weekend, can be like torture. Torture for your kid if they have nothing to do, and torture for you if you have to sit there and listen to them complain that they have nothing to do.  (Been there, done that.)Yeah, there are apps and smartphone games aplenty out there but sometimes they can get a little boring. Your child might also be too young to really enjoy them, or you simply may not want them to play those types of games, and that's where the Swim Meet Activity Book really comes in handy.I'm a child of the 70's and we used to have these for everything. These days they are few and far between though, unfortunately. This one is geared towards swimmers of course, and loaded with games, puzzles and even 'Mad Libs' that the kids can create, fill-in and answer while riding in the car back and forth to meets.  Great stuff!The last meet we had I brought this and my son Alex and his buddies thought it was great!  They loved the Mad Libs of course, but the other activities were popular too.  I was surprised to be honest because they are all between 12 and 14 and I thought they would think it was 'boring'.  They didn't, and the trip was a blast for all of us!For younger kids this would be absolutely perfect, and for parents of swimmers looking for a little relief from all that constant nagging and repeated cries of 'are we there yet?!', this will be a godsend. I hope they make more. Highly recommended.

I just finished reading The Mind Shaman for the 2nd time and I have to say, I'm still blown away by some of the ideas and insights that author Luca Bosurgi packed into his book.I guess I should say Dr. Bosurgi because the guy has more degrees than probably 4 other men put together.  I consider myself intelligent but I think he's on another level entirely.The book starts out with what I first thought was a bit of a deceit; the life of a young man as told by that young man from pre-birth until his early 20's.  Yes, I said pre-birth. The story begins when 'Liam" is conceived and follows him through 9 months of pregnancy (inside his mother, of course) until the day he's born, than onward as he matures from baby, to child and finally to adult.  It's a unique and thought-provoking look a how a human life is 'started', that's for sure, and although I can't say I loved this part I will say that it was a very interesting look a the world from inside the mind of a child.Once 'Liam' is an adult however the story begins to really take shape and we meet the esteemed Dr. Bosurgi.  I can't say that I understood everything about 'Bosurgi Syndrome', named after the author, but I can say that the theories and ideas that were introduced had me thinking own life and the relationships and emotional ties I had with my parents (both of whom are deceased).If you're considering reading The Mind Shaman book (and I highly recommend it) you should know this; you won't be the same after you're finished. As I mentioned I have read it twice already and I'm keeping it on my night table for reference over the next few weeks.  It's deep, metaphysical stuff that will stick to your brain like velcro, and the actual syndrome discussed may well hold the key to some of my own, how shall I say, deficiencies.This is NOT light reading by any means.  It will open your mind (maybe too much) and force you to do some actual thinking and contemplation.  If you're not ready for that you might not want to pick it up to be perfectly honest, but if you're looking for a book that will stick in your mind and open your eyes to how the human psyche really works, as well as find some answers about your own life, The Mind Shaman is that book.  I recommend it highly.

Let's face it, getting kids to sit down and read a book today is no small feat. My daughter hasn't read a book in ages and she's not really big on the 'fantasy/adventure genre.  Luckily however, I am.This is a book geared towards teens or, as they say today 'young adults' / YA.  With that in mind I wasn't expecting the kind of thoughts and ideas that author SE Sledden presented, and I say that in a very good way.  She doesn't talk down to her audience in any way and the main character, Tillie, is a firecracker of a girl in the mold of Merida from Brave, the recent Disney/Pixar film.She's contemptuous of all things 'adult', as you might guess, and wants nothing more than to escape to 'something better', even though she has no idea what that might be.It's standard teen angst fare, to be sure, but told in a charming way that really held me in sway for a few solid hours.  I wish my daughter would read this, I really do.  I think she would appreciate the similarities that this fictional character has with her own real life.  Maybe I can convince her...In any case, if your daughter is an avid reader this is a wonderful, charming and thought provoking book, no question.  A great lead character, well-rounded surrounding cast, plenty of surprises, lots of adventure and solid 'coming of age' type stuff.  All beautifully written to boot!  I highly recommend it.

When a new book reminds you of a classic you know it's a good one, and this one reminded me of Mark Twain's 'The Adventures of Huck Finn' quite a bit. it's been a long time since I read a book that was so much fun.I bought it for my son and he liked it so much that he said that I "had to!" read it, He reads quite a few books and is quite the young critic so I took his advice.  The Treasure at Devils Hole has all the markings of a classic adventure. There's treasure to be found of course, as well as a scary nemesis, quirky sidekicks and a pretty girl waiting to be won. Author Jody Mabry certainly knows his way around a good yarn and sets up this instant classic for a lot of great payoffs at the end.It's definitely a lot of fun and I can understand why my son enjoyed it. What young man (or older man, for that matter) doesn't dream of going off on a treasure hunt with his best buddies or brothers? It's the quintessential American adventure and has a universal appeal that Mabry taps into with great aplomb. I got swept up in the adventure myself and ended up reading it in one sitting.This book definitely has a lot going for it. It's got a great tale, fully fleshed out characters that you can visualize quite easily in your minds eye and enough twists and turns to keep even the most finicky of readers interested from start to finish. It also has quite a few laughs and I was quite surprised at how deftly the author was able to handle the comedic side of the story.I would recommend this for any young reader that's looking for a great adventure story with some fun, thrills and laughs thrown in for good measure. My son and I both enjoyed it quite a bit and both of us recommend it highly.

I get hangovers very easily. Usually I will experience a headache and nausea after five or six drinks. I have looked into other hangover prevention products (mostly nothing but vitamin blends) but havent had much luck. Finally I decided to give this a try and was pleased with the results. The product works, but I have noticed that its effectives declines when an extreme amount of alcohol is consumed. See below for an explanation of what I mean.1. If I drink 5-7 drinks in a night and take two capsules the DHM relieves 100% of all hangover symptoms.2. If I drink 8-10 drinks in a night and take three capsules the DHM relieves 80-90% of all hangover symptoms3. If I drink 11-13 drinks in a night and take three capsules the DHM relieves 50-60% of all hangover symptoms4. Id I drink 14+ (which I dont do often and dont recommend anyone ever drinks this much), in a night and take three capsules the DHM relieves 25-35% of my hangover symptoms.I have found that if I keep it under 10 drinks this stuff eliminates all (or almost all) of my hangover symptoms.But, if you plan on getting obliterated to the point you black out and expect to wake up the next morning without any hangover symptoms you are out of luck. It will help, but it wont work any miracles.

I will briefly say that I like these lights because the fact that they blink is one of the favorite things I remember from my childhood. On the other hand, the fact that I've only had them for two weeks and three of the bulbs have already blown makes me wonder how many will actually work when I use them again next year.

I suppose the first thing that I should admit before starting this review is that I'm quite skeptical about any claims of psychic powers.Okay, now that I've gotten that out of the way I can admit that I actually enjoyed this book quite a bit and was surprised at some of the ideas, thoughts and real-world applications that author Embrosewyn Tazkuvel has jam packed into this excellent read. From using the inborn psychic powers that all of us have to increase focus and for self defense, all the way to telepathy and telekinesis, the argument for everyone having innate psychic abilities that he makes is very strong indeed.The most important question is simply this; does it work? To that I will also answer honestly that, in my extremely recent experience with reading the book and using some of the information I found, it actually might. I don't want someone to purchase this book because I said that "yes, it will help you to be a psychic!" but it did open my eyes to the possibility and, coming from a lifelong skeptic, that's saying something. even more telling is that I plan on rereading it again.No matter your belief, it's a well-written and extremely interesting book. The author's writing style took a little bit of getting used to but once I had gone through a few pages I found myself unable to put the book down. If you've always been intrigued about whether or not psychic abilities are "for real" or maybe that you have some of your own, this is definitely the book that you want to read. I have no problem recommending it highly.

Anyone that knows me knows that I am a fanatic for cookbooks. Not any kind of cookbook either, but cookbooks that lean towards healthy, easy and quick to make recipes that don't take a ton of prep time. I am not trying to be a gourmet chef, I just want to be able to whip up something healthy and delicious without spending half a day in the kitchen.That's why I like this book. Author Lynn Ahbonbon knows her way around the kitchen and some of the recipes I found in her book are not just easy to make but absolutely delish. On the healthy side, they're low in fat and empty carbs, which I really appreciate and bonus, my kids have (so far) loved every recipe that I've made.Two standouts are her Coq au vin (chicken in wine), a dish from France that my mom used to make when we were kids that I haven't had in years, and also the Butternut Squash Soup which was super fast to make and really yummy.Anyway, as you can see, I really like this book and I'm looking forward to making quite a few more of her recipes.this is one cookbook that really delivers on its promise. It's got recipes from all over the world that are healthy, delicious and, best of all, easy to make. Highly recommended.

Look, I'm not going to sit here and try and convince you that this is the best book I've ever read. To be perfectly straight it threw me a little bit at first because of the ideas and images that it was talking about. After reading it first time I wasn't really sure exactly what I had just read, but I kept thinking about it anyway.So I went back and read it again. The second time around I really opened my mind to what the book was trying to tell me and what the author was trying to say. I'm glad I did because the second time was definitely the charm.Many of the themes In the book touched home with me, like being alone in the universe, trying to find out why we're here and what we're meant to be or do.  Like Kerouac himself the main character in the book is searching but he's not exactly sure what he searching for.What I will say about 'The Man Who Followed Jack Kerouac' is that, if you take your time and really listen to what author Christina Westover is saying, you will come away a changed person. For me, that definitely makes the book worth reading.

I'm a big fan of Carol Vale and have another of her books.  All I can say is that if you like making food that your family will truly LOVE you need this book!  I am from an Italian home and food is as important as breathing to us, so for me a great cookbook is a must.  Carol's recipe's are fun, different and, most importantly, DELICIOUS!Am I gushing?  Yes, I am.  :-)  The Turkey with Herbed Ricotta Stuffing is amazing!  I made it last week for Turkey Day and it was a HUGE hit. I made the Maple Roast Pumpkin too and the Apple and Rice Stuffing on the side. The Cider Gravy?  OMG!!  My sister wants a copy of the book for Christmas!Anyway, as you can see I'm a big fan of this wonderful book.  Easy to understand recipes that will make you look like a 5 star chef!  Highly recommended!

I'm a repeat reader of author Tim Houston's books (I read 'Leads to Referrals' not too long ago) and, while this new book is well written, insightful and definitely helpful, I was kind of hoping for just a little bit more in the way of unique techniques to help me with the process of generating more referrals and more business.That being said, Houston's newest book 'The Referral Rules! 7 Ways to Get More Profitable Referrals' is still an excellent book that, for the beginner as well as the seasoned veteran, gives heaping helpings of great advice for generating referrals and keeping customers happy.  I have no problem at all recommending it and, compared to other books on the subject, it is a definite standout.

Ive owned 2 different types of small businesses including a health food store and several massage/day spas. Recently I was presented the opportunity to purchase a hair and beauty salon but, since Im not experienced with that type of business, I decided to search for help online before making my decision.I found Hair Salon Marketing: Achieve Greater S.U.C.C.E.S.S. With Less here on Amazon and decided to give it a full read. Im very glad I did to because not only is it extremely well written but it had so much excellent information on marketing for not only a hair salon but for small businesses in general that its definitely going into my must re-read marketing library. Author Tony Jackson truly knows what hes talking about and the advice he gives is just as good for the beginner (like me) as it is for someone whos been in the industry for decades.Even if youre just a stylist who has her own (or his own) chair at a local salon this book will definitely help you to increase your client base and your repeat business. And thats the point, because the hair salon industry thrives on new business and repeat customers. As with most small businesses, without a constant influx of new people about the only place youll be going is belly up.My wife and I still arent sure if or going to be buying this hair salon but, thanks to this excellent book, if we do Im certain that it will be successful. Highly recommended.

Amber Shea Crawley is my new hero!  This is a fantastic cookbook, filled with not only a ton of yummy recipes but also lots of information and advice hat anyone can use to slowly but surely ease their way into a raw food diet.  I have a little bit of experience (I owned a health food store for 7 years) but I have never seen such a great collection of recipes and info all in one place.  Crawley also writes with a very easy to read and cheerful style that anyone will love no matter their taste in food.  Highly recommended, especially the Flax Jacks with miso/maple butter!  Delish!

Okay, Im going to admit this right at the start. Being nearly 40 years old I am probably way too old to be reading a book like this. The Latecomers Fan Club is definitely leaning towards the young adult crowd, and I am no longer a young adult by any means. That being said, I have to admit that I thoroughly enjoyed this book from start to finish. I think the main reason is that it really reminded me about how great, and how messed up, things were when I was in my 20s.I actually got this book because a colleague of mine (a woman in her early 30s) was raving about it one day at work. She was so enthused that I asked her the name of the book and picked it up a couple of days later. There are three main characters and author Diane V. Mulligan jumps around between the three of them, giving their viewpoints and narrating her story from the same. I really liked that a lot as most books only give you the inner thoughts and viewpoint of one character.Mostly though I really enjoyed how realistic the story was. From the people to the settings, the situations and feelings, it all felt very familiar to me and really brought back a lot of fond (and maybe a few not so fond) memories of when I was making my way through young adulthood and making all sorts of stupid mistakes. I got my heart broken, dated the wrong women, stayed at enough crappy jobs to last a lifetime and broke a few hearts myself during that time, and this book reminded me why I wouldnt want to change a single thing.Being from the Northeast myself a lot of the settings were very familiar and, even though Im a guy, the insight that I got from the viewpoint of both Maggie and Abby was not just interesting but refreshing. Nathaniel reminded me of myself (although Ive never been much of a musician). Hes a nice guy at heart but just doesnt get the fact that women need more than he can give. Talk about familiar.Anyway, while the opinion of a guy in his late 30s might not be very valuable to the target audience of this book, if youd like my opinion Ill tell you that this is an excellent story from an excellent author and well worth wrapping your mind around for a few hours. It has compelling characters, a great storyline and is extremely insightful and, at times, quite moving. Highly recommended.

I found Black White and Shades of Greyy (The Within Greyy Line) to be an extremely interesting book and one of the most original stories that I have read in the last few months. Im not a huge fan of Pirates but when a book is written this well Ill take a great seafaring adventure any day. Theres also the fact that this book incorporates a bit of fantasy as well (the lead character, Greyylene, is an elf) as well as quite a bit of rip roaring mayhem and suspense. When you add it all up it amounts to a fun read that should quench the thirst of anyone looking for a bit of rollicking adventure.Author ElissaBeth Frear is obviously a very creative writer and gives the book just the right tone, somewhere between swashbuckling adventure and romantic comedy.  Her characters are full of life, to say least, and the settings and locations that Frear describes seem to jump off the page. If youre a fan of all things pirate or you just looking for a book that will keep you on the edge of your seat for a few hours, you could do far worse than to get Black White and Shades of Greyy I highly recommend it.

I just turned 50 and Ive heard about hypnosis many times over the years but, to be honest, I never really gave it much thought or respect. That all changed about 5 years ago when a colleague of mine went through a quick and drastic change because of hypnosis. He was an alcoholic and, when he drank alcohol, he also smoked cigarettes. He knew it was a problem and went to a hypnotherapist for help, seeing him for 2 sessions over 2 days. That was 5 years ago and he hasnt had a drink or smoked a cigarette since, something that still amazes me to this day.Its because of this that I picked up Self Hypnosis As You Read.  Its actually the sequel to another book written by author Forbes Robbins Blair called Instant Self  Hypnosis and, now that Ive read this book, Im quite eager to find and read the first.Both books have an incredibly interesting proposition that the author, an accomplished hypnotherapist, discovered on his own; anyone, no matter who they are or what they believe, can hypnotize themself while they read words out loud. Im talking about reading a book with your eyes wide open and going into a  hypnotic state while doing it. Indeed, both of his books have allowed thousands of people to self-hypnotize in the comfort of their own home and that would now include me.Now, frankly, if you would have told me that this was possible before I read Blairs book I would probably have laughed in contempt (or at least giggled a little bit) but, after having read the book and actually using his techniques on myself, I am completely convinced that his technique works. In fact, Im amazed at how easy it was and at some of the results that Ive already had in my life after reading his book.As I was reading his book (specifically, the parts meant to be read for self-hypnosis) I actually went into a relaxed and hypnotized state. (It was really something.) Blairs book gives 42 specific goals that you can address using his technique.  As of now I have used 2 of them including Override the Fear of Rejection and Tinnitus Relief and, no lie, my tinnitus has gone down considerably as well as the fear of rejection that I have had for many years. (Im a writer and a former chiropractor and I thought it was part and parcel of both.)Self Hypnosis As You Read was written for the layman and as such it is extremely easy to understand, easy to read and also very well written to boot. I have already purchased 2 more copies to send to a friend of mine and my ex-wife, both of whom suffer from a couple of problems that Blairs book addresses.Many people have the same bias towards hypnotherapy that I used to have but, if thats you, I can say with 100% conviction that this book has opened my eyes to a new and amazing idea. Not only that but it has actually helped me and I look forward to using it for a number of other problem areas in my life.At the end of the day, it certainly is a heck of a lot less expensive than any other kind of therapy I have ever used and, better yet, it actually works. Highly recommended.

It doesn't take a genius to realize that there are a metric ton of "how-to" books being written these days. I know, because I've read quite a few of them. In my 49 years I've been a moving & storage salesman, a chiropractor, the owner of a health food store and I'm currently a writer. I've also learned two languages on my own (Dutch and Spanish). So, when I tell you I've read a number of how-to books, I'm not exaggerating. (Margarita Madrigal's Magic Book of Spanish is a great how-to book if you want to learn Spanish. Just FYI.)I was actually given "Get Paid to Speak: How I Went From a Poor Utah Teacher to a Rich Speaker in Just 6 Months!" by a friend of mine who knows that I am interested in becoming a public speaker. To be honest, I have already done quite a bit of public speaking but on a very small scale. When I was practicing chiropractic in Peru I would give weekly "charlas" or speeches to groups of new patients ranging from three or four up to 40 or 50 depending on the week. This is an excellent way to build a chiropractic practice and I know that there are lots of people who make a living from public speaking but I didn't really know the nuts and bolts about it.This book, as I said in the title, is possibly one of the best how-to books I've ever read. Author Russ Johnson has, like me, had a very interesting professional life and done quite a few different things professionally. (We're also just about the same age.)  His book is extremely well written, organized and straightforward. As he says right in the beginning it's not going to show someone how to "get rich quick" but I can attest to the fact that, if you're looking for information on how to start a public speaking career, this is definitely one of the first books you should read. I have already started using some of the excellent information in order to make the transition and set up the contacts I need.Johnson gives step-by-step instructions on what to do, what not to do, and most importantly, how to turn your life and career experiences into something viable and valuable that people will pay you to hear. From the basics about how to be `found' through getting over your fear of public speaking and finding paying gigs, this book has it all.  For me it's been a revelation and I'm looking forward to the next up in my life which is going to be as a public speaker. If that something that you aspire to, buy this book first. Highly recommended.

When I was a kid my parents used to play games like Pictionary and I used to hate it because they would always make us go to bed early and then keep playing the game after we went to bed. I would be in my bedroom listening to the squeals of laughter from downstairs in the den and be jealous that they were having so much fun, wondering why they were squealing like kids too.Today my wife and I have a fairly active social life and we were looking for a game to play that was similar and recently found You're Pulling My Leg, a great game that is sort of like a "truth or dare" from years ago. In it you basically tell stories about yourself, some of them false and some of them true, and try and get the people playing with you to decide whether the stories are true or not. It's a heck of a great way to get to know your friends and neighbors a lot better and open up some fun conversations. As a way to sort of "break the ice" at parties it's excellent and gets the whole gang laughing.Just like when we were kids we let ours join in the fun until bedtime and then, once they're safely tucked away, the real fun begins. After a little bit of wine you'll be amazed what you find out about even your best friends and occasionally your spouse as well.If your next dinner party isn't as fun as you'd like, I would definitely suggest whipping out You're Pulling My Leg. Before long things will get a lot more fun, I guarantee. I recommend it highly, especially if you and your circle of friends are close and like a good laugh.

My kids are both big fans of Jim Carrey and his "Pet Detective" movies so, when I saw this game, I quickly bought it for them and crossed my fingers that they would like it.  The reason I crossed my fingers is because, with all of the video games and smart phone games that kids like these days (including mine) it's really hard to get them interested in a "regular" board game anymore.  It seems that these kind of games aren't "cool".Anyway, I can't really tell you how the game works or what the object is but it does have something that both my kids like a lot which is  cute, furry animals. Not only that but, with the four "custom" cards they actually can make game cards with pics of our own pets in them.  (1 dog, 2 cats, 1 rabbit and several fish.) I thought that this feature was really cool myself and the kids have a lot of fun switching out the pictures with new ones that they take and print out here at home.All I can say is that if any game can keep my kids occupied for more than five minutes it has to be a good one and, since the kids have been playing this for a few weeks now (and sharing it with their friends) it's got to be really, really good. That's about the highest praise that I can give any type of board game, so if you are worried that your kids are becoming video game zombies, get them Pet Detectives and let them have some honest-to-goodness fun with an old-fashioned board game for a change. I think you will be pleasantly surprised.

You're Pulling My Leg! Junior is one of the best games I have purchased for my family in a long time. I was actually starting to think that my kids were getting a little bit too old to play games with my wife and I but we have had so much fun playing this game that I wish I would've gotten it ages ago.  I'm a professional writer and my kids are always asking me how I come up with some of the stories that I write. Well, this game is certainly a good way to become a great storyteller.The object of the game is to fool the other people with stories (both true and false) and try to make them "believable". It promotes plenty of creativity, that's for sure. (I just hope they don't use it against us when they get older and start dating and driving the car.) This is definitely a good game for older kids although if your younger ones have a vivid imagination they would probably enjoy it as well.My son had a birthday recently and he and his friends played this game for hours during the party and the subsequent sleepover. My daughter has also talked about it with lots of friends because she really enjoys it. For me, anything that can bring the family a little closer together for some good times and lots of laughs is good by me. The metal tin is also great because it takes a lot of abuse and doesn't fall apart like some boxed games. Highly recommended.

This book is highly researched and well thought-out and when you add up and evaluate all of the parts of this book, its a most impressive effort but thats to be expected when you consider the dedication of Mr Lawrence along with the deep pool of experience and support of the Dupuy organization.The book begins with a bountiful Prolog/Prehistory (roughly 350 pages) It includes war history as well as immediate pre battle conditions, preparations and assessments of both sides for the upcoming operation. This preface mentions Kharkov and Stalingrad but also Leningrad and Moscow as well as a myriad of other topics not directly related to Operation Citadel. I found these topics interesting though some weren't essential to Operation Citadel. One topic of interest concerns: Did Germany have a chance to defeat Russia. Despite the German kill ratios being higher than the enemy's, the reserve pool of draftees for the Soviets were too large and the Red Army would be able to outlast the Germans in this extended war. In other words could the Germans bleed the Soviets white before they had to surrender. Not earth shattering material but still an interesting discussion.The next nearly 1,000 pages covers Operation Citadel on the southern salient and the subsequent Soviet counter offensive. The time is from early July to mid August when the Soviets recovered all lost ground. The battle history is delivered chronologically in two, three or four day chucks. Its not as precise as daily coverage but it makes for a smoother, easier to follow dialog. The battlefield was broken up by German Corps sector with activity of the 48th PzC leading the narrative, followed by the SS in the center and ending with the 3rd PzC on the right flank. This may sound surprising when discussing a book of such dimensions but while the operational narrative was very interesting, effective and covered equally from both sides, it was not exhaustively complete. There is still material that can be found in other high quality books that could still expand your horizons.Besides the smooth delivery of battle history, Mr Lawrence inserted hundreds of timely, well chosen quotes to supplement his commentary. Though most of the quotes were operational in nature, it made the narrative seem more personal. It will allow the reader to understand that the officers of middle to upper ranks and some enlisted men had a pretty good understanding of the circumstances occurring in their sector. These comments delivered some of the analysis that supplemented the author's commentary as the battle progressed.The air war is also given good coverage in both text and data tables.The next major segment to consider will be Maps. There are many black and white maps spread out throughout the book; they appear to be original war maps. Some German and some Soviet. With a little time the German maps were pretty well deciphered but the Russian language maps were more difficult to study. The author also provided a few fold out maps that were twice the size of the other maps and were easier to read. For me the difficulty in reading some of these maps clearly brought down the effectiveness of this section but this may not be an issue for others. Another issue to consider is that these maps are not fully populated which also brings down their utility a little. Having more unit designations on the maps could clearly help the reader follow the narrative and analysis.The next major category to consider is the vast array of statistical tables. I didn't count them but scattered throughout the book there are probably 200 data tables. Some tables are used as summaries for individual battles while the remaining tables which are housed in the Appendix are generally overall campaign summaries. There is tremendous amount of information here and even if the US Army gathered some of it post war, it must have taken Mr Lawrence a lot of time to gather, organize and resurrect this data into these nifty tables. These tables could clearly be helpful to researchers.The Appendix just mention is roughly 350 pages and contains more than tables. I also enjoyed the sections on commander profiles and even if you're well read on the war, there probably will be some nuggets of interesting information you can learn on your favorite officers. Following these profiles are many portraits of officers on both sides. You get to see the portraits of the names that are so frequently mentioned. Its another way of personalizing this battle.There are other photos to study. There are war time aerial photos of the battle sites as well as present day photos of the terrain; both types were useful in understanding what the Germans had to contend with in reaching the Psel River area as well as seeing how the Soviets were able to stop the advance. Other battlefield photos are included to round out the visual aspect. Some of the photos are grainy.There is also a large Bibliography, Footnotes and a useful Index if further study is desired.I enjoyed this read a great deal and fully appreciate the effort Mr Lawrence has made in writing such a thoughtful book and strongly recommend it to all enthusiasts of the Campaign.

Even if you have read the two creditable books that have recently been published on the Moscow campaign, you should still consider getting this new book translated by Richard Harrison for it has material that the earlier books don't have. The study written by the Soviet General Staff and overseen by Marshall Shaposhnikov primarily covers the three month period of November, December and January 1942; the first months includes insights of Soviet resistance during the German advance while the last month shows much greater details of the Soviets as they initiated their own counter offensive that eventually saw the Germans pushed back to the general line that included Rzhev.The book is highly Soviet centric and nationalistic in nature and is no different than the other Soviet studies that were popularized by David Glantz some years ago. Without condoning the errors included in the original book but also not correcting the miscues, the translation by Mr Harrison is a strict interpertation of the original study but at least he highlights the key but probably not all the exaggerations that have found its way into the study .The book begins with a brief situational summary of the war in October when the Germans launched Operation Typhoon. Its shows the general plan of the Germans and the counter measures that were put in place by Zhukov. Army Group Center had about the same number of men as Western Front but had a clear superority of tanks and artillery that gave von Bock confidence that even with winter approaching his exhausted forces could still take Moscow. The Germans were unaware of the size of the reserves moving up to man the multiple defense lines in front of Moscow when it was decided to extend the advance past November. The Soviets saw the attack as primarily a two prong attack that would envelop Moscow from the north and south. While the central German advance, the more direct Vyazma-Mozhaisk-Moscow route is covered, special attention and analysis is given to the panzer groups attacking toward Kalinin in the north as well as the attack toward Tula in the south.With such a large battlefield to describe and with so many military units deployed among so many towns and cities let alone defending along rivers and canals, reading this battle can sometimes be challenging. Following this story is made a little easier with the inclusion of battle plans before the actual individual battle coverage as well as post analysis.Since this study was meant as a training aid for future battles, the analysis was extensive and battle coverage also included partisan actions, logistic concerns, commissar motivation and air force coordination. The tactical importance of holding certain towns, roads and rivers was especially interesting. Two minor points to mention though not criticism for it was outside of the author's purview. There is not much in-depth discussion of individual officers. The most attention was given to Belov, Zhukov and Stalin plus a handful of other Soviets officers on an even smaller scale. For the Germans Hoth, Guderian, von Bock and Hitler were discussed. FM von Kluge with his promblematical command decisions of late November and early December was glaringly absent. The other aspect that was lacking sufficient attention was the effect the freezing temperatures and deep snow had on the two armies, particularly the German side. Not fully prepared for winter fighting, these conditions had an extreme impact on the men, tanks and other weapons of the German armies.The dozen b&w maps, most are full page, are good and will be helpful. The maps show the key areas of fighting and highlight the text.  An Order of Battle and a useful Index are included.Despite the Soviet bias, I still enjoyed this book, learning some new aspects of the campaign and freely recommend it to all enthusiasts. If you're new to the Moscow campaign Col Seaton's or Mr Zetterling's books on the campaign might be an easier place to begin your study and if you like the campaign definitely get this book to round out your campaign research.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book for it covers a lot of important ground and it should appeal to both novice and avid student though , I believe, the more experienced student will get the most out of it. Balck recounts his military experiences starting with WWI right up to May 1945 when he commanded Army Group G on the Western Front. I'll bypass his family introduction and officer candidate experience and jump into WWII on the Eastern Front where I found his higher rank and greater responsibility more interesting though he did distingush himself in France in 1940. Much time is spent as CO of the 11th PzD and later the 48th PzC. Never being far from the front, Balck had intimate knowledge of each battle and as such his descriptions of the battlefield and general tactics used were enlightening and will appeal to the avid student who have probably read about some of the key battles like the Chir River defense, Dnepr River defense, Korsun Pocket, Zhitomir, Tarnopol and more from authors like David Glantz, Douglas Nash, Rolf Hinze, Stephen Barratt and others. The inclusion of Balck's memoirs with the reading of these other authors makes for a more meaningful understanding of the battlefield events. The wisdom and insight of the author, though naturally biased, was still appreciative and helpful.The narrative was much more than just battlefield coverage; the author also covers not only the hardship and misery of fighting on the frontline as well as the morale of the Landster that frequently had to fight under poor conditions. Decisions made at Corps, Army and Group levels as well as the OKH and of course Hitler's impact on the war effort were also discussed. Officers such as Manstein, Model, Guderian, Mellenthin, Manteuffel, Kesselring and Stauffenberg, among many others, were frequently discussed, providing the reader with a profile of each of these men. General Balck had much praise for Manstein, Guderian, Mellenthin, Manteuffel while acknowledging the ability of Model but also saying that many officers and men didn't like him for he micromanage and was aloof. Hitler receives the greatest amount of attention; he was given praise for certain things but for the most part was criticized for his handling of the war and his WWI mentality that caused so much grief and death.In addition to the battlefield history and officer profiles, the author also provides political background during his military career, especially the good and bad points concerning Germany's Allies that adds to the general overall usefullness of the book.The book also includes twenty maps, a useful Appendix which includes Balck's career curriculum and important statements and documents. Photos, extensive Notes and Index are also included.These memoirs and the fine job of editing makes this one of the key books in my library and freely recommend it to all interested parties who want to study the wide ranging and distinguished career of a German General during a critical time of our recent past.

Mr Nebolsin, using primary and secondary sources, has created a creditable battle history of the highly decorated 2nd Tank Army during 1943 and the first part of 1944. The story is predominately operational in nature. Even most of the first hand accounts are operational though the author gives praise to some individuals for their bravery under fireThe author begins by including the origins and indoctrination of the army and the war status as of early 1943 before quickly moving into the major engagements. The first major engagement involved the northern boundary against Model's 9th Army in Operation Citadel where 2nd TA played a key role in stopping the German advance in the center of the line. The subsequent offensive for the Orel salient is also included. In the last quarter of 1943, the Sevsk offensive is presented. In early 1944, the Korsun Pocket is discussed, followed by the Uman Operation and then the invasion of Romania. The remaining months of the war wil be in Volume 2.With only a couple exceptions, the author uses from one to three pages (excluding tables) to cover each combat day. It doesn't sound like much but with his efficient writing style, the author delivers ample coverage. Included in the coverage are the specific 2nd TA units involved, their deployments and objectives for each engagement. The German division targeted is usually also provided. After engagement results are then listed with special attention given to casualties of man and machine. Many tables are provided for easy study of numbers entering the engagement and the casualties. The author always give specific numbers of T-34s, heavy assault guns and light tanks that were deployed.There was much about the book I enjoyed; I especially liked the fair presentation of the battles including when the Germans took the advantage of certain battlefield sectors that caused horrendous casualties on 2nd TA and its supporting infantry. The effective Luthwaffe was also included. There was no sugar coating or excuses when the army made mistakes, had difficulties or took heavy casualties. I also liked coverage drilling down beyond Corps level to Brigade level in many cases, providing deployments and objective for each unit.There are also 16 full page color maps. The maps have good eye appeal and covers the deployments of 2nd TA but they're not comprehensive, many times lacking full coverage of supporting Soviets units or the German units that were trying to stop them.There is also a large photo gallery that was really good. There were many battlefield shots that included many tank photos in action or moving up to the line. There were quite a few officers and men as well. A decent Bibliography and a helpful Index was also included.I really enjoyed this book though it doesn't have the level of detail that "Demolishing the Myth" or "The Viazma Catastrophe, 1941" has and yet it provides a good overall picture of the many contributions the 2nd Tank Army made in the last years of the war. Its highly recommended to all fans of the operational but I should also say some readers may be a little disappointed with the scarcity of in-depth truly personal, anecdotal experiences of the war.

This book is a sequel to the author's Operation Typhoon, which covered the German October victories of the pocket battles at Vyazma and Bryansk. This book will take you through the rainy November period to early December where AGC stumbles badly, allowing General Zhukov to halt AGC's advance within sight of the gates of Moscow. (I hear the author's next book will cover Zhukov's counter-attack that pushes AGC back many miles and saves Moscow from capture.)This book like the author's other books is a command level view of the German perspective. While there is mention of divisions attacking key battle sites and the tactical importance of those sites, providing a brief overview of the battlefield, that is not the main purpose of the book. The primary purpose of this book like the series is to show that despite the initial victories of encirclement, Germany didn't have sufficient industry, resources, men, weaponry and vehicles to defeat the Soviet Union. It is also shown that Hitler, the OKH as well as some of the field generals didn't have the proper strategy or the insight to improve it. If you enjoyed the earlier books and are not growing tired of this theme and format no matter how well its presented then you will enjoy this effort as well.While Mr Stahel continues to pound away at the deficiencies of German strategy, poor insight and dubious actions, he adds weight to his perspective by including numerous pertinent, comments and opinions by politicians, soldiers of all ranks and civilians. These numerous comments and diary entries, not only show the extent of his research but also create profiles of key people and strongly assist in showing that by the end of October the Wehrmacht was whipped and to resume its attack toward Moscow was dangerous and unrealistic, even crazy. To believe that after fighting constantly for five months and losing a quarter of your men and even more of your armor to Operation Barbarossa, the exhausted army was expected to surround and clear the huge capital during winter was sheer fantasy. Its like a challenger entering the 10th round of a championship fight against the Red Bear and despite getting in a few good punches during the earlier rounds was standing on wobbly legs while the champ was just getting into stride and ready for another ten rounds if that's what was necessary to win the bout.Though I wish the author would include greater coverage of battlefield events**, I do acknowledge and appreciate the depth of Mr Stahel's research and his insight at this high command level as well as the choice of anecdotal selections to bolster his comments. Topics of discussion include the friction brought about by the discrepancy of strategic views between Hitler and his top commanders, the friction that developed between the field commanders, the independent action that a few generals made that actually had a negative impact, the delusional estimate of the physical status of AGC after the pocket battles in October that generated a hold and defend posture in early November, the poor intelligence gathering, the poor even desperate decision to drive toward Moscow so late in the year with heavy rains followed by extreme cold and snow to contend with. Overlooking the desperate need for vehicle maintenance, rest for the men and buildup of supplies must also be considered on how it would impact the resumption of the offensive on the fortified capital must also be factored into the equation. The lack of planning if Moscow was encircled or was entered. There is also the aspect that despite the fact that Soviet defenses were now slowing the German advance, Hitler, Hader and the OKH deluded themselves into thinking the Soviets were finished and sound tactics were unnecessary. And with AGC not having a plan in case the Soviet Union actually did counter-attack made them even more vulnerable. With all this in mind the overriding central theme of Mr Stahel's position is: Did Germany have the potential ability and resources to defeat the Soviet Union in a longer than expected war of attrition. The author once again believes the cost of German victories throughout 1941 was too high coupled with insufficient armor, planes, men and industrial support at home would doom the Germany's chances for victory. The author takes on each of these topics and more and convincingly proves his position.(**There are already good books that have such battlefield coverage and if interested should be read along with this book. Three books quickly come to mind; the authors are Albert Seaton, Zetterling and Frankson, and Radey and Sharp.)There are 18 b+w, large scale maps which will be helpful; there is also an extensive Notes Section, Bibliography and Index if further research is desired.The author, as usual, does a nice job of tying these latest circumstances into his overall position that the Germans didn't have enough resources or a proper coherent strategy to defeat the Soviets and in fact argues the war was lost by the end of 1941. The author paints a vivid picture of the conditions and hardships facing the German troops and the impossible task the OKH was ordering. I personally believe the author has taken this theorem as far as necessary and has proven his point and I hope will now concentrate more on the battlefield historiography, tactics and anecdotal experiences with his future books. I've been very impressed with this book and series and fully recommend all Mr Stahel's books to all interested students.

Of the six new "Bulge" books that have been released in the last two months, this book at least from my perspective of favoring battlefield operations and analysis is most impressive. In addition to this inspiring story is an equalily impressive map set and a large photo gallery. With the book having dimensions of nearly 9 in. by 12 in., most of the maps are large and the many photos will not overpower the story.The book opens with three introductory chapters that covers the prehistory of the sector, the planning of the German offensive and then the preparations for the attack. The next three chapters takes up the offensive for at least the first week of the campaign. The time period varies, being longer in some sectors. The battle actions begins with 5th PzA sector against the 28th ID defenders, followed by the 7th Army attacking 4th ID and finally the 6th SS PzA as tail end Charlie attacking in the north against 99th ID. The next two chapters covers the air war followed by the siege of Bastogne and collectively these five chapters consume the bulk of the offensive. The last three chapters covers the action starting with the new year and you'll read about the Operation Northwind to the south of 1st Army, the beginning of the Allied counter offensive that will eventually push the German forces out of the Ardennes. Coverage ends at the end of January.Mr Bergstrom has a military bearing and I enjoyed his dialog as he describes the military events. He sets up the combat engagements very well, using a no nonsense approach in describing the combatants facing each other, mission parameters, the deployments being used, axes of attack and flanking positions if any. Terrain and weather conditions are also often included in the mix. The avid student of the operational will really appreciate this writing style. The combat coverage frequently drives down to company level or combat group level and when the skirmish is larger, battalion and regiment level is usually provided.Military profiles of key officers and men of both sides are included and provide additional insight into the decisions made on the battlefield. Interesting sidebars are also provided throughout the book that are related to the battlefield action but not directly a part of the battle action.To enhance his narrative, many snippets of after action reports are included as well as quotes from key people in the campaign. Also at the end of each chapter, a helpful summary of conclusions and results are mentioned. This end summary will help clarify any concerns you might have while reading the chapter. Coverage is fairly even between the two combatants, neither side being permanently overshadowed.In addition to an expert narrative, the author has included twenty excellent B+W maps. These maps are visually appealing and well populated and the reader will be able to gleam a lot from them. These maps have been wisely chosen in with regards to sector and time. These maps could be used as reference when reading any book on the "Bulge". The large photo gallery which, includes helpful captions, is also an asset to the book. The book also contains a nice set of color plates of tanks and planes that were involved in the campaign. The expert Notes Section, Bibliography, Appendix can also be of good value if further research is desired. The author has used a wide range of primary and secondary sources and the results of his efforts are clearly evident.The narrative ends with Conclusions. This chapter is also creditworthy (for the most part) as the author who is clearly sympathetic to the German cause, gives final appraisal and summary to the campaign. I was perplexed with part of the opening paragraphs when Mr Bergstrom discusses the positive aspects of the German battle plan and its subsequent execution of it. I fully agree that the German plan and preparation of said plan was generally very good, especially considering the lateness in the war, having been pushed back from Normandy and the shortages of fuel and other materials as well as the lack of training to many of the German soldiers. However the battle plan, at least from my perspective, was not as perfect as the author states in this opening but luckily as the chapter evolves, the author clarifies many of those points of contention, at least with regards to the 6th SS PzA. The comments by the author regarding the questionable execution of the SS Army plan clarified much of my concern for the author's comments but I would also submit the fact that with Hitler giving Dietrich, an officer of questionable command experience, the most powerful army of the three and gave him the worse terrain for armor as a major flaw in the plan. When several divisions were late arriving to their launch point and with the problems with the Heydte airdrop, I submit a major alteration to the original battle plan, especially concerning Elsenborn Ridge, should have been exercised but wasn't. There are a number of other tactical concerns that could be debated but, overall, looking at the overview and summary of results as a whole the chapter is noteworthy. The brief dissussion on small solution vs big solution was interesting, especially the part regarding the serious circumstances the Allies would have found themselves in if the warehouse system in and around Liege had been captured by the Germans."Ardennes 1944-1945" is an awesome effort by Mr Bergstrom and it deserves all the praise that I'm sure it will get. For me it's a must have reference for my library and would suggest to all avid students of the campaign that it be added to their's as well. Highly recommended!

I wanted to compare "Thunder at Prokhorovka" with two leading books. I wanted to see how it would fare against the best. I chose David Glantz's "The Battle of Kursk" and Mark Healy's "Zitadelle". All three books are operational in nature and should prove a good match. I'm making this comparison not because I enjoy being humbled but because it should help me write a better book in the future.Mr Healy has spent a little more than half the book on the preparation and introduction to the campaign. It starts with the relationship of Hitler and Manstein at the time of the Kharkov Offensive and then expands on the discussion with Zeitzler, Manstein and other generals in deciding on which form of the Kursk Offensive: the "Fronthand" or the less aggressive "Backhand Approach". Once decided, Mr Healy enumerates every situation or condition that will have an effect on the offensive. Its an extensive analysis that is impressive. It includes Stalin's spy ring, Churchill's notification of the offensive to Stalin, Hitler's delays, planning the offensive, Luftwaffe support, panzer production troubles, partisan interaction, Lend Lease assistance to Stalin and much more. I particularly liked the discussion on Hitler's views on Manstein. It was also significant how many of the generals disavowed the "Backhand" approach.Glantz and Schranck also discuss such items but not in as much length or detail. This area goes to Healy.The next area to compare would be Wonder Weapons and tanks in general. Mr Glantz discusses Hitler's new panzers in chapter one and in chapter two a little about Russian armor. The Tigers, Panthers and Elefants are furthered discussed throughout the book. Mr Healy devotes an entire section of 7 chapters - Part Three- to the subject of wonder weapons and tank tactics. "Thunder" also has good coverage of these weapons but the material is interspersed throughout the book and may be less conveinent to study than the other two books.The presentation is impressive for Mr Healy and he wins here.Mr Healy spends 170 pages on the offensive while David Glantz spends 176 pages and Schranck spends 432 pages on the offensive. The volume is about the same for the first  two authors while "Thunder at Prokhorovka" spends over twice as much time on the battlefield. Glantz lists more engagements than Healy who is more selective but gives greater depth to each selection. Schranck provides greater breadth of the fighting and extends the coverage to the end of August in regards to the Orel salient. Mr Glantz provides good coverage of the tank battles near Prokhorovka but Thunder provides even fuller coverage and it has better analysis of the Soviet armored assault.  I'll give this section to Schranck.I have an interest for July 8th and 9th for its a pivotal period in the campaign. The moves and counter moves made will lead to the tank battles near Prokhorovka just a few days later. The first two authors cover the days well but Mr Healy writes an auxiliary chapter, Chapter 37, that discusses the Soviet contention that it was their blocking actions of these attacks south of Oboyan caused the Germans to shift to the east toward Prokhorovka which resulted in the massive tank battles. He presents evidence to the contrary, that it was in the German battle plan back in May to shift to the northeast. Very interesting chapter. In a related matter, Mr Healy refutes Soviet claims of destroying thousands of panzers in the first few days. This theory is confirmed on July 13th when Manstein, believing he still has ample armor, argues with Hitler to continue the battle in the south. Both Mansttein and Kempf were confident that by continuing the assault, Soviet tank reserves could be shattered. The other two authors also provide coverage on this topic. "Thunder" is the only book that has a battle map of the Soviet armored counter-attacks.Near the end of Chapter 4, Mr Glantz states in his book that due to the stalled advance of Kempf and the stiff resistance facing 48th PzC driving north toward Oboyan that Hoth orders the 2nd SS PzC to shift its axis toward Prokhorovka. This would be more in tune with Soviet doctrine and a difference with Mr Healy. Schranck also provides good coverage on this important issue, exploring both sides but in the end shows Hoth had intended to move toward Prokhorovka before the campaign started.Another point of related interest is the number of tanks destroyed in the campaign. Each author have similar comments and quote similar numbers for this topic. An important point is that the Germans were able to recover many damaged tanks for use in future battle. About 325 panzers were destroyed while another 1600 damaged panzers were recovered for future use. Its estimated that the Russians lost 1614 tanks, five times the number of German losses. This topic is a draw.In one area where the authors might have improved their coverage concerns the battle for the skies. This is not unusual for Mr Glantz but he does mentions in Chapter 3 the condition of the Luftwaffe in the sector before the start of the battle. Mr Healy does discuss a little fuller on the air war in Chapter 16. The air war coverage in "Thunder" is delivered on a daily basis and is similar in scale to the other two. This catagory is a tie.Each author ends his book with Conclusions. The main theme to the earlier books is the future implications to the lessening of German offensive capabilities. Both are good but Glantz is more extensive in this specific area and he takes this sub catagory. Schranck spends less time of the future potentials for the combatants and spends much more time discussing and analyzing the good and bad decisions made during the campaign. Special attention is presented on the errors made by General Hoth, the improper deployment of 3rd PzC and the armored charge of General Rotmistrov. The battleplan for Rotmistrov was ill conceived and a alternate plan is suggested that would undoubtedly have harvested better results. Its close but Schranck takes this catagory.Both of the leading books have photos but "Zitadelle" has many more and better ones and in this area it clearly wins.Each book have maps. "Battle of Kursk" have functional ones, timely interspersed throughout the narrative and are relatively easy to study as your reading. Mr Healy only has a few maps at the beginning of the book. He does have a map of the July 12th tank battle which was helpful. "Thunder at Prokhorovka" have more maps and they are in color. They are fully populated and are easier to study. There are also six large color pull-out maps that can be used alongside your book as you read. Schranck takes this catagory.All three books have an Appendix. They're similar in nature but "Battle of Kursk" is more extensive and Glantz wins here.The last category to be compared is the readability of the book. I'll give the winner first then an explanation. Both Glantz and Healy are experienced writers and both do a good job of writing their book but I would have to give Healy the win here for he provides better balance between operational history and writing an interesting story. While I like Glantz's writing style, his exhaustive descriptions of deployments and axes of attack can be overwhelming.The writing style for "Thunder", the author's first book, shows signs of author inexperience, having moments of awkwardness and redundancy but these circumstances goes beyond experience.
