The book is also German-centric but the Soviets are still represented fairly well.There is a very capable Notes section and an impressive Bibliography of primary and second sources if further study is desired. An abbreviated Order of Battle for both sides is helpful as well. The author also quotes Glantz, Nipe and Carell. There are a few typos but nothing that would cause a lot of confusion.This is an interesting, easy to follow story that will provide sufficient operational information that will probably satisfy most readers and plenty of first hand accounts blended seamlessly into the story to show what it was like fighting in a tank, a plane or a trench during this horrific battle. This is a quality effort and if you have an interest in Operation Citadel, you should consider reading it.FYI: This book is the exact same book as the author's "The Battle of the Tanks".

For anybody who wants to read about the Campaign for the first time or for those who have read about it a long time ago, this would be an excellent overview to read. To the best of my knowledge, it contains the latest scholarship that refutes some of the exaggerations that have been around since the battle. One area that Mr Clark frequently visits concerns the number of tanks that were destroyed and the subsequent numbers of remaining tanks available to the key corps and divisions to continue the battle.In addition to the ground action, the author frequently touches on the air war, showing examples where a battle was won or at least not lost with the help of their air forces. Extending the coverage further, partisans ambushing a supply convey that would never reach Hoth or visiting a field aid station with overflowing patients waiting for attention or sappers trying to clear a mine field during a bitter battle and more are presented in this book. The key officiers like Vatutin, Rotmistrov, Hausser, Manstein and others are discussed with mini profiles developed. Appraisal and analysis is also provided which was good and accurate but with a depth that was a little less than can be found in books by Glantz or Zamulin.Considering the format and content of this book, I would consider this ideally suited for new or intermediate students of the Campaign or collectors of Operation Citadel. Of the 382 pages devoted to the main section of the book, only 174 pages cover the campaign. The other 208 pages are directed to the first years of the war from Barbarossa to Kharkov 1943 to the buildup of the launch of Citadel. The history of the two countries and their dictator's rise to power since the end of the Great War begins the book.As a comparison Valeriy Zamulin's recent book, "Demolishing the Myth" consumes 559 pages on just the operational aspects of the Campaign. If I hadn't recently read "the Myth", I probably would have rated this book five stars but when you compare these books on an operational level for amount of information, insight and analysis provided as well as the ability of the author to put the reader on the battlefield, Mr Clark's book is fairly rated.Along with the narrative are ten maps; six are small scale maps of the salients. They're attractive and quite helpful showing key sites and deployments of key units as well as axes of attack but I would have liked more of the villages and fortified hills that played such an important part to this campaign displayed and not all of the Soviet units were shown. The maps were spread out throughout the book but from my perspective weren't aligned with the story very well. In some cases the reader will have to scroll back to hunt for the map that displays the information that is currently being read. A small photo gallery is also provided.Both salients are covered but the southern battle is more dominant. The book is also German-centric but the Soviets are still represented fairly well.There is a very capable Notes section and an impressive Bibliography of primary and secondary sources if further study is desired. An abbreviated Order of Battle for both sides is helpful as well. The author also quotes Glantz, Nipe and Carell. There are a few typos but nothing that would cause a lot of confusion.This is an interesting, easy to follow story that will provide sufficient operational information that will probably satisfy most readers and plenty of first hand accounts blended seamlessly into the story to show what it was like fighting in a tank, a plane or a trench during this horrific battle. It also provides ample background information on the war prior to Kursk. This is a quality effort and if you have an interest in Operation Citadel, you should consider reading it.FYI  Clark's other new book, "Kursk, The Greatest Battle" is the exact same book!!!!

This is a good but select overview of Operation Barbarossa. While there is one chapter of the German drive toward Leningrad and another chapter on its drive toward Rostov in the south, the major emphasis covers the advance of AGC toward Moscow as well as the Soviet counter-attack that repulses the Germans from entering the capital in December 1941. It also emphasizes Guderian's 2nd PzG's march south in September to assist Rundstedt's AGS in closing the Kiev pocket. Some of the battles of AGC include the capture of Minsk, Smolensk, Kiev pocket, Vyazma, Bryansk, Orel, Mozhaisk, Kaluga, Kalinin and the attempt on Moscow. It also shows that with so much armor with AGC, the flanks had a difficult time taking Leningrad and Rostov.The objective of the author is more than describing the introductory status and conditions of the two sides and the military highlights of the Operation; the strategic significance of the book is to show the Germans were able to advance and destroy Soviet armies at first but by December 41 when it reached the Leningrad, Moscow, Rostov line, it had reached its zenith, had exhausted itself and didn't have enough men and panzers to finish off the Soviets. By the time it reached Moscow their own large casualties and the extended line prevented the capture of Moscow and through implication that the Germans actually lost their chance to defeat the Soviet Army. An important element within this overview was the author's coverage of the controversy within the German ranks of rather it should go straight on to Moscow from Smolensk or delay AGC's advance and have Guderian divert to Kiev to relieve flank pressure before moving on the capital.Mr Glantz covers the actual historiography in some detail on the advantages and disadvantages of taking Kiev first before moving on Moscow but then only briefly states the general reasons why going straight on to Moscow in late September when the Western Front was preparing defenses was the wrong strategy and gives little hard core numbers or other facts to support this contention. You are to accept his word as accurate during the narrative though some of his supporting material can be found in the Endnotes but it can be a trying process to navigate for the casual reader.The author's presentation of the Kiev first strategy may be more convincing to hardcore contrarians if a credible scenario could have been developed showing the Moscow first strategy failed worse than the Kiev first strategy. The scenario would begin showing 2nd PzG defending near Roslavl through 9/10 and launching with AGC toward Bryansk after Timoshenko canceled his offensive. The time sequence of this new scenario would be somewhat different than actual history due to different launch times and locations, strength status, defense preparations and deployments as well as different reinforcement schedules and weather etc.The conclusion was short but credible and was the glue that binds this book together. It started by explaining why the Soviets were completely unprepared for the invasion: the recent purges, poorly trained soldiers, inexperienced officers, inadequate defenses at the new border and obsolete weapons and equipment. Mr Glantz proceeds to list the many strategic mistakes Stalin and the Red Army made in the opening months. Then a list of changes the Stavka started to implement to improve their Army that would eventually lead them to be the equal and then surpass the Wehmarcht is provided.On the German side, a concise discussion of Hitler's changing objectives of Operation Barbarossa that would delay the advance of Moscow and cause friction within the Army is prominent. The author expands this train of thought to briefly describe the difficulties AGC would have had if it did advanced past the Desna River toward Moscow in September without ever sending Guderian southward. The chapter was concise and covered the key points but greater depth of the existing points (as mentioned above  would have made the book more compellng.There are eight useful B+W maps that show the general deployments and axes of attack that complement the narrative well. Since this is not a tactical reconstruction like the author's Barbarossa Derailed series or his Stalingrad series, the author didn't feel it necessary to have many maps.The Notes Section is very useful and provides a lot of secondary information if you take the time to study it. The included Appendix has Orders of Battle and key documents like Hitler's Directive 34 and 35 to study. A Bibliography and a few photos are included as well.As a summary, I gave this book five stars for it covered the necessary points to argue his position that despite the early successes, the Germans were unable to defeat the Soviets while they were vulnerable and that in a long war of attrition, Germany couldn't defeat the larger, improving colossus that was the Soviet Army.Though enjoying the book and freely recommend it, I found myself and suspect other enthusiasts of the Eastern Front will want more after finishing the book. The author's new book, "Barbarossa Derailed" does add to the key points of this book in a limited fashion and is also recommended as is Bryan Fugate's "Operation Barbarossa".

I bought this to replace the worn out lint screen in my Fisher Paykel dryer.  My original screen was plastic, but the screen that I received is a metal mesh.  In reading other reviews, it sounds like both metal and plastic screens are being sent to customers, so if this matters to you, then check with the supplier.  I have had both types and I really don't think that there is a big difference.  This fit perfectly in my dryer and it works well.  I paid about thirty five dollars which, to me, seems expensive for what you get.  That said, I did shop around and could not find it for less.

I am not a photographer.  I bought this to add light to objects I was photographing in a table top photo dome.  It is a very nice set of lights.  I like that the cords are long and they have a switch on the cords.  There are carrying cases for the tripods which detach from the light fixtures.  There is no case for the light fixtures, so I just put them back in the box.  At full extension, the tripods raise the lights to about four feet high.  The base of the tripods are not very wide.  I like this because they don't get in the way, but it does feel a little unstable when at full extension.  The light bulbs provided cast a nice natural light.  The whole thing came packed very well.  I paid about forty dollars which, to me, seems like a good value.
I use these with my Stanley Light Duty Staple gun.  It is a great assortment for a variety of basic projects you would have around the house.  For the price, it is a good value.

I have had this for about a month, and it is working great.  It is a nice, basic coffee maker with a few features at a nice price.  The display is lighted which makes it easy to read.  There are settings for coffee strength and how hot you want to maintain the warmer.  It's programmable and has a sturdy feel to it.  The coffee tastes great and for the price, it is a good value.

This is a pretty basic three tier jewelry display.  The three tiers are nice since they hold a lot of items and can accommodate various lengths.  The "leatherette" feels like plastic on a fabric base.  I paid twenty eight dollars with free shipping, and this arrived in good shape.  I am thinking about getting another one for my children to display their Rainbow Loom bracelets.

This works very well on materials such as paper and labels.  It is easy to use and the retractable blade is made of stainless steel.  I am using the perforating blade.  The edge has remained sharp, and it makes a nice perforation.  You can also buy replacement cutting wheels if needed.  The cutting wheel is 28mm in diameter and 0.3mm thick.  I don't have the exact dimensions, but it makes a cut about 6mm long and then a space of about 1mm.  Be careful to use a cutting mat so as not to damage surfaces.

This is mostly a good deal, but there are some negatives.  On the plus side, if you purchased all of this track separately it would cost about two hundred seventy dollars.  So, you are getting a bit of a discount on the track.  Also, Lionel FasTrack is a nice track system.  It snaps together easily and looks good.  Some say that it is a bit on the loud side, but to me, it is fine.  On the negative side, this layout requires about 8.5 by 4.5 feet of space.  Most people end up putting layouts on 8 by 4 sheets of plywood, so this would require a odd size table.  You could reduce it in size by replacing a 10 inch track on each side with a 5 inch track and it would then fit.  As is, this is just track without a transformer.  If you are buying a transformer, you would need at least a CW-80 to power this.  If you already have a set that came with a basic loop of track, then you are better off buying the additional track to make this layout separately.  If you are trying to expand a basic loop of track, then instead of this, consider getting the figure 8 pack and then add a few switches to make a siding or two.

I put these casters on a small toy train table that we push out of the way when not in use.  The casters are solid and roll well.  The bracket fits well on the 5/8" frame.  The bolt provided slides through one side and screws into the other.  I had a hard time drilling a hole that lined up perfectly on both sides. Once I had these attached, I was happy with how they performed.

I was looking to expand my basic Lionel set and bought this because it reminds me of a Frisco Boxcar I had in the 1960s.  This is 10.5 inches long with operating couplers.  The trucks are plastic and they work fine.  The color is a bit more yellowish than the picture.  This version of the Frisco boxcar came out in Lionel's 2014 "Ready to Run" Catalog.  It is O-Gauge and can run on tight curves like O-27.  It is considered to be part of Lionel's Southwest Regional Freight cars.

Adding a Lionel water tower is a nice way to add scenery to your layout.  Lionel has many versions of this water tower (different paint jobs) so take a look at the other versions before picking one.  I like this, but it is a bit pricey for what you get.  It is plastic and is about 13 inches tall.  Also, this needs to be screwed down to stop it from falling over. There are two holes in the base for this purpose.

I found this to be helpful for setting the wheel gap to the recommended distance and for getting the axles in straight.  You can go to abc-pinewood-derby dot com to see the instructions on how to use this.  I found it worthwhile to sand the axles smooth, add some graphite and then use this to install the wheels and axles.  Once installed, spin the wheels for a few minutes to let the graphite work in.  Then push the car across the floor to see if it goes straight.  If it doesn't, then twist each front axle slightly with a needle nose pliers to see if that corrects the alignment.  Add some weight to the back of your car to get it up to 5oz, and you'll have a competitive car.
My wife is Swedish, and I got her this as a gift.  She loves it and says that the attire is very accurate. She likes it so much that she has it on display in the box.

We bought this for our children to play along to music on the radio.  Overall, they like it, and it is helping them develop a sense of rhythm.  Most of the triangles on Amazon in this price range are similar.  Each leg of this triangle is a about six inches long and the striker is also six inches.  Six inch triangles are pretty light so they tend to spin and swing, but that is expected for this size triangle.  Overall, triangles come in different sizes - 4, 6, 8, 10 inches are common.  For little children, this is a nice size.  The striker is just bent metal without a handle, but that is pretty typical for smaller triangles.  We like to use a variety of items as strikers since that is what produces different sounds.  For example, knitting needles or wooden spoons.  If you can buy this in the five to seven dollar range, then it is a nice way to encourage children to participate in music.You might also consider the "Lyons 25 Note (G-G) Bell Set with Case" which typically sells on Amazon for twenty dollars.  For about twelve dollars more than the triangle, you can get a nice, tuned, entry-level xylophone.

There are several lengths of Fastrack. The most economical in terms of cost per inch of track is the 10 inch track. However, there are times when you want to adjust your track in less than 10 inch increments. For that, Lionel sells Fastrack that is 5 inches, 4.5 inches, 1.75 inches and 1.375 inches. Using different combinations of these allow you to construct sections of Fastrack that are almost any practical length. All of these look the same and snap together the same way.  The 1 3/8" track also has jumper cables and a split rail.  This is helpful for making a siding for a second engine that you do not want to be powered.

There are several lengths of Fastrack.  The most economical in terms of cost per inch of track is the 10 inch track.  However, there are times when you want to adjust your track in less than 10 inch increments.  For that, Lionel sells Fastrack that is 5 inches, 4.5 inches, 1.75 inches and 1.375 inches.  Using different combinations of these allow you to construct sections of Fastrack that are almost any practical length.  All of these look the same and snap together the same way.

We bought a few switches to make our basic loop more fun. The switch comes with a quarter turn piece of track. You can change the side that the switch post is on from the left to the right. This is helpful since the post can get in the way on some layouts. It is well built and trains make it smoothly across the switch without derailing. They are a bit expensive, but it makes your train set more fun. Be careful when ordering because there is a left hand and right hand switcThe red switch post that you turn to open and close the switch can break. If this happens, you can buy a replacement post. To remove the old post, pull straight up on it. Then push the new post into the place. I agree that Lionel needs to make these stronger. The replacement part number is 6102017094 RED SIGNAL LEVER / FASTRACK MANUAL SWITCH. It costs less than $4 and you can buy it at a hobby shop or Lionel sells replacement parts at lionel dot com.One last recommendation which has nothing to do with the switch - to make your set more fun consider adding some 1:43 scale cars, fire engines, buses, trucks, etc. Just search Amazon for 1:43 diecast. This scale is about the same as O-gauge and you can find some fun items at a reasonable price

This is worth about five dollars so if you can find it for that, then it's worthwhile.  All the parts are made of foam except for the scarf which is thin plastic.  It comes with little pegs to attach things.  The picture on the box way over exaggerates what this really looks like.  We ended up using wire ties to hold the mittens onto two sticks that we used for the arms.  We built a snowman today, and it was fun adding these.  So, if your expectations aren't great, and you can get this for a respectable price, then it's OK.

The towel is 100% cotton and is 28 x 58 inches.  The weight seems similar to other beach towels (lighter than a bath towel).  The graphic on the front is just like the photo, and it is white on the back.  I paid about fifteen dollars for one beach towel plus shipping.  Sometimes this is sold as a two pack for around thirty dollars.  Check the description to see if you are getting one or two towels.  My son really enjoys Sonic so he takes this to the pool, but he also likes using at home.

First off, note that this has the small 2.5 mm plug.  3.5 mm is probably the most common size so be careful to order the correct size.  This is a very basic head set that works well for talking on your cell phone.  There is a little clip on the microphone that you can attach to your shirt or the seatbelt if you are in your car.  There is no volume control or on/off switch.  This is adequate for listening to music, but I would not recommend it for that purpose.  The size of the ear piece seems to be about the same as other head sets I have tried.  I paid about four dollars plus free shipping.  For the price, it is a nice 2.5 mm replacement headset.

The shirt is 100% cotton and is medium weight.  The image is exactly the same as that shown in the photo.  So far it has held up to washing.  I honestly don't understand the popularity of Breadfish, but I got this for my teenager, and he really likes it.

Lensed in 1971 at the beginning of the Grindhouse Exploitation boom of the '70s, BLOOD AND LACE makes its way to us in a beautifully restored DVD/BluRay combo courtesy Scream Factory. The presentation deserves more merit than the film itself--the parts definitely greater than the sum.Teenager Ellie Masters (Melody Patterson, F-TROOP) is sent to an orphanage after her promiscuous mother and Mom's trick of the hour meet their maker by way of a nasty hammer bludgeoning, seen through a lengthy POV camera shot. Vic Tayback (ALICE) plays the detective working the case and Milton Selzer Ellie's hospital case worker. 1950s Film Noir Queen Gloria Grahame takes the role of the widowed Mrs. Deere who runs the orphanage with an iron fist and Len Lesser (SEINFELD) plays her boozy right-hand man. Mrs. Deere is a conniving witch who has some secrets in the attic and others in the deep-freeze in the basement.Despite an intriguing premise, the movie never lives up to its' potential. There's a mishmash of ideas that don't quite gel together; the direction is flat like a Made-for-TV movie and some of the acting by the teenage orphans is substandard. Patterson is especially shrill and unlikeable and Tayback lacks the gruff bearish persona we all know him for on ALICE. Still, it's one of those cult titles that people seem to love despite the problems.Scream Factory has given us a beautifully restored print. The title card however reads THE BLOOD SECRET which is actually a more appropriate title and the discs are in widescreen but have been cropped at the top and bottom. I posted some comparisons in the IMAGES section from my old VHS copy and this new release.Not as gory or sleazy as it should've been and some bad acting taints it overall, but worthwhile for seeing Grahame slumming it and some early work from Tayback and Lesser.

**NOTE: This review had to be re-worded in order to meet Amazons strict guidelines**Set in a small backwoods town, THE FARMERS DAUGHTERS opens with the local sheriff enjoying some afternoon delight with his pie-baking wife (Gloria Leonard credited here as Gale and easily the best thing about this picture) while his three curious, horny daughters spy on them from outside. Local goon Fred catches the girls in the act, and for this transgression is bound, gang-assaulted, humiliated and the lucky recipient of a three-head, warm amber shower.Meanwhile, three cons have escaped from the nearby prison seeking refuge at the farm where they proceed to have their way with Gloria and force the daughters into a fellatio and back door orgy culminating in the convicts giving them amber showers (Karmas a bitch, isnt it?) at gunpoint. Fred comes to the rescue, but because hes not one to easily forgive-and-forget, the girls and their parents are forced to commit perverted acts of inter-family relations until the explosive climax (PUN INTENDED).A dirty and grimy experience complete with excruciating close-ups of pubic hair, ugly bodies with appendicitis scars, grimacing female faces registering the pain of being rear ended, this definitely NOT a date movie. This is quite the raunch-fest and the fact that the picture hasnt really been cleaned up for DVD release is actually appropriate considering the sleaziness of the film itself. If youre drunk, watch it with a few friends for a good laugh at what your parents or grandparents porn was like.

Being a fan of 70s Grindhouse flicks, I could easily oversell this dud by telling you it features a deranged butcher-knife-wielding transvestite, lots of gay subtext, psychedelic camera tricks during the murder sequences, copious female nudity, geriatric junkies and a do-it-yourself Caesarian section. Tempted? Dont beMARTHA is so flatly directed and shot and devoid of any real suspense or sleaze and scored in such an incongruous fashion the whole thing comes across more like a demented episode of THE DORIS DAY SHOW or any other innocuous single camera TV sitcom from 1971.**MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD**Shacked up together in suburban Florida, Paul the older of the two (and a dead ringer for Andy Kaufman) dresses up in drag as Aunt Martha to reckless Stanley (who looks pretty long in the tooth for eighteen; but that may be due to all the coke he snorts with bodacious blonde Barbara Eden-wannabes). The two are on the lam for a robbery/murder that the drug-addled Stanley committed in Baltimore.Pauls cross-dressing isnt of the twisted PSYCHO sort; hes just trying to stay under the radar and its played more for comedy as he resembles those 1960s and 1970s character actresses such as Maudie Prickett or Priscilla Morrill with the sensible shoes and frumpish frocks he dons for the charade. Its quite the bizarre sight seeing the hirsute and shirtless Paul character pace around the house still in skirt and lady-loafers with his hairy chest exposed while chomping on a cigar, all man from the waist up with grandmotherly lower half.Stanley seems to be all for peace, drugs and free love yet weirdly freaks out and calls for Paul every time a member of the fairer sex attempts to get into his pants. There is an ambiguity to their relationship as the two are seen sleeping in the same bed and its never made clear whether Pauls possessiveness of Stanley is jealousy or protection. The nudity is far from titillatingone drugged-out dancing girl has repulsive breasts that look like shriveled turnips.The restoration of the film print is minimal; there are still issues such as interlacing and burn marks throughout but the picture looks much better than it did on VHS or Youtube.If youre a fan, you will want it for the improved video quality and the commentary, otherwise theres not enough of anything (its not creepy enough, sleazy enough, suspenseful enough or funny enough) to make it enjoyable for fans of 70s Exploitation. TWO STARS.

Ace Records knocks it out of the park again with another Lesley Gore remaster, this one boasting the original ten tracks from 1967s CALIFORNIA NIGHTS album plus a whopping ELEVEN Bonus Tracks from the albums MY TOWN, MY GUY AND ME (1965) LESLEY GORE SINGS ALL ABOUT LOVE (1966).Though this LPs title track reached #16 on Billboard (and was a bigger hit in Canada) and proved she was moving forward as her 1963 contemporaries the Beach Boys had done, radio did not embrace the artistic evolution of Lesley Gore. Its a mystery as to why because this material was up-to-date at the time and there was plenty of missed opportunities for singles from the groovy, frenetic, hand-clap heavy British-flavored OFF AND RUNNING to the slow, sorrowful CRY LIKE A BABY (not the Box Tops hit) with lots of tambourine and fuzz guitar. Lesley uncharacteristically snarls her way through THE BUBBLE BROKE which is refreshingly darker than anything she had done before.Among the best of the Bonus Tracks from 1965-66 are the bouncy MY TOWN, MY GUY AND ME which is like a fast-paced DOWNTOWN while the soothing and heavenly LET ME DREAM and ONLY LAST NIGHT also have much in common with Petula Clarks output during this time. The Sesame Street producers apparently stole their theme song sound from START THE PARTY AGAIN; I WONT LOVE YOU ANYMORE (SORRY) has a lush sound awash with strings, speaking of which Lesleys spectacular version of the Teddy Bears TO KNOW HIM IS TO LOVE HIM is just as great as the 1958 original and features a spine-tingling string section. I JUST CANT GET ENOUGH OF YOU and YEAH, YEAH, YEAH (THAT BOY OF MINE) are fast-pumping, playful songs reminiscent of Jay & the Techniques' "Apples, Peaches, Pumpkin Pie" that feature great backing vocals.Sound quality is of course excellent and the material is wonderful and definitely better than whats found on the subsequent MAGIC COLORS Deluxe CD.

Liberty Records in Canada released this compilation in 1985 to cash in on Tinas big PRIVATE DANCER comeback and at the time it served its purpose well: to give younger fans who were just discovering Turners talents a condensed musical backstory of her work with Ike in the 60s and 70s by way of the following ten tracks. Aside from the classics PROUD MARY and RIVER DEEP, MOUNTAIN HIGH the other standouts are the gritty A FOOL IN LOVE and soulful take on LETS SPEND THE NIGHT TOGETHER. The album contains a re-cut, updated version of RIVER DEEP so Liberty Records could not get the copyright to use the original 1966 version.Side 1:PROUD MARYI WANT TO TAKE YOU HIGHERNUTBUSH CITY LIMITSA FOOL IN LOVELETS SPEND THE NIGHT TOGETHERSide 2:RIVER DEEP, MOUNTAIN HIGH (new version)HONKY TONK WOMENOOH POO PAH DOOBABY, GET IT ONGET BACK

DIANA ROSS & THE SUPREMES SING MOTOWN. The title says it all. In 1985 the 60s Renaissance was in full-swing and Motown was packaging and repackaging their back catalog in innumerable permutations.**NOTE** The album I am reviewing contains the following songs and the cover can be seen in the IMAGES section of this product:Side One: Money (That's What I Want), I Can't Help Myself (Sugar Pie Honey Bunch), With A Child's Heart, (Love Is Like A) Heat Wave, Get Ready, This Old Heart Of Mine (Is Weak For You).Side Two: Baby I Need Your Loving, You've Really Got A Hold On Me, Come & Get These Memories, Do You Love Me, It's The Same Old Song, What Becomes Of The Brokenhearted.Not a must-have and nothing here surpasses the original versions by the Four Tops, Temptations or Miracles. The best numbers are MONEY, (LOVE IS LIKE A) HEAT WAVE (Ross surprisingly really lets loose and tears into thisnot as good as Martha does, but stillgive credit where credit is due), GET READY, Both BABY I NEED YOUR LOVING and THIS OLD HEART OF MINE are given more upbeat arrangements with the latter complete with signature Supreme handclaps probably the best track here and the former gets some interesting guitar work from Marv Tarplin. COME AND GET THESE MEMORIES offers Mary Wilson a rare lead vocal and you can really hear Florences strong backup on DO YOU LOVE ME where Diana shows some real attitude on the tell me and watch me nows.I admit I was probably more enticed to buy this back in 1985 because of the cool pastels cover rather than the content but this is one I didnt dare donate to the thrift shop because some of the material here is better than certain songs that have appeared on anthologies, MOTHER DEAR for example.

The best numbers are MONEY, (LOVE IS LIKE A) HEAT WAVE (Ross surprisingly really lets loose and tears into thisnot as good as Martha does, but stillgive credit where credit is due), GET READY, Both BABY I NEED YOUR LOVING and THIS OLD HEART OF MINE are given more upbeat arrangements with the latter complete with signature Supreme handclaps probably the best track here and the former gets some interesting guitar work from Marv Tarplin. A curious artifact more than anything else, LOVE ME BY NAME dares to show a different side of the former Queen of the Teen Weepers, but after listening to this album a dozen times I still dont know exactly what she or producer Quincy Jones were going for here. Theres a common celestial vibe that runs through most of whats here. The title track is a strange hybrid of space-age jazz, while the hyper PARANOIA comes off as something that was cut from THE ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW although Lesley does spit out the lyrics convincingly enough. IMMORTALITY tries to be both futuristic and retro and echoes First Class hit single BEACH BABY on the chorus. Both GIVE IT TO ME SWEET THING and CANT SEEM TO LIVE OUR GOOD TIMES DOWN suit her voice better and would not have been out of place on her prior album.A lot of the material seems a mismatch for Lesley and nothing here shows off her vocal abilities in their best light. Both her 1972 album SOMEPLACE ELSE NOW and 1982s THE CANVAS CAN DO MIRACLES are much better than this oddity from the mid-1970s so avoid paying the high prices this album is commanding on various auction sites.

Even though none of Lesley's signature tunes appear on this album, GIRL TALK is most representative of the girl-group pop sound with which she is so synonymous and on the whole is the best album of her career IMO. The Ace Records remaster sound amazing and is the way to go since it contains 13 Bonus Tracks! A few of her second-string hits appear on this disc, "Maybe I Know" (my personal favorite song of hers), "Hey Now" and the original version of "Look of Love without the Christmas bells.The best thing about this disc is that there are some delightfully moody numbers here such as "Little Girl Go Home", "Say Goodbye", "I Don't Care", and especially the gritty, pessimistic "I Cannot Hope for Anyone". It's refreshing to hear Lesley display such attitude on these hidden gems. Anyone who liked Patty Duke's gloomy "Don't Just Stand There" will love these!Other highlights are the dramatic and slower "Don't Deny It; the Phil-Spectorish "I Died Inside" which is driven by lively castanets; "Moving Away" somehow transcends its simplicity and cuteness (it doesn't hurt that the background vocals are superb); "You Didn't Look Around" combines a myriad of '60s musical styles. It has twangy Ventures-type guitar, blaring "Bend Me, Shape Me"-type horns, Four Seasons/Angels' clomp-clomp rhythm/handclaps as well as the charming triangle from Lesley's own "It's My Party". This everything-but-the-kitchen-sink approach actually works much better for this song than it sounds on paper.Lesley sounds refreshingly sassy on fare like "Sometimes I Wish I Were a Boy" and "Wonder Boy (which shares the same beat as the Vandellas' "Heat Wave) proving she wasn't all sugar and spice. It should be noted that the mix of "I Just Don't Know If I Can" which sounded rather muddy with Lesley's vocals somewhat buried on the Big Bear box set has been rectified and can be heard in all its 1965 glory along with What Am I Gonna Do With You.Lastly, the fierce "No Matter What You Do" was a real departure for Lesley; a loud psychadelic-sounding/soulful rocker thats like a hybrid of Jefferson Airplane meets Aretha Franklin and proves that her range had widened greatly since her debut album just one year prior.This is the best Lesley Gore album there is, Buy It Now and if you own a previous version, upgrade to the new Ace Records remaster because these songs have never sounded better. FIVE STARS.

Lesley Gores debut album contained too many standards and wasnt totally representative of the pop music sound of 1963, but such isnt the case for the sophomore effort LESLEY GORE SINGS OF MIXED UP HEARTS. This one never lags and the production is flawless and chock full of winners including three well-known hit singles. The sound on the Japanese remaster is incredible. The background vocals, handclaps and piano on the Top Five smash SHES A FOOL are more clear and audible than ever before and the hit single SUNSHINE, LOLLIPOPS AND RAINBOWS also appears here as well as the timeless classic YOU DONT OWN ME in a spine-tingling crystal-clear mix (the mono version has appeared on various previous releases).The bouncy, irresistible "Hello Young Lover (You Ain't Gonna Get My Heart)" which shares the same beat as "It's My Party" and sounds like it would be right at home in one of those old Elvis or Ann-Margret movies sounds ten times better here than it does on the 1994 Big Bear box set from Germany. The song is so wild and infectious I can't help but imagine Candy Johnson frugging up a frenzy in one of those '60s Beach Party movies--amazing the label never released it as a single.I Struck a Match basically steals the plot of "Party"--but manages to be great in its own right; "The Old Crowd"; "Consolation Prize"; "Run, Bobby Run" and "If That's the Way You Want It"--all of these are pleasant, lightweight pop songs about teenage love and heartache--Lesley's specialty and all have never sounded better than they do now.I still say GIRL TALK is Lesleys best album overall but this one runs a close secondget it!

This CD by WMO (Wonderful Music Of) is composed largely of mono versions and I recommend you skip this one and go for the Ultimate Petula Clark CD by BMG Heritage. It features the cover photo of Petula sitting on a rock by the water barefoot. The sound quality on that collection is amazingmuch better than whats found here. It is only 2 dollars more and you get 21 tracks versus the 16 here. The only difference is that this one contains Pets version of THIS GIRLS IN LOVE WITH YOU which does not appear on the BMG CD.

With a premise tailor-made for AHS, Season Fours FREAK SHOW stills brings the thrills and chills but unfortunately an early demise of the seasons creepy killer, an underwhelming finale and some sloppy writing and clichd storylines hold back what could have been perfection.Set in 1952 Jupiter, Florida in a travelling sideshow, Miss Elsa Mars (Jessica Lange) acts as surrogate mother to her little monsters who inhabit Elsas Cabinet of Curiosities, but she also has designs on a show-biz career like Marlene Dietrich and resents anyone stealing her spotlight. This allows for some anachronistic musical numbers to appear as well as songs on the soundtrack such as David Bowies FAME. Hearing these as well as a performance of Nirvana by Evan Peters take the viewer out of the moment. The same thing happens when the writers carelessly slip in some crass hip-hop speak (who was saying Im trying to get a nut back in the 50s when referring to sex???).The season is somewhat of a homage to Tod Brownings FREAKS with several plot points liberally borrowed from the 1932 horror classic and many real-life human oddities among the cast to give it authenticity. It would not have worked as well without them and all do an admirable job. Most of the repertory players are back with Angela Bassett a standout as the sassy hermaphrodite (sporting an Ethel Mertz hairdo) and her strongman husband (Michael Chiklis) has one of the more interesting arcs this season. Frances Conroy does what she can with her limited role as a rich widow with a deranged, spoiled son (Finn Wittrock) and has the best line of the season when she tries to calm one of his violent rages by offering We can play June Allyson paper dolls. Kudos to the special effects department and Sarah Paulson as they have the difficult task of bringing the Siamese Twins Bette and Dot to screen with a premise much more difficult than the old Patty Duke doubles trick.The kills are some of the most wonderfully gruesome this show has seen, and juxtaposed with the bright, squeaky-clean image of the 1950s the images are doubly disturbing. There's some flashback footage to 1930s Berlin in which Miss Elsa is filmed performing acts of depravity which is truly unsettling as well as a flash-forward to 1962 that cleverly ties into ASYLUM featuring a cameo by Lily Rabe as Sister Mary Eunice and a chilling performance by Mare Winningham as evil personified.A tighter finale would have served the season better but theres still plenty of creepy enjoyment to be had in AHS: FREAK SHOW. Four Stars.

If David Lynch and John Waters had teamed up to make a porn flick in the 70s, this is what the end result would probably look like. Filmed in glorious black-and-white and possessing a weird dreamlike atmosphere and long-winded soliloquies mixed with full-on graphic intercourse, "Thundercrack" is like nothing you've seen before. It takes the old horror film cliche of disparate travellers becoming stranded in a mysterious old house and not only turns it on its' ear--it knocks it on its' a** and penetrates with everything it's got!! Horny gorillas, pickled bodyparts, blow-up dolls, vomit-encrusted wigs,  "Thundercrack" will blow your mind!!For years, the copies being sold here were bootlegs and the quality is what you'd expect from 2nd or 3rd generation VHS dubs. Synapse Films has been working on a fully-restored, 180-minute director's cut for some time and its taken forever since (as one of their reps stated) "this thing looks like it was shot on toilet paper".Finally, just scraping under the wire to be released in time for its 40th Anniversary, comes a restored BluRay release with the Bonus Features fans have been dreaming of for years including outtakes and audition footage. I ordered mine direct from their website so hopefully it will arrive early and I will post screen grabs and comparisons here but if you love offbeat cinema and weird 70s Exploitation flicks, this one is a MUST-HAVE on day of releaseget it!!

I just wanted to comment that I bought my set new from a seller on the worlds largest Internet auction site and all four discs played perfectly so maybe those with glitches were all from a bad batch that Amazon received.That being said, DONT TRUST THE B is okay but doesnt merit repeat viewings. Its like a mean-spirited, 2010s female version of THE ODD COUPLE but cruder with bathroom humor, sexual innuendo and fast-paced silliness that has nothing to do with reality and makes the show feel like a live-action cartoon with its fast pace and quit-cut editing.The cast are fine with Dreama Walker playing the chipmunk-cheeked idealist June new to New York and sharing an apartment with the tall, angular selfish party girl Chloe (Krysten Ritter) and James Van der Beek playing a self-absorbed parody of himself.THREE STARS.

1982s SO EXCITED is a bit of a comedown for the Pointer Sisters from their last few albums as much of this material is subpar compared to what came before. HEARTBEAT and HEART TO HEART TALK are pure filler and the lackluster I FEEL FOR YOU pales now that everyones more familiar with the bombastic Chaka Khan version. Even though AMERICAN MUSIC enjoyed some minor chart success, its blandness has made it one of those lost 45s.Despite the average numbers, the scorching IF YOU WANNA GET BACK YOUR LADY more than makes up for those and justifies the purchase of this CD even if the rest of it were garbage. LADY is the Pointers best dance number ever, besting even everything on the BREAKOUT album. Other winners include the forbidden love triangle saga SEE HOW THE LOVE GOES with its slightly ominous chords; ALL OF YOU with the smooth and simmering verses bursting into a rousing chorus and of course the original rendition of the timeless IM SO EXCITED.An okay album overall but not as good as some of their others. THREE and a HALF STARS.

Sonically, this reissue from Big Break Records is probably the best sounding of all their Pointer Sisters remasters. The clarity jumps right out at you from the opening notes and Latin percussion of SWEET LOVER MAN.In 1981 the musical landscape was populated by Adult-Contemporary and Country Crossover acts such as Sheena Easton, Air Supply, Ronnie Milsap, Christopher Cross and Hall & Oates and this album takes a soft-rock/AC approach and less R&B than 1980s SPECIAL THINGS yet its never boring. On the lite AC numbers such as SOMEDAY WELL BE TOGETHER (not the Supremes hit) or GOT TO FIND LOVE the girls harmonies are as sweet as ever. Also, just try and sit still during the boppin TAKE MY HEART, TAKE MY SOUL or doo-wop throwback SHOULD I DO IT or not sway and sing along with their smooth Top Five smash SLOW HAND from Fall 81.FALL IN LOVE AGAIN is a throwback to the previous decades grittier soul sound; WERE GONNA MAKE IT is a breathlessly fast-pumping pre-Flashdance number and the slower, sultry WHAT A SURPRISE is probably the highlight of a truly wonderful album. Bonus Track HOLDING OUT FOR LOVE has a Ray Parker, Jr. vibe.A rock-solid effort from the Pointers; just make sure to splurge for the superior-sounding Big Break Records release and you can imagine sitting right in the studio with them while they recorded this.

What a difference a year makes! While only released twelve months before 1978s stellar ENERGY album, The Pointer Sisters 1977 HAVING A PARTY album is stylistically worlds away from its follow-up and is recommended for completists only,This is the last album Bonnie recorded with her siblings before embarking on her solo career and her vocals dominate much of this material. All the songs also go on much too long to the point where they wear out their welcome and sometimes it gets to the point where it seems the Pointers have been asked to join in on a jam session with the band going on and on and the girls just trying to endlessly ad-lib to keep up with them (most obvious on the jazzy BRING YOUR SWEET STUFF HOME TO ME).Though recorded in the latter part of the Me Decade, much of this album sounds like a throwback to the early 1970s R&B sound. I NEED A MAN, though one of the stronger, more memorable offerings, would have been right at home on the soundtrack of SHAFT or any Blaxploitation flick with its chunky guitars and sassy ghetto vocals. The other standout is the slinky DONT IT MAKE YOU CRAZY which is driven by hypnotic bassline.Other than those, the rest of the album is forgettable and can be skipped without missing much. Its definitely NOT worth the exorbitant price the import CD is commanding. TWO and a HALF STARS.

Overproduced and much more dated than Contact or Hot Together, much of this material would be fine for the upstart divas of 1988 such as Pebbles or Paula Abdul, but it comes off as rather cheap and juvenile for established vets like the Pointers.  This is especially true of Flirtatious, the title track Serious Slammin, as well as Shut Up and Dance the latter two lacking in good hooks or melody.The slick dance production comes off much better on the catchy He Turned Me Out and both Pride and Uh Uh, two really punchy, assertive tracks. There are some other highlights here and they include the beautifully moody and laid-back Moonlight Dancing and the closer I Will Be There which starts off unassuming and gradually builds to a memorable declaration of loyalty with explosive synth accents. My Life is inexplicably recycled, remixed and included from the last album (but to be fair this version is superior) and the lone ballad Im In Love has Ruth on lead.The production here is typical late 80s: brash, cluttered and overpowering but there are enough good numbers to still make it a worthwhile purchase for Pointers fansits just not one of their better albums or up to the standard of Energy or Breakout.

A commercial disappointment when released in late 1986, The Pointer Sisters HOT TOGETHER boasts some of their sassiest, sexiest material in retrospect and is definitely worth dusting off nearly three decades later. I do recommend shelling out for the Big Break Records release that contains the Bonus Tracks though because while 12 mixes could be superfluous back in the 80s with nothing more than a minute or less of extra instrumentals, the longer versions here of MERCURY RISING and GOLDMINE as well as the remix version of MY LIFE definitely pack more muscle than the originals with thicker percussion that sounded more tinny on the album.The best tracks are the slick MY LIFE and title song HOT TOGETHER, infectious GOLDMINE (their most underrated song ever), MERCURY RISING (remember how standoffish they were to their lovers advances on FIRE? Well, MERCURY is the flipside with the ladies now trying to quench an insatiable romantic appetite) as well as the gorgeous ballad ALL I KNOW IS THE WAY I FEEL. The remainder of the original album is mostly composed of very dated-sounding filler with SAY THE WORD and SET ME FREE being the best of the bunch but they too are mostly generic and forgettable.Like 1982's SO EXCITED and 1988s SERIOUS SLAMMIN, this is not one of their very best albums, but it does grow on you with repeated spins and contains some of the best songs in their catalog.

The extended mix of I CAN'T STAND THE RAIN only adds a little bit of extra instrumental at the beginning, otherwise just stick with the album version from "Private Dancer". I bought this back in the '80s more for the flipside, Tina's cover of the Prince tune LET'S PRETEND WE'RE MARRIED, which totally rocks in this live version.

E.G. Daily is the daughter of actor Bill Daily (Major Healey on I DREAM OF JEANNIE and Howard Borden on THE BOB NEWHART SHOW) and released her debut album in 1986. Not sure if Daddy used some of his residuals to help finance this venture, but Elizabeth Ann was able to secure some of the hottest producers in the music biz at the time (Jellybean Benitez and Harold Faltermeyer, among others) and the result is an overlooked, professional, polished album that deserves more credit than it got.The cute and infectious single SAY IT, SAY IT inexplicably only reached #70 on the Billboard Singles Chart, though it did make #1 on the Dance Chart. It certainly deserved better as being a Jellybean production it has the same appeal as Madonnas early singles. Theres a cover of SUNSET PEOPLE on which Ms. Daily almost holds her own against Donna Summer. LOVE IN THE SHADOWS is another highlight and E.G. comes across like a young Pat Benatar with a touch of Kim Carnes trademark rasp on the spunky cuts WAITING, IS ANYBODY HOME and DONT LET THEM TAKE THE CHILD AWAY.Make no mistake, despite the fact she was a looker, E.G. Dailys WILD CHILD album is no piece of kittenish fluff like her contemporaries Stacey Q or Regina. This material has much more depth and more in common with Patty Smyth/Scandal and Laura Branigans up-tempo tunes than with the disposable Madonna-Wannabes of the mid-80s.Retro radio needs to be unearthing music like this instead of playing GIRLS JUST WANNA HAVE FUN or HOLIDAY for the zillionth time.FOUR STARS.

If the album and single version of Janet Jacksons NASTY was too sparse and stark for your listening tastes, then the Cool Summer Mix is the version for you. Not only is there some added percussion, extra keyboard riffs and background keyboards added, but there is sampling of WHAT HAVE YOU DONE FOR ME LATELY and some other experimental sounds on this version (squeak toy sounds among them) that fans will love as well as a cool echo effect.  I just dug out my old vinyl 12 and it sounds just as cool in 2015 as it did nearly 30 years ago.

At a full nine-minute running time, Dead or Alives fall 1986 release of the 12 version of BRAND NEW LOVER: The Dust Monkeys Love Bubble Mix is not only their crowning artistic achievement, but its also the pinnacle of the Hi-NRG movement pioneered by Stock, Aitken and Waterman and gets my vote as the best extended mix of the entire 1980s dance music landscape.I remember seeing this in the record store in October 1986 and grabbing it sight unheard and hoping it would be as good as the previous singles from YOUTHQUAKE which was a pretty tall order consider how fantastic those extended mixes were of SPIN ME, LOVER COME BACK, and MY HEART GOES BANG.From the opening notes to the second when Petes voice began stuttering back and forth between my speakers I knew this one was going to be explosive. In fact, the opening instrumental salvo is the best part of the song, with the classical violins soothing the ears only to be shattered by that musical c*mshot of electric guitar solo. When the song finally does start, the melody and lyrics are much more substantial than SPIN ME, yet not at the expense of its danceability.An intoxicating dance-floor masterpiece and again, the best Hi-NRG song ever made, ahead of everything else by DOA, Divine, Hazel Dean, etc.

Ive never been one for ghost or haunted house stories, but American Horror Story draws you in with its intricate plotting, surprise twists and excellent cast. I began with Asylum, which was great, so I didnt expect that this debut season would live up to that, but it did. The goings-on in this show are just CRAZY and you watch it like a train wreck, mesmerized by all the chaos. The writers rarely tip their hand, so the twists are not telegraphed, though the clues are all there beforehand, so the audience has no reason to feel cheated.Jessica Langes character is so mysterious, yet likeable, you cant wait til she appears onscreen again. The show is full of accomplished actors, young and old who all really sell this material. Its like a great combination of those 70s psychological thrillers like Burnt Offerings crossed with Desperate Housewives, yet too competent to qualify as a guilty pleasure.

Let me preface this review by stating I normally have no interest in movies and programs that deal with zombies, witches, vampires and the like. Ive never seen an episode of The Walking Dead or True Blood but a colleagues recommendation prompted me to check out American Horror Story and having read the synopses of the series so far, I decided Asylum would be the best place to start since the premise sounded the most intriguing (well, at least since S4 isnt available to purchase for another two months).From the creepy David-Fincher inspired opening credit sequence I was hooked and although the season borrows elements of everything from Texas Chainsaw Massacre to Silence of the Lambs and The Exorcist to Close Encounters of the Third Kind, everything works. The storytelling overlaps and flashes back and forth in the timeline but the program is cohesive. The cast are terrific and its great seeing former Six Feet Under alumni Frances Conroy (as a creepy yet beautiful Angel of Death) and James Cromwell (in a deliciously wicked role) reunited onscreen. Sarah Poulson and Evan Peters will have you rooting for them all the way and Lily Rabe reminds me so much of a young Julia Duffy.But its Jessica Lange who steals the show. Kudos to Ms. Lange for not falling victim to the Hollywood vanity trap of Boxtox injections and facelifts to maintain an illusion of youth. Theres no way she could have pulled off the complex role of Sister Jude/Patient Judy if her face was unable to register the range of emotions required. Its because of her I am now working my way through Season One and will eventually get around to seeing the rest.

Following the breakout success of their hit single FIRE, 1979s PRIORITY album was somewhat of a commercial disappointment for the Pointer Sisters. Perhaps the problem was that this album was not diverse enough to please a broad spectrum. Instead its a collection made up entirely of Bluesy Rock that paints that gals as a female version of Grand Funk Railroad or Bad Company. Not that they arent up to the taskon the contrary, the girls tear into this testosterone-charged material like Ian Hunters WHO DO YOU LOVE, Gerry Raffertys BLIND FAITH and Bob Segers ALL YOUR LOVE with ball busting vigor that rivals Linda Ronstadt, Bonnie Tyler or any of the other lady rockers of the time. Like their previous album ENERGY, the material consists largely of cover versions of established acts and writers, but the Pointers totally make them their own.Graham Parkers TURNED UP TOO LATE, The Rolling Stones HAPPY,  Springsteens SHES GOT THE FEVER and Robbie Robertsons THE SHAPE IM IN all get a female makeover to great effect and IMO the albums best moment comes when the gals warn DONT LET A THIEF STEAL INTO YOUR HEART which is like the female answer to the Eagles WITCHY WOMAN and has the same sinister vibe.Those who are only familiar with NEUTRON DANCE or JUMP may find this album too abrasive but for those who are interested in how masterful the Pointers were in conquering the traditionally male-dominated arena of Blues-Rock, PRIORITY is quite the revelation.FOUR STARS

On MEETING IN THE LADIES ROOM and KLYMAXX the group had cultivated a sound that was all their own. There was no confusing them with contemporaries such as The Pointer Sisters, Mary Jane Girls or The Flirts. Not so on THE MAXX IS BACK on which the production is no different than anything at the time of Bel Biv Devoe, Pebbles or Johnny Gill. This monotonous sound is a large reason why I loathe the R&B and Dance music to come out of the early 90s for the most part and why this album largely fails IMO. Its in my music collection because Im a completist but this is one of those CDs that sits alone at the bottom of the pile largely ignored.On the title track, they sing about returning with a new identity, the same old savoir faire but nothing could be farther from the truth. This album is little more than generic beats, annoying, cluttered (now terribly dated) 90s production and lackluster songwriting with no ear-catching melodies or clever hooks or diva anthems like THE MEN ALL PAUSE, SEXY or FASHION. Even the lyrics this time are trite and the girls seem to be coasting or just filling an obligation to the label. The fact the group has been whittled down to a trio may also have been a factor. Whatever the reason, the magic is gone.The slinky groove GOOD LOVE and sexy slow jam WHEN YOU KISS ME are probably the best of the bunch but that isnt saying much when even the filler tracks on their first two albums (songs like I BETCHA or DANGER ZONE) are still ten times more original and memorable than whats here. SHES A USER is the closest thing to past glories but as the last track, its a case of too-little-too-late.A few of the high-powered hip-hop tracks like GIRLS CHASING BOYS and DONT MESS WITH MY MAN just go on and on like endless unnecessary noise and FINISHING TOUCH is so over-syrupy listening to it more than once may cause cavities.Its too bad this comeback album is such a mess but it only makes MEETING IN THE LADIES ROOM and KLYMAXX all the more valuable as 80s R&B/Dance classics. I wish we could have had a third jewel from these ladies but alas, this album isnt it.

1978's ENERGY album is where the Pointer Sisters career finally picked up steam as producer Richard Perry helped sharpen their overall sound with a collection of material that showcased their diversity and let their harmonies sparkle (not to mention the band is incredible).Big Break Records have done a wonderful job remastering almost the complete Pointers' catalog and this is undoubtedly their best album of the '70s which is surprising since it almost entirely contains cover versions of songs recorded earlier by famous artists (and not just because it contains their first really big smash single, the timeless FIRE, penned by Springsteen). ENERGY features material from prolific songwriters such as Kenny Loggins, Bob Welch and Russ Ballard previously recorded by The Doobie Brothers and Fleetwood Mac among others but the Pointers totally make these tunes their own.My favorites here include their cover of Steely Dan's DIRTY WORK that features incredible spine-tingling harmonies and outshines the original; the thumping and infectious HAPPINESS should have been a huge Disco hit; the sultry grind of the aptly-titled HYPNOTIZED (much better than the Fleetwood Mac version) will do just that to your brain.Both the rocking LAY IT ON THE LINE and ANGRY EYES are a precursor to the kind of abrasive, harder material that would compose almost the entirety of their follow-up album PRIORITY in 1979, which does showcase their versatility but is not as diverse an album.I'm not so fond of the slower numbers such as Stephen Stills AS I COME OF AGE (great harmonies though) and the Sly and the Family Stone cover EVERYBODY IS A STAR but I'd rate this album 4 1/2 stars overall and well-worth getting as it's their best of the '70s.**There are 3 Bonus Tracks: NOTHING BUT A HEARTACHE is not noteworthy; LOVE IS LIKE A ROLLING STONE is another gritty number that would have fit well on PRIORITY and there's a 12' Disco Version of HAPPINESS that is a welcome addition.

Though Disco was a dirty word in 1980, the tainted genre's patron Saint, Miss Donna Summer managed to score a Top-Five hit early in the year with "On The Radio" which not only was the theme song from the Jodie Foster film "Foxes" but also the title of her best-selling Greatest Hits package. By the fourth quarter of 1980, it was time for another studio album from Summer to hit stores and that effort was "The Wanderer". Treading carefully to ensure this album would not immediately fall victim to the cut-out bins due to the Disco backlash (see Sister Sledge Love Somebody Today), the album is given a more pop-rock feel overall but still retains some Disco overtones as not to alienate those who fell in love with Donna's music in the first place. The result is a well-produced, varied effort that actually sounds better today than it did at the time.The title track went Top Five in November 1980 with the help of Giorgio Moroder whose production gives Summer's vocal a unique echo/reverb. "The Wanderer" the single also frames verses with some coarse guitar licks to balance out the techno aspects and give this one more radio-friendly sound than the hypnotic club anthem "I Feel Love". "Cold Love" was the second single which inexplicably bombed in early 1981, despite it being one of Summer's best performances on record and a perfect example of why she could have easily attempted a full album of rock-oriented material. The third single also failed to make big dent in the charts. "Who Do You Think You're Foolin" along with album cuts "Looking Up", and "Breakdown" employ a danceable pop-rock sound that continued throughout the first half of the '80s on which others such as Laura Branigan based their entire careers.The remainder of the album contains the eerie, futuristic synth number "Grand Illusion" which is made all the more hypnotic by Donna's high-pitched vocal; "Running For Cover" has a slick, sophisticated urban opening before breaking into a fast tempo for the rocking chorus making it the most musically ambitious cut. Fans of Disco Donna will love "Nightlife" which echoes the thumping percussion of "Hot Stuff" and "Bad Girls"; "Stop Me" is another musically ambitious effort that sounds very '60s bubblegum on the verses then rocks out on the chorus. "I Believe in Jesus" closes the album, and while I have nothing against Gospel, the melody isn't very catchy and arrangement just isn't exciting enough. Still, this remains a personal favorite of mine and sadly underrated album of Donna's. I prefer this over any of her 1970s efforts.FOUR STARS

The title track of Carole Pope's latest EP paints a vivid picture of the goings-on at the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival and be warned folks--some of it ain't pretty as Carole tells us in spoken passages.Yes, it's explicitly blunt, but Carole fans wouldn't expect anything less, would we? Those who prefer the beautifully poetic lyrical content of the "Transcend" album may be turned off by the coarseness but unless you're a novice Carole fan, you should already know what to expect.FOUR STARS--nowhere near her best work; but it's a grower and it's catchiness will etch itself into your brain after a few listens with it's tribal bongo drums, whistling chorus, handclaps and climactic rap courtesy of Peaches. The complete EP features three other songs and is available exclusively on CD from Carole's website.

Boasting the same production values and sound as her landmark album "Broken English", Marianne Faithfull was worthy of commercial success in 1981 with the equally stellar but more radio-friendly "Dangerous Acquaintances". Seriously, the upbeat numbers on this album are so chock full of killer hooks, if they had been recorded by a more conventional female vocalist, we'd still be hearing them on radio today. But Marianne is anything but a sell-out and I'm glad these remain hidden gems.The punk-reggae sound that worked so well on "Why'd Ya Do It" gets some variations on the terrific opener "Sweetheart", which sets the tone for whole album. When Marianne cries "My freedom means too much to give up now" she sounds more apologetic than threatening. This album is not as acidic and nasty and pessimistic as "Broken English" but it's not Sheena Easton either.Horns and sax contrast the weary, depressed vocals on "Intrigue"; there's a Motown vibe that comes through with all the tambourines and handclaps on "Tenderness"; the simmering "Easy in the City" is easily the most infectious number; while the sinister guitars of "Eye Communication" contribute to the stalkerish feel. The funky '70s "Brother Louie"/"You're No Good" sound works well on "Strange One" which finds Ms. Faithfull's lover with a boyfriend of his own; she's at her most plaintive and introspective on "So Sad" and "Truth, Bitter Truth".I tend to think of this album as "Broken English"-lite. It's a more upbeat Marianne and a terrific follow-up to her masterpiece. The Japanese remaster is definitely money well-spent.FIVE STARS.

Kim Carnes' "Lighthouse" was released in 1986 and was her swan song for EMI records. The In-your-face World Beat vibe that appeared on the previous album is toned down though it's influence is there, but subtler on "Divided Hearts" and the uplifting "Dancing at the Lighthouse". The production is still loud and brash but not as cluttered as it was on "Barking at Airplanes". Actually, the production often exceeds the songwriting (the fast-driving "Love Me Like You Never Did Before" and "Only Lonely Love" and mid-tempo "That's Where the Trouble Lies").The high points are the kickass, infectious, bluesy rocker "I'd Lie To You For Your Love" (one of Kim's best album cuts ever) with screaming '80s guitar solo; the sultry, sax-driven "Black and White"; the beautifully simplistic and forlorn "You Say You Love Me (But I Know You Don't)". The remainder of material isn't quite as good: the Springsteen-esque "Piece of the Sky"; and bland "Along With the Radio".Worth getting for several of Kim's best songs ever and a step up from the "Barking at Airplanes" album. Probably my favorite Carnes album after "Cafe Racers".FOUR STARS

While "Barking at Airplanes" is a come-down from 1983's stellar "Cafe Racers" LP, it does have its' moments. The production is loud and cluttered as was the norm around 1985-86. This is most evident on the single "Crazy In The Night" and "Don't Pick Up The Phone" (which borrows the melody from 1982's "Take It On the Chin" to better effect). The shouting male chorus is prevalent on both of these. "One Kiss" is kind of bland; "Begging For Favors" on the other hand, is one of Kim's best album cuts ever with the melody and dirty little sax licks giving the song an appropriate seediness that matches the lyrics. There's a primal, World Beat vibe on several cuts here: "He Makes The Sun Rise", the bouncy "Abadabadango" and Calypso-flavoured "Touch and Go". Both the plaintive "Bon Voyage" (interesting echo on the vocals) and "Rough Edges" are synth ballads with the latter almost a prototype for Cyndi Lauper's "True Colors" while "Oliver (Voice on the Radio)" seems like a retread of 1982's "Breaking Away From Sanity".FOUR STARS. Not Kim's best but worth it for "Begging For Favours" and "Crazy in the Night".

Kim Carnes' 1983 "Cafe Racers" is arguably the high point of her career. After the synth-heavy, aggressively '80s "Voyeur" album, this one has a more organic, accessible pop sound with flawless production and perhaps the best songwriting ever heard on a Carnes' album. Which makes it all the more tragic that Kim was unable to mine any hit singles from it. There are at least FOUR songs here that should have made a dent in the Top 40. Perhaps it was lack of promotion, or the oddly unflattering album cover; in any case, if you pick one album of Kim's to own, make it this one.You Make My Heart Beat Faster (And That's All That Matters) - Terrific pulsating opener with an unforgettable hook; wonderfully infectious earwormYoung Love - Tic-toc percussion on the gloomy verses gives way to dynamic rock/new wave chorusMet You at the Wrong Time of My Life - Percolating, wistful Adult Contemporary numberHurricane - Fluttery synth and handclaps accompany disquieting melody and lyrics; should have been a big hit singleUniversal Song - An uplifting, almost-classical number with tic-toc percussionInvisible Hands - Fast-pumping, synth-pop with an incredibly contagious hook; another missed opportunity for radio; the most-'80s sounding offering hereI Pretend - Mid-tempo, laid back AC number; another terrific hookHangin' On By a Thread - Simple piano ballad that lasts just long enough (2:46) to not bore or slow the album down too muchA Kick In My Heart - Yet ANOTHER melody that will stick in your head for days in this mid-tempo gem with slight Country-Rock influence that seemed tailor-made for AC radioI'll Be Here Where The Heart Is - Pretty ballad with rock guitar and keyboard to spice it up but the album's weakest cutFIVE STARS...Buy This Now!

Kim Carnes' 1983 "Cafe Racers" is arguably the high point of her career. After the synth-heavy, aggressively '80s "Voyeur" album, this one has a more organic, accessible pop sound with flawless production and perhaps the best songwriting ever heard on a Carnes' album. Which makes it all the more tragic that Kim was unable to mine any hit singles from it. There are at least FOUR songs here that should have made a dent in the Top 40. Perhaps it was lack of promotion, or the oddly unflattering album cover; in any case, if you pick one album of Kim's to own, make it this one.You Make My Heart Beat Faster (And That's All That Matters) - Terrific pulsating opener with an unforgettable hook; wonderfully infectious earwormYoung Love - Tic-toc percussion on the gloomy verses gives way to dynamic rock/new wave chorusMet You at the Wrong Time of My Life - Percolating, wistful Adult Contemporary numberHurricane - Fluttery synth and handclaps accompany disquieting melody and lyrics; should have been a big hit singleUniversal Song - An uplifting, almost-classical number with tic-toc percussionInvisible Hands - Fast-pumping, synth-pop with an incredibly contagious hook; another missed opportunity for radio; the most-'80s sounding offering hereI Pretend - Mid-tempo, laid back AC number; another terrific hookHangin' On By a Thread - Simple piano ballad that lasts just long enough (2:46) to not bore or slow the album down too muchA Kick In My Heart - Yet ANOTHER melody that will stick in your head for days in this mid-tempo gem with slight Country-Rock influence that seemed tailor-made for AC radioI'll Be Here Where The Heart Is - Pretty ballad with rock guitar and keyboard to spice it up but the album's weakest cutFIVE STARS...Buy This Now!

Madonna's "Rebel Heart" is a mixed bag, but a step-up from 2012's "MDNA". First, the bad: the Electronica thing has been done-to-death since 1998 and that, along with the lyrical religious references have become beyond tiresome. Don't even get me started on the vocoder. A lot of the songs are overproduced but not to the extent they were on "MDNA". The absolute low point comes in the downright embarrassing, ultra-hyper "Bitch, I'm Madonna" where she tries to convince us how badass she is by employing hip-hop speak and yet another unwelcome guest appearance by the execrable Nicki Minaj. I guess if Minaj had to appear it would make sense that she show up on this unlistenable turd of a song which makes "Gimme All Your Luvin'" sound like "Ray of Light" by comparison.The good thing is that the songwriting is better than it was on the last album for the most part and there's an attempt at making a more diverse-sounding collection of songs for "Rebel Heart". The piano used on "Living For Love" gives the song a much-needed organic slant before the sick beats kick in on an album opener that is just the kind of irressistible dance number about spiritual empowerment that embodies everything Madonna (it helps that the song is everything "Gimme All Your Luvin'" WASN'T). The reggae-tinged "Unapologetic Bitch" scores points for originality; Madonna channels her inner coffeehouse chanteuse in "Body Shop"; there's the unique militant/gospel fusion of "Heartbreak City", a stark confession of vulnerability in "Joan of Arc" and the understated "Wash All Over Me".Of the Bonus Tracks; the winners are the sultry "Best Night" with it's Middle-Eastern flavour and spoken passages reminiscent of "Justify My Love"; the clever, lyrical checklist of past hits makes the self-reverential "Veni Vedi Vici" fun instead of what could have been annoyingly narcissistic. (Though it could do without the Nas rap at the end). There's an irresistibly moody piano riff (shades of Eminem's "'97 Bonnie & Clyde") and hypnotic bassline that drives the cheeky "S.E.X" (which is like the musical equivalent of "50 Shades of Grey"); and the charming and folksy ode to self-acceptance and title track "Rebel Heart" inexplicably didn't make the cut for the official album.The rest of the album offers nothing particularly noteworthy and is no better than anything she's done since "Confessions". There are no instant classics like "Vogue" or "Hung Up"-esque earworms. This is an album I will use for mind-numbing workout music more than anything else, but I will give her points for better songwriting on some tracks than we saw on "MDNA". This would be a stronger effort if the Bonus Tracks had been made part of the official album with weaker tracks like "Bitch, I'm Madonna" deleted.All fans will have their favorites here, but IMO this would rate Five Stars if the album had been composed of these 11 songs:Living For LoveDevil PrayVeni Vidi ViciUnapologetic BitchS.E.X.Joan of ArcHeartbreak CityHoly WaterGhost TownBest NightWash All Over MeThree-and-a-Half Stars.

How do you follow up one of the biggest singles of the 1980s? Well, apparently not even a unique, gifted songstress like Kim Carnes had the answer as she was never able to recapture the success of "Bette Davis Eyes" although her subsequent albums proved she was hardly a Flash-in-the-Pan. It's just too bad the average listener was robbed of hearing her efforts on Top 40 Radio.This album's first three offerings ("Voyeur", "Looker", "Say You Don't Know Me") as well as "Undertow" are quite sinister-sounding and the title track/lead single may have been too dark for Top 40 Radio explaining why it failed to rise beyond #28 here in the fall of 1982. "Say You Don't Know Me"--the best of the four--is a great fusion of Rock and New Wave with a sax solo and hypnotic tic-toc percussion. "Does It Make You Remember" is an amazing power-ballad in Diane Warren mold that should have been a big hit. A child's chorus appears on "Breakin' Away From Sanity" to give the piano ballad some added flavour; Kim channels her inner '80s-metal-chick on "The Arrangement"; "The Thrill of the Grill" is a straight-ahead fast rocker; "Merc Man" will make you want to put on your leg warmers and Flashdance t-shirt and twirl around the room. The closer "Take It On The Chin" has a melody that was reworked for 1985's "Don't Hang Up The Phone" to better effect."Voyeur" was the first album Kim recorded in the official MTV era and the synth-heavy production reflects that, so if you are a fan of her Country-Rock sound, this album likely won't be to your tastes, but the songs contain memorable hooks and this is as equally as good as "Mistaken Identity" and is a warm-up for some of her best work that came in the next two albums she released.FOUR STARS.

Of all Kim Carnes' albums, this one took the longest to grow on me, even though it was her best-selling and contains her signature song. The indelible keyboard riff from "Bette Davis Eyes" and Kim's trademark raspy vocal made it one of the biggest singles of the decade and is still well-loved and remembered nearly 35 years later.The synthesizers on this album bring a new dimension to the Country-Rock numbers and give them an '80s touch, though "Hit and Run" is oversung by both Kim and the backup singers and suffers for it. Conversely, "When I'm Away From You" is pure perfection with a terrific reverb-guitar solo.The lite-jazzy title track has Kim delivering a pensive, wistful vocal as she prepares herself to close the door on a dead-end relationship, while "Break The Rules Tonight" is a wonderfully brash, head-bopping, rousing roadhouse rocker. "Still Hold On" is an achingly desperate ballad with pretty chimes and another highlight is the simple synth-pop "Don't Call It Love" which recalls last album's "More Love" right down to a sax solo but this one's got a little more bite.The album's second single "Draw of the Cards" remains an oddity with Kim doing little more than chanting and shouting random bizarre phrases over a percolating, airy keyboard backing track and hypnotic, ominous bassline. The remaining cuts are the ballads "Miss You Tonight" and "My Old Pals" of which the former is the better of the two built around a synth backup and the latter is straight piano and the album's weakest link.While it contains her biggest hit, this album is not Kim's best effort overall. "Cafe Racers" and "Barking at Airplanes" are better albums, but if you aren't a big fan of the MTV-era synth sound, you will probably like this one better than those.FOUR STARS

Australia's Raven Records gives us a 2-for-1 in this release that contains Kim Carnes' first two albums: 1979's debut "St. Vincent's Court" and the 1980 follow-up "Romance Dance".The first album is heavy on late '70s Country-Rock and Kim comes off little more than a Linda Ronstadt imitator on several cuts ("What Am I Gonna Do", "Jamaica Sunday Morning"). At the time, Kim hadn't yet fully developed that trademark rasp and at times she doesn't even sound like the Kim we know and love. She sounds like Toni Tennille on "Paris Without You", and Nicolette Larson on the jazzy, infectious "Skeptical Shuffle". The bass-driven, laid-back "Lookin' For a Big Night" is a highlight and Kim's rep as the "female Rod Stewart" is never more evident than on the bluesy "It Hurts So Bad". The rest of the first album is not bad but is quite forgettable.The second album kicks off with much more energy in the Rod Stewart-esque "Swept Me Off My Feet (The Part of the Fool)" which is like the female version of "Maggie May" and arguably the best cut included here. The two covers of '60s chestnuts "Cry Like a Baby" (The Box Tops) and "More Love" (The Miracles) also fare very well with the latter making a dent in the Top 40 during the summer of 1980 although it deserved to be a bigger hit than it was. Special mention also must go to the kickass country-rocker "Tear Me Apart" which Kim rips into with great gusto and to "Where Is Your Heart" because it's synth-heavy chorus foreshadows the musical direction Kim would take on her next album.This CD would play better if the best numbers from both albums were combined into one having weeded out the filler. For completists and a decent listen; just not as good as her '80s output. For a better representation buy "Cafe Racers" or "Barking at Airplanes".
