Perhaps I am biased since I've loved every one of Mink Stole's scene-stealing antics in all those John Waters movies, but I really like parts of this oddball album. This is one of those CDs that's great to have in the car to keep you amused during a traffic jam. It's unpredictable, diverse and for the sheer audacity of embarking on a singing career in her 60's, Mink should be commended.Though Mink's voice is too soft and fragile and lacks power (her version of Divine's "Female Trouble" done in light jazz-style lacks bite), she surprises every so often by lashing out on a song like "Born of a Restless Spirit".Cher's "Bang Bang" is covered in French and though I can't understand a word she's saying, Mink sells the song with a passionate delivery. "Thank You Baby" is a quirky cross between Helen Reddy and Spanky McFarlane and the lyrics are unintentionally hilarious (or are they?). Mink sings it so straight I can't tell if she's kidding or not.My personal favorite here is the blissfully forlorn and moody ode to her hometown "Baltimore" (written by and recorded in 1977 by Randy Newman--Mink's version is better) with an arrangement full of doom-and-gloom but other bright spots are when Mink channels Blondie circa 1977 on the fast-pumping "Waiting for the World to Catch Up" or does her best Astrud Gilberto impression on "Sometimes I Wish I Had a Gun". Mink does a terrific take of "No Nose Nanook" from "Vice Palace: The Last Cockettes Musical" which is a hybrid of Eskimo folk song and Broadway showtune.I'd rate this CD higher, but Mink's cover of Lyle Lovett's "If You Were to Wake Up" ironically has the opposite effect on me as does the duet with Arty Hill "Yours and So Am I" or the jazzy "What Can I Say After I Say I'm Sorry".Thought not for everyone's tastes. this album is a gas--so many absurd moments--intentional or not; but I give her credit for trying. Thanks...love you Mink!

I'm a ginger fanatic and have tried almost every ginger ale and brew on the market. At first, Bruce Cost Ginger Ale has a nice, crisp, clean taste. You can see the real flecks of fresh ginger floating in it, and it's clearly supposed to be an elegant, elevated soda both by taste and by virtue of only having four simple ingredients. But it is lacking in carbonation and a bit watery, especially as you near the bottom. By the time I got to the last few swigs, the chunks of ginger kept getting into my mouth and were totally gross. So don't try to drain the bottle! Where Bruce Cost Ginger Ale really lives up to its name is it "costs" more than any ginger ale on the market. Too bad it's not worth it. For my money, the best ginger ale is made by Maine Root. That stuff has bite! By bite, I mean you can feel the ginger burning all the way down, and it's spicy as hell delicious.

Let me begin by saying I own all the sets and most of the Promo Cards. I am a huge Dominion fan and avid player for five years now. This ninth expansion set is the best and worst of Dominion in one box. I do NOT recommend it be the first one you buy (try Seaside or Prosperity instead, then Dark Ages or Hinterlands). I say that because some of these cards are quite complicated and fiddly with a fair number of annoying new rules to remember. That's true of any expansion, but seems to be amplified here.My biggest complaint is the horrible cheapness of the new cardboard tokens. They are ugly, amateurish, and feel like they belong in a different game. Definitely NOT up to the same standards as the metal Victory tokens and gold coins of previous sets. With the exception of the tavern mat, the images are all too dark and tiny to read well, and the text (although easy to read) is weirdly right justified. These poor quality tokens are a cheapskate, rip-off move by Rio Grande Games who are usually much better at including quality components than this. I have never been more disappointed with this game than these new tokens.Now, on to the rest of my review: There are a lot of new cards of all prices, some quite fun, some not, and some so weirdly complicated, I can't be bothered to learn them. There are more orange Duration Cards (first introduced in Seaside), including ones that last the entire game once played. These seem too powerful, even at a cost of 6. Example: Hireling lets you draw 1 extra card per turn, every turn. I'd call this a 7 or 8, but it only costs 6.A new type of card is the Reserve Card, which goes on your Tavern Mat when played, then may be "called" into your hand on a subsequent turn to produce a secondary effect without costing an action. These are quite handy. The problem, like any cards that are set aside, is remembering to use them.There are two sets of Progression Cards that act as pseudo-adventurers you can upgrade all the way from a cost of 2 to 6, and each time you do, you swap out your current card for its next one up the chain. Each card has different powers, but the best are of course saved for the permanently put into play final upgrades that cost 6 and are super-powerful, including the Champion, which grants you +1 action every time you take an actionmeaning you can always play every action card in your hand. Oh yeah, and you're immune to attack cards too!So you can see there's a lot of interesting stuff going on with the new cards for the supply piles, but the super-star of this set are the new oversized Event cards, which do not form a supply pile (there's only one of each event). Instead, they stay in play all game and available to buy their effect just for that turn by using one of your buys on them. Examples include getting +2 Buys and place one of the gained cards on top of your deck, or placing a -2 cost token on one of the supply piles so that future purchases of it by you cost 2 less. You generally use one or two Event Cards per game, and these really change how the game is played. They breathe new life into the game and are the best possible way to get this game back on the table if your group has grown tired of it after all these years. Note that the Event Cards are of the same high quality as the rest of the cards (it's only the new tokens that have the quality control issues).By the way, the new regular cards and Event Cards are easily integrated with the previous sets, so you can mix-and-match things however you want. This has always been one of Dominion's greatest strengths. I'd like to issue a warning that the example set up games they included are horribly designed and not much fun, but that's been a problem in the past too. Just pick cards randomly and you'll probably create better, more balanced set-ups without even trying. And don't play with too many of these new cards in any one game or you'll go nuts remembering all the new rules.To sum it up, if you're already a Dominion fan, you're going to want this, and even the horrible cheapness of the new tokens shouldn't stop you from buying it. But if you're new to Dominion, save this purchase until well after you get a few more expansions sets.

An astronomer and a handful of former green berets discover the government is covering up a massive asteroid strike that will hit North America in 90 days. The asteroid will kill 90% of the population when it strikes and create a nuclear winter from the resulting dust and ash in the atmosphere. There is nothing that can stop it. The berets purchase a decommissioned missile silo and set about stocking it with supplies to survive 18 months underground. They also invite 50 people (mostly single mothers and their kids) to join them to give the human race a chance to survive. Meanwhile, the world outside descends into chaos, turning all "Mad Max" with warlords taking over and turning to cannibalism to survive (hence the book's title).I listened to the audio book and enjoyed it. The narrator was good and production level excellent. As for the story itself, it was pretty good, but the prose (though well-written for a first novel) was a bit dry and took forever to get to the apocalypse. The asteroid didn't even hit until near the end of Disk 4 (of 12), which is way too long. On the other hand, once I resigned myself to the fact that this was the direction the author wanted to go, I began to appreciate the level of detail he put into how the decommissioned silo was being set up, stocked, and populated: who and what was chosen to survive in the shelter and why. I liked Jack, the main character and commanding officer, for his confidence and sense of humor, as well as his vulnerable streak.Cannibal Reign takes a more thoughtful approach to how the apocalypse would go down than the cheesy B-movie title would indicate. This is both its greatest strength and weakness, because it didn't match my expectations. So in some ways, I got more than I paid for, and in other ways, I got less. With a more serious, less exploitative title, I may have had fewer issues with the long, drawn-out beginning of the book that was firmly stuck in "prepper" mode. Then again, without the gory title, I might never have picked it up in the first place. It definitely jumped off the shelf at me. It isn't really a horror book though, despite some of the horrific things that happen in it.The one thing I hated about the book was the code-breaking sections, where huge chunks of code were thrown at me in the most boring, obnoxious way possible. These seemed to drag on forever. I fast-forwarded past them, much like I skipped past all the boring cathedral-building architecture descriptions in The Pillars of the Earth by Ken Follett. Nobody reads these kind of books to get that level of academic detail. We signed up for action and adventurean interesting insight into other people's livesnot a cryptography lesson.Another, lesser issue was the sprawling, split-nature of the story. While the majority of the book focuses on the Green Berets and missile silo, some chapters spend time on other characters in different parts of the country. Yes, these characters all meet up with the Green Berets sooner or later, but it made the story seem a bit bloated. In other words, it messed with the pacing.Overall, I liked Cannibal Reign because the author tried to do something a bit different while still hitting a lot of the "check boxes" fans of the post-apocalypse genre want.

I really wanted to like this book more, but found Peter Rabe's writing too cold and detached to get into. Noir should be white-hot, desperate, doomed, and sexy. All I got out of these stories was desperate and doomed. They take way too long to get to the action, and without an engaging femme fatale, fall flat in the sexy department. I've read a lot of Rabe's Gold Medal contemporaries like Gil Brewer, Bruno Fischer, David Goodis, Jim Thompson, etc., and managed to enjoy them even at their worst. These two novels (The Box and Journey into Terror) are supposed to be Rabe at his best. Not a good sign. That said, they're certainly readable, but I don't get how anyone could put Peter Rabe in the same class as the other authors I mentioned. This book does include three different bios of the author that I found more interesting than the actual novels.Also, the Stark House version I got had one of the worst, most amateur-painted covers (not shown in this listing), poor cover and interior design, and plenty of embarrassing typos. Not sure if they cleaned it up for whatever version they're selling now (with the boat on the cover), but I doubt it. Stark House does a good job finding rare noir but a poor job presenting them (although the bonus author bios are always a nice touch).

I never played Descent, but everyone else in my group has, and this is basically the same game with a Star Wars theme added on. It plays like a role-playing game without any role-playing, just co-op tactical miniature battles. It is similar to the old WotC Star Wars Minis in this regard, but better--except that game had prepainted minis, and a lot more to choose from. The minis in Imperial Assault are clearly superior in detail, but unpainted.Unlike Star Wars Minis, where you can just throw any old map down and start fighting, Imperial Assault's set up takes forever and is confusing with all the tiles to choose from, especially since you can't organize them numerically in the box (this is due to the radically different sizes involved).The quality of all the components is excellent, very sturdy, from the minis to the map tiles to to the little punch out damage and condition tokens. We did find it impossible to completely assemble the AT-ST Scout Walker, however. The laser cannon under its "chin" won't fit no matter what we do, and we're afraid of breaking it if we try to force it any harder. Other than that one problem cannon, the AT-ST snaps together no problem.We played two games, the basic "learn how to play" scenario, and the first adventure in campaign mode. Campaign mode gives you better abilities and the chance to earn money from completing missions to buy cards representing better weapons, armor, or equipment. This is fun and allows you to customize your character, similar to leveling up in Dungeons & Dragons.You begin play as either a melee combatant (like a jedi) or a ranged combatant (like a stormtrooper), but with campaign mode, you can add ranged or melee weapons and powers. You need a mix of ranged and melee types to win. Jedis are good, but not too unbalanced against non-jedi. I played a Rebel sniper and kicked plenty of Imperial butt with my blaster rifle. A third type of character you can play (the officer) isn't great at any kind of fighting, but excels at giving bonus actions to others in the group (like Grand Moff Tarkin in Star Wars, or the warlord class in Dungeons & Dragons). Everyone enjoyed their roles. It did seem like the clock running down and a lack of focusing on mission goals and teamwork was a far bigger threat than any of the Imperial forces we encountered. Not that the Imperial player didn't have nasty surprises in store for us, but the nastiest of these were environmental (like putting force fields around key computer terminals we needed to destroy) than actual bad guys. Maybe they get tougher later on...It takes a roughly 2 hours to play each game. I enjoyed it and would play it again. Imperial Assault does a good job evoking the Star Wars theme, and is a fun co-op experience.

Finally got to play this after waiting fifteen years due to disappointing reviews and high cost. I would say the poor reviews are justified.CON's: The game is unbalanced initially in Japan's favor so it's absolutely no fun for the Allied players (especially poor India/Australia), and then it becomes unbalanced in favor of America thanks to its enormous income. They can replace an entire fleet in a round or two, whereas Japan is doomed if it loses that many ships.Also, it becomes impossible for the Japanese to conquer either India or Australia against a decent, experienced Axis & Allies player if that player uses most or even all the British convoy money for building stacks of infantry in India, and again in Australia (when threatened). Maybe it's not broken, but it's not a lot of fun either.The 40+ page rulebook lacks an index, so it's a pain to look stuff up, even though it's decently organized.PRO's: The new rules for combat air patrol, air and naval bases, Japanese destroyers acting as 1 infantry transports and allowed shore bombardment, along with the two-hit battleship, are all welcome additions, as are the USA marine units and kamikaze rules.The quality of the pieces and board are there.NEUTRAL: The only player who can build new factories in this version is USA, which kind of sucks, but also makes the game more challenging.The game takes forever to set up and break down, but that's the way this series has always been, so it's no surprise here. Expect half an hour of set up time, with an average play time of eight to twelve hours or more if you want to go to the bitter end. (Note: In my test game, the Japanese player conceded after five-and-a-half hours [about four or five rounds]. I would say most of the fun we had was from socializing rather than playing the game. It was a 3-player game with two experienced Axis & Allies players as Japan and India/Australia, with a war game newbie playing China/USA).This game is worth playing once if you're an Axis & Allies fan, but seems pointless to own. I can't see it ever hitting the table more than that. It completely lacks the magic and fun of the original game and the Europe edition.There is a new second edition of Pacific available that hopefully corrects some of these flaws, but I haven't played it.

The hilariously creepy nutcracker box screams, "Buy me!" Unfortunately, what's inside is basically just glorified trail mix without the raisins, not the amazing sense of "Wow!" proclaimed on the box. It's an OK product, but super-crunchy and a bit too salty and not chocolaty enough for me. The size and contents of the snack clusters varies wildly and that means you may get zero chocolate, or only a single chip per snack cluster. In my opinion, they need to up the chocolate ratio slightly (by at least +10%), because when I see the word "chocolate" on the box I expect to get some in every bite. Adding raisins could also help the sweetness factor.Snacklemouth was certainly cheap enough at my local food coop to take a chance on it, but I won't be buying it again. That being said, if you're a trail mix fan (I'm generally not) and your taste runs more toward salty than sweet, by all means, give this a try.WARNING: The box, while fun for adults, may frighten or disturb small children. Also, the hard, unevenly-shaped snacks inside could present a choking hazard for kids, pets, and vacuum cleaners.ALLERGEN INFO: Almonds, Soy. This is a certified gluten-free product. I didn't see any dairy listed in the ingredients either (full details provided below), but "dairy-free/casein-free" is not specifically promised on the packaging. I have both gluten and dairy allergies (as intolerances) and experienced no problems eating this product.Ingredients: Almonds, Organic Blue Agave, Dark Chocolate (contains Sugar, Cocolate Liquor, Cocoa Butter, Soy Lecithin, Vanilla Extract), Gluten-free Oats, Gluten-free Oat Bran, Brown Rice Syrup, Cashews, GMO-free Canola Oil, Sea Salt.Produced on equipment that process peanuts, tree nuts, and soy.Serving size: 1/4 cup. Calories: 140. Calories from fat: 70. Total Fat: 8g/12%. Saturated Fat: 1.5g/8%. Trans Fat: 0g. Sugars: 7g. Protein 3g. Sodium: 8%., Total Carbs: 6%. Dietary Fiber: 8%.Each box's net weight is 5.5 oz. (154g). There is one bag of snacks inside and it is not resealable, so bring your own ziploc.

Tried a two-player game and one player got all the best good cards and best bad cards to play on me. Could never catch up or hurt her flamingo production enough to make a difference. The problem with having flamingos as the scoring mechanic means the game will end suddenly and clearly, with no chance for anyone else to steal the victory from whoever is in the lead. This sucks. Also problematic in the two-player version is there are way too many trailers, so your park never gets more than half-rented to residents even if you make an effort to fill it. The rules are vague and poorly written. Too many of the cards are too complicated to remember.  The trailer cards use actual photos of real trailers and are amusing to look at, but the residents and other cards use goofy, bad art which is distracting. Not much else I can say about this game except it isn't much better with 3 or more players. It's not horrible (so I'll rate it two stars instead of one), but there are way better games out there like Ticket To Ride, Dominion, Stone Age, etc., and I certainly have no interest in playing Trailer Park Wars again.

These are the best rice cakes on the market. They're non-GMO, with no cholesterol, no gluten, no fat, no sugar--just lightly salted whole grain brown rice. They are just salty enough to impart a pleasant flavor without going overboard. The square shape is fun, and I like how they are thinner than regular rice cakes, yet extremely sturdy. They don't fall apart and sprinkle crumbs everywhere like other cakes. Not that they don't crumble a bit here and there, but there's no wholesale crumbling or breaking in half even with heavy knife pressure while spreading peanut butter, etc., and the few crumbs are small. My only complaint is I wish they came in resealable packaging.You get 27 cakes per package. A serving size of 3 cakes contain 54 calories and 30g of sodium, 12g of carbs, 1g dietary fiber, and 1g of protein.Note: This product is manufactured in Belgium in a facility that also produces products that contain wheat, milk, sesame seeds, and soy. I require a gluten, dairy, and soy-free diet and had no problem eating them. Those with basic intolerance to any or all these ingredients should be fine, but those with celiac disease or other extreme food allergies may want to exercise their standard level of caution or email the company to find out what the facility's cleaning process between different product batches is.Another quality, good-tasting gluten-free brown rice cake is Lundberg Eco-Farmed Brown Rice Cake, Lightly Salted, 8.5-Ounce Units  (Pack of 12), but they are the standard size thick disks, seem a bit heavier on the salt, and are much more prone to crumbling than these. Lundberg also makes Lundberg Organic Brown Rice Cake, Unsalted, 8.5-Ounce Units  (Pack of 12).

My kitten had IBS: chronic diarrhea and loose stool even after being dewormed, so it was a food allergy issue. I tried vet-only sensitive stomach dry food (too expensive, didn't help much), then Science Diet Sensitive Stomach dry food (cheaper), and began supplementing her diet with organic canned pumpkin to help with fiber intake. The organic pumpkin helped a lot more than the Science Diet seemed to, but the kitten still had issues. I switched to Blue Basics Sensitive Stomach and haven't had any real problems since. I kept up the pumpkin for awhile, but she is doing fine without it now, just eating Basics. It really is a miracle food. No grain, no proteins except turkey and potatoes. As someone with multiple food allergies, I know how important it is to eat the right things and what happens when I don't--I was able to solve my IBS/food allergy issues by radically changing my diet, so I knew it would work for my kitten if I could just find the right food. Blue Basics is the best on the market.IMPORTANT: Note that the other Blue Basics formulas are NOT grain-free (at least at the time I'm writing this review) and use different proteins. I tried one when my local pet store was out of this type, and my kitten instantly got diarrhea, so I switched back and she was fine again. Also, please be aware that many cats are allergic to poultry (such as chicken!) and turkey is NOT poultry, but its own type of meat altogether. That's what makes it an ideal protein.UPDATE: Bad news: As of June 2015, Blue Buffalo has discontinued this food without notice, leaving customers like me in a lurch. Good news: The first food I switched to NULO NUL DRY GF CAT DUCK 12# (Duck and Lentils recipe), was a perfect replacement for the old Blue Buffalo. It's been several weeks now and my cat hasn't had diarrhea once after the switch. I also think it's even higher quality food.UPDATE: September 27, 2015: It's been four months now since I switched to Nulo Dry Grain-Free Cat Duck Food, 5 lb and my cat's diarrhea has gone from about once a month on Blue Buffalo Sensitive Stomach to NEVER. Hooray! And the Nulo has chicken in it! My vet had previously suggested she had a chicken allergy, but I'm no longer convinced that's the case. Anyway, she loves the Nulo even more than the Blue Buffalo, and it's a super-premium, healthy food on top of stopping her diarrhea. Win-win!If you need a different choice, try Hill's Science Diet Adult Sensitive Stomach & Skin Dry Cat Food - 15.5 -Pound Bag. It worked about as well as the old Blue Buffalo, but was not foolproof like the Nulo.

Don't understand the bad review. The box I got, the cookies were in perfect condition and never fell apart, but I bought mine at a local store. Maybe the other reviewer's cookies (bought online) were damaged in shipping? The cookies were expensive, yes, but delicious. Plus, they are dense and you probably won't want to eat more than one or two at a time (you get 10 per box). They taste like "real" cookies, not gluten-free. Salty, sweet, and crunchy. Would buy again, but any seller charging more than six bucks a box is overcharging! They cost just under that at my local store, and I can get them on sale sometimes for four bucks.Calories: 120 (50 from fat) per cookie. Sodium: 130mg (5%). Sugar: 7g.Ingredients: tapioca starch, dried cane syrup, palm oil, brown rice flour, cashew pieces, eggs, tapioca syrup, toffee bits (rice syrup, palm oil, cane sugar, almonds, salt, agar gum, natural flavor), potato starch, molasses, salt, natural flavors, vanilla extract, caramel color.Allergen Alert: Contains Eggs, Almonds, Cashews. May contain peanuts, milk, soy and other tree nuts.My opinion: Probably not recommended for those with multiple food allergies or sensitivities. If other allergens are a concern, Enjoy Life makes a full line of cookies and energy bars that are free of the 8 most common allergens (including gluten). Most of them taste great too. In particular, I recommend Enjoy Life Foods - Crunchy Cookies Chocolate Chip - 7 oz..

While the flavor and texture are great, I don't really think of this as "sandwich" bread. However, slap some butter and/or honey on it and this bread makes a fantastic side dish for meals. It's moist and tasty, reminds me of cornbread.

This was not chocolaty enough and the texture was off, more cake-like than brownie-like, and not in a good way. They were edible, but not all that enjoyable. Didn't hate it, but definitely disappointed. Will never buy this product again. Vastly prefer Pamela's GF brownie mix for their flavor/texture.

Some of my gaming buddies are all hyped up about the BSG board game. They have a bunch of expansions and have been trying to get me to play it for years. OK, so I finally got suckered into it. And I was underwhelmed. It was OK--not great, and kind of boring. I am not a fan of SyFy's BSG series (preferring the 70s version I grew up on), nor do I tend to enjoy cooperative games or backstabbing games, so there was pretty much zero chance I was going to love this game. However, I did not hate it, or dislike it enough to say I'd never play it again, so three stars is fair.The problem was for the first half of our six player game, nobody was a Cylon traitor, so nothing exciting happened. Everything was way too easy. The game improved somewhat afterward, when two of us became Cylons, including me, but before I could do anything, the other Cylon, not realizing I was on his side, had me executed, then got executed himself! LOL. Even though we were both resurrected, I hardly got to do anything fun as a Cylon, but at least we were able to make the humans run out of fuel, so we won the game.Other things I didn't like were the constant voting, and trying to decide what to do on my turns (I was the Admiral, by the way). There were too many cards, too many choices, or in the case of some players like the pilots, no choice at all. Most players turns took too long, including mine. The game lasted about three hours, which my friends told me was rather short for this game! Things I liked were the cool spaceship miniatures, and overall production value of the boards and misc. components. As for the rules . . . whatever. They're OK, but a bit complicated for my taste.Note that we played with more than just the base game, including the Battlestar Galactica The Board Game: Pegasus Expansion, and maybe a few others, but I'm not sure which. These added cool Cylon basestar miniatures (the base game came with dumb tokens), and more options for the Colonials and Cylons, and these seem like a good value if you are a fan of the game.

Elizabeth Scott's The Living Dead Girl is easily one of the all-time greatest, most disturbing pieces of YA fiction ever written. Other reviews can tell you about the bone-chilling plot, etc., but I wanted to specifically recommend you get the unabridged audio book version. It is amazing, simply flawless, and the actress who performs it is absolutely spot-on. She captures the voice of 13-year-old "Alice" perfectly.Although not technically listed as YA, Megan Abbott's The End of Everything: A Novel tells a similarly haunting, twisted story, only from the perspective of a 13-year-old girl who is coping with the abduction of her best friend. Like Living Dead Girl, it is beautifully written for such a dark tale, and will stick with you the rest of your life. I also recommend you get the unabridged audio book version of Megan Abbott's book as well. The actress who performs it is great!

I've enjoyed Mi-Del's GF gingersnaps in the past, so I thought I'd give their holiday gingerbread men a try. They're pretty much the same as the regular gingersnaps, only in a fun new shape. I like the flavor well enough, but the ingredients include SOY (both flour and lecithin), which I'm allergic to--just not as bad as I am to gluten. Pretty much all Mi-Del GF products contain SOY and/or EGGS (which I'm also allergic too--again, not as bad as gluten, but which I try to avoid).Note these Canadian-made cookies are not produced in a dedicated GF facility (but it is dedicated peanut-free). The box claims GF products produced there are "routinely tested using the ELISA method to ensure there is less than 20 parts per million of gluten," so that's good.Nutrition info: A single serving size of 4 cookies has 100 calories (25 from fat), and 7g of sugar. There are about 6 servings (or 24 cookies) per box.Ingredients: GF flour (corn flour, soy flour, potato flour, rice flour, corn starch, potato starch, xanthan gum), sugar, modified tapioca starch, canola oil, unsulphured molasses, ginger, baking soda, organic caramel color, sea salt, soybean lecithin, xanthan gum.

This is the absolute best cat litter I've ever used and would never, ever, go back to using any other. I used mostly Arm & Hammer Double Duty Clumping Litter, 20-Pounds before, but the cats spread it everywhere (making a mess), and it didn't do a good job at odor controlling either urine or feces. Plus, it wasn't even that great at clumping--at least not without wasting a bunch of litter. This new walnut-based litter from Blue Buffalo eliminates both urine and feces odors much better, it cleans up easily when changing out the box, the cats don't track it everywhere, and best of all, it clumps perfectly without using too much litter--which means it lasts significantly longer than any other brand, easily 2 or 3 times as long. Yes, sometimes my cats do get their white paws dusty brown after using it, but that's no different than the gray dust they got from other litters. I've never found particles of it stuck under their paws like my old litter. However, this litter does track about as easily as any other, but I don't use a mat, so your experience may differ there.The negative reviews are dead wrong! To be clear, this litter has NO weird smell, it absorbs odors, it clumps awesome, and cleans up quickly and easily. Try it and see for yourself.

Enjoyed this bread mix very much. It rose and produced a nice crust. Inside was soft and chewy. We added rosemary, garlic powder, honey, and molasses. I think the molasses might have made it too moist and it took an extra five minutes to bake before quickly achieving the "perfect" temperature of 206 degrees. Will leave out the molasses next time to see if that helps. Despite that, this tasted almost exactly like "real" bread, though I would only eat it hot with butter, and with honey or jam. The texture and flavor are nice, but it's a bit dense and not what I'd call sandwich bread. It's great as a side dish or appetizer for a meal.My favorite gluten-free presliced sandwich bread is Food 4 Life's Multigrain (in the frozen section), but it's over eight bucks a loaf and you have to toast it to make it taste good. Once you do, it's amazing.If you are in Western Washington, you should check out Olivia Super Free breads and desserts (from the same people that own Wheatless in Seattle). They make amazing pizza crusts, sourdough boules, brownies, cupcakes, french mini-baguettes, hamburger buns, and a variety of sandwich breads--there's an even longer list of products on their site, but I can't find them in stores). Also, there is 8 Arms Gluten-Free Bakery in Olympia, WA, that make jalapeno cheese bread, rosemary + kalamata olive loaves, chia-millet bread, and "sunshine" bread. For good gluten-free desserts in Olympia, I recommend Pockets Full of Pies (cinnamon rolls, cupcakes, donuts, and pies). These three bakeries all have limited distribution, so ask for them at your local Puget Sound food coop or GF store.

I did not like Thebes my first time playing it, and have little desire to play it again. Even my friends, who own it, say it's a game they only enjoyed their first few times out of the box--it got old fast and now they want to sell it. The artwork is bland, though the boards 'n' bits are durable with cute Indian Jones meeples and cloth bags for each of the five dig sites. Although the first part of the game is all strategy getting the knowledge you need to get the most treasures from the digs, when you actually go there, it becomes a ridiculous luck-fest as you try to blind-draw variable value treasure tokens from a cloth bag that is also loaded with zero-point sand tokens. You could literally draw nothing but sand and waste a ton of time for nothing. Not much fun there!I can't recommend this game and have no idea how it got such great reviews. The game drags on and on and there were many turns where none of us could do anything except inch the game toward completion by moving one space and doing nothing, hoping the cards would change by the time our next turn rolled around. To be fair, I didn't hate Thebes, but neither can I recommend it. There's just something fundamentally wrong with the game's mechanics.

This is a super-fun collection of horror stories, from the gross-out to comedy, covering vampires, aliens, zombies, cannibals, ghosts, psychos, and all sorts of things that go bump in the night. Not all the stories are great, but most are at least decent to downright fantastic. While these may be fine on paper, I heard the audio book version and Macleod Andrews (the actor who reads them) is amazing! He does all kinds of different voices and accents perfectly, especially the moronic rednecks that populate a lot of these stories. They're all brought to life so brilliantly that I can't imagine imagine anyone else ever reading these stories half as good.As for the stories themselves, by far and away the best ones are the two vampire stories: "The Screaming" and "Trailer Sucks." These will stick with you in a way few other vampire stories can, and both for completely different reasons. "The Screaming" is a (relatively) classy homage to Dracula, while "Trailer Sucks" is a full-tilt redneck sleaze-fest that still manages to add a new twist to being a vampire--one which I won't reveal here.If you're a horror fan--especially of the gross-out kind who loves EC Comics/Tales from the Crypt style twist endings--there's a lot to like in this collection. What keeps it from being a five star collection are the stupid, not funny comedy stories (at least five or six, and which take up most of disks 6 and 7). Things like were-squirrels, were-canaries, radioactive monkeys, etc. I would have much rather seen these stories put into a separate anthology--one I could have avoided.

The plot: 12 teenagers in high school join a Satanic cult led by a fellow student (also a Neo-Nazi) who convinces them to kill themselves so he can steal their power to become a great wizard. Only it doesn't work and the cult members come back as evil ghosts with some kind of power to hypnotize other students into killing themselves. So then instead of having the central heroine be a student (which would make the most sense), instead we get Tess, a stupid lady art teacher, who starts a romance with the hunky gym teacher. That's the "A" plot. Lame! The "B" plot involves one of the dead girls' unpopular sister moping around and dealing with her parents and joining the Nazi Satan cult. Then the "C" plot is the Nazi Satan kid trying to form a new cult so he can get them to kill themselves "correctly" this time so he can steal their power. Hardly any time is spent with the cult leader or ghosts' POV. Just a lot of boring, badly written nonsense with people hearing spooky sounds and seeing shadows, or a crazy mom taking her dead daughter's books to school thinking she's still alive. This has "Lifetime Movie of the Week" written all over it, and that's not a compliment.Oh yeah, and the cult leader is named after a Ninja Turtle, which the gym teacher makes a joke about a hundred pages in. That might have been a timely pop culture reference back in 1994 when this dreck was written, but it's still a bad idea to name your villain "Donatello" after a famous cartoon character... or an Italian painter.The writing is awful, so bad you can skip tons of pages and not miss a thing. I ended up skipping over a bunch of the "A" plot with the boring teacher because nothing interesting ever happened. While hardly brilliant or original, the "B" plot with the high school girl moved at a much better pace and was the only reason I was able to finish reading this mess. The book is loaded with unnecessary "who cares" details, clunky big words (like "adamant" and "inverse proportions"), awkward sentence construction, run-on sentences, and stilted, unrealistic dialogue that info-dumps all over the place, plus a lot of telling us how characters feel instead of showing us. The cover art is kind of cool, and the basic premise had promise, but in the untalented hands of "Abigail McDaniels" (aka Dan and Lynda Trent, according to the copyright notice), none of it matters. The Uprising is not scary, not clever, not sexy, not anything really but a time waster typical of the hack fiction factory at Zebra Books. Yes, that Zebra Books--the Kensington imprint who are guilty of churning out more bad horror novels than any other publisher on the planet (except maybe Leisure/Dorchester).Here's an example of the dull, phoning it in crap writing from p.119: "Knowing it would be at least seven that evening before the first of her volunteers returned to school [to help her paint scenery for the school play], Tess treated herself to a leisurely meal at Paulson's Family Restaurant. The food was good, the service adequate, and even though she preferred company when dining out, the break from routine was enjoyable. Or at least that was what she told herself." Yawn. Why do I care where Tess ate or how well her dinner went? It does nothing to advance the plot or inform me of anything useful about Tess. Pretty much everyone prefers company when dining out. That's kind of the whole point, right?And check out this excerpt of awfulness from p.121 after Tess gets to school: "As she progressed toward the stage, her pace diminishing in inverse proportion to the increasing darkness, she tried to remember where Janis had told her the stage light control panel was located. Janis had been adamant that the replacement bulbs were too expensive to use for scenery building. Instead, she was to use the smaller ones that were recessed into the ceiling above the stage. Unconsciously trying to repel the fear-provoking sensations that threatened to seize her, she tried to recall whether the front of the stage was upstage or downstage. Drama had never been her best subject." What a bunch of nonsense! None of that information is important. The whole book is written in this plodding, amateur style. I can't believe it was published. Oh wait--it's Zebra Books, so yes, I can. The only thing missing are the blood-dripping skeletons their other terrible horror novel covers are (in)famous for. Want to see some? Check out Runaway and Wait and See.

Lords of Waterdeep was awesome, and Scoundrels of Skullport makes it even bigger, better, and crazier, like the original game on steroids. You get two expansions in one: Undermountain and Skullport. Both feature 3 new Lord cards, 3 new basic building locations (each on a separate small game board), a ton of new buyable buildings, plus a huge amount of new quest and intrigue cards. Skullport includes a Corruption mechanic that penalizes your end-game points by the number of Corruption tokens (blue skulls) you have vs. how many remain on the included Corruption Track (also on a small game board). You gain Corruption by using the awesome new buildings or completing some of the crazy new quests. Corruption is easy to gain but hard to get rid of (ask any politician, lol), but the game includes a number of ways to get rid of it a bit at a time (such as through using certain buildings, completing certain quests, or playing certain intrigue cards). Corruption management is vital. Don't worry about it early, but be sure to start cutting back by mid-game and reversing the number whenever possible.This expansion also includes a 6th player faction, The Gray Hands, and an extra agent meeple for each color with optional rules to play a long game where everyone starts with an extra agent (you must use the long game rules when playing with 6 people). There are also caravan tokens which stand in for large numbers of adventurer cubes in case the supply runs short. In a 3-player game, this only happened once, but I can see it being necessary with 4-6 players because you will gain a lot more adventurer cubes a lot faster using either or both expansions.Tried playing a 3p long game with both expansions, and it tripled the game time to almost four hours, but it (mostly) flew by. Part of the length was because we were learning the new rules and freaking out over the expansion's super-powered new stuff, partly chatting, and one of the players suffers from "analysis paralysis" big time, with the other two having milder cases. Pretty sure the game would have only doubled in length if we were less chatty and more familiar with the expansions.Some of the new stuff seems like it might be underpowered or overpowered (and we don't like half the new Lords, including Xanathar who makes your Corruption penalty less, or Halaster Blackcloak and Sangalor who only score by buying their expansion's buildings and completing its quests, which get diluted when using both expansions). Compare those lords to the one who lets you score 6 pts. from any 1 quest type of your choice, or 5 for each 10+ pt. quest you complete). There are several ways to play 2-3 or even more intrigue cards per turn, and that really slows the game down and feels unfair and overpowered to the rest of the players. That said, both my opponents in the 3 player game I mentioned had the ability to play multiple intrigue cards per turn and I still beat them by hardly playing any intrigue cards. I focused on Corruption management, going from a high of 7 to only 1 at the end, which was only worth -4 pts. to me (instead of -28 pts), and solving as many double digit pt. Piety quests as I could (including a 40 pt. one) to get my Lord bonus of 6 pts. for any 1 quest type of my choice.If you combine both Undermountain and Skullport in the same game, you have to remove 12 buildings, 30 quests, and 25 intrigue cards from the base game to accommodate all the expansion stuff. That'd be fine--once--but the rules want you to do it every time you play by randomizing which base set bits are removed. I'm not sure I can imagine only playing with one set after trying both, so maybe the best solution in this case is just to yank all the crappiest stuff out of the base set once and never use them again. Also, when the game is prepped for using both sets next time, neither the new storage tray or base set hold the combined buildings and cards properly, resulting in unsightly sprawl with loose cards floating around and a bunch of buildings having to be split between both boxes--which sucks.Nitpicks aside, I do love this expansion, and you get a TON of stuff to freshen up the game that will keep you going for months. It's a great value and a lot of fun. It's so big and crazy, I'm not sure what the designers can do for the next expansion, but I'm looking forward to finding out!UPDATE #1: Decided after another game using both expansions at the same time that it's just too swingy, too super-crazy, and unpredictable. And the Xanathar lord is broken and guaranteed to make you lose the game, so I've thrown that card out until it gets an official fix. Tried a game using only Undermountain, and that played much more like the regular game, only reasonably souped-up. Game time was increased to about 2 hours, nothing crazy like the 4 hours using both expansions. And I completed four 40 point quests! Will try using only the Skullport expansion next and update my review if necessary, but for right now, I'm advocating you restrain yourself from trying the mega-game and just do Undermountain first, then Skullport, then maybe try to combine them once just to see what that's like. But I think the expansions were not really meant or balanced to be used together.UPDATE #2: After playing just the Skullport expansion, I have to say I'm not that fond of it or its Corruption mechanic. Undermountain is way more fun. Not that Skullport doesn't have good stuff, just that a lot of it is overshadowed by Corruption. I've decided to just streamline the base game and the expansions and weed out all the inferior or overpowered stuff (including anything that gives or removes Corruption), mixing just the cards and buildings that are the most fun. Some of these cards and buildings never get bought or played, so what's the point of bothering with them at all? Still others are possibly broken and OP, like the Yawning Portal (4 gold cost building that gives the user 2 cubes of their choice and the owner one and basically hands them the game if they get it early enough), or the Undermountain building (name escapes me) that lets you play three Intrigue cards. And all the new cards that let you steal people's buildings are unfair and create more hard feelings than fun. That still leaves a ton of good stuff to choose from. I'm knocking my rating down to four stars after having played with this set for about a month. It's not balanced well enough, and I hate that expansion games can take so much longer to play. The game isn't deep enough to support more than 60-90 minutes of play time.

I recently watched a bunch of professional game reviewers gush all over the internet about how great Trains is. They said incredible things like "the best game of the year," and "you can throw away your Dominion sets now!" I was really hoping this game wasn't overhyped. Well, let me tell you, it's not! I just played my first two games of Trains and it manages to out-Dominion Dominion, with a touch of Power Grid and Ticket To Ride thrown in for good measure. Players take on the roles of competing 21st century Japanese rail barons. You get a starting hand of 10 cards (7 coins, 2 lay rails, and 1 station expander). Pretty much just like Dominion. You draw five cards, then play your actions and/or buy new cards. Unlike Dominion, you can buy as many cards as you can afford, and take as many actions as you're able, which is a welcome relief from Dominions restrictive 1 action, 1 buy mechanic. There are 8 decks of different cards (bigger money, additional lay rails, additional station expanders, victory point cards, and waste, which are filler cards that you get for laying rails and building stations. Then there are eight randomly determined cards to mix it up and make each new game different. Again, all this sounds very much like Dominion. Where it rapidly starts to diverge is by providing a double-sided hex grid map board of Tokyo and Osaka. Whenever you lay rails, you place a cube of your player color on a hex. If that hex contains a city, another player, a station, a remote location, and/or difficult terrain, you must pay extra money to build there. Although you can't block your opponents, you can make it very expensive for them to move in and through your territory. Stations in cities score victory points as do remote locations. Different cities can support different numbers of stations (1-3). Although it's possible to win by ignoring the board and concentrating solely on deck management, it's just as possible to win by ignoring deck management and going crazy on the map. Most players will strive for a mix, as it really is more fun to engage on the map while still trying to maximize deck efficiency.The game is for 2-4 players, ages 12 and up, and takes about  45 minutes to an hour or so to complete a game. The game ends when any 4 card decks get bought out, or when all the stations have ben placed, or when a player runs out of all their wooden cubes (each player has 20). Most of the points will be tallied at the end, but some cards may let you score in-game. There are a lot of cards here (many reminiscent of ones seen in Dominion), and randomizers are included and clearly marked on the card face (unlike Dominion). A larger file card is included to help sort the cards in a Rolodex-style fashion (the bottom of the plastic tray insert is corrugated to allow for card traction). The box comes with a bunch of foam pads that can be removed later to help store future card expansions. The rule book is 12 pages (including a reference sheet on the back cover), but with a lot of white space, large font size, and pictures, so it's really not all that hard to learn. If you know Dominion, you already know 80% of how to play Trains.The production values are high, the cards are thick and have a nice sheen to them with lots of nice, photo-realistic illustrations of railroad life, and everything seems durable and well put-together.My only real complaints are:1) I wish the game used little plastic bullet trains instead of wooden cubes (and the blue player color is super dark and easy to get lost on the maps).2) The "mountain" hexes look like forests. Seriously, the picture is just a bunch of trees, no mountain visible. Get a clue, designers and artists! If you call something a "mountain," it better look like one.3) The maps look rather amateur, just like they did in the original Japanese limited edition. How hard would it have been to have a better artist make the maps look super cool? At least the scoring track around the board is nice, with plenty of room for scoring markers to share the same space.4) The game goes a bit too heavy on the icons, so many cards have zero text, just symbols you have to memorize (there aren't very many, but it is annoying at first).5) Some cards provide BOTH action(s) and money, but they aren't readily apparent because they are color-coded red (action) not blue (money), and the designers screwed up by not making such cards coded red AND blue (like Dominion does for treasure/victory combo cards) so they are easy to tell apart. Also, a money card ("Tourist Train") also scores you one in-game victory point each time you play it, but it looks too much like the regular money train cards and it's easy to forget to score it as a result.6) The "Tourist Train" card may be overpowered according to some players. I ignored it the first game and bought none while my opponent had 3--I lost on a tie. In the next game, I bought 4 of them early and often (my opponent bought 3 of them but not until at least mid-game) and I easily won, scoring off the chart. So if this card is available to buy in the game, you have to buy some and do it fast or you might be guaranteeing yourself a loss no matter what happens on the board. The safest thing to do if Tourist Train is OP is just not to use it.7) There are multiple cards that discard cards or trash waste, but only one card that trashes money, and one card that trashes itself for money. There are a fair number of boring, underpowered action cards and expensive rail laying cards that negate some situational penalties, but the latter are nearly worthless in a 2p game. Some of these cards suck and will never get used. Although that leaves a fair number of interesting, fun, and decent cards to choose from, the game is screaming for more variety and better cards, including a card like "Chapel" in Dominion that lets you trash multiple cards of whatever you want.8) The game needs bigger money and victory point cards like the Platinum and Colonies from Dominion Dominion: Prosperity. None of the victory point cards are as good as in Dominion but (mostly) cost the same--this seems intentional, however, as you cannot ignore the board in favor of a strategy of buying victory point cards alone--you will lose this way, so that's a good thing, but I'd like to see one more Victory Point card comparable to Colony. And the money-trashing card, "Temporary Timetable," becomes a deck clogger once you upgrade most of your money cards and/or one of the bigger money card stacks runs out and you have nothing to upgrade to.I know these sound like a lot of things are wrong with the game, but they are small enough--and the rest of the game is awesome enough--that I can still highly recommend it. Trains isn't perfect, but it is a great game. The theme is tightly integrated (unlike Dominion's loosely medieval-inspired nonsense), and frankly, Trains feels more like I'm building a railroad than Ticket to Ride ever did. It's also easier to learn and a lot more fun than Power Grid, with way more variety. This is a better game than Dominion without much added complexity. In fact, it's the added complexity and challenge of the maps that helps make it so much better. Once Trains gets a few card and map expansions under its belt, I doubt Dominion will ever hit the table again with my group.By the way, if you can't wait for the official expansions, you can get some free promo maps online at Board Game Geek. Maps so far include GenCon (Lake Geneva, Wisconsin area), Northeastern USA, China, Germany, Nagoya (Japan), and Poland. Also, you can find rules for running Trains as a 5 player game there. Basically, you deal everyone their usual starting hand of 10 except they get 1 less normal Train (Money) and 1 Landfill (trash Waste) card instead, then add two random extra card stacks to buy from, and the game end changes to when any 5 stacks run out, or all stations are built, or all rail (cubes) have been laid. You'll need to add 21 tiny wooden cubes from another game you own in a color that is not red, green, blue, or yellow for the 5th player (one is a score marker, the rest are rail tokens).UPDATE #1: Played 8 two-player games now and still absolutely loving it (though I discovered a few more nitpicks I've added to my original review). I can tell games with 3 or more players are going to be tough and brutal, hotly contested affairs and can't wait to try some!UPDATE #2: Finally have a 3 and 4 player game under my belt, and it does radically change things. The maps become infinitely tighter with lots of interplayer conflict (or at least the potential for it), and card stacks, stations, and cubes run out much faster. I love 2p Trains, but 3 and 4 are even more fun (but lower scoring). You pretty much have to build into opponent-held cities to win. 3 of the 4 new players loved it (the other wasn't sure yet, but he lost badly). All were experienced Dominion players. 2 of them thought it wasn't quite as good as Dominion (at least not yet), and 2 of them thought it was already better. Everyone agreed it needs more maps and cards, but I'm sure those are in the works. I've played all the cards and 3-4 player games now, so the only thing left to try is the unofficial 5 player rules. Will post my results as soon as I can put a 5p game together.

You take on the roles of greedy Indian merchants trying to outdo each other to become the Maharajah's personal trader. This is a light, simple to learn 2-player resource trading game that you can teach in five minutes and be done with in twenty. And yet the game is fantastically balanced and requires careful thought, planning, and strategy. Most games are just a few points apart. You can try it for free online at Board Game Arena. Once you try it, you'll be hooked. This will be a game you'll be playing for years, great for couples, and great for quick filler between other games (I also recommend Guillotine for that, which works for 2-5 players). The artwork, box, and components are all beautiful and durable. Best of all, the cards are pre-shuffled and the pogs are pre-punched and pre-sorted! Everything is ready to play right out of the box. Zero effort required. Nice!I found some rules to increase the number of players to 3 or 4 over at Jaipur's page on Boardgame Geek.For 3 Players: Deal out 4 cards, hand limit 6. Game ends with 4 coin colors depleted. No end for cards, just shuffle the discard pile when needed.For 4 Players: Deal out 3 cards, hand limit 5. Game ends with only 1 coin colors remaining. No end for cards, just shuffle the discard pile when needed.PS: Another two player foreign merchant game (this time with an African theme) that is worth checking out is Jambo.

OK, after the epic literary disaster that was The Libertines, Episode One, Max's writing is clearly a bit better this time out. There are less typos, better and more varied sentence construction. However, his writing skills still leave plenty to be desired. Word repetition is rampant. For example, in chapter one, I counted three uses of the word "committed" or "committing" on the first page alone, real close to each other. Big no-no. Also, Max uses the hero's name, Connor, way too much. Connor said this, Connor did that. Dude, we know it's frickin' Connor, because you just told us it was him fifty million times already! Try and use the word "he" instead. First establish it's Connor, then switch to the "he" pronoun for a bit before switching back to the hero's name again. Also, it's bad if too many paragraphs too close together begin with the same word or name--in this case, "Connor."Max is still faking a bunch of 5-star reviews to make himself look like a better author than he is, and using fake profiles to attack people who post negative reviews. Seriously, man. Stop. If you put half as much energy into improving your writing as you do into pimping yourself, you will EARN some real positive reviews that will make you feel like a king. Crush your ego, take a workshop, read some how-to write guides, and hire yourself the most vicious, demanding editor you can find, and you will be amazed how much better your writing can get.

Sons of Anarchy, this ain't.Max Billington needs to read at least a dozen books on how to write and then hire a ruthless editor to whip him into shape. He writes in a strange combination of short, choppy sentences that read like "See Jane run" mixed with annoying run-ons where he can't even keep the point of view straight. Toss in all the typos, incorrect grammar and punctuation, plus a ton of horrible cliches, and you've got a recipe for literary disaster.Oh, and by the way, it's obvious the author and his friends are deliberately planting fake glowing reviews, then unfairly attacking any critical reviews in the comments section and by marking them "unhelpful."Self-published or not, it's not easy writing a book. I get that. But that doesn't mean what you wrote is any good. There's an old saying authors have, "Your first million words are crap" (paraphrased to avoid censorship filters). In Max Billington's case, if he doesn't humbly and sincerely take the criticisms he's getting from myself and others to heart and use them to grow as a person and an author, then he might need an extra few million words to get his *beep* together--like maybe a hundred million.

It has a strong fruit flavor, and is crisp and clean, not too syrupy. I like it, and the huckleberry is fun and unusual (I've never had a huckleberry before in my life). This soda would be fantastic with vanilla ice cream in a float. I'd buy it again, and definitely be willing to try other sodas from the Americana line.

Lemmy is the only lemonade flavored soda I know of. At first, it tastes exactly like what it promises: sparkling lemonade, tart and sweet, but then it has (at least for me) a bit too much sodium in the aftertaste. It's definitely interesting, and I'm glad I tried it, but I can't say I like it enough to buy it again. It's made with cane sugar, not high fructose corn syrup, so that's a point in its favor. I tried it straight out of the bottle then, as an experiment, tried mixing it with a shot of high-end vodka. Unfortunately, the sweetness got lost (but not the sodium) and it wasn't the improvement I was looking for.Description from the bottle: Since 1939, Lemmy is the original sparkling lemonade drink. For the taste of fresh-squeezed lemons, just say, "Lemme have a Lemmy."Nutrition Facts: 43g of sugar, 75mg sodium, total carb 43g, fat 0g, protein 0g, Calories 160.Ingredients: Carbonated water, cane sugar, citric acid, natural lemon flavor, maltodextrin, lemon juice, essential lemon oil, sodium benzoate (a preservative), yellow #5.

I absolutely love blueberries and had super-high hopes for this soda. I've tried Capt'n Eli's Parrot Punch before and thought it was pretty good. This blueberry soda's flavor was muddled, however, and a bit too heavy. Not crisp and clean enough, not sweet enough. Would drink it again if I had to, but would never buy it.Maine Root is the only other company that makes a blueberry soda and although I have yet to find it anywhere but from the company directly, I'm confident it would kick Capt'n Eli's butt. Maine Root's Maine Root Ginger Brew Soda, 12 Ounce - 4 per pack -- 6 packs per case. and Maine Root Root Beer Soda, 12 Ounce -- 24 per case. are the world's best, absolutely crushing all other brands, even specialty "gourmet" brands like Reed's and Virgil's.

Fitz's makes great soda with real sugar and they come in a variety of flavors. Fruit flavored sodas are tricky to get right as they can easily be too sweet or so acidic you can feel your teeth rotting (Strawberry Crush, I'm looking at you). This orange is great and kicks butt. My favorite Fitz's flavor is grape. It's the best grape soda I've ever tasted, even better than (Retro) Nugrape Made with Real Cane Sugar 12 Pack and with less sugar, though it's still a bit high at 42g per bottle.

I remember trying Whoopass back in the early days of energy drinks and not thinking enough of it to ever buy it again. Flash forward to over a decade later and me trying the new, improved Whoopass in the big can with the new logo. It's got a decent standard energy drink flavor that's pleasant but nothing special (it tastes like a smoother, lighter Rock Star). The real star of the drink is not the taste but that it's made with pure cane sugar (not nasty high fructose corn syrup). It offers a good mix of vitamins and other energy-boosting stuff without a crazy amount of caffeine. I never get too wired or have a sugar crash after drinking it (though I never try to drink the whole can at once, so your experience may vary).So what's the verdict? I may not love Whoopass, but I certainly like it enough to make it my new energy drink of choice--at least until I can find an even healthier, organic one.

Lords of Waterdeep is a fantastic light worker placement game, and along with Stone Age Board Game, the perfect gateway game for non-gamers. Experienced gamers will likely also love it. It is so elegantly designed, so easy to teach and remember, yet difficult to master, that it is a classic of its kind, right up there with other great gateway games like Ticket To Ride, Guillotine, Stone Age, and Dominion. The quality of the components is excellent with (mostly) nice art throughout. The board is easy to understand and only rarely runs out of room for new buildings (10 slots are provided, but there is room in the center of the board to fit a few more in). Sure, the D&D theme feels slightly pasted on, but the mechanics are sound and it's a hell of a lot of fun, with excellent replay value.At the beginning of the game, each player gets dealt a secret Lord card, representing which of the secret lords of the city they are playing. Each lord prefers two different types of quests and gives a 4 point end-game victory point bonus for completing quests of those types (no two lords prefer both the same quests, though many overlap with one). There is one exception, a lord who gives no quest bonus, but instead a 6 point bonus for each building you control at the end. This lord is harder to win with in games with more than 2 players, but in my experience, can be almost impossible to beat it in a 2-player game. You also get dealt two random quest and intrigue cards, which I'll explain below. Intrigue cards are kept secret until played, but quest cards are public knowledge and kept face-up until completed.You get a number of meeples ("your lord's agents") who are placed one at a time in turn order until everyone has assigned all theirs. On the 5th round, everyone gets a bonus meeple. Most places, only one person can get the space's offering that turn. Two of the spaces allow up to three meeples to be assigned (including multiple of the same player's meeples). These are for gaining new quests or playing intrigue cards. Intrigue cards let you get a bonus, or mess with another player, or give everyone a bonus (but the person who played the card gets the best). The Builder's Hall space lets you choose from three different buildings to buy. Buildings offer cubes or money or intrigue cards beyond and better than the spaces on the board. They cost 4-8 money each. When you buy one, it is instantly available for use by all players. Whoever assigns their meple to the building space gets its offerings, but the owner of the building gets a reward too, which is usually a lesser version of the building's offering, but some offer in-game victory points. So you want to buy buildings and hope other players use them. If you use your own building, you don't get the owner reward, just whatever anyone would get for using it. All the other spaces give money or one or two of a specific color cube ("adventurer for hire").You usually score in-game victory points by completing quests, of which there are five types: Warfare, Piety, Skullduggery, Commerce, and Arcana. Each requires a variety of colored cubes and/or money to complete, and the type of quest determines the bulk of the cubes and/or money it requires. White cubes are clerics (Piety), Purple cubes are wizards (Arcana), black cubes are thieves (Skullduggery), and orange cubes are fighters (warfare). Commerce quests all require money to complete in addition to a mix of cubes. Some quests offer an ongoing bonus power but are worth less (these are called Plot Quests and clearly marked on the quest card). However, most just give you an immediate victory point bonus and/or some other cool thing, such as bonus cubes or money. One even gives you an extra, special colored meeple, but is worth no points and is a pain to complete. Get it early enough, and you can have a huge advantage. Get it or complete it late and not only will it not be of much help, but will likely cost you the game if you waste resources on it that could be better spent collecting other quests that hand out victory points.The game lasts eight rounds. Each round, all the spaces you can place your meeples on refresh with whatever goods they are offering (money, buildings, intrigue cards, etc.). There is also a space for getting the first player token. There are always four face-up quests available, but if you don't want any of those, you can choose to discard them all in favor of four new ones, but then you're stuck with keeping one of whatever new ones come out. There is no penalty for uncompleted quests at the end of the game.My only real complaint is with the box itself. The way it is designed is arty-farty with a dumb extra "fake" bottom that can't be removed and exists just to look cool, so don't put any weight on it, as that bends/crushes the box easily, which is not acceptable, especially for a game that costs this much. And, due to the stupid design of the bottom, you can't put the top lid over it. It won't fit. The plastic insert tray holds everything separate and mostly snug (but way too snug in the case of the money and jewel tokens which are an absolute nightmare to put back in). As seemingly snug as things may appear, however, I wouldn't go turning the box upside-down if I were you. Also, after owning the game for a month, the inside bottom part of the box is split on two corners! Do you know how many game boxes have done that to me? Zero, at least in the time frame I'm talking about here. Normally, it takes years, possibly decades, for a box to fall apart, but not this one. In my opinion, this is the worst-designed game box in board game history, and the plastic insert tray is no prize, either. All the other components (cubes, cards, meeples, etc.) are solid and durable, however.The new Lords of Waterdeep Expansion: Scoundrels of Skullport (D&D Boxed Game) is due out August 20, 2013, and the rules are available to preview now as a free PDF on the Wizards of the Coast site. This double expansion contains two new add-on maps (one for the evil underground town of Skullport, one for the infamous dungeon of Undermountain). There are a ton of new buildings, new quests, new intrigue cards, six new Lords (including the beholder crime lord, Xanathar), a new resource called Corruption (and an associated Corruption Track board), as well as optional rules, important rules clarifications and errata for the base game, and a set of gray meeples to add a sixth player. It also includes an extra meeple in each of the original player colors for longer games, which are mandatory when adding a sixth player and optional otherwise. So a two-player game would have you begin with five meeples, then add a sixth one on round five. This expansion--the first of what will hopefully be many--adds a ton of replayability and new ways to strategize and win. After reading the rules, it looks like a must-own.Note that a guy in Canada is selling custom, laser-cut, painted "DnDeeples" (search for them using that term). For hardcore lovers of Lords, these can replace the cubes with meeple-looking clerics holding maces, dual-dagger wielding thieves, wizards with staff and pointy hat, and viking helmeted fighters with a sword! A gaming buddy of mine bought 'em and loves 'em. I'll admit they're very cool, but a totally extravagant expense.

These are generic "who cares?" meeples and a waste of money. In what way do these represent adventurers better than the cubes that come with the game? Also note that although these are being listed as "Lords of Waterdeep Mini Meeples," they are in no way official or endorsed by Wizards of the Coast for their game. I'm no entertainment lawyer, but this sounds like trademark infringement to me. They should probably be re-listed as "Mini Meeple 100 piece set, suitable for use with Lords of Waterdeep" not made to sound like they are a Wizards of the Coast product.A guy in Canada is selling custom, laser-cut, painted "DnDeeples" (search for them using that term). For hardcore lovers of Lords of Waterdeep, these can replace the cubes with meeple-looking clerics holding maces and wearing helmets, dual-dagger wielding thieves, wizards with staff and pointy hat, and viking helmeted fighters with a sword! A gaming buddy of mine bought 'em and loves 'em. I'll admit they're very cool, but a totally extravagant expense. However, they're not much more expensive than these and a million times better. If you're going to splurge, why bother with anything less than the best?

While I would have preferred a more gourmet vanilla bean flavor rather than plain old vanilla, these Home Free Crunchy Vanilla are still excellent cookies for anyone with gluten or other food allergies (or without, as they taste just like regular cookies). They have a satisfying crunch, are certified organic, and free of the most common allergens, plus they are low glycemic.Serving size: about 7 cookies (30g)Servings per container: about 5 (approx. 32 cookies)Calories: 140. Calories from fat: 50.Total Fat: 6g/9%. Saturated fat: 0.5g/2%.Trans fat:: 0g.Cholesterol: 0mg/0%.Sodium: 90mg/4%.Total Carbs: 21g/7%.Dietary Fiber: 1g/4%.Sugars: 10g.Protein: 1g.Calcium: 2%, Iron 4%, 0% on Vitamins A and C.Ingredients: Gluten-free whole oat flour, organic evaporated cane juice, organic high oleic safflower oil, organic pear juice from concentrate, organic tapioca starch, organic buckwheat flour, organic lemon juice from concentrate, organic pure vanilla extract, baking soda (sodium bicarbonate), salt, baking powder, xanthan gum, cream of tartar, sunflower lecithin (an emulsifier), and rosemary extract.Allergen Info: Made on shared equipment using stringent cleaning processes and frequent testing for gluten. Made in a dedicated facility containing NO peanuts, tree nuts, eggs, dairy (including casein), fish, crustaceans, shellfish, wheat, sesame, mustard seeds, or sulfites. We carefully source ingredients and test for peanut, almond, egg, and milk products.Important allergy note regarding Home Free Ckie, Gf, Mini Choc Chip, 5-Ounce (Pack of 6) and Home Free Ckie, Gf, Min, Cho Cho Chip, 5-Ounce (Pack of 6): The chips used in these cookies contain SOY lecithin! For a truly soy and all other allergen free crunchy chocolate chip cookie, I recommend Enjoy Life Chocolate Chip Crunchy Cookie, 7-Ounce (Pack of 6) and Enjoy Life Double chocolate Crunchy Cookie, 6.3-Ounce (Pack of 6).

I grew up in the 70s and 80s playing D&D like the author, but had a completely different, positive experience gaming. The author clearly hates himself, his life, and blames D&D for everything when he is the problem--and the other jerks he gamed with. Throughout the book, he constantly bashes D&D and gamers, and paints himself as a completely obnoxious, unlikable twit. Yes, this is occasionally hilarious, but gets old quick. There is no real character arc here. He just goes from being a geeky loser to a regular loser and never redeems himself, just gives up gaming practically overnight. He says bullies were right to assault him on the street and throw him in the fountain because he was wearing his elf cloak in public. Not only that, but he aspires to be like them and bully others, including his readers. He ditches his best friend for a sadistic idiot and then, when he sees his ex-friend twenty-five years later, calls him fat and a failure and explains how his ex-friend might've turned out better and done less drugs if he'd kept hanging out with the author. He also blasts the poor guy for turning religious and equates that to trading one fictional fantasy kingdom for another. The author then goes on to state how anyone who plays D&D is sick, delusional, obsessed, and addicted, and should promptly trade in their books and dice for what amounts to a bow tie and a 9-5 at an accounting firm or else they are wasting their lives. The message of the book is totally anti-gaming, anti-imagination, pro-bullying, and pro-conformity. You can tell by the author photo on the back flap of the hardcover that there's something wrong with Mark Barrowcliffe. His smile isn't so much a smile as a sneer, and his eyes are cold and dead inside. The photo is creepy, and that's what I thought before I read what a vile person he is in the book.The fact is, outside *maybe* a few people in the UK, nobody knows who Mark Barrowcliffe is or cares. The only reason anyone picks this book up is to read about a fellow gamer growing up in a similar time period and hopefully recounting similar experiences in an amusing way. What we get instead is to be kicked in the teeth and insulted page after page, with far too little about D&D and far too much about the rest of his stupid, boring life and racist, fascist friends. As such, the book is, in the parlance of today's youth, "an epic fail." Another annoying part is the frequently impossible to understand British slang. These stop American readers dead in their tracks to scratch their heads and go, "Huh? What the hell does he mean by that?" The one mildly interesting thing I did learn from the slang is that British gamers don't "roll" dice. They "shake" them. LOL. Wish that had been on page one so I could have chucked the rest of the book in the trash.Shame on the author and his publisher for tricking people into thinking this was a pro-gaming book, but who would buy it knowing it was actually a hate-fueled journey into an angry jerk's mind?

These gluten-free chocolate cookies are delicious and highly addictive. Be careful, because you will be tempted to eat the whole bag in one or two sittings!Unfortunately, I'm allergic to eggs as well as gluten, and after eating a bag of these, they gave me the worst gas of my life. I farted for days and days, practically non-stop, lol. If you are allergic to eggs, I don't recommend eating *anything* by Pamela's, as she puts them in everything (butter too, if I recall correctly), but none of her other products ever gave me a horrible reaction like this. You might try Enjoy Life Double chocolate Crunchy Cookie, 6.3-Ounce (Pack of 6) instead, which are egg-free as well as gluten-free, and free of the 8 most common food allergens, unlike Pamela's.I'm not sure how to rate this product, since it made me so sick. Taste = five stars, but smelly death-farts from hell = zero stars. To be fair and helpful to anyone who's not allergic, I'll just call it five stars, but with the caveat previously mentioned.

My favorite gluten-free cookie, tied with Enjoy Life's crunchy chocolate chip. These cookies look, feel, and taste just like their wheat-based counterparts and make a fantastic treat for anyone with food allergies. I vastly prefer Enjoy Life's crunchy cookies (all varieties) to their chewy ones.

I don't like these as much as the regular crunchy chocolate chip cookies from Enjoy Life, but these are still very good for a gluten-free cookie. They taste like their real, wheat-based counterparts and have a great crunch. I think Pamela's Products Simple Bites Cookies Gluten and Wheat Free Extreme Chocolate -- 7 oz Each / Pack of 2 are way better and highly addictive, but unfortunately, they are made with eggs, which I am allergic to. I ate a bag anyway and ended up with the worst gas of my life. Was farting for days, lol. If you don't have an egg allergy, then definitely check out Pamela's, otherwise Enjoy Life is your next best bet.

Originally released by Rio Grande Games, Zman Games has licensed the game and put it back into print as of May 1, 2013. I talked to ZMan Games and a rep there assured me the only changes are some minor rules clarifications (not new rules). All the original high quality components (including the leather dice cup) from the Rio Grande version are going to be included.Stone Age is an awesome, amazing game that only takes a few minutes to learn, but is challenging to win, with multiple winning strategies. Suitable for experienced gamers and the whole family. It takes about an hour to play, maybe 90 minutes. This is a great gateway game and introduction to the worker placement games popular in Europe. Can't say enough good things about it. It scales well regardless of the number of players. Never gets old.
