A true modern gaming classic right up there with Dominion: Big Box and Ticket To Ride.I also recommend the super-fun expansion, Stone Age Style is The Goal, which lets you add a fifth player, plus new huts, new cards, a new resource, and a new village location with its own trade track that lets you convert your existing resources into the ones you need.Another awesome light worker placement game that's like this one but with a fantasy theme is Lords of Waterdeep: A Dungeons & Dragons Board Game, but it does feature some "take that!" screwing your opponents over mechanics.For a game without that, I highly recommend Hawaii, which has a lush, tropical theme. Hawaii is slightly more complex (at least initially), but offers more variety. The board is modular and where each location goes is randomly determined at setup. Plus, the price of everything changes each round, ensuring you also get a different experience in-play, not just at set-up.NOTE: You can try both Stone Age and Hawaii out for free online against real opponents at Board Game Arena (live) or Yucata (remote). The rules and everything are there for you to check out.

This is a useful book any writer will find helpful. It's got you covered no matter what market you're trying to crack, from nonfiction to fiction (including screenplays, magazines, poetry, etc.). Written and electronic submissions are covered. Samples include a "correct" and "incorrect" version for side-by-side comparison with the reasons why each works or doesn't clearly pointed out. Most of the information you need to know how to properly and professionally submit your writing to any market is here, spelled out clearly and concisely.There are a few problems however:1) There is absolutely NO information on how to pitch an anthology or series! With more and more publishers wanting to establish franchises like Harry Potter, Twilight, Divergent, and the Hunger Games, this is a major oversight that needs to be addressed in future editions.2) I would have liked to see a few extra sample pages for the "correct" novel outline that encompassed a complete chapter rather than just the first page. As presented, it says to write "chapter-by-chapter outline" on each page of your outline, but is this really necessary if a chapter description requires an extra page? Which many easily could, because of the 1" margins, double-spacing, and line breaks! This is not made clear.3) Furthermore, there is not enough advice on the best way to write a synopsis, which is your novel's most important marketing tool to agents and publishers. I had to search all over the web to piece together the necessary advice when this should have been provided in the book.4) There were not that many "exclusive tips" from leading agents and editors as promised on the cover, and they were all pretty much just common sense advice, nothing earth-shattering.5) Lastly, I would imagine many writers are only interested in writing for one or two of the markets presented, making large chunks of the book wasted space for them.Verdict: I bought my copy used knowing I would never need most of the info in this book and am happy with my purchase, save for the criticism above.

Dominion Guilds is the final expansion and the best of the three "small box" sets (Dominion: Cornucopia and Dominion: Alchemy are the other two). The gimmick this time is cards that grant you bankable money tokens or allow you to "overpay" for the cards in order to get an immediate bonus when you buy them. There are 13 cards and 5 blanks included along with the rules and a small bag of metal coin tokens (identical to the ones that come in Dominion Seaside). There's a great mix of cards that can really change the game, some more complicated than others. Not all the cards are standouts, a few being overly complicated or hard to use like Butcher and Doctor, but that's true of all sets. My only major complaint is the rules only include three sample card setups for the Dominion base set and three for Dominion Intrigue. There's nothing about the best setups using the other expansions. Of the included setups, all the ones with the base game were fun and balanced, but the ones for Intrigue seemed extremely poorly thought-out and lacked any kind of fun. Guilds mixes really well with all sets, including the big money games you can have with the Dominion: Prosperity expansion.Overall, I really enjoyed this set. There was a little bit of a learning curve adjusting to the new mechanics as is often the case with Dominion, and I don't recommend it for beginners, but Guilds is definitely less complicated than Dominion Dark Ages Expansion and more versatile than Alchemy. If this is truly the final expansion, the designer went out on a high note.

This was a decent but flawed teen vampire tale. I'll lay out the pros and cons below:PROS: The writing is a bit better than average for YA fiction. It certainly starts well and doesn't waste any time getting into the heroine's head and racing off to the first vampire attack.Having a strong heroine who does smart, logical things in her own defense is a refreshing change from the weak, mopey, helpless kind that populate a lot of YA fiction (I'm talking about Bella from Twilight, Rhine from Wither, etc.). Although not a fan of vampiric super-speed, I still enjoyed her resourceful of thieving clothes and equipment from the mall and local stores as well as setting up her lair's defenses.For me, the best part was that the author tries (more or less successfully) to create his own unique take on vampires and their powers, including some metaphysical concepts that I found interesting. However, he tries to make it all explainable by science and that was a bit of a turn-off.CONS: The author loves to show off his knowledge of the NASA facility (where he works) and astronomy, but I don't care about math, space, or science, so I found it annoying and boring. Plus, having the love interest be named after "Cosmos" host Carl Sagan was too clever to be believable and I hated hearing the heroine call him "Sagan," over and over. Frankly, as soon as I read it took place mostly at a NASA facility, I almost didn't want to read it. The location was too unique and yet not all that interesting. The book could have been set anywhere, so why pick a place that most readers have no clue about? It makes it harder to imagine. Everybody understands an abandoned factory, but not an abandoned test silo or whatever it was supposed to be.The book needed tighter editing. The same word (such as "pretty") would appear in adjacent sentences or within the same paragraph often enough to be annoying.For some reason, all the vampires speak German, despite only the main villain obviously being of German heritage, and the overuse of the foreign language was distracting and annoying, especially as it seemed to serve no real purpose. The story doesn't take place in Germany and all the vampires are Americans from the mid-1800s to early 20th century with nothing called out in their backstory or names to imply they were recent German immigrants. Not all the German words are translated, which is super-annoying. Like I'm supposed to type them into an online translator to read those parts of the book? Fat chance. There's way too much German in the book, and way too much untranslated German. Again, including it serves no point I can see as Germany itself has absolutely nothing to do with the story.I didn't much care for the epilepsy parts, especially calling the grand mal seizures "tonic-clonics" because not only does it rhyme, it sounds stupid. It doesn't matter if that's what the seizures are really called or not, it's distracting. I know the heroine's epilepsy was a major plot point, but I never found it all that interesting or credible in how it related to her bungled transformation into a half-vampire.The author frequently fails to credibly write the heroine as a believable sixteen-year-old girl, sounding more like some middle-aged dude trying to write like one. There are a lot of big, technical, or uncommon words throughout the text that no teenage narrator would know or use (the book is told in the first person from the girl's POV). Another example is when the heroine finds inappropriate moments to recall romantic details during scary action scenes. Trust me, you're not going to stop and think about your first kiss while being chased by a vampire through the spot where you had it. I mean, unless you *want* to die. This type of poetic detail does not belong in an action scene as it slows and dilutes the tension. Keep those thoughts for the quiet moments.All the swear words are cut out with ellipses ( . . . ) or are intact but in German, making me feel like the book was more than a bit old-fashioned and prudish, having been dumbed down for its target teen audience when most YA books these days include at least a little cursing, and the book feels like some kind of neutered throwback to 70s/80s YA without any, even the milder ones.There was not enough romance (and no sex), but some fairly explicit gore. Twilight fans should look elsewhere.The middle drags. There's not much in the way of vampire attacks, and it takes forever for the villain to show up in person, instead he shows up in her dreams, astral projecting into her room a few times. I liked the astral projecting part, but it's not enough to sustain the suspense. I was anxious for the book to be over. It should have been *at least* a hundred pages shorter. The side-story about a good vs. evil vampire war never really felt fleshed out and worse, didn't go anywhere, making the heroine's entire time spent with the good vampires an info-dumpy "who cares?" None of the other vampires in the entire book were fully realized, interesting characters, including the cartoony villain. This side-story should have been cut.Some tech items that seemed like they would be important for the climax turned out not to be (like the solar flare viewer, the deadly acid vial, etc.) or felt underused or used incorrectly. For example, the heroine brags about possibly using a garden hoe to kill vampires, then never uses it herself. She brags about the acid vial being so deadly she's afraid to even carry it around, then the villain drinks it on his own and nothing happens to him except he gets a sore throat! Dumb, dumb, dumb. What's the point?The heroine has specialized knowledge it does not seem credible for her to have about medieval siege tactics (despite the info-dumpy way the author tries to justify it), as well as rigging up home defenses, alarms, and safe zones, plus knowledge of technical names for things like a "gantry" that a girl of her age and background would never believably know. It's like she turns into Rambo all of a sudden. That felt forced and was never properly set up. If she came from a survivalist background, then sure. But she doesn't.I was disappointed by the ending which tries to turn the book into a brain-dead action movie, but then fails to commit even to that, having the girl hesitate or decide not to kill her attackers when she knows it's a fight to the death situation and mercy will only get her and her friends killed. Also, nobody on the NASA base sees or hears the explosions or comes to investigate all the screaming, a jeep being thrown through the air, or the raging fire. Way too convenient. Which is one of the biggest problems with setting the story on a NASA base, even an abandoned part. There's still people working on the base and round the clock guard patrols.The cover art, title font, and overall book design are cheesy and cheap-looking, making me not want to pick it up. Only the fact it was a teen vampire tale made me give it a chance.VERDICT: The unique vampire powers/physiology and metaphysics like astral projection and auras are what really make this book worth a read. The rest of it (past the great opening) is just OK. Although the cons clearly outweigh the pros, I didn't dislike the book enough to give up on it and I will try other books by this author. All in all, Throat tries hard to stand out from other teen vampire books and give us something different. I respect that even if the author doesn't always succeed.

These are certified organic, gluten-free noodles with just a hint of pumpkin/ginger flavor to them. I wish they had more flavor on their own, but they do easily absorb the flavor of whatever dish you put them in. You get three single person servings per bag, each one parceled out and bound. The lack of quantity is kind of a let down. Overall, I do like this product when I'm making asian noodle dishes. It has the taste and texture of regular wheat noodles only without the wheat/gluten so I can eat them with my food allergies and they are ready to eat in under 10 minutes. My only real concern is all King Soba products are made in China, which makes me slightly concerned as to their integrity even with the certified organic label on the package. They also make gluten-free King Soba Brown Rice Ramen (Pack of 3) (see my review) and buckwheat ramen. The package includes multilingual directions in English, Dutch, French, German, Italian, and Spanish.Tinkyada makes a variety of delicious non-asian, non-flavored gluten-free Italian pastas (in natural and organic varieties) and their products are made in the USA. For example Tinkyada Brown Rice Spaghetti with Rice Bran, 16-Ounce Packages (Pack of 12) (but don't buy the white rice versions, they aren't as good).

This stuff rocks! Kiss Soda tastes pretty darn close to Squirt, but even better--crisp and citrusy, flavored with grapefruit and lemon and made with cane sugar. Unlike Squirt, Mountain Dew, and certain other citrus sodas on the US market, there is NO cancer-causing brominated vegetable oil in this and NO high fructose corn syrup, so you can drink all you want and not worry about getting fat or dying a slow, painful death. Kudos to the makers of Kiss and all the micro-brew companies out there for giving soda-lovers a tastier and healthier alternative.Nutrition Facts: 160 calories per bottle, 30g sodium, Total Carb. 42g, Sugar 42g. No fat, no protein.Ingredients: Carbonated water, cane sugar, citric acid, natural and artificial flavors, sodium benzoate (preserves freshness), extracts of grapefruit and lemon. Contains no juice.

A bunch of alien energy beings, research scientists from another planet, are sent to earth on an experiment on humans by possessing them. Some of the aliens, unused to having physical bodies and emotions, learn to enjoy indulging themselves in sex and violence and turn selfish and evil as a result. They have a fight with their alien brethren by pitting the possessed humans against each other. The story is told in the most hateful, homophobic, and politically incorrect way possible. It read like a parody of right-wing values, that's how far right it went--straight off a cliff.The basic concept of the story is OK, and I think I can see some sort of angel/demon religious allegory in the subtext, but in the hands of prolific hack fiction author, William W. Johnstone, it becomes a muddled mess even worse than his usual brain-dead nonsense. THEM is without a doubt the dumbest, most poorly written book in his entire career. None of his 200+ books are what I would call good, but some are at least entertaining in a cheesy, guilty pleasure sort of way (for example, the first three books in his over-the-top "Devil's" series: The Devil's Kiss, The Devil's Touch, The Devil's Heart). Unfortunately, THEM is entertaining in a whole different way. You will be laughing at the author's feebleminded incompetence from page one. The torture of reading this monumental failure is beyond words. It's like a bad 50s sci-fi movie written by a paranoid rightwing redneck choking on his own hatred and lack of I.Q. This is hilarious, pathetic, ridiculous junk that never deserved to be published. I doubt it was even edited or went much beyond a first draft.Johnstone was one of those crummy authors who had to publish something like ten books a year because he couldn't write one good blockbuster instead. Which would be OK since some of his early to mid-1980s stuff was so bad it's good, but by the mid to late 1980s, even the subpar quality he'd set for himself started going down the toilet, and kept plummeting in that direction right up until the day he died in 2003 (THEM was written in the 90s). Instead of putting entertainment first as any good fiction writer should, Johnstone became increasingly obsessed with editorializing, forcing his bitter, hateful, grumpy old man far-right political and religious opinions into everything, including a manifesto for creating a fascist Christian dictatorship (ostensibly written to complement his From The Ashes: America Reborn post-apocalyptic series, but it seems obvious to me that this was what he wanted America to become in reality).Note: To be fair, somehow Johnstone has mindbogglingly managed to get on the New York Times bestsellers list (more than once, even after his death), but I think this speaks more to the fanaticism of a fanbase that shares his far-right values than to Johnstone's alleged "talent."

This is a great tasting organic energy drink I've been drinking for a few years now. There's no sugar crash and depending on my needs, a can can last me most of a day without going flat or funny tasting. Unfortunately, this and the passionate orange flavor have both been discontinued. Expiration date on bottom of last batch of cans is November 25, 2013.

What a snoozer! This book is dry, boring, academic, and kept putting me to sleep. Writer's Digest has a spotty track record of putting out quality books that actually deliver on their promise, and this isn't one of them. I learned nothing from it because the author does not have a clue how to engage, entertain, and educate her readers, so why should I believe she has anything of value to say? Just give me the facts without all the filler and fancy words. What a waste of time, and I got it for free from the library. If I'd actually paid money to own it, I would have been mad as hell and returned it.

Good, comprehensive book detailing hero and heroine archetypes and how they interact with each other. Followed by Tami Cowden's solo sequel, Fallen Heroes: Sixteen Master Villain Archetypes, which is also good, but unfortunately does not attempt to explain how the villains interact with the heroes and heroines in this book.Another book I like that offers the same idea as this one is 45 Master Characters, Revised Edition: Mythic Models for Creating Original Characters by Victoria Schmidt. It not only has a character archetypes, but a complete breakdown and worksheets for charting the different adventure paths for males vs. females. Also recommended is The Virgin's Promise: Writing Stories of Feminine Creative, Spiritual, and Sexual Awakening by Kim Hudson, which focuses on a step by step guide to creating feminine adventures vs. male ones (but a slightly different system than in 45 Master Characters). Both 45 MC and VP provide an easy to understand breakdown of Maureen Murdock's The Heroine's Journey, which itself is a feminine version of Joseph Campbell's The Hero with a Thousand Faces (The Collected Works of Joseph Campbell) (the Hero's Journey; theory of mythic storytelling structure used in Star Wars, The Lion King, etc., which Christoher Vogler breaks down for writers in The Writers Journey: Mythic Structure for Writers, 3rd Edition).And not just for its screenplay advice, but because it is easily adapted for novelists, I recommend My Story Can Beat Up Your Story: Ten Ways to Toughen Up Your Screenplay from Opening Hook to Knockout Punch by Jeffrey Schechter. It espouses a Jungian theory of a "unity of opposites," so both the hero and the villain and their teams will be mirror images of each other and be out to prove the opposite (or some more reasonable compromise) of the story's theme (such "faith vs. technology" in Star Wars). It provides great examples of this theory from blockbusters like Star Wars, Star Trek, the Dark Knight, etc. If you go to the author's website (with the url link in the book), you can download a cut chapter that extends the mirror image theory not just to the characters, but the first half and last half of the story. So some action that happens in the first half is repeated in the second, only on a larger scale with more dramatic results, which readers like because of its circularity.Unfortunately, not all of the archetype books mesh well with each other's systems (nor do all the story structure ones), so you might want to pick one to get you started. What's nice about The Complete Guide to Heroes and Heroines is it has the villain sequel, however, that doesn't mean these are the best books on the subject. They're a perfectly good choice, and deliver exactly what they promise, but I love getting the mythic hero/heroine journey story structure help and find myself referring far more to those books throughout the writing process than books that solely provide archetypes.

Roundworm/tapeworm infestations can cause secondary bacterial infections in their gut, such as spirochetes that cause insanely chronic diarrhea, so you may need to get your dewormed cat both a probiotic like Endurosyn (to restore the healthy bacteria) and an antibiotic (to kill/reduce the population of the unhealthy ones back to normal levels).The dispenser syringe is kind of annoying and doesn't come with instructions how to work it (at least, mine didn't, but I got mine directly from my vet so maybe it does come with some, I can't be sure). You have to unscrew the base ring to the dose line to get it to work. Once it does, you do get totally accurate dosing, but my kitten does not like the taste of this stuff, which means I always end up with about half the dose on her ruff or the outside of the tube. I have found hiding whatever I can scrape off the tube inside pill pockets works well at getting the rest in her, even when I do a sloppy job of hiding it. Other than the (at first) counter-intuitive syringe and bad smell/taste (plus it's poop brown and looks and feels like paste, not gel), Endurosyn works well at getting your cat the probiotics it needs.

I don't know why this is selling under a different title, but it appears to be the same book as The Bitch Posse by Martha O'Connor (lots more reviews for that version, by the way). The story alternates between three different women--in high school in 1988--and years later in 2003 as 33-year-old adults. The chapters switch point of view and time as each woman recounts her messed-up life with and without her friends from the Bitch Posse. Little by little, the terrible secret that bound them together and tore them apart is revealed. Has some similarities to Lois Duncan's 1979 Young Adult feminist thriller, Daughters of Eve and to Kerry Cohen's Loose Girl: A Memoir of Promiscuity.Although this is technically considered "chick-lit," it's more like "bitch-lit." It's got a very dark, gritty edge to it with swearing, cutting, mental illness, abortion, drinking and drug abuse, plus many graphic sex scenes that make this book appeal to both male and female readers looking for a well-written, twisted story.

XEN-TAN Moroccan Tan Ultra actually does an excellent job of simulating a natural sun tan. It mimics my natural sun tanned skin color very closely, great for extending my tan through the winter months. The color lasts a few days before it starts fading significantly, though it doesn't streak or leave any splotchy patches like some products do. Application is very easy and foolproof if you follow the provided instructions.One thing to note is that I have mildly sensitive skin and I tend to get a little itchy from the drying effect of most of these sunless tanning products. This one hasn't caused any noticeable itching or irritation, but as with most things, your mileage may vary.

This is a great value in a basic indoor cycling bike. The heavy steel frame is extremely durable and all of the joints are fully welded, not tack welded like some lesser quality brands. The bike comes well packaged and the parts protected, the smaller parts bagged. Assembly was incredibly easy and only took about 15 minutes total. The provided tool allows you to assemble the bike without the need of any other tools of your own.Thanks to the wheels on the front support bar, lifting this up and rolling it around is an absolute breeze. The seat and handlebars are both fully adjustable up and down as well as forward and back, not to mention the seat pivots and locks securely in place. This indoor cycle fits my 5'6" frame fine and can easily adjust to fit those well over 6' without any problems at all.The 40 pound flywheel provides a smooth and consistent resistance that is easily adjusted on the go with just the turn of a knob that also doubles as a brake, and the brake will definitely stop the rotation in a hurry; I was a bit surprised at just how smoothly and quickly the brake works.Even the water bottle holder is heavy coated wire that is very durable and held to the frame very securely with two strong bolts. No cheap plastic cup holder... I think that actually impressed me more than anything. It's the small details like that, that help leave an overall great impression of the machine as a whole.

This product has similar ingredients to a popular brand of OTC migraine medication, which is a mix of aspirin, acetaminophen, and caffeine. Being in a powder form seems to help it dissolve faster so it can go to work relieving your pain in record time. For me, this product really does go to work fast and helps relieve light to moderate headaches with the first dose the majority of the time. The powder is mixed fruit flavor, and while it's not displeasing to the point of making scrunchy faces, it certainly won't be mistaken for a pixie stick powder either.Fast acting, convenient to carry, easy to take. Not much more you could ask for.

Swiffer Duster 360 was pretty impressive at picking up and holding dust instead of just smearing it around. This duster is great for bookshelves, blinds, the refrigerator top, or just about anywhere. Really convenient to use and just throw the dusty mop head away. No more redistributing dust everywhere, this picks it up and traps it really good. I'd really like to write more about this product, but there's not a whole lot to say. It just works. Pick one up, use it, and see for yourself.

This stuff has the taste of bitter medicine, in that it tastes pretty bad. That's a good thing though, as it will help keep kids from wanting to abuse it should they manage to get ahold of it. The bottle is small, easy to tote along in a lunchbox, briefcase, or purse without taking up hardly any space.Unfortunately, the sample bottle I received did nothing to even take the edge off my back ache after day's work, and so I just had to suffer through it as I didn't want to add medication on top of this. It's supposed to be fast acting, and I suppose it is, since it was fast about doing nothing. Can't say if that bottle was a fluke or if it'll help with other aches and pains or not. Not going to buy more to be a guinea pig to find out.  I'll just stick with what I already know works.

I thoroughly enjoyed reading The Curse of Crow Hollow. It is a story written with much care and thought put into every chapter, into every character, and into every plot twist. The story is somewhat dark and has a distinct psychological element to it that is sure to put you on the edge of your seat at times. While I wouldn't describe the book as fast paced, it is far from a drag either. This is a great book for really sinking your full attention into, in order to get the most out of it.I enjoyed being pulled into the story from the very beginning, and especially appreciate that the ending didn't feel rushed, or unfinished. Not many books these days seem to pull that off, and those that do usually don't do it nearly as well.

Panasonic makes a lot of high quality products that outperform and outlast a lot of other brands. The ES-ED50-N wet/dry shaver and epilator is no exception. It is a high quality personal grooming tool that you'll feel confident using time after time. The ergonomic design makes using it that much easier too. Even the foils and blades are made to be hypoallergenic so that sensitive skin sufferers can be at ease. They even gave the body a stylish color design that makes it fun looking!Everything about the unit is pretty much self-explanatory in how the features work and how to use the device and it's various attachments. If you still need help, the instructions provided are written clearly and are easy to understand.Overall this truly is a 5-star product that's earned it's stars in both features and performance.

When you buy cheap furniture, you get less than stellar quality, and this South Shore piece is no exception. For what you get, it's okay, but it does have some disappointing areas even knowing it's low-budget furniture. First off, it is a nice size chest of drawers with a decent capacity. The laminate coating that gives it a finished woodgrain appearance came without any scuffs or marring, which was a pleasant surprise. The unit is also heavy and stable on it's feet, which is a very good thing. Another nice surprise was it came with the ability to mount the back of the chest to the studs in a wall to provide extra stability should you have tots that insist on climbing around on everything they shouldn't.The assembly experience could have been a lot better. While I had no problem doing the entire assembly by myself, the instructions were lacking in description and details. You pretty much just had to follow the little pictures and hope for the best. At least all of the necessary hardware was there with no missing pieces. They were even thoughtful enough to throw in a touch-up marker.Sadly, the assembled piece is about as elegant as a brick. It is rectangular. Every part of it ends in sharp, square edges. There are soft contours to be found, no sculpted edges, no fancy lips or corners on anything. Even the drawer pulls are small and simplistic.Any major problems? One of the legs (or front feet, if you prefer) was partially cracked through along the grain, but not enough to effect stability or integrity. I just hid the cracked side to the inside where nobody could see it.All of the drawer runners and and sliders are plastic and they simply press into the MDF panels. I can see these getting wallowed loose after a while just from the natural weight shifting caused by opening and closing the drawers. It's just a matter time. They are also non-adjustable, which is a shame because the drawers DO NOT line up perfectly even. Some of them cause the drawers to sit slightly cockeyed which is noticeable when all the drawers are closed.Also, some of the drawers stick out slightly father on one side than the other when the unit is completely assembled. This is confirmed to be caused by a combination of misaligned holes drilled from the factory that aren't even from one drawer section to the next, as well as from the front panels of each drawer being slightly warped, which was confirmed by checking them with a carpenter's square.Still, this is a cheaply priced chest of drawers, so it's no surprise that it's cheaply made. Nonetheless, it is a perfectly suitable chest for a guest room, a child's room, or anywhere else you don't really need or particularly want nicer furniture to be located.

This fleece shirt from Wrangler is everything you'd expect from the brand. It has quality seams with even stitching and a true to size fit with generous shoulder and arms for freedom of movement. The pockets are nicely sized too. The fleece material is slightly warmer than your average flannel shirt, but it isn't as heavy duty or rugged as a chamois shirt. The fleece material is perfect for light-duty wear where you won't be subjecting the shirt to much abuse. It is a warm shirt for those cool autumn days, and it can even be used as a shirt-jacket on breezy days while helping to keep the wind out. On bitter days, better break out the chamois shirt though, as a harsh winter wind will definitely cut through the less dense fleece material. Overall this is a classic shirt that's great quality and good comfort to match.

I own several Wrangler shirts, so it was no surprise what to expect. This sherpa lined denim shirt is extremely soft inside and out. The seams are stitched with precision, and the buttons are large enough for fumbly fingers to easily manipulate. The fit is roomy, but not big. It allows a generous amount in the upper arms and elbows for freedom of movement. The overall style is fairly plain, no fancy stiching, plain pockets with no flaps, just a good utilitarian shirt jacket that will keep you warm on chilly, breezy days.

This is a simple to use espresso machine that looks good and makes consistent brews time after time. The fit and finish is decent enough. Cleanup is easy too. The settings are fairly self-explanatory for those who have used espresso machines before. For those new to the countertop espresso makers, you'll probably find the instruction books a bit lacking, they tell you how to use the machine, but it doesn't really tell you how to USE the machine to get good results. For that, you'll either want to buy some books, watch some online videos, or get help from some experienced friends. Once you actually learn how to use the machine properly, you'll get excellent results time after time.

This is a great toy for the small children of John Deere fans. The toolbelt has different John Deere sayings when you press a button, but it's kind of humorous too, because even some adults eyes light up when they hear the popular John Deere slogan. This is a great set for letting the little one help daddy fix stuff around the house or farm. Pretend time may be commercialized, but it's fun nonetheless.

Ace bandages have been a trusted name in my household for as long as I can remember. They are quality products that get the job done. The fastener on this bandage is leagues better than the old metal clips with sharp pointy teeth; they hold better and don't bend or poke like the old ones did. As a compression bandage, this can be adjusted for various amounts of compression, and while it does seem to stretch a little over the course of a day, it isn't nearly as bad as some cheaper products do. Readjusting the fit is quick and easy.

What you are supposed to get is 21 packs of snack mix for the sake convenience and having a salty-sweet and tasty treat ready to go. In theory this seemed like a great idea. What arrived was a plastic canister filled with 21 packs of snack mix that had everything chocolate melted away and stuck to insides of every single wrapper. I wouldn't consider this a very pleasant or worthwhile experience at all.

This is a very well made cleaning rod. The stainless rod is polished to a very fine finish that won't hold grit that could be abrasive and damaging to the rifling of the barrel. The six inch rod length is perfect for a variety of pistols and revolvers, anything from .22 caliber on up.The threading accepts standard threaded brushes and jags from a variety of manufacturers, so no worries there whatsoever.My only nitpick is the freely rotating handle isn't built to the tightest tolerances, so there is a little bit of wobble there that isn't really necessary. I've got rods from other manufacturers that spin freely with virtually no "play" between the handle and rod, so there really is no excuse for any amount of wobble between the handle and rod.

Classic s'mores in a kit form from Hershey, that pretty much speaks for itself. Everything you need to build your s'mores in one kit ready to go. The chocolate bars came melted from the heat of being carried around in hot cargo areas in the heat of summer, but considering the chocolate is going to be melted once the s'mores are assembled, it really wasn't that big of a deal, just something worth mentioning. This makes enough s'mores to go around for a good size camping crew.

This is a really nice hair dryer from Remington. The handle and controls  are very ergonomic, and the head is well balanced so that it doesn't get to be a chore handling it. The heat settings are what you'd expect, and the dryer does a good job of getting your hair dry fast without too much static buildup. What I really like about this dryer is the generous cord length and the ability to hand the dryer from a hook. The attachments fit well, but the diffuser attachment comes in the handiest as always.

Irons have come a long way since I last bought one. This Black & Decker D3030 iron is a lot more iron than I expected. From the soft grip handle to the easy to use controls, everything seems designed with the user in mind. The contoured sole with generous button ridge makes navigating the iron simply fantastic. Everything about this iron is better than I had expected, and it even feels like a well-built product. The best part is this iron doesn't leave big wet splotches like my old one did.The iron is a bit larger than I was expecting though. It wouldn't fit on the cabinet shelf where I kept my old iron. I ended up having to lift the shelf above it a couple notches in order to get it to fit.

CAD has been around a long time and is well known in both the pro and home-recording circles. They are known for producing good quality products with performance that in many cases exceeds their price bracket.With the ZOE USB condenser mic, you have an affordable recording solution that is virtually plug and play. Just plug it in and Windows will automatically detect it, and you're ready to start using it within seconds. It really doesn't get any easier than that!Build quality is decent. The plastic housing is lightweight, but doesn't flex or feel flimsy. Sure, it's no tank like the old Astatic D-104, but it can surely hold it's own against a few bumps and bruises. (Like the cat jumping on the desk and knocking it over).The little supplied tripod is easy to set up, just extend the legs all the way, screw the mic onto the mount, and plop that baby down. Of course this little tripod stand is no good at damping vibrations, and it just doesn't feel all that sturdy. Luckily, the screw mount is the same size as most universal mic stands and desk stands, so go spend 15 or 20 bucks on a more solidly built stand with a shock absorbing base pad if you feel you the need, since the mic will screw right on and be good to go.The microphone size is actually pretty darn small. I was impressed with the small size, which is great for travel since packing it in the laptop bag is a lot easier when you don't have a lot of bulk. For comparison sake it's about half the size of my Heil PR-40 broadcast mic, or about the same diameter as my Heil PR20 stage mic and half the length. Yes, it really is that compact! For those wanting to record in 24-bit mode, you're going to be sorely out of luck. You have two choices with this one: 16/44.1 or 16/48. For things like Skype calls, Google Hangouts, recording podcasts, video conferencing, and assorted VOIP platforms like TeamSpeak 3, Mumble, or Ventrillo, then these settings will be just fine and are perfectly suited for those uses. It even works great for EchoLink if you're an amateur radio operator.Headphone output is loud and clear, and it's really easy to adjust the volume with the buttons on the front of the mic body. It had no problem whatsoever giving a solid, loud signal to my Audio-Technica ATH-M50s headphones. In fact, there was plenty of volume adjustment loudness to spare.Finally, sound quality. At this price point you aren't going to get sound quality that matches pro recording gear, and you shouldn't expect to. But here's the thing: it'll get you 90% there, and most people with untrained ears wouldn't be able to notice that last 10% anyways. Especially not for things like VOIP and podcasts going to Youtube where the audio is butchered and usually highly compressed anyways.The sound is a little bit mid-present with articulate highs that help with intelligibility, but not so mid-forward that it imparts that godawful stuffy, nasal honk I tend to hear far too often from other mics (at least on my voice). You do get a nice warm proximity effect up to about 3 inches away from the mic, but any closer and it starts turning to mud. Considering that this isn't a dynamic mic, you should be trying to eat the mesh anyways. Anywhere from 6 to 3 inches provides a rich, full sound. Just play with the placement for your particular voice and situation and use your ears; you'll know when it sounds good and when it doesn't.The 50 Hz low frequency roll-off is an interesting choice. It helps eliminate deeper LF rumbling, while preserving a good amount of the lower octave of the voice for that chesty resonance. Most other mics either don't roll off at all, or they'll start to roll off at 80 or 120 Hz which tends to suck a little too much of the fullness out of a lot of voices. I think CAD made a wise choice choosing 50 Hz for this mic.Overall, it's a decent little mic with a lot of good going for it. Some people might need a slightly longer USB cable than the one provided, but for most people the one included will be fine. In my case it was barely long enough, but did work. Sound quality is decent and you'd be hard pressed to find anything audibly better at this price point. If you need a compact USB mic with low-latency monitoring and good sound quality, I really can't see any substantial reason not to recommend getting one of these and giving it a try.

Being the owner of a couple different Heil microphones (the Heil Goldline Pro and the Heil Heritage) which never fail to impress, I decided it was time to step up to the Heil PR-40 to see what it was capable of as well. I purchased the Heil PR-40 to serve a few different purposes, mainly as a new mic for my ham radio, but also for use in VOIP applications, and finally to use for recording narration for videos. It suits all of these purposes just fine, but of course I knew this already since the same source is used for all those applications, that being my voice.The mic itself is everything I would expect of a Heil microphone. It build ruggedly, and has a beautiful, flawless finish. The PR-40 comes in a padded leatherette carrying case that also holds the included mic clamp. The clamp has an adapter that screws in to allow the clamp to be used on different sized stands and boom arms. Also included was a Heil Sound decal. I have to say I'm disappointed the Heil mics don't come in the wooden presentation boxes they used to, but I am quite happy with the padded case they use now too.The XLR jack on the mic is a little tight, it took a lot of effort to get the Neutrik XLR connector on my mic cable to lock into place. Removing the o-ring from the Neutrik connector on the mic cable allows the cable to lock into the PR-40 with no effort, but I prefer the slight amount of compression the o-ring provides to help keep dust out as well as prevent any rattling.The thing about Heil mics is they pretty much occupy their own audio space in the world of mics. Nothing else comes close to sounding like a Heil mic, their timbre is unmistakable, but in a good way. A lot of people have trouble getting used to Heil mics because they're used to older design mics that need a lot of EQ to make them sound good. With Heil mics, they don't require an obscene amount of EQ to make them sound great, they pretty much sound great with the EQ set flat.What I really like about the Heil PR-40 is it has a slightly scooped mid-range that takes the nasal "honk" and stuffiness out of my voice. I've never used a mic that sounded so broadcast-ready right out of box, and much of that is helped by the extended low-frequency response (when compared to most other dynamic mics) that picks up more of the deep chest resonance of the person talking or singing into the mic. Of course, this also makes the mic more prone to picking up low frequency rumble, but installing the mic in the optional accessory shock mount takes care of that problem without having to EQ out the low frequencies, which EQ really should always be left as a last-ditch bandaid only anyways, as you're essentially EQ'ing out an entire octave of the human voice.Proximity effect is really sweet on this mic. With the PR-40 anything more than 6 inches away from the mouth starts sounding way too thin, with the sweet spot being around 2-4 inches from the grill. However, you can literally get your lips right up against the grill and the proximity effect is still controlled to the point that the bass never becomes too thick or muddy, the mic just takes on an extremely warm, intimate sound that is absolutely spectacular.Even though the mic comes with an internal sorbothane shock mounted capsule, the mic is still fairly prone to picking up low frequency through the mic stand or boom arm. I highly recommend getting the accessory shock mount to go with this mic, I guarantee it will make a world of difference.What can I say? I'm more impressed by the mic than I thought I would be. I can gladly say I have absolutely no buyer's remorse whatsoever. This one is definitely a keeper.

This is a very nice rice cooker overall, but there are a couple small issues that could be improved which I'll cover last. First of all, the brushed stainless finish is very pleasing to the eye and it goes nicely with the rest of my kitchen appliances. There are thoughtful little things like the carry handle, as well as the slots  on the sides to hold the included utensils.Functionally, the rice cooker is very easy to use. The included instruction manual is thorough and easy to understand. The included clock even holds the time while the unit is unplugged. So far I have used this cooker for white rice, brown rice, and sticky rice. It has cooked all of my rice selections wonderfully well, and without the hassle of conventional cooking. The convenience is absolutely worth it to me.Cleanup is a breeze. The coating in the cooker pot is very non-stick and any residue just wipes right out with a damp cloth; no scrubbing necessary.The reason I gave this rice cooker 4 stars instead of 5 is as follows:First, the sample I received has a slightly marred control panel. For an item of this price level, it should have had better quality inspection before it was boxed. While it doesn't affect the performance, it is an ugly blemish on what should have been a gorgeous kitchen appliance.Second, the feet are very slick. This cooker slides around on the counter-top effortlessly. A small child or a curious cat could easily send this thing careening off onto the floor with no problem whatsoever. It would have been nice if they had added some rubber feet or other grippy material to the base so that the cooker doesn't slide around so easily.

Black & Decker has a very nice slow cooker with this model. The stoneware pot does a great job of holding an even heat across the entire cooking area, and is also very easy to clean up. The tempered glass lid is vented enough where it meets the pot so that steam can escape with causing any rattling. The printed design on the cooker looks nice and fits in well enough with my kitchen decor.I am especially impressed with the sticky rubber feet that really grip smooth countertop surfaces, keeping the cooker exactly where you put it.I am not as impressed with the lid handle, main cooker handles, or the control knob. They have a very cheap feel about them. I'm not knocking off a star for this though, as they are performing fine so far and only time will tell as to their durability.

The compact size of this Eton FR1 radio is one of the major conveniences when stocking your emergency kit. The features are fairly basic for this model. AM/FM radio, WX radio, flashlight, and hand-crank. There is no solar cell on this model like others, but for most purposes it wouldn't be needed anyways.Reception is decent, though not great. There are other models from other brands at this price point that do a better job at receiving local FM and WX stations, but they are also more bulky. If you're in a rural area that might be a problem, but in more populated areas and major cities, the performance would be absolutely fine.The plastic housing on this radio is creaky, and not as durable or rugged feeling as the older models were. Whether that affects its longevity or durability has yet to be seen, but for an emergency product that will see infrequent use, I doubt it will pose any problems.The only real issue I have with this device is not the product itself, but the owner's manual. The manual lacks much in the way of detail or specifics. For instance, this device allows for charging it's internal battery from a USB power source. It does not, however, state whether it's okay to leave it plugged in permanently via USB to keep it topped off via a maintenance charge, or if this will cause the battery to overcharge thereby damaging it and shortening it's life. Including details like that in the instructions would be very helpful.Overall it's a good basic emergency radio. Not great, but certainly not bad either.

I've been slow to jump on the Swiffer bandwagon, but now that I've tried a couple of their products, I can say that they really are convenient and do a great job. This Sweep and Trap is really easy to load the disposable pad onto, and the soft little flippers really do a a great job of taking care of the bigger stuff first. The flippers only turn in the forward direction, but don't work in reverse (this is expected as the trap is on the rear only). The concept is similar to that of a carpet sweeper, only this is for hard floors. Using this first, and then following up with the Swiffer wet mop device makes for a really clean floor in no time at all.This device is really easy to steer around corners too, the special way the head pivots and swivels makes steering this thing at just about any angle possible.

I'm not usually one that takes well to rose fragrances, but this particular scent is absolutely intoxicating. I cannot express well enough just how much I like the scent. As for the soap, it is made by Pre de Provence, the same company that makes some of my favorite shave soaps and after shave balms. Knowing the brand so well, I had high expectations for this bar of body soap, and I can say without a doubt that it lives up to the fine reputation it's earned with me. The soap is quad-milled and creates a smooth, creamy lather that is top-notch. In hard water the lather isn't quite as rich, but it is still much nicer than the typical run of the mill drugstore brand soaps. This soap rinses well without leaving any sticky feeling, and leaves the skin soft and moisturized with no need for lotion afterwards.

These training gloves are probably not going to last through too many training sessions. The seams are very poorly done and will likely start to split after a few uses. The padding is good, but not great. They are comfortable, and they feel very ergonomic. They don't breathe very well at all, the ventilation is extremely limited. A good pair of training gloves will allow bursts of air to enter to allow your hands to breath and not become sweat-soaked, but these tend to get very hot in a hurry. They may be advertised as "pro style", but they perform nothing like a pro pair of gloves would. Given the price of these, you can't really expect pro-quality performance though.

Probelle says this product will help stop nail biting and thumb sucking. As long as you keep reapplying it vigilantly it will be effective at reducing those bad habits due its bitter taste. This stuff wears off really quickly though. Put it on the thumb of a child, first suck will  taste nasty and they'll recoil and stop, but two minutes later they'll be sucking away again as the flavor has been washed off / worn off by their saliva. Same with nail biters, really. So yes, this does work, but only in a very limited way and you have to be willing and able to constantly reapply the product.

This little children's adventure vest is really cute. The breathable mesh back means your child can wear this even in warm weather without getting overheated. The pockets are plenty large, allowing your junior adventurer to pack along a pair of binoculars, a compass, and some other necessary gear. The seams are all well finished and the product appears to be made quite durable. It should stand up to a couple seasons worth of adventures without any problems.

This bluetooth speaker is really ruggedly made. The metal and plastic housing is extremely sturdy as well as weather resistant. The controls are very easy to use thanks to the large buttons, and the buttons require a firm press to activate so that there are no accidental changes. Connecting the bluetooth was effortless and took just a couple of seconds.Braven says you can get up to 15 hours from a single charge, and this seems right on with normal usage. Constant playing of  music or using it as a speakerphone for extended periods will of course shorten the battery duration significantly.Sound quality is really good, the unit produces a full sound that can get pretty loud without any distortion. I'm very pleased with the sound quality from such a small unit.The access panel has a flip lock that is weather resistant and quite secure. The entire design of this thing is really well thought out. I'm planning on getting a lot of use out of this baby.

These are very comfortable, as comfortable as regular underwear. They flex and move with you like regular underwear. They don't bunch up nearly as badly as some of the older designs did, but some bunching of the absorbent material is unavoidable if you're active. These are practically undetectable under normal clothing as well, bringing a whole new level of discreet to wearing them. These are great for people who have light to moderate leakage problems. Odor control is well managed as well.

My dog really likes Waggin' Train treats. He likes these mini jerky treats a lot too, however I'm only allowing him one of these treats per week. I'm a little leery of them, because they are a product of China, and there is a lot of stuff going around about tainted products from China harming pets. While Purina has a quality control standard that they post for the world to see, I'm still not 100% confident in giving these to my dog on a regular basis. I really wish Purina would use domestically sourced resources for its products.

It is pretty much a given that you can't expect the power and performance of a two-cycle gas engine from a battery powered tool. However, for a lot of chores around the home and land you don't always need the added weight or power of a gas engine. That's where this Scott's chainsaw comes in. It is great for cutting down saplings and removing low hanging branches from trees. Don't expect it to take down 8" diameter oaks though, as this thing will definitely choke on those. When applying a little common sense to using the right tool for the right job, this tool definitely has it's place and usefulness. The battery life is seems to be okay, it hasn't run out juice during work sessions, and I make it point to recharge the battery each time I finish a job so it's good to go for the next.I only give this 4 out of 5 stars though, as the construction feels a little flimsy, the plastic creaks and flexes more than I'd like. I also had to sharpen the chain before the first use as it was relatively dull right out of the box.  Other than that, it's a good light-duty tool for those that don't need the power or longer bar length of a gas chainsaw.

While it's still too early to know if this is going to have any tangible, lasting benefit, the LED device does at least give the face a nice warm massage. The science behind the product says that it stimulates an increase in collagen. While this holds true for very expensive professional treatments, this handheld device skirts the lower limits of what might be considered ineffective. Time will tell, but I'm not going to down-rate a product based on an unknown. What the device does do for certain is make your face feel good. The shape of the unit allows for a comfortable grip that is easy to control while using. If I would complain about any one thing, it would be the power cord could stand to be a little longer.

I was skeptical of this camping pad, thinking the design would make it be uncomfortable. I'm happy to say I was wrong with my skepticism, and this camping pad has turned out to be something I don't want to be without when I'm out camping. This thing is very comfortable to sleep on.The small, lightweight design makes packing it into camp a breeze as the storage size when not inflated is relatively compact. Because of it's design, it can be used either inside or underneath a sleeping bag, but I've found I prefer it to be inside a roomy sleeping bag for the most comfort. The design allows air pockets to be formed that help keep the body at a comfortable temperature, neither too warm nor too cool. If you're one who sweats a lot in their sleep, this will definitely be a help in keeping you from getting damp and clammy or feeling like you're stewing in your own sweat.I've not owned this long enough to speak of it's durability, but it seems to be a well made product and I expect no problems out of it for the foreseeable future.

I like this cookbook a lot. The recipes are named after various sci-fi and fantasy foods and drinks from television and movies. The various recipes do a good job of emulating the look of what you see in the shows. It is absolutely a fun novelty cookbook that is a perfect bookcase edition to every sci-fi lover's collection. The recipes themselves are well written and easy to understand, but many of them have some very odd ingredient combinations you just don't see anywhere else. The recipes cover a vast array of different movies and shows, so don't be surprised if you only see one recipe in the entire cookbook for your preferred program.

Bastards: A Memoir is a masterfully told story. The dysfunctional nature of the family life portrayed is certainly no laughing matter, but it does provide for some very interesting food for thought. Mary Anna King did a delightful job turning a unique situation into something we can all learn from. As I sat and read the book, I found time passed by faster than I intended, as the book is very hard to put down. The story of her life is gripping, but so is her ability to capture and hold the reader's attention. I've read several memoirs over the past year, but none were as fascinating, or memorable as this one.

The color of this blue black is very striking, and does a great job of blending in the grey hairs. Clairol Natural Instincts Crema Keratina Hair Color goes on easy and doesn't smell nearly as bad as the hair colorings of years past did. The colors come out rich and vibrant, and hold up fairly well, though you have to make a conscious effort not to overwash your hair, even with dye friendly shampoos. The instructions are clear and easy to understand, and anyone who's ever colored their hair will pretty much know the drill with this one as well. The only drawback is that like most do-it-yourself blue-black colorings, the bluish sheen fades within a week and you're left with more of a dull, flat black.

Honestly, it's a piece of thin plastic the size of a postage stamp. It adheres to whatever phone case you want to stick it to. Then a special holder you purchase separately clamps on to the tiny little plastic square; it's about three cents worth of plastic. The blister packaging that it comes in would cost more to produce than the product itself. Keep that in mind when considering the cost of this thing. As far as function goes, it works okay, it's mates up easily with the other things you have to buy for it in order to make it work as a system.

Clairol Nice n Easy hair color is really easy to apply. The product doesn't smell too bad, but you'll still want to be in a well ventilated area. The color comes out vibrant and full of life and last a good long while before starting to fade, but this one doesn't take to my gray hairs very well at all. I realize gray hairs are some of the hardest to take color and hold it, but overall this is one of the worst I've tried in that regard. As far as the instructions go, if you've colored your hair before, you pretty much know the routine. If you are new to coloring your hair, the instructions are printed clearly and are very easy to understand.

The natural brown color of this is almost a perfect match for my natural hair color, and does a great job of blending in the grey hairs. Clairol Natural Instincts Crema Keratina Hair Color goes on easy and doesn't smell nearly as bad as the hair colorings of years past did. The colors come out rich and vibrant, and hold up fairly well, though you have to make a conscious effort not to overwash your hair, even with dye friendly shampoos. The instructions are clear and easy to understand, and anyone who's ever colored their hair will pretty much know the drill with this one as well.

This is, in my opinion, a well thought out design that is easy to use and functions as intended. It is designed not only for the best penetration and fast, human kill, but also designed so that the sportsman can easily remove the broadhead without doing more damage to the flesh. Though I'm relatively new to the sport of bowfishing, I've found this easy to use yet effective design perfect for what I want. Even the seasoned bowfisherman who had been teaching me was impressed by the design.

This is one of those Teriyaki sauces that is sweet, yet not strong in flavor. It is not meant to be a super-authentic style sauce, but one of those food-service sauces that can please the masses. The flavor of the sauce is not unpleasant, in fact it is designed so that it can go with quite a number of different things without overpowering the dish. Versatility, not authenticity is what makes this sauce a go to for so many things.

This Cuisinart CTR-140 Non-Stick Taco Grilling Rack is really impressive. It is heavy duty in design, meaning it will hold up to the intense heat of a grill for years to come. The non-stick surface seems to do an excellent job of not allowing anything to stick to the surface. While this works great on my Weber charcoal grill, it also can be used in the oven with equal success. The slotted design seems to allow for better heat transfer to the outsides of the tortilla shells, while also allowing for a whimsical design to be charred into to the sides of each tortilla. Grilled tacos sound odd, but once you've tried them you'll be hooked!

This is a very tasty sauce, yet mild. Its mild flavor makes it excellent for dipping or drizzling over foods, as well as an excellent marinade. There are plenty of more "authentic" sauces out there, but this one is very pleasing and the mildness of it makes it suitable for a wide variety of uses. It even makes for a good glaze for vegetables going onto the grill. Overall an excellent addition to the kitchen.

These are great clippers. They work much better than the standard drug store clippers I've been using all my life. They are sharp, precise, and my thumb doesn't go sliding off the lever mid-cut. The build quality of these seems to be excellent. The catch feature is a bit gimmicky, I still end up with more nail trimmings going everywhere else. Finish up with a quick filing and you're good to go. These are a definite upgrade from the run-of-the-mill clippers you see everywhere.

This is a good, lightweight scanner for general consumer use. It's small footprint and light weight make it easy to set up, and the controls are equally easy to use. It does a good enough scanning job for most hobby uses by the average consumer. Scan speed is decent as well. The supplied cords could be a little longer though, they are a bit on a short side.Scan quality is the main thing. It's scan quality is very good, but not excellent. Fine for making copies of documents, or old snapshots to share online. It does not match the quality of professional level scanner though, so if you're into preserving or restoring photos and need the sharpest scans possible, you likely won't be satisfied. This isn't a pro scanner, nor does it claim to be. Just be aware of that when making your purchase and you'll not be disappointed.Overall it is an excellent hobbyist scanner and it will surely please. Certainly worthy of a 5-star rating given it's market segment.

This unit replaced a much older entry level Fellowes paper shredder that I bought many years ago. While the old one still worked fine after years of nearly daily use, I was glad to set it aside and give this new model a try. This model comes with it's own basket to catch the paper shreds, which is very convenient and more secure than the adjustable slider on the old one. The noise level is about the same, there is no mistaking this one is running. Since the shredder covers the entire basket, it adds a more refined look to my office area. The window near the top of the basket is great for seeing when the unit needs emptying.This shredder is very efficient at shredding paper and cross-cutting it, which makes for a more secure shred and harder to reconstruct. (Always reminds me of the Penguin in the Batman movie "a little patience and a LOT of tape.") Though I haven't tried shredding at max capacity, it handles 5 sheets of standard copy paper at a time just fine. Does a number on unopened junk mail too, which would jam up the old unit half the time.The safety lock is a nice additional feature on this shredder. Especially when the cats try to use it as a jumping platform.My only nitpick is the power cord isn't all that long. It would have saved me an extension cord if the power cord would have been about 2 feet longer.

These are very comfortable shoes. I have had no problem wearing them all day long. My feet stay comfortable with no tired or sore feeling at the end of the day. They have a moderate amount of arch support, which is good for my flat feet. They have a decent amount of grip on damp grass, I don't feel like my feet are slipping around. My only complaint with these shoes is that they don't breathe as much as I'd like.

It's a spark plug. All it does is make a spark when a current from the coil is sent and it arcs across the gap. As a spark plug, it works fine. But it is no magic bullet. It doesn't create any extra horsepower or cause you to have better fuel economy. Any seat of the pants feel is purely psychological. Any real improvement would likely be due to the sparks plugs they replaced having the electrode worn and gap set incorrectly, or the electrodes fouled. With that said, I see no reason why to not use these spark plugs if you can get them for a good price, they'll perform as well as any of the major brands out there. Just don't expect them to live up to any wild snake-oil-esque performance claims.

I have been fighting moss around my crepe myrtles for years. Just as soon as I think I've gotten rid of it all, it ends up coming right back and spreading even further. Thanks to this Scotts Turf Builder with Moss Control, the moss is gone and has stayed gone! This stuff is a real godsend for soggy northern Florida where the high humidity really gets the moss growing everywhere. Finally I've got grass growing where the moss was taking over.

I've tried over and over to write a long review about how much I liked this book, but the truth of the matter is, I just keep getting lost for words on this one. The book is incredibly insightful, sobering, and thought provoking. The author goes into a great amount of detail about his life and his journey to recovery. The fact that I share many of the same interests as the author probably helped me to relate to him a little bit deeper than a lot of people might. One thing is for sure though, it was an emotional struggle, undoubtedly torturous at times. The fact that he was able to pull through and how he got through it is an amazing feat. Highly recommended reading for those with an interest in the topic.

I really didn't know what to expect from the LeapFrog LeapTV Educational Gaming System. I had a hunch the youngin's would take to it straight away though, and I wasn't wrong. There is a variety of programs available to run on this system and the number of titles is supposed to be increasing over the next year or so. The system covers a pretty good range of ages, so your kid won't likely outgrow for a number of years.The system comes with clearly written, easy to understand instructions, as well as everything you need to be up and running in just minutes. Installation is literally as easy as 123, and soon enough you'll be watching your kid learn and have fun. There is even a bit of whole body physical activity involved in some of the activities, which is always a good thing.Overall a pretty impressive system that should make a good addition to any home with young children.

I've always had excellent, trouble-free performance from TP-Link networking products. They always seem to perform with stability, never needing reset or rebooted. This dual band range extender is another networking product I've had great results with. Following the included instructions, which are well written and easy to understand, I was able to have this product up and running in just a few minutes time. This range extender was just what I needed to extend the wireless from my house out to my workshop building, which is on the same circuit. Now I am able to access online data and plans from my workshop instead of having to run back over to the house to look up information online. This is a great convenience and a major time saver.

I have a lot of trouble getting into the majority of Sci-Fi books, but Lightless was an incredibly good book. I have to admit, I lost a few hours sleep a couple nights in a row because I was too into reading the story to want to put it down and go to sleep. Author C.A. Higgins has done an exemplary job of putting the reader right into the middle of the action. You don't just feel like you're an observer, you feel like you're a part of the story.I was pleasantly surprised by the number of twists and turns. The unpredictability of the story far outweighed my expectations. Just when you think you've got everything figured out, you get tossed another curve ball. It really does make for a suspenseful story that's incredibly fun to read. Combine that with the steady pace of the book, which doesn't feel slow, but doesn't feel rushed either. In fact, the pace of the book feels deliberately calculated to be such that you can absorb tons of details without feeling overwhelmed, or bored either.I'm very excited to see what other works C.A. Higgens has up her sleeve.

This is a very solidly made dehumidifier. Here in Florida, especially during the rainy season like it is now, our central air just doesn't kick on enough to keep the humidity levels in the 40-60% range in parts of the house. I set this unit up in the laundry area which is the main problem room and it has done an excellent job at quietly keeping the humidity level down to a reasonable level. This is especially important at helping to prevent mold and mildew growth.The unit is very easy to set up and maintain. The instructions were well written in a clear and concise manner. I'm very happy with the performance of this dehumidifier.

Avery makes a ton of useful things for getting organized. This binder is one of the more fun things they have. The kitchen design is classic and whimsical, everyone in my household mentioned how fun looking it was. The binder itself is of average quality, it is not flimsy, but it is also not heavy-duty. The rings inside open and close firmly, but not stubbornly. There are also a few handy conversions in the pocket sleeves on the inside of the covers.

After thoroughly cleaning the trim pieces, simply mask off the painted areas around the trim you want to restore to black, protecting it from the messy overspray, and you're good to go. It's really that easy to apply and it makes the black trim on vehicles look as good as new again. This product, like all Meguiar's products, are excellent and long lasting. I generally prefer to use Meguiar's products on all my vehicles because it always performs well.

Scotts Turf Builder Southern Gold mix doesn't seem to do too well here in northern Florida. It browns out to a nice golden color if not kept well watered, and it definitely does a lot better in shade. It just doesn't seem to handle full sun around here at all. If you're the type that only lets the natural rain water your lawn, you're going to have a lot of dead grass. This grass is for the lawn maintenance zealots that can't go a day without sprinkling their lawn.

I really liked how easy it was to get this grass seed started. It seems to be heat resistant enough to handle full sun here in Florida, though it tends to start browning out a little faster than some varieties during an extended dry spell. With that in mind, this is the grass for you if you're a regular with keeping up with watering. On the other hand, if you're a water-miser, you might consider looking elsewhere.

I tend not to give very many books a five star rating because I'm such a nitpicky reader. If the story doesn't completely gel, if the ending feels too rushed, or if the characters are generic and one-sided, it all just takes away from what should have been a wonderful journey of book reading. Consume managed to tick all of the boxes for me and earn that coveted 5-star review. Now, this isn't a book report, I'm not going to sit here and ruin the story for you by giving you a TL;DR play by play of the important plot points. What I will say is this book is fantastically fun to read. It held my attention from the start and didn't let go even after finishing the last page. The wording is artfully styled, I hesitate to say a "beautiful prose", but it is far from dry reading. The characters are well developed and each one has its own personality that you'll love or hate. Everything about this book shows that the author put a lot of time and effort into crafting a memorable and enjoyable story.

I bought these for a 2013 Nissan Xterra.  Amazon's "Garage" function indicated these would not fit my vehicle.  I checked with Rugged Ridge, and they assured me they would in fact, fit. They are extremely nice, and fit perfectly.  There is another brand out there that costs about 2X as much, and I can't imagine they would be 2X as good.  After all, it IS just a floor mat!  Just a really nicely-made, mud-containing, grease-holding, spill-trapping, non-slipping, near-perfect floor mat.

I bought this trimmer to replace an almost-identical Conair trimmer (model GMT170B) I bought 10 years ago.  The old one had finally become dull.  Do yourself a favor and forget the rechargeable models...AA battery-operated trimmers are the way to go.This trimmer works as well as the old one.  It is slightly noisier, but not bothersome.  The beard trimming head snaps off and a nose/ear trimming blade easily snaps on (my old model did not do noses).  Both implements function very well.Complaint:  The adjustable blade guard fits **VERY** tight.  It is a real struggle to move it it.  It feels like you are going to break it.  IT IS WAY TOO TIGHT!  If you break the guard, you will be out of business.Can't beat the price...if it lasts three years I will get my money's worth.

Part arrived very quickly from supplier.  No trouble there.  Supplied motor was a perfect mechanical replacement for the motor in a 25 year-old Kenmore dryer.  My old motor had no wiring harness or plug; all the wires were connected individually.Had the usual trouble (read other reviews) getting the blower fan off.  No need for it to be that tight, considering the fan and threads are made of plastic with a square mounting shaft.  It is incredibly easy to round this shaft off, no matter how careful you are.  Believe it or not, I had to finally use an air impact wrench on the front motor shaft to remove the fan.Part came with two sets of wiring instructions...one larger and one smaller, apparently identical copies of each other.  Followed the wiring instructions, would not start.  Two frustrating hours later, examined both sets of instructions with a magnifying glass, and noted that they were completely identical, except for the placement of one wire!!  Of course this was after I had made all the wiring modifications, and used up all the weirdo wire terminals supplied.The instructions and wiring diagrams are not just terrible; they are misleading...even for a relatively handy person.  BTW, the instructions that were "correct" for my dryer were the "small" ones.Motor is tremendously loud, to the point where you would swear something is wrong.  I actually took the back of the dryer off to see if anything else was amiss.  Nothing else is wrong, it's just LOUD.  Really LOUD.

These cameras are amazing! Until I started doing some research, I had no idea these cameras each encompassed a tiny computer and web server!  My mind was still back in the day when analog video went down a wire.I studied the reviews of this camera here on Amazon for a couple of hours, trying to figure out where most of the snags and pitfalls were, in advance of ordering.  For example, here is a handy tip from another user: "If you want to use the preset camera positions you MUST first uncheck the "disable preset" box in the PTZ menu under Administrator."  You could spend hours trying to figure out the 'presets' without that little tiny tip.  Thank you!  Once I compiled a list of things like that that were likely to go wrong, and fixes for them, I ordered two cameras.It took me a couple of hours to get two of these set up, with my bare-bones knowledge of IP's, routers, and networking.You have to take the setup step-by-step, and test between steps!  Don't try to do it all at once! Once you get one function working, proceed to the next level.  There is a lot of useful information written in straight English on the Foscam site, so I hardly looked at the manual.The little program they supply called 'IP Camera Tool' is incredibly useful in getting things set up.I did NOT use the CD.  I just downloaded the latest firmware from Foscam, and updated that on the cameras once they were hooked up (one at a time) thru the ethernet cable.  There are two parts to the firmware, a "System Firmware" and a "Web UI" firmware. Update both. My cameras were one version behind.I was able to get video through the ethernet cable in a couple of minutes.  I set mine up as fixed IP's so their IP addresses would be a different numerical series than computers, but you don't have to do that if you don't know how.  Wireless setup was easy; once you set the IP, enable wireless, and reboot (the camera), you should pull the ethernet (NOT the power) cable.  The cam should then communicate by wireless after a minute or so.  Once the wireless was working, it was easy to set the motion alarm.  Once I got the motion alarm going, I had the system start emailing images to me (had the camera trained on a busy suburban street).  In order to test the email settings, you have to hit SUBMIT before you hit TEST, another little tip.
