You just have to be sure to cut the tip opening smaller than you think when you start and cut larger if needed and dial in the flow control based on the caulk. 100% silicone is a breeze even with a tiny tip cut. The flow control is easy to adjust on the fly. The real test came with polyurethane caulk which requires Hulk hands to dispense from a hand powered caulk gun. It worked great with the polyurethane caulk.It has a "reversing" mechanism that requires some getting used to because if your hand slips off the trigger, it pulls the plunger back immediately and when you restart, it can leave a big caulk blob when it starts again. The "con" for this unit is the weight - if you have to hold it overhead, it gets heavy fast. I'm no lightweight - 225 pound weigh lifter and hockey player and it's a lot of work using this for 15 minutes overhead. I also wish it came with 2 batteries not one because it's pretty pricey. Overall, if you have a LOT of caulking to do with heavy bodied caulks, this is a decent investment but it's not perfect.

I bought these for a Keurig K-155 machine which the description includes as a machine in which these filters allegedly work. I tried two different filters using multiple grinds of coffee from medium drip to very coarse drip using a Capresso grinder with fresh coffee beans. I used 3 different cup sizes, 4,6 and 8 ounces and both filters leaked like mad, pouring hot water out the sides and leaking into the cup. Regardless of cup size, the coffee tasted lousy - really weak, regardless of grind or how high or low I filled the filter with coffee. A total let down. They might work fine in other Keurig machines but in a K-155, they stink.I tried a 3rd filter and finally, with a very coarse grind, it sort of worked. It finally didn't leak hot water all over like the first two filters and it required a very coarse grind to flow properly. I'm not sure how the coffee really tasted because I had hit "taste fatigue" after grinding a 1/4 pound of coffee and making about 20 cups of coffee. I poured 19 cups down the drain after a few sips but I think the 20th cup was OK. So if you are going to buy these for a K-155, buy the 6 pack because 2/3 of them won't work. I may return all of them tomorrow after I clear my palate and try the one filter that actually worked. I'll also try the other three filters I have not used yet. Quality control with these filters is obviously not high.All I want is a simple one cup coffee maker that doesn't require proprietary company pods that cannot be recycled and are an impending ecological disaster.  If anyone has a reusable filter pod that works with a Keurig K-155 machine, guidance on a great one cup coffee maker (The Bunn MCU?) or a recyclable/degradable Keurig style pod that isn't absurdly expensive, please let me know. Thanks!

For my money, Battery Tenders are the standard in the industry for float chargers and maintenance of any type of battery from lawnmowers to cars to motorcycles. I have Battery Tenders I've had for ten years and they still run perfect. I needed a new one for my AGM (absorbed glass mat) battery in my cycle and this works great at a solid price from Amazon

Well made, fit as expected. I'm a 38" waist and the XL were ideal. The waist band lays flat and does not roll up as has occurred with other Under Armour boxer briefs I have bought. These wear really well and retain their elasticity for a long time.

Heavy duty 6" adjustable drain cover with 100% stainless steel mounting hardware. This is a well made drain cover that has small "feet" that hold it off the ground about 1/8" so the cover will not interfere with even a small amount of water reaching the drain. It's probably 16 gauge stainless steel. The mounting system is 4 metal clips that are held to the grate via stainless screws and nuts and are adjustable in the long slots seen the picture. I could see where this mounting system might be problematic if your drain is cup shaped or rounded. The mounting clips require about 2 inches of straight drain side walls to fit really well. I wound up reversing the clips to allow it to fit a 4" drain in a tile floor but it worked out OK.
If you pay $174 for this set you're smoking dope....

A bit too small for the shredded memory foam pillows I bought from Amazon. It's a challenge to change the pillow covers due to their less than generous size. I'm no pillow case expert but the material seems pretty average to me.

Simple to use, effective saline nasal rinse. Great for allergies, head colds or general nasal stuffiness. Use care and low pressure when utilizing the rinse so you don't force it into your sinuses - it will come running out of your nose later when you lean over!

This was my original 1 star review (be sure to read the addendum I added at the bottom of this review!):The Amazon wiper size chart by make and model is wrong for this Trico exact fit blade. My wife has a 2014 WRX 5 door Limited (regular WRX, NOT and STI) and the "find your wiper size" chart is wrong. It says the WRX Limited car takes a 12" rear blade and it really takes a 16" blade. The sizing chart says the ONLY Subaru WRX's that takes a 16" rear blade are the STI and the STI limited.So now I have a 12" peewee wiper blade that will cost me more to send back than buying a new blade that is the right size. Very aggravating but the lesson learned is wait until the wife gets home from work with the car and measure the blades before ordering rather than trusting the vehicle fitment charts on Amazon. I'll go the local NAPA store instead and make sure I get the right blade that I can easily exchange if it's the wrong size or blade mount.ADDENDUM/UPDATE - OK, I wrote a 1 star review because the Amazon wiper blade fitment chart was wrong and I ordered the wrong blade because of that error in Amazon's fitment system. Then I changed it to 5 stars after Amazon did something very cool - read on to find out what they did.I went to the "return item" section on the Amazon return page and entered "description on website was not accurate" which sums up the problem. I wanted to register the fact that their system told me to order the wrong blade even if I had to eat the $12 I paid. When I got to end of the return process, Amazon said I did not have to return the blade. OK, so now I have to extract my size 11 foot from my mouth and say thanks to Amazon for being cool and not making me ship back the incorrect blade and pay the postage.I shot a photo of my laptop screen showing that the fitment chart tells me that the 12" blade fits the 2014 WRX Limited and another photo of the 12" blade on top of the original equipment 16" blade so you can see that the ordering chart was wrong and that the 12" peewee blade is indeed incorrect. But, as I explained, Amazon made all of this go away by simply giving me an instant credit and not making me pay the postage to return the incorrect blade. Got to get to work pulling that size 11 out of my mouth.....As for the blade itself - it is exactly the same as the one on the 2014 WRX limited 5 door, it's just 4" too short and the 16" blade will be ideal when I order it. Just to be CERTAIN, I took the old blade off and mounted the 12" blade to be sure it REALLY fit and it did. So I'll order the 16" Trico exact fit 16B blade from Amazon and say thanks again for standing behind your customers and your products!

REALLY disappointed that iXCC has changed around the size of the plastic tip on the lightning end and made it larger than the previous ones they sold. I bought this to fit my LifeProof Fre case for my iPhone 6 and it won't fit. I was going to send them back but I wound up swapping them with my wife who has a different phone case that will work with the larger tips. If you own a LifeProof Fre case DO NOT buy these power cords! Otherwise they work fine but I'm taking 3 stars off for increasing the size of the lightning tip housing.

I was a competitive swimmer since the 1970's - before they "invented" real swim goggles like these and I worn every brand you can name (Speedo, Tyr, Swim Fit and Nike) over the ensuing decades. These "Friendly Swede" goggles are absolutely the finest fitting, best performing and the first totally fog proof swim goggles I have ever used.A few notes on the "Friendly Swede" models - the black set have dark lenses if you are swimming outside and want some sunlight protection for your eyes, the black set works well. The other pair are totally clear. The side vision is good on both. The straps are comfortable and they fit me perfect right out of the box. Speaking of the box, each pair has it's own carrying hard shell carrying case which is great because my old goggles are scratched up from rattling around loose in my swim bag.The fit was important for me because I have a large, round face and a lot of goggles just don't fit me well. These were perfect. They don't leak, fog up or misbehave in any manner. Overall, a solid purchase at an excellent price and I highly recommend them.

I wear a size 8 hat. It's tough to get a swim cap to fit without feeling like my eyeballs are going top pop out of their sockets. I looked at the various Amazon swim cap choices and I took a shot on the "Friendly Swede" brand. I have used them a few times since the purchase, The caps are brightly colored, tough, have a lot of stretch and fit me well. I dunked the cap in the pool and it went on my 6.3mm hair with no problems. I don't know how these would work if you have long hair or dreadlocks but for my large cranium, they fit fine.I don't care if my hair or head get wet, it's not an issue for me so I can't comment on that if you are truly looking for a "dry" swim cap. My "old school" head crushing silicone cap is going in the trash barrel tonight and I'm going to give the "Friendly Swede" goggles a shot and see how they perform.
Great quality cutter - the best on the market. Hard to believe they can produce this level of quality for this price. I use it with my Oster 76 clipper.

The description is technically accurate - it says two grill plates and one griddle plate but what that means is that only one of the plates is smooth - the other two plates are grooved. The flat plate also only fits on the right side, it is not interchangeable with the left hand grill plate. It has a full length opening between the grill/griddle plates that is about 1/2" wide and the drip tray is directly underneath that opening. The plates remove and replace with equal ease. It heats quickly and I bought this for doing panini, reubens, pancakes and eggs. If you want a large, unbroken smooth griddle surface, buy the All Clad 99014 20x13 griddle. I figured this unit had more utility than a dedicated panini press and I already own the 99014 so for me the double grill plates were welcomed.It is typical high end All-Clad quality, the non-stick surface is very well done and drip tray is full length between the plates. It's very easy to clean, heats up quickly and unless you are trying to blacken something, it gets really hot. It is very good with panini and grilled cheese sandwiches and especially with eggs. I have not tried bacon yet. The highest temperature setting is "sear" which is above the 450 degree setting. I'll update this review as I get more experience with the unit. The reason I gave it 4 stars is for the ambiguity in the description - it can easily lead someone to think it has two flat panel inserts and one grooved plate which is NOT accurate. I think the description should be better written so folks don't accidentally order this thinking it is like a traditional flat griddle. The 1/2 space between the plates is not clearly disclosed wither and you want to make large pancakes, it can't be done on this unit without spilling into the drip tray.Overall it's a high quality unit that I bought for almost half off at an external site so it was worth it for me. But be warned, this is not a full flat griddle and it has a 1/2 gap between the middle of the plates1/1/15 Update - Contrary to other opinions and reviews, this unit sears very well as long as you use a bit of olive oil, butter or other oils on whatever you are trying to sear, especially boneless chicken. Don't use spray oils like Pam - they will void the nonstick warranty. One "warning" based on actual experience. I grill a lot of Jamaican jerk chicken and used the griddle along with the very excellent and spicy Walkerswood Jerk marinade. I had the griddle on "sear" and the spices in the jerk marinade aerosolized and it was like opening a can of Mace in my kitchen. We literally had to eat dinner in another room while I used a fan to clear the air. If you plan to sear very spicy food, think twice or do it outside.I have quickly grown to favor this unit. It heats fast, is easy to clean and it cooks fast. It works well for pancakes, chicken, bacon and Panini. I plan to try steaks soon. The non-jerk chicken I cooked (marinated in a locally produced Italian salad dressing) was excellent - restaurant quality, better than my charcoal fired Grill Dome Kamado smoker. More to come as I gain experience and clear my lungs after the jerk chicken incident.

There was a lot of notes about how big this hat is for most users. Not for me - it's tight. I have a head like a Martian Brain Man - 7 3/4 and this is tight. If you have a really big melon, larger than 7 3/4 - don't buy this, it will be too small. Otherwise it's great quality.

If you can get this screen protector in place with perfect alignment and no bubbles, it's 5 stars. I read and followed the kit directions to the letter. From what I read it looked pretty simple to install but it wasn't. I was really careful but I still can't get a few small bubbles out from under this protector. Make sure you have the glass cover PERFECTLY aligned with the screen because there is almost zero room for error.  You also need to be certain the Surface screen is ABSOLUTELY clean and I don't think the kit supplied moist towelette and the lint free cloth are good enough.Per the directions, DO NOT TOUCH THE ADHESIVE SIDE ON THE SCREEN PROTECTOR FOR ANY REASON because it will leave a mark that you cannot remove from the adhesive side. In an attempt to be super careful, I also wore a pair of new, dust free vinyl gloves. As I was trying to align the screen, it slipped a tiny bit and I accidentally touched the adhesive side - instant, indelible mark. I don't think gloves are totally necessary because if you touch the adhesive side with or without gloves, it still leaves a mark.I would also recommend that you have a can of computer dust-off handy and give the screen on the Surface a quick shot of that compressed air after using the moist towelette and the lint free cloth.  Work in an area with really good lighting, no dust and absolutely no air movement. Now that I have experience with one of these covers I could get the next one on perfectly and I think you can as well as long as you are prepared to be really patient and methodical prior to the installation. I would have rated this higher if the installation process didn't require such high precision and additional measures (the compressed can of air) not mentioned in the directions.Once in place, it's an awesome screen - very clear and super touch responsive and if you can get it in place without incident, it would be a 5 star product but I was aggravated enough with the incomplete installation instructions and the actual process to knock off two stars.

I have bought 4 or 5 of these cables between 25 feet and 50 feet long for connecting a modem to a TV or for gaming connections. Never a problem, excellent data transmission, awesome pricing and a solid, molded connector at each end. Similar cords are $30-$40 at electronics specialty stores. One of the best deals on Amazon.

I bought this case directly from Lifeproof in mid-November 2014 because Amazon did not stock it until after December 5, 2014 or so. I bought the belt clip about six months later when it became available. I decided to condense my prior evaluations into a simpler "pro" and "con" format with some comments and a summary.Pros:Thin, good screen clarity, mostly functional buttons (except the initial cases mute button - more on that shortly), waterproof, shock resistant, fingerprint reader cover that works better than one on the Otterbox Defender. "Free" shipping. I paid $79.99 for this case and now it's down to $60. When you see a price drop like this it means that demand is waning.Cons:High price even at $60. Biggest issue for me is the screw-in easy to lose/forget "extension cable" required for most headphones and ear buds. Lifeproof made this choice to retain a waterproof case seal. You can't plug most ear buds into this case without the extension cord except for a pair of Bose ear buds I have that just happen to fit without the Fre cable. The sound mute button was useless on my first case but after the button finally came off after messing with it constantly to get it to work, Lifeproof honored their 1 year warranty and sent me a new case. The mute button on the new case works fine.  If you bought the Apple branded converter for the iPhone 4s to the lightning power tip, it won't work with this case unless you remove the phone from the case (a total pain). The case has a tendency to separate when used with the Lifeproof belt clip and I noticed some damage to the case from the Lifeproof belt clip on the side of the Fre case after a few months of use.Wish list for Lifeproof:  I wish Lifeproof would make the headphone pigtail cable about 2-3 inches long and self-contained in either the belt clip or the case itself so it's always available. I wish the belt clip had a backer plate like the OtterBox belt clip. The three points of contact design with the open back of the current case leaves the back of the phone exposed and to prone to getting knocked out of the case. The phone mostly commonly pops off the belt holder when I'm getting out of the car and I've fished it out from between the seat and console at least 15 times.A little known fact is that the iPhone 6 Fre case WILL fit in the OtterBox Defender belt clip for the iPhone 6 - it doesn't feel 100% secure but I had been rolling with that setup for about 6 months with not a single drop as long as you insert the Fre case into the Defender belt clip with the volume buttons facing down towards the ground.Summary - Slim design and basically a decent case but it's over priced with a quirky mute button and annoying extension cable for headphones and a belt clip that does not hold the phone securely. If you require a waterproof phone case, this case is worth the premium but if you keep the phone in your pocket or carry it in a bag or purse, keep looking for a lower priced alternative or go back to Otterbox which is what I did this past week after I grew weary of the phone falling out of the open back belt Lifeproof belt clip. It's two stars because it's over priced, quirky, the belt clip design makes it prone to falling out and required headphone cable is annoying.PS - I greatly appreciate the "manufacturers comment" from 9 months ago telling me about the "new color options" and that they would provide updates on product improvements. A bright color would help me find the phone after it falls out of the belt clip. I have seen ONE improvement made by Lifeproof in their case - the mute button cover. Lifeproof FINALLY quit censoring reviews on their own website. I suspect that was due to the real world reviews from Amazon. Bottom line is that if a waterproof case is a must for you, this is a good case but for me, it has too many shortcomings and quirks that do not justify the price point.

I wasted $50 on a metal oil can for olive oil that I bought on Amazon and it dripped and eventually leaked around the seams. I needed some sort of oil dispenser because I cook every day and I picked up two of these for $10. I use one for extra virgin olive oil and the other for vegetable oil and in a word, they are excellent. I can see how much oil is in them, they do NOT drip, they dispense the oil evenly and they are easy to wipe clean. They are also very heavy glass - restaurant quality bottles - the kind you see in Greek restaurants on the tables. The pouring spout looks like a standard liquor spout but for $10 for two of them, it doesn't matter. Sometimes the best solutions are inexpensive and simple like these bottles.

I bought this to cover my commercial lawnmower (36" Wright Stander) so I could leave it outside over the winter and put another car in the garage. I bought the small size - 8'x11'. I screwed around with it for an hour trying to find attachment points that would work so I could pull the tarp snug. I moved the clamps all over the tarp trying to get it to fit properly. I finally introduced rubber bungee cords which are pretty much required to a attach this tarp to an irregular shaped object and I snaked them underneath the mower to hook the clamps onto. Even with bungee cords, the tarp was still was loose in some areas and I had to fold over the tarp 12'-18" from the edge and attach the clamp further up the tarp at the expense of wasting tarp coverage.The Covrall tarp might work better on something like a boat or a quad where it's easier to climb around under the item to get it covered but I still think you will need a variety of bungee cords. By the time I figured out it wouldn't work on my commercial mower, I had gotten it pretty dirty and returning it was not going to happen (I bought it right from Covrall based on an Amazon sponsored link to the company). Since covering my lawnmower was out, option B was to use the Covrall tarp over my existing Grill Dome (Kamado style) smoker table cover which is not really waterproof and with winter coming, I want to better protect the Grill Dome and table. I wound up using a woodworking nylon band clamp to cinch the Covrall tarp down around the smoker table and the funky attachment clamps are sitting unused in a tool box in my garage because I could not find a way to pull the tarp tight without having about ten different sizes of bungee cords. The tarp does not stretch as far as I hoped it would and I was concerned if I over stretched the tarp it might tear.If you are trying to cover an odd shaped object, I think you are better off with a good quality nylon tarp (NOT the ones for $8.99 at Harbor Freight) with grommet holes around the perimeter that you can attach much tighter with greater ease. You can get a darn good tarp for $40 (1/3 the cost of the Covrall small size) that will be a LOT easier to attach. The plastic hooks Covrall supplies seem to hold tight but the hooks are sort of clunky in terms of size. The actual tarp was thinner than I thought it would be. It will be interesting to see how it holds up to a Buffalo, NY winter on top of my Grill Dome - more to come on that next spring.The Covrall tarp is an expensive solution for select purposes. I think the price is way too high and the clamps require bungee cords to really be effective. I knocked off a star for the high price and another star for the aggravation of not being able to get it to fit tightly on my commercial mower, especially after seeing the photos of that precise application on their website. I just wonder how the heck they got it attached to that mower on their website and how many guys it took to attach the tarp and how long it really took. The testimonials are their website are lame - nameless blurbs probably written by their staff.  Overall I had hoped this tarp would be a really special product and I wound up being disappointed by a lot of marketing bluster, the extraordinarily high price and the limited utility.

Other reviewers have said the magnetic closure is not secure, and I wonder if they fixed that in response, because mine is quite secure.  I can get it to come open if I flap it around, but otherwise, it's good.  I can carry it in my purse all day, or loose in my arm, and it stays closed.  Generally, I don't use cases alone, but in tandem with sleeves.  There is no case that will protect the lens of the rear camera, not and leave it accessible.  The top and bottom here are exposed, as are the speakers on the side.  Some of this is by necessity (for the speakers), some for simplicity of design (for accessing the ports and controls on top) and some for consistency of design (the bottom, which lacks any buttons or ports).  I've found this sufficient to carry in my purse without additional sleeves for now.  I don't see the cover coming loose and allowing anything to have access to the screen.  It stands well in portrait mode, and as has been pointed out, not at all in landscape.

It's extremely thin.  I may be a bit biased coming off the keyboard case to this, but it is about as thin a case as I've ever seen.  The inside padding clings to the device to protect it -- it's not at all prone to opening in my bag.  I favor a full sleeve around the case, but I'm paranoid mostly of it opening, something getting under the case and scratching the screen.  I don't think that will happen with this.If you close it, the device shuts off.  Open it and it turns on.  Very convenient.For videos, where you want a more acute angle between the surface and the screen you position the spine at the top and fold the three panels in to form a quadrilateral.  It'll just go into the correct orientation by itself.  For a  more obtuse angle, for reading or for displaying a recipe, you position the spine at the bottom and fold the three panels into a perfect square.The purple is elegant, fun but not too bright.  The back is black. Only the front panel is actually purple.  It has a nice texture and feels good in the hand.

These are incredibly comfortable headphones.  The cushions on the ear are perfect and give you the "listen to the ocean" effect of hearing the blood in your ears if you have no sound coming in.  They are about right for noise cancelling.  You can hear traffic.  You can hear someone yelling.  You won't need to hear someone next to you blab on about some nonsense you really don't want to listen to while riding the train or bus.  They're lightweight, so you can wear them for long periods of time comfortably.I've used them for audiobooks, music, and movies, and they work perfectly for all of the above.  Fair warning, if the audio feed has a sudden moment of getting very loud, the headphones will project that.  They have tremendous range both in pitch and volume.  I review a lot of headsets, and I received a sample of this headset in exchange for a review, and these are the best I've seen in a very long time.  They compare favorably with headsets in the $100 range.They come in a very nice, hard carry case and the audio cable is detachable, which means replaceable, which is important as that is the component most likely to be damaged.  If you're spending this much on a headset, you want it to last.

The concept is not entirely new, and not entirely fictional.  Children of powerful families are held hostage against their parents' good behavior.  That makes this a book that must be discussed on two grounds.First is its own as a book.  For that it is quite good.  It's thrilling.  The characters are fun.  The twists, while obvious in hindsight, are surprising in the moment.  It's the kind of book you can take on a long road trip and it will not fail to entertain.  I stayed up way too late finishing it, and I'm an adult who should know better.  It's that good.Second is how a book like this may impact a child as a student and reader, and that is where this book truly excels.  There is more than enough here that overtly parallels history that, when the child encounters that history in school, and it's hard not to, they will see the connection that binds literature to history.  That's one of the kinds of magic that can make a child a lifelong longer.

It's a classic coming of age story told pretty much on point to the archtype (not so much formula as hitting all the points that a good coming of age story should hit).  I found some of the "find yourself" messages to be more than a little heavy handed, but that is common enough in kid's literature, and perhaps necessary.  The characters were believable and easy to identify with, and I think kids will enjoy it and adults will enjoy it enough to make it worthy of family reading time.  Not many books can do that.  It's also a good book to read with kids and explore the theme of self-realization both in the story and in the children's own lives.

This is so much nicer than the cane sword.  It fits on the left hand and the blade ejects with a snick kind of sound, and quite a bit of force.  It's spring loaded, and if you look very closely you can see the spring, but I could imagine the "original" was the same.  It's heavy leather and has gorgeous detailing.  This one is worthy of Comicon or serious cos play.The "metal" looks aged aged, a little oxidized, and not at all like plastic. It barely feels like plastic when you run your fingers over it, only a bit too warm in the cold weather.  The leather looks distressed, and a bit worn, even on the inside by the knuckles.  The stitching in the leather is impeccable, and with a great eye for detail.  Some of the stitches are a tad longer than others, which happens with hand sewing, not typically with machine stitching.  Yes, it was clearly done by machine, but the effect is to look pre-industrial which fits the game perfectly.  There is even fake dirt in the spring of the grapple line.The buckles on top are non-functional.  It stays on with velcro straps on the bottom.  It fits my small woman hands only barely and I imagine would be fine on a fairly tall man as well.As with the cane, this is not for kids.  The blade is on the sharp side, as is the assassin logo grapple point (I didn't notice in the game that the hook is the logo -- very cool detail).  It could do some damage, especially if pointed to the eyes, and the grapple hook is a bit delicate looking.  Nothing serious, but handle with some care.

It's an okay mix of sweet and salty, leaning more towards sweet. The pretzels are sparse. The toffee is plentiful. The pieces are substantially larger than I'd like and hard to break up if you just want a small sweet. It isn't well mixed so some pieces are just toffee. Most lack chocolate, which is odd for a Hershey product. There isn't as much popcorn as I'd expect either. Mostly, it's toffee. Big hunks of toffee.

It's really soft, not at all scratchy, and very warm. You can wear it doubled, or as a hood and scarf.  Either way, it is extremely warm.  Alternatively, you can leave it as a single loop which is still warm, but less so.  Good if you (or your meteorologist) misjudged the temperature.  I wouldn't say it's ever going to be a fall weather scarf. It's too warm for that.  But it's perfect for anything from mild to severe winter days.It's a high loft fiber, more on the black than the red which leads to it being very squooshy, visually interesting (the contrasting texture of the two yarns gives it more character than is clear in the photograph) and good at trapping heat, so it will keep you warm.  The trick to a warm garment isn't that it is dense, but that it can hold in the air warmed by your body.  A high loft item like this will do an excellent job of that with limited excess weight to carry around and make you feel too bundled up and overburdened in the cold.I've been trying to dissect the pattern.  There is a seam in the inside, so it was done flat.  The seam looks like it was joined by chain stitch, which is unusual in a machined piece.  The inside looks like it alternates between one knit one purl one row in red and then two rows knit one red purl one with a thicker black yarn that leads to the image of red windows surrounding a black background.  But not quite that. There is something else going on with the black stitches and I'm not sure what.  On the front it looks like the same K1P1 rib in red, followed by a row of yarn over red, knit one black, then knit one red, knit one black. Except the yarn overs lead to long stitches, not holes so something else is going on.  I'm going to be fascinated by this all winter.  Your knitting friends will love this just to figure out the puzzle.I found one knot in the yarn, and the instructions say dry clean only.  Those are the only faults I could find with it.  I received a sample in exchange for review.

My only complaint is that I could not find the mentioned App on the XBox One.  Perhaps with the Windows 10 update.You can change the color, and it goes through the entire spectrum, right from the controller.  It has a very long (I think ten feet), very stable, not prone to tangle cable.  It is responsive, has good rumble features and works well on both the XBox One and the PC.  I've been using it to play Halo: Master Chief Collection and I've yet to find it lacking.  On the PC side, I've played a little Splinter Cell: Blacklist and so far it is perfect.  Definitely the best controller I've ever tried on PC. I'm running the game in Steam on Windows 10 if that matters.

The planet had to be there, except it wasn't.Einstein's great brilliance often manifested in seeing reality as it was and in assuming that what the data told us was correct, even if the theory stated otherwise.  It is a rule that underlines how science works, and yet it is a rule too often ignored.  If the planet wasn't there, then Einstein looked for, and found, the error in the theory, or rather he created the entirely new model for which he is best known.This book is very much for a casual lay reader.  It's easy to follow.  It's friendly in tone.  It's about as light as would be appropriate for the subject matter.  Don't expect a lot of equations.  Don't expect a deep dive into relativity.  Still, for anyone with even a casual interest in science, this is an excellent book.

It's not meant for kids.  Ubisoft is clear about that and they're right.  It's too heavy.  The blade on the bottom is too sharp.  Children will get hurt playing with this.For adults, it's kind of okay.  I wouldn't call it appropriate for serious cos play.  You wouldn't take this to comic con or anything of the sort.  But for Halloween or a casual larp it's really good.  Let's call it mid-range quality there.  It isn't quality enough to serve as a display piece.  It looks too much like cheap plastic for that. It's clever for casual detail in the corner of the room to give the room a little character.For a cane, it seems oddly good.  I don't use a cane, but it feels as sturdy and as stable as any wooden one I've ever held.

I was able to pair this pen easily with the 2015 Kindle Fire HDX 10" and the original iPad Air.  The Air was already paired with another Livescribe 3 and it took the second pairing without complaint.  Data transfer is quick and simple.  The app is much the same on both platforms, with the addition of a free helper app on the Kindle side (it just runs in the background; you won't need to worry about it once you've set everything up).  It can sync with a host of services, including OneNote and Evernote.The back pouch of the notebook has the normal Moleskine phamplet, along with a bookmark for all of the controls for a host of Livescribe pens (Echo, Pulse and Livescribe3) and a larger card with the same controls along with a tap keyboard for setting up wifi on the Echo.The included sleeve does not fit around the entire notebook, which is what I expected, but rather it fits just around the front cover.  There is a zippered pouch, a front sleeve pouch, and a back sleeve pouch that actually sits inside the notebook.  I have taken to keeping the generous supply of ink cartriges there, and by themselves in the little paper envolope they came in they are snug and safe and do not damage the notebook.The pen loop, and why you need a pen loop for a pen case bewilders me, but there is one there, sits towards the spine side of the book.  If you put the sleeve on the back, it sits towards the opening, but then it is uncomfortable to write in the book.  I may take it off as I get towards the end of the notebook.Digital technology is best for archival and retreival.  If you want to store information over time or need easy access, you go digital.  Paper and pen is faster for input.  If you want to jot something fast for single use, or for later transfer, you go for paper and pen.  This marries the two, and it can do OCR to read your handwriting and convert it into digital notes, with accompanying corrections.  My handwriting is notoriously bad. In my social group, I'm the poster child for illegible handwriting, beating out our group doctor (but to be fair, she has stereotype-breaking beautiful handwriting). This is running about a 99% accuracy for me out of the gate.  That's not only impressive, it's frightening.For those who love the feel of pen on paper, this is a smooth, luxurious pen, a good ink flow on par with a Mont Blanc ballpoint, and the sumptuous paper for which Moleskine is famous.Fair warning.  It comes with a one year subscription to Evernote premium.  Once you get started with that, you will not want to walk away.  It is entirely too useful a tool.The only tiny issue I have, and I certainly won't ding it a star for it, is where other notebooks have you tap the band on the outside to confirm the notebook is available, this has you tap the band to archive the book.  I'm suspecting that means archive the last book of this number of this type, which is very clever, but it's not what long time fans of Livescribe are used to.That requires some explaining.  You can use a page over again, adding more notes, annotating, whatever, and the pen will update as you go.  In order to do that, the pen needs to know which notebook you're in.  Each type of book is coded differently, so it knows a one subject spiral from a flip book.  Within the categories, there are numbers.  So a number 1 flip book is coded differently than a number 2 flip book.  You can only have one book matching both type and number in use at any one time.  When you're done with a book you archive it, and then you can reuse the type/number combination and the pen will see it as a new book.  You get a number one Moleskine book with this.  There is a number two Moleskine book available.  The only difference in them is how the pen sees and differentiates them.  So rather than test, this one just archives the prior (I assume) and lets you go from there.This is a must have item for students, busy professionals, or anyone who needs to write things down and get at that information again quickly.

It is very quick and easy to assemble and the top is adjustable.  It does not reach high enough to touch my ceiling, but I'm told I have very high ceilings, and I could probably buy a longer screw for the top if I need to.  As it is, my cats jump on it all the time, and climb right to the top and it's perfectly stable.  I'm still dinging it a star for being short.The little tube is definitely for kittens.  My 8 pound cat won't use it.  My largest cat, a ten year old fifteen pound tom, is completely uninterested.  He could fit in or on the cut out cat face areas, and on the larger platforms, but he just isn't hearing it.  I put him on it.  He flies right off.  The younger queens, both three, one 8 pounds, one 11, both adore it and play on it all the time.  They haven't figured out the ladders yet, but they really don't need them anyway.No one is interested in the ropes at all.  Overall, I think they like it.

It works exactly as expected.  The cord is ample for most purposes, and the USB ports are sufficient to charge a  phone or tablet.  The grounded outlets are placed far enough apart that somewhat larger plugs can sit by side.  A must have for a modern desk. I received a sample in exchange for an honest review.
It works pretty quickly, doesn't get too hot, as I'd feared. It's not uncomfortably hot. And it doesn't catch in my tangle-addicted hair. It's a good time saver.

It's a nice concealer, but I find it a little shinier than I'm used to. It blends well, and while I see the point of the metal applicator, I don't like it. It's uncomfortable enough I stopped using it. It reduces circles under the eyes as any good concealer should, and does it somewhat better than most.

Collapsing a work as complex as The Secret Chord into a simple summary guide is no small accomplishment, but it is executed masterfully here.  We are given first a very straightforward recitation of what is far from a simple straightforward plot, and from there we get analysis of the characters, the themes, the world of the story and the world of the bible in that time.Characters are analyzed as who they start as, who they become, and what the journey means. "Finally, as a contrast to them both, Natan details the unsullied personality of Shomo, who combines the best qualities of both David and Natan."I love the writing style in this one.  "David trash talked the giant with his mesmerizing voice and beaned him with a stone."  I never thought of David trash talking before, and now I can't get the image out of my head.I would recommend reading this if you want to see The Secret Chord would appeal to you.  It would be good to read it after, to see the story in a compressed form so better to get a holistic view of the work.It is especially useful to book discussion groups or for classrooms (not in lieu of reading the original if it is for school) as this summary covers a wide range of discussion points. "David's glorious but flawed life raises key questions about what makes a good man and leader."I received a free copy in exchange for an honest review.

I'm in the process of upgrading a few hard drives that are working fine, but are too small for my needs.  This does fast work of cloning the smaller drive to the larger one, and at least for Windows 10 I do not need to fiddle with the partitions afterwards, which is a big plus.  I did format the destination drive in advance.  I'm not sure if it is required, but it seems to work that way without partition problems.  For cloning, this is a very useful tool.

You need to pair the guitars to the USB dongles.  Unlike say Rock Band where they are just Bluetooth.  If you buy the two pack, good luck remembering which dongle goes to which guitar.You can't buy songs, to play over and over, it's more a jute box situation where you buy plays.  The good news is you can earn them in game.  The bad news is you have to play whatever it throws at you to get them.The controller disconnects repeatedly, so the game puts up an error message, but the notes keep coming.  New batteries didn't help.  Clear line to the dongle didn't help.  The thing just doesn't work.You can't calibrate the game manually.  At best you can let it sort of figure it out on its own.  At best, it suggests putting the TV in game mode.  Calibration was a well-established technique back in Gen 7.

Naruto and Hinata sittin' in a tree...This one is a little silly (ninja escapade on the moon) and a little flighty (there is more talk about knitting in this one movie than in the combined remaining body of ninja anime) and a lot of fun.  Naruto is at his best here, and Hinata comes more into her own.  This picks up sometime after the end of the series.  It is worth it for any Naruto fan.

I'm accustomed to having short socks like these fall into the show, but these fit perfectly.  They stay up.  They're very comfortable.  They look great inside short shoes.  They're the perfect summer socks.

This is possibly her most brilliant book until chapter 16.  Once we get to chapter 16 she seems to have realized she needs to wrap things up and it all kind of falls apart, but until then, brilliant.We get Kirball.  We get intrigue.  We get romance.  We get Amily in a combination chainmail armor/wedding dress.  We get the most interesting villain Lackey has ever written.  Seriously, the bad guy in this is freaking amazing for the first 15 chapters.When traitors inside Valdemar seek to dethrone an allied king, and drag Valdemar into an unjust war, it is up to Mags, Amily, and Nicholas's own teacher to find the culprit and bring him to justice.

My podiatrist told me to get these for Plantar Fascia problems and in days my feet started feeling better.  The only concern, you'll want a pair for each pair of shoes.  Once they're in the shoe, they're not coming out.

You can't play with all the toys in all the adventures.  We're not talking Lego Dimensions here, and that's by design.  You can sort of kind of play with all of them in the Toy Box.  Or rather, you should be able to play with all of them in the toy box.My experiences so far.  Start as Vadar.  Try to get to the top of the castle to collect stars.  Discover that Vadar has somehow managed to gain Kitty Pryde's power to walk through solid walls, and can't control it.  Reboot and try something else.Hey, let's do the racing challenge with Luke Skywalker.  Ooops, he inherited his father's power and now he is half inside, half outside a wall and can't move.  Lovely.  Reboot and try again.Why not try paintball with Leah.  Oh wait.  She's got the family power too.Unless you want a tour-de-force performance on the myriad manifestations of clipping errors, stay clear of this game.
This is not nearly as red as pictured or described.  It is pink.  It is a fabulous pink, but still not red.

The summary, much like the book it is based on, takes more liberal tone than would be expected from a generally conservative pundit like Bill O'Reilly. In tone the summary matches the source.  The later analysis skillfully brings in four other works, referenced in the back.  I like that it is that thorough in so short a piece.  The discussion on both the state of mental health care in the 80s, as influenced by, and then visited upon Reagan, was interesting.There are two points of concern here.  The first is that it obviously follows a formula designed for fiction.  It has a section on characters, character relationships, and themes.  Now, Reagan was something of a character, but he's usually not referred to as such in the description of a history textbook.The second is the writing style.  The author is prone to cliche.  In a very short section (locations 146 through 167) we have "She (Nancy) controlled his every action", "Nancy was dogged and determined in her relationship with Reagan" and "He (Reagan) seemed to have no problem bending to her will".  The book is somewhat repetitive.  "Alzheimer's disease affects memory.  ....  Alzheimer's disease robs the patient of one of the things that makes a person human: their memory."The book excels in that it compresses a substantial amount of information, and most of the tone of the original work, into a smaller package (and honestly, the synopsis is better than the full text in this case).  It ends with a brilliant analysis of O'Reilly's styleIf you want to know what Killing Reagan was about, this is a great overview. It was shockingly thorough for so short a work.  I received a copy in exchange for an honest review.

This plays with much of the plot from Dragonball Super (which needs to come to the US already!).  Frieza is resurrected with the help of the newly upgraded dragon balls of earth (now Shenlong grants two wishes, the second one used is sort of a throwaway, so no reason to introduce it here).  He trains.  The Z-fighters train.  They come together in an exceedingly predictable fight and kick the snot out of each other.And it is so much fun.  Beerus is a trip the entire time.  Vegeta is at the top of his form, so much better than the last movie, Goku is that crazy combination of serious and funny that makes him so delightful and Krillian kicks it old school.  This is the movie for a grab a beer and shut of the brain night after a hard day of work.  This is pure fun, total brain candy, and absolutely worth it.  Fans will love it.

This has got to be the worst stylus I've ever used.  The clip is effectively cut into the barrel, to keep the cylinder of the barrel perfectly straight, which means you can't actually clip it to anything.  I've tried an iPad case.  I've tried my shirt pocket.  It doesn't clip.  Why is there a non functional clip on a stylus?It's short and stubby, which I expected but the pseudo-clip keeps it from being comfortable.It is very responsive and it works well.  I'll give it that.  But that's a minimum expectation.
It does a good job, especially on those awful days of the month that the skin seems to want nothing but to oil up.  It's easy to use, smells nice, and is effective.

This reads more like the history textbook of an alternate universe than a fantasy novel, and I really like that.  Micheal Livingston is an academic, with a background in history, the middle ages in particular, and it shows.  There is little here that does not convince, little that does not ring true.  The world, the time, is more the appeal than the story or characters, not that there is anything wrong with either, but the world-building is astounding.  Highly recommend for fans of Heinlein.

This lies somewhere between a college book report on Grey, and the Cliff Notes.  Like a good book report, it's short enough to read right before the dinner party with the friends that read these kinds of books (if you're the type that reads these kinds of books, you're not reading the summary anyway).  It's detailed enough that you will be able to talk about the book with those friends, but getting some wine in them is advised if you want to keep the charade up for too long.There are no quotes, nor selections from the book.  Like the Cliff Notes there is a character guide, is a cursory analysis of the book, dealing with the surface topics but not delving into any area, and a very interesting section of the general public reaction to the entire series.  I would have liked to have seen something on how Freud might have interpreted Christian's behavior, or how the book plays the mentor/student story archetype, but that's probably more analysis than a book like Grey deserves.It was at points quite insightful, and I highly recommend it to students who have read Grey and who want to better understand literary analysis.  This text is such a clean, simple example of how literary analysis is supposed to be done at a fundamental level it would be helpful for students struggling in lit class.The writing style is straightforward and simple, presenting the facts clearly and concisely with an understated voice.  It gets you the information you want quickly and gets out of there.  If you're reading a summary, that's exactly what you want.  It could not be better executed.  I received a sample in exchange for an honest review.

It's a reasonably good representation of Cookie Monster, but how impressive is it to emulate a puppet?I dislike the hands in that they are flat with no filling. They look unnatural and wrong.  I absolutely hate the eyes.  They aren't googly, as would be suggested by the picture.  They are like two pool balls glued together and painted.  They're really hard, so if your child hits himself/herself with it, it will hurt.  This coming from someone who managed to bonk herself in the nose on pulling it from the box.  If your child is in the bites on everything stage, you don't want them biting on those eyes.  The stitching is good, but I found a few snarls in the thread.  Not very noticeable, but enough to show a lower grade of craftsmanship.For an adult as memorabilia or part of a casual collection, it's pretty good.  For a serious collector it has quality flaws that would suggest against it.  For a child, those eyes are enough of a problem I would advise against it.

The bottles are quite sturdy (they have not broken despite my cat's best efforts, and she knocks them down a lot).  The brush is very convenient.  I use it to clean glasses, pitchers, anything hard to get into and it does a great job.  I'm really enamored with it.  Of course it does a great job with these glasses too.I use them for mixing single serving ice teas or fruit punch or whatever, and then close them and let them chill.  They're especially good if you're worried about spills.  You can close them when not in use.  I do that if I'm keeping a bottle of iced tea next to me while I'm gaming.  I received a sample in exchange for an unbiased review and use them quite often.  They're handy.

This is very clever.  You push the top into the bottle a little then pump to create a suction beneath that pulls it down.  They stay in the bottle very well, but can be a bit fiddly to get out again.  Not a big deal, just fiddly.  They work even if the bottle tips to one side or the other, say if something else bangs into it in the fridge.Two concerns.  One, it's a bit more work than the simple push in stoppers, so you won't want to have it as a temporary closure while you are using the bottle. You know, pour a glass, put on the top, someone else wants more so you lift, pour, put the top back on kind of deal.  This is only good for when you're putting it away.  Second, all the instructions are in Portuguese.  Takes a bit to figure it out without being able to read the instructions.Overall it's quite useful.  I received a sample in exchange for an unbiased review.

This is pretty much the sweet spot between a basic wheel that lacks force feedback and a top of the line wheel that costs more than a console.  It clamps to the table (and do clamp it, or it'll go bouncing around if you crash into something).It is fully wired.  You need to plug it in for power, and the cord is pretty short so you may want an extension cord, and you plug the wheel into the USB port on the PS3 or PS4, so you may need a USB extender if you're far from the TV.  I'm playing at about 80 inches from the TV with no issue, but that's close to the limit.The force feedback is adjustable, at least if you're playing Project Cars, and it's a good idea to flip through the options to find the one that's right for you.  It emulates a semi-automatic car with gear shifting paddles behind the wheel.  Project Cars at least responds to that.  Since I've never driven anything but an automatic, I'm basically flapping them around trying to get a sense of what they do.  The wheel is comfortable to hold and turns easily enough, but with a little more resistance than a real car.  The pedals are big, close enough to the size of the pedals in a real car as to make it hard to notice the difference.  If you are playing on a hardwood floor the pedals will slip around.  Get a welcome mat to put under them when they are in use and they will stay put, this assuming you are attaching the wheel to the table and not going all the way with a frame setup.  The pedals are responsive and adjustable.  In the default configuration the break offers more resistance than the gas.The PS3/PS4 switcher is fairly hidden in the front behind the wheel, as it should be given you will be using that switch least of all.  You have full controls for both, including a dpad, options, share, and the triggers (but not the bumpers L1 and R1 that I've seen) right on the wheel.  Project Cars (can you guess my favorite PS4 racing game?) recognized it with no configuration required.Overall this is a lot easier and a lot more fun than racing with the controller.  I'm having a blast.  Now if only I could stop crashing into the walls.

These are very cute.  They are asymmetrical hearts, so the hearts either bend into your face or out to frame it.  They are quite small and lightweight, delicate and understated, but more playful than sophisticated.  They pair best with a casual event and summer dress or jeans, though they are fine for business casual.  They are comfortable and come with the little stop for the back so they don't fall out.  The stops are secure, which means they take a bit to fit them on.  These are well made and look exactly as pictured.

I think this one is the best of the line in terms of value.  It does close to everything the more expensive ones does (I think one has a foot attachment and this doesn't, but that's all the significant features).You have a razor that is easy to clean.  No brush like the bigger ones, but you don't need it.  The easiest thing to do on any of them is pop off the head and run it under water.  The epilator head is effective and well designed.  It comes with enough of a charge to use it at least once, and it recharges pretty quickly.It feels good in the hand.  It's easy to use.  It can work in the shower.  It can work on dry skin.  It's really all you need.  No sense wasting money on excess accessories and features.  This one is more than enough to get the job done.

It is a combination epilator and razor, with the typical bikini attachments and one rather odd attachment of a thinner epilator head for bikini and underarms.  I'm not sure that head is terribly useful.  It comes with a cleaning brush, also not terribly useful as the entire thing snaps apart easily to clean it.  It also comes with a storage pouch that is sturdy and very useful.Press the button once for normal mode, and twice for a "soft" mode that slows the unit down and makes it less uncomfortable.  It becomes easier once you get used to it.  The main epilator is a double row of tweezers, making it more efficient than any other I've seen.  It comes party charged and ready to use, charges quickly and holds a charge very well.I like this one, but I prefer their three in one on it being a better value.

This is a mini-game expansion to Disney Infinity 3.0.  You will need the base game to play it of course.  Just putting that out there if someone is considering it for their kids.  And it is most definitely family friendly.  It supports split screen co-op for two players, or it can be played solo.It's a collection of go kart races, your standard run around the track hitting power up race, a race against time (also with power ups), and fighting go karts.  A giant blue hand appears to point the way you're supposed to go.  You can coast a bit (L2 and R2) and after two seconds of that you get a power up to lay on a burst of speed.  You can make the car jump.  This is the kind of stuff you expect to see in Mario Kart, and if you don't have a Nintendo console, this is a pretty good variation.You can run any Infinity characters against each other, so I had Luke Skywalker neck and neck with Aladdin for a while.  Until I crashed Luke into a wall.It's a welcome addition to a fun game.

This is a good introduction to the Raspberry Pi and to Python.If you have an interest in learning software development, and this is a field with a tremendous shortage of skilled workers, this isn't a bad place to start.  Python is a good learning language, and it is still used in the field in some places.  The Pi is a very cheap starter computer, and the Pi 2 is powerful enough to learn multithreading effectively.The book is clear and works through a series of step by step skill building exercises.  At the end you will have a solid foundation in Python and a very clear understanding of what it is to develop software, at least enough to decide if it is something you want to pursue.For those who already know how to code, it's a good guide to Python and a nice overview of exactly what the Pi is capable of.  You'll want to skim some parts of course, but there is enough here to make it worthwhile.  It's a great introduction to the tiny computer.

One can can make a margarita for two people and fill a typical margarita class for each.  It's has a strong lime taste, not too sweet, and very pleasant.  There isn't much complexity here.  Even with a decent Tequila, from impact to savor it's all semi-sweet lime.  It's a not very serious summer drink for a casual, fun party.  It's not like any margarita I've had, but it's good in its own right.  I'll be serving these for quite a while.

Nice headphones.  They don't come with the little tips you can switch to get the right size, which is a minus, but then you can't lose the little tips, which is a plus.  I always lose those.  They fit comfortably for me (5' 5" female if that matters).  The volume is a little more than most, so I find I turn the iPad down when I switch to these.  The range is very clear with a strong base and no tinniness on the higher notes.  They're perfect for music.  The microphone is well placed and works well, but since I'm still not used to walking down the street looking like I'm talking to myself, I find I pick it up to be obvious I'm on the phone.  It doesn't pick up noise from being handled and it doesn't mind some wind.  It handles wind better than most I've tried.  I received a sample in exchange for an  honest review.

Very good sound, akin to 2.1 ssurround. You can audiolocate left and right with it. Good pickup on the microphone without an excess of background noise. The microphone is good about not popping the p sounds. The controls are conveniently placed. It is quite comfortable for a long session. It compares well with a few $100 headsets I've tried.

This is a nice cable.  I use it to charge my DualShock 4 for the PlayStation TV and it really is a fast charging cable.  The end that goes into the charger looks different than a normal USB cable, but it fits in the USB port just fine and works exactly the same way.  The cable comes with an attached velcro wrap to keep it neat looking and tangle free.  I received a sample in exchange for a review.

I was offered one of these to review and fell in love with the very idea.  Why has no one put fingers on an oven mitt before?  It's brilliant.It works very well.  I baked pumpkin loafs at 350 degrees for 70 minutes and pulled the tray out with this.  It worked as well as an oven mitt, only gave me a lot more manual dexterity.  It is somewhat bulky, and it needs to be.  But it's a lot better than a mitt.My only concerns are that the fingers run a bit on the short side, and you really need two.  I'm going to pick a second one up soon.  They're great.

These fit very well and the sound quality is far above par.  They can handle a good range in pitch with no issue and level volume as a quality headset ought to (so you're not constantly grabbing the controller to turn up the dialog and down the special effects while you're watching a movie).  The microphone is good, and while those of us who feel a bit self-conscious walking down the street talking to the air can lift it to be more obvious what's going on, it does a fine job simply hanging where it falls.  I received a sample for review.  I will likely buy another pair if destructo-cat eats these.

I received a sample in exchange for a review, and I honestly didn't expect it was going to be that great given the low price.  I was pleasantly surprised.  I can charge two phones and an iPad at once with no trouble.  It seats easily.  It works properly.  It does exactly what it should be no issues.

I love this.  I don't use it for the phone so much as to listen to movies or music, but for that it is awesome.  I did try making a call with it, and it works well, but I got a few too many funny looks walking down the street having what looked like a conversation with myself.  I'm not used to the near invisible phone era yet.It's pretty easy to manipulate the components to get everything just the right size and the ear buds fit surprisingly well.  It's easy to pull the works out to wash the hat and then put them back.  It charges on micro USB and lights to show that it is charged or that it is on and working.  Pairing was fast.  Just hold the play button for a few seconds and it will beep to say it's in pair mode.  The sound quality was excellent, and somewhat leveled for movies (the difference between loudest and softest is compressed, which is ideal for headphones but often not implemented).My only complaint is that it shows up as some product code in the listed bluetooth devices as opposed to "baseball cap speaker" or something equally unambiguous and obvious.  But that is my only complaint.  Otherwise, it's solid.  I have not used it for more than three hours at a stretch, but it handles that without an issue.I am amused that the earbuds are oriented properly if you wear the hat with the brim that's supposed to shade your eyes in front, such that it shades your eyes.  You can pull them to wear the hat backwards, but it's more awkward.  I kind of hope this encourages kids to experiment with front-brim orientation.  I received a sample in exchange for an honest review.

The one thing that surprised me is that it is outlet only.  You can't run it off batteries.  That seems kind of last century, but then pencils are a bit last century.I tried it with a host of art pencils from 8B to 5H and it was able to handle them all.  The points came out clean and did not break in the process, which can be a problem with the very hard ones as they can run a bit brittle or the very soft ones as they are, well, very soft.  This was able to deal with all of them.The automatic shut off is a great feature.  No pulling the pencil out to check if its done, just press it down until the sharpener stops.  It's good to know I'm not the only person who wants an idiot proof pencil sharpener.

There is a light, floral aroma, but not as strong as most conditioners, more subtle.  It is better for detangling than for body.  It rinses out very easily with no residue.  I'm kind of getting tired of conditioners that don't know when the party is over.  You put them in, let them hang a minute or two, then try to show them the drain.  And they won't leave.  You're just rinsing and rinsing and they're hoping for another round of drinks or something.  This one does its job and gets the heck out of there.  I really like it.

Light, quick game.  You build bridges between islands in an attempt to control those islands.  The player with the most islands at the end wins.  You score at three checkpoints, and the tie breaking system is the hardest part of the entire thing.  It's fast to learn, and really there isn't much to it.  It's a laid back, casual kind of game.  Interesting enough for serious table top gamers.  Easy enough for casual players.  I'm definitely using this to lure more friends into table top games.  It's a great gateway game for the purpose.It's good for kids, and relaxing for adults.

You can move your five explorers (you don't need to use them all) on any of five paths.  You can move one square forward on each color if you play a card of that color that is higher than the last card you played.  So if you play a two, you can play a three or a four etc, to move forward.  You can't play a lower card, but you can discard it, and your opponents can pick it up.  Along the way you get bonus points and artifacts to raise your score.  Three rounds makes a game.This game is supposed to take 30 minutes to an hour, but I have yet to find even a three player version go that fast.  There is too much strategy and planning involved.  You need to think about what cards you need now, what you need later, what your opponents might use if you discard a card, and how many "for later" cards you can retain.  You need to decide when to bite the bullet and take a big number jump (limiting your later moves) and when to hold off.It definitely plays better with more than two players.  It's fast to learn, and a lot of fun.

This game is possibly the hardest cooperative board game I've ever played and I love it.  You can pick up one of the earlier kits -- Rise of the Runelords was first -- or you can start right here.  The game is structured so that Wrath of the Righteous is an adventure path.  It contains seven adventures.  Each adventure contains multiple scenarios.  You can play a single scenario, a single adventure, or the entire path.  You won't finish in a day.  Figure you're going to have a regular group meet for many session to finish.  We can get through one scenario in a day, though I've heard of players who can finish a scenario in an hour.The box contains everything you need for adventures 0 and 1.  You will need to purchase the cards for adventures 2 - 6 separately.  There are other optional card sets to boost each character class, or to take the game from a four player max to a six player max if you like.  The rather huge box can hold them all.  You will probably need rubber bands to keep each character deck.This game is hard, and expect to fail a few scenarios or have at least one character dead as you come up to speed on how it all works.  But it is a lot of fun, and well worth it for serious fans of table top gaming.

This is not a Rubik's cube, but a knockoff, and not a very good one.The large cube came damaged.  It was packaged properly, but the panels were scratched and uneven in color.The small cube is effectively useless.  It does not turn properly, and the difference between the rust-red and the red-rust  is so slight as to make it nearly impossible to differentiate the two.  At least they sit on opposite sides of the cube.  You can get much better ones for much less money.  Don't bother with this.
It's more of a choker than a necklace, very short, and very delicate.  The chain is elegant and quite fine.  It catches the light beautifully.  It's dainty, for a sweet, understated look.

It''s a quick, convenient meal.  It takes a minute in the microwave, stores at room temperature, and you can eat it right from the pouch.  For convenience, this will be hard to beat.  For flavor I found it a little too spicy for my taste.  If you like your food hot, you'll love it.

It's like Tetris or Tangrams as a board game.The game is played for nine rounds.  At the start of the round everyone gets a puzzle board.  One player rolls the dice and everyone uses a key at the side of the board to determine which pieces they can use.  They then must fit all the assigned pieces into the puzzle board as quickly as possible.  You get gems for finishing in time (there is a sand timer), gems for finishing first and gems for finishing second.  At the end, the player with the most valuable gems wins.  You can play solo if you like.  It's a game for 1-4 players.There is an app for iOS and Android (though I could not at the time of this writing find a Kindle Fire version) that teaches you how to play, but really, it's not complicated enough to need that. It's really simple to learn and lots of fun.You're supposed to yell "Ubungo" when you finish your board.  Adult version -- take a drink.

This was a bit more viscous than I'd expected from a shampoo, making it a bit of a pain to rinse out properly, but it did a good job controlling frizz and adding strength and healthy body to the hair.

It's a fantastic detangling conditioner. My hair tangles worse than most, but this did a good job with it. It's also good for strengthening the hair. I like it and the matching shampoo. They work well for thin, frizzy hair.

My cats love it, but each uses it for a different purpose.Hikari uses it as lounger. At 10, he's not an old cat, but older yes. He loves his toys, usually and while this claims to be enticing to older cats as a toy, he's not into it. As a lounger, he loves it. I put it in the living room, and if we're in that room he's lying on it, at least unless one of the girls chases him off.Shinta loves the scratching post. This thrills me because she's not good about scratching posts generally and I had all but given up trying to find one she'd use. It seems to hold up pretty well, and she's really digging into it, but if she manages to destroy it I plan to buy another. It was supposed to come with a bag of catnip, but there was no catnip in mine.Aiko likes the ball, somewhat, and again surprising since she's never been much for toys. The battery is included, just pull the protective tab. There is a tiny hole on one side in which the ball sometimes gets a little stuck, but getting it loose seems to amuse her, so I'll call that a feature.I've yet to see one cat use two of the features of this product, but each very much enjoys the one feature he or she uses. In the scratching pad and toy it has succeeded where other products have failed. That makes it a win with my group.

Easy to clean. Huge crock pot. At least twice as large in volume as my old one. The hinge is nice when just stirring contents or checking on the progress or temperature. The lid flips up/down but can also be pulled straight off to open or remove it for cleaning. The ceramic pot is very large and heavy. I'd strongly advise washing it sitting on the base of the sink because it is large and awkward to hold without hitting anything. The cord is ludirously short. It's about 16" or 18". You therefore must have this immediately adjacent to an outlet. With the flip cover it cannot really fit under a cabinet, so be sure you have an open counter to place this one. Otherwise you will need to lift the cover off instead of flipping to open it.It cooks well on medium. I cooked grains readily with the medium temperature for about 4-5 hours. Came out very moist mixing only a couple of times. Held the moisture in well. Not quite as well as a steam/rice cooker, but really about 3/4 as good for an appliance that can do many other things. The warmer works fine, although I would have preferred a slightly lower temperature for grains (so they don't get dry), it is probably configured to have a higher temperature to keep meats in the safe range where bacteria do not grow.Overall an excellent appliance and I appreciate the simple black finish. I didn't much fancy the flowers on my old one!

I have a number of Epson printers including this ET-4550, an Artisan 830, XP-820, and an XP-830. Like all of the other Epson printers this one includes the same package of driver software with utilities for scanning, copying, printing, and faxing. The software is easy to install whether for USB or network connected. This is a great product principally because of both the value of the included ink, the long terms cost savings in ink, and just as important avoiding the wasted time of changing cartridges frequently - AVOIDED.I was disappointed using the arrow controls on the b&w screen when all of the other Epson printers I've used have larger full color touch screens. This sadly DOES NOT have that capability. That counts most when copying or printing photos directly from a USB or other memory stick device. The trays on this model are pulled out by hand (the XP820/830 come out and retract automatically). But other than the display, it is a fast and high quality printer. Never had any problems with any Epson printer jamming even with the very thinnest recycled paper! I obviously have NOT had to refill the ink wells on this model (it runs for an estimated 11,000 pages before that is necessary). So we will have to wait to see how easy or hard that is. I'm sure there are many users out there who may buy this and NEVER put ink in it for a 3-4 year life and use of the product.

Great microphone quality (very very good quality -- no echo, no background noise). I like the visual indicators on the mic boom (arm) which can be configured to show mute/no-mute and connected/not connected). I like the volume control (rear of the left earphone). Very easy to use. No problem connecting to Windows 7 and Windows 10 tablet and computer respectively. The USB adapter was quickly recognized and driver downloaded.Sound quality was good, but honestly not nearly as good (listening to high quality music) as two Sony headsets we have. Giving it -1/2 a star for this.In terms of comfort it is quite comfortable and seals out some, but not all external point. Giving it -1/2 star for this. Overall I think you can find more comfortable and better sound quality headsets, but the microphone is better than most and the microphone boom/arm is sturdy and has alert LEDs that are very helpful.Regrettably I purchase this for use with an XBOX 360 -- which it will NOT work with. It is compatible with XBOX ONE, but NOT the 360. Corsair's site says that it require a Microsoft (USB) adapter to work on the XBOX ONE.

Exact replacement for the original installed with my HVAC system. With mineral build up these tend to last about 6 years for me. I have them running for condensate on instant hot water heater and two hvac systems (including one with a humidifier). Thankfully the internal float and adding a second external float provides a safety shutoff to prevent water damage when the pump fails.

I have an Epson Artisan 830 (a different printer), an XP-810, and an Epson ET-4550. This XP-830 is the same size as the XP-810 and has similar features, but is a newer printer. The best feature of this printer is Internet based printing. When configured for either Epson cloud printing or Google (cloud) printing, you can print to this printer from any computer, tablet, or cell phone while you are on the go. When you get home or back to the office -- your document will be there on the printer. It is extremely useful for printing something like recipes that you'd rather have on paper. I've used it to print in between errands, etc.The printer works well on WiFi. Whereas I had problems on the Artisan series with WiFi no such problem here. The print tray opens up when needed, so be sure not to store anything in front of the printer. The display is a larger color display and is an easy to use touch screen for photocopies and scanning. You can scan directly to your computer.This printer also has a nice feature for built in graph and lined paper. If you ever need graph or line paper for school work, you can just print out a few sheets as needed. This is very handy for my middle and high school kids.After many years as an HP fan I gave up because of HP's rising ink costs and horrible printer quality. I'm now fan of the Epson printers. You will find it loaded with features whether it is for your children, the whole family, a college dorm, or a small office.

Much smaller than it looks (which is good). This compact surge protector is great for use in a location where a larger power strip may not fit. The reset/power switch is lit, so be aware that the light will be visible at night. It may not be the best choice for a bedroom because of that. Some new power strips (which are also surge protectors) have some or all outlets spaces further apart to allow for space for AC adapters. This one DOES not. It can only fit 6 plugs if they are basic 2 prong or 3 prong plugs. It also fits the slightly larger (new) compact USB adapters which are not inline style adapters.

Does not leave stains, strong mint flavor but not as strong as Listerine. This does contain both artificial colors and artificial flavors. This may be important for consumers or parents to know before buying the product. The size is perfect. Small enough to keep on the counter or fit inbetween the rather small shelves of a typical bathroom medicine cabinet. Most other bottles are often too tall or large to fit there.

This is a very solid, well made watch. It comes in a nice box and is very well packaged to protect the watch from damage. The face and band are completely covered in peel off plastic to protect it. The watch is turned off and cannot be turned on until you remove a plastic piece below the middle dial on the right side. After removing the plastic insert the watch immediately began running. The color is a dark charcoal (not quite black I think) -- it has just a hint of metallic in the color keep it from being jet-black. The other ring rotates for time zones.I found the watch to be a bit heavier than I expected from the look. The face piece is about the same as a modern large cellar linked watch like a Samsung, Motorola, or iWatch.
