When her husband Ed is diagnosed with Alzheimers  she deals with the diagnosis, and later, with the deterioration of the man she loves, with a strength, kindness, and patience that few people would be able to muster.  And yet  there is still that other side of her personality that never really goes away.Its the true Alzheimers, she said, with something like pride at the thought that if her husband were to be destroyed by a degenerative neurological disorder, it would be the undiluted article, the aristocrat of brain diseases.Her thoughts and feelings are incredibly forceful and intense  so much so that many times she is unable to let them out.  In one scene, her husband and son are hugging just after they all learn about Eds diagnosis.  Her son, Connell, invites her into the hug, but The idea of a group hug embarrassed her and she couldnt comply.So much of Eileen is about the external.  How one is seen in the world, what other people think, what ones possessions say about him or her.  And yet, her life turns out to be more about whats inside. She, who dreams of the perfect, idyllic life does not shy away from the most grueling of circumstances.  Without complaint and without much serious thought of giving up, she cares for her husband until long past the time when most people would have buckled.If this book was about almost any other subject  I would say the level of detail, the descriptions that seem to go on and on would be too much.  But Alzheimers  the gradual disappearance of ones memory and identity  needs this minute step-by-step depiction in order for the reader to have some level of understanding of how cruel and unremitting it is.  Eds fight to hold on and Eileens determination to be with him during every step of that fight is an remarkable story  one that the reader cannot help but admire.Even with her faults  by the end of the book  Eileen proves herself to be a rare soul.  And as I finished this, as hard as it was to read at times, I could only think of those rare souls out there either battling this disease or those loved ones watching the battle being lost.

I couldn't resist the summery, cheerful design of this.  Picnics, barbecues, summer parties - it's just perfect for fun outdoor events.It's look is probably the best part - not that the rest is that bad.  It's just a little bit cheaply made (the insulation does not appear to be that sturdy and the handles are a bit stiff) - but once I read the tag - I realized that it's not maybe as versatile as I thought when I ordered it.  The small tag on the inside of the carrier says, "After removing casserole from oven, allow to cool for 5 minutes.  We recommend that you cool to 200 degrees."  I'm OK with the 5 minutes - it's the 200 degrees that I have a problem with.  I use these carriers (I also have a Traveling Chef carrier) to take hot dishes to places where there will probably or definitely not be a way to reheat them.  If I have to cool a dish down that far - this doesn't help.That being said - I will keep this and use it to transport dishes that need to stay cold - not hot.  (Also - I decided to keep the cardboard ring that comes on the inside of the carrier - I think that will help keep the top of the carrier from squishing down onto the food.  Helpful if the dish is only covered with foil or wrap.)This is a very cute carrier that I plan to use a great deal in the warm months whenever I have a dessert or cold dish to take to a party.

I own and like the Brother PT-P700 PC Connectable Label Maker  but since I use it so rarely  it is stored away  and is kind of a pain to get out for just a single label.  I have to get it out, hook it up to my laptop (which is also stored away), run the program, print the label and then put it all back.  (Wow, that makes me sound lazy!)When I saw THIS labelmaker  I thought it would be perfect.  I can keep it plugged in and tucked awayand just use my iPhone to print the random single labels I need.  (Note:  I saw the sticker on the side of the printer letting me know that I could just put my phone next to it and print and I got really frustrated when it didnt work.until I slowed down and actually read the note.  Only for Android phones.  DRAT!)But the app is simple to install and after a quick install so that the printer is part of our home Wi-Fi network  now this is simply perfect.  If I need to print a label for a binder or tote  just click the app, enter the text and print.  SO easy!This is just perfect for someone (like me) who likes labels (maybe a little bit too much) but wants to be able to print them on the go and without much fuss.  I just love this and plan on keeping and using it forever!

My father-in-law is a handyman - and he does everything.  Builds decks, fences, knocks down old buildings, builds pergolas and steps.  Since the weather is getting nicer - he is doing more deck/pergola work - which requires drilling into concrete for mounting braces and brackets.  Without the right equipment - that can be extremely difficult and time consuming - so I thought these would be perfect for him.He agreed - this set works very well - and the best feature is the built-in hex collar stop.  With most bits - you need to try a few test holes and then tape the bit to indicate the correct depth.  With these - there is no testing or guessing required.This set has exactly what he needs and he is very pleased with it.

If you need something that smaller kids will LOVE and have a great time playing with for one afternoon - this castle is perfect.  It's easy to assemble (one person can do it with a few seconds of assistance from another person) and is sturdy enough for a few hours of play.It's not very sturdy - but if the kids aren't trying to destroy it - it should withstand some play.  The turrets are very cool and there is a LOT of white space just waiting for young artists to fill up.  I got this for when my nieces (6 and 4) visit and I think they will love it - and that will last just about as long as they are here.

More than anything else, I love the tone, the sense of mystery and days long past that shrouds the books of Carlos Ruiz Zafn.  The words of his stories surround the reader with sepia tones, slightly blurry while lovely images, and the faintest background music of sad, romantic waltzes.  Just opening one of his books takes me to worlds Ive never seen, worlds that may never have existed  except in the longings of his characters.The Sarri cemetery is in one of Barcelonas best-hidden corners.  If you look for it on the map, you wont find it.  If you ask locals or taxi drivers how to get there, they probably wont know, although theyve all heard about it.  And if, by chance, you try to look for it on your own, youre more likely than not to get lost.  The lucky few who know the secret of its whereabouts suspect that this old graveyard is in fact an island lost in the ocean of the past, which appears and disappears at random.In Marina  his main characters are younger than usual  but no less surrounded by mystery.  In addition to the graveyard, there are majestic yet crumbling old mansions, an opera house lost in in tragedy, and family secrets that cling and nearly choke.Even after finishing the book, I know almost nothing about the main character, Oscar, and that is completely OK.  I know his part of this gothic tale and through his eyes; I was able to escape again to a long ago and far away world that I love.This book was sad and glorious.  Beautiful and horrific.  A wonderful story and an unbelievable fairy tale.  A great book and one I was sad to put down.

This is just a beautiful pan.  The styling is clean and elegant - and the size is perfect for stir frying.  I was a bit worried that the handle would be too long - but with no need.I still can't believe it is cast iron.  It weighs just as much as a regular (but well made) pan - but it cooks like cast iron.  I've sauteed in it with excellent results and made a bean dish in it.  It cooks very well and very evenly.  I have not yet tried taking it from stove to oven - I am nervous that it will ruin the look of the pan.The only criticism I have is that the lid doesn't fit as securely as I would have expected.  It's not a deal breaker - but I wish there was just a bit more heft to the lid and that it was just the slightest bit bigger so that there was a better seal.Overall, though, this is a wonderful pan and I plan on using it for years to come.

While I was deciding whether or not to splurge on wireless headphones for running - a friend lent me her set.  They were $99 - which was more than I planned to spend - but I wanted to get some sense of how much better running would be without the hassle of cords.The answer was MUCH better - but I wasn't impressed enough by the sound to spend that much money.  I looked around a bit more and found these - that seems just like the other pair - with the main difference being the better price.I'm so glad I shopped around!  Again - the sound isn't as good as my wired headphones...the bass isn't great and the sound is a bit echoey because they are jammed into your ears (the huge benefit is that they never fall out) - but for running?  They work just great.The controls are just like my iPhone headphones - super easy to use.  They charge quickly and pair with my phone with no problem.I love these and LOVE the fact that I paid so much less to run wirelessly!

I went back and forth with this book.  Was immediately interested in the bookstore, shelved it for a bit while finishing a few other books, got into it once I started it a few weeks later, forgot about it for several months, then picked it up again and then read it in two days.There is a great deal of The Killer Next Door that is standard thriller.  The cast is chock full of people with mysterious pasts, and until the identity of the killer is revealed  they are all suspects.  But starting with when that reveal happens (not at the end) and the depth that many (not all) of the characters are given  this is more than just a thriller.The story takes place in a rooming house, one managed by a very odd and sinister man, and inhabited by people who all have stories  few of them known by the other tenants.Vesta has lived at 23 Beulah Grove all her life.  Shes desperately hanging on to the only lifes shes ever known, even as she wishes for something different.  Shes been seeing her face in this carved wood frame for the whole of her life.  Still feels a sense of profound shock every time she glances into it and sees an almost-seventy-year-old woman staring back.  Where did it all go?  Did I really do so little, that Im still living here, surrounded by reminders of my parents tenancy before me  the Waterford vase, Mums collection of ceramic cottages, the framed photos of long-dead ancestors on the tallboy, The Crying Boy in the frame on the wall, Nans good teaset behind the glass of the display cabinet  with hardly a mark of my own life added on top?  Vesta is not the standard nosy old lady character.  Shes both terrified and brave, yearning for and fighting against change, and both utterly alone and the one tenant trying to create a family.There is also Collette  a woman trying to hide away in someone elses flat, Cher  scraping together some sort of life as she tries to find a way to a better future, Hossein  seeking both asylum and escape from his former life, and Thomas  the neighbor who no one really notices and who then plays the biggest role when a terrible accident changes everything.He stands awkwardly above them all, looking about for somewhere to site and radiating an air of suppressed astonishment that the chairs have run out.  I bet hes one of those people, thinks Collette, who always gives off a faint air of reproach, one of those people whos never truly happy unless hes hard done by.This book is not for the faint of heart.  Some of the descriptions of murder and the actions taken with the victims are truly sickening.  But the way the story is written and both the plot and the characters revealed make this a great read and a more than average thriller.

Ive read all of Jo Nesbos Harry Hole books and loved them.  I loved reading about such a flawed character  one who seems nearly fixated on destroying himself even as he tries to save others.With Blood on Snow  Nesbo has introduced another flawed character, Olav.  Hes a fixerin that he kills people for money in order to fix problems for his boss.  Olav is almost a killer with a heart of gold  the reader almost cant help but feel sorry for him and root for him even as he murders people without much emotional distress.This very short novel reads almost like a fairy tale.  Olav put me in mind of the characters of Quasimodo or even the Frankenstein monster  beings so far removed from normal human life that they seem doomed to lose even as they yearn for love.  The book is dreamlike and yet extremely violent.  Is heartbreaking as it is coldly calculating.  Nesbo toys with the readers emotions as much as he manipulates their impressions of events.Blood on Snow did not engross me the way the Harry Hole books did  but it was a short reminder of what I love about them and about the characters that Jo Nesbo brings to life.

Over the holidays, we got (2) pairs of wireless headphones.  This Turtle Beach set and a MEElectronics Air Fi Runaway set.  These two headphones are at wildly different price points  but they made for an interesting side by side comparison.The Turtle Beach headset has a charging station, which I think is fantastic.  It makes for an easy place to keep them and one less random cord at our charging area.  Connection via Bluetooth was seamless and quick.  They are also very flexible in that they twist and turn numerous ways and seem able to fit nearly any head type/shape.  The sound is good  with the foam pads completely enclosing the listeners ears  there is a true sense of surround sound and the bass is very rich.But.  These are SO heavy.  I cant imagine wearing them for more than maybe 15-20 minutes.  And I know devout gamers play for hours and hours on end  I dont know how these would be comfortable for that sort of duration.  Also  the max volume wasnt all that loud.Using the much more affordable headphones as a comparison  that set is FAR lighter and more comfortable, and the volume can be increased much louder.  But the bass and depth of sound isnt as good as the Turtle Beach set.I liked the wired option that the Turtle Beach set provided  I can see using these while working on a PC  but probably not for too long given the weight.At this price  I am not sure these headphones are worth it.

I found this book to be just fascinating.  The title is certainly intriguing, but it was also a rare book that actually made me change my opinions on an issue.  And THAT doesn't happen very often.  I also think in the research and writing of this book, author Jon Ronson had a similar experience.One of his first quick examples involves an LA Fitness that was shamed on social media because they wouldn't cancel the membership of a couple who had lost their jobs and couldn't afford the fees.  The result of that was that LA Fitness backed down - a story that makes one believe in the "power of the people"."Something of real consequence was happening.  We were at the start of a great renaissance of public shaming.  After a lull of almost 180 years (public punishments were phased out in 1837 in the United Kingdom and in 1839 in the United States), it was back in a big way.  When we deployed shame, we were utilizing an immensely powerful tool.  It was coercive, borderless, and increasing in speed and influence.  Hierarchies were being leveled out.  The silenced were getting a voice.  It was like the democratization of justice."He may have started this project with that feeling, I don't think he believed this at the end.One famous (infamous) example of modern day public shaming was the story of Justine Sacco - a woman who had made a VERY ill-thought out tweet at the beginning of a plane flight to Africa - and whose life was ruined by the time she landed.  (To confirm how long public shaming can stay with you - I just typed "Justine S" into a search engine - her name was the first result and this happened in 2013.)  As Ronson researches her story, and more importantly, meets and talks to Justine, the far reaching implications of a mistaken action that took only seconds to take, becomes very clear to him."A life had been ruined.  What was it for: just some social media drama?  I think our natural disposition as humans is to plod along until we get old and stop.  But with social media, we've created a stage for constant artificial high drama.  Every day a new person emerges as a magnificent hero or a sickening villain.  It's all very sweeping, and not the way we actually are as people.  What rush was overpowering us at times like this?  What were we getting out of it?"While most of what Ronson examines is what the shaming does to the shamee - but also - what it says about those who participate. I don't remember him using the term "mob mentality" - but that phenomenon is the underlying message of these case studies.The portion of the book that had the greatest impact on me was Ronson's conversations and dealing with judge Ted Poe.  (I, and maybe others know of him without knowing him - the judge that imposes sentences on people like standing on street corners holding signs about their crimes.  What I knew of him made me think he was cruel and something like a "hanging judge".  WOW did I have a different opnion after reading this part of the book and what we has to say about the people he dealt with.And I think (feel) the same thing happened to Ronson.  As he speaking with Judge Poe, "Social media shamings are worse than your shamings," I suddenly said to Ted Poe.  He looked taken aback.  "They are worse," he replied.  "They're anonymous."  "Or even if they're not anonymous, it's such a pile-on they may as well be."  "They're brutal," he said.I almost hated to put this book down - but in the week since I did so, I've thought about it many, many times - and have mentioned and discussed it with most of my friends and family.  This one will stick with me for a LONG time.

I don't buy or wear very much makeup - so what I do use needs to work and needs to last.  This eyeshadow seems to be exactly what I need.  The color palate is well chosen, and the shadow goes on smoothly and evenly.Again, because I don't wear much makeup?  I appreciate (and use) the chart on the back that shows where to apply the different colors.  I am a bit afraid of the boldest color - but with the picture showing just where and how to put that color - I ended up looking better than I expected.  (My 14-year old daughter said it made my eyes pop!)The quality of this appears excellent.  The shadow isn't cakey and after hours of wearing it, still appears smooth and even.  I'm very pleased with this product and will use it for (in my case) a LONG time to come.

I do slideshows for my family for major events (40th birthdays, 90th birthdays, graduations) and I put all of our video clips together at the end of the year  so I was very interested in this product.  I usually use MovieMaker  but the process of pulling the photos/clips into that program is long and tedious  and it takes HOURS to finalize the project and burn it to a DVD.  Ive looked at some other programs  but many of them dont allow the user to burn to a DVD  they allow online publishing only  so this was looking to be one of my few good options.The install process took quite a while  20+ minutes.  Once that was done, though, I decided to try it out without using any sort of manual or tutorial and see how intuitive the program was.  I did pretty well.  I like the layout  that for slideshows  I can mass import photos and then rearrange them VERY easily.  The tile layout style made the photos very easy to work with.I then turned to videos  and that was a bit trickier.  Once I figured how to import the movies as clips and not full movies  I started working faster.  (Also  once I turned the view to Timeline  that helped a GREA deal.)I was curious how full featured the music editor was.  Thats a big deal for me as I always want songs or lyrics to hit in just the right place of a slideshow.  As such, I need to do quite a bit of trimming and editing.  The answer was  very full featured.  More than I will ever use/understandand yet I can do what I need to.The publishing and burning to DVD still takes quite a while  although it is faster than MovieMaker.Im looking forward to really putting this program through its paces with my end-of-the-year movie in a couple of weeks  I think this will make the process much smoother and easier.

This is simply the perfect time in our nation's history to read this book.  With the recent financial collapse and the big banks only getting bigger and less responsible - a story about one of the most prolific bank robbers who IS punished for stealing while the banks get off scot-free - is just simply compelling."People today dont remember  the government doesnt want us to remember.  The Bank of the United States just vaporized  with $100 million of peoples life savings.  Its still the biggest bank failure in the history of the world.  Thousands of people were wiped out.  And did any of those bank managers responsible go to the big house like Willie did?  No they did not.  They sat around their country clubs laughing it up."Willie Sutton.  Willie the Actor.  An infamous quote is attributed to him: "Why do you rob banks?"  "Because that's where the money is."  It's a great quote - but he denied ever saying it.  (Although he did use it for the title of one of the two books he wrote later.  In "Where the Money Was" - he says, "Why did I rob banks? Because I enjoyed it. I loved it. I was more alive when I was inside a bank, robbing it, than at any other time in my life. I enjoyed everything about it so much that one or two weeks later I'd be out looking for the next job. But to me the money was the chips, that's all.")This novel about Sutton was just fascinating.  It was well written, well laid out...and was based on just an incredibly interesting character.  "He was Henry Ford by way of John Dillinger  with dashes of Houdini and Picasso and Rasputin.  The reporters know all about Suttons stylish clothes, his impish smile, his love of good books, the glint of devilment in his bright blue eyes, so blue that the FBI once described them in bulletins as azure.  Its the rare bank robber who moves the FBI to such lyricism."Whether the story is taking place in the present (the Christmas Day Willie was released from jail) or in his past - the action, events, characters and descriptions are just so well done.  They are vibrant without being overblown.  The reader is made aware that the events are based on Willie's memories - and that they may be colored in the process.  And the flavor of the times the story moves through - from the 1900's to the 1980's...is just so well delivered."Baseball is everything at Eastern State.  Its the best way of killing time, of forgetting time, and one of the few sources of triumph and manly pride.  The six prison teams, therefore, play to win.  Murderers pitch inside.  Mob bosses crowd the plate.  Arsonists steal home every chance they get.  Things can get out of hand quickly.  And yet every game also features a moment or two of pure calm.  With each home run comes a tranquil pause, not just for the batter to round the bases, but for everyone else to stare in envy and wistfulness at the spot where the ball went over the wall."When I finished this book (far too soon, it felt) - I was left feeling about the story the way one of the chroniclers of Willie's tale felt."Reporter admits to himself, driving from the steak house back to the hotel, that its a ridiculous hope.  But no more ridiculous than being fond of a hardened, unrepentant felon.  Then he corrects himself.  He wasnt fond in the usual sense of the word.  He wouldnt want to live in a world full of Willie Suttons.  Hes simply not sure that hed want to live in a world with no Willie Suttons."

I LOVE the idea behind this book.  Ghost ship?  Possible time travel?  Im in!The first chapter was intriguing.  Suitably spooky without being a horror story.  I was quickly sucked into the story of the ghost ship Valkyrie.  Sailors board a deserted ship found as they drift through a mysterious fog at a time when their compass is malfunctioning.  They hear (or almost hear) voices  but there are no people left on the ship.  It is completely deserted. They hear noises that make no sense.  There is ice forming around them  in August.  It was a great start to what promised to be a fascinating mystery.And then I got to Part Two  Kate.  Kate, a.k.a. Catalina Soto, is one of the most poorly written characters Ive ever read.  Shes extremely uneven.  At times she is incredibly emotional  all while the reader is being told she is tough as nails.  She finds herself extremely attractive  but in a way that a 14-year old girl might.  At one point, she actually says (out loud) - I think shes much prettier than me, when discussing another female character.Some of the sections written about Kate are just nearly painful to read.  The old Kate was back, joyfully irreverent, if only for a brief time.  Easy now, world. Im still just as screwed up.  The thought popped with such force that Kate almost jumped.But as much as I couldnt accept Kate as a remotely believable character, I kept reading so that I could find out what the Valkyrie was all about.But then  as she becomes more involved with the ship and with the mysterious billionaire who owns it  I just found myself shaking my head too often.  After another ship experiences a disaster as it nears the Valkyrie  Kate is told that it was an accidental explosion.  Kate, who is a reporter, remember, thinks:  She had seen the fire from the explosion.  She was no expert on the matter, but she was certain the fire had not been caused by a steam valve bursting.  Pretty impressive that she could tell the cause of an explosion on a ship was could only see across the water.So  I gave up.  I may go back to this as I would really like to find out what happens  but I can only take so much of Kate (or to be more accurate  the poorly written character of Kate) in one sitting.

This product is extremely difficult to set up.  After opening it - I read the manual (where the diagrams aren't particularly helpful) and tried for about 30 minutes to get through the setup process.  I gave up.  I could never get the pen/receiver/iPhone app to sync up.  So I put it aside until the weekend - and then started over.  STILL confusing - still hard to set up - so I went to the manufacturer's website - which is absolutely awful.  Not a single helpful tip on there - unless you want to buy one of these pens.  THAT they make easy.So in desperation, I turned to YouTube - which I normally hate.  But - a helpful video by a user of the pen gave me the directions I needed to get the pen synced and working.  And once the setup process is over (thank goodness) - this is a great product.I often have take take meeting notes at work and then go back to desk and transcribe them.  With this pen, now it is a MUCH faster process.  With the text recognition feature - not I don't have to do the work twice.  (My handwriting is awful - so I still need to edit the text that comes up - but it still saves a great deal of time.)  And the fact that you can send straight to Evernote?  Which is one of the best programs/apps ever?  A HUGE plus.A few small things I've noticed:1) The edges of the paper you're working on seem to be tough for the receiver to pick up.  If you leave a decent margin around the sides of the paper - you'll be fine.2) You can't write on a pad of paper - only loose pages.  Probably 5 at most.3) The video I watched said the pen could store up to 10,000 pages - which seems astounding to me.  I'm nowhere near that amount - but I would say that this pen would cover most anyone's needs.4) Drawings made with this pen show up on the screen just like they are on the paper.  That is extremely cool.5) Another thing I didn't realize until I watched the video was that you can take just the pen and the receiver with you, write whatever you write, and then later one, turn on the app and import your notes.  So as long as you have the pen and it's charged - you don't need to have your computer/iPad/iPhone with you.Overall - I would give the setup process 1 star and the use process 5 stars.  If you can get this working - it's a fantastic product.

When this lantern arrived, I was in shock.  I was sure there had to be some sort of mistake.  This looks like a lantern made for a Barbie.  Seriously - it's basically palm sized.  Small.  Lightweight and CERTAINLY compact.Once I stopped shaking my head, I put some batteries in and tried it out.And stopped laughing.  This thing, running on (3) AA batteries is REALLY bright.  Even on the lowest white setting, it easily lights a dark, windowless bathroom.  It has (2) brighter settings - and I would think that given the light it puts out - would light up a tent/camp site or large room in case of a power outage.  And really?  Only (3) AA batteries?  This would be a perfect lantern for a backpacker or for keeping in the car (which I plan to do).I am still surprised but very pleased with this.  I almost can't wait until the first time I need it...for the reaction on other peoples faces when I first pull it out - and then turn it on.This is just a great, rugged, ridiculously compact lantern.  Seems a bit overpriced - but if performance and size matter?  It's perfect.

This is really cool!  This coil design makes for tweezing hairs in sensitive areas much less painful.  I had to turn it a few different ways before I really got the hang of it - but twisting the coils is a much easier and much less eye-watering way to remove unwanted hairs.I did some facial hair areas very quickly, without much pain or redness and my face was much smoother afterwards.  There were a few more coarse hairs that I ended up having to tackle on their own - but for a couple of minutes work - this device took care of all the rest.After the first few seconds - it is easy to get the hang of this design and I am very glad I got this.  I would definitely recommend this over regular tweezers and certainly over those stinky creams or waxes.

I chose this to wear under my Thanksgiving dress. I thought it was the perfect occasion  need to look your best AND be able to eat a LOT of food comfortably.  This certainly succeeds on the comfort front  it feels snug but I am still able to eat, breathe, sit, move, etc.What I wonder about is the look of it.  I ordered a Medium  which per the size chart  should work for me.  But it feels like this is too long waisted.  The panel that should be holding in my stomach site down at my hips  and if I move it into place  I get lines and rolls.  Still  I tried this under my dress  which is medium weight jersey.  I didnt notice all that much difference  but my husband and daughter said that my waist looked noticeably slimmer.  One definite drawback, though, is the neckline.  This has a relatively high rounded neck  which I found surprising.  Mine is a wrap dress, so I think I can make it work with judicious use of a safety pin.  But a low V-neck would be better.So the jury is still out a bit  but I guess since I think it is comfortable and people looking at me think it is flattering  then this is a success.  Once I wear it for longer periods of time  well see how it holds up and how I hold up wearing it for longer hours.

This is a combination review for both of Sara J. Henrys books featuring Troy Chance Learning to Swim and A Cold and Lonely Place.  I am combining them because after reading the second book (Cold and Lonely) this weekend  I rushed to get the first book (Learning to Swim) and read both of them within about 48 hours.  And even though Id read them out of order (and the second book heavily references the first)  it didnt matter.  I was absolutely hooked by the authors style and by her main character.Troy Chance is an extremely interesting character.  Much of the choices shes made in her life regarding her job, how far she chooses to live away from her family and her relationship status seem to make her seem like somewhat of a loner.  When she reflects upon these choices, it seems as if she thinks that to be the case as well.  But at the core of her, the reader discovers, the problem is not that she doesnt care about other people, it is that she cares too much.  Troy is incredibly empathetic without being overly emotional.  She connects with the people she meets and the people she encounters in these two books in a way that I found very compelling.  She makes their lives, their problems her own  and has a very difficult time when it comes time to break away.Several times in each book, Troy finds she has information that she can choose to give to a person whom it will greatly impact.  She wrestles with the choices, and with the results.  Sometimes letting the truth out lets people heal, and sometimes it makes things worse.  And you couldnt really know which, until you did it, and sometimes only later.I almost couldnt put these books down.  Not only was I drawn to this interesting main character and to the plots of the books  author Sara J. Henrys writing style just washed over me.  Her prose is clean, uncluttered and yet is still descriptive enough to pull the reader into the places and events as if they were actually there.These were well-written, interesting and at times suspenseful novels that I enjoyed a great deal.  Im hopeful I dont have to wait too long for another Troy Chance book!

This is a combination review for both of Sara J. Henrys books featuring Troy Chance Learning to Swim and A Cold and Lonely Place.  I am combining them because after reading the second book (Cold and Lonely) this weekend  I rushed to get the first book (Learning to Swim) and read both of them within about 48 hours.  And even though Id read them out of order (and the second book heavily references the first)  it didnt matter.  I was absolutely hooked by the authors style and by her main character.Troy Chance is an extremely interesting character.  Much of the choices shes made in her life regarding her job, how far she chooses to live away from her family and her relationship status seem to make her seem like somewhat of a loner.  When she reflects upon these choices, it seems as if she thinks that to be the case as well.  But at the core of her, the reader discovers, the problem is not that she doesnt care about other people, it is that she cares too much.  Troy is incredibly empathetic without being overly emotional.  She connects with the people she meets and the people she encounters in these two books in a way that I found very compelling.  She makes their lives, their problems her own  and has a very difficult time when it comes time to break away.Several times in each book, Troy finds she has information that she can choose to give to a person whom it will greatly impact.  She wrestles with the choices, and with the results.  Sometimes letting the truth out lets people heal, and sometimes it makes things worse.  And you couldnt really know which, until you did it, and sometimes only later.I almost couldnt put these books down.  Not only was I drawn to this interesting main character and to the plots of the books  author Sara J. Henrys writing style just washed over me.  Her prose is clean, uncluttered and yet is still descriptive enough to pull the reader into the places and events as if they were actually there.These were well-written, interesting and at times suspenseful novels that I enjoyed a great deal.  Im hopeful I dont have to wait too long for another Troy Chance book!

Our other toaster JUST started to go out on us - so I chose this as the replacement.  Starting out - my one complaint about this toaster was that the cord is not retractable.  (To be fair - the description never said that it was - I just feel that should almost be standard.  We keep our toaster in a cupboard and to not have a cord mess is a HUGE benefit.)Other than that - this is a good toaster.  I LOVE that the control is digital.  That is a major upgrade from what we had.  We have four toast eaters in the house - all with differing opinions on toast done-ness - and now that we each know our perfect #?  There is no fighting about turning the dial back.  This is a great feature.I also like the "Bagel" and "Defrost" options.  We eat frozen waffles and without that - it's tricky to get them completely done.  (Note:  Read the directions that say to press the "Defrost" or "Bagel" option AFTER depressing the lever.)The toaster starts up with a default level of "4" - which was perfect for my toast.  My kids like it lighter - the use "3".  Because this is chrome - I wonder how the surface will stand up to finger marks - but since we keep it out of sight - that really isn't a factor for us.This is a good toaster so far and the digital display is by far the best feature.

I am working on a slide show project and have LOTS of old picture to scan.  I chose this scanner because it was lightweight, only needed a USB plug-in and not separate power, and because we have a Canon printer that we have been happy with.All in all, the printer/scanner we have does just as good a job processing photos - if not better.This scanner was pretty easy to install (but be sure and turn it over to unlock it before you get frustrated and think it's broken) - but it doesn't scan very quickly.  Also, it makes a sort of grinding/cutting noise as it is scanning.  (Like an electric paper cutter or a label maker at it cuts the tape.)  I scanned the same picture in our Canon MX520 and in this scanner - and the picture quality is nearly identical.  (I thought the image from the printer was slightly better - my husband though the scanner image was slightly better.)At the end of the day, I would say that if you had a great deal of photos to scan and wanted to be able to move around while you do it (I tend to sit and watch TV while I scan) - this is a good scanner for you.  Again - because you can just plus it into your laptop and go.But if you already have a decent quality printer/scanner - I am not sure this is worth adding.

I just love these.  I first saw them at a chain retail store for $14.95 - and immediately wanted them!  But since I wanted to get 3 amber and 3 white strands (Thanksgiving decor then Christmas decor) - I didn't want to pay $14.95 each.This pricing was MUCH better and they just look lovely woven through garland.  Every time I turn them on - I like them more.  These are WELL worth the cost and I am extremely pleased with this purchase.

I really enjoyed "The Bookseller".  I am a huge fan of books that manipulate time/present alternate realities.  In "The Bookseller", a woman named Katharyn/Kitty finds herself dreaming of an alternate version of her life.During the day she works with her best friend in their bookshop, goes home to her cat, and is very close to her parents.  She  enjoys the freedom of a single life.  At night, once she is asleep, she finds herself as a married woman named Katharyn.  She is married to a handsome, kind man named Lars, she lives in a custom home, has children and doesn't work outside the home.  There is much of this dream life that she loves - Lars seems wonderful and their life together seems picture perfect.  But the more dreams she has, the more she experiences of this alternate world, the more she learns that nothing is perfect.  No life is perfect.Her lives are similar enough that there is a great deal of intersection.  She lives in the same town, at about the same time (the two versions are about 6 months apart).  But in each - there are differences.  She's made different choices, different life-changing events have or have not happened - and she finds herself struggling to keep a hold of what is real - what her true life looks like and what she really wants.I usually make notes and mark quotes as I read a book.  But this one was so engrossing and I was so eager to find out what happened next that I read it in two days with nary a note.This is not only a book that gives Katharyn the chance to see "what if" - it also gets to the heart of how life changes us.  How the events that occur, or don't occur, in our lives shape us and guide our choices.  "The Bookseller" also takes a look at the person we are at our core.  Who we truly are, regardless of circumstance, and how we deal with what lives we have.This was a great book and a very enjoyable read.

My husband said that these briefs fit well - if just a but snugly.  With the material it is made of - that is to be expected.  They breathe very well - he's run in them and felt very comfortable.They do take a bit of getting used to under jeans - with a snug fit on the upper legs - it certainly feels different than cotton.  The waistband is comfortable - and my husband is a big fan of tagless clothing.These are very good for everyday use but might be even better for exercise days or hot days.

I love Kindle covers.  I have a Kindle Fire - and 4 different covers for it.  I have a Kindle Paperwhite - and this is my second cover for that.  Of course I want the cover to protect my device - but I also want it to look nice and more importantly, feel good in my hand.  Because I use it a LOT.The cover is pretty basic as far as looks go.  It's sleek and modern - and is a bit bigger than my previous cover.  The inside elastic straps hold the Kindle firmly, and the elastic around the whole cover holds it closed when you are not reading.  (That is a feature my other cover does not have that I miss.)  Also - that strap works as a hand hold - so you can read one-handed with your right hand.  Unfortunately - there is nothing to grip if you wanted to read holding it in your left hand.The cover is relatively lightweight so that it doesn't make your Kindle too bulky.I'd say this is pretty basic as far as covers go - no cool designs or spectacular features - but it certainly does the job and does feel good even after hours of reading.

These drills feel good to hold - the size is great for around the house projects, not too heavy, but rugged enough to feel confident they can stand on their own.The drill is powerful enough to handle the wood I used it on with multiple sized bits.  The light feature when you press the trigger is convenient when you're working in not so well lit places.  The impact drill is great for small projects and speeds the process of replacing a bolt/nuts.  I'm not sure if my husband will use the carrying case much, but if he needs to - it's not too bulky.The batteries snap in and out easily - and help a great deal in reducing the weight of the drill.  The one thing my husband pointed out was that the impact driver did not come with a 1/4 " bit - so in order to use the driver - you will need to either have one of those or purchase one to use this with any of your sockets.So far - this is a nice set and very easy to use!

My 11-year old son really liked this book.  He thought it was very entertaining - and while he was reading next to me - there were several parts that he had to read aloud to me because he thought they were so funny.His favorite character was March McQuin (the main character) - the son of a notorious cat burglar.  When March's father dies - March tries to step into his father's shoes - and tries to find the sister he never knew he had.The action moves quickly and my son stayed up late a few nights reading - so I think this book was a hit.

Both my 13-year old daughter and I LOVED the first book in this series.  It ended with a huge cliffhanger  so when I saw book 2 was out  I had to get it right away.  (And read it as fast as possible so I could pass it to my daughter.)Reading it quickly wasnt a problem - I enjoyed Times Edge almost as much as the first book.  Second books in great series play a very tough role.  The novelty of the first book has worn off and expectations are probably higher.  With a book about time travel  there is also some catchup to play on the readers part  remembering what has happened in the past AND in the future.  That being said, when I read the following paragraph near the beginning, I knew I was all the way in again:"I rinse away the shampoo , and a small leaf that must have been caught in my hair slides down my leg toward the drain.  It's red, dappled with gold, and I realize that I must have carried it back from Dealey Plaza."  Kate (like so many other time travelers) ventured back to Dallas in November of 1963  and this sentence just reminded me all over again what I love about these What If? type books.  There are so many possibilities  so many chances to imagine alternate realities.Kate has so much on her shoulders in this book.  She knows what the future holds if she is unable to accomplish her mission and prevent the deaths of half of the worlds population.  As a character, she balances that incredible knowledge and responsibility well  while also worrying about whether her boyfriend, Trey, will be able to love her again despite the fact that he doesnt remember even meeting her.At times the book is a bit of a brain twister as Kate travels to multiple times/places  and some places multiple times.  Keeping track of who did what in which timeline can be tough  but after a while  its easier to just put that aside and just flow along with the action in the book. Rysa Walker does a good job of keeping things on track  and of balancing the elements of teen romance/time travel/social commentary.This is just a very enjoyable book  one that both my daughter and I were very excited to read.  The last 50 pages or so kept me up late last night  and sure enough  theres another cliff hanger to end the book  making me that much more anxious for more!

My review for this pillow depends on the size of the person.  My husband is 6' 4" and loves this.  He's only used it for long car rides so far - but it's extremely comfortable when trying to sleep sitting up.  The fabric is plush and the memory foam holds his head up yet allows him to rest.  He thinks he'd take it for plane rides as well - but the size is pretty big for air travel - so he's not completely sure.I'm 5' 5" and I don't like it.  I don't think I have a particularly short neck - but almost from the moment I put this on - I felt like it was almost choking me.  It keeps my head straight up and I can't find a position in which I can imagine myself sleeping or resting.  It's just too big and comes too high up on my neck - almost into my face.So I would say this is ideal for larger people and for car rides.  We'll keep ours in our car, most likely, and I think it will be officially my husband's.

Previous to this  my 11-year old son liked Poached the best of Stuart Gibbs books.  He liked Space Case even better  so we are both hopeful this is the start of a series.The main character of Space Case is Dashiell  a young boy who parents were chosen to go to Moon Base Alpha  the first colony on the moon.  Its supposed to be nice and a great adventure  but it turns out not to be anything like that.Dashiell gets involved in a mystery regarding the death of Dr. Ronald Holtz.  Everyone else thinks he died as a result of an accident  but Dashiell suspects foul play.  No one believes him  and other people are trying to keep him quiet.My son really enjoyed this book  he thought the best part was when Dashiell solves the case.  He read it very quickly  and again  we both hope there are follow up novels.

I debated getting this book after skimming some other reviews.  They were positive - but several mentioned that the story wouldn't make as much sense/be as meaningful without reading the other books about the main character first.I would guess that the story would be a bit richer had I known more about Charles Maddox's past - but I was able to navigate through and thoroughly enjoy "The Pierced Heart" as a stand alone novel.The prose is nearly hypnotic as the reader is immediately drawn into the Victorian age and into the lore of vampires.  There is a haunting feel to both the sections from Charles' viewpoint and the sections from Lucy's diary.  The two narratives mesh nicely together - and the only stumbling points were when the story is pulled from them into an omniscient point of view. The feel and the flow of the story are interrupted and would be better served without these sections.This story of darkness and light, of love and madness, of science and of experimentation was well done and I will make a point of looking for a new book in the series.

Although at the beginning of the book, the main character's voice reads as far more mature than his years, this story is interesting and I was engrossed in it from the start.  The action moves quickly and the characters are interesting.  I did feel that the grief aspect (once one of the main characters dies) was glossed over.  There is a great deal of discussion about how grief is perceived and how one of the characters should feel - but this death doesn't seem to affect anyone the way it should.I already placed a pre-order for the next book in this series.  I absolutely had to once the story takes a MAJOR 90 degree turn at the end and I can't imagine not finding out what happens next.

I have another or these portable chargers and it is a life saver.  Being able to store power for when you really need it is VERY handy.  Because we use that one so often - I decided to get another.  (We have a ridiculous number of devices in our household.)I was pretty surprised at how heavy this charger is.  It has some serious heft to it - and if someone was buying this to hike or backpack with - I am not sure they would be pleased.  (We just take ours for car/plane travel - so it is not an issue for us.)That being said - it charges FAST.  We charged my husband's iPhone 5s from 10% to 95% in an hour and a half AND when we were done - the portable charger still showed full battery capacity.  (My other portable charger will charge the phone - but more slowly and will be depleted at the end.)This will be very handy to have around for emergencies.

I am SHOCKED that I was able to install this and that it works.  My HP laptop is...5 years old?  And it is crazy slow.  but I just can't bring myself to buy a new one right now as this one is still serviceable - it's just frustrating.  So when I saw this product - I asked a friend of mine who is FAR more computer savvy than I if he thought I could install it - and he said yes.Even then - it sat on my shelf for a week before I was brave enough to start the process.  (Partly because it did not come with the cord  I needed to connect this drive to my computer for the cloning process and I had to buy a USB to Sata converter cable (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008ASF5MC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) from Amazon.  Also - keep in mind that this drive comes with NO instructions - and that you'll probably need another PC or tablet open so you can be reading from that as you work through the cloning and install process.Finally - I felt ready.  I tried downloading the recommended cloning software from the SanDisk site - but that did not work.  (The software was never able to recognize the drive.)  Read through another Amazon review for this drive and downloaded Macrium Reflect software.  With that - it was able to recognize the SSD drive and start cloning my hard drive.  That process took about 3 hours.  Then, I took a few deep breaths and opened my laptop, carefully removed the hard drive, removed the bracket from it, installed the SSD drive into the bracket and then into the laptop, tightened the screws, put the battery back in, plugged in the power cord, turned it on, closed my eyes and crossed my fingers.The speed is SO much better.  While it certainly doesn't seem like a brand new laptop right off the shelf - the boot up time, the time it takes to open programs is WAY better.  And as far as I can tell (so far) - everything still seems to work!  (I do have all of my data/pictures/video stored on an external drive - so that did take some of the stress off.)Anyway - so far so great.  Drawbacks are the lack of cord and lack of instructions - but if I can get to the instructions and pull of what seems like a computer miracle?  Anyone can.

There is something to the quality of Anna Quindlens writing that just astounds me.  Somehow, it is both incredibly delicate and undeniably powerful.  She is able to describe moments and feelings in a way that is both stunning it its beauty and its strength.Blessings is the story of several people whose lives are forever changed with the arrival one night of a baby girl.  Left on the doorstep of the mansion which is the centerpiece of a small town, this baby becomes the center of the lives of Lydia Blessing, the owner, and her caretaker, Skip.  Each is forced to reevaluate their lives as they find themselves forever changed by the life of this child.Lydia Blessing, now an old woman, finds herself changing is ways she never expected, and realizing that her life had been very different than shed previously thought.  And the child at its center, crowing and smiling and waving her arms about.  They had all made her want more than she had.  The curse of having young people about the house was that they were always so redolent of possibility.Skip, a man whose life is at a crossroads between possibility and disaster, takes in and cares for Faith.  His life changes in an instant, to something he can barely recognize, and to something he is in constant wonder about.  That was all right, too, because seeing it just reminded him that it was kind of a fluke.  Like Faith had been, a burst of something incandescent in a long stretch of grey days.This is a story of choices and consequences.  Where people are forced to reexamine who they are, who they were and who they hope to be.  How people adapt, or refuse to adapt to circumstances.  How the past has a greater impact on our current lives than we can possibly until  sometimes until it is too late.It is also a story of incredible loss.  Loss of life, of love, and of possibility.  The world continues on, whether we want it to or not  whether we accept the direction or not.  There was a weight to the emptiness of rooms in which you had once lived that was more fearsome than anything she had ever encountered in life, not because they were haunted, as she had joked with Skip Cuddy, but because they were not.  The conversations, the quarrels, the long fraught silences, the tears: they had disappeared utterly and completely.As Ive thought about this book and the best word I might use to describe it  the closest I could come was poignant.  Its not what I would choose  but the definition, affecting or moving the emotions certainly applies to this beautifully written story.

These placements are a big improvement over my old ones.  Big in style AND size.My old placemats were boring - solid olive green.  They do the job - but they didn't lend any style to our table.  These placemats are bright and dress up our table setting.  When I originally ordered these - I was unsure whether they were a daisy print or a more Asian design.  They are neither - they are more a throwback to the sixties - a slightly muted "harvest gold meets avocado green" type pattern.  (My husband likes them but says they make him thing of his grandma - I think they are more hip than that.)And big in size!  That is the only drawback for me.  Ours is a taller bistro-ish type kitchen table - 36" x 54".  Our old placemats were 12"x17" - these are 15"x18" - they seem to take up the entire tabletop.  I'm still getting used to that...Other reviews have mentioned that these need to be ironed (which is a task I despise) - but even our old thicker ones needed to be pulled out of the dryer wet and dried flat - so that doesn't bug me too much.Anyway - they liven up the table and brighten up the kitchen - so for now I really like these!

In a slightly less dark way  The Supernatural Enhancements puts me in mind of House of Leaves by Mark D. Danielewski.  That was a book of twists and turns  ones that are puzzling at the least  gravity and time bending at most.  There is an unreliable narrator (for different reasons) and all along the reader knows s/he is only being given the smallest glance through a peephole to try and catch a fleeting glimpse of what is going on.This story has all of the elements of a classic haunting.  Using letters, journal entries, book excerpts, newspaper clippings and accounts of audio and video recording  the reader learns of a mysterious house bequeathed by a distant uncle whod committed suicide.  (Or had he?)  The lore surrounding the house including a girl ghost (or was she real?).  A main character who cannot speak (or can she?). The reader is unsure who or what to believe  and doesnt know if the main character, the mysterious A, has any better ideaor if through his perspective, we are being sucked down the rabbit hole along with him.The writing, in the narrative sections, is well done.  There are a few phrases I could have done without, Crop fields dash across her irises as she feasts on the continent.  But most of the book does an excellent job building the tension, giving the reader tantalizing bits of a much larger, haunting story.This silence here was somewhat heavier, lonelier than the preceding one.  The former was an elevator silence; this one was a walking-through-the-woods-by-night silence.There is a sarcastic sense of humor at play as well that I enjoyed.  Theres no way ghosts can casually wash up in social talk.  People who just let slip a reference to the occult in the middle of a serious debate (like, I read in the Post that the global economy will relapse, and so says Saturn in Capricorn) deserve execution.  "A often acknowledges the absurdity of the rapidly deteriorating situation in the old house  yet in doing so  doesnt let the tension sag.There is a wonder to the story as well.  A desperately wants to believe in something larger than himself, and cannot.  He mocks faith while being jealous of those who have it.  He is obsessed with his search for answers, while wanting to find something that has no explanation.  It is one of the few things in the world that trespasses on the boundaries of our comprehension, that blatantly escapes mankinds consensus of what is real, of what is possible.This is a ghost story, a story about humanity, a mystery and a love story.  All of these things  of sorts.

When I saw FROM THE EDITOR OF STIEG LARSSON, author of the Millennium trilogy on the top of the description of this book  I had two very conflicting thoughts.  1) That is really cheesy.  Not the author  but the editor?  REALLY?!?  2) Wow  I think I really want to read this book.  So their cheesy marketing ploy?  Totally successful.The other thing that drew me to this book was the term Hitchcockian.  Which was a term I didnt really think applied as I read through the first few chapters of the book.  And then.  Then I got to the first twist.  And I was completely hooked.  And just when I thought it was safe to settle into the book thinking of it as just a good thriller with a twistI got to the next twist.  And then I knew I couldnt take anything for granted in this book.In Alex  the terms hero/heroine/victim/villain become very had to pin down on any one character.  Every time you think you have someone figured out  it seems like the next page reveals your mistake.The writing (translating) style is very clean  allowing the reader to fly through the book.  Its not great literature  but its not meant to be.  Its meant to be a crackling good story  plot driven but with characters that have enough depth to be legitimate.  I very much enjoyed reading this book and certainly look forward to reading the next book in the trilogy.

I was surprised at how small the box was and was afraid there would be a LOT of assembly.  But as my husband laid it out - the plate and the bracket were hooked together so the only assembly was to connect the arms (really more like fingers, I guess) to the plate, mount the plate to the TV and then to mount the TV to the arm.  (The template provided was VERY helpful in mounting the arm to the wall stud.)There was a level included, which was nice AND there was a level on the plate itself.  The construction felt very sturdy - which was nice given how expensive an object was going to be mounted on it.  My one concern is that because of the design of this (with the modulating arm) - the mount would only be attached to one wall stud.  That SHOULD be enough - but time will tell.  In our application, the arm was absolutely necessary as we need to mount our TV in a corner.The swivel options are good - you can move the screen in many ways to create a better viewing experience.The install process might be longer than expected (30-40 minutes) but most of that has to do with wanting things very secure and in just the right place.All in all, this appears to be a great product that does what we need it to do in a very small space.  We've gotten other products in the past that we couldn't use but finally have one we can.

My husband's first shave with this was on a day where he had a pretty decent beard - it had been at least 4 days since his last shave.  He charged it fully and then set to work - and even though there was a LOT of shaving to do - he ended up with a very close, smooth shave and the shaver still had 83% percent power.  The shaver was quiet, very light to hold and very flexible - able to maneuver in and out of crevices.He used it today (2 days later) and it was still at 71% after being off the charger. The shave was very smooth again, and after accidentally cumping the "+" button - he found out it works even better at a faster speed.  (Although that did tell me that the speed buttons are easy to bump.)  He also tried out the trimmer - and it worked very well on his sideburns.As an observer (and a wife) I am not thrilled with the size of the cleaning base.  I think it's really big - providing even more clutter on our bathroom counter.  He didn't even notices the size - being so thrilled with the self-cleaning aspect of the shaver.So far - this shaver is a huge hit.  Given the price - it should perform as well as it does - but so far - I've heard nothing but raves.  Quiet, efficient, fast, sell-cleaning?  It meets all needs!

As a grill for ONE person - this is a good product.  The plates are nonstick and flexible enough to accommodate a thick chicken breast, burger patty or sandwich.  They don't burn the food and provide for an even consistency.  We did grilled turkey and cheese - and the cheese was very evenly melty.  It seems kind of cheaply made?  But I know people who've owned these in the past and they seem to last. It heats up fast and is easy to clean (though please note - the plates do not come off - you just need to clean them with a wet soapy cloth.)But.  This product says this is a grill for 4.  I do not see ANY way you can heat up food for 4.  Again, we did grilled sandwiches - and we fit 1 - maybe 1 1/2 sandwiches on there.  I can see maybe 2 chicken breasts fitting - if they were on the smaller side - but there is NO WAY you could cook food for 4 on this.  It's WY too small for that.I think this is a perfect grill for a single person, or for a quick lunch - but this is not the size grill for a family.

The texture of this tablecloth makes it look and seem fancier than it really is (based on price).  It looks very elegant  yet the fabric seems far more practical and better able to stand up to stains and spills.Because Id read several reviews regarding the size and shrinkage of the cloth  the first thing I did was throw it in the wash.  It did shrink  now JUST covering the 6 table I got this for.  There are maybe 2 inches of overhang left on either long side.  Its JUST acceptable enough for a dinner party tablecloth  but hopefully the shrinking is done.  I was impressed by the very few wrinkles it had after going through the washer/dryer  requiring much less ironing (which I despise).This is a very pretty, elegant and affordable tablecloth  as long as it stays long enough to actually cover the table.
My son LOVES Hurley shirts and this is a nice design to add to his wardrobe.  By the size charts, he should be a medium - but I had to return that and get a large.
My son LOVES Hurley shirts and this is a nice design to add to his wardrobe.  By the size charts, he should be a medium - but I had to return that and get a large.

This book grabbed me from the first sentence.  They never found his hands.  After that  I practically inhaled this book  reading it on one day.I am a reluctant fan of unreliable/anonymous narrators. Its a tricky plot device to pull off  so when it is done well (as it is here)  it adds to the readers interest.  When not done well  those are books that make me roll my eyes.  In The Forgers  the only once named narrator is very unreliable yet the reader believes enough of what s/he is being told to be all in and to root against those who wish him harm.  This character refers to himself as a shadow man several times  adding to the intrigue. Usually endearments  none of which need to be listed here, as we are all guilt of the same maudlin sobriquets  dislodged my given name from our conversation, which was fine by me.  Shadow men never like being called by nameOur narrator is a forger.  Mostly, supposedly, reformed.  This story takes place with his legal troubles in the past  and with a different scandal, the murder of his girlfriend Meghans brother (he of the forever missing hands) just having been discovered.The reader is never really able to get an authentic sense of our protagonist.  At times  he is very bitter about not being able to create his art  and the reader is sure he will lapse back into forging inscriptions and letters by famous authors.  That he cant keep saying no to the yearnings that call him to put pen to ink.I incarcerated the word permanent because I think it is one of the most fraudulent words in the English language, and signifies an incontestable falsehood.  Another part, however, suspected the letters and that unpublished manuscript fragment were simply too good to be true  much like the idea of permanenceAt times, we are told and feel, the great love he has for Meghan  and it seems she will be enough of an incentive for him to stay the path of the straight and narrow.  We do see him lie to her  but only at times that seem warranted by the increasingly disturbing circumstances that surround him.It takes a lot of truth to tell a lie.  Truth must surround the pulsing heart of any lie for it to be convincing, believable.  A pack of lives, like a house made from a pack of cards, will never remain standing.  But a gracefully designed construction built on both visible and underlying truths had every chance of passing muster, of passing the test of time.Yet his life always circles around the temptation to forge.  To improve rare books, to add to the history surrounding great authors and immortal literature.  To put his mark, in his way, on history.  And he meets another shadow man  who proves a great danger to his carefully scripted life.  We both were forgers as well as forgeries  we pretended to be real men, sophisticated, educated, entrepreneurial gentlemen, men who got away with what we set our minds to get away with. But as much as it pained me to admit it to myself, we were only the shadows of men of true substance.In this element of his character, I was constantly reminded of Humbert Humbert.  A man who considers himself far above the rest, of refined tastes and of high intelligence...who just beneath the surface is one driven by the basest of instincts.  A character the reader knows he or she should not like  but who captures the interest and refuses to let go.The main character of The Forgers is himself a forgery  and remains so after he claims to have turned his life around.  Just what details of his life turn out to be fake  are startling to say the leastand had me almost turn right back to They never found his hands.

I like the design of this.  The little, stubby (but VERY secure) feet give it some style.  The handles are easy to grip and make me feel more secure about holding it even when working with hot pasta/pasta water.Speaking of the feet - this is an improvement over my previous colander - because the feet are just that little bit taller. Totally not of interest to me. The rest of the series was top notch. This book was something else entirely, and while it may well appeal to some readers, I think it's safe to say the reasons it would appeal are going to be separate from those that defined the pull of the other books.

The show is fun, and I enjoy it -- but the original movie was serious, and honestly.... I enjoyed that considerably more (Limitless is a great movie, highly recommended.) I think the series makes a mistake in trying to make it so much about humor.Having said that, I do watch, and I will continue watching. Perhaps if I had not seen the movie first, I would be perfectly happy with it. I really liked the show Chuck, so it seems likely that funny takes on serious issues isn't the root of my issue here, it's more that this particular subject matter was simply better when treated as drama.

The audio quality with this is less than ideal. There is a strong "whine" in the audio output received by the FM radio; the most you can do is crank your phone or other audio source up as far as it will go, so that the music is, hopefully anyway, louder than the whine. Unfortunately, when the type of music you like has quiet spots in it... then you're going to hear the whine no matter what you do. This is a pretty serious problem for a device which is intended primarily to reproduce music.Other than that, it's easy to use, simple to plug in, and the display isn't too bad, although my power source jacks in my truck are far enough below my line of sight that I can't read what it says anyway. Doesn't really matter; the action and interface you need to deal with are on your phone, unless you're using a USB stick or a memory card.

This is one of Laumer's classic hero /  adventure tales, told across multiple adjoining universes. Newly relevant in 2015, when evidence for exactly this has been described, it is fascinating to consider what "could be" when multiple universes are involved. True SF in the sense that there are no plot devices that don't have some kind of basis in current science - and not too many SF authors can say that this long after publication!I really enjoyed reading this (again), and for new Laumer readers, I humbly suggest Laumer's "Galactic Odyssey", which I consider to be the very best of the best of this genre, hands down, no exceptions at all. And I've been reading SF since the 60's, so that's really saying something.

Arrival:The packaging was amazing; Apple beats everyone hands down there, which is somewhat silly, but nonetheless, they do it. It was like unwrapping a particularly special Christmas present. :)Installation:I replaced our DSL modem's WiFi with the Apple Airport Extreme. I have to say, it was a very "Apple experience" in just the way they like you to think of it. Turned off the WiFi on the DSL modem, then plugged the AAE into our DSL modem / router. At that point, both my old 10.6.8 and my SO's 10.10.5 OS X across our shared office popped up an airport utility,  no download required, it was "just there."I quit the setup utility on 10.6.8, and we used hers as the odds are hers is more up to date, just as her OS is.The setup utility asked us 3 things; network name, airport name, and password. Once those were provided, it then set itself up as an access point on my network on the proper subnet, etc. Couldn't have been a whole lot easier. In fact, I don't see how it could have been '*any*' easier.The good:Security defaulted to WPA2 which is what you want; WPA and WEP are less robust.The beamforming antenna works well. I setup my phone (a Galaxy Note 3) with a wifi measuring application (WiFi Overview 360 Pro) and measured signal strength at the north end of our property. It was weak, but usable. That was at about 100 feet from the AAE. Then I turned WiFi off on my phone, after which I moved 180 to the front of the house where I was probably about 30 feet from the AAE, and turned WiFi back on while watching the signal strength on the graph; the graph came up, then took another significant step up, then another, then once more - four different levels of signal strength, all increasing by quite a bit. Once the signal was up, it stayed up. The whole process took about 3 to 4 seconds.I am almost certain this was the AAE "aiming itself" at me rather than an increasing partial average in the graphing math, because the graph responds almost instantly to changes in the orientation of the phone and does not incrementally vary after such a change.Beamforming seems to be less effective when multiple devices are in widely separated locations, but I'm not really certain of that yet. It is definitely no worse than the DSL modem was anywhere in the house or the yard; that's a 50'x100' expanse altogether.The iffy:There's a fan in the unit, which surprised me a little. It raises a vague concern about internal dust accumulation and subsequent requirement for service. That's pretty far out in the future, though, and it may be that simply applying a vacuum to the fan ports on the bottom would be sufficient. Can't determine that until it's actually dusty.The 5 GHz signal on my unit is consistently about 10 db weaker than the 2.5 GHz signal, so generally speaking, your dual-band phone or other dual-band device is going to choose the 2.5 GHz band. This hasn't caused me any issues yet, but it is kind of a shame, as the 5 GHz band is a lot less crowded and I'd prefer to be "up there" rather than "down here", if you catch my drift. Of course, if your device is 5 GHz only, then it'll do just the right thing.The bad:I have no no bad to report. I think this is a good product.The wishlist:I wish the 3-port switch offered more ports. If it had, I would have converted my DSL modem to passthrough mode  and let the AAE handle everything; but with 3, it would have left me short on physical Ethernet connections, so I didn't set it up that way. However, I don't think that a larger switch would add much functionality for most people, which is probably exactly why there isn't one. Plus you can always add a switch downstream if you want to go that route (no pun intended. Ok, kidding. Pun intended. :)My situation vs. yours:I have this running as an access point on an already established network, which means it is not functioning as a router for my entire network. So all of my observations should be taken with that in mind - if you are going to set this up as your primary network router, the AAE has to do some other things that I did not get involved with.
